comments: The first signs of the migration in Minnesota were reported on August 8th by Naturalist Jim Gilbert who received news of monarch butterflies aggregating in the Walker area.  Also, another observer reported having about 40 monarchs fly through her yard in a short period of time that day, all heading south.

I observed the first big pulse of fall migration today. I saw monarchs flying at rate of one per minute during a 20 minute count, while I was rowing across a lake in a strong NW wind. Later in the evening, I found tens of monarchs aggregating in maple trees at sunset, along busy county road where I've never seen them before. August 12th was the first sign of fall migration. Of the 4 monarchs I saw that day, all were clearly headed in a southerly direction, under powered flight. Their clear "directional flight" qualified these as the first migrants of the season. Their behavior was identical to that of "migrating monarchs" which normally I don't think of seeing until the second half of August.

Lots of Monarch activity today!  We counted 58 Monarchs traveling through our yard between 3:00 and 4:00 this afternoon, many times in groups of 2 or 3 every 30 seconds or so.  Some came down to the lawn sprinkler for a drink, too!  All seem to be headed southeast. These seemed to be in very fresh condition, a brilliant orange.  Lower humidity today and a great breeze to float along on NW winds at 16 mph 80 degrees.

The day was an exciting one. We had about 75 butterflies spend the night last night.  Our neighbors had 300-400.  They rested in clusters on box elder trees.  We have other trees in the yards, but this was the tree of choice.  The branches were both leafed and bare.  The branches used were lower, 10-15 feet high, and they were on eastern and southern branches.  There was a cold front which moved through the area on 8/16/00 which dropped the daytime highs from @85 to the lower 70

It was totally awesome. It was about 4:30pm on August 20, 2000 and my family and I were looking at  our garden. We happened to notice all of the butterflies hovering around 2 of our trees in the backyard. We then decided to take some pictures of them. We are hoping they will turn out. We have never seen anything like this before. Late yesterday afternoon (08/20/00) I checked on the monarchs and sure enough they were still around. However, there were probably only about 15 to 20 of them.

I have hundreds of monarch butterflies in my backyard. They started appearing on the 16th of August            It's a heavenly sight! They hang from the trees like leaves and fly whenever I walk by them and darken the sky. It is a wonderful sight!! After 2 weeks time (Aug. 30) they are still here, but have grown smaller in numbers. It was great having them here, I think they liked all my flowers!"

We are getting hundreds, yes, hundreds of phone calls from people, telling us about monarchs in their yards. I would say Monday the 28th was the correct date of the first big influx. On the 28th The Outdoor Campus received sighting of hundreds in the Dell Rapids area, and in Rock Valley, IA, Rowena, SD and Sioux Falls, SD of monarchs by the hundreds in trees. On the 29th from South Dakota towns including Sioux Falls, Lyons, Colton, Renner, Beresford, Dell Rapids, Canton, Aberdeen, Brandon, and Lake Vermillion and also from Luverne, MN. On the 30th from South Dakota towns of Tea, Colton, Alcester, Sioux Falls, Beresford, Lennox, Parker, Brandon, Rowena, Humboldt, and Hartfod. Also from Inwood Iowa and Hills, Minnesota
Hundreds of Monarchs have arrived.
Monarchs roosting in trees in the hundreds.  As members of Monarch Watch, my family and I tagged 68 in just over an hour.

August 6th seemed to be the first day an increase in monarchs was noted.  During the ensuing 10-12 days, large numbers of plump, fast-flying, vivid monarchs were observed.  It was not unusual to see 300 monarchs/hr and while driving a 30 mile stretch of highway. There was not a time when there was not a monarch in sight.  The peak seemed to be from the 16th-22nd of Aug, by the 27th, the lack of monarchs was quite noticeable. The monarch migration seems to be long gone from this part of the country.  It is now the 4th of Sept and only an occasional monarch has been spotted.  Temps in the 70's for highs and 50's for lows.  Enjoy the spectacle south of here, it was magnificent.

Students have reported seeing groups of 20-50 butterflies gathered in low hanging bushes and trees. Our temperatures have been very warm,but have cooled over the weekend. We expect to see more butterfly activity this week.

A friend has a large number of Monarchs congregating in her city yard now, about 6 blocks from Lake Michigan.  She usually sees 4 or 5, now is seeing at least 40 on her Joe Pye weed.  Meanwhile, I still have about 12 in chrysalis, and six caterpillars eating.

On 8/28/00, observed monarchs seemingly everywhere, perhaps 40 or 50, as we rode through a mixed tree belt (predominately ponderosa pine, easter red cedar, cottonwoods) that separates our house yard and horse lots from farm land (field of BT corn). Most observations made while riding horseback in early evening, between 6 and 7 p.m. DST. Riding path runs through middle of trees. Will repeat the horseback riding route tonight (9/5/00), to include both the tree belt and liatris patch, and report tomorrow morning. On 8/22/00 saw 4 or 5 monarchs in patch of rough gayfeather (liatris), of which they are particularly fond.

For years monarchs have been coming to stay in my yard for several weeks in August. I first noticed them this year around the17th and they are still here (September 1). I have a large yard, with a southern tree line. I just started researching them this year to find out why they come to my yard, and how they know where it, how long they stay, things like that. The town I live in has 340 people, out in rural Minnesota. We are right on the North Dakota border, 20 miles south of Moorhead.

Last night we saw 500 monarchs, and the number increased today to 600 plus--maybe even one thousand.  The butterflies are roosting maybe 100 to a branch.  Several homes in Shenandoah have called us to let us know that they have monarchs roosting.  On Friday afternoon the children and I walked over to the Vaughn home and saw the monarchs roosting in the trees.  The area is very shaded.

The first of the migrating monarchs have arrived here in York (9/6). We figure they came in that night when a cold front came through.  The wind changed around to the northeast and it was much cooler the following day. There were tons of butterflies here over the weekend (9/9 & 9/10).  They were nectaring on butterfly bushes, alfalfa, rose bushes, and other flowering plants.  They were on trees in Cherry Hill and in our backyards.  Unfortunately, some were on our cars' grills.  It was very hot over the weekend and windy out of the south.  We hope a cold front comes through to cool us off. People from all over town have told stories about the butterflies in their backyards (9/11).
Yesterday I saw a huge aggregation of Monarchs at Folsom Point Prairie in Pottawattamie County Iowa.  Have also been seeing sever per hour flying over the prairie area near our store.
Students and staff at Harding have been reporting seeing groups of Monarchs from 6 on a fence post to 100 on butterfly bushes.We have released 75 tagged butterflies to this date.

We saw a large number of monarchs right after the storm last night.  The front passed here around 7 pm.  With it, the wind changed around from the north and temps cooled by at least 10 degrees.  At that time, monarchs were everywhere among the trees.  There were hundreds of monarchs in our yard at that time.  They must have continued on with the front because they were not roosting in the trees this morning.  We are located in east central Iowa along the Iowa river.

There were clouds of monarchs in the air as the front moved through Waterloo, Iowa on Sept. 11. They were thick in the air above the cars. A teacher at my building said what appeared to be over 100 monarchs roosted in her neighbor's tree last night. We did not get any rain out of this front, but the temperature dropped significantly.  Today there are several feeding in our butterfly garden, more than we've seen all summer. There has been an unbelievable lack of monarchs in our part of Iowa this summer. By now I've usually tagged at least 150 or more; this year I have only tagged 24.  Are others noticing this?

Yes, we are seeing clusters of monarch flying south..Several students report seeing trees/ plants covered at night.....The first butterflies were spotted around August 28 with more being seen each day.  Our town has two special trees at a park that are covered at night--literally covered...Students rarely see one--always more than one this week.We really have enjoyed this project and the data!!!!!

I live in the country, and we have a grove of trees by our house. I went out there, and there were hundreds of butterflies roosting there. The temperatures of our days here are still in the nineties, but I night it cools down quite a bit.

We definitely had a large number of monarchs descend just before the Sept. 11 storm in Mount Vernon, Iowa, and they were still festooning one of my favorite roost trees the next morning. I tagged 70 in about an hour, just picking them off with my fingers and placing them back on the pine needles because they still were dormant. Had to quit tagging and go off to work. There must have been at least 500 monarchs on the lower branches.
There were lots of monarchs gathering in the Gaylord City park. I must have seen 50 to 100 of them, but then it happened--mosquito spray killed thousands of monarchs
I saw 25 in 10 minutes the temperature was 70 degrees an the windspeed was 15 mph coming from the south.
I saw 25 and my mom saw 84. My class saw about 80 to 100  monarchs  over the last two days.This must be the peak migration in Iowa city. The temperature is cool,70's and the days are sunny.

Although I only observed a maximum of 5 monarchs nectaring on zinnias and butterfly bush,their appearance during the days of September 7-17,is within the same time frame I recorded first seeing multiple monarchs return to our corner of northwest Illinois last year. I began looking in early September and saw two on Sept 7th,three on the 8th & 9th, four on the 10th, zero on the 11th & 12th (high winds and rain), five on Sept 13-15, one on the 16th&17th. Two monarchs at the school garden emerged from their chrysalises on Sept.11th & 13th. Will continue to watch to see if the 17th will be the last monarch passing through to Mexico.
Thousands of Monarchs are arriving in our 50 acre wildlife habitat at Heritage Manor Bed and Breakfast, 33 Heritage Road, Aline, Oklahoma 73716 http://www.1aj.org

The main movement appears to have gone through about August 26th, as I have had an additional report of about 20 individuals at Point Lepreau, NB on that date.  Point Lepreau is about 40 miles NE of Grand Manan Island along the Bay of Fundy coast.

The main movement appears to have gone through about August 26th, as I have had an additional report of about 20 individuals at Point Lepreau, NB on that date.  Point Lepreau is about 40 miles NE of Grand Manan Island along the Bay of Fundy coast.

My family and I counted approximatly 50 Monarchs headed south on Saturday, Sept. 16, 2000.  A Muskogee Parks employee reported tome today that Honor Heights Park was FULL of monarchs heading south.  I am heading out there after the last bell today (9-20)and will report back tomorrow.

6752        Monarchs migrating at  rate of 200 per hour today! A cold front came through yesterday at about 4:00 P.M.  Within the next hour about 20 Monarchs per hour were observed heading almost due south (with the wind).  It was cool and rainy this morning but as the sky cleared this afternoon(9/20), the migration rate was about 200 per hour!   Monarchs drifted by at all levels roof top to over 300 feet up. The direction of flight was variable and mostly South but some were flying West.The wind was out of the NNW 5 to 10 miles per hour, temperature was in the 60's.
Yesterday,  20 Septemer 2000, migrant monarchs finally have arrived in Central Virginia.  Both in my home garden and at Sweet Briar College, there is the first evidence of fresh migrants on the move.

I have been making a count for the past 2 hours here in Columbia, and am up to 310 for the period! From about noon to 12:30 over 100 came through in that one half hour alone. They have slowed down a bit now from that though, but 155 per hour seems like a good rate. When I went out for lunch they were flying all over town. Almost all of them are flying to the southwest today. We had our first big migratory push on Sept. 21st. There were fairly large numbers moving in directed flight. In two hours of observation I saw exactly 200 Monarchs. The rate slowed somewhat during the past half hour as the winds have picked up and became more variable. We had a cold front move through the previous two days. It rained for part of the day on the 20th and then cooled off. It was warmer with a north wind on the 21st though, and they began to move through in numbers.
Since last Thursday (9/21), we had a cold front move through over the weekend that brought rain to Columbia. Yesterday, the front moved on through and the temperatures are rebounding this morning. As a consequence, the Monarchs are on the move again. I saw a dozen moving through in less than five minutes this morning (9/26) so it looks like this may be another major day of migration.

On 9/22 we checked a 20 acre corner of a pecan orchard and counted approximately 1,000 Monarchs in about an hour. We saw about12,000 Monarch butterflies total. The butterflies were hanging on the tree limbs on the side away from the wind. Wind was from the S at app. 20mph and gusty. Sky was clear & 98°. A count of my own 1/4 acre revealed a total of 263 Monarchs in 15 minutes. On 9/23, approximately 20,000 Monarch butterflies passed overhead between 5:30 and 6:00PM. A front was moving through, and there were thunderstorms to the NE. Very low counts in my garden.

Each day this week from 12:30 - 1:15p.m., my kindergarten students and I havelooked for monarchs.   At 5:00 p.m (Friday, 9/22/00)  my students and I were called to 2 yards on N. Sam Houston Street, in Odessa. We observed a constant arrival  of butterflies  for the entire 2 hours that we observed.  We saw many more males than females. All together we estimated we saw 300 butterflies roosting in Chinese elm, pecan, and  a 30' by 6' stretch of English ivy. A  small pond, several large bird baths and a good supply of water from the sprinklers placed out to keep the grass and vegetation maintained provided moisture. Sat., Sept. 23rd our wind changed to a northern wind about 5:30 p.m. The monarchs were everywhere.  They even spent the night in our pecan tree at 710 Gill.  It was a beautiful sight.  You could look straight up and just see hundreds.  On Sunday, 24th.  The northern wind took them out of Abilene.

Today we saw one-hundred and one monarchs fly over our house in about 35 minutes. That's a rate of 2.9 per minute, or 173 per hour!
One of them landed in one of our trees for a little while.

Migration rate:
173 monarchs per hour
2.9 monarchs per minute

9/23/00 Saturday, 10:30a.m.:  It appears that the same number(300) of monarchs were gathered in the yards at 1803 N. Sam Houston, Street, in Odessa, TX. As reported yesterday, the butterflies appear to be gathering and resting on the tree limbs and vines.  As we gently walked through the area,  groups of butterflies near us would flutter into short flights and land on other tree limbs a few feet away as if our presence made them nervous.

9/23/00, Saturday, 6:30p.m.:  A strong northerly breeze had picked up, causing noticeable movement in the tree limbs and leaves of these protected yards.  Only about half of thenumber remain in the yards at 1801 & 1803 N. Sam Houston, in Odessa, TX.  It appears to me that as the breeze strengthens, the butterflies are blown in a southerly direction to rest in other areas of the neighborhood.

The monarchs are here! Sunday the 24th we woke up to find 7 tattered monarchs on one milkweed plant. I quess the cold front pushing through Texas has moved the monarchs through our area. As of Monday the 26th we are having gusty winds and morning temperatures of 58 degrees.  I hope to see more today.  Patty Perkins

There were between 50-100 monarchs in our yard on 9/22.  On 9/23-24 there was a storm that came through and the temps have dropped dramatically.  I saw a few single monarchs but not a great abundance (over 100) as yet.

On Thursday, September 21, we spotted 52 monarchs and were able to tag 9.  The day was mostly sunny, 65 degrees.  The location was on a local river (Neosho River) in a wooded area.  We had been seeing several (5-10) for a few days before but on this day there were concentrated numbers of healthy monarchs.

From 8:30 a.m. to 5 pm on the 24th of Sep, we saw 132 monarchs migrating south or southwest.  Some were very high, drifting past at limit of our binoculars. Others were fluttering by at our feet.We also saw Common Buckeyes and Red Admirals migrating.  Two dragonfly species were migrating:  Green Darners (only 3) and Black Saddlebags (22).

While we were outside on our Autumn nature hike at about 1:30 pm we observed a monarch flying south over the pond in the park next to our school.  Many students that live near Lake Erie have reported sighting clusters of monarchs flying south this past week.  In the late afternoon large groups of monarchs can be seen at Mentor Headlands Beach State Park resting in the trees after flying over Lake Erie.

Hundreds of large, healthy Monarchs on their way south were tanking up in yards where the grass had been watered the night before. We discovered bushes and trees covered with butterflies after school around 4:00 p.m.  They stayed the night and then left the next day as the cold front and rain made its way into our drought stricken area. Abilene, 57 miles north of Bronte, reported sightings the same day.  They were beautiful!!!
We saw 150 Monarchs resting on the bark of a tree.  It was truly an amazing sight!  They were obviously preparing for the big journey South.

The fringe of the monarch migration is definitely moving through Early.  I saw approximately 20 on a short 5 minute walk around campus at 11:40 a.m. today.  They were all in beautiful condition.  The sky is clear with a very slight breeze and the temperature is in the low 70's.  My Kindergarten students will be really excited about seeing the monarchs when they go out to recess.

With winds gusts up to 30 mph on the Virginia Coast, Denise Gibbs saw "the largest wave of Monarchs here so far this migration season, with 900 Monarchs per hour migrating (being blown) through.
From my field journal: I stood on the beach dressed in 2 layers of hooded polartec with windblock topped with an Eider-down jacket. My face, (the only exposed skin on my body) felt raw from the sandblasting wind. I watched helplessly as Monarchs rolled and tumbled past me like tiny orange tumbleweeds on the sand. Normally on this island Monarchs favor north or northwest winds for migration, but today the north wind's fury is forcing them down to the ground. If they're lucky enough to land on vegetation--dune grasses or Seaside Goldenrod, they cling to the leeward side, staying 3-5 minutes to rest and warm their flight muscles in the sun. Others, not so lucky are landing on the exposed sand and are trying to get a foothold on the loose, blowing grains of sand. Monarchs that lose their grip are getting blown out to sea.
See daily monarch migration records recorded by the Chincoteague Monarch Monitoring Project on Assateague Island, Virginia.

We were leaving the gym on our lunch hour and heading back to work when we spotted a beautiful monarch butterfly.  My sister and I started looking and they were everywhere - just floating down the road.  We began counting and counted 16 in about 20 to 30 seconds.  They continued to come, but we quit counting.  They were all heading South.  We began talking about the fact that they must be on their way to Mexico for the winter.  It was really cool!
Bowie Elementary 2nd grade spotted a Monarch sitting on a tree branch by the pond.

We were on our school playground this morning.  We think we may have seen five different monarchs. They were fluttering around. We hope they found our butterfly flower garden that we planted last spring. It is now blooming with some different flowers.
Second monarch sighting at Bay head School by Greta.
My students and I witnessed 2 Monarchs crossing above the soccer field this morning. Bright sunny day, with temperature in the mid 60's perhaps.

First large numbers of monarchs moving through.  My two daughters, Caitlyn, age 9 and Kylie, age 5, my wife, and I watched about 50 or so pass by during the late afternoon.  Adjacent to our house there are several large salt cedar trees.  In years past, thousands utilized one particular tree as thier roost.  The arrangement of downward hanging branches must have been appealing to them.  A couple of years back one of the major branches on this tree blew down.  The monarch stopped using the tree as a roost and would not use adjacent trees.  Yesterday about 100 or so were roosting in one of the other large trees.  It will be interesting to see if more monarchs begin to use these other trees as roost sites.
First Monarachs of the year sighted among the sunflowers in pots on my deck in the Adirondacks.It has been a summer without butterflies and many birds.

We counted over 100 butterflies on Monday (9/25/00) when the cold front came through. Before the front we noticed that they seemed to be going directly the opposite way they were supposed to, and were a little worried.  But they're going the right way now. We counted almost 60 the next day. We counted 28 today.  On Monday they were flying really high.  We actually saw one disappear into a cloud!  On Tuesday and Wednesday they were back down near the trees. They are beautiful!!

The Monarchs are here! The numbers seem much smaller this year than last but the ones seen may be scouts. I've only seen two or three fluttering at any given time. The lantana is a Monarch magnet but only small numbers are feeding now.

About 50 Monarchs were sighted today in our school yard at recess.  Last year we planted a Millennium Butterfly Garden in our school courtyard and interestingly, we have not seen Monarch's there in over two weeks.

I went to the ocean beach around 1 PM to do some painting.  I was there until 5:45PM.  The whole afternoon there was a leisurely procession of Monarches fighting a stiff westerly wind.At least it looked leisurely to me.  It was probably very hard work for them.  At any given time there were 15-20 in sight but none were bunched up.  This is first time I have seen them this year but unfortunately my trips to the beach have been limited.  Last year's peak was 9/18/99 when I saw thousands in the dunes and on the beach at any given time for several hours. I guess I missed it this year unless it will be later by more than a week.
I saw  a  monach   in my    backyard.  Three other students reported seeing a monarch, too.

AT P.E. and recess today, we saw quite a few monarchs.  We think it has something to do with the temperature.  We have been in the 70's again.  When it was cooler and rainy a few days ago, we did not see any monarchs.
Sighted a roosting Monarch on a tree limb in schoolyard this morning. Sunny, but cool in the mid 50's.

We have seen most of the Monarchs when we are outside for recess this week.  We have seen about a dozen.  We were on a field trip to Conner Prairie, a living 1836 historical museum, when we sighted the most butterflies.  They seemed to dance along with us in the open fields as we played and walked.
Monarchs are also swirling through San Antonio Texas. One of my students say 25 flying together another saw about 60 or more Deborah Bustamante
Mrs. Penz's 5th Grade from RISD Academy saw a monarch on the branch of a tree near the pond at 11:30am while they were studying erosion.

Our first monarch was sighted today, Sept. 27, 2000 flying in a south westerly direction.  We only saw one.  Monarchs are scarce this year.  Last year during migration the students saw an average of one per hour.  This year just this one lone monarch so far.

Two different children reported seeing two Monarchs on the playground at Crestline today.  There is an overgrown lot near the school that has milkweed.  Every year when I go out on the lot to look for caterpillars,  the city comes and mows the lot.I always wonder what they think I am finding out there.

As we were watering our flowers today my daughter Kendall (2), my niece Leslie (who is visiting from college this weekend)and I observed three or four Monarch butterflies. I am happy to say that they seemed to be enjoying themselves immensely as they fluttered about. We are having very mild weather this week and I am thrilled that we are able to be out of doors.  I am very happy that I made the effort all summer to keep those flowers alive so that the Monarch's can stop by and get nourishment on their journey.  I look forward to seeing them again on their way North.

Yesterday and today, observed more Monarchs coming in.  Counted 24 yesterday, and 26 today.  Have neighbors callings to say they have them in their yards, also.  High today in the high 80's, slight wind from the NE.

Just before I was to enter a house where I was working on this particular day, I saw a Monarch fly over the house and sail southward. After work I was traveling north on a hwy toward home and saw four Monarchs coming at me as if they were following the southern route of the hwy! Very cool and magical!

I'm so busy these days that the only time I'm able to view the out-of-doors is while I'm traveling to and from work. For the last three days I've seen between 3-6 Monarchs heading south as I'm heading home in the aftenoons. Funny...they seems to follow the roads and hwys! Well, at least from where I'm sitting ;)
I took my family shopping today and we spotted 6 Monarchs heading south, while we were driving. They're still coming!

Monarchs finally arrive in Northeast MS.  I counted 9 monarchs from 3 to 5 pm today along the Tenn-Tom Waterway near Peppertown, MS.  Four were nectaring on goldenrod and the others were flying southwest from 5-15 feet above ground.  Temps were in the low 80's with low humidity and east winds at 5-10 mph.  Skies were mostly sunny.  Nectar sources are very limited due to the prolonged severe drought conditions.  Wildflowers are more abundant in the low areas along the Tenn-Tom Waterway.
Started seeing Monarchs today (Sat. 9/30/00)  We caught and tagged 8 monarchs in the backyard. Glad to see them.  I was beginning to wonder if they were coming this way.
one adult nectaring on "butterfly bush" 6:04pm, spent about 5 minutes visiting most of the blooms on the plant
The last 2 days we have seen 4-10 Monarchs on our butterfly bush at any time during the day.  It is windy, from the south, and they are feeding/resting.  Monarchs seem large and healthy.

My students have reported sporatic sightings of one Monarch per day since September 2.  While we were in the school yard last week doing field observations,however, we came across three instances of Monarch migration.  These lone Monarchs were flying above the ground about ten feet up.

I am so excited.  I finally have been fortunate enough to see several monarchs.  I went to school to straighten my class room for tomorrow and decided to check out the butterfly garden.  There on the the butterfly bush were 8 to 10 monarchs.  I took pictures with my class digital camera then came back about an hour later and there were even more.  They were so beautiful!  It is an experience I'll never forget.  I only hope it happens again.
I noticed the monarch as I was wandering through the local flea market.  It was a beautiful day here in Oxford and the butterfly was just a beautiful!

On 9/22 we checked a 20 acre corner of a pecan orchard and counted approximately 1,000 Monarchs in about an hour. We saw about12,000 Monarch butterflies total. The butterflies were hanging on the tree limbs on the side away from the wind. Wind was from the S at app. 20mph and gusty. Sky was clear & 98°. A count of my own 1/4 acre revealed a total of 263 Monarchs in 15 minutes. On 9/23, approximately 20,000 Monarch butterflies passed overhead between 5:30 and 6:00PM. A front was moving through, and there were thunderstorms to the NE. Very low counts in my garden.10/01 the monarchs are coming through again from the NE.  Counted 50 yesterday in my gardens, and so did my neighbors in theirs.  The Merritts' reported 3,000 at the pecan orchard south of town.  Today counted about 80, and they are still coming in. The high yesterday and today in the high 90's, clear, wind this evening from the south at app 10-12mph.
Single Monarch seen flying south across highway in front of my car. Sunny and warm, 70 degrees.
Single Monarch roosting on flower in my garden. About 70 degrees at 2:30 PM.
I saw the monarch in the front of my house.

2900 Yesterday's reports coming from members of our group seem to indicate that we might be having our peak. Many were spotted flying through the Woodbridge area, one about every 5 minutes all day yesterday. Netted & tagged about 30 in 1 1/2 hours. Sunny, temps in mid 70's, slight wind from the southeast.  Jim Kupcho
Six monarchs and one viceroy eating hungrily at the butterfly bushes and dahlias...most monarchs sighted this Fall thus far.

On September 27,1999 we had 1,952 monarchs fly through Lenoir in 70 hours, or, 27.8 monarchs an hour.On September 27,2000 we had 35 monarchs in 70 hours,or, 1 every 2 hours.We are hoping that the  numbers will increase as we get into October.We have had many sprayings for the West Nile Virus in our area  and the surrounding counties and states this summer , but we do not have any idea whether or not this has had an effect on the numbers so far.Beverly Smith, Hudson River Aududon Society
school: Hudson river audubon society of westchester county

comments: 2 Monarchs  sighted by trail maintenance crew at 9:30 am  both near water
At 6:15pm my husband and I saw a monarch feasting on our butterfly bush.

We counted at least 10 monarchs on the playground and in the butterfly garden today.  Many of the children reported seeing several monarchs over the weekend.  My husband spotted at least 10 on his way home from work today. They have definitely arrived!

We have had the most fantastic sightings 9/29 thru today, 10/02/00. On Fri the 29 there were 200+ monarchs in our backyard (south Ft. Smith)-some feeding on the flowers in our "butterfly garden" some feeding on crepe myrtles and most just resting in the 47 large oak & hickory trees that are in mine & my neighbors' yards. On Sat, 9/30, it was wild! There were 800-1000 monarchs everywhere-fluttering in the light breezes, feeding, resting in the trees. On Sunday there were 200-300 and today there were approximately 150-200. When they leave they head west/southwest. Temperatures have been in the upper 80's each day. They are fancinating to watch, and we tried a crude experiment to see what colors there were attracted to or repulsed by. White & red shirts were not what they like but they did get close to my daughters wearing light pink and aqua blue. I also went kayaking on the Ark River (east Ft. Smith) Sunday (10/1) afternoon to check out the camphor weed- it has already peaked and I only
A beautiful Monarch was seen on a Butterfly Bush in the Home Depot garden department.
My 8th grade class saw 8 Monarchs during a 30 minute observation period.  It was about 2:00p.m. and they were flying about tree-top high.
Sited at a gas station while I was pumping gas.

Estimados amigos de Journey South,
El sabado 30 de septiembre a las 11 de la manana me reportaron 50 mariposas por minuto en la carretera No. 57 a la altura de La Muralla, al sur de la ciudad de Monclova.
Saludos desde Coahuila,
Rocio Trevino

Estimados amigos de Journey South,
Las mariposas estan pasando por Saltillo y sus alrededores, aunque son pocasaun (3mariposas cada 5minutos). El sabado 30 de septiembre a las 11 de la manana me reportaron 50 mariposas por minuto en la carretera No. 57 a la altura de La Muralla, al sur de la ciudad de Monclova.
Saludos desde Coahuila,
Rocio Trevino
Over the last 24 hours, our third graders spotted 64 Monarchs around their homes and soccer fields. This weekend I was on the Alabama Gulf coast near Mobile. I counted 25 Monarchs in one hour.

We saw four monarchs come together on a purple butterfly bush at the end of the day around 5:00 PM.  One arrived all alone and then the other three appeared.The students were very excited to see this gathering.
Our whole class saw two monarchs on the patio near our butterfly bush outside of our classroom today.  We saw one in the morning and one in the afternoon.

The numbers are increasing in the southward migration.  I can't really give exact numbers because this year they  are circling my yard and staying in the yard for hours.  I saw maybe 25 or so.  I went to the Garden Nursery and there were Monarchs all over the flowers there.  The nurseryman and said they had been there for about 3 days and at his home in Bixby right nearby.Also I have noticed that some of the Monarchs have damaged wings.  I also found a dead Monarch in my yard with just the wings and no body left.  I thought they were poisonous to birds.  I feed birds in my yard also.  Today the Monarchs stayed in  my yard until evening.  Usually in the past the main activity has been around 2:00 pm.  This year they are staying longer.  It is still very warm here - in the 90's.  Our weather is about to change dramatically by Friday (morning expected 34 degrees).

Today the numbers of Monarchs have slowed down somewhat.  I only saw about 10-12 or so.  The Monarchs were still actively flying south late in the afternoon.  2 on the Monarchs had found places on the Morning Glory leaves and were resting in the shade.  I don't know if they were preparing to rest the nightime.  The weather here is still very hot in the 90's.

WE HAVE MONARCHS!!!!We sighted MONARCHS laying eggs on our milkweed plants.  Their wings were a bit tattered, but they appeared strong. We have had other male milkweed butterflies on our eupatorium greggi for about a month.

Several students have seen groups of monarchs on weeds near their church this past week.  We have seen some near school.  Our school is under construction, so there aren't many plants for them right now.  We're going to plant a garden by our school.
We are still observing about 1 every 5 minutes this afternoon. Still getting to net and tag some of them.                 Jim Kupcho  (MONARCHS NJ)
Each of the past three days, we have seen monarchs passing over our playground at about 1:30 pm.  They have been solitary and travelling in a NE to SW direction.
Two monarchs in farm field on wild asters. Sunny day, unseasonably warm, in low 80's as was yesterday when I saw one monarch in my garden on gaillardia flower.

For the past two days 10-3-00 and 10-4-00, 300 to 400 monarchs have been roosting in the drainage ditch 1/2 block from my school. Our temps have been in the 80s and 90s during the sightings and the wind is from the south at 17 mph.  Since the drainage ditch offers shelter from the wind, I assume this is just a stop over until the direction of the wind changes to a north wind.  The monarchs are roosting on low branches hanging near the bottom and on the concrete wall near the opening under the street.  I have had monarchs nectaring in our wildscape on the native lantana everyday from 8:00am to 5:00pm this week. Last year we had very few monarchs during the fall migration. It has been a glorious sight! Hope my digital pictures come out!!!!

Last week we released four beautiful monarchs grown in our classroom on milkweed leaves from our garden and watched them leave "for Mexico", my first graders thought. Today, we were on our way to recess and there were three back in the garden enjoying the Mexican sunflowers! Could these be the same ones or others on their way to Mexico? We're not sure!

The Monarchs are still heading south through here.  They have been flying through my yard since early this morning. Just one, two, or three at a time.  This afternoon 2 just stayed a couple of hours or so in the yard going from flower to flower.  It is still in the 90's here, with a cold front coming tomorrow night or Friday morning.  There is still a freeze warning for the weekend- we will see if it makes it - usually our first freeze is the end of October! There has been a strong wind from the south yesterday and today.It is just so beautiful to watch them knowing they are on their way to Mexico.

Only a few monarchs are in the inner city at my garden but have collected about a dozen eggs which all have lived and some are still in the larva stage and others have emerged and I have tagged 4 of those (3 were females). I have them in a rearing cage outside in the shade. The weather is hot, 90° during the day and very humid. There is not much activity in the way of any butterflies.

We have seen a few Monarch Butterflies fluttering around in the area Saturday through Wednesday, October 1-4.  Very few, maybe less than 25 in our yards.  It is so dry. We are not allowed to water except with a hand held hose.  We are hoping we will have another big wave of Monarchs before long.  They are beautiful!We have a cold front coming in Wednesday night or Thursday sometime.  I guess it will push the butterflies on down south.

Last Friday (9/29/00) in northeast Oklahoma we saw around 60 monarchs. Tuesday (10/3/00) in southwest Missouri we saw around 10 or 12.  Today (10/4/00) we only saw 1 or 2 flying very slowly and low to the ground.
4 monarchs sighted near the creek in the morning by Northrich Elementary 5th grade students studying geology.
5th grade students from Mrs. Parada's class sighted a Monarch over the dry culvert while they were studying erosion.  A cold front is anticipated on October 6.
two monarch's nectaring, spent about 3-5 minutes visiting every bloom on our butterfly bush.  One had a "scar" on upper wing. 3-4mm long dull brown "scar" tissue on wing.

We are still seeing the Monarchs in their southward migration.This morning I saw about 10 Monarchs go through my yard in about 10 minutes of time.  There are still Monarchs feeding in my yard. I seen Monarch wings from dead Monarchs near the flowers where they were feeding. I'd never seen that before.  I just found a preying mantis (sp?) hanging off a Zinnia flower with a Monarch butterfly in its mouth and it has eaten most of the body.  I did not know they ate butterflies.  I have always encouraged their presence.  If anyone reads this and knows - Is this normal??  We are in a region where there has been one of the worst droughts ever. Our wind this morning was coming from the south and was still warm and now at 1:25 pm the wind is switching and is supposed to be cold by tonight.  I have seen more Monarchs flying higher than I've seen this week.

Four children from different areas of town reported seeing a Monarch yesterday evening after school so the few that come through this area must be passing through.  Since we hatch Monarchs in our classroom,  I feel that these were reliable reports.
Second graders from RISD Academy were studying life cycles and saw 6 monarach butterflies in the creek bed.
Second grade from RISD Academy found 5 Monarch butterflies, 4 near the creek and one near the pond while they were studying plant and animal parts.

I have to tell everyone about the monarch sighting today at the same drainage ditch 1/2 block from my school.  At least 400-500 monarchs lined the graffiti marked walls of the underground area of the ditch.  It was remarkable how nature was able to disguise the scourge of many neighborhoods, if only for a short while.  I also learned a bit of history about this site.  The monarchs have been coming to this spot since 1965, after the ditch was put in.Roosting monarchs: 400-500  Time: 2:45pm  Temp: 91 Wind: Southwest 16mph.  I'm hooked!!!   Janet
Monarchs began showing up in increasing numbers two days ago.  They're on the flowers, at the beach, most everywhere,

Peabody Children have become very aware of monarch butterflies in our neighborhood, Capitol Hill in Washington, D. C.. Capria from Mr. Watson's class saw two on a sunny warm day 9/14/00 at 8th and C Streets, NE, and two more at Third and G Streets, NE on 9/17.   Shawnta saw three on 9/24/00, another warm and sunny day, on our school playground.  She said, "They have very pretty colors."  Tyquia saw six at the neighboring Stuart Hobson Middle School on 9/27, another warm and sunny day. (We've had great weather).  Tyquia said, "The beautiful monarchs were flying".   While on the playground on 10/4 the whole class saw two more and while at the Stanton Park, across from the school, on October 3, they saw six more. That day was cool, windy and 70 degrees or so.  The butterflies were resting and flying and were counted within just a few minutes of each other.  Mr.  Burst's class is also watching for butterflies on their way to Mexico.  Grace reported for the class that they saw one.
My lantana flower beds are covered with hundreds of monarchs.  They have been here for about 9 days now, and the weather is getting colder. I'm concerned they may not leave before freezing.

The students of Donoho School's third grade have spotted a few Monarch butterflies, but not as many as in previous years.  Taylor D. saw two this past week, Blake saw one at the soccer field, Trey saw one on a flower drinking nectar, Ben saw three at church, Taylor K. saw three at the lake, Charlie saw about 8 together at the mall, Erin saw one at school, Ellen saw 4 on flowers at her house, Rachel saw one at her Dad's office, Jake saw two flying around, Will saw one on the playground.  These sightings were over a week and a half time period.  The weather has been very hot and dry here.  Flowers have dried up and there is not as much water available.  We wonder if that is why we haven't seen as many Monarchs.  A cold front is moving in this weekend. Our class wonders if we will see any more Monarchs after it turns colder.

October 3,2000 I was at the butterfly garden counting and the monarchs seem to be picking up here. I counted  10 monarchs in 2 hours, and yesterday, October 4,2000 I counted 15 monarchs in 2 hours which is the most we have seen so far. Others who were at the garden later (but not counting) said that they saw  many more monarchs than usual during the time they were there.
school: Hudson river audubon society of westchester county

comments: One monarach sighted about 11 am over the pond.  Cold front arrived about 3am.

For the past 3 weeks, I have seen only 1-3 monarchs (maybe) when I was outside. This afternoon the sky is full of monarchs. I counted in the range of 25-50 monarchs flying over just 1 building in a 5 minute time span. We just had the 2nd cold front of the season come through last night, and I assume the monarchs are using the north wind to make part of the final push to Mexico. It is late afternoon and temps are in the upper 50's with winds in the 10-15 mph range from the north. The monarchs are heading in a southeast direction. I'm guessing the big migration is now reaching us.

Monarchs rising from the fields as the cold front began to come through.  They were joining hundreds of monarchs at about 200 feet altitude.  Following this observation came the cold front, and a strong north wind blowing everything due south.Near Fayetteville, AR.

The wind started blowing from the north at a good clip early this morning, but the subtropical jetstream won out over the northern branch.  The cold air got hung up on that barbed wire along I-10 and never made it.  We had a shower of rain just before noon but never had to shut off the sprinklers or soaker hoses.  The high was after midnight, 78 dF, and the low is current, 55 dF.  Some places esp. along I-10 had over  half an inch to an inch and a half, but not many such places.  Half an inch will go farther now than two inches did a month ago.  We had figured the weekend would be a "monarch wash out" but will have to keep our eyes open tomorrow.  There had been a report of many (1000's) of monarchs passing overhead near Garland in Dallas County on Oct 6.

Monarchs rising from the fields as the cold front began to come through.  They were joining hundreds of monarchs at about 200 feet altitude.  Following this observation came the cold front and a strong north wind blowing everything due south.   Location - NW Arkansas - Feyetteville

After four days of daytime temps in the 40's, and night time temps in the 30's, I was suprised to count almost 30 Monarch butterflies in my gardens today when the temp got up to 57°.  They were all nectaring on flowers of various kinds.  This is so unusual for us, both weatherwise and Monarch wise.

In the last 24 hours our third graders have seen 97 Monarch butterflies!  They are refueling here, flying and also landing on our flowers which are in bloom! Current temperature is a nice 19º C with a low of 4ºC last night.  The wind is out of the north at 5 mph.

Monarchs meandered their way through Austin, Texas, all day yesterday, 10/10/00, and most of this morning.  Some travel alone, some in pairs, some in groups... they all look as though they could be on their way to a dinner party.  I imagine the hum of casual conversation as they stroll along.  Skies are overcast, and we're having temps in the 50s and 60s with a mild NE wind.  The Monarchs are a magical addition to the scenery!  Thanks for letting me share.

(Also see report for 10/29/00.)Today, 10/11/00 we drove thru thousands of monarchs between Gulf Shores Alabama, and Perdido Key, Florida, which is about a twenty mile ride. The road is approximately 1/8 of a mile from the Gulf of Mexico and runs parallel the entire distance. The bad news is, we hit and killed at least 5 along the way. There were hundreds of other cars that did the same. The good news is, the dunes are full of milkweed and they are laying eggs with great gusto. The strong winds last week, from the north, delivered them to the Gulf Coast. They must have arrived at night because we didn't see a single monarch during the day and we live about 2 miles inland from the Gulf.

Saw the first monarchs this afternoon that we would call true migrants.  Three in ten minutes at the peninsula at the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway.  Has been cold, wet ... these were facing into a northeast wind but the actual movement was closer to northwest to southeast.  Central Texas has millions of migrating monarchs trying to pass thru the small of the funnel between the Texas coast (and probably some that have taken off across the Gulf) and Big Bend of west Texas ... and the weather has been terrible for them.  Late hummingbirds have stacked up along the coast and some were reported in torpor from the cold.

At approximately 2 pm to 4 pm on Wed., Oct. 11, we saw over 50 monarchs from our backyard in central Georgetown, Texas. They flew either singly or in pairs or a few triplets in the same pattern down the north-south street adjacent our house, heading south and then a little west. Amazing to us that they all flew in the same exact direction, and how beautiful and large they were. A few stopped to sip on the crepe myrtle blossoms in our backyard.
Last week was probably the peak around here, although there are still quite a few around now.

It seems the monarchs have finally reached us.  Although this years peak does not compare to last year's - we were able to count 50 monarchs feeding in a field of goldenrod and asters.  They seem to be almost a week later in getting to our area than they were last year.  Most of the ones we saw were very fat and looked very bright and healthy.

The monarchs are moving through the Austin area today.  The sun has come out after a week of cold and rain and they are passing by in the thousands. They are everywhere! I counted 75 in about an hour's time and had reports from friends in other parts of the city with about the same numbers.

As it turned out, the monarchs themselves hinted at their intentions by appearing in abundance on dirt roads and in fields. I suspected that the move was on, and time soon showed that to be the case. The last of these endearing insects appeared to have moved through around September 18-19. I did not observe them beyond these dates, which were followed by rain and cooler weather.

The last monarchs that I observed were in excellent condition and appeared to be very active. I can't say that I specifically saw any of them feeding, although the main flora still in bloom was the aster (the New York aster, specifically, was the dominant species).

My family has land on the Colorado River in the Ballinger area and we saw thousands of them along a creek that feeds into the river twoweekends ago ( Sept.30 and Oct.1)  They have been coming and stopping off there for the last 15 years, that I know of.
Monarchs are nesting in our desert willow trees, have been here for three days now-there are hundreds of them and they are a sight to behold!

The annual Monarch southern migration through the Pensacola FL area is here.  We sighted about 100 Monarchs over Pensacola Bay from the Garcon Point bridge. October is also the month in which Monarchs are seen in large numbers at Pensacola Beach on Santa Rosa Island, and this year is no exception. In our backyard butterfly garden in Gulf Breeze, Monarch caterpillars continue to eat our milkweed, pupate, and hatch - we've had about 10 hatchlings in the past 2 weeks - but this year has seen fewer than previous years. We speculate this may be due to the drought.

Monarch Butterflies are a rare sight here in the suburbs except for at this time of year - I have seen 50 - 100 monarchs in my own backyard within the last week among other local species feeding off the flowers.  I have many different varities of plants, however the Monarch is feeding more on the PorterWeed and Ixora.  They are used to me and allow me to be close-up to them within touching distance.

This surely is the Peak Migration for Northeast Texas.  I counted 50 Butterflies all nectaring on (Verbesina virginica) or Frostweed.  We are expecting rain and cooler tempertatures so I guess they will travel south.  This has been the strangest migration that I have noted.  They come, disappear and then come back again.  I am sure our strange weather has a lot to do with this.

We were driving from Longhorn Caverns on Park Road 4 to Hwy 29, through Burnet, and back to Liberty Hill. All along the way, monarchs were flying across the roads.  Most were very large butterflies in groups of 3 - 5. There were some loners and several groups of a dozen or so. We saw 40 to 50 groups, so around 150 - 200 monarchs in all. It was hard to see any details or really enjoy their beauty as we were driving along at 65 mph. It was amazing though and made us think about God's creativity and His ultimate plan for all life!

Kindergarten teachers and students have been sighting monarchs over the past several days.  One teacher reported spotting 8 - 10 in our butterfly garden. One of my students told the class that she saw lots and lots of monarchs in her grandmother's garden on Saturday.The weather has been breezy and moderatelycool - in the low to mid 70's.
Student reports of 30 monarchs in his yard.

As of last Friday (10/13/00), hundreds of monarchs have made a temporary home in our blooming Anaqua tree which stands in our front yard. They (along with the humming birds and various bees) appear to be ingesting the nectar produced by the abundant and fragrant flowers of this tree. As of today (10/17/00), there only seems to be about 1/4 of the original population of monarchs remaining.
In the last 24 hours our third graders have seen 127 Monarch Butterflies in their yards.  They are feeding on the nectar of the flowers and flying south.

We saw several Monarchs in our yard, so we went outside to investigate.  There were so many in our trees, that we couldnot even count them all.  They were resting on branches in about 5 big oak trees. My son drove his car past them and scared them.They were flying all around and there must have been hundreds.It was an awesome sight.

Thousands of monarch butterflies the past two days flying in from the north and heading south. Flying above ground level up to 10 feet in the air.We have never seen the monarch migration, it is breath-taking.
I saw 10 monarch butterflys at lunch at the MOSI museum in tampa florida

Hundreds of monarchs cruising over Texas Military Institute campus, Northern Bexas County, Texas.  Some so high they were tiny dots...some landing to nectar in the butterfly garden...and hundreds in between.   Students netted 50-60 for vital statistics studies.  We are keeping them in a large outdoor cage over flowers in the butterfly garden and some inside in smaller cages until we finish our data collecting.  Then we will conduct directional studies as we release them.

The first flurry of migrating monarchs appeared along the Texas mid-coast at the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway today.  We got there at five and very quickly had netted, measured, tagged, and released three that were nectaring on goldenrod.  In about 40 minutes of observing, we sighted 16 monarchs on goldenrods.  We did not look up or farther out over the water as the ones within fifty feet of the shell road on the peninsula held our attention.  Three males (53, 54, and 53 mm front wings), two females (54 mm and 53 mm), some fading (2 to 2.5), with very "plump bellies" and yellow "feet" from the goldenrod pollen.  Saw three more between Victoria and Port Lavaca.

29 people saw 128 Monarchs. They were seen on afternoon break at the middle school, at homes, on butterfly bushes, at a sister's birthday party, flying through the woods, at a scout camp, at a post office, at a butterfly garden, at cheerleading practice, at several Habersham County schools, in people's yards, at playgrounds, on a field trip and Ms. Wight saw one while riding her horse in the mountains behind her house.  Hurry to Mexico before it gets cold!

We witnessed approximately 500 to 1000 monarchs passing over our property yesterday and today, following a cool front.  At dusk last night, the monarchs settled into a Cedar Elm on the dry creek to roost for the night.  This morning around 9am the monarchs in the area took flight, and could be seen everywhere, headed south-southwest.

While eating a picnic lunch at Our Lady of Lourdes Grotto on Oblate Road, San Antonio, TX, we noticed a huge Live Oak tree, central to the grove, was full of resting monarchs.  What a beautiful sight!  We estimated 1000 were in that tree, with only a few other trees containing a scant population in comparison.  There was a light breeze which periodically caused those resting in the branches to temporarily take flight before resuming their well-camoflauged position among the oak's branches.  They clearly preferred this massive centrally-positioned tree to all the others, as well as shunning many bright garden beds with plumbago, lantana, and salvia in full bloom.  A large percentage of these butterflies appeared to be faded in coloration, but about two-thirds were quite vibrant.  As thunderclouds rolled in late that afternoon, and today was filled with numerous showers, we wonder if we'll see them if we visit the Grotto tomorrow. ~~ Bright Star Academy (MJEA)

Greetings.- We have read in local newspaper on monarch sightings in the areas south-west of town by the mountains (I live in east side aprox. 20 miles away), reports that on Sunday 15th around noontime were seen aprox 4 to 5  per minute.Local observers reported above and comment that the main body is expected around the third week of October onwards.Saludos,EB Durell

My first sighting of the journey south, today at 6:30 PM as I was leaving my office I spotted few Monarchs circling around a couple of Cottonwoods (Alamos) like inspecting for perching or for flowers. After a few turns took off flying southwest.  Weather conditions we have and advancing front from Texas, we had rains in the early morning and have overcast skies, forecast for rains on next couple of days. Slow to moderate winds from  NE, RH of  70 %. Area of sighting is  NE of Monterrey, by the airport area.Best Regards,EB Durell

Governor and Mrs. Ventura visited the ancient Aztec pyramids of Teotihuacan on Sunday, October 22nd and at an Ambassador's reception on Monday night told the guests, "When we climbed to the top of the pyramids we saw a monarch butterfly."  The Venturas then gave a gift to the U.S. Ambassador--a James Brandenburg photo of "a monarch on a Minnesota prairie before starting its migration to Mexico," Mrs. Ventura explained.

¡Las primeras mariposas han llegado!
The exciting news we've all been waiting for just arrived from Angangueo, Michoacan: The students in the schools surrounding the sanctuaries are beginning to see the first monarchs!

"Los ninos gritan 'ahi van mariposas!' y los demos las cuentan," wrote teacher Senor Gilberto Salazar of Escuela Pedro Ascencio. Just a mile up the road sits Escuela Benito Juarez. The school is nestled on the mountain just beneath the Sierra Chincua sanctuary. "El miercoles estaban jugando futbol y vieron una mariposa!" they reported. The town of Angangueo is in the valley below, and Escuela Issac Arriaga is located beside the town square. According to students there, the first monarchs appeared in town last week, apparently looking for a needed drink of water after their long journey: "Muchas mariposas pasan por donde ahi arroyos y rios," they observed.

Desde el dia 15 de octubre se estan reportando por la carretera 57 ya en el estado de Nuevo Leon, San Luis Potosi y Guanajuato.  Los lugares que me reportan son ejidos y no aparecen en el mapa, pero creo que pueden mencionar a Matehuala y a la ciudad de San Luis Potosi, ya estan por alla estoy segura.

Desde el dia 15 de octubre se estan reportando por la carretera 57 ya en el estado de Nuevo Leon, San Luis Potosi y Guanajuato.  Los lugares que me reportan son ejidos y no aparecen en el mapa, pero creo que pueden mencionar a Matehuala y a la ciudad de San Luis Potosi, ya estan por alla estoy segura.

Desde el dia 15 de octubre se estan reportando por la carretera 57 ya en el estado de Nuevo Leon, San Luis Potosi y Guanajuato.  Los lugares que me reportan son ejidos y no aparecen en el mapa, pero creo que pueden mencionar a Matehuala y a la ciudad de San Luis Potosi, ya estan por alla estoy segura. Rocio Trevino, Correo Real

Fowarded by Don Davis, Toronto, ON.
El di'a de ayer fue calido y de poco viento y lasmonarcas seguian llegando, en Piedras Negras y enEagle Pass Texas las veiamos pasar una por minuto; seque el clima mejora por que ellas estan pasando,cuando estaba lloviendo tambie'n supe que despue's decinco di'as de lluvia continuava por fin mejorariacuando emezaron a irse. Aqui murieron muchas a causadel clima.

On a trip to West Texas I kept track of Monarchs as we traveled over 600 miles from Houston to Ft Davis, Texas during peak migration on 10/22/2000. Traveling west on Interstate 10 from 10 am to 2 pm I counted monarchs crossing the highway. There were hundreds between the towns of Kerrville and Sonora on a vector of southeast. The largest group was seen just west of Kerrville, where I saw 6 in a flying pattern close together. Between Sonora and the Pecos River I saw 38 monarchs in about 75 miles.
There were 20 monarchs nectaring on Mexican Sunflowers 1 mile east of the Caverns of Sonora at the Sonora Rest Stop, which is beautifully planted in butterfly attracting flowers. All appeared in excellent condition and about equally male and female. The butterflies would let me touch them, they seemed most intent on tanking up on nectar. I did not expect to see many west of the Pecos River, but I saw 6 of them, between 2 to 2:30 pm. The last one at mile marker 261. What a hardy creature, as there seems to be nothing for them to consume in the West Texas desert, but there they were!

On a trip to West Texas I kept track of Monarchs as we traveled over 600 miles from Houston to Ft Davis, Texas during peak migration on 10/22/2000. I reported the data east of here on a previous report.  Here I report where the numbers ofmigration monarchs appeared to drop off in number.The number of monarch sightings dropped drastically after we crossed the Pecos River at Sheffield.  We sighted only six monarchs west of the Pecos River.  Two were seen within a mile of the river.  Then between 2 to 2:30 we saw 4 more flying south crossing Interstate 10 at mile markers 294, 276, 275, and 261.This was the last sighting.  Despite careful watch no more were seen west of mile marker 261.

Today was warm with a slight wind and I saw one last Monarch feeding on Frostweed.  It was pretty tattered and did not seem to be in a hurry.  Last week they were clustered all over and then they left without laying.  None of the local milkweed had eggs and all they seemed to be interested in was feeding.I think the end is near.
We have seen a good many over the past several days.

Sunday morning, (9:00) thousands of Monarchs were traveling east along the primary dune line of Perdido Key, in the Gulf Islands National Seashore. They were traveling with Gulf Fritillary Butterflies which outnumbered the Monarchs 10 to 1. They were all traveling at a pace faster than you could walk and were all going in the same direction (east). The majority of them were following a narrow line along the south side of the dune. There were so many of them, that if one did try to turn  and go back, it would get run over. Neither species stopped to nectar or lay eggs. We were there about 2 hours, and they never stopped going by. The wind was gentle from the north and the gulf was flat. Both species looked in good health with bright colors and untattered wings. They looked liked newborns. We wondered where they were going in such a hurry, and why to the east?

El sabado 28 por la manana, fui a marcar mariposas a la finca El Ahuacatal que se localiza casi a la entrada del Canon de la Huasteca en Santa Catarina, Nuevo Leon, estuvimos algunos miembros del club de observadores de mariposas Papalotl deleitandonos con el magnifico espectaculo que ofrecieron miles de mariposas Monarca, perchadas en diferentes tipos de arboles, formando racimos tan densos que unicamente me habia tocado ver en los santuarios. La manana completamente nublada con una temperatura de 20 C.

We have a butterfly garden outside our classroom.  My life science students netted and tagged 34 monarchs from 10:00 am until 1:00 pm.  In years past the monarchs were observed flying due west over the building, with the garden we are observing them coming back over the building for nectar from the butterfly bushes.

The Monarchs are coming in masses today.  There are 5 and 6 on every butterfly bush.  We captured and tagged 54 monarchs today.  Mandy Ryan a student reported sighting hundreds of Monarchs near the Chattahoochee National Forest which is located 5 miles north of our school, North Habersham Middle School at 5 pm.

The monarch migration along the central Texas coast seems to have peaked about November 20:  http://nov2k.homestead.com/nov20.htmlThe two previous years the highest numbers were the last two weeks of October thru the first week of November.  This year the migration was later by two to three weeks ... possibly because of the drought.  The 7th graders reported about eighteen monarchs moving from off Matagorada Bay to the southwest in Calhoun County last Friday.  On November 25, there were still three varieties of wild, native milkweed blooming in the county.  We will be looking for the first northbound, returning monarchs by mid February ... not overwintering monarchs, but very faded and tattered monarchs.

We just witnessed hundreds of monarchs on our street.  We live in the west end of the inner city of Winnipeg and found it absolutely beautiful.  Our streets are lined with canopies of elm trees where the monarchs have been visiting since yesterday.  It was quite remarkable to witness this beautiful creatures.  My three boys and myself are quite interested in learning more about them.

On Thursday August 9th, the morning after a strong cold front went through, we had thousands of monarchs in our yard. I could not even make a guess at how many but for sure thousands. Our large oak trees looked orange. Most of them left Thursday afternoon (8/9), and by Friday morning (8/10) we only had a few hundred left. Today we still have a few hundred here even this cool morning (8/13); it's 43 (F) here. The monarchs started to arrive here on August 1st with about 40-50 that day. The numbers grew into the thousands by the 9th. I spent many hours watching them during those days, it has been unbelievable. Watching them quiver awake on the cooler mornings, and come in and out of the yard to and from the clover. If anyone has any questions let me know and I'll try to answer them.

Hundreds and hundreds of monarchs are filling our trees this evening! The butterflies definitely were not here in these numbers until this evening. Thursday night about 6 p.m. we found large aggregations of monarchs totaling approximately 1000 butterflies. They were clustered in groups ranging from ten to several hundred in a cluster. During the week we had observed an increased number of single monarchs flying south through the area. Temperatures had dropped from the 80's-90's to the 70's, with lows in the mid-50's at night.
