August 16 (con't.)
They were clustered on the S/SE branches of 11 maple, oak, elm & birch trees in our yard. The branches of choice were 10-20 ft from the ground-both with leaves and bare. The butterflies were still on the trees at 8 a.m. the next morning. We are surrounded with alfafa (recently mowed), clover (in full bloom) and corn fields. This is a very quiet rural area with good milkweed growth. The butterflies have also been attracted to open sugar-water feeders in the yard for the finches, orioles and hummingbirds. We found no monarchs in the butterly house.

I've been seeing LOTS of monarchs in the past couple of weeks, but nothing like I saw on August 14.  I was walking on the St. Olaf College campus on a cool, cloudy afternoon when I came upon a stand of large shade trees (I believe they were maples).  Several of the branches appeared to be covered with dead leaves, but suddenly when a flying monarch came close, the "dead leaves" opened up to become brilliant monarchs!  It was like watching the speeded-up film of flowers opening, and with the sudden burst of color they would start fluttering about en masse. It was unspeakably beautiful, and the first time I've ever seen such a sight.Some of them took off to flutter about the trees, but maybe because of the cool temperatures and lack of sun, they seemed to all lite back on the branches fairly quickly.  There were definitely hundreds, and possibly thousands, in that little grove.

On the 18th of August, 2001, thousands of Monarchs gathered in the evening in our 4 acres of woods.  This is surrounded by fields although there are other wooded areas nearby.  It is on top of a hill.  Every year we have seen these over the past 9 years we have lived here.  It seems that they might be earlier than usual, however I haven't kept track of the date.  This year seems even thicker than normal.

The butterflies which came after the rain did stay for the night.  We have @ 500 butterflies roosting. The neighbors have more. As I stated in the earlier sighting today, the rain came in from the north east instead of the usual north west.  At 8:30PM, the butterflies had moved mostly to one tree, and are in very large clusters on the branches.  They are from 10 - 30 feet off the ground, on the south side of our tree. It is a box elder.  They are on leaves mostly, but two groups are on bare branches.

We were traveling through the State Park in St. Ignace on Aug. 17,01 in the evening and saw hundreds of Manarchs fluttering around the trees, landing and gathering in the branches for the night.  We went back the next morning to see if they were still there and they were. They just seemed to be gathering there, We never saw them flying anywhere, just amongst the trees. I took some pictures and videos of them. It was a beautiful sight. I had read an article in our paper just before we left about them so I was thrilled to actually see some.

We have lived in our house for 19 years. Every year we have a large number of monarchs that seem to gather in our yard and then disappear to on their journey. Over the years we have seen various numbers, ranging from a 100-200 up to 400-500. This year, we are totally amazed at the numbers. This evening there are at least 800 monarchs - and that is not an exaggeration. There are probably more. Our neighbors have branches full, we have several trees full - it is amazing. I know that they will be gone tomorrow as there is a front coming through and the wind will switch to the north. We live in western Wisconsin, Hammond, which is 16 miles from the MN/WS border east of the Twin Cities.

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

On the evening of 9 August I sighted monarchs flying overhead around 7:15 p.m. There were many more than usual so I stopped hanging clothes and followed them only to find them in OUR trees!!!!!!
There were 2 main clusters of monarchs-it looked like the Mexican colonies except in a much smaller area of course. The following morning I got up at 6 and watched until 7:20 when the highest "colony" left the branches. I watched as the sun started to hit the leaves and branches and they began to unfold wings. They left in clusters of 15-20. I didn't see the lower group leave. The same thing happened the night of 10 August and again (less monarchs) on 12 August. When watching them on the morning of 13 August, about 150 (this is a rough guess) flew off together. It was like watching gold in the sky. I have never experienced such a beautiful event.

While running many maple trees long the lake were covered with monarchs. They hang with wings tight in the shade. Weather is about 68 degrees and humidity high. We have seen clusters of 300 - ? on many trees in the area. Are maple trees the most popular to roost?

The pine trees bordering our property have been covered with monarchs.Everytime I walked under the trees I was greeted by a cloud of monarchs.I have no idea how many are roosting in the trees.I counted 20 on a small branch and while I was counting there were at least 5o flying from tree to tree.Several of my students have reported large groups of monarchs in the trees in their yards as well.The weather has been hot and humid.I saw the largest number of monarchs the morning after some showers had gone through the area.

As of September, 6th, there has been a big change here in the last week.The trees in my yard that were covered with monarchs a week ago are now empty. Yesterday afternoon I saw only one monarch flying between the pines.Quite a change from a week ago.Several of my students havbe reported the same thing.The weather here is clear temp. in the mid 80's.rain is expected tonight.
Scores of Monarchs roosting over night.

Hundreds of Monarchs in two trees in my backyard and also in the trees of the neighbors. I didn't realize Monarchs migrated, and noticed all the butterflies when my neighbors called my attention to it. There are so many of them it's almost unreal.
As of September 6th, we are still seeing the Monarchs. Tuesday evening, 9/4 we had hundreds of them roosting again in our trees; I would say not quite as many as8/28, but they were still in awesome numbers. My neighbors tell me thatthey have frequented my trees in past years, in fact the school brought kidsto see them. I don't know what is so special about my tree or theneighborhood, but this is the first year I have seen them.
Visiting the family farm with Daniel and Ryan. There are so many Monarch butterflies here - it's just incredible.  There must be at least two dozen of them in the lane by the mailbox -

The most amazing spectacle was well over 1000 Monarch butterflies sitting all along the 2.5 km of beach just above the flotsam line where the wet sand changed to moist sand. Most were aligned facing the lake and as we scanned the beach it looked as if 1000s of shark fins were sticking out of the sand. It looks like Monarchs had a good year in Ontario.
Contributed by Carolyn King, Toronto Entomologists' Association (This is an excerpt from a bird sightings report from Dave Martin of Harrietsville, Ontario about his outing today to Port Burwell Provincial Park.Port Burwell is on the north shore of Lake Erie about 20 miles southeast of London, Ontario.)
Our migration watchers started reporting monarchs clustering on Saturday the 26th and Sunday the 27th. We observed several sites with 1,000 plus butterflies. We began tagging on Monday.

We travelled from my Grandma's house (30 miles N Goderich ) to London on this day. On our travels we noted an unusually large number of Monarch flying alongside. The most were located in the Auburn area when we counted over 100 monarchs in about a 1 miles stretch. The area was a heavily cropped area of Corn and some mature hay fields. We tried to miss hitting as many as we could.

We saw Monarchs way early this year..Peak migration seemed to be end of August when trees at Kessel Park had hoards of butterflies on them. The "Monarch Tree" at the town park had hoards of them over the past days and last night there weren't as many. The 5th and 6th graders are surprised to see the monarchs migrating already when compared to last years data.  We predictedthat they know a early frost is on the way.

Hundreds of Monarchs have rested in pine trees on the Sears farm North of Huxley. The family reported they have been there other years. Twenty were captured and tagged. Most were too high up in the trees to catch.

We counted 73 monarchs flying over our playground between 11:10 and 11:25 AM. We were anxious to get back out there at 2:00! We have a nice wind from the north today. From 1:45-2:00, 114 monarchs were sighted. It looks like a peak. We had to stop, only because we had to come inside from recess. The students are having a great time with this.

On August 31 at 6:00 PM, I spotted about a 100 or so Monarchs in our backyard trees for the first time. They were settling in for the night. We are about 9 miles NW of Kalona, IA.

Over three days of visits to the Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge near Prairie City, Iowa, east of Des Moines, I estimate I have seen more than 1,000 monarchs concentrated in several areas where the tickseed sunflowers are growing in mass. Amazing sights. The refuge also includes stands of thistles, goldenrod, Maximilian's sunflowers, compass plant, and Jerusalem artichoke--to name a few other plants, but the tickseeds are by far the favorites these days. The aim of the refuge is to restore the tallgrass prairie on more than 8,000 acres in central Iowa, and the hundreds of monarchs are loving the location. Given the overall size of the refuge, there seems little doubt that hundreds more monarchs are going uncounted each day!

Our family group of 5 young children, their two mothers, one father and grandmother and grandfather, caught and tagged 400 butterflies! There were thousands in the trees. Many hanging low enough that the 2 and 4 year olds could capture. Making great family memories here. . . Interesting to note that 6 of the ones we caught today were actually tagged by us in the same location yesterday. Perhaps the group is resting here waiting for the next big push.

Monarchs have been thick in the trees since August 25. In addition to today's taggging we have tagged 450 butterflies in the past week. The past 5 years we have not begun to tag until Labor Day weekend. Last night (8/30) we tagged 133 in one and one half hours . . . so many more roosting high in the trees. Awesome sight!

Another great day for monarch watching. The highlight came in the afternoon--from 4:15 p.m. to 5:15 p.m.--when 302 migrating monarchs were counted in the air during the single hour. The wind was blowing from the northeast, and the monarchs were essentially riding the wind--especially when they were flying or floating at 1,000 feet or above. The counting was done from a single spot near our butterfly garden in Altoona, Iowa. The garden is just a few blocks from the open prairie to the north, and the monarchs appeared as singles and in groups of two or three as they flew over at heights from 5 feet to more than 1,000 feet. Later, at least 30 monarchs were feeding at various places in our butterfly garden.

Link to Prof. Woodward's Monarch Butterfly Migration Journal

Peak migration for Sault Ste. Marie was August 16th. On September 2nd I have just returned from my second journey along the north shore of Lake Superior and Lake Huron, from Wawa, following Superior to Sault Ste. Marie, and then along the north shore of Lake Huron, Georgian Bay, and then along the French River to Lake Nipissing and south-east through Algonquin Park.  In early August I travelled the same route and encountered Monarchs every ten minutes or more frequently from North Bay to Wawa. On my second journey which just ended on Sunday Sept. 2, I saw virtually no monarchs along the highway - the weather in early August was extremely hot and dry.  This past weekend, the weather was sunny, warm days with cool nights, and I was just ahead of a low pressure system.  I anticipated many more monarchs this week.  I am now teaching up in Bancroft Ontario for the fall and winter.  We are searching for signs of larvae and adults.

Thousands of monarchs were gathered at a student's home on a farm outside of our town.  They were so thick that you couldn't mow the lawn or walk on the grass without disturbing hundreds of them.   Within 3 days they were mostly gone.   Jamestown, North Dakota.

I have been watching in our wooded lane where traditionally we see a small to large gathering of monarchs during the start of migration.  Over the last three days the number of monarchs in the tall trees has gone up each day.  Today I saw about 50-75 as we passed through to town.  This has been the peak day often over the years.
Monarchs crossing L. Erie from the north.  By 09/01 monarch eggs in Toledo area are rare and adults appear anxious to migrate. (Cluster at S/SW corner of large monarch house ready to go)

A late-morning visit to Chichaqua Bottoms wildlife area in northeast Polk Country was highly productive. After several days of being slowed by the heavy rain and strong winds, the monarchs suddenly were on the move again. Between 10:50 a.m. and 11:50 a.m., 923 monarchs were counted in the sky heading south--many with the naked eye and others with binoculars. A look at the Iowa map hinted what had happened.  On Friday afternoon, some of the heaviest wind damage and rains occurred in the community of Nevada and surrounding areas to the north. The monarchs must have been waiting for the all-clear before they moved on over Iowa. And move they did--racing at 500 to 1,000 feet in groups of 10 to 15 and as singles, doubles, and triples. What a sight it was! Later, on the roadways of Polk, Marshall, and Jasper Counties, hundreds more monachs were observed moving across the land at lower heights.

For the past two years hundreds of Monarchs have spent the night in the trees in my front yard. It's such a joy and spectacular sight that I call the Kids in to watch and discuss the wonder of it all. Last night {9-8-2001} was the evening of the Butterflies. They spent the night in Maple trees in my yard.

We saw the first mass migration on 9/4/'01. We had lost count at over 500 at our home in Olds. We have continued to see monarchs in dwindling numbers resting in trees after they refreshed themselvews with favorite flowever nectar. Our neighbor had thousands just covering his apple tree, as they do every year, but this year they seem to be much thicker.

The first ones we saw at our house were on 9/4. The monarchs were resting in the trees, as I had come home late--7:00, went out to water my flowers and found them. I lost track of butterflies after 500, as it was too hard to distinguish them higher in the trees. Only a few were still flying around. They left early the next morning.Our neighbors saw monarchs earlier and reported peak on 9/1--theirs was the loaded apple tree--we probably had them in our trees, but were busy and didn't get home till late each night. More have been arriving daily, but the numbers are around 235 to 300+, with last night being the lowest number. Hope to get home sooner tonight.We had spotten 12-24 flying around our butterfly garden during the day at school, it seems that there are many more large butterflies. The first mass number was the 9/9 report on the trees here at Stewart--was working in the garden, and noticed them heading toward the same area. Unfortunately that was after the students had gone home. Most of them have never seen this happening.This is the first time that we had butterflies resting here--the trees were planted two years ago at the same time we put in a butterfly garden. We have extablished a good stand of butterfly weed, and now some milkweed. So we look forward to seeing more in the future, and hope to raise some through the life cycle. Neighbors of Stewart Elementary had many more, and a friend just sent that observation in today (9/11/01).

We are participating in Journey South and my class is on the lookout for monarchs! Several sightings occurred over the weekend in our rural area. One boy brought in 9 monarchs that he and his grandpa (carefully) caught and we were able to observe them up close and then we released them!
Just counted 114 Monarchs from 1:45-2:00 PM.  It looks like a peak.  We had to stop, only because we had to come inside from recess.  Rats.  The students are having a great time with this.

This years monarch migration is in full swing here.  Monarchs are very abundant.  We were able to tag many this morning at roosting sites and they are very hard to avoid along highways and gravel roads.  They seem to like the moisture on the damp gravel roads.  We also tagged twenty five that had stopped to nectar on Golden Rod plants this past Saturday as hundreds flutterd high overhead - traveling due SW with the winds from a cold front that was moving across the state.

Last week my tree by my house was full of monarchs.There were far too many to count.  I captured 55 monarchs from the tree, and my class tagged them all.  We released them last Wednesday (9/5/01).  I live in State Center, Iowa. Many trees in State Center where filled with monarchs.

When the sun came out yesterday afternoon (Sept. 9) after a cloudy morning, my yard was absolutely alive with orange wings.  It was the most beautiful thing! It was like being inside a butterfly cage!  (my farm is south of Lake Park,IA)This morning my students reported back on week-end homework.  We are located just north of the IA MN border in Lakefield, MN (Pleasantview Elem).  Josie, Megan, Rachel, Micah and Mike reported back.  Their findings were as follows:Radhel and Megan saw 24-29 monarchs on their block and they thought it was because their moms had so many flowers.  Josie saw them at her house in town and on her grandparent's farm north of town.  Mike reported a group of monarchs on a tree in an alleyway behind his house. Micah saw a group floating through the air at his house.

Saturday, September 8th, 2001 was the first time in my life I've been lucky enough to witness the Monarch migration. We were swept away with hundreds of Monarch Butterflies in our trees. We've moved into this home in rural PA this Summer & have loved watching nature. I've told people that this house is like being in heaven- the views are beautiful. Standing in the sun with hundreds of butterflies fluttering around me was as close to heaven as one can get- and still go in the house & have lunch.

I am happy to report that at about 2p.m Monday afternoon the 1st, 2nd and 3rd grades at Mary Our Queen Elementary counted over 230 monarchs migrating south in less than 15 minutes. The Monarchs were flying in groups of one,two,three, and even six right over our heads both high and low, it was amazing. I have only seen them roosting and found it an extrodinary site to watch them fly directly over the students  heading due south on a beuatiful sunny blue skied day. Our temps were right around 80 with a soft southerly breeze. Quite stricking to see so many bright orange gliding butterflies in the blue sky!!!

I am happy to report that at about 2p.m Monday afternoon the 1st, 2nd and 3rd grade at Mary Our Queen Elementary counted over 230 monarchs migrating south in less than 15 minutes. The Monarchs were flying in groups of one,two,three and even six right over our heads both high and low, it was amazing. I have only seen them roosting and found it an extraordinary site to watch them fly directly over the students heading due south on a beautiful sunny blue skied day. Our temps were right around 80 with a soft southerly breeze. Quite striking to see so many bright orange gliding butterflies in the blue sky!!!

Tonight we observed about 2000 Monarchs.  They settled in at about 6:30 tonight.  They have been here about 3 weeks.  We have a feeling that they will all migrate in less than a week.  It has been great fun watching them.

Velma Ludwigs of Sioux City, Iowa has reported hundreds of monarchs roosting in her trees since 9/3/01.

Contributed by Dawn Chapman, Dorothy Pecaut Nature Center, Sioux City, Iowa.

Judy Saltsgiver of Sloan, Iowa has been thrilled by the sight of monarchs in her trees since 9/3/01. There are hundreds of them roosting at night. She has lived at her present address for 23 years and she first noticed this occurrence last year and is excited that they have returned in 2001.

Contributed by Dawn Chapman, Dorothy Pecaut Nature Center, Sioux City, Iowa.

Chuck Hinrichsen of Hinton, Iowa reported hundreds of monarchs in the trees outside his home 9/8/01. He phoned on 9/10/01 to report that the monarchs have thinned and aren't as concentrated outside his home.

Contributed by Dawn Chapman, Dorothy Pecaut Nature Center, Sioux City, Iowa.

Beth Hickey of Sergeant Bluff, Iowa has had monarchs roosting in the pine trees, mulberries and silver maples of her farm grove for several years and they are back! Monarchwatch tagging volunteers from the Dorothy Pecaut Nature Center in Sioux City tagged more than 150 monarchs in one hour at Beth Hickey's house on 9/6/01.

Contributed by Dawn Chapman, Dorothy Pecaut Nature Center, Sioux City, Iowa.

Wow, I've finally SEEN the numbers these guys can form during migration!! This afternoon (9/8/01) in Vining, IA, 42 degrees N latitude thousands of Monarchs were observed roosting in Catalpa, Mulberry and assorted evergreens at the old St. Mary's Church here on the north edge of town. Impossible to count them-they made the trees look like they were full of brown leaves while roosting in clumps! Most of the butterflies were nice and large and all appeared to be very fresh.

Very little nectaring noted at between 2:30 and 3:30 p.m.--primarily roosting and flying around despite the proximity of flower beds which included much goldenrod in full bloom. About 2 miles due East, at the old St. Mary's cemetary, several hundred Monarchs were observed roosting in a row of old evergreens all along the eastern edge of the cemetary.
We had a major weather event locally last night about 9:30 to 10:30 p.m. including over an inch of rain in an hour, major winds (causing serious damage just east of our town) and impressive thunder and lightning. The morning was very cool, damp and overcast until about 1 p.m. here and then in a sunnier afternoon, the temps got up into the lower 70's F.
Unseasonably cold weather here plus mostly overcast skies seemed to have stalled the Monarch gathering here by the 9th. We went over to check in the morning and later in the afternoon (9/9/01) and the trees around the flower beds there (quite a sheltered location) were still "coated" with roosting Monarchs. In the afternoon, temps got up to perhaps 63F and there were some flying all about, but no nectaring was noted either time.
Kind of good luck for the town here as word is spreading around and many folks are taking the opportunity to go and see this marvelous sight!

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

My husband and I have 5 acres of woods where our house was built. We had lived here 11 years and never have seen what we found in our woods 4 days ago (9/3/01). My husband was mowing the paths in our woods and all of a sudden hundreds of monarch butterflies started flying everywhere and they are nesting in trees. I did look a few things up on the internet and found that Iowa is in the path of migrating monarchs to Mexico. Could that be where they are going? If so, why are they in our trees and not our neighbors? There seems to be about 2 acres where they are gathering to the east of our house--but not to the north, south or west. Is that odd?

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

We live in the country near Hudson, Iowa.  We first saw the first Monarch's about three weeks ago.  A week ago(9/5) we had thousands of Monarchs in our silver maple, walnut, and pine trees in our yard.  We still have Monarchs in our trees but the numbers are greatly reduced from what they were a week ago.  Possibly there are several hundred now.  Today is Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2001.

We have spotted monarch masses here in southeast Iowa [Thornburg, Iowa--HWY 22] 20 miles south of I-80 exit 201.As of 9/11 we are still seeing Monarchs pass through. The mass was spotted last Thursday(9/6) along the railroad tracks just outside of town.

I live in NE Nebraska along the Missouri River.For at least a week we have had huge numbers of monarchsin out fir trees (blue spruce, cedar etc.), swarming when you walked by. They were also gathered in very large bushes.They would also fly in great bunches.What a sight!Very unusual sighting, although the numbers are lessening.We had none in the spring that we could identify.

A late-afternoon visit to the Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge turned up approximately 100 migrating monarchs feeding in one area. Unlike previous times this fall, when the monarchs stopping at the refuge were observed feeding primarily off the tickseed sunflowers, this time the monarchs were favoring the goldenrod. The observation time was 4:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. The afternoon sun was warm, and the wind was blowing lightly. Once again this day, monarchs were seen along the roadways across central Iowa.

We have seen numerous monarch sitings in the area. We can tell it is time for them to move Southward.  They arrived yesterdary (9/10) in our area. We are located 8 miles from the Wisconsin border about 60 miles North of Chicago.
We have hundreds of monarch butterflies roosting on the trees of our property right now. We live in Barstow, Illinois and they have been there now for a couple of days and more are coming each day.

"A large wave of monarchs moved into the Cape May area on Friday, September28th. We recorded our highest census run count for the season, and over10,000 monarchs were counted in local roosts. Data for the first four weeksof the Road Census is now available at our website," reports Dick Walton, director of the Cape May Monarch Census.

FROM THE CAPE MAY NATURAL HISTORY & EVENTS HOTLINE: A major coldfront at the end of September with winds from the north andnorthwest triggered one of the most dramatic MONARCH concentrations inseveral years. By 2 p.m. on September 28 bushes in the dunes at CapeMay Point were vibrating with roosting Monarchs that had settled in andstopped migrating because of the strong winds. That evening and dawnthe following day (September 29) were times to remember. Pooledsightings documented at least 70,000 Monarchs roosting at 3 differentlocations: the undeveloped dune forest at Stone Harbor Point, the dunesand backyards in Cape May Point, and the stands of Red Cedars at EastPoint (in Cumberland County). There were no doubt many more Monarchs inSouth Jersey than those 70,000, since many other coastal stands ofnative vegetation were not checked for roosting Monarchs. The coldfrontwas followed by Indian Summer temperatures and winds from the wrongdirection, winds that do not aide migration. The result has beenlingering Monarchs in gardens the last three days (Oct. 2-4).

Now in its 10th year, this annual migration census is providing a long-term record of migration patterns at this migration hotspot. Located at the tip of a peninsula, monarchs congregate here in high numbers to avoid the over-water crossing. Learn more at the Cape May Monarch Census Web site.

Denise Gibbs, of the Chincoteague Monarch Monitoring Projectreports September 29th as the strongest migration to date, with an average rate of 880 monarchs per hour, and 350/hour the previous day! (Prior to this, September 19th was the strongest migration to date, with an average rate of 70 monarchs per hour.)

Here are her comments:

The first big wave of monarchs arrived hereon Assateague Island on Friday, Sept 28.The migration was constant all day Friday and most of Saturday the 29th. Thousands of monarchs clustered in the bayberry thicketsat dusk on Saturday and have remained theresince then. A storm caused temperatures todrop and the north wind increased to 25mphwith higher gusts. This morning (Monday) theconditions are: heavy rain, wind north at 15mphand 50 degrees F. Monarchs still cling to the bayberry, Groundsel-tree, and goldenrod. Here'swhat worries me now: The combination of a waxingmoon (full tomorrow night) and coastal floodingfrom the storm is creating a high tide thatis breaching the primary dune and has alreadywashed out part of the beach road. The beacharea along Tom's Cove is gone. Waves arespreading up into the beach grasses and seaside goldenrod. This is the site whereseveral thousand monarchs are clustered on thegoldenrod flowers. The ground is flat hereand I fear that if the flooding continues,they will drown on the incoming tide.

Interesting Migration Pattern Noted by Denise

During 3 seasons of monitoring on the East Coast we noticed this pattern: About 150 miles to our north, Dick Walton would report big "waves" of monarchs coming through Cape May, NJ. It would take 2 days for these waves to reach me at Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge in VA.

I would report big waves to Mark Garland at Kiptopeke (which is about 70 miles south of me) and he would receive them one day later.

Although I have no data in the form of recovered tagged monarchs, this was not a one-time event. It happened time after time over the 3 seasons. Usually, but not always, the winds were from the north, northwest, or west-northwest with full sun.

Annual Monarch Migration Monitoring Site
Daily monitoring began Saturday, September 15, 2001.
Our 2 second grade classes have counted 100 monarchs today flying along the coast. We have been seeing several monarchs every day at recess.
Several second geade students have sighted monarchs in the city.

Large group of Monarch Butterflies seen around 5: p.m. Was looking for Monarch Catepillars when seen. Have never witnessed before!Student report: "The North side of the stop sign. On the bike path. There were lots of butterflies. They are monarch."

Today one of my 6th grade students came into class very excited about what he had seen the day before near his house in Marengo, IL.  He had witnessed about 50 monarchs flying overhead.  We had been watching for approx. 2 weeks and no one had seen more than a few flying around at any one time. The temperature has made a dramatic change in the last few days.  We are also seeing hundreds of birds congregating to begin their flight away from our area for the winter.

Waves of thousands of monarchs arrived today, riding strong winds from the E/NE.  Skies were overcast, temperature at 70 F, winds gusting up to 30 mph.  Counted 112 in one hour (2-3PM); then counted 114 in one hour (6-7PM).  Most flew at heights well over 100 feet.  These might be the first wave of the peak migration coming down from Iowa.Definitely the Day of the Butterflies!!

A look at the late afternoon sky showed a wonderful picture--and suggested there are still a lot of migrating monarchs to be viewed in central Iowa. The monarchs were moving again in heavy numbers--this time to the west, flying at heights of 25 feet to more than 1,000 feet and riding a wind from the east.  Between 5:30 p.m. and 6:15 p.m., 223 monarchs were counted with the naked eye and binoculars. Many could easily be seen against an ever-changing cloudy sky, and their shadows against the clouds were beautiful as they raced and/or floated toward the west.

For the second consecutive day, large numbers of migrating monarchs could be seen. When I arrived home in the early afternoon on Friday, monarchs were observed swirling around the walnut and oak trees in areas adjoining our butterfly garden. A look to the sky showed monarch movement similar to the previous day--mostly from east to west as the butterflies took advantage of the wind that continued to blow from the east for another day. On a day when I had seen the national day of remembrance gathering on television at midday from the National Cathedral in Washington, D.C., the sight of many monarchs in the sky seemed to be nature's special message for those who would see the flight. From 1:15 p.m. to 2:15 p.m., I counted 248 monarchs. I then watched more television coverage of the national tragedy concerning the terrorists' bombings. Returning to nature, I counted 76 more monarchs between 4 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. The temperature at the time was 59 degrees, and the wind was blowing from the e

Heavy monarch activity across central Iowa continued, or perhaps a second wave was coming. The heavy numbers over a longer period of days hold out hopes the overall migration is larger this year than it has been in years past.

I estimate that I observed 1,000 or more monarchs on this day. In early afternoon in our butterfly garden, I counted 323 monarchs in an hour. Earlier, at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, I observed 252 monarchs in 45 minutes. Throughout the day, numerous monarchs were seen along the central Iowa roadways and in our butterfly garden. The day ended at dusk with 25 to 50 monarchs swirling around the trees near our home.

Other Migration Highlights:

September 13th: 223 in 45 minutes
September 8th: 923 in 60 minutes
September 3rd: 302 in 60 minutes

Hundreds of gorgeous orange and black butterflies went into the air when we were talking near our large mulberry tree on Saturday, 9/15/01, about 9:00 AM. They settled back into the tree and looked like dry leaves. They flew out several times on Saturday and Sunday as friends and relatives came by to see the spectacular view. They circled a short distance and settled back into the same tree. We had a cool rain on Saturday evening and they were still here on Sunday at dark and it is beginning to rain again.
Therewere a few, maybe 100 left this morning (9/19)and they seem to be all gone thisevening. We had light to mediumdrizzling rain all day Tuesday (9/18), so I guess this sunny day today was right tocontinue on their southern journey. Each time they fluttered out of thetrees they would fly up south westward and then settle back down in themulberry or oak trees.
It was sad to see themgone after a Saturday, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, and part of Wednesday visit.How beautiful and fun it has been.
On Sunday at Verona Beach New York saw many monarchs traveling south along Eastern shore of Oneida Lake.  I counted about 150 in two hours.  And I know I missed many on this short count.

This evening we had perhaps 100 Monarchs roosting in our Lincoln, NE common ground. This is not the 1000 we usually see, but they were oh, so beautiful!
There were one or two butterflies in the area around 5 PM, but by 6 we noticed them arriving... flying high overhead, first one at time, then two, then five. To find the roosts we merely watched a single butterfly until he or she landed amongst friends in the cottonwood tree to sleep and wait for morning.
I will post images on my website by the end of the week.

It seems that I am seeing at least one monarch flying at all times in this area. As soon as one disappears, I look around and can find another. On Monday, Sept. 10, I saw a cluster of about 30 butterflys on various limbs in a sheltered wooded area in the City park overlooking the Mississippi River. This was in the city of Clinton, Iowa. Earlier in the day I watched the monarchs as they flew by and most were headed almost due South.On Wednesday, the 12th, I was 10 miles South of Clinton in a county park along the Mississippi River and saw more Monarches clustering on limbs. Once again they weren't on just one limb, but rather scattered in an area that provided protection from the wind. Most of the monarchs on this day were headed in a Westerly direction.

We had thought that we missed the peak migration because we saw so many early monarchs migrating in August but we didn't.  This weekend (Sept 15&16) we noticed a large number of monarchs on flowers and bushes and then Monday it peaked with 10-13 monarchs coming and going all day long to our butterfly bushes in our school's courtyard.  The students are so very excited about this phenomena.   We are so glad that we did not miss the peak of migration.

On Friday, September 14th, the 6th grade Life Science class at Malvern Preparatory School, in the suburbs of Philadelphia, observed approximately 8 monarchs all flying in a southern direction.

These observations took place during a 15 minute mini-lab/observation, between 2:40 and 2:55 pm.

It was a cool, rainy day with a temperature of 70 degrees.

Yesterday afternoon (9-12) students at Morton School found monarchs inlarge numbers roosting in trees around town. Hastings is 40.35 N 98.23 WThe temps yesterday were in the upper 80's with a 10mph breeze from thenorth. This may be the first wave for us. Numbers are not unusually highbut we seem to have an enlarged area of roosting sites. Normally inprevious years there were a few parks and shelter belts which were alwaysfilled. Yesterday monarchs were more clustered into the center of townroosting in backyard trees.

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

Thousands of monarchs on the Toronto waterfront
Based on my success yesterday at Presqu'ile Provincial Park, 150 km eastof Toronto, after work today I drove down to the Toronto waterfront andTommy Thompson Park (Leslie Street Spit). Again good numbers of monarchsand I tagged over 200 from 4:30 pm to 7:30 pm. As the sun set and Ithought the activity was finished for the night, I came across a number oflow roosts containing 50+ monarchs each. Other roosts much highercontained more and I suspect down in the park there were probably somelarge roosts ( primarily on willow, poplar, Manitoba maple and even asmall elm). In short, many many more monarchs than I could ever hope to tag. Probablythousands. Many seeking shelter from very strong south-westerly winds.

September 18
After all the movement noted last week at Presqu'ile and Leslie StreetSpit (Toronto) and at Port Dover on Lake Erie (Long Point), I think thepeak of the migration is over. On Monday, I collected 200 on the LeslieStreet Spit, with most being found at the tip of the peninsula. Today atPresqu'ile, things were overcast, almost no wind, and almost no monarchs.Those present seemed focused on migrating and not feeding. The 10 I caughtwere caught on the fly and were also found at the tip of Owen Point,ready to head off across the lake or to Gull/High Bluff Islands. Our weather will be changing overnight to showers - which are desperatelyneeded. We are still in a Level II drought, and this could be upgraded toa Level III (severe enforced water-use restrictions).

No news of monarchs moving through Point Pelee National Park.

Dropped by Presqu'ile Provincial Park this afternoon to capture monarchsand found good numbers in the abundant goldenrod. Monarchs were fightingto make progress in the south-westerly winds (which had been out of thenorth earlier in the day) and congregated in areas with goldenrod thatwere sheltered by trees. In four hours, I had captured 350 monarchs. Many seemed to have recently hatched as the wings were relatively soft andunhardened. Also seeing monarchs passing through a number of towns and villages alongthe north shore of Lake Ontario, crossing high above our major 6 and 4lane expressway (highway 401) that follows in close proximity the northshore of Lake Ontario (and which extends from Windsor in the west all theway to the Quebec border in the east. All soaring in a typicalsouth-westerly direction.

September 18
After all the movement noted last week at Presqu'ile and Leslie StreetSpit (Toronto) and at Port Dover on Lake Erie (Long Point)

Many thousands of monarchs were reported at Port Dover on the shores of Lake Erie by John Power at Wings of Paradise Butterfly Conservatory. This was the same day I reported thousands of monarchs on the Toronto waterfront.
Reported for John Power by Don Davis.

We have an unobstructed view to the north from our house. If I look back and forth and up and down with my binoculars, I can see perhaps 100 Monarchs at a time, all heading south.
Two hours after my earlier post, the "flow" had slowed to about 1/10th ofwhat I indicated originally -- perhaps 10 in the sky at any one time.
Iassume there was a front moving in from the north with many butterfliestaking advantage just at the time I happened to look out my window and thenfiled the original report. Now the sky to the north is essentially empty.
We have a couple of places on the KSU campus where Monarchs congregate eachyear and I'll check each of them out tomorrow.
Contributed to Monarch Watch.

Friday evening, September 14, approximately 6:30 PM, I saw about 30+ Monarchs flying in and landing in trees around our house. I have never seen this before...they were not stopping to feed on any flowers (I have butterfly bushes), just landing in the trees.
We were outside lighting candles as part of the candlelight vigil in remembrance of the tragedy in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania andcould not believe all the butterflys in the sky flying onto the trees inour yard. We got the binoculars and they were, indeed, Monarchs. Ihave never seen so many at once before and wonder if this is part oftheir regular route.
Contributed to Monarch Watch.

I just want to report that hundreds of monarchs were present atop Mt. Philo just three days ago (9/16/01), according to the State Park Ranger.  He confirmed what I imagined to be true, that there were more this year than in the past two years.

We had several hundred monarchs arrive Sunday night, Sept. 16, and settled into the trees.
It rained most of the night and the temperatures were in the 60's today and rainy, so they were grounded all day Monday. They flew around in circles a little but didn't go anywhere. Tonight, Tuesday September 18, many more arrived around 5:00 and now they are dripping off of the trees, waiting for the weather to let up and the temps. to rise - I suppose.
We are in south Kansas City, that makes us a little south of Lawrence, Kansas (Monarch Watch) and north of the Baker Wetlands area where they tagged so many Saturday. We had not seen them in any numbers until Sunday night.
They are clustered on wild cherry trees (I think). We have about three acres of natural habitat. The monarchs have been stopping by here consistently for 5 years with by far the largest numbers in 1996. Every square foot of air was filled that year.
Contributed to Monarch Watch.

In the aftermath of Tuesday's terrorist attacks on America, Craig Tufts, Chief Naturalist of the National Wildlife Federation wrote from his home outside Washington, D.C:

In the mid-Atlantic states, the passage of a front on Tuesday evening brought rapidly clearing skies Wednesday morning. In recognition of Tuesday's horrific events, my employer had given us the day off to catch up with friends and family and to overcome some of the shock of the terrorism. My wife and I attempted to do that and started the day slowly, going out to our deck with our coffee and appreciating the phenomenally beautiful day that had been given us.

We live in extreme southwestern Loudoun County, VA, and our house overlooks Mt. Weather, one of the Federal Gov't's emergency preparedness centers, located atop the Blue Ridge just 4 miles away. The sounds of Tuesday evening's helicopter ferries from the mountaintop were replaced with silence, except for a stiff breeze through white pines, at 9:30AM.

At about 10:25AM, with brilliant blue skies dominating and winds from the NNE at about 10-15mph, small groups, and then kettles of broad-winged hawks began amassing about 1000-3000 ft above our house. Ten minutes later, the kettles of hawks peaked. We had counted over 400 broad-wingeds that flew past in that brief burst. For the next hour, smaller groups and individual hawks streamed past, higher and closer to the mountain ridge as noon approached. During the entire time we watched, monarchs, as individuals or apparent loose clusters of 2-5 individuals, followed the same path south, often flapping upward in circles but mostly riding the winds. At about 11AM, I counted for just a minute or two and estimate that by focusing in and out with 10x binoculars directed toward the ridge, I was seeing about 1 monarch every 2 seconds. This went on for at least an hour and may have been occurring even before I first saw the hawks. Many of the monarchs were flying at an estimated 2000-3000 ft above the ground.

Seeing and recognizing that some wonderful aspects of life on this planet go on, no matter how frightening and uncertain other parts of our lives may seem, helped steer things back towards whatever normal might mean for us in the months ahead.

Several sixth graders here have reported seeing trees with up to 200 estimated monarchs in them in the past two weeks (writing 9/19). The estimated peak was September 10th, when about 225 monarchs were sighted. Another peak seems to have been in the September 4th, with approximately 74 counted.
My students report to me how many they estimatethat they saw on a given day. That's not very accurate, and on some days Ihave more students reporting than on others. I suppose this is true formany reporters from schools. I'd be interested in how other people are counting, so that I can adjustour method here and feel our counts are more accurate.

A few Monarchs have been observed the past three weeks.The past two weeks there was a noticeable south west flight direction.We have had 2 days of rain but today is partly cloudy and calm.I observed at 1:30 PM approx. 100 Monarchs visible at one time.The height varies from rooftop to as high as the eye can see.In a part of the sky were there is a white cloud for backgound they are too numerous to count!As per Natures scheme.Later,Ron

We had noticed quite a few at 12:00 recess so we went outside for about 15 minutes at about 2:20. We saw hundreds of monarchs floating in the air up high. Then all of a sudden they descended on our playground as if to say hi to the 2nd graders. There were lots of birds and dragonflies flying with them,we assume trying to eat them.It had rained for the last 2 days and was finally sunny. This was the most we have seen at Corinth Elementary in 4 years!

We are in the midst of one of the big pushes for sure. Today, at home (Nellysford, VA) and at Sweet Briar College, there is a big peak of monarchs nectaring on Buddleas, Solidago, and various cultivated asters in our butterfly gardens. Sunday 16 September, the monarchs began building up, nectaring on goldenrods, Buddleia, and various asters in my garden. On Monday 17 September there were more, Tuesday more still, and today there are at least 150 in the garden. All monarchs--except for a few old laggards--are very fresh and in mint condition, which indicates we are now have shifted into the migratory phase.

The butterflies are very skittish, and one patch of goldenrod had at least 50 on the flowers, and all flew up when a cloud passed over. This reminded me of the behavioral response to clouds in the Mexican overwintering colonies that we described a couple of years ago (in: W. H. Calvert, L. P. Brower, and R. O. Lawton. 1992. Mass flight response of overwintering monarch butterflies (Nymphalidae) to cloud-induced changes in solar radiation intensity in Mexico. Journal of the Lepidopterists' Society 46:97-105.).

I also checked a field site that I monitor in Nellysford, VA Monday afternoon (4:12PM, 17 September 2001). Ten days ago there were 2 monarchs in the field. Monday I counted 17 on a species of yellow daisey, and 32 more in the same field on the lovely orange flowers of "butterfly weed", Asclepias tuberosa. (This is very late for tuberosa flowers, but the farmer mowed the field about 6 weeks ago and the milkweed shoots resprouted, hence the new blooms.)

We have also been monitoring our Buddleia garden at Sweet Briar College, and the same temporal build up has and is occurring.

It will be interesting to see how the Atlantic costal migration is proceeding (Denise Gibbs is monitoring for with us at Chincoteague on the coast and Dick Walton and at Cape May, NJ).

Upwards of 3000 monarchs clustered in 5 trees.

The butterflies started coming in around 5pm Friday Sept 14, 2001 when a quite strong cold front was coming through but weather was very clear. The next morning, as we watched them it was very cold (40's maybe) and they didn't start moving till at least 8:30am, when the sun was just starting to hit the trees. They then started moving only very sporadically. We didn't stay past 9am so didn't catch the main exodus, but none came back Saturday night..........The coordinates for the monarch-occupied Tulip Poplar trees (about 5 trees) at the Michael McGowan homestead on Turner Mountain are 38.06N, -78.62W. Turner Mountain is on the Charlottesville West section of the USGS maps.

We've been watching for monarchs for about a week now.  Until today, we were seeing mostly viceroys.  Since noon, we have counted over 100 monarchs passing over our playground.  We were lucky to tag about eight.  Tomorrow we are going on a field trip to a spot that is usually full of monarchs-we hope today was not the peak day!

Best day so far. Hundreds have been observed and many tagged, not only in Woodbridge, but by the butterfly club members over at Sewaren. Sunny, temps in 70's, east winds 7-10 mph. Rain forecast for Thurs., so things will probably slack off.

We went outside to count Monarchs today.  We saw 10 monarch flying in 15 minutes.  Most of the Monarchs were seen at our butterfly garden.  Yesterday we didn't count, but we saw a lot more.The butterflys were very bright looking ansd seemed very healthy.It was fun.  Monarchs are Beutiful.

On Sunday evening Sept. 15 we noticed several monarchs flying around our property upon further investigation we found that in the back of property (1 acre) there were thousands of monarch on our trees.  The later the evening got the more butterflies there were.  They continued most of the week, but there seemed to be fewer each day.  Upon checking yesterday evening (Sept. 19) they were all gone.  We do not believe they have been there in previous years.   What a beautiful site they were.

Today, September 20, while I was conducting my field research project at Lodge Glade in Ha Ha Tonka State Park near Camdenton, Missouri (Camden County) I saw literally hundreds (if not thousands) of Monarchs nectaring on Liatris aspera (Rough Blazing Star).
The season has been quite a good one there for both the blazing star and the monarch. There were many hundreds of plants of the Rough Blazing Star in full flower and the Monarchs were making good use of them. There was good evidence that the Monarchs were roosting in the trees surrounding the glade and were coming from these roosts directly onto the glade to nectar on these plants.
I had seen a number of mating Monarchs at this glade earlier in the season and the glade also supports a number of species of native milkweeds which are utilized by the Monarchs. The temperatures today reached around 80 degrees or so and it was a bright sunny day with a light to moderate breeze for most of the day. Coincidentally there were many other species of butterflies present in large numbers also. The Monarchs were also using several other species as nectar sources, including wild oregano (Cunila origanoides) and several species of goldenrod (Solidago species).
This was probably one of the best days for Monarchs that I have ever seen, given the numbers and the fact that many of them were also fresh and very brightly colored.

We reached a peak on Sept 12 & 13 when the Monarchs were falling out of the sky onto our butterfly bushes.  We tagged 29 Monarchs in our small yard with six butterfly bushes, missed about 20 more.  A cold front pushed through on the 10th and the skies were very clear, they were riding the wave!

After successfully raising several hundred monarchs from eggs this year, I am equally pleased to see such abundant numbers throughout migration.  Thursday, Sept. 20 was a peak day in Central Illinois with one, two, and three monarchs at a time coasting into my butterfly garden, one group after another.  Their favorite plants appeared to be the butterfly bushes, zinnias, tropical milkweed and water snowball (a pond plant).  Unfortunately, they disappear quickly after being captured and tagged.  The weather has been cooperative for now, but we are expecting low temps this Sunday.  I hope to use up the rest of my 200 tags this weekend (Sept. 22-23).  The monarchs and migrating hummingbirds are the only things bringing joy to my life these days after the tragedy out East.  I am so thankful for this gift from God.

My students and I were out to recess and within a 10 minute time period, over 30 monarchs flew by us heading directly south. It was an incredible sight!

Nearby... A student from St. Joseph School observed about 100 monarchs roosting in trees near his home on 9/21/01.

Spent the day (9/22) visiting Clinton & Warsaw MO (by Truman Lake), about 110 miles SE of Kansas City, MO. What a day for butterflies!  I have never witnessed such a heavy migration.  While at Clinton, the skies were full of Monarchs, too many for me to count, but I figured they were coming at the rate of 30 or more a minute. While at Warsaw, again saw incredible numbers of Monarchs, flying in large groups ranging again up to 50 a minute.  Awesome!!!  In an hour saw thousands floating high above the trees, they just kept coming and coming.

At 6:45 pm we observed approximately 60 monarchs gathering in several select trees in our yard, preparing to roost for the night.  This is the greatest concentration we have seen to date.  The afternoon was windy with a front passing through which brought cooler temperatures.  What a display!  My students and I will check our playground tomorrow for further sightings.

For two hours we traveled in a NW direction from Bolivar in the MO Ozarks to Kansas City (10:30AM - 12:30PM).  The temp. went from 78 to 82 degrees. The sunny breeze was from the northeast.  We started seeing Monarch butterflies drift from right to left (NE to SW) in front of our van and from 6 to about 15 feet high. In total we counted over 231 Monarchs.  We also saw many Sulfer (yellow) butterflies.  We've made this trip many times but this event certainly made it more enjoyable!  I would call it "Peak Migration" for Southwest/Central Missouri.
Saw about 300 in the trees around 5:00 p.m. on Saturday

The alfalfa fields near our high school are full of butterflies feeding on the flowers.  We also have seen them feeding on sweet autumn clematis and especially milkweed and sedum.  They are spending their nights in the trees all over town.  They seem to like red oak trees.  We took some movies of them feeding.
We spotted at least a dozen monarchs on our Buddleia bush today in the garden. They are feasting on the nectar as I write this message.
Thousands of Monarchs were roosting in Elm trees on the evening of Sept. 23rd. This is the first migration noticed in this area this year.

We live in the country 3 miles east of Olney...At 6:45pm, 9/24/01, we noticed considerabley more butterfliesthan normal...We have 3 huge mulberry trees in our front yard...the monarchsare having a feast...there are hundreds of them...such a gorgeous site.
About 200 monarchs at overnight roost.  Today was the first large increase in the number of monarchs.

The first Monarchs arrived in Ardmore the second week of August!  The earliest they have arrived in the 12 years I have tracked them.  But!!!!  Right now, in my Monarch Sleeping Tree (a huge Oak tree on the edge of a 20 acre field of milkweed) there about 3,000 Monarchs curled up for the night!  They have not reached peak, because when they do we see about 10,000 an hour!  They do not spend the night every year, but often, and never in the Spring, only in the Fall.We have heavy infestations of varigated Oak Leaf Cutter caterpillar this year, so I just knew they would fly by, but here they are!!

Best day this season. Hundreds going over and through the back yard in Woodbridge. Many stopping to nectar on the butterfly bushes. Reports from our associates in Sewaren, NJ report the same. Was able to net and tag over 100 over the course of the day. Sunny, windy, temps in the high 70's. Rain coming in over night, so expect to see lesser numbers tomorrow.  JIM (Monarchs NJ)

Over the weekend 85 sixth graders reported seeing 471 monarchs.  They were concerned that there might be some repetition because of a sighting during their pe class.  Large numbers were seen at butterfly bushes.

On Friday, 9/21, my brother realized that a heavy  migration was flying through Warsaw, Kansas.  He  scanned the sky over Truman Lake  with his binoculars, and was astonished to view a huge, flowing "river" of  butterflies.  The skies, he told me were simply filled with thousands and  thousands of Monarchs, he had never seen anything like it!  I am just overjoyed with what I have seen, and his  and other reports of so many Monarchs on the move.  Look out Arkansas and  Texas, they are on their way!!!

We saw many monarch's in Jefferson City, MO this weekend while playing soccer along the Missouri River bank. I would guess that there were about 50 that I saw in 20 min or so observation. They were beautiful.

I had over 100 Monarchs in my prairie on the weekend of the 8th and 9th of September.  The number has dropped over the last two weeks.  The large group was very friendly and wanted to be part of my work.  They would follow me into the woods. I was planting several understory trees that weekend.  I still have lots of black eyed Susan's, goldenrod and aster in bloom.  Numbers of Monarchs are running about 20 right now.  For your info: my prairie is around 2.5 acres.  I have several rocks for sunning and good mud spots for puddling.Michael Horton, Fairborn OH

There were lots of monarchs sighted in our area in the afternoon on Saturday.  When a family was traveling from Hallsville to Mark Twain Lake, they saw about 10 monarchs every mile.  One student brought in 3 monarchs that he had caught in his house when the door was left open for a long time.  We are releasing those monarchs today so they can continue their migration.

From the top of Lake Ft. Smith dam we counted 44 monarchs flying over in a 30 minute period.  The Monarchs were flying over the lake and would coast downward after crossing over the dam.  They were beautiful as they passed between us and the sun - like very small stained-glass works of art.  We wished them well on their journey to Mexico. The day was clear with a northwest wind, temperature around 75 degrees.

The past week has been a monarch bonanza here on the edge of and in the Blue Ridge Mountains in central Virginia. My impression isthat large numbers came through on the cold front last week and have beenin a holding pattern while nectaring heavily through yesterday. Virtuallyall are in mint condition.

Today (24 September2001) another cold front is coming through with periodic heavy rain. It willbe interesting to see what happens as it passes over us......

Since 19 September 2001 therehave been numerous monarchs nectaring on Buddleas, Solidago, Asclepiascurassavica, and various cultivated asters in our butterfly gardens at homenear Roseland VA and at Sweet Briar College, in Amherst, VA.On Saturday 22 September while sampling in our experimental garden at theCollege, there were about 20 monarchs nectaring on a white floweredvarietal of Buddleia davidii. There was a light wind from the NNW and itwas warm and sunny, but as I approached them a cloud partially obscuredthe sun and every one of the 20 monarchs flew up off the Buddleias wherethey had been intently nectaring and flew with the wind to the south. Thisresponse reminded me of what we termed the "cloud response" at theoverwintering sites in Mexico (see Calvert,W.H., L. P. Brower, and R. O.Lawton. 1992. Mass flight response of overwintering monarch butterflies(Nymphalidae) to cloud-induced changes in solar radiation intensity inMexico. Journal of the Lepidopterists' Society 46:97-105).Yesterday (23 September 2001), in the local roadside fields and pastures,monarchs were nectaring by the threes and fours on European thistle and onthe yellow native composite Actinomeris alternifolia.

On the 23rd of September 2001, between 1:45 to 2:00 PM, I counted 89 monarchs nectaring in the gardens. It was sunny and humid with the temperature in the upper 70's F. The butterflies were very skittish and would fly up and cruise about when approached. Almost all were in mintcondition, and judging from our Sweet Briar College censuses (20 mile southof here), all the females are now un-mated. Most of these butterflies weremoderately plump, meaning that they have been nectaring assiduously andconverting the sugars to lipids that they store in their abdominal fatbodies. In the evening, a cold front came in with heavy rain.

The 24th of September was a day of stormy weather with an accumulation oftwo inches of rain. A few very unhappy looking monarchs were seen flyingduring lulls in the rain, but I made no census. By late PM, the cold fronthad blown through and by midnight the sky was bespeckled with stars.

The 25th of September dawned brilliantly clear and cool (below 60F).Clouds built up to a partly cloudy condition by 2PM, at which time thetemperature was approximately 61 degrees F. Between 2:35 and 2:45 PM, Icounted a total of 9 monarchs, only one tenth of the number that was therethe day before yesterday!

So, when did the monarchs leave? Not on the cold front per se whicharrived during the night of the 23rd. They could have left during the rainor lulls in the storm on the 24th, or they could have left this morning(the 25th)...Here is where we need patient observers. Someone to sit in their gardenfrom dawn to dusk for several days. Careful records are crucial to obtain.The reason we do not have them is because no one since Jenny Brooks inLawrence Kansas in 1907 has had the patience to do just this!!!! Any volunteers????

(Brooks, Jenny 1907. A night with the butterflies. Harpers Magazine 115:108-111.)

My butterfly instincts told me that the weather conditions today mightbring a "Last Hurrah" or flurry of monarch activity through Toronto. Thepast few days have been cool and cloudy with much needed rains, so therewas little monarch movement during these days. Scheduled for later in theday today were clouds and showers. As I drove along the 401 expresswayand down the Don Valley Parkway through the centre of the city to thelakeshore, monarchs soared high overhead in a south-westerly direction. Asure indication that this was going to be a good day.

I arrived at Tommy Thompson Park about 11:30 am and by 3:00 pm, had tagged290 monarchs, and run out of tags. I knew I had 160 tags left over fromlast year, and collected enough monarchs in envelopes to use those up aswell. What a beautiful sunny day - initially with very little wind, thena south-westerly wind, followed by easterly winds.

My net seemed sticky from the nectar and pollen from flowering goldenrod. The monarchs were also showing a high degree of interest in the the newlyopened New England Aster. I suspect the rains of the past few days havedone much to increase the amount of nectar in these plants.

Fall arrived in Oklahoma City, OK this a.m (9/24/02). We have had a steady stream of new arrivals here in the butterfly garden atthe Oklahoma City Zoo (Oklahoma City, OK) since 9/24/01. Below are thenumbers we have tagged since that date. We are recapturing many individualsthat were tagged early in the month here at the zoo. One individualcollected today was tagged here on 9/8/01. We are also still seeing mating,egg laying and found 6 larva on 9/24/01.

Temp is in the low50's, sky cloudy and a strong north wind. I just finished scouting regularroosting spots near the Oklahoma City Zoo's butterfly garden this a.m. Weare seeing an influx of monarchs as compared to last week. I found 4 smallclusters of about 20, plus several loaners roosting in large hackberry andelms roughly 20 yards to the north of the garden. Upon returning to theoffice I scanned the sky and observed 7 high flyers screaming past on thestrong north winds.
