We were at an outing where there were a lot of trees.  We saw Monarchs flying around all afternoon.
5 Monarchs were nectaring on the butterfly bush in front of our school. This is the largest number anyone has seen at one time. The weather that day was dry and sunny.

While playing soccer with friends, we spotted numerous Monarchs arriving from the North and gathering in a tree on the golf course behind our home.  The wind was out of the North and the termperature was cool all day.

Experienced a major push of monarchs over the weekend. Clusters of 30-70 and hundreds all around. All were gone by Sunday evening after a cold frontmoved through. Didn't see a single monarch fromSunday evening until this afternoon. This evening hadslow but steady singles coming into cedar trees about6:30 (9/25/01).

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

Large number (1000's) of monarchs arrived in town this evening.There is also a cold front moving through. Have been seeing 20 or so monarchs in the yard feeding, etc. for the past twoweeks.

As of 29 September, monarchs are still in the 1,000's here in Winters, TX (60 miles south ofAbilene). I've only noticed a fewnectaring. Large clusters in trees all over town and in the surroundingfarming communities.

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

220 monarchs were sighted in south Abilene by Nick, a second grade student.  There have been many sightings all over the city.We had a cold front hit Abilene Sat. Sept. 22nd. Temperatures Monday, High 76 degrees and low was 46 degrees.  This is the peak of migration for our area, I believe.

Witnessed monarchs as driving on 161st East Avenue in East Tulsa, near 31st Street.  Saw one about every 2 seconds as driving.  Probobly have seen 100 total.  Beautiful sight!  Especially uplifting on these most unusual days!

We went on a short drive around this noon and kept seeing many monarchs. So we went back home and my Mom sat in our backyard and watched dozens of monarchs fly overhead. She counted them all and came up with 105 monarchs in about 1 hour and 10 minutes. I was with her and it was fascinating. The monarchs went in waves, sometimes the rate being at least 3 a minute and other times 1 a minute. The wind was great and almost every monarch was heading west or slightly southwest. Almost all were about treetop level, flying without stopping to nectar. The air space we were viewing was about 3 acres or so. All appeared to be in good condition, although I couldn't see very well since they were up so high.
We saw 40 monarchs in 20 minutes today (9/26)at 10:30 am.  It was 63 degrees and calm and clear.  This afternoon we saw 73 in 20 minutes!!

While on the school playground at Oologah Elementary School, Oologah, Oklahoma, Mrs. Helvick's first grade class counted 106 monarch butterflies flying south on Wednesday afternoon from 12:10 - 1:00 p.m.
Approximately 200 Monarchs were sighted just west of Youngsville in the small town of Pittsfield.  They were seen in a group over a field of golden rod and milk weed.

The migration seems to have arrived!  I saw at least 24 adults nectaring in a patch of Liatris mucronata in a native prairie, one resting on a tree trunk and six flying.  I also still have one larva on Asclepias curavassica in our butterfly garden.

Count of monarchs in my backyard went from 7 last week to 23 this week; after the cold front and storm came through, count is down to 3...safe journey, good friends!Glad there were many more this year than last!

The monarchs are really arriving!  Today I found 68 adults nectaring in several colonies of Liatris mucronata and saw 7 additional flying.  It is interesting to me how few I see flying compared to the number I find on good nectar plants.

One of our students has a grandmother who lives in Grayslake, Illinois, and she told him that she saw about 30 monarchs in her garden on Saturday. Our class thinks the butterflies were there for the nectar. Wesley thinks his grandma plants specific flowers to attract butterflies.
A student oberseved about 100 monarchs roosting in trees near his home.
About 400-500 sighted.

Hundreds and hundreds of Monarchs still floating, fluttering, moving south through northwestern Vermont.  In an abandoned pasture now overgrown with flowering goldenrod and wild asters and with podded milkweed, I watched them feed.  As the sun fell in the west and the temperature began to plummet, they sought out roosting trees in a woodland at the edge of the field.  Each one seemed to plaster itself to its own tree leaf.  I had never observed this before, and was awestruck.

Apparently everything started up here in Texas as of Tuesday the 25th. An observer in El Dorado reports 200-300/night in the pecan grove as of 9/25 and every night every since then (as of 9/28/01). This is pretty far south. El Dorado is about 40 mile south of San Angelo, so almost the latitude of Austin.

For the first time I have monarch migrating over my house!  I live on a mountain in the southwest edge of Henderson County, North Carolina near the South Carolina border. For three days the monarchs have been flying over our house, sometimes so close my husband and I could have touched them; others so high  in air currents, they were gliding without flapping.  This is a truly a miraculous sight - these tiny little navigators with so much intent to fly to Mexico.  It has strengthened my soul after the bombings in New York. (Writing 9/24/01, pm)

This week the weather has been cool (70's and 80's during the day and 50's at night). Each day at recess we have seen a stream of Monarchs flying over the school. Our recess lasts only 20 minutes and takes place at noon. We count about 15 each day (writing 9/28/01).

Ms Moon's class, Pickens Elementary

Students in all of our towns are reporting seeing several butterflies in their yard-or moving in a southerly direction.  The cooler winds seem to have indicated--it is time to move south. One student reported seeing several on a wall in her yard in the a.m. They were gone when she returned from schoool.

I was outside much of Sunday 23 September and saw a steady supply of monarchs heading south on the 20 mph N NW winds blowing down the Canadian River by Norman, OK. Monarchs were coming through on an average very roughly of about one every two minutes at 4 pm.I'd be curious if that sounds like the main population coming through or just the beginning.

Reported by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife

We saw our first monarchs (only 2) on 9/10.

But our first large influx was on 9/24. On Tuesday (9/24) evening, we watched monarchs coming in from the west and from the north. The ones from the west were roosting in my neighbors' denuded ash tree in his front yard. The majority of the ones from the north were roosting in a fruitless mulberry tree in his backyard. From 5:55 p.m. - 6:45 p.m. we counted 397 in the front yard, and then from 6:50 p.m. - 7:10 p.m. we counted 269 in the back yard. It was as if they were using our house as a dividing line for determining whether they would roost in the front yard or the back. I'm certain that there were many more than the ones that we've counted because they are also roosting in at least three pecan trees at the back of his yard.

On Wednesday (9/25) at 7:00 p.m.-7:20 p.m., we counted 253 roosting on a fruitless mulberry tree. They had already come in and were hidden by the shifting shadows. And we don't

We observed 72 butterflies from 10:30 am -10:50 am!! It was a calm, cool day.

At 10:30 am yesterday morning (9/26) we saw 40 monarchs in 20 minutes. In the afternoon we saw 73 in 20 minutes!! It was 63 degrees and calm and clear.

Last friday September 21,2001, I counted a cluster of 10 monarchs near our school. As I drove home I counted thirteen more along the roads. This is the most I ever ever seen at one time! I have also seen two monarchs on September 27,2001. (I'll keep looking up.)

Today our 7th and 8th graders went outside around 2:45 to enjoy the mild weather and kick around the soccer ball.  While outside, we saw 9 Monarchs over a 30 minute period of time.  They were flying alone and heading directly south.  We are finishing up our symbolic migration, so we were excited to see the real thing.
They have been arriving a few at a time for the last week.  Yesterday Thursday 9/27/01 there were A LOT, more still today.  Every where I look I see Monarchs.  Mountainburg AR  72946
Sighted 50+ Monarchs at dusk near the RiverBend Golf area by the Washita River on elm and cottonwood trees.

75 Monarchs were seen over a period of approximately 75 minutes (10:00 a.m. to 11:15 a.m.)while my students and I were working on tree identification in front of the high school.  The monarchs were flying due south from the University of Arkansas and over our building, which is lower in elevation than the U. of A. campus. One monarch even decided to land on one of my student's shoulder and take a short rest.
I saw about 25 Monarch butterflies throughout the afternoon flying south!  Beautiful weather 84 and sunny.
As I was driving between 4:00pm and 4:10pm, I saw 17 butterflies flying in a southerly direction.  It was a beautiful, sunny day.
52 monarchs counted in one hour traveling south southwest, 68 degrees, clear skys, light breeze

The first cold front passed through Houston on 9/23.  Today I counted 17 monarchs passing one point in 30 minutes (12:30 - 1 p.m.).  They were all flying south and southwest, from 6 to 200 feet elevation.  The weather was partly cloudy, 84 degrees F, winds northerly @ 10-15 mph.  I hope we see a lot this year!
17 miles west of San Angelo,Tx, 3 miles off the ranch road. Monarchs started gathering on Sept. 25th and peaked on the 28th. There were hundreds and hundreds hanging from our live oak trees.

Tuesday, September 18, was our largest Monarch sighting to date.  Collectively our class observed 61 Monarch butterflies in the hour after they got home from school. Most of the Monarchs were seen nectaring in backyard gardens, though some children spotted them flying among the trees.  We are hoping to see the butterflies flying more purposefully in the next few weeks.

For the past two weeks, Monarch's have been arriving daily to our 5 acres. The last 3 seasons, the first ones didn't appear until October. Today, Sept 30 - There were 18 on a 10'x 8' section of Lantana montevidensis. All appear to be in good condition, bright colors, with no apparent torn wings. Other nectar sources that they are gathering on are Lantana radiation, Salvia leucantha, and Salvia uliginosa. At around 1:00p.m. I observed a pair coupled, and resting on a Grevillea. This evening, just after sunset, they were still there and coupled. It is hard to get a total count, but at least 75 to 100 were flying around today.

For the past five days our butterfly bushes have been covered with Monarchs. From past experience this appears to be the peak of the migration in this area. We're located 20 miles north of Greenville SC on Glassy Mountain.

An impressive monarch migration was reported by James Coman to the Carolina butterfly listserve on Monday, September 17th:
Between 6,000 and 10,000 monarchs were observed passing in several hours at Bullhead Mountain in Alleghany Coounty, North Carolina.

9/28  I drove south from Mountainburg on Hwy 71 about 11 miles at 1 p.m..  I saw about 30 Monarchs flying southish. Unfortunately, I hit several Monarchs as did a car in front of me.  9/29 I drove the same route at about 11:30 a.m.and saw only 3 Monarchs.  It is long sleeve weather today but wasn't yesterday. Hope this helps. Will look again tomorrow.

We've been seeing monarchs here for about 2-3 weeks, with the largest numbers so far last week and this week. The cold front that came in last week did bring many more individuals than I had been seeing.  One day last week I saw over 40 on the butterfly bushes and Lantana below my office in the Botanical Garden.  It may be we're close to peak -- I'll keep watching!

We don't see a great wave of monarchs here.  In the last three weeks, we have seen between 0 and 4 during 20 minutes outside in the afternoon.  However, on Sept. 12, 2001, a Saturday when we weren't at school, many students and I saw lots of monarchs.  Some students saw clumps of monarchs.  So we think that is our peak day.  We have not seen so many since.
We saw one monarch during our morning recess.  We generally never see more than one at a time and one or two during a week.  We feel amazed that some classes would see 100 or more at a time!

While driving along Highway 227 from Sonora to San Angelo (67 miles) I began to count the numerous monarchs crossing my path.  I was up to 68 when about 15 south miles of San Angelo we encountered a virtual storm of butterflies.  They were coming so fast and furious, I couldn't count them all.  I estimated 200 or 300.  The encounter lasted about 2 miles and then the numbers thinned down again.  I continued to observe sporatic numbers for the rest of the day, all the way to Abilene and then along Interstate 20 back to Midland.

They're Here!Driving in town from 12:45 p.m. until around 2:45 p.m. spotted approximately 1 every 5 minutes, flying in a definite westerly direction, straight down streets or crossing avenues, (our town is laid out in a traditional avenue north/south, streets east/west)  Mostly about 10 to 20 feet in height, doing the Monarch bob.  Weather is beautifully mild and sunny, cool enough for a sweatshirt and shorts.  Expect to see plenty more tomorrow.

On the south shore of Lake Ponthcartrain monarchs are collecting on wildflowers as they complete their crossing of the lake. One lone goldenrod plant had a dozen monarchs on it. At least one thousand "shiny new" monarchs are feeding in a strip of wildflowers roughly three blocks long and thirty feet wide. Every monarch seen by me today, through binoculars, was virtually perfect and new looking. This same patch of wildflowers is feeding thousands of buckeye butterflies along with the monarchs.

One of my 4th grade students, Ashley, reports sighting approximately 25 monarchs in her Dallas backyard early Saturday morning.  Interestingly, 2 years ago, Ashley and her family had hundreds of monarchs choose a tree in their backyard as an overnight resting spot.  Last year, they saw no monarchs in the yard.

Tuesday I began seeing monarchs steadily crossing Lake Lewisville at theHickory Creek Branch. From the horse trailer parking area near Pilot KnollPark on the southwestern side of the lake, I observed a steady stream ofhigh flying monarchs coming out of the north, crossing Hickory Creek andheading south. The monarchs were flying with a marked intent and I countedone per minute over the course of an hour and a half at one location. Theywere on the wind which was out of the north and higher than I expected tosee them traveling, taking advantage of the wind currents I suppose.

Reported for Karen Mangum by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife

I think the Monarchs are peaking in NorthDallas. Today we saw 31 in less then 2 hours. They were all headed duesouth, most from 30 to 50 feet. Wind was about 5 miles an hour on theground. All passed over except for 3, which came down to feed at our redrose bush. None stayed long. We watched from 10:30-11:30, 1:30-2:00, andfrom 5:00 to 5:15. Temperature was about 75 degrees. Last week we saw only3 or 4 per day.

Reported for Nancy King by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife

We counted monarchs traveling over us on the Devils River on Saturday afternoon. We counted 100 monarchs in 5 minutes. This was at a locationabout 15 miles downstream from Dolan.

On September, 29th: Monarchs are streaming into Dolan Falls. I tagged 50 this morning (9/29/01). Many ofthem were flying south early this morning, using the river as a corridor.

Dolan Falls Preserve
The Nature Conservancy of Texas

Reported for Bea Harrison by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife

A steady stream of monarchs were migrating south across the 24 mile bridge connecting the north and south shores of Lake Pontchartrain here in the greater New Orleans area of Louisiana (Causeway Bridge). According to Joel Lyons, his colleague counted 92 monarchs in the half hour trip from Mandeville to Metairie. Later he tallied 142 monarchs in just 15 minutes:

"During the half hour trip south from our Mandeville office to Metairie, Melanie totted up 92 Monarchs: all sizes ... some in a hurry ... groups of two or three doing that aerial engagement ballet thing they do ... some basking on bridge rails. She arrived at our south shore office with that report and we began to work on deadline briefs for the Office of Hearings and Appeals. I decided to deliver them myself which would give me an excuse to motor up to the south end of the Causeway Bridge and check out the action. I gave myself 15 minutes and tallied 142 Monarchs within that time frame. As I
Thousands of Monarchs covering trees in a cow pasture east of Pawnee, Oklahoma tonight Saturday, September 29, 2001.

I observed 14 monarchs in about 10 minutes, while driving (35mph) alongremote grassland near Rhome, Texas 25 miles N-NW of Fort Worth, TX.  It wasaround noon Sept 27th. 80 degree F,clear sky,  Wind was northerly at approx3-5 knots, they were headed south and southwest travelling individually 10-20 feet over the ground.  Saw an additional 10 monarchs in the next 30 minuteswhile headed toward Ft Worth area.  Driving into Louisisana today, on I-20, saw only one or two.

Today, 2 October 2001 we made the following observations in our Buddleiamonitoring garden at Sweet Briar College, Sweet briar VA.

The monarch butterfly migration is at its peak. We justcounted more than 150 monarchs at one Buddleia patch. This may be the lastpulse of the season, or it may be followed by more over the next two weeks.
We spotted 9 or 10 monarchs on the butterfly bushes outside our classroom.  Are these migrating monarchs or will they overwinter here?

Peak Monarch migration seems to have just passed us here in Northern Virginia. Last week my students were sighting 8-10 at a time Monarchs feeding on our butterfly bush. This week we have only 1 Monarch. Even our classroom nursery has slowed. We tagged and released 6 Monarchs last week. We have several chrysali still to emerge.(Writing 10/02/01)
We are seeing the peak of the migration of Monarchs here.  They are about 4 inches in wing span.  It is a beautiful, clear day with 74º F and a very mild wind.   We counted 20 Monarchs in an hour.
The principal at our school reported seeing about 20 Monarchs in their garden Sunday.  Two girls in our school reported seeing about 30 Monarch in the trees around their house this weekend.

We have seen numerous monarchs the past two weeks in our butterfly garden at Norton Elementary in Snellville, GA.  Three years ago all we found was old wings.  We planted an abundance of milkweed this spring and it has made all of the difference.  I think the monarchs we are seeing are the last generation because they have fresh wings and very bright colors.  The children chase them feverishly on the playground as they zoom south west towards Alabama.  I brought several larva into the classroom for observation.  One emerged this morning and we are observing her (it is a female) and then will tag her and release her tomorrow.  We have named her "Miss Liberty."  The students love the name and so do I!

Although I was not priviliged to see the sights I have had 2 different people tell me of sighting hundreds of Monarchs.  One report was from the Bayou Meto(72076 Zip Code)area near North Little Rock.  The friends live on a hilltop and spotted hundreds of Monarchs at a time in the tree tops resting.  They said one group would move out and another group would come in.  Another person reported seeing large groups of Monarchs on Mt. Magazine, which is near Paris, Arkansas(72855 Zip).  This mountain is the highest peak in Arkansas(elevation 2,753).

Observed a large number of monarch butterflies in the trees on our ranch, while moving tractors to drill wheat. About 4 trees were full of butterflies. I saw them just before sunset. Looked at a 10 inch section of a branch and counted 7 butterflies. They were gorgeous.

After having seen this, I wished I could remember where I had seen the website about their journey north. I was thrilled just now when I found it again, and will share it with my students immediately. They will be interested in following this project via your website.

I was at my Baseball game in the dugout, when a monarch butterfly flew over the Baseball field. I was so exited I could hardly move. Then I noticed my mom and I ran over to her and I told her I had seen a monarch butterfly,Then she said "wow". Then I went back into the dugout.

I spotted 11 monarchs while driving around the peninsula for about a total of 75 minutes between 1 pm and 4 pm.  They were all flying generally to the south, not stopping and looked quite colorful and pristine.  The day was a sunny, balmy 75 degrees after a week of chilly weather and a chilly 55 degrees the night before.  Winds were very calm. I've not seen a single Monarch in this area before except those visiting in my own and in Grafton Bethel's butterfly garden, so this was quite remarkable.  My son even spotted a Monarch crossing the athletic fields during his PE class that day.

Monarchs in large numbers seen near Old Fort Elementary:Beginning 9/22 when we sighted 156 over a 5 hour period, another 200 were sighted on 9/23 through 9/24! Colder weather after then slowed the migration to 1-3 sightings a day.

Both Saturday and Suday we watched with delight as monarch after monarch came to our milkweed.  We drove across LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN toward the east and couldn't even count the number of monarchs we encountered. This is the most fabulous fall encounter that we can remember and we have been watching for years

Yesterday (10/01/01) I drove from Big Bend National Park to Houston. US 90 from Sanderson to Del Rio was thick with monarchs heading south. My drive was before noon. I counted 3 a minute around 9:00 a.m. and up to 12 a minute at noon around Del Rio.
Reported for Adams Clark by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife
Traveling the 23 miles from Abilene to Albany, Texas on Hwy.351, I observed 164 Monarchs "on the wing", crossing the road, headed south!

Our 5th and 6th grade multiage class has been observing monarchs for the past two weeks and observed the largest numbers during the period of 9/22-9/25 (22.  Our observations this week have been single flying butterflies, our theories are that they are stragglers or are migrating from a more distant location (1).  We are located in a large town, so we may not have as many food sources as other locations.

Second wave of monarchs is here!  Once again, the three buddleias are packed, with numbers in the teens on each! It's great that there are so many more in evidence this year than last.  They are enjoying the nectar and warm sunshine.

Yesterday, October 3rd, 2001 I saw the first monarch butterfly. It was the only one and today I did not see another one so it really was the first one to arrive to Monterrey Nuevo Leon!Gabriela

And from Maria Teresa Tamez on October 8th.

One of my dauther's friend said that they are monarch butterflies stopping in her house and I saw a monarch butterfly and another friend of my daugher saw another one!! And some monarch butterflies are in my house!! I will still send you more reports in other cases.(teretamez@hotmail.com)

At 1:00 - 1:30 p.m. today, we were having a Monarch presentation, tagging and release at Oak Park Magnet School, and as I was explaining the migration to the children and teachers and telling them how to look for the migrating Monarchs in our midst with this wonderful year we are having, I spotted one doing exactly as predicted, heading from east to west at about 10 feet off the ground, then up and over the school building.  Then continuing with my talk, I noticed several more, and as I started to open our screen cage to lift our Monarchs out to pass out for release, a teacher came up and said she had just spotted at least twenty behind me, which was south of our Pavilion, as I was talking to the children!  We were outside for at least 1 1/2 hours and may have seen a total of 30 without looking out all the time.  We released about 20 tagged, but mostly bred Monarchs, who are the parentage for the instars we are developing in the classrooms for a larger release later in the month.  I wi

Tuesday, when I arrived at school there were Monarchs everywhere.  There were about 30 resting on the grass outside my window and more in the air.  They fluttered around a tree that is flowering across the street.  As I walked up the breeze way, no matter in which direction I turned my head, there were 3 to 5 monarchs fluttering around.  Some had very worn wings with little color left but others were rich in color with little sign of wear.It is not unusual to see one or two fluttering by at a time but never this many.  Our school is located in Kenner, a suburb of New Orleans.  We are about one mile south of Lake Ponchartrain and three miles east of another lake and swamps.   A man at church told me Sunday that when he crossed Lake Ponchartrain on Saturday, the monarchs were thick.   Some have been nectaring but others are laying eggs on our exhausted milkweed. I have four chrysalis' about to emerge to add to the flight. This has been truly the thickest journey south that I can

We have not noticed a large increse in the number of monarchs at school. However, our secretary said her daughter ran into a huge amount on Monday, October 1 while driving across the Causeway Bridge over Lake Pontchartrain. The Lake is north of New Orleans. So maybe the monarchs flew north of New Orleans.
The monarchs started showing up in mass late this afternoon in groups of 5 to 10 and then in streams. The main mass should begin to show tomorrow.
While doing a bit of birding today I saw well over 100 monarchs. Most were in small groups of 5 about 10 yards or so apart. Had about 5 in my yard today.

At 4:00 pm I was photographing the New Haven Lighthouse and I observed a large migration of Monarch Butterflies. What a magnificent sight. I used my many years of birding to estimate at least 400 Monarchs resting on the leaves and branches of Chestnut and large leaf linden trees. They primarily rested in groupings of about 100-200 on the eastern quadrant of the trees about 20 -40 feet up.

Yesterday at approximately 3:30pm monarchs began to filter in to our country area, and by dusk, we had approximately 3 to 4 thousand that had began to hang in one of our large mesquites and fruitless mulberries! We were able to tag about 200 last night, and a 100 more this morning! Could have tagged many more but never expected so many, and ran out of tags! Big mistake, but a wonderful, and beautiful experience this year, compared to years before! Have noticed that all of these monarchs are huge, again compared to years before! Also they are making good use of the tropical milkweed that we have planted, using it as both a nectar source, and a host plant, yes even this late in the season ,still laying eggs! Also feeding on several other nectar sources we had planted on their behalf! Seems to be a "great year"!!!!!!!!!!!!! We are located approximately 5 miles n.e .of Abilene, TX in Hamby, Texas.

All of the 75 5th graders at Timothy Road Elementary School have been watching for Monarchs at school and at home.  This is the 1st time we have participated in the symbolic Monarch migration, and everyone is very excited about the project.  We finished making our paper butterflies and they are in the mail.  During the week of Sept.25-October 4th, the students observed a total of 236 Monarchs at school during recess or the after school program, either on the playground or in our butterfly courtyard.

Our monarch sightings went off our classroom graph! The total number of monarchs observed Wednesday was 112.  Children reported seeing them in groups of 2,s, 5's, and small clusters.  Few children saw single monarchs. Some were reported to be nectaring, others were flying overhead. There are still many flowers in bloom, as the weather has been warm and there has been no frost.

10:30 am.  Sunny, slight southerly breeze, temp in  the 70s.  Saw many dozens of monarchs on a 3 mile drive through Tulsa.  They were single, pairs and trios, many spiraling upwards together over parking lots.

The leading elements of the Monarch migration are now arriving by thehundreds at the Foundation. This should change shortly to a Monarchpopulation of 10's of thousands. Those persons wishing to tag or justobserve the butterflies should begin making plans to visit the LehmannResearch Foundation . Reservations are required in advance and visitingwill be limited so as not to disturb the resting Monarchs.

The migration hit this area big time today. I had to make a trip to San Antonio today, My grandsons (Erikk, Peter, and Robert) and I made the following counts enroute:

276 Monarchs in 30 minutes (10:00 a.m. to 10:30 a.m., from Tarpley to Bandera)
446 Monarchs in 42 minutes (10:30 a.m. to 11:12 a.m., from Bandera to San Antonio.)

Reported for Ronald Hood by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.

I was just outside (4:00 pm 5 October)looked up and saw monarchseverywhere. There are 30 to 50 visible at any one time over the city rightnow. A strong front blew in today right at noon and the wind switched atthat time. I didn't see anything flying at 1:40 (a hard rain was going) butthe rain has ended for the moment and the monarchs are all scudding high andfast. For all of you south points south - here they come.

Reported for Forrest Mitchell by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.

We're having another "river of monarchs" flow through Eagle Pass today continuously since 9:00 a. m. I just picked one small strip of visible sky out the window looking northeast and counted everything that crossed it in one minute. There were 93. I just got out the calculator and did the multiplication on that, and it comes to 5580 an hour. And that's just the narrow strip across the width of my yard--some 150'. Small breeze quartering out of the SE at 10-12 mph. Temps 93.8F. Scatteredclouds, but hot and sunny.

The front came through yesterday (10/5/01) about 7:30 pm and created a few scattered sprinkles. No monarchs. Temps went to 56.1F, then up to 91 thisafternoon. Breezes very light from the north. All day the 6th: no monarchs.

Then at sunset they began tumbling down out of the skies from the north andclustering in the same trees they have for the last 22 years that I knowabout. I don't have a count yet, will wait till about 11 p.m. to check andbegin tagging.This makes this fall arrival 6 days earlier than previous years.

People around Eagle Pass are reporting butterflies yesterday afternoon at 2 aminute. Trees behind the offices for the Rio Bravo Nature Center had twoareas of clustering last night when I counted. One consisted of about 200 individuals andthe other area, more spread out, had about 10 clusters. One of these Inetted and caught 37 in a single net sweep. Scattered and unclustered I'destimate another 200 or so for a minimum 800 in a 30 yard area.

Reported for Carol Cullar Rio Bravo Nature Center by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.

A friend reported seeing rather large numbers of monarchs in the Biloxi, MS area on October 1 and 2. He was on the 2nd floor of a building overlooking the bay and; he said they were moving by frequently and mostly at the 2nd story level on both days.

St. Marks National Wildlife Refuge Annual Census

Saturday at St. Marks was a stupendously super day! Congratulations to the crew of volunteers that morning: 1,197 monarchs were counted! That one day almost equaled the total number counted in the 1999 season (1,463). The cold front that sweep through the area a couple of days earlier certainly pulled a pack of monarchs along with it.

For perspective, look at this fall's other daily counts:

(Counts begin before dawn and last 1 to 2 hours. We count roosting monarchs predawn, over a one to one and a halfhour period across two levees covering about a quarterof a mile each. our survey covers the two levees east andwest of the St. Marks lighthouse every Wed and Sat through the migrationperiod, which runs from early Oct to almost Thanksgiving. The count beginsbefore dawn (e.g., 6:30) and generally runs a hour or more depending on thenumber of monarchs we find clustered in the trees and bushes. We count themonarchs in each tree or bush, then capture as many as we can, put thecaptured monarchs in mesh cages or in glassine envelopes to place in a cooler,and, after all else is done, tag and release them. If we have a large numberof monarchs, we'll take 30 males and 30 females back to the office where weassess their condition, and record their wet weight and wing length. Thissame procedure has been in place since 1988, except for a five year hiatus inthe mid-1990s.)

October 3rd
The first ripple of migrating monarchs reached the St. MarksNational Wildlife Refuge. Wednesday we counted 30 monarchs in aone-hour period on the two levees leading out from the lighthouse. Wecaught and tagged all we could, and upon release some headed southwestout over the Gulf of Mexico. We began our fall surveying a week ago,but yesterday was the first day we saw monarchs roosting in the trees(at 6:00 a.m.). There have been monarchs in inland areas through mostof the summer and early fall, but this is the first time we've hadevidence that they've roosted overnight in the trees on these twolevees. The two levees, along with coastal islands along the Gulf,generally serve as overnight staging (roosting) areas for migratingmonarchs.

I just wanted to let you know that on Tuesday, October 2, I saw large numbers of Monarchs (between 100 - 200)flying around in the saltmarsh and the small trees at Brazoria National Wildlife Refuge in Brazoria County.

Reported for David Heinicke by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife. "I believe this is the largest report of Monarchs from along the Texas coast," said Mike.

We currently have monarchs passing through our location just west of Belton. Wehave thousands of 'Frost' plants that they are gathering on. They arrived enmasse about three or four days ago...(estimating 10/1/01)

Reported for Joe Dorn by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.

This last weekend my son & I were bow hunting 8 miles south of San Angelo off of Highway 277. We noticed hundreds upon hundreds Monarchbutterflies migrating to the south.....What a sight !!

Reported for Darrell Farmer by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.

I live in Graham,Texas and for over 10 years the Monarch butterflies have been coming to our back yard. They arrived in large numbers Wednesday and Thursdayof this week--hundreds, maybe thousands on our pecan and oak trees and our Crepe Myrtles. I don't know why we are so blessed with them, but I wanted to let someone know they are definitely on their way south in the largest numbers wehave had in several years.The milk weed was particularlyprevelant this year. There are a few other places in townwhere they stay as well, but I have been told we have thelargest numbers. We are due a cold front tomorrow, and theywill probably leave with it--that is what usually happens.My husband and I look forward to their short stay with useach year and wanted to share our good fortune with someone.Thank you for all you do for the natural habitat of thisstate!

Reported for Diane Cody by Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.

First witnessed hundreds of Monarchs on the Outer Banks of North Carolina. I assume that this is the same migration mentioned by the observers in Chincoteague, VA on the Eastern Shore. I did not perform an exact count per hour; however, I feel comfortable stating that the rate had to be at least several hundred per hour. There had been a strong storm with heavy northeast winds for the previous two days but this day there was clear skies and temperatures in the 70's.The Monarchs were feeding on sorrel bush.  Some people may call this cottonwood bush.

We are a 2nd grade group of 21 "Junior Scientists" at Allen Academy.  We have sighted 46 monarchs around our school campus and in our yards near our homes.  They seem to be very strong in their flight.  We are going to begin daily visits to our school's butterfly garden to count the numbers of monarchs in the coming days and weeks.

Saturday--drove 12 miles (15 minutes), counted 63 monarchs.
Sunday--drove 25 miles (round trip, about 20 min each way), counted 103 monarchs.
All were headed in a very general south and westerly direction--after a fashion. Haven't seen many since, maybe 1 a day as I'm out picking up the boys from school. Saw one around 8am this morning--trying its hardest to gain some altitude on a very soggy morning. This has been an incredibly exciting watch.(Writing 10/12/01)

Last night about sundown my wife and daughter saw hundreds of Monarchs flying overhead.  The night was foggy; this afternoon around 4 pm the sun came out and we saw a number of them in our back yard drying their wings.
Here they come!  A storm blew through this morning.  As it cleared, around noon time, a steady stream of Monarchs began to flit their way through, headed due south.

When I came out of the local grocery store, I saw 7 Monarchs flying south in the space of about two minutes.  On the way home, kept seeing Monarchs. I stopped for gas and saw more.  In 15 mintues time, I saw 16 Monarchs today.  My wife and daughter went to the Ft. Worth Botanical Gardens today and tagged 8 Monarchs and saw many more.

We have seen several hundred Monarch's in the air today. We saw the first ones in Waxahachie this morning.  This afternoon we traveled from Waxahachie, Tx. down to Corsicana, Tx. and saw them on I-45 almost all the way down.

We were driving into Austin and the first 1/2 mile down the road my children and I counted 35 Monarchs.  It was about 11:35 am, there was a nice breeze, and the temp. was 78 degrees.  Between our home and Austin we counted an addition 60 Monarchs flying over the highway.  We were so excited to have seen that many flying south.

At 6 p.m. CST on Sunday, 10-14-01, my husband and I observed several dozen monarch butterflies flying across our backyard, coming from the North.  They were heading South, flying from tree to tree (oak and pecan trees).

Counted approx. 350 per minute for fifteen minutes in a line of sight event between 6:45 and 7:00 pm in front of the auditorium at my school just east of Eagle Pass.  Moving NNE to SSW from 5 ft to out of sight overhead.  Conditions were ideal, clear and calm with just a slight drift of wind from the north.  They were flying before I got to the school, and I left them flying to attend a play.  I had noticed the flight as I drove to the school approximately two miles from the school.  The width of the flight was large.
school: Cc winn campus/eagle pass high school

comments: Approximately 50 Monarchs roosting in hackberrys & mesquites at my home north of Quemado (78877).  Out of tags.
school: Cc winn campus/eagle pass high school

comments: This is our first year of observing monarchs so we were unsure of the peak as it went through.  We took notes and tagged for Monarch Watch.  Sept 5 and Sept 8 were days of the highest concentrations of monarchs.  After the weekend of the 8th we saw very few around.  Both the 5th and the 8th the weather was warm with light winds.  The butterflies were located in a wooded lot and in a restored prairie.  They clustered in twos and threes.  They were mainly on thistle in the prairie and in the pines in the wooded lot.  We did not observe roosting areas.

On Sunday morning, October 14, starting at about 9:30 A.M. , I observed hundreds of Monarchs flying south in groups of 20-30 butterflies. This continued until about 5:30 PM. It was a beautiful sight,reminding us of the beauty of God's world.

I saw six monarch butterflies. They were in my front yard going south. They were very interesting to watch because the wind was picking up.  Note:  Located where we are on Lake Ontario, we rarely see large migration groups so for us 6 is a big number!  It has been fairly warm, but today it is only 6 degrees Celsius and rain is expected so perhaps we have seen the last of the monarchs for this year.Grade 5

We have an isolated oak grove that is in a valley on the family farm. Historically, the second weekend in October is the peak for us (approx. 50 miles NW of Austin). This year we had our peak the first weekend of October. The grove is about the size of a football field, in years past we've tried to count and I would guess around 5,000 monarchs have roosted on good nights. This year it seems like the numbers are down, I would say probably 1500 to 2000 the first weekend, and around 1000 the second weekend. The second weekend was also 5-10 degrees cooler than the first weekend this year. Big cold front is supposed to push through Monday the 15th. I will send another report if I see anything interesting the third weekend. Thanks.

This is the first day that more than the usual oversummering monarchs have appeared along the mid coast.  In Calhoun County six monarchs (one depositing eggs on wild milkweed) were reported near Indianola on the southwest end of Matagorda Bay, one in Port Lavaca depositing eggs in our backyard, and another late in the afternoon "cruising" near the edge of Lavaca Bay at Point Comfort.  In northeast DeWitt County at least two dozen monarchs made an appearance in the afternoon.  An eighth grader and her mother chased many but managed to net only two.  They reported the monarchs were entering the pasture generally from the north and then disappearing to the south.  In Victoria County, eighth graders reported seeing a few during the afternoon, the first that they could recall seeing any since last spring.  This could be the beginning of the migration along the Coastal Flyway.  Last year it was October 18 when the first monarchs began to appear in numbers per hour across Lavaca Bay flowing f

The 4th grade saw 972 monachs this week. It has been quite a week.  The kids are very excited.  This has been the peak.  There are  125 kids in the Discovery program from Habersham County who have been reporting Monarch sitings this fall.  Ms. Wight says she hasn't seen this many monarchs in one fall season in at least 10 years !

The Discovery kids have decided that the peak has happened.  We are all not seeing many monarchs.  There are  125 kids in the Discovery program from Habersham County who have been reporting Monarch sitings this fall.  Ms. Wight says she hasn't seen this many monarchs in one fall season in at least 10 years !

We don't see a great wave of monarchs here. We monitored the monarchs for about threeand a half weeks. We never saw any more than 4 in one day during a 20minute period. We saw 4 on several days.

But on Sept. 15, which was aSaturday, a cold front came through. I was outside for much of the day andsaw many, many monarchs, (probably 10 in a 20 minute period, but at adifferent time of day and different location) but I wasn't at school and Iwasn't able to get to school at the same time we usually watched formonarchs. So, I couldn't say we saw x amount during the same time at thesame place. The following Monday, I asked students if they had noticed moremonarchs than usual. Many reported seeing lots of monarchs too, and acouple of students said they saw clumps of them. The numbers really seemedto dwindle after that weekend. We don't get monarchs going through this area in great numbers, butit was neat to try and find the peak day. We had hoped to get data in number form by watching every day at thesame time in the school grounds.

On Sunday, Oct. 14th, we saw 131 monarchs in 55 minutes while we were eating lunch on an outside patio.  We also found two 5th instar caterpillars in a nearby field.  The adults were all flying south.  They were on the back side of a cold front that brought storms to our area Friday - Saturday.  Sunday was the first warm, sunny day after the front.  Lisa, Brendan and Maddie

During a 20-minute period, starting at about 10:15 this morning, we saw between 50 to 60 monarchs flapping their wings or gliding on currents as they crossed over East Oltorf. They came one, two, three at a time. They were never together but spread out over a several feet.

My brother, Scott and I went on the dirt trail close to our home. We saw lots of little yellow butterflies. Then we went a little ways more and saw hundreds of Monarch butterflies on the ground and in the trees. It looked like an orange ans black sunset. It looked so cool!

Hoy fue un dia muy emocionante, a las 10 de la mañana fui a Monterrey a dar una platica sobre la mariposa Monarca en el Parque Chipinque. Al Salir de Saltillo empece a contar a las mariposas que cruzaban la carretera durante 43 Kilometros mi contador me indicaba 110 mariposas, de ahi en adelante, en los siguientes 30 Kilometros, mi contador me indico 330 mariposas. Pero la sorpresa fue al llegar a Santa Catarina, N.L. habia ciento y cientos volando bajo, a 10 metros del suelo. Igual numero de mariposas observe en San Pedro Garza Garcia hasta llegar al parque. Ahi habia un buen numero. A las tres y media de la tarde que me regrese, el espectaculo de la migracion estaba en lo maximo eran miles y miles de mariposas, desde casi el nivel del suelo hasta que se perdian de vista en lo alto del cielo. Esto duro hasta la altura del campo de carreras de caballos. Esperaba al llegar a Saltillo ver buen numero y mi sorpresa fue observar unicamente tres mariposas en 15 minutos.

Las mariposas siguen pasando por Saltillo, se ven por docenas a ciertashoras del dia. Los dias han estado muy calientes (30-32 grados centigrados)y con vientos ligeros del norte o noroeste, lo que no nos ha permitido vergrandes racimos y para las 7:30 de la mañana ya estan volando.

Yesterday afternoon (10/13/01) I followed the Rio Grande River in South Texas in search of the monarch migration. Although I saw a few monarchs in Roma in Starr County, I moved upriver to Falcon State Park.At Falcon Lake, I found a steady stream of migrating monarchs passing overhead in large numbers, sometimes as many as 100 per minute. At dusk, I walked out into the brush and discovered hundreds of monarchs roosting in retama (paloverde) trees along the shore of the lake.

I counted about 20 Monarchs a minute flying almost due west this morning. Morning was clear and wind speed almost zero.  about noon the numbershave been reduced to about 10/minute now flying southwest.  First time Ihave seen so many Monarch in Hondo in two years
We were at the Cibolo Nature Center for an hour at noon today.  Saw about 80 monarchs per hour nectaring on Maximillian sunflower and flying on.

Monterrey, Nuevo Leon Monarchs moving southward in great numbers with pulses of dense clumps. Hundreds to perhaps thousands visible at any one time upward to the limit of unaided vision. An incredible sight, rivalling the bat flights from Texas caves. Sulphurs and Snouts moving southward with the Monarchs.

Santiago, Nuevo Leon Monarchs moving southward in large numbers at ground and canopy level but not high in the sky. Sulphurs and Snouts moving with the Monarchs but stopping flight before sunset. Monarch flight persisted long after the sun had gone down. (After the sun went down behind the mountains, I was floating on my back in the hotel swimming pool, looking up at monarchs passing some 5 to 20 feet overhead. They were illuminated by the sunset glow. I think they stopped flying when the last light went from the sky.)

10/17/01Date line Carrizo Springs in Dimmit CountyLehmann Research FoundationHigh Monarch migration continue to pass thru and linger at the Lehmann Research Fooundation. The Monarch Population continues to number in the 10's of thousands.From 10/12/01 thru 10/17/01. And currently looking good we have tag 300 Monarchs and had groups out here for research and some just to observe. website www.LRFonline.org

Just before sunset 10/16/01 monarchs flew to a juniper in our yard about 9 miles s/sw of Kerrville, TX, near Hwy 16S. As they prepared for an overnight stay, we watched in awe.  The morning of 10/17/01, we went out before full daylight so we wouldn't miss the flight south.  During their three-hour process of awakening, warming, exercising wings, and one-by-one flight, we stood enthralled as 75-100 Monarchs resumed their flight to Mexico. One had a damaged wing which looked as if something had bitten the tip of it off but it could, and did, fly.  A great experience!

10/19/01Dimmit County, TexasLehmann Research Foundation10/12/01 thru 10/19/01Monarchs continue to arrive and depart daily at the Lehmann Research Foundation. Numerous visitors marvel at the 10'S of thousands of butterflies that flutter throught out the forest. For more information go on web site www.LRFonline.org or phone 830 374-3373

I was playing with my kids in the University grounds a few minutes ago(Sunday 21 october), which sits on a small hill, (the famous historicalsite, Cerro de las Campanas) and my girl Jennifer said, "Hey, Daddy themonarchs have returned."  Sure enough, there they were, not a lot and theyheld close to the vegetation, and not like I have seen in heavy flightactivity when there are hundreds in the sky. Its a clear, almost windlessday, the same as yesterday after the cold front that came through eary lastweek.  I assume this is the first wave here, and in the next week there willbe more.  Looking out from my office here looking out over the Cerro, we didnot see any. (The Cerro deCampanas hillside, in the middle of Querétaro City, is the historic site wherethe ill fated emperor of Mexico, Maximiliano was executed and citizen rulewas "restored" to Mexico.If I have time, I'd like to see just where they pass in their flight in thenext week. I suspect that they keep to the higher altitudes and vegetationand do not fly through the desert areas. If I have time I'll check variousspots and try to take some kind of measurement (per minute in field ofview?). I have a class of 15 students in my Invertebrate Class and maybe wecan run a field class to do some counts.The locality here is N 20 degrees 35.372, 100 degrees 24.653'.

We are seeing them while traveling in our cars, at school, and near our homes.  Many dead Monarchs have been identified by the children.  We are checking our butterfly garden daily.

We've had good numbers of Monarchs moving southwest through Huntsville for the last few days. It has been fairly common to see 50 or more at a time strung out along some of the roads on the western side of I-45. I've heard several others commenting about it as well.(Writing 10/19/01)

A student said that there were a lot of monarchs in Real de Catorce,SLP this past Saturday.(Read about this former mining town, now a ghost town, not far from the Tropic of Cancer monument on Mexico Connect Web site.)

I saw two Monarchs mating in a large oak tree behind our school at 1:00 p.m. Friday 19th of October.  The weather was warm and sunny. We came outside to do the phenology measurement.Brittany KeyesMs. Key's 5th grade student
3:51 p.m. Monarch flying westsouthwest on Line Road off of Lower Myrick Road, southeast of Laurel, MS off of Hiway 15 South.

Driving southeast into Laurel around noon today, sightings regularly every 30 to 60 seconds.  Wind was out of the southeast and gusting slightly from the southwest, yet, the Monarchs were still heading into the wind, westsouthwest.  Good going.  Beautiful hot day, and everyone seemed intent on travel.  On to the school grounds and more sightings.  Again, all moving southwesterly.  The children are getting really good a telling the difference between Monarchs and Gulf Frits and others.  Lots of excitement all afternoon as everyone continued to spot them until around 3:00 p.m.
We saw 156 monarchs in 20 minutes!!  What a fabulous sight.  It was 65 degrees and a clear, sunny day.

The Causeway Bridge connecting Mandeville with Metairie, Louisiana over Lake Pontchartrain is a significant Monarch migration route.  This afternoon I counted 54 determined Monarchs accompanying me on the 24 mile trip south overthe choppy water.  This count is down from last friday (124) on the same route.

The orange and black parade!  November 16, 2001 ... 24 mile Causeway, Lake Pontchartrain, Bridge ... South from Mandevilleto Metairie, Louisiana ... sunny ... mid 70's:  58 monarchscounted spread out over the entire span.  A week ago over thisbridge:  125 counted, almost all over the first eight miles around two p.m. Guessing overcast conditions earlier in the caused a late start. Meanwhile, here in New Orleans, a halfhour away, the milkweed is rife with monarch caterpillars inour garden.

On Monday, August 19 and around 7:00 pm there were hundreds of monarch butterflies in flight just at tree top level following the Green Bay shore off of Lake Michigan.

The butterflies just kept comming from the north and went straight south in large groups. Closer to nightfall they dwindled until we could no longer see. The birds flew over head and often seemed to dive at them but did not eat them. I thought perhaps because they eat milkweed, they may be toxic. We alerted the campers near by and everyone was enjoying the show.

Today, August 28, is traditionally the day I see the most monarchs in the lane near our house.  Each year they roost in the tall cottonwoods and even in the smaller box elder trees before starting migration.  Last year the lane was full of monarchs.  On a slow drive you would chase dozens down the lane.  Today I followed a large harvest combine down the lane.  It brushed the branches of the trees and the monarchs were disturbed and flew around for a few minutes before relanding in the trees.  I saw 5 monarchs.  Quite a difference from last years 50-75.

I've only tagged 550 monarchs to date, compared to 4,000 at the same time last year (August 28th).

While this could indicate that the population is down, the numbers tagged could be low this year because the conditions have not been good for tagging this year:

Nights have not been cool like they were last year. (Tonight's low will be 75F.) Monarchs cluster together tightly on cool nights (say 55F), so big groups of them are easy to capture. Clusters this year are small--say 15-- compared to the groups of 50,60 or even 100 on a cool night. What's more, after we swoop the net when it's warm, the butterflies are capable of flight. With cool temperatures, the butterflies aren't able to fly well so we can usually even catch them by hand when they fall.

Last year I had 2,950 butterflies roost in my yard up to 8/27/01 and had tagged 550. This year I have had a total of 88 Monarchs roost in my yard and have tagged 58 of those. The most onany one night this year is 58 versus 900 last year.

I tagged my first Monarchs on August 23rd. I had 20 butterflies roost in my yard and tagged 11. To this date last year I had about 2200 roost in my yard and had tagged 400.

The numbers sure seem way down this year. I keep hoping that the migration is late and there will be a "surge" of butterflies coming. Probably wishful thinking.

Tuesday, September 10 a cold front passed through and on the afternoon Route I counted 203 monarchs. I estimated there were probably 600 in the Picnic area. We put Monarch Watch tags on over 350 monarchs on Tuesday evening. Another 100 monarchs were tagged on Wednesday morning, September 11. We were so busy tagging, we could not really watch the butterfly behavior and see if any were heading out over the lake or bay.

This is our peak this year; usually we have two, one early August and theother late August/early September. Maybe I should say so far! It has beena very unusual migration monitoring season this year.

A group of 60+ Monarchs flying overhead, some are quite close to the upper branches of trees, it's early evening and cool, maybe they are landing for the night. I noticed another observer saw a group about an hour before me, as he is North of me (about one hour), it was probably the same group!

While driving south on Memorial Drive along the Lake Michigan shoreline from Two Rivers to Manitowoc at 9:00am today (The trip took 4 minutes, at the speed of 45 miles an hour, the tempurature was 71 degrees), I counted 320 monarchs flying over the highway. Some were circling in large groups and others were heading southwest.  In many areas there were so many monarchs flying overhead it was difficult to count, particularly while driving!  I deliberately took this route because of the cold front that passed through our area yesterday.  On the return trip at around 11:30am, I counted 26 monarchs along the same route.  In fact there was a ratio of 1 monarch to at least 8 dragonflies traveling in a south westerly direction.  Suggestion for a challenge question:  Do the dragonflies follow the monarchs?

I saw several monarchs coming in Tuesday evening, Sept. 10. Weather hadreally cooled off. Wednesday a.m. I counted 11 monarchs on a hackberrybranch. I saw monarchs coming in again Wednesday evening, but didn'thave time to watch. This morning (Thur.) I have counted approximately 75monarchs in maple trees. They're up high enough I had to try countingusing binoculars. I'll keep watching!

September 8, 2002
It was really weird this year, asthe critters came in on Sunday and Monday, 9/8 +9/9, and were gone on 9/10.The wind was from the north and they were gone. I would say we had about50-60 - not anything like last year.(See below.)

August 15, 2001
We have lived in our house for 19 years. Every year we have a large number of monarchs that seem to gather in our yard and then disappear to on their journey. Over the years we have seen various numbers, ranging from a 100-200 up to 400-500. This year, we are totally amazed at the numbers. This evening there are at least 800 monarchs - and that is not an exaggeration. There are probably more. Our neighbors have branches full, we have several trees full - it is amazing. I know that they will be gone tomorrow as there is a front coming through and the wind will switch to the north. We live in western Wisconsin, Hammond, which is 16 miles from the MN/WS border east of the Twin Cities.
Another day with many Monarchs flying south on a Northwest wind. While I was standing outside talking to a friend about 25+ flew by!

The monarchs have arrived in and around Sidney.  There are not as many sited in the usual roosting places, maybe 10 where there were 40 last year.  Approximately 5 miles northwest of Sidney we have spotted hundreds of monarchs feeding on goldenrod.  The area where we observed the most monarchs is a 20 acre tract of CRP (set aside, unmowed)land.  This area also has lots of milkweed plants in the lower areas.  We estimate about 25 monarchs were sited at one time in a 10ft. x 10ft area.We have taken digital photos of monarchs on the goldenrod.

Hi-we are seeing more groups of butterflies passing on the playground.  Our classroom is flying-literally as we have hatched and tagged almost 20 butterflies( 283 RW through 299 RW ) and released serveral without tags too....We are predicting a cold front to come through by weekend and are hoping to have all butterflies hatched and released by Friday!!!!!!The students have observed many newly hatched butterflies and have been amazed how they pump fluid from their abdomens to the wings WOW!!!!  We are sad to see the end the Migration season coming.

My class had noticed many Monarchs around their own backyards on the 17th. From 7-21 were seen in southern KC in bushes, trees, and on Milkweed plants. The weather was changing from warm and sunny to cloudy, windy, and threats of rain.

We watched the monarchs come through our region from 9/5 through 9/12. Although there were fewer than last fall, and a migration peak was hard to discern, there was still a substantial number of monarchs around. Our biggest day was tagging 16 in one hour.

A beautiful day filled with thousands of Monarchs.  All along an 8 mile drive from Liberty, Missouri to my home in Kansas City, I saw waves of Monarchs.  In Liberty I counted 15 to 20 per minute while standing outside a store for 10 minutes.  At home, I counted 101 in an hour (12:30 pm to 1:30 pm).  This evening from 5:15 pm to 7:15 pm I counted 31.  All in all a really rewarding day.  So heads up on further South of Kansas City MO, they are on their way!!!

Monarchs started arriving Sunday the 22nd and have increased into the hundreds by this evening, Monday the 23rd. We are north of Enid about six miles, have lots of trees, grass and water on about 18 acres. The Monarchs regularly spend a few days here almost every fall.

September 25th Update
The monarchs are still here. Still about a thousand, no increase from Tuesday. Wind may change to the north Thursday, and that might trigger the Monarch'sto move out. We'll let you know.

September 27th Update
We had a gentle north breeze today and most of the monarchs have gone. Thetemperature early this morningwas about 52 degrees.There may be 50 or so left having overslept or missed the flight for someother reason. Perhaps they'll just stay here with us since theaccommodations are so nice.

This first day of Autumn has greeted us with what appears to be the monarch migration at its peak.  While taking our Autumn nature hike in the park next to our school we observed monarchs throughout the day.  Between noon and 2:00 pm we saw over 50 of them, usually alone but sometimes in pairs.  The warm sun and light breeze helped to move them along at a fast pace.

Checking in from east of Kansas City~Migration today (and STILL at 7:30pm) report-Winds changed to north/northwest, cooler temperature dropping rapidlyapproximately 6 pm. Seeing literally hundreds of Monarchs flying southeach and every hour. Heaviest between 5 and 7pm. Also seeing 'flocks' (isthat proper?) of Monarchs groupings flying south as well...

Yesterday (9/23/02) morning in Vineland, there was a huge concentration of monarchbutterflies in and around the newly planted "Millennium Forest" just northof the Agriculture Canada building on Victoria Avenue (very close to thesouth shore of Lake Ontario).

There were hundreds, possibly thousands ofbutterflies in the area. Some were flying around, and others were roostingin trees, basking and vibrating their wings to warm up. The butterflies were undoubtedly atvarious body temperatures- some were flying around (some strongly, someweakly) and others appeared to be actively trying to raise their temperature(basking on the bald cypress trees and some vibrating their wings).

Quite an amazingspectacle- I've seen monarch congregations at Long Point, and this blew itaway!

Today, there is not a monarch to be found- I wonder how far they got?
Here aresome photos that I took.

Kim Barrett

Forwarded by Rod Murray from ONTbirds, a province-wide internetlist for reporting rare bird sightings.

Tuesday evening 9/24/02 about 75 to 90 monarch were seen clinging to one of our maple trees out back.  Earlier in the day it was a glorious sight when out back in the butterfly beds there were monarchs every were you looked.  At one point we counted 13 monarchs and 4 swallowtails on one verbena bonariensis plant.  The temp was about 71 degrees.  It was a magnificent sight.  I can not wait to get my photos back.

Sorry, I'm late, my system has been down.  On Sat., Sept. 21,while out and about and while on a 60 mile round trip road trip I counted over 35 monarchs,  They were about 20 to 40 yards up, drifting &/or fluttering southward. On Thurs., Sept. 26, while hiking at Burr Oak Woods Conservation Nature Center with third graders,  we counted over 10 Monarchs necturing on the prairy flowers.  The Temperatures this week have been in the low 80's and morning and evening air in the 60's, with cool breezes, absolutely gorgeous!

On a Warm and mostly sunny day we saw Hundreds of Monarchs feeding Goldenrod and Fallasters on the shores of Lake Ontario.I haven`t seen so many for a long time .I must thank the Town of Ajax for leaving big areas uncut ,onsprayed ,back to nature on our long waterfront.All Monarchs looked the same size and in A1 condition .(I asume young once.)Today there are more in all our gardens ,Temp is 28 celcius and we have a southwest wind .I do hope they have good crossing .U
At least 2 dozen monarchs nectaring in a friends garden along the western shore of Lake George in Sabbath Day Point.

Forwarded by Carol King from Dave Brown of Hawk Cliff Hawkwatch

In addition to good migration of raptors observed, "Another highlight for the day was (and I'm not exaggerating) 1000's of Monarchs on the move. At one point Keith was counting 60-70 Monarchs a minute crossing our line of sight and down along the willows behind us to the west. The sheer number of butterflies became even more evident as the storm front moved in and the Monarchs flitted enmass all around us to get into the willow trees for cover right behind us. Quite a sight indeed!"

(Hawk Cliff Hawkwatch is the oldest Hawkwatch in Ontario - since 1931 - located just east of Port Stanley on the cliff overlooking Lake Erie.)

"Weather: An interesting day for weather...started out with light SW winds and still farily warm temperatures to 26 C. Around 1:00 PM (EST) a series of very black clouds moved past just north of the cliff. We actually got a few minutes of rain and then back into the sunshine. At this point however the winds had swung around to the NW and became very strong and gusty to 40 kph."

Migration Hotspot: Point Pelee, Ontario

Observations of Alan Wormington of Point Pelee Provincial Park, forwarded by Don Davis from the Ontario Birds Hotline:

"This afternoon (Sunday, September 29) there was a massive migration of Monarchs in progress at Point Pelee, with hundreds leaving the Tip on a constant basis. The situation suggests that there should be a massive overnight concentration at the Tip."

Point Pelee, a 10-kilometre sandspitstretching into Lake Erie, is world famous for its seasonal migrations of birds and monarch butterflies.

About 17 Monarchs today - This is more than I have seen all summer and fall combined!  It is unseasonably warm today with a high of 80 degrees expected.  All of the butterflies were spotted as I was driveing South from Plainfield, NH to Charlestown, NH on route 12A - A distance of about 30 miles.  This route follows the Connecticut river that is a natural migration route for birds of prey and other creaturres.
We think we have peaked. 436 at 8  per min. We even used  sugarwater to feed them.

This was the first day we saw monarchs in large masses at our school. They roosted in several bushes and trees around the ground, we estimated about 250-300. This was more than we had last year! We still have caterpillars on our milkweed!

At home, I had the opposite--only having a couple of hundred where we had what looked like thousands last year! Hopefully, a few more will make it in the warmer weather we've been having--haven't seen any caterpillars on my own milkweed, however.

Oct. 17 Update
Wow, I was so surprised to see that our first mass sighting of butterflies on 10-9, would be our peak. The most we've seen since that date has been 13! We have now had a hard frost, so we're sure we saw our last monarch yesterday. It was an adult male, with some tattering on the right anterior wing.
On this day I walked slowly down my driveway(1/2 mile long) past the golden rod and the Indian plantain and spotted about 35 monarchs. None tagged that I could see. What a beautiful sight!
10/12/02 Monarch Migration Report Location is Gulf Shores, Alabama.

The monarchs made it to our area on Saturday, October 12.  We counted almost 300 monarchs in a period from 11:30 AM to 1:00 PM.  We were at Millwood Lake just east of Ashdown, AR, in Little River county.  The monarchs would come up over the spillway and down into a field of goldenrod to feed.  The day started out sunny but clouds had moved in.  There was a light breeze and temperatures were in the upper 70s to low 80s.  As long as the clouds stayed in the area the monarchs came down to feed.  When the sun came out again they all seemed to leave headed south to soutwest.  We were able to catch and tag 60 of the monarchs. All of them were very large and looked fat and healthy.  The majority of the ones we tagged were male.

I was on the Panama City Beach last week and saw hundreds of Monarchs washed up, dead on the shoreline. We walked .7 mile to the pier from our hotel, and there were probably 25 per yd on the beach. I did not see any flying. I figured they must have had trouble as a group while migrating. The weather was beautiful when we encountered them, no rain at all, mild temperatures and slight breezes. We saw them in Panama City Beach, FL on the 10th of October, 2002. Can you comment on this please??
