Quoting from this full note:
Rain kept me out of the field most of the morning with only brief lulls. The rain quit about eleven, but no clearing occurred until about 30 minutes ago (7:30 p.m.). Shortly before noon the Monarchs started flying again. I went looking for birds, but today there was little bird activity, so I concentrated on the Monarchs.From my Big Sit location I timed two individuals clearing the sky north to south at 0:03:42 and 0:04:01. And twice I counted the entire visible sky, getting totals of 626 and 715 Monarchs. They were flying at roughly the same rate until about 4 p.m. when the numbers dropped way off. so i guess my actual count for the day was 1343. but I used the old sky-clearing blackbird counting technique (which i also favor for estimating any large flocks (hawks, robins, etc.). using conservative numbers of 4 minutes and 650 individuals over a four-hour flight i came up with an estimate of 39,000 Monarchs through my patch of sky today (my area of visibility here is about 4.5 miles in diameter, but of course the distance for seeing Monarchs even with binoculars is quite shorter). during that time period, i also looked for birds and Monarchs at my home, as far as Mountain Home and Kerrville, and found the flight just as strong. yesterday's flight seemed stronger than today's and lasted longer, but using the same conservative numbers for yesterday's flight time of 1 to 7:30 the estimate works out to 63,375 for that narrow patch of sky. i feel like both day's estimates are very reasonable. not a single other individual butterfly of any species was seen either day (not even a Snout!).

Monday, 10/14/02 in Camp Wood between 5 p.m. and 6 p.m., hundreds and hundreds of Monarchs descended on the top of the Pecan trees by the Nueces River and started roosting in the top of one of the tallest Pecan trees.

Since prior to this time, I had seen only three over a space of two weeks, Idid not expect to see much if any of the migration activities.

They wereflying so high up that they looked like mosquitoes in the sky. If you knowhow high Hawks and Vultures fly, that is how high these butterflies were.Today has been raining and cooling to 50-60. There is heavy cloud cover,and I can only believe that the Monarchs were flying above those clouds.They were coming from the East and going toward the trees on the West sideof our property.

I don't know if you can see how thick they are from these two picturesbecause the day was so gray and the light very dim.

We checked the next morning from 7:00 a.m. on the Monarchs that were in thetop of the tall native Pecan tree. It was at exactly 9:00 a.m. that theystarted leaving the tree and went in a Southwest direction across the NuecesRiver. There was no feeding or delay.I believe that wherever those Monarchs came from, they must have hit thecold, wet weather and were exhausted.I have seen only two Monarchs since and they were flying lower and seemed inno hurry.An item of interest that is occurring here along with the Monarchs. TheScissor-tailed Flycatchers mass on different areas. I read one report froma Uvalde person that they ate Monarchs. Well, for over a week before thismigration of Monarchs came, Scissor-tailed Flycatchers were all over thearea. Now they are gone!

I will keep you updated if any further Monarch action occurs.

Yesterday observed nine Monarchs nectaring in my yard.  This was after three weeks of seeing maybe two or three individuals, total.  Today ten were nectaring. The are Monarchs in the yard from late morning until dusk. Most appear fresh.

Hundreds per second over Crystal City and over the Nueces River at the Lehmann Research Foundation.

The clouds were in the right area for the Monarchs to stop and came down to feed. A group from the Y.L.O Club from the Crystal City Memorial library had a great time.

On 10/15/02, Ted Dracos emailed me this from his home near Reagan Wells, Texas ..."Clouds of Monarchs coming through this morning.  Never seen more. And up above them - a lone golden eagle hunting.  Who says there ain't no heaven?"

This past week has been a good one for monarchs travelingthrough Louisiana.

A cold front came through on October 13. On October 15 I began noticing a few monarchs visiting my garden. Each day the butterflies persisted. Yesterday, October 19, I rode my bicycle for about 2 hours covering about 4 miles and noticed approximately 15 monarchs sailing about. Their general flight direction was southward.

This influx of individuals has been the highest I have seen this year.

"On Sunday was a huge, southwardly migrating body of Monarchs at high altitudes in a large kettle configuration similar to Buteos. It was Monarchs as far as you could see(10-20,000+).

Reported by Charlie P. to the TX-BUTTERFLY listserv

Starr County, Texas, October 20, 2002, posted to the Texas Butterfly List by Charlie Parides and reported here with his permission:  "Danaus plexipus - Monarch (10-20,000+), Fronton, (US83 and FM 650).  Large migrating body at high altitude (~500+ ft) in ~500-2000 ft deep kettles.  Notes:  ... overhead at this location Sunday was a huge southwardly migrating body of Monarchs at high altitudes in a large configuration similar to Buteos.  Total numbers were easily in the 4th range.  It was as monarchs as far as you could see." Then " ... was a unique treat."

Este Sábado por la mañana salí al patio de mi casa cuando de pronto miré hacia el cielo y fue cuando presencie la el paso de las mariposas monarca. Que afortunados somos los que tenemos la oportunidad de ver este espectáculo.

Thousands of monarchs per hour were crossing Lavaca Bay this afternoon, generally from ENE to WSW. I plotted many at about 10 degrees north of the late afternoon sun.

Several times I held my arms out in front of me with thumb tips touching (I'm six-one) and between my upward pointing index fingers (framed!) I could see twenty-five monarchs.

Many monarchs were stopping to nectar. At 5 pm, I counted 36 monarchs nectaring on a 10 X 20 foot patch of short seaside goldenrod. Saw several coupled pairs both nectaring and crossing the bay.

About 5:10 it dawned on me that many were "coming back"--about 2 out of 5. At 5:20, almost half were on a heading back between north and northeast ... almost as if they didn't want to make the three and a half mile trip across the bay before sundown. About 5:30, as I was standing on the shell beach road about fifty feet from edge of the bay, there were hundreds of monarchs milling around me, that then slowly dispersed northward to the clustering sites. There were a few, very few, that flew on across the bay after 5:45. After 5:45, I started looking, and the best cluster in a three foot square had about 75 monarchs in it. Clusters were forming up and down the beach as far as I could see, on brush and taller weeds along the shell beach.

We've tried for years to figure out where the monarchs that were trying to cross the bay in October and November might cluster for the night. This was the first time to be in the right place. I was standing in the middle of hundreds that were milling around between 5:30 and sunset about 5:45. I saw more monarchs during those two hours yesterday than I have seen in the past seven years combined ... it was fantastic!

Second day of sun, light northeast wind. The wind was calming, the sun was setting, air was still warm ~80 degrees F. A front coming in tonight. The site is twenty miles inland of the Gulf barrier islands.

Monarchs in numbers were reported up the coast yesterday, about 130 miles northeast of us, so we were expecting some, but not thousands, of monarchs today.

La migración fue espectacular el viernes, sábado y domingo (25, 26 y 27).El viernes llovió casi todo el día, a medio día paró unas horas la lluvia y aparecieron mariposas por miles en el cielo, dando vueltas, no en su camino al sur, esa noche llovió mucho y amaneció muy nublado, a las nueve de la mañana las nubes empezaron a levantarse y aparecieron las mariposas, en remolinos, tomando las termales y elevándose alto en el cielo. Mi nieto y Yo contamos las que pasaron por la casa y contamos ¡10,014 mariposas! en 35 minutos. Ese día tuve muchos reportes, pasaron por todos lados. En la tarde, recibí una llamada por teléfono de un miembro del Correo Real, andaba paseando en bicicleta por las faldas de la Sierra de Zapalinamé y en uno de los cañones observó a las dos de la tarde a miles de mariposas perchandose en los arbustos. El domingo también fueron abundantes, pero no como el día anterior.El lunes, martes y miércoles de esta semana casi ya no vieron ( un promedio de tres por minuto) se levantan temprano ya que la temperatura es de 17 o 18 grados a las seis de la mañana. Muy caliente para ser fines de octubre. Desafortunadamente sigo sin recibir noticias de los observadores de Querétaro y San Luis Potosí.

Nuestras orugas se han desarrollado rápidamente, encontramos más ya son 21 y tenemos 10 ya en la fase de crisálida.

Seguiremos en contacto

Saludos a los compañeros de Journey North
Llegan las mariposas! Las fotos tomadas en La Madrid en los canales en donde duerme la mariposa.

On October 28, Nydia de la Cruz took this picture of the sky overhead filled with monarchs in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon. “It is not very clear, but the monarchs are really high up in the sky,” writes Senora de la Cruz.  How many monarchs can you count?
This week was the peak week.  We saw a total of 15 monarchs in the first week of October.  We sighted four with in five minutes one warm afternoon.

My life science students captured and tagged an amazing 44 Monarchs today.  It was a whirlwind.  They worked in15 minute shifts.  There were 22 males and 22 females tagged.  Today was the peak migration in our tagging program.

I encountered a massive migration on Friday, August 29th in Glencoe, Minnesota.

I would have missed it entirely had I not remembered Bill Calvert's tip for watching monarch migration during a north wind: "Use binoculars and look beneath the clouds. The butterflies travel way up high and are easier to see against a white backdrop." Sure enough! Monarchs were flooding southward on the strong north wind (20+ mph). It took a minute or two to train my eye, then suddenly I saw them, zipping by as fast as the wind. I counted 86 in 5 minutes. Each darted across my field of vision in just 5-6 seconds. (In contrast, I saw an average of 7 per minute while driving along the highway.)

The trick was seeing the first one; it seemed to take a minute or two. Then others at higher and higher altitudes came into view. Those highest were tiny dots, so there must have been others too high to be seen even with binoculars. All were traveling in exactly the same direction. They looked like tiny paper airplanes folded identically, with wings pitched for an effortless glide. Had they had vapor trails behind them, like passing jets, every line of travel would have been parallel.

Whenever I took my binoculars down, to look with my naked eye, the entire scene vanished. I couldn't see anything but clouds and blue sky!

I had parked on a quiet dirt road and was using the open car door to steady my hands. At one point a gruff old farmer stopped in his pickup and asked suspiciously if I needed directions. "I'm watching butterflies!" I said exuberantly, pointing at the empty sky."They're migrating to Mexico! Do you want to see?" He broke into a smile, got out of his truck, and we watched together for awhile. (He became, in a word, chatty: "Oh my! There they are! I see them! Why do they fly so high? Does it take much energy to float like that? How long does it take to get to Mexico?" etc.)

As I drove back to the city I just couldn't believe the migration was still taking place right over my head. Twice I stopped to look again. There they were, silently streaming by like shooting stars. As I drove on, I wondered about other everyday miracles that take place beyond our notice.

I also saw many southbound dragonflies, and tree swallows hawking other insects riding high on the winds.

Don't forget your binoculars the next time you go out to see the migration! I couldn't have been more surprised.

While I was on a boat on Lake Minnetonka this afternoon, I observed at least 40 monarchs in the course of an hour (about one every minute and an half), all streaming in a southward direction. Conditions were sunny and warm
Master birder, Oscar Johnson, reported seeing dozens of migrating Monarch butterflies today.

Yesterday while I was talking to a friend in Bobcagen (at a Cottage Country about 2 hrs northwest of Ajax) she was telling me about the many, many Monarchs flying by. She has been living up there for 4 years. Along the waterfront she saw 40 all at once. Not roosting,but hovering over some kind of pink wildflowers.
While driving we observed steady streams (dozens) of monarchs stopping to nectar on Goldenrod.

As I was monitoring my milkweed site for MLMP, I counted 60+ Monarchs flying over head.  They didn't stop to check out the flowers that were blooming, but kept gliding on with the North East wind assisting their flight.

I was checking the milkweed plants at one of my MMLP sites and noticed 60+ Monarchs fly over in a period of about 45 minutes. They were gliding by assisted by a North East wind. None of them stopped off at the butterfly garden for food, but kept flying South!

The observations for the morning turned up 370 monarchs today--the most yet in daily visits to the refuge.

Central Iowa is exceedingly dry now, and some areas of the refuge are showing the strains of lack of rain.Some wildflowers are drying out early and dying. Does the dry weather affect the monarch migration--the timing of it and the places visited?

Family members aided today in the first half of a 2 1/2-hour count of monarchs at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Two of our grandchildren, ages 5 and 2, had their first field experience of tromping through the prairie grasses and watching the monarchs flying over their heads. The observations for the morning turned up 370 monarchs--the most yet in daily visits to the refuge.

While sitting in my kitchen enjoying breakfast at 9 a.m., I noted a large number of migrating monarchs. I began leisurely counting them, and in a one hour period noted 99 monarchs travelling due west. I am sure I missed a number of them as I was also busy with clearing up . What I find unique in the direction they are taking is moving west takes you away from the lake. The front of my house faces directly in the middle between south and west, with each corner pointing in a compass direction. This is the second time my home has been in the direct flight path.
There were thousands of monarchs migrating along Jones Beach.  I counted 40 in one minute.

Today I traveled between Iowa City and Waterloo onI-380.  The Monarchs were very numerous, especially from south of theIndependence exit all the way to Waterloo!   I have not seen so many alongthe road before.   They weren't in "packs" but were scattered out along theway.   I think about 5 or 6 ended up smashed on my windshield.  I thought ifevery car going north today killed at least 5 Monarchs, that would be a LOTof Monarchs wiped out in Iowa, and they have a long way to go yet!   I livesouth of Iowa City, so am anxious to get out tomorrow and see if the mainmigration is coming through here yet.  We had a few flying through ourplaygroung at school this past week.     We will be releasing four sometimethis week, too - as soon as they emerge from their chrysalis'.     Two yearsago, we had hundreds in our trees.  That was a sight!

There was a large westerly movement of monarchs alongthe north shore of Lake Ontario from at least Oshawato Oakville on Sunday. I decided late on Sunday toalso check out Rod Murray's Oakville monarch havenabout 5:30 pm and the area was filled with monarchs.What really impressed me as the sun was setting wasthe number of monarchs coasting along at extremelyhigh altitude in a direct westerly direction (usingthe sun as a compass?). I captured a few monarchs, butthese were readily replaced by others that either flewin off of the lake or dropped in - possibly attractedby the scent of flowering plants. Even as the sun wentdown, some monarchs lingered on flowering plants. Ataggers paradise!Expect more of the same today! Wish I could be there!

Hundreds of monarchs appeared in the meadow and along the shoal drinking nectar from the goldenrod and asters. Each plant was host to 4 or 5 butterflies. They had crossed the 5 mile stretch of water from the Upper Pennisula (Route 2) to St. Helena Island. Several days later, when the wind was right, most of the monarchs took flight and crossed the remaining stretch of water to the Lower Pennisula of Michigan.

Migration Highlight

Hundreds of monarchs,(but not as many as sighted at St. Helena Island), were feeding on tall purple flowers in the gardens of the Grand Hotel. The Grand Hotel sits on the ancient beach ridge overlooking the Straits of Mackinac and the Lower Penninsula of Michigan further to the south. The butterflies probably flew across the water from St.Ignace, Michigan and were stopping for lunch before finishing the crossing of the Straits.

A small group of monarch butterflies were seen flying south over the water of Lake Huron about 25 miles east of the Mackinac Bridge.The butterflies could have been traveling to Bois Blanc Island to rest or possibly trying to cross all the way to the Lower Penninsula of Michigan in one flight.

While conducting a hawk watch from 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. we counted 289 Monarchs.

(Migration rate: 72 per hour)

Tonight about an hour before sundown I was boating near the Eastern shoreline ofLake Michigan just south of St. Joseph, Michigan. There were hundreds of Monarch butterflies headed south. My wife and I observed them for over a half hour. They were flying I would say 75 to 200 feet up. Wind was very light out of the North and the butterflies were all headed due south.

I have lived in Michigan for over 20 years and boated on Lake Michigan the same amount of time but I have never seen this many butterflies at once ? it was fantastic.

I'm an avid nature lover and watcher. I help track the hummingbird migrationeach spring, have created a butterfly garden and have our wooded city acrelot registered as a backyard wildlife habitat.

We went out to Sportsman's Park right before school was out.  We saw 30 monarchs in 20 minutes.  Most were just fluttering around the wildflowers out there. It was a hot, sunny day and there was a light breeze.

The Holiday Beach Migration Observatory reported a big monarch butterfly migration day on Sunday, Sept. 8, with 1,380 monarchs counted during the 8 3/4 hour observation period.

The highest count in all previous days was only 50 monarchs. The monarchs are counted as they fly above the 40 foot observation tower used for watching raptor migration. The Observatory is located in Amherstburg, Ontario, not far from Detroit, Michigan.

(Migration Rate: 158 monarchs per hour.)

As of September 11th, the peak of monarch migration has now passed Kingston and area.

Prior to September 4, the number of monarchs passing through the area steadily increased.

On the afternoon of the 4th, the local population maximum was reached when I counted about 200 monarchs in about 2 hours(12.30 PM-2:30 PM) in one meadow, most of them feeding on red clover flowers.

There was a steady northwest wind of about 20 km/h which made it favourable for them to take a run at crossing Lake Ontario, but I am not sure if they did. On the 5th, the number of monarchs in the same 2 hour period in the same meadow was down about 50%. On Monday, the 8th, I counted about 25 monarchs and that number diminshed to only 2 monarchs on the afternoon of the 11th of September.

My class observed 27 Monarchs flying in a southwestern direction during our 2:00-2:15 p.m. observation time.  It is an 85 degree, sunny day!  The butterflies were fun to watch because one at a time each would fly over our school building and rest in a pile of rock before flying off again.
About 100 in my woodland/wetland back yard around 5-6pm

Nice migration through Kansas City MO today.

From 2:20 pm to 4:20 pm (CDT) observed 227 Monarchs.

Notice the peak at 3:20 to 3:50 pm.
2:20 - 3:20 pm - 83 Monarchs (1 hr).
3:20 - 3:50 pm - 85 Monarchs (30 minutes).
3:50 - 4:20 pm - 59 Monarchs (30 minutes).

Good wind from the North, 10-15 mph, temperature in lower 70's, lots of sunshine. Lots of FUN!!!

This was another big day in the migration of monarchs through central Iowa. The morning was cool, the sky was clearing, and the monarchs were on the move again after rainfall in previous days. In two and one-half hours in the late morning, 317 monarchs were counted at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Some were flying speedily south, and others were stopping to feed on thistles on the prairie. In an area where only two monarchs had been seen on a rainy Saturday, the sky and the thistles were alive with the butterflies this Sunday.

Oh, boy, what fun!!! A wonderful migration wave just went through Kansas City MO this afternoon.

In 2 hours I counted 227 Monarchs. A good North wind behind them, so many were up above the pin oaks (over 60 feet), some I saw in binoculars. Temp in lower 70's. Most were flying high.

My count and times, notice that in 30 minutes from 3:20 pm (CDT) to 3:50 the number was much higher, that was a definite a good wave:

2:20 to 3:20 pm - 83 Monarchs
3:20 to 3:50 pm - 85 Monarchs
3:50 to 4:15 pm - 59 Monarchs

for a total of 227 observed in my location north of Kansas City, MO (I'm next to Gladstone).

Can't wait to see the next wave. Does anyone know how far they can travel in a day? The wind speed was at least 10-15 or more during the migration I observed. Also, I haven't seen any more, it just stopped at 4:20 pm.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Walking outside to day about 10:15 AM, I noticed a large amount of Monarch butterfly activity, they were all close to the ground and flying about, and resting on the ground, just in my field of vision, there must have been about 50 to 75 Butterflies. About 20 minutes later I drove a couple blocks to the post office and a friends house next door to post office, he asked me whats with all the Butterflies, thats when I noticed even more at his house. There were what I would think to be hundreds of them, flying and landing everywhere. They were in the grass, and on the street, as cars would go by they would all fly up in the air. I found this to be very interesting, thats when I came to the internet to see if I could find out more about them. I looked higher in the sky as suggested and saw nothing, these are all flying about 15 to 20 feet off the ground, no more. Just curious what they were up to. By the way you have a very nice site here for the kids, Great Job!!!

These were for sure monarchs (and not painted ladies) andlots of them. Now today (09/17) I looked again and haven't seen even one..... guess they must ofmoved on.

I attended the K-State football game, which started at noon.  I was in thenosebleed section -- far, far above the playing field and fairly far abovethe surrounding ground level (the playing field is dug into the earth).Soon I noticed Monarchs floating by, at my eye level.  There was a bit of awind from the north and so it was an easy ride for the butterflies.I soon began looking up, with my binoculars.  For the next two hours therewas a rather steady stream of butterflies, many of them quite high (totallyinvisible to the naked eye), taking advantage of the stronger winds upthere.  It was not uncommon for me to have 10 Monarchs in my binoculars'field of vision at any moment.Then, about 2 o'clock it all ended.  Suddenly, I could find no Monarchs,either at eye level or in the sky.  In fact I recall seeing only onestraggler for the rest of the game (until 3:30 or so).  But for the firsttwo hours what was going in the sky was at least as interesting as what was

While driving from Chicago westward, my passenger counted 62 monarchs in an eight minute period. The expressway goes around the Des Plaines river area. (we were going around 70 mph -good luck making a math problem out of that!! :)
Counted 23 Monarchs in a 10-minute period outside a 6th-floor window in downtown Chicago, heading generally south and west into a contrary wind blowing from the south.

I am most impressed by the movement of monarchs ineast Toronto this morning, as well outside of the cityalong the Hwy. 401 expressway. Across one smallportion of one major north-south street (Kennedy Road)from Eglinton to 401, I counted 7 monarchs crossingthe highway, some flapping, many soaring. This patterncontinued as I drove along the expressway to Ajax.

Migration weather has been amazing since well beforeLabour Day. Today, little wind. Nights cool - downinto the 50's. Right now it is 68 F and sunny at 10:45am.. We really could use some rain and hurricaneIsabel is heading directly towards Toronto.

Looks like a bumper crop of monarchs.

The Monarch migration continued today in significant numbers, which is the third day in a row with large totals observed. Over that time span there must have been tens of thousands that moved through southern Ontario and Michigan.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

On Tuesday, standing in my small yard, I saw at least 65 monarchs duringan hour time span passing through my yard (so I estimated 500 in a day). Some stopped to nector, but most had no interest. They were flyingsouthwest. I also noticed that most of the monarchs I have released inSeptember have been females. Was it just coincidence, or are there morefemales late in the season?? Does anyone know?

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Last Sunday,(9/21) in the field in back of our house, we saw Monarchs in a large number..they were landing on the wild alfalfa. We caught, tagged and released 12 of them(seven female, five male)..so let us know...down South if you see initials on the wings! It was a warm and beautiful afternoon and the Monarchs abundant. That prior week we had seen about 40 Monarchs per minutes flying across this area.

It is Saturday, September 20, 2003 and the Monarch Butterflies are fluttering along from 1 to 3 per minute.  Sometimes the south west wind is blowing them east.  A rare one stops to feed on the Purple Cone flowers as well as the Verbina purple flowers.  One did not make it and I found it dead on the road so I picked it up and put it in the car.  It will be a neat souvenir of this year's migration after Isabel.

A beautiful day filled with butterflies!  Sunny, temperature in the 60's, light winds.  I observed a steady stream of Monarchs throughout the day, at approximate rate of 1 per minute, sometimes more.  From 10am (CDT) to 10:45 am - 50 Monarchs; from 1:00pm to 1:30 - 27 Monarchs.  They just kept coming, floating and gliding, their orange wings illuminated by the sun.  Most were above 15 feet or more.

It rained yesterday, but today it was clear and breezy. The wind was coming from the northeast. We thought it might be a good day to spot monarchs. Sure enough, our 3rd grade class spotted 26 monarchs migrating in a 30 minute period. WOW! All the kids went crazy to see so many beautiful monarchs. We had fun making observations. Our teacher has never seen so many before. We have raised some monarchs this year. Right now, we have 2 chysalises.

Migration Highlight

Welive in the south central part of Kansas-Winfield, Kansas which is 50 mi SEof Wichita, on a farm 7 miles Se of Winfield. Sunday morning when we got upand looked out our picture window, our yard was covered with Monarchs andthey were flying all over the place, up into the trees, around thetrees--they were everywhere, but what was unique was how they would all landon the limbs and cover the trees like leaves. The way they hung looked likebrown leaves on the tree. They hung around all day Sunday (and it wasreally rainy in the morning). When we got up this morning, they were gone.There were some who saw more than usual in town, but I didn't hear anyoneelse talking of the thousands that we saw. What a unique experience. Itook three rolls of film.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Thirty five miles east of my Kansas City home, in Blue Springs, MO is Burr Oak Woods Conservation Nature Center where I am a volunteer. On Sunday, Sept 21, I assisted there in a catch, tag, release Monarch Butterfly program for the public.  In 3 hours we caught over 125 Monarchs in our Native Prairie, sexed them, tagged them, then released them.  It was amazing to see and hear the excitement of the participants.  One lady carried a child, captured three Monarchs at once and was taking pictures at the same time.  It was a great experience.

We counted a total of 7 Monarchs in view on Wednesday the 24th. The main attraction was our "Nanho Blue" butterfly bush, but they also liked our orange zinnias. There was a great deal of activity all day.

Literally, once again, 100's of Monarchs flapping and soaring along with the wind over Cranberry Marsh and the meadow on the west of Hall St. S. close to Lake Ontario, sw. of Whitby, Ontario, Canada.  My guess is there are 1 - 2 every minute migrating towards the west.

In two hours on Saturday September 27th, seven of us tagged 215 Monarchs in a clover field.  The day before I tagged 48 in one hour. I have been tagging for three years and have never seen so many Monarchs in Vermont.

While at my brother house on Sep.27,2003 at a family gathering we all saw anywhere from 200-300 monarch butterflies flying in a south direction. After pointing out the great number of them we all decided that it was the first time that we had ever saw that many at one given time.  A teacher that is in the family was there and she said that she did not know that they traveled south, but we had came to agree that something was up.  When I got up this morning I got onto the internet to search hoping to find out.. So I'm very glad that we all were not losing our minds and that we all had the chance to witness this great event.  All of the children that was there thought that it was great.  The butterflies moved at such a slow but still a graceful way, sometimes gliding in what little breeze there was.  Now that we know that the travle through our part of the country maybe next year we will also be watching for the great migration of the monarch butterflies.
Five Monarchs were seen flying overhead during the 10:30-10:45 observation time.

My husband and I went out this weekend to tag Monarchs.  Near Russellville, AR. we tagged 163 Monarchs in one field.  We had to stop tagging because we ran out of tags.  Still lots of Monarchs left in the field.  This was on Monday, Sept. 29th.  On Saturday 27th, and Sunday 28tth and Monday 29th we have tagged 525 Monarchs.  This is the most we have ever seen and I believe it must be the peak.

Hi! Just thought I'd report that I observed a few hundred monarchs today in a nectaring area in Bethlehem, PA. heaviest day of the season so far. I notice there is always a strong spike every year this same week, only a day or two different from year to year. Conditions were perfect. High pressure blowing in northwest winds. They had their minds on nectaring. High of 63 degrees but nice sun and cloud mix. Thought you might like to know.

Contributed to Monarch WatchMigration Highlight

144 monarchs sighted between 3 and 4 PM Sept 28 along a 15 mile stretch of Hwys 160 and 65 near Branson, MO.  Often there were 5 or more flying together in a loose group.  All were headed in a southwesterly direction. Many more uncounted individuals were observed on Sept 27 and earlier in the day of Sept 28.  These numbers followed the passage of strong cold front on Sept 27.  Gusty NW winds 10 to 15 mph characterized both days when the monarchs were observed.

Hundreds of adults flying south both on Monday the 29th and Tuesday the 30th. Very few nectaring. Many flying in groups of up to six. Most of them on the large side. All looking very healthy.

Relaying the reports of L. Anderson and L. Peterson from Beach Haven.

Today in about a one hour time slot I saw approx. 13 monarchs heading south.This was the most I've seen at any onetime here in such a short time. Usually I've only seen 4-5 at the most.My father was at a place in N. Ridgeville, Ohio and said they saw approx. 30 monarchs flying in a southerly direction. They were up high in the sky and flying and not stopping and feeding anywhere.
In Cleveland, Ohio today I saw a steady stream of high flying monarchsheading due south. I counted 18 in a 20 minute span at 11.30 am undermostly sunny skies.

We observed monarchs over the past month to determine peak migration. September 20th-27th appears to be our peak migration, we saw 33 monarchs.This was the week following the hurricane. Normally,peak migration for this area is earlier in September. We observed no monarchs during the hurricane.

Yesterday between 11-1130am morning I counted 13 monarch butterflies flying high and heading directly south flying very high. My father was in Sheffield,OH and saw 30 monarchs flying very high and heading south.
I counted approximately 50 Monarchs during a 10 minute observation.
Seeing about 100 per hour.  7mi hour north wind is helping to carry them south.
Sightings have increased to 200 per hour.  7 mile per hour north wind is helping to carry them south.
hundreds of monarchs passed by our shop today, all day every few minutes (seconds even) we would see 2-3 at a time.

On Oct. 2 our first grade students at the Episcopal School of Dallas in Dallas, Texas observed hundreds of monarch butterflies flying south over our playground.The temperature was in the high 70's, the wind light from the north, and the sky partly cloudy. The monarchs appreared exceptionally large. They were flying approximately 20 to 100 feet from the ground in a southerly direction. We raise monarch butterflies in our classroom, then tag and release them to join the fall migration. The children were thrilled to see such a spectacular sight.
Monarchs passing through the woods at a rate of 10 per minute
Monarchs continuing to be sighted passing through at a rate of 8 to 10 per minute and some resting on trees.

On my way to class I counted 24 Monarchs in about 15 minutes.  Channel 8 did a story  on a lady who had Lots of Monarchs roosting in her tree.  It was beautiful,  the lady lives in Carrolton which is north of  Dallas.
Saw more that 20 Monarchs on a small patch of Goldenrod, at the edge of a rural road.  Have also been seeing many individual Monarchs for the last week over North Dallas.
While sitting in a football stadium, Monarchs flew just over the up of the stadium. I observed 30 to 50 within two hours.

Well, I thought last week might be the peak monarch migration through North Texas, but since we've been having such interesting weather, I decided to wait and keep watching, and sure enough on Sunday (10/5) the monarchs filled the skies floating through on a cloudy and warm/humid afternoon following am rains.  There were literally hundreds in the air all afternoon, and dozens descended upon my butterfly bushes (Buddleia sp.) to nectar.  Later in the evening, a woodland roosting area appeared orange from a distance due to the immense numbers of roosting monarchs!  J

The monarchs have really been pouring through southwest Arkansas.  We don't usually have large number of them, but this year they are here by the hundreds.  They were especially abundant at Grandview Prairie in Hempstead County.  We were there from about 3:30 through 5:30 P.M. on Saturday, Oct. 4.  We were able to tag 50 monarchs without moving our car.  We also tagged another 25 before we left.  We counted well over 300 monarchs.  The ones that were flying were headed in a west to southwest direction.  The ones that were feeding were mostly on Scaly Blazing Star.  In fact all of the ones we caught to tag, except two were feeding on these flowers.

On a drive on Preston Rd. counted 129 flying south in about 15 minutes.  Usually flying in small groups of 2-4, but maybe all traveling together.  At home, took some pictures and probably saw 100 more flying over.  So beautiful!We live 1/2 hour north of Dallas.  Today must be a peak.
We have seen monarchs all day today, especially while traveling along the local highways. We've seen one right after the other.

Today was unbelievable!!!!!!  This morning I was riding my horse when Monarchs started coming out of the sky,  6 at a time,  5 at a time,  2 and 1 at a time.  It was wonderful, everywhere I looked there were Monarchs and this went on for a few hours.  They were flying high, low and in between.  A few were nectaring on the Mexican milkweed I have, but mainly they were flying south.  This evening they were still coming.
Finally, we have spotted groups of monarchs in the Rockport/Gloucester area.  Butterflies nectar for a while and then take off SW.
Several monarchs were seen on our buddlia bushs along with some viceroys and numerous painted ladies.

Saturday September 27th- 2 students (Chris and Ryan) from my class spotted and counted about 67 monarchs flying southwest within about 1 hour time span.   This was during a parade in  DeSoto Missouri (Bicentennial).  Some appeared to be mating.Sunday September 28th-I observed about 2 dozen monarchs within a 2 hour time span headed south.   This is while I was jogging outdoors at about 2:30 PM.   It was sunny and warm but brezzy.   This weekend, as we have observed, was the last weekend in the St. Louis area for remaining warmer low temps at night.   After this weekend, the lows dropped significantly.   Prior to this weekend, we had not observed significant numbers of monarchs.
Observed large numbers of Monarchs passing through eastern Oklahoma at Sequoyah State Park in Cherokee County. Monarchs were roosting in the oak trees along the eastern edge of Fort Gibson Lake.

Yesterday afternoon, Tues. Oct. 7, 2003 I counted 405 monarchs in just under an hour . It was misting rain, temps mid-50s, low hanging clouds, no wind; mostly powered flight and some gliding, heading S-SW toward Looking Glass Rock on the beautiful Pisgah National Forest. Around 5:30 pm they started to sail around and then into some of the giant red oaks at the overlook, and likely roosted there for the night. Most flew into the oaks where there was some early fall coloration from the anthocyanins, perhaps being interpreted for other aggregating monarchs? I breathed a big sigh of relief as I feared TS Isabel had swept them out to sea from the East Coast areas north of WNC.

This afternoon was cool with puffy clouds and light westerly wind. It was a Cooper's Hawk day, with 14 soaring over my house in Broken Bow in about an hour.

But more amazing and interesting (to me) were the hundreds, maybe thousands of Monarch Butterflies soaring over at all altitudes. Some were just specks in my 8.5 power binocs, all heading southwest. The last two days have been similar, but not so many passing by. A busy time in this area.

Posted to OK Birds
A friend reports large clusters of monarchs at Boothbay Harbor and at Popham Beach in Maine Oct. 5

Yesterday, students in class counted over one thousand Monarchs in their daily observations. Today the number has decreased to 200 sightings. It would seem that our peak has passed by! We'll keep recording!

Mrs. McCoy's first grade class at Willie Brown Elementary witnessed the Monarch Buttlerfy's miracle.  None of the children or their teacher had ever seen so many monarchs in one place.  As we walked out of the gym at 11:10 on Friday, we looked up to see a dark gray cloud.  No, it wasn't a rain cloud; we were watching thousands of monarchs flying south.  The class observed for thirty minutes as the mass of monarchs grew smaller and smaller.  We found that if we were very quiet, some of the butterflies would float down close enough for us to be able to see through their wings. What a sight!

Today was in the mid 70s with no breeze, and the Monarchs were out in full force!  I caught and tagged 24 in 15 minutes in a clover field.  Every 10 feet was another Monarch, and they seemed to be languishing in the warm sun.

Visited an event at the the Balcones Canyonlands National Wildlife Refuge today celebrating the 100th birthday of National Wildlife Refuges. From 1:00-2:00 just observed a queen, tawny emperor, numerous sulphurs, but starting at 2:15 we began seeing monarchs dropping down out of the clouds. We counted 50 every two minutes for the next half hour. They continued to move overhead. It was very overcast, temperature in the low 70's, wind 0-5 miles an hour. Then the wind became breezy and the rain began to fall. The monarchs started heading into the large oak trees and began roosting high overhead.

This fall has been amazing for monarch sightings in our area.  During the week of October6-10 monarchs were passing through our woods at a rate of more than 30 per minute.  This week we are only seeing the occasional straggler.  However last weekend a group of us was driving north on US 281 from Marble Falls to Hico and Monarchs were approaching us at about 5 per second!  We stopped just north of Evant, TX and saw what we thought was a flock of blackbirds high in the sky.  When we put our binoculars on the "birds" they turned out to be hundreds of monarchs.

Sunday, 12th of October, at 11:50 a.m. began a drive across the Causeway (26 Miles) to Metairie, LA (a suburb of New Orleans, LA) which ended at 12:40 p.m.. In total I counted 60 heading west south west.Today, 13th, back at Sunset Point, Mandeville, LA 70448, (St. Tammany Parish), in a fairly fresh morning, 10:40 a.m., The Monarchs were there, with partly sunny weather, some periods of overcast, but then breaking into only high clouds looking to be moving south. The Monarchs were nectaring on lantana, as opposed to available goldrenrod, (the preference in my garden, 129 Miles to the north), wild verbena, and one of the white eupatoriums, which was their choice last weekend throughMonday. Netted and tagged three today.

I was seeing at least 10 per minute between 10:40 and 12:45 p.m. Some scooting along the coastline of the north side of Lake Pontchartrain, to the Causeway which is about 1 mile away. Others were going over the drive area of the scenic point,and they were also m

October 16, 2003
This has been the most intense butterfly season in this area since at least back in 1972. I have been spotting migrants between Meridian, Ms and Laurel, MS for more than a month. We are seeing migrants all over Laurel, Ms. They are all heading into the sun and they are all at that telltale height doing the bat, bat, glide motion. Today I saw three within a block and a half of 7th Avenue and 7th Street, within 1/2 a minute in time.

October 9, 2003
September 18, 2003
Migration Highlight
When  I saw it , it was sunny and at 5.00.It was Thursday,and at Chandler T.X  seconde street there were 3.

Students in our class have seen an estimated total of about 65 monarchs over a period of the last two weeks. Some were seen on our school grounds; or while students were coming to school or going home. Three students were fishing Sunday and saw monarchs near Lake Houston. Most of them were eating nectar or on plants. Several have been seen flying southwest without stopping. Two of these sightings happened in Clear Lake and near Arlington, TX.
West end of Galveston Island, 10 monarchs per minute flying by our beachhouse heading west.

Ayer y hoy han estado pasando miles de mariposas monarca. Observé desde la Presa la Amistad hasta Acuña y Piedras Negras más o menos una franja como de 120 kilometros de longitud, muchas volaban muy bajo por lo que eran embestidas por los automovilistas, es un espectáculo muy bonito el que tuvimos estos dos días. Hace frío y no se están deteniendo para descansar. Les pasé la película de las Mariposas a los alumnos de 4, 5 y 6 de primaria y a los de Preparatoria del Colegio Americano donde estudian mis hijos y les interesó bastante. Ahora las pueden ver físicamente y están muy interesados en conocerlas mejor.Adicionalmente están llegando al área de la Presa la Amistad los Pelícanos que al parecer provienen de Canadá

Courtesy of Correo Real

Driving the Causeway both ways and a couple of hours apart. 224 Monarchs around 2:00 p.m. on the southbound and 449 Monarchs around 5:15 p.m. on the northbound trip arriving back in Mandeville at 5:53 p.m  I saw and noted different migration patterns in different areas of the Causeway.  There were no Monarchs south of the old causeway turnaround going in either direction.  It would seem that the Monarchs are using the bridge to a point, then cutting off across the water.  There were definitely more on the northshore side of the bridge and they were moving directionaly towards the southwest.

Tagging and Observing peak migration at Sunset Point from 2:00 p.m. until 6:20 p.m.  13 Monarchs netted and tagged.  Monarchs observed moving in a west south westerly direction towards Lake Pontchartrain Causeway and beyond.  The flow on Monarchs ranged from 10 and 15 per minute to 5 per minute towards sunset.Another 11 Monarchs netted and tagged at the same location on Monday, October 20 between 9:54 a.m. and 11:25 a.m.I noted 10 per minute in the early hours and tappering at this location to 5 per minute closer to the noon hour.Moved to a different location in the afternoon....under a separate posting.

I drove out Lake Avenue in Lacombe, La, a long single lane gravel road into the marshlands out to a point looking south across the water at the end of the road.  Just at the last block of pavement before the road turns narrow and to gravel, there is a road off to the right called Mildred Drive. Along this little lane, which borders on the Bayou Savage Wildlife Management Area and Goose Point Marshlands Area is growing goldenrod, asters, eupatorium (wild ageratum), and some other flowers including a very tall pink penstimon, which they were not nectaring on, and loads of hemp vine flowers, some orange lantana, and some other small bright bluish purple flowers.  Also, a yellow flower that I am not familiar with.  I have photos of everything  and most of the Monarchs I tagged.  There were so many Monarchs along the lane that my hand was getting cramp from filling out the tag sheets.  When I first beheld the Monarchs on Mildred Drive, they were in the little curve and coming down the hill

Hoy desde las 10 de la mañana estamos observando nubes de mariposas Monarca pasando por casi toda la ciudad. Por la tarde impartí un taller para niños en el Museo Minipape y salimos a contar mariposas. Estuvimos contabilizando un promedio de 27 mariposas por minuto.

Esta mañana viajé a Monterrey y conté a las mariposas que cruzaban frente a mí cruzando la carretera desde la salida de Saltillo hasta la entrada a Santa Catarina y contabilicé 1230 mariposas en 35 minutos. También observe algunas durante la mañana en el Planetario.

Courtesy of Correo RealMigration Highlight
Wednesday, October 22, we had 4 butterflies nectaring in the butterfly gardeen at school.  This is the most we've seen since September 15th.

This is a report from a friend, Ted Dracos who observed monarchs west of Del Rio a little over a week ago (10/15/03)  "The migration around Reagan Wells has been very slow but steady. However, I was driving west of Del Rio two days after the current high pressure ridge blew out all that rain we'd been having - about 9 days ago - and I saw more monarchs than I've ever seen at one time. Clouds of them - all heading SW. It was great, except I kept on swerving my car to avoid individuals without success - but did endanger my life a few times. What a drive that was though. Very memorable".

I spent the day mostly in a vehicle driving first around town and then down to southeastern Mississippi on Highway 15, Highway 98, in the counties of Jones, George, and Perry over to a small hamlet called Leaksville to pick up some lumber.The first Monarch I spotted this morning was in the quadrant of my mother's apartment building, looking around for nectar at the second floor level, around 10:50 a.m..  I observed Monarchsflying in a migration direction virtually every 5 minutes until around 4:45 p.m.  They were in all parts, on the eastern and western sides of Laurel, Ms, then when we headed south, theywere crossing the highways on a regular basis.  For the most part they are flying at 30 to 50 feet, but occasionally would be at almost windshield height, so I was doing some ducking in the passenger seat, as I saw them, and then my driver caught on, and paid more attention.  We didn't actually smash any, but still it was a hyper moment, trying to physically will them over the
IT WAS AT 4.00 AND COLD. I SAW IT AT THE PARK.

Early this morning I saw a large group of Monarchs flying overhead as we were driving to school.  There may have been fifty or more.  We had a long rainfall yesterday, and it got clear today, so maybe the weather pushed them south.

Oct 26, 2003, Total of 480 on bridge, driving at a speed of 55 mph.  On to Sunset Point where there was plenty more action:1:19 p.m. arrived at Sunset Point, Mandeville, La after crossing the Lake Pontchartrain Causeway Bridge from Metairie, La.  When we arrived at the point, the count of overhead migrational flying of Monarchs was thick, and they were flying between 60 and 20 feet.  At the beginning of my count taking 5 minutes, I was counting 20 to 30 in a line across the point, directly overhead, and the these lines were 2 to 3 feet apart.  My heart nearly jumped out of my chest at the sight of so many flying rapidly against the northwest wind as they flew in a southwesterly direction.   Based on 5 minutes of time and 20 to 30 per 5 seconds, (average 25) would indicate 1500+- Monarchs flew across my line of view.  (I don't know how to count that many, so if Chip has a system, I would like to know how to use it.)Tagged 92 Monarchs, lots of photos of people joining the fun

Hace algunos días les escribía diciendo que era raro que para estas fechasno se vieran tantas mariposas monarcas como en otros años. Pero ya hoy enla mañana pudimos ver varios cientos volar sobre el Parque Chipinque. Juntocon la monarcas y como otros años, también compartían el cielo con las llamadaspicudas o gallitos, dos o tres especies diferentes de pieridos amarillos y algunas fritilarias del golfo.

El día de hoy al regresar de la casa a la oficina, me encontré con el paso de las monarcas nuevamente, sólo que esta vez si no volteas y pones mucha atención al cielo, no es posible percibirlas, ya que están volando muy alto y algunas parecen un punto negro en el cielo. El 15 de Octubre realice un conteo de 25 mariposas en un minuto tomando como referencia un rango de 25 m entre el observador y un punto fijo a una altura no mayor de cuatro metros. El día era soleado despejado y templado sin viento a las 10:00 am. Como referencia cabe mencionar que los pobladores de Sabinas Coah. no habían observado mariposas en días anteriores. Este día su flujo fue casi continuo y con la misma intensidad desde Sabinas a Muzquiz; se les pudo observar durante todo el trayecto, a una altura no mayor de cuatro metros.

01 y 02 de Noviembre del 2003, continua el paso de las Mariposas Monarca por la ciudad de Querétaro. Las mariposas monarca siguen pasando por la ciudad, generalmente en las tardes, su paso durante estos dos días fue de alrededor de 20 mariposas por minuto. A su paso por el estado de Querétaro las mariposas abarcan una franja de aproximadamente 60 km. de ancho, pasando por diversas poblaciones como Querétaro, Bernal, Ezequiel Montes, Pedro Escobedo, Tolimán.

November 2, 2003:  Arrived at Sunset Point at 4:55 p.m. and netted 9 Monarchs in 18 minutes, 5:00 p.m. to 5:18 p.m. Tagged all. Released immediately after tagging.  Crossed the causeway after sunset.November 3, 2003:  Crossing Lake Pontchartrain Causeway Bridge, northbound, 3:05 p.m. to 3:35 p.m. counted 154 migrational Monarchs.Arrived at Sunset Point at 3:38 p.m. and tagged first Monarch at 4:15 p.m.  Netted and tagged 25 Monarchs by 4:55 p.m.All these Monarchs has been directionally flying, even when moving from nectar source to nectar source.  The weather on the Sunday was perfect.  Beautiful sunset.  The weather on Monday was another perfect day.  Nectar plants included asters, (preferred), lantana, goldenrod.  The gulf frits pair up on the Monarchs and run them away from the lantana bushes.  Also lots of blue eupatatoriums, but not a favorite with the Monarchs at this time.

Monarch butterflies on migration were sighted in Yucca Arizona during the week of 10/19/03.  Peaking on about 10/20/03 and continuing to dwindle thru 11/06/03. (Not sure exaclty how to word this sighting, I guess I could use an example or some tips on proper reporting).  I photographed the Monarchs on 10/20/03 and there were 30 to 40 present at any given time at about 9:00am.  on 11/06/03 there were about 3 or 4 present per hour during the day.

My seventh grade life science classes  captured , tagged and released 17 monarchs from the butterfly garden located outside our classroom today.  There were only 5 females  and 12 males.  Usually it is almost equal male and females that we capture.  The students discovered a preying mantid making a meal of a monarch.

We saw tons of Monarchs at soccer practice.  The whole field saw them.  We pointed them out to our team.  It was like a huge wave.  They were black dots in the sky.  At first we thought they were birds, but we figured out they were Monarchs.  There were at least 5 or 6 hundred.  They were all heading on their journey south.

I think the migration at this latitude is over.

September 1st, high 80's, sunny, at least 100 monarchs still nectaring. The evening and night were warm above 70 and they never group-roosted. They were in the woods but spread out and single or doubles.

The next day, September 2nd, was hot and sunny, yet not many monarchs--maybe 10.

At the Holiday Beach Migration Observatory outside of Windsor, Ontario, we have a 40ft tower where hawk counters monitor the fall migration of hawks, songbirds, hummingbirds and now the tagging of Monarchs.

Today our counter indicated many hundred monarchs were flying over the tower early afternoon at rather low altitudes. He was able to see them with his naked eye; no binocs or scope necessary. Winds were out of the south at 5-10 mph all day. Dense fog covered the area until well into midmorning. These were not particularly good conditions for any type of migration yet our Monarchs were moving.

I was down on the ground where my husband and I were banding songbirds and hummers. I saw just a few Monarchs that were definitely within a "distinct directionality of their flight" ;on the move. The temperature was 86° F and very humid.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

In late afternoon, the largest daily observational count of the season turned up 525 monarchs in an hour and one-half at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Once again two fields of clover were providing the key source of nectar for the migrating monarchs.

More activity was apparent across central Iowa during the day. In the midday hours, 17 monarchs were observed in our butterflly garden in Altoona, and single monarchs could be seen floating across the roadways on the way south.

I live in West Bend WI, (just 15 minutes north of Milwaukee) and since yesterday morning (9/21/04) I have seen about 50 monarchs all flying southward. There doesnt seem to be as many as last year, but we are still seeing them heading south! Look for these little guys coming your way soon!

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

"A steady flight of Monarchs was observed all day long with perhaps several thousand moving through the area," reported those monitoring raptor migration at Lake Erie Metropark.

The southeast Michigan area is a very important autumn site for migrating raptors. It is situated at the end of a geographic funnel formed by Lakes Ontario, Erie and Huron. Because migrating raptors from eastern Canada are reluctant to cross these lakes, the geography diverts the birds in their journey south and west, concentrating their numbers as they cross the comparatively narrow Detroit River near the western end of Lake Erie.

See the Southeast Michigan Raptor Research website for more information.

Captured 16 during a day of activities at our park --- perfect migrating weather --- winds from NW and bright beautiful sunshine for the first time in two weeks --- Other than this day we haven't seen many but are sending a hundred or so that we raised ourselves on to Mexico with tags!

I've just returned from Page County in Southwestern Iowa. I was happily surprised at the number of monarchs flying south. The ones I saw looked very good in color and wing form. Page, Union and Montgomery County all seemed to have great numbers. These monarchs were observed well away from the Interstate system on county roads.

A number of people in the Shenandoah (Page County), Iowa, area reported clustering in large numbers and have seen the clustering for about a week now. Unfortunately I didn't have my tagging stuff with me, but the sight of the large number of monarchs was very welcome. Especially after so few during the summer. I still maintain, Iowa had such a wet and cold spring, they flew right over us. But they are stopping by this fall! And being welcomed by many!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

A weekend visit to Ontario's Long Point Provincial Park included many observations of Monarchs heading along the 40 km sand spit which runs east into Lake Erie. Over the 2 days we observed many at the "Monarch's Rest" Campground searching for nectar sources (asters in full bloom and goldenrod past prime). Most headed along the spit (i.e. eastward) as they had to battle strong west winds off the lake.

This morning, the lake and the winds were calmer and we observed a steady flow along the beach with a few attempting to make the risky crossing of lake Erie (I estimate 30km of open water from Long Point to the American side).It was encouraging to see so many after a summer of so few and limited signs of migration back in Oakville, on the NW shore of Lake Ontario, where we live. We have had, however, sunny, warm and clear skies for the last 2 weeks (mid 20's C) with another fine weather week to come. I hope that the good weather has allowed many eggs/larvae/pupae to successfully mature.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

I read with interest the observation from Ontario. After three weeks of looking for monarchs to tag and finding few, we are finally seeing them today in strong numbers along the south Lake Erie shore in our favorite goldenrod/aster tagging fields. This is late for us, and surely not as heavy a migration as last year. In the ten years or so that I have been tagging, I have never recaptured a tagged monarch originating in Canada. I tagged about 40 in an hour this afternoon, but our total at this time last year was well over 400!

A river of Monarchs passed over today. This was mostly observed from our place 5 km NE of Utopia in SW Bandera Co.., but we ranged southeast as noted.

By noon I had seen a few Monarchs in the yard, passing south (S) to southsouthwest (SSW). By 1 it was about 6-8. At 1:30 I saw 5 at once, and grabbed my binocs and started scanning. 1:32 to 1:37 standing at one end of my porch I was counting 100 perminute. All going S to SSW. They were everywhere. Up high 100', groupsthermalling. I walked around trying to get a vantage point from the bowl we're in, and for a half hour, anywhere you looked you saw a hundred as fast as youcould count them. A minute. I would look east, and count a hundred within one binoc field of view, within a quarter mile, and it was the same to thewest behind me.

Between 2:10 & 2:30 it seemed to slow to 50 per minute in everydirection. It seemed to me that ten thousand passed at minimum in the hour, and itwas likely twice that, or more. This was a slice of a kilometer or so width,of a mass of unknown width. So we headed to town (Utopia) 5 km SW. All along the way the river continued in density as fast as you could count them(100/min. approx). The town was full of them, but shortly after getting north oftown they decreased rapidly. There were only small numbers of them at LostMaples SNA later in the afternoon.

However back here at the adobe, at 6:30 p.m. theywere still going over to the SSW at the rate of 10 per minute. This leads me tobelieve they continued in high numbers here (after I left), for some time. Theywere not further north in the valley, and were clearly coming into the SabinalRiver Valley from the NE, mid valley or so..... anyway, some settled in and are roosting,so there should be a liftoff tomorrow. It was some moving movent moments. The passage lasted probably 5 hours, with a 2-3 hour peak, and it was at leasta couple kilometers wide, with therefore thousands per hour. Considering most were early in the afternoon, I would expect they made if off the escarpmentalready, only 10 miles south. I wouldn't be surprised if there were 100,000 that passed.....

Contributed by Texas Monarch Watch

deep in central Mexico.

Monday, September 19--No monarchs anywhere.
Midmorning thunderstorms. Temperatures in mid-70s. Winds from the west.

Sunday, September 18: Monarchs 2
Two bright monarchs nectaring at the hydrangeas. Saw three others in flight during the afternoon and early evening. Sunny, with temperatures in upper 80s. Shoreline winds were from the east, tapering off farther west.

Saturday, September 17: Monarchs 1
One monarch at the hydrangeas. Two others in flight during the afternoon. Temps in mid-70s. Shoreline winds from the east.

We don't expect to see more than the occasional straggler now. The hydrangeas are rapidly fading, so they would not be the best host plants. Still, we are seeing very few monarchs elsewhere in the area.

Thursday, September 15: Monarchs 1
We saw one monarch--a very tattered and faded individual-- on the hydrangeas nearest Lake Michigan. It was not moving at all. Today was one of our few cloudy days all summer, with temps in the lower 70s. Usually, we see some in-dividual monarchs in flight around town during the day or early evening. Today and yesterday we did not see any at all.

Wednesday, September 14: Monarchs 0
For the first time in more than a month, we found no monarchs at all at the three sites we have been monitoring. We had some overnight storms, but the rain ended long before dawn and had probably passed over Lake Michigan before any monarchs would have departed Michigan this morning. We'll keep monitoring over the next several days and let you know if things change appreciably. But, I think this time the peak may really have passed.

Tuesday, September 13: Monarchs 11
Today's numbers dropped even more. Only 11 total. The site nearest Lake Michigan did not host even one monarch when we were there! Temperature 90 degrees Fahrenheit, sunny and humid. The hydrangeas are beginning to wilt in this prolonged and unusual late heat spell. Still, they have plenty of blossoms.

After leveling off in the low hundreds over the weekend, the monarch numbers at our observation sites plummeted today. Here are the daily reports:

Monday, September 12: Monarchs 19
We saw just 19 monarchs total at the three sites. Temperature 84 degrees Fahrenheit, lakeshore breezes continued from the east.

Sunday, September 11: Monarchs 102
We counted 102 monarchs at the three nectaring sites. The day was partly cloudy, humid, with temperatures in the upper 80s.

Saturday, September 10: Monarchs 117
117 monarchs nectared at the three groups of hydrangeas. Temperatures were in the upper 80s, with east winds along the Lake Michigan shoreline.

September 9: Monarchs 119
The monarch numbers continued to drop today. We counted 119 total at the three locations. At one site, however, grounds crews had just finished sprinkling again, so that could have had some impact on the numbers there. Temperature 84 degrees Fahrenheit. On the lakeshore, east winds still dominated.

September 8: Monarchs 145
After climbing for the last three days, our monarch numbers fell to 145 total for the three locations today. Still a substantial number compared to past years at this time. Our storm last night was very brief and came after dark, so it probably did not have much effect on migration. Temperature 77 degrees Fahrenheit, winds from the east.

Wednesday, September 7: Monarchs 240
Our monarch count at the three locations continued to go up today. We saw at least 240, including some arriving at the hydrangeas from the beach. The east wind was a little stronger today. Temperature, under sunny skies, was 84 degrees Fahrenheit. We have storms predicted for tonight, and possibly tomorrow, so we will see how that affects the migration.

After staying low through Sunday, the monarch count at the three nectaring locations I've been monitoring took a surprising turn on Monday. Here are the daily reports:

Tuesday, September 6: Monarchs 219
Our monarch count jumped to a total of at least 219--the highest we have ever observed! It was difficult to count them accurately, as individuals kept rising, floating above the hydrangeas, then coming to rest again. But, with my husband, Jim, assisting me, I believe we got a pretty accurate count. Winds were from the east, temperature 84 degrees Fahrenheit. We have been watching the monarch migration closely for several years, and we do seem to be seeing more than usual this year. For the most part, conditions have been ideal for crossing Lake Michigan from the east and northeast--warm, mild, no storms. The drought we have been experiencing here may actually be helping the monarchs. Some years, we see scores washed up on the Lake Michigan beaches after being caught in storms while crossing the lake.

Monday, September 5: Monarchs 121
To our surprise and delight, the monarch count at our nectaring locations soared to 121--a new peak--today! The jump surprised us, since the southeast winds would have made migration across Lake Michigan more difficult than on recent days. Of course, we do not know what the conditions were in Michigan when they started out this morning. It was a sunny day, with temperatures in the mid-80s.

Sunday, September 4: Monarchs 13
Our count jumped to 13 under partly cloudy skies, temperature about 80 again, wind from the east. Two of the nectaring monarchs may not have been migrating, or, if they were, they faced a more difficult journey than most. One was very faded and missing half of one forewing. The other was battered, with crimped forewings that did not extend completely.

Saturday, September 3: Monarchs 7
We saw only 7 monarchs at the hydrangea nectaring sites. Temperature about 80 degrees Fahrenheit. Sunny. Throughout the afternoon and evening, we saw perhaps 10 more high-flying monarchs heading west.

September 2: Monarchs 7
Our nectaring monarch population had a very slight uptick today--a total of 7 at the three sites. We saw one of the monarchs flying across the beach to nectar at the hydrangeas nearest to Lake Michigan. Today's northeast winds would have helped potential migrators from Michigan. Temperature was about 80 degrees Fahrenheit under sunny skies. Several cabbage whites, one painted lady, one sulphur, and one comma butterfly joined the monarchs at the hydrangeas.

September 1: Monarchs 4
The monarch numbers at the three sites I am monitoring diminished even more today. I saw only four--one at the first site, two at the second, one at the third. The day was a bit hotter--83 degrees Fahrenheit--and the wind had diminished, but was still from the north. The hydrangeas, a variety of hydrangea paniculata, still attract large numbers of hornets, spider wasps, and other wasps. Last week we also saw about one painted lady a day among the monarchs, but we have not seen any this week.

August 31: Monarchs 13
The monarch numbers at the three observation sites on Northwestern University's campus continue to dwindle. Today's total at about the same time was only 13. Temperature in the mid-70s, wind from the northeast. Not as sunny as the last few days.

August 30: Monarchs 22
Today, at about the same time, with similar conditions to the last few days, but with slightly stronger winds from the east, we saw only 22 total at the three sites. At one site, however, the university grounds crew had just finished watering, so any monarchs could have been disturbed and flown off. We did, however, see four on those hydrangeas, about the same as yesterday's five.

Monday, August 29: Monarchs 31
At the same time, we counted only 31 total. East winds from Lake Michigan prevailed on all three days and temperatures ranged from upper 70s to low 80s under sunny skies.

August 27th and 28th: Monarchs 100
I may have seen the peak migration on Saturday and Sunday. For about 2 weeks, I have been checking three groups of hydrangea plantings on Northwestern University's campus that attract migrating monarchs. At about 2 pm, the total number of nectaring monarchs increased steadily with each passing day. On Saturday and Sunday, they totaled almost 100.

We went over to Lake Michigan (on the Michigan side of the lake) on Aug 30th 6 PM. There was a great monarch migration going on, the wind concentrating them on the lakeshore. In one binocular view, saw 162 in 3 minutes.

The butterflies were migrating until almost dark, then just dropped into the trees with a beautiful sunset over the lake. We were watching from a high dune and from the beach. Did not see clusters forming, just wafting into the trees and settling nilly-willy in the twilight.

Seeing them overhead or straight out, they were just floating with wings set, letting the wind carry them. Sometimes they were going sideways and sometimes even backwards.

There was also a dragonfly migration going on but it seemed lower in number (although they were harder to see).

Winds were out of the ENE 8-11 mph. Observations were made Saugatuck-Douglas, Michigan.

My family and I climbed Owl's Head Mountain, a little mountain in Keene NY, on Sunday 9/4/05. At the summit we were amazed at the monarchs streaming by. In the span of about a half hour we counted easily 80 butterflies flying across the top of this mountain.

Owls Head Mountain is about 2200 feet. The weather was cool and misting in the morning but as the afternoon arrived it had cleared and was partly sunny with temps in the seventies. We were on top from 3:30- 4pm. The winds I believe were from the northeast at maybe 10-15mph. There were monarchs flying lower than us and some flying maybe thirty feet over us while we were on the summit but most were flying at eye level across the summit along the same path.

We were at the Michigan City, Indiana lakefront (Lake Michigan) today and noticed HUNDREDS of monarchs coming through. Thought you might be interested!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

I am told that out on High Bluff Island, hundreds of monarchs were congregating on the thistles there (the farthest point of land out in the lake, with some returning to the mainland and others crossing the lake).

Hundreds and hundreds of monarchs on the Toronto Islands and monarchs clustered in the trees there. I was walking around and noticed a few trees that were full (well, 100s and 100s) of monarchs in them. My best guess is that they're "waiting". It was beautiful.

The temps are still warm here, in the 70's at night and 80's during the day. There is a slight breeze from the south. Like other observations there are a few dragonflies in the same area.
There have been 100-200 monarchs roosting in ash trees in my front yard for the last 2 weeks. Was curious to learn more about their behavior and why they were here, so I found your site.

Many Monarchs seen today. We saw many on Aug 24 through 26 also. A photo and a .MOV movie from the August sightings can be viewed at: http://www.davelevasseur.com/images/100_0835.JPGandhttp://www.davelevasseur.com/images/100_0836.MOV --- Dave

hundreds of monarchs roosting in our shelter belt again today. nice day, wind from the south.

September 1
I leave for work at 6:20 a.m. so I asked my mom to watch the Monarchs this morning. She and my daughter saw hundreds again this a.m. about 8 o'clock. They had not left yet, still gathered in trees. Saw about one thousand total during the day in early afternoon and again about 6:30 p.m. also.

August 30
This was AMAZING! There had to be thousands of Monarchs roosting along an alfalfa field. The field also has clover. The roost was all along about a 1/2 mile grove of trees. We don't know the kind- some were box elder but some were maybe 40-50 foot tall with cherries on them also. At first we thought thre were hundreds--but the roost went on, and on, and on--with hundreds in each tree. How beautiful. I took lots of photos and some short videos on a digital camera. They were all on the south side of the trees. Little wind- maybe 10-15 miles or so. I can't wait to get home and go look again tonight. My husband saw them about 6:30, don't know when they arrived, hadn't been in that field lately before last night. Will report daily. YAY!!! August 31Saw Monarchs roosting again. Monarchs have begun to increase in numbers each day. Went out last night to check the areas where they usually roost and finding several monarchs getting ready to settle in for the night. I would think that in the next few days the peak of migration will be here. Nancy Newlon
Report from Janelle Tripp, farm just north of Lennox, SD:  They have hundreds of monarchs in their shelterbelt for the last two evenings.

On the 31st starting at 7 AM we checked the area at Muskegon State Park that we have checked the last 2 years for overnight roosts. The wind was N 8-11 mph, 63 degrees. In 1 hour 30 minutes we found about 325 monarchs, with clusters of 32, 28 and 20. At about 8:30 AM they seemed to leave the roost site (several acres of mixed pines and deciduous trees) and start migrating. We stopped in Grand Haven and again in Saugatuck/Douglas on our way south that morning and counted but the numbers migrating were smaller tha the previous evening (reported for 8/30/05), but then it was earlier in the day.Highest number seen roosting for the 3 years of observation.
Report from Mary Devany, Harrisburg, SD: hundreds roosting in trees next to her house nightly.
We got a call this morning from Gerald Kraft, 7 miles south of Wessington Springs, South Dakota, saying they had over 100 butterflies gathering in the evening along their cottonwood and willow trees.

We're seeing hundreds clustering in a few familiar sites in the Sioux Falls/Harrisburg, SD area. We are finally seeing numbers of migratory monarchs again here in easternSouth Dakota. Our "drought" of the last two years is apparently over.

In the last two days we tagged nearly 600! We aren't getting the calls in town like we used to (West Nile spraying?), but nearby towns and rural areas are calling and it's like the old days when you could easily get 20 or more in a single sweep of the net!

I live in the country outside of city limits. I discovered hundreds of monarchs randomly flying and choosing a roost for the night in my grove of trees (ash, maple, & Black Hills Spruce).    Weather facts for the day: Sunrise 6:49am Sunset 8:05pm Low temp 53 High temp 84; 0 precipitation, Wind North. I have never seen so many on the property before. I do have a large flower garden. Could that be the attraction? They remain on the property this morning - randomly flying. They were amiable to my photography efforts.

Observed one small group of monarchs roosting in a young ash tree's branches. There were 60 to 70 monarchs roosting at dusk with a few more straggling in out of the northeast.  All of these migrants were roosting together on the same branches and the east side of the tree.  This tree was in the midst of many large pines and located adjacent to the same nectar-laden field where my kids had been netting and tagging earlier that weekend. We have had high temps in the 70's and lows at night in the upper 50s.

Over a period of 30 minutes around 7 p.m., in the same area that I reported from yesterday (15 maples, 6 other trees), with a temperature of 57 degrees and wind speed of 5 mph, I observed the following clusters: 16, 7, 6, 5, 5, 6, 7, 4, 1, 11, 2, 12, 7, 1, 16, 3, and 32 flying about that I didn't see land (109 roosted and 32 flying to total 141).  Again, I was only counting those that I could see on the lowest branches.  Earlier in the day, around noon, I simply looked out my window and saw 9 roosting on the locust tree.  Last year I didn't count, but it seems like there are more monarchs this year.

August 28I am uncertain what they are doing here, but I sighted over 100 and possibly more monarchs in our trees. We have many trees on our property and my husband notice them 2 days ago (8/26/05). As of tonight they were still here. I don't know their flight path and if they have been here before. We have lived here for sometime now and haven't noticed them before. I was so excited about it that I wanted to learn more about what they really are doing. So I searched on the internet and found this web site.August 29I really do not know much about this. I just knew that it was unusual to see this many monarch butterflies at one time in your yard. I even came home at lunch today to see if they were still here. Which they were. Tonight it is around 6:00 PM and I was outside one time and did see a decrease in the number. I would imagine as of right now about 1/2 as many. I am going to go outside and try to observe them again.

For the past few days we have observed thousands of monarch butterflies in our windbreak and grove.

Migration Highlight

Over a period of 20 minutes, around 7 p.m. with a temperature of 54 degrees and a wind speed of about 2 mph, in an area of about 15 maples and six other trees, I counted the following clusters: 7, 2, 23, 11, 3, 2, 1, 2, 1 and four flying about that I didn't see land (56 total).  All of those counted were on the lowest branches, where I could see; and I was perhaps most likely to see the monarchs that had landed on dead or dying branches.  I managed to take a couple of nice pictures, too.

The Monarch population has certainly rebounded in my area. So far they don't seem very interesting in heading south (even on calm nights or North wind they are clustering in my yard). I expect that as soon as the wind comes out of the north again they will be off towards Mexico. It is sure fun to see numbers of butterflies again.
