I see the Monarchs here every summer at this time, clinging from the trees.  This location is relatively high, on a hill over a river valley.  They show up on the maple trees more than the others.  Today I saw up to 22 butterflies per branch.
Saw one butterfly yesterday in our front yard. Checked in the back yard and in the orchard this afternoon, and there were lots (100?).

It's that time of year. The Monarchs just keep flying one-by-one over our banding station. I love to watch their graceful and focused wing beats as they glide against the clear blue sky. It puts a smile on my face all day long. If they only knew how many of us are migrating with them in spirit.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

We are getting a steady stream of migrants coming through today, September 4. I was just out taking flight directions between 3 and 5 p.m. this afternoon. There was a leaf-rustling, small-branch-moving southeast wind this afternoon, and quite a few monarchs were being forced westward if they got more than 6 to 8 feet above the ground. But the ones that stayed low were making their way south-southwest to southwest. I recorded precise flight directions of 28 monarchs in two hours, and there were others that were too far away for me to reach.

There have also been large numbers aggregating in the oak savanna in McFarland Park, a county park about 6 miles north-northeast of Ames during the last few evenings.

So folks, keep smiling - they're on their way!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

August 26
Strong, tight roosts on 08/21 through 08/24 each night it was 55°f or lower. 55°f and lower seems to really encourage the concentrated roosts. Each day there are thousands nectaring on the flowers but on the warmer nights they roost in the trees as singles or groups of 5 or less. I've been experimenting with finding roosts. I have found several by looking for overgrown fields or ditches with many flowers blooming I then look for the nearest groups of trees. Then I return in the evening or early morn. So far I have had success 4 out of 5 locations. I think the key to finding roosts is very much dependent on finding the nectar source. Even when migrating hard they seem to stop for a sip.

While driving along the major expressway, highway 401, linking Montreal and Toronto today, there were many hundreds of monarchs crossing the roadway on their migration. Monarchs were observed flying into the north part of Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge as the fall migration continued to expand. Seventy monarchs were counted during an hour and one-half visit to the refuge. Monarchs were nectaring on thistles and tickseed sunflowers, and others were observed flying and floating across the prairie's big bluestem grasses.

August 31
The migrating monarch butterflies were highly active again at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, especially in a stand of tickseed sunflowers. During an observation visit of a bit more than an hour, 56 monarchs were counted. Many of them were found flying in and out of the tickseed sunflowers where they were nectaring. From a distance, only an occasional butterfly could be spotted floating into the mass of yellow flowers, but a walk into the center of the stand of plants brought one of those magical moments where the monarchs showed their colors by flying about in all directions. This was the first time this autumn when the monarchs were seen primarily on wildflowers other than thistles.

August 30
Early monarch migration activity was noted at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. During an hour and one-half visit, 44 monarchs were observed on the prairie. Most of them were nectaring on thistles even though other monarch favorites such as goldenrod and tickseed sunflowers are blooming now, too. It's interesting to note which wildflowers seem to be the favorites during different days in the fall migration season. In other years, goldenrod and tickseed sunflowers have proven to be popular at times with the migrating butterflies.

We had some rain this morning and since lunchtime we have a steady stream of monarchs going south with a nice breeze.Just in straight lines .Some follow rooftops,some the Sidewalk and others the border between the fields and gardens .If we sit in the front of the house or the backyard they are coming .I hope it is a good year for them .

My wife and I finished tagging monarchs on the 27th of August. We found a clover field right on the outskirts of Shawano. I tagged 29 in 40 minutes on the 26th and my wife and I tagged 90+ on the 28th in 2 hours. There were numerous species of butterflies in this field.

Painted ladies, milberts tortiseshell, fritillaries, cabbage whites, sulphers, and of course many, many monarchs. We had 175 tags this year. We tagged 150 and the other 25 I am saving for school. We were lucky because by the next weekend the field had been mowed and no more butterflies.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

This was a special day for monarch watching. During a three-hour morning visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, 615 monarchs were counted--the most during a visit this autumn. The monarchs were nectaring on a variety of sunflowers and thistles, and they were found in several areas of the refuge. More than a hundred were counted near a savanna trail that has woodlands on one side and the open prairie on the other, The monarchs were flying out of the woods onto the prairie and were nectaring on tickseed sunflowers. Another stand of tickseeds also has become a favorite stopping point, and a number of monarchs were counted there. Another 150 were nectaring in tall sunflowers, creating scenes of 5 to 10 monarchs billowing up from the plants into the sky at a single time. Near midday a powerful wind and rainstorm burst across the prairie, showing the natural threat that monarchs face during their migration south. Winds from the northwest hit more than 80 miles an hour in several place

Carold Mettler called to report 500 to 1000 monarchs roosting in her elm trees in the evening near Menno, South Dakota. She said she had many 3-4 years ago, but not nearly as many in the last couple years.

Point Pelee also had a good number.  Also present were two Giant Swallowtails.  I am sure there were others, but I was paying more attention to the birds.

Wow, how exciting the past few days have been! All of my 225 tags have been used quite easily this year. We tagged our final 57 monarchs by PM today, and boy if we had another 200 we could have tagged even more. We had a steady flow for the past 3 days, but today topped them all. When I went back out just to check during the day... I counted hundreds nectaring on the goldenrod, thistle and asters. The goldenrod is in full bloom and very little has started to turn brown. The monarchs were unhurried, as if they knew I was out of tags and didn't have my net.

Is it because we had such a hot dry summer that has brought the masses out? We are expecting temps in the 80's and 90's through the middle of the week. I am curious to see if they keep coming as they did today.

The hardest part for me is not having enough tags to continue to tag all that I have seen!! Talk about an addiction! Well, I just wanted to let you all know in the South-West that there are many coming your way, and I didn't tag them all!Good Luck and enjoy the best 2 weeks of the year!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Many monarchs roosting in the trees around 7:30 tonight on the edge of a clover field. Many more than 2 days ago. We pulled around 35 from the trees and tagged them. I am looking forward to going out tomarrow in the daylight to see how many there are, and hopefully tag more.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
MANY Monarch's are flying over our house at 6:40 pm. We have never seen this before. We have had many butterflies this year which is quite different from seeing only a few for the past several years.

On the beach in Cobourg on Friday Sept. 9th on a warm and sunny afternoon I counted a hundred butterflies. The beach is half a mile long and I estimate conservatively that there were 150 to 200 butterflies on it. They were close to the shore facing the edge of the water. Since then I have seen a few butterflies 4 or 5 per day but not in the same large numbers as Sept 9th (Friday). The weather continues to remain warm in the mid 70's (22-24C)and sunny. Best wishes, Your observer from Cobourg, Judy Smith

As I was standing outside of my workplace on 9/14/05 at about 10:00 a.m. I saw approximately 100-150 monarchs flying south. They would come in groups of about 10-20, with many flying solo or in groups of 3-4. I have never seen this before. I was also amazed by the difference in their flight patterns. Some were very high in the sky, and some were nearer to the ground. Very beautiful to see.

Just checked our Wisconsin birdnet news and found a post from Dan Panetti noting the movement of raptors along the Lake Michigan shoreline. He was at Concordia University in Mequon and also noted from 11:15 am until 11:45 am the passage OF OVER "500 MONARCHS" migrating south along the lake. An amazing 1/2 hour!!!!! Steve Kupcho (ret. 6th grade teacher - 3 years) Glad to see my old school district still has my e-mail address on file. 'Twas good to post to the 'Journey North" site again.
74 monarchs sighted flying through our backyard in one hour.

Sunday 09/11/05 tagged approx. 75 monarchs in clover field here in Ottumwa. There had to be hundreds nectaring, but I ran out of tags. Today, Sept 14, I saw at least 12 monarchs flying across the road in front of my car, and flying through our yard in Ottumwa. All flying fairly low, and heading in the southwest direction. Today was our first cooler day, with a high near 78, and winds around 5-10mph. Today was the first day I noticed so many Monarchs on the move.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Tagging Monarchs here in Toronto this year has been a pleasure. My wife and I tagged well over 400 last weekend. There are still thousands nectaring here. Over the weekend while we were tagging at a park (East Point) on the shore of Lake Ontario, two adults which had been tagged a day earlier were netted again, and this evening we noted clusters in the trees as dusk arrived.

Last year at this time we had tagged and released a total of 40, most of which were reared. This year we are over 500, the majority of which have been netted as adults. The numbers here are reminiscent of 2003.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

I drove 70 miles each way today from Omaha to the Audubon Society's Spring Creek Prairie southwest of Lincoln today to do a semi-weekly butterfly transect count. Saw 11 monarchs along my transect at , three of which were obviously migrating, and one of which was nectaring on dotted gayfeather. But the real fun was counting all the migrants crossing Interstate 80 as I drove down and back. Saw 87 on the way down (approximately 10 to 11 AMCDT) and 41 on the way back (approximately 2 to 3 PM). Today looks like the one perfect migration day that we get each September - temperatures in the 70's, very slight wind (from SE), clear skies. This is usually the peak week for us each year.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

WOW! In our rural town park at about 7:15 pm, after a wonderful cold front came through bringing a north breeze, several HUNDRED monarchs! The orange beauties were everywhere in the park. Most where already settled down to roost, but many were trying to find just the right spot. I had not seen that many in quite a few years! It was an incredible sight!
Roosting sites every evening since 9/5/05. Several hundred each evening up to and including last evening (9/13/05)

I received a call from a friend of mine in Two Rivers.  She was called by a couple that lives on Lake Michigan.  They said "The monarchs are coming in".  Sure enough, the following day I drove down Memorial Drive from Reed Ave to Columbus Street and counted 60+ monarchs on the 3 mile drive.  The monarchs were just starting their warmup flights around their roosting trees.At my own home in Mishicot as well as the surrounding area, I have been noticing migratory behaviors since Aug 29th. The patroling behaviors of the males had ceased by then. There had also been some southwestern movement across Hwy 42 at the rate of approx. 7 monarchs per mile. As of Sept 15th the majority of the monarchs that had been fueling up in my garden, had left.Another interesting observation in Marinette....my sister-in-law has reported finding eggs as of Sept 12th.  It looks like there may be a small 'second wave', that is IF they manage to develop in time before it freezes.  I still have 2 Chysalis's

75 degrees, wind out of NW at 11 miles per hour. Observed monarchs flying south from 3:30 to 4:30 pm at about 1 per minute. They were flying low over treetops and then dropping down to fly low over a 55 acre restored prairie planting (Sand Creek Preserve, Alamo Township,Kalamazoo County, Michigan. Adjacent to the prairie planting is an area of Canada goldenrod, Joe-Pye-weed, asters (spp) and pasture thistle. A few monarchs were seen there nectaring along with a multitude of fritillaries, and a smattering of other butterfly species.
We are seeing many monarchs, especially in the early afternoon and evening. AT school we have tagged 86 and plan to get more the kids are really enjoying it.

For the last 2 years I was able to go out my back door and tag anywhere from 100 to 200 Monarchs.  It was so easy, but not this year.  Peak migration in my area is usually 9/11 and I did have some Monarchs on that date this year, 50-75 in my backyard, but nothing like in previous years.  I had to go out in the fields and find them this year.  One day I got all excited when I saw a number of what I thought were Monarchs, but turned out to be the Viceroy butterfly.  It has been more of a challenge for me this year to use up my 300 tags that I ordered.  I usually can tell when the peak migration is here by the number of Monarchs flying along our interstate and in the big cities. I saw that scene 2 days ago. There are still a few that I tag each day, however the peak has passed.  I usually have 100's roosting in the trees, but not this year.  My son who lives on a farm 5 miles south of me usually has the Monarchs roost in his cedar trees, but he commented that he has not seen very

I received a telephone message today from Tamara Chipperfield of the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority. It would seem that the many monarchs I reported seeing yesterday along the Gardiner Expressway and Don Valley Parkway in Toronto were only the "tip of the iceberg".

Tamara reported that a "huge monarch push" began in the morning and by 1 pm, "thousands" of monarchs were to be found on Tommy Thompson Park (also known as the Leslie Street Spit) - a 10 km L-shaped park/peninsula that just out into Lake Ontario.

This is a man-made structure made out of demolished building bricks and rubble covered with dredged soil from the waterways or excavations. This web page has an aerial view of the park and another picture below shows how goldenrod carpets the Spit:http://www.trca.on.ca/parks_and_culture/places_to_visit/tommy_thompson/Default.asp

I would suspect there were some excellent roosts there last night. The movement may have been in advance of a cold front that arrived in the night, bringing cooler temperatures and showers today.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

We observed around 100 monarch resting and feeding today in our front yard butterfly garden. I counted around 30 on one sedum and we have about 7 sedum, 2 butterfly bush and a lot more plants they enjoy. We have five acres which we have mostly restored to prairie and I planted a larger butterfly garden as well. We live out in the country surrounded by corn/soybean fields for miles in each direction so we are an oasis for all sorts of critters, but particularly butterfly.

I did see a number of monarch in large goups that appeared to be flocking, similar to what you see with birds as they prepare to migrate. Could this be what they are doing?

September 20
We did counts at 9:30 am and again at11 am. During the first count we saw 24 in a 15 minute period. The second count we only saw 8. Today, September 21, we didn't see any. They must all be gone!

Standing in our yard near Morgantown, Indiana, my husband and I saw 25 Monarchs per 15 minutes this morning! Some were lower, but most were 60 - 100 feet elevation, traveling in a south, south-westernly direction. What a marvelous site!

Today at 4:30 PM, 21 fresh monarchs arrived in our front garden and are nectaring on the asters we have planted. This is almost certainly the first wave of monarchs of the fall migration. (This garden is located at Cat Rock Mountain, Nelson Co., Roseland, VA)

Interestingly, I do not think the wave has hit Sweet Briar College yet...there were only three fresh monarchs on the entire Buddleia garden...about 80 blooming large bushes. Will keep you posted.

As I was driving home on Memorial Drive, which runs right along the shore of Lake Michigan, I began noticing monarch after monarch heading toward Manitowoc. Migrating with them were dragonflys, although I'm not sure where they migrate to. The entire drive I watched them flying. I later heard someone commenting about seeing the butterflies in mass through the 3rd story window of a hospital located along the route. What an awesome sight to behold!
Because the winds are strong there are approximately one thousand monarchs roosting here.

The Hamilton Naturalists Club Birding Report for Thursday, September 15th, 2005 reported "a tremendous Monarch Butterfly flight was observed along the lake."

Contributed by Carolyn King

Port Burwell Migration Watch reported "a huge flight of 100s of Monarchs that increased throughout the morning."

Contributed by Carolyn King

It seems as if the migration has moved across the Lake!

On the south shore of Lake Erie at Dunkirk, we are seeing hundreds of monarchs for the first time in the goldenrod on or near the shoreline in far western New York. The first of the crowd started yesterday (9/18/05). I tagged about 50 in two hours - not great but better than nothing, which is what we had been seeing.

Today the same field had many times more monarchs nectaring - tagged 75 in an hour all by myself.

I expect that if the weather holds we will be tagging into the hundreds per hour over the next few days. The migration seems to me to be great this year by comparison to the past 10 or so, if a bit late. The goldenrod was late blooming - perhaps they waited for the food to show up!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

I noticed a steady flow of Monarchs in a SW direction during a drive in the north east end of Toronto this morning.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Approx. 600 butterflies spent the night here Sept18th.In one hour 10minutes from (9:50 a.m. to 11:00a.m.) Sept19/05,We counted 2007 butterflies.The mornings count from 9:45a.m. to 12:45p.m.Usuing actual minute count totals and estimates we estimate 4,500 to 6,300 Monarchs passed the shores at Monarch Landing. Our daily total for Sept 19/05 was estimated at 10,409. For more detail please visitMonarchlanding.ca

In 1/2 hour there were 2 dozen monarchs streaming into community gardens in Amherst, MA. Mint and amaranth were the most liked plants for landing on. It was a windy day with winds from the SW as Ophelia moved our way.

On Sunday afternoon (9/18/05) from about 3 - 4, I counted about 50 Monarchs hovering over an open field in Southboro nectaring on the clover. It was sunny and about 75ºF. How exciting to see so many Monarchs!

We've got flocks of monarchs moving through Illinois, just east of St Louis in Fairview Heights today while I was picking up my husband I saw around 20 or 30 all flittering their way southwest, and I wasn't really paying too much attention, so there could have been more. Cheers!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Every year for the past 10 years we have observed monarch migrations. This year we've noted a record number of monarchs. It has restored our hopes. Last year we did not tag one single wild monarch. We are in full migration right now. An abundance of monarchs have been in our school's courtyard. We have tagged 25 monarchs so far; 20 males and 5 females. This past weekend I traveled to Ocean Grove, New Jersey. I was thrilled to count a monarch a minute headed south. I think that the monarchs have recovered from the "West Nile" spraying and the freeze in Mexico. My class is wondering if anyone else noticed more male monarchs than females. Also, we wanted to know if during migration do the males migrate first before the females do or isn't there a difference? If the males migrate first, why?

In the afternoon, thousands and thousands of monarchs were feeding on goldenrod and New England aster in the Port Dover area of Ontario near Long Point on Lake Erie.. Towards the evening, large clusters formed on nearby trees. According to John, it would not be an exaggeration to say some clusters contained 3000 - 4000 monarchs.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Migration Hotspot: Cape May, NJ
Data for the Cape May Monarch Road Census is postedon the Cape May Monarch Census website.

September 22
A great day for monarchs at Cape May, NJ . . . our best of the season to date! Northwest winds in the morning brought in large numbers of monarchs. Although the winds shifted into the south in late morning, reducing the rate of incoming monarchs, hundreds of monarchs were seen nectaring throughout the day around Cape May Point. Three census runs yielded a total of 296 monarchs. (Editor’s Note: Each census run take approximately 20 minutes.)

September 27
A large influx of monarchs into and out of Cape May on 9/27 and 9/28 coincided with the wave reported 210 miles down the coast at Fisherman Island. Dick Walton reports 255 monarchs were observed on a census the evening the 27th, and roost counts in the late afternoon totaled 5000 to 6000 monarchs. Only 30 were seen the next morning!

About the Cape May Monarch Census
Now in its 14th year, this annual migration census is providing a long-term record of migration patterns along the Atlantic Coast. Located at the tip of a peninsula, monarchs funnel into Cape May where they often congregate in high numbers until the wind is right to make the over-water crossing. Data for the Cape May Monarch Road Census is postedon the Cape May Monarch Census website.

Last night (9/21/05) when I came out of work at about 6:15, I saw at least 25 Monarchs flying over the parking lot and adjacent field here in Shelburne, VT. I don't think I have ever seen so many Monarchs in one place in such a short period of time (maybe five minutes)!

After noticing strong south winds most of the day, I realized that the sky was calm as the Monarchs were flying about. I wonder if they had all laid low for most of the day before continuing their journey south under calmer conditions.

I have been seeing more migrating Monarch butterflies this year than last fall, when I think I saw one all season. For the most part, I have just been seeing one or two individuals at a time, scattered here and there.

Last night sitting on my deck we saw 107 butterflies in a 45 minute time frame.  They all flew in the same path, and we only saw one to four at a time in the sky.  They all flew high in the sky. The butterflies glided only flapping their wings every once in a while. This happened between 6-7 p.m. At around seven the butterflies stopped coming.  We took a walk and saw a few butterflies feeding on flowers.

On Sunday 9-18-05, we had over 1,000 monarch in the trees in our yard.  The day before, we thought 100 was a large amount of butterflies but by Sunday it looked like an invasion.  Every branch on the two trees on the north side of our house was covered with the beautiful butterflies.  During the day they would go out into the clover field of our house then return before sunset to roost in the trees.  By Thursday, 9-22-05 we were down to just a dozen.  It was a wonderful experience while they were here.

I was taking my early-evening walk and started noticing a few Monarchs along the road, sipping from a puddle. I walked a little further and then saw a few more. When I looked up, there seemed to be thousands of Monarchs above me, at all levels in the atmosphere. Here we have the Prarie wind and it was blowing south pretty good this evening. The highest Monarchs were traveling the fastest. There were A few also near the ground, seemingly looking for water or food. It appeared that with the wind, there was very little energy required by the highest of butterflies. That was amazing!

On my way back from lunch on my bike, I decided to take the path less travelled and went off-road behind some back buildings. I had no idea that the block-long row of bushes would be filled with Monarch butterflies and as I rode by slowly, they took flight all around me. What a great experience with nature. They were there on my way home so I got to see them again but by the next morning, they were gone.
I have been taking my class on Nature Identification walks today and we saw dozens of monarchs sipping nectar and flying in our meadows.

I've been reporting for about 7 years and have never seen as many monarchs as I did today. They have been all around my garden, but I was amazed to find 10 on a large goldenrod plant. In previous years (not counting the last few when we saw none) we saw one here, one there. I think I can actually call this part of the migration. It's very exciting.
The clover field in Amherst was full of Monarchs today and it was a beautiful day. I was able to catch 2 dozen in 45 minutes.

At 4:15 p.m. as I was driving through Wooster, OH, I noticed a pattern of individual monarchs flying SW across Rt. 83 north of town. The monarchs were flying on a due course from NE to SW along a quarter-mile swath through Wooster at approximately 10 butterflies per minute.

There has been a steady stream through northeast OH, for the past week or so. Everywhere I go I count them as they pass. Lots of them on the highway. Went to central OH last week for the day and they were very abundant there also. Looks to be a good migration this year. I have tagged almost a hundred. They are getting tougher to catch, the more intent they are on flying. I have also tagged home reared as well, and they seem to be joining in on the southerly trek.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

A huge gathering of migrating monarch butterflies - up to several thousand a night - occurred over the last few evenings in a grove of trees in Jerusalem Township. Doris Stifel, Toledo's renowned Butterfly Lady and monarch authority, said the clustering was beyond expectations. "This is the best thing I've seen in this part of the country. It is the closest thing to what I've seen in Mexico, ever" The migrant monarchs, likely having completed a crossing of western Lake Erie from Ontario, clustered to rest in the grove of trees. It is probable that other roosting monarchs have occurred in trees throughout the region.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

With the leading edge of high clouds from Hurricane Rita filtering the sun, a nice wave of Monarchs flew below.  The peak seemed to be from Noon to 3:00 p.m.  They flew at all levels, but well over half were above the tree tops, riding on thermals.  Temperature was in the low 80's, very humid, no wind to very light wind from the S/SE.2:00 to 3:00 p.m. observed 90 Monarchs.To my surprise, I also observed a mated pair.  The male flew with the attached female to roost on my pin oak at around 2:30 pm.
There are approximately 300 Monarchs roosting in our Hedgeapple trees.  The trees are near a stream.
I observed over 30 monarchs in a 10 minute period gliding/flying in a westerly direction.

Saturday morning I was driving across town and noticed 4 Monarchs about 40 feet in the air. So I kept looking and sure enough as I was traveling across town I counted 43 Monarchs. I drove back down the street to double check what I was seeing and I counted 27 on the return trip. Then on the way home I counted 32 more. We had had storms the night before and it was a cool, cloudy morning. By 10:45 the sun was beginning to come out and it had warmed up alot. It was truly a sight to see! Our 2nd grade classes have been studying and raising a Monarch and I am hoping that some of our students also noticed the migration taking place this weekend.

On 9/25 I would say my observation times were about 10 minutes each time I counted them. I traveled the same path 3 different times. I did not want to miss anything! It was an awesome sight to see and one that doesn't come around very often. My husband and I saw many Monarchs all day on Saturday and fewer on Sunday. This is very unusual for Russiaville, Indiana. We may see a few here and there over the summer but never anything like this was.
Kayaking on Rose Valley Lake today, 09/24/05 between 3:45 and 5:00 P.M. Would estimate seeing 15-20 butterflies per minute migrating south.

We were in downtown Milwaukee Wisconsin this morning for a large run/walk on the lake. We observed about 10-15 monarchs (bright colors...none faded) every minute flying directly south. It was overcast and chilly (65 degrees). During the 2 hours that we were down there we continued seeing a steady flow of them. It appears that they were coming from the trees along the Lake Michigan shore so possibly the spent the day yesterday crossing the Lake. It has been overcast, chilly and raining off an on all day but I continue seeing them (although not the numbers we saw this morning.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Between 10:30 am - 2:30 pm over 100 monarchs were counted over Brigham Hill in Essex, Vermont.

“It was pretty wild. Every time I would scan the horizon or sky for hawks, I would see Monarchs. They were everywhere. At first it was kind of frustrating, because I'd think I'd have a hawk only to realize it was a butterfly. Once I realized how many there were, however, I was able to appreciate what we were seeing,” said
