At 12:30, our  wonderful school secretary, drove up to her Lake House  at Lake Latawana outside of Lawrence, Kansas. She saw at least 20 monarchs at once on her pink butterfly bush. They did not like the white bush.

We were seeing an average of 7 monarchs an evening the last 10 days. All were flapping southward against a wind. This evening we counted 380 roosting in our trees. I was very surprised because I had never seen so many monarchs in my life. Last year we only saw, on October 6th, 120 monarchs in our backyard trees.

During two fifteen minute recess times, the fourth graders at Tarkio Elementary observed 108 monarch butterflies fly over the elementary building one or two at a time. They were heading south! We observed the same thing two years ago around the same time of year.

September 26
While out fishing in the country 25 miles northeast of here, my friend and I spotted at least 100 Monarchs gathering around a 30+ foot tall Blackjack tree on Sunday afternoon 9/25. Monday the 26th I was delighted to see literally hundreds of the fluttering critters flying south. Most of them were flying at a height of about 30 feet, riding the north wind which was blowing about 10-15 mph all day. A mild cool front passed through here last night which dropped the temp to around 65 degrees (I'm guessing on the temp). Every time I stepped outdoors today, I was observing at least one per minute, but often 5-8 per minute! I'm happy to report that a few members of the herd today fluttered into my back yard to maybe say, "Can ya see me now? Well, good!" We're anxious to see what tomorrow may bring in from the north.

September 27
Another outstanding day of the orange and blacks heading south here. Just like yesterday, literally hundreds were observed here. About half of what we saw here were flying low and being sociable; the other half were flying at a height of apx 30 feet and in a hurry. We spotted one that was probably 60 feet up and it was setting a Monarch speed record perhaps...whoosh! The Monarchs must have been late risers this morning as we didn't see any until 9 AM. We had a very light breeze today from the northeast with temps in the mid 80's. This morning was a very comfortable 65 with not a cloud in the sky for the most part. We didn't need clouds, we had the Monarchs!

September 28
Thanks Teresa Jones of Perry OK. (40 miles south of here) for the great report. We experienced similar circumstances here today too. This morning I was able to spot 45 Monarchs between 9:30-11:00 AM. The south wind shifted (around 1 PM) to the north in a matter of 10 minutes, and after that, we saw very few. Winds were gusting to 30 mph with the onset of what appears to be the strongest cool front of this season. The 45 I saw this AM were all flying low as the south wind was breathing on us at about 20 mph...I guess 30 mph winds might make it pretty tricky for them to navigate. We'll see what tomorrow brings. Predicted low tonight 46 degrees.

October 4
Today I spotted 38 Monarchs throughout the day all fluttering slowly, close to the ground. Oct 2nd and 3rd we observed around 10 each day. I'm surprised to see them still making their way southward this late in October. Although in the past I've not been as tuned into the migration as this year, it seems that usually by now we are seeing few to zero. Temps here the past 3 days have been in the upper 80's and humid with generally a southern wind from 5-20 mph. Another cold front is predicted to pass through here tonight/tomorrow.

October 6
With the passing of the latest cold front, we had high temps in the lower 50's with a brisk north wind. Zero Monarchs, or any other insects for that matter, were seen here today. We're feeling lonely here again.

October 7 & 8
More Monarch stragglers were spotted meandering their way south on the 7th and 8th. Although I wasn't outside all that much, I counted 9 on the 7th and 10 on the 8th with a per day observing time of about 1 1/2 hours scattered throughout the day. 100% of the slow-pokes were flying from 3-15 feet high. Their unfocused flight patterns might indicate why they're so far behind the rest of the pack. Daytime temps here are in the 60's with a light easterly to southeasterly wind at 5-10 mph.

October 10
Surprisingly we're still seeing Monarchs passing through here every day. Yesterday, the 9th, we counted 20 in about 2 hours time. Today, the 10th, I counted 30 with brief observing times scattered throughout the day. Every single one we have seen lately have been flying very low to the ground. This afternoon I had 5 of the beauties fly all around where I was sitting in the back yard. One landed on my knee for about a second! I have never observed Monarchs migrating through here this late in October...quite an exceptional year!

October 11
I counted a total of 33 Monarchs today with a total viewing time of about 1 1/2 hours. Half of the beauties were flying low doing circles, often through my small back yard. The other half were flying at a height of apx. 20-25 feet. We've been having beautiful Autumn weather with a high today of 70 under partly cloudly skies. There was very little wind here today...light and variable. During the past week, I've not observed any Monarchs before 9:00 AM. Today I saw the majority of them between noon and 1:00 PM.

October 13
What an amazing year this is for the fall migration of Monarchs! I am fascinated with all the reports from Texas, particularly in the Dallas/Ft. Worth area. There are many more headed down your way Texas! The past two days, the numbers here have dwindled to about 8-10 per day...but of course I don't live outdoors, so these are seen only during brief outdoor breaks during the day. The peak that Dallas is observing passed through here 2-3 weeks ago. I have never seen Monarchs still in this area so late in October! Weather here is perfect with low variable winds and highs in the 70's.

October 15
This is more like a NON-sighting report I'm sorry to say. Today was the first day in quite a while that we didn't see at least a few Monarchs passing through here. Maybe the slow-pokes have finally all made it by here.

October 16
Went out fishing this afternoon on a private lake 25 miles NE of here, and we saw only 3 Monarchs passing over the lake. It appears the beauties are almost all south of this location now. Very nice, stable weather here with a high today of 85 degrees with a southerly wind from 5-15 mph. !

October 17 & 18
Yesterday, the 17th, and today, the 18th, we counted a grand total of 2 Monarchs both days meandering their way south with many pit stops to check out strange things, like a mutant Monarch observer sitting on my back porch...ooops, that was me. The 4 were all flying from 4-10 feet above ground and evidentally taking in all the boring sights of north-central Oklahoma. The weather here is still very stable with highs in the 80's and virtually no wind in the past 48 hours.

The eighth grade students of Kittatinny High School have been seeing a lot of Monarchs in the last few days!  We have had several reported observations:9/23: 1.4/min (20 min observation)9/23: 1.5/min (10 min observation)9/24: 0.7/min (20 min observation)9/24: 1.2/min (20 min observation)9/24: 0.9/min (20 min observation)Sunny and clear days!

I observed the Monarchs flying over my school during my recess duty.  I was not counting them, but there were quite a few, at least 20 in 30 minutes.  When I came home from work, I sat on my deck and counted the butterflies as they flew over my house.  I counted 43 Monarchs in about an hour.  The wind was blowing from the NNW and the butterflies were whizzing over my house! The conditions seemed perfect for their migration!

This afternoon between 2:30 & 4:30 PM CST I viewed a total often monarchs.  This is the most I have ever viewed in one afternoon OR in a single week. The migration is in full force.  In years past I have only viewed a few monarchs for the entire summer.Adrian WhiteLake Ozark, MO 65049
Around 6:15 p.m. 20-30 monarchs were fluttering and clustering around in my backyard.  They were feeding on zinnas & lavender flowers on the butterfly bush.  Magnificant!
Multitudes of Monarchs are here today. We have been seeing them in large groups all day.  For the past two weeks, I have seen one to two at a time in my garden.
For the past week, the number of Monarch butterfly sightings in this area has dramatically increased. Per acre, approximately 55 monarchs have been sighted.

September 27
We watched Monarchs for one hour from 11:25 a.m. to 12:25 p.m. with a wind speed of 5-7 mph. During that time we saw 135 Monarchs. We calculated that we saw 2.25 Monarch Butterflies per minute.

We received an email from a man in Ponca City that said more Monarchs are headed our way. We will be counting again at the same time tomorrow to see if the numbers increase or decrease and discussing why.

September 20
We only had ten minutes to observe. We saw 2 Monarchs in the ten minutes.

October 6
Our class sighted several Monarch butterflies on the playground at noon. They were flying over our heads while we were at recess. It was a group of only about six or seven, but we thought it might be important. They were flying around and around. Students mentioned to me that they saw some Monarchs the day before (10/05/04) at the football stadium around dusk also.

Having a nice flow of Monarchs stopping to nectar in my yard since Sunday.  Yesterday was a wonderful day, temp in mid 80's with a light easterly wind.  I had around 50 Monarchs in my yard nectaring.Most heavily used nectar plants were Tropical MW, Mexican sunflowers, Mexican flame vine, and Salvia Indigo spires.Off to a great season in Kingfisher, Okla.  Hope that there's more to come.

Monarchs began arriving in the Oklahoma City in decent numbers beginning Sunday, September 25 during the evening hours. By Monday (9/26) a cold front caught up with them. The wind was gusting up to 20-25 mph out of the north. Probably saw about 100 all day mainly 200+ feet above the ground. Today (9/27) we tagged 8 from 10 a.m. to 12 noon.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

A co-worker's mother reports large numbers of monarchs migrating high over Wichita Falls, on the OK-TX border...

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Over the course of 6 hours we saw 6 monarchs heading south.  I know this doesn't sound like much, but we saw very few monarchs heading north this spring, so we are very excited.  The weather was sunny with southwesterly winds as the remnants of Rita passed through the night before.

Just spent 20 minutes at the Sewaren Library Garden Waystation. At least 70 adult monarchs nectaring on the "butterfly bushes" and the "caryopteris". As I was leaving, there were still more coming in. This is the most I've seen coming through, at one time, this year. Unfortunately we have run out of tags.

Flying into a 10 mph headwind at 11:30 am, I would estimate about 200 or 300 in a 30 minute period. Never done this before and didnt have any plans of it. Was just a cool observation at lunch break. Me and a buddy were amazed at how many. They seemed to deal with the headwind very well. They number may be higher but dont want to over estimate. I think it was higher. They were everywhere. Hope its of use.

Monarch "fallout" in Forrest Park at the Grasslands, and inside the St. Louis Zoo in the gardens there. No roosts, probably 10 monarchs withing any line of sight. Many flying high in the sky if you look with binoculars. Multiple butterflies per flower in places. Two or three per plant or bloom.

One student in the 4th grade classroom counted 43 Monarchs feeding on nectar from her Lavendar plants in her yard. Several other students also counted numerous butterflies in their yards over the weekend. The butterflies are definitely making their way over Kansas!

One student reporting seeing 100 on a butterfly bush in the backyard in the early morning. Students are seeing more groups of 5-8 butterflies flying overhead. Most sightings are either early in the day on the way to school around 7:30 AM or in the evenings Single sightings are also being reported. Students come in daily saying they have seen some butterflies.

Last night at sunset as I was walking for 45 minutes at Hammonassett State Park in Clinton, CT I observed over 70 monarchs on their migratory route. I also made a few other observations. I noticed that most of the monarchs were flying in groups of two like they were "couples". I also observed that the monarchs roosted in PINE trees and that surprised me. Perhaps they rest overnight in pine trees. This has been the best monarch migration season I have witnessed for the last 18 years. My hope has been restored. Also, my class has observed many monarchs in our courtyard this week. There are at least 5 monarchs on our butterfly bushes at all times today. We finished all of our tagging last week so we are simply observing and it's amazing how many monarchs are here this year!

I do think we are in full migration right now.

The Monarchs are here! Out on Fisherman Island I had 82 in 1.5 hours. When I got the the hawk watch platform they had recorded 515 by 10 am. best estimate right now is there have been 700 seen so far.

I got permission to tag Monarchs in a 3 acre Alfalfa field and tagged 9 in 20 minutes. The owner of the field reported that they get 4 crops a year and the first crop yields 1000 bales of Alfalfa, pretty good crop for 3 acres. I could get to all of the Monarchs in the field, I will return later in the afternoon.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

We had hundreds of monarchs arrive to ourbackyard Tuesday, September 27th and they were still here last night. Welive on the main street in town and have been having them grace us withtheir presence since the late 1980's. We have more this year than lastyear, but not as many as some years past. I just heard from two friends,one who lives on the west side of Lake Graham who has many hundreds andanother who lives about 8 blocks east of us who has a few. This seems earlyfor us; usually it is in October that they arrive.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
Hundreds landing in Live Oak and Pecan trees in back yard at this time (7PM)

Hello from the beautiful southern Blue Ridge Mountains... Monarchs are being seen steadily gliding through the mountain passes on the Blue Ridge Parkway south of Asheville, NC as well as through valleys near Brevard College. Many are nectaring on native wildflowers that thoughtful gardeners have allowed to bloom in meadows as well as flower beds they have planted for their Waystations. The first migrating monarch I saw was Sunday, Sept. 18. On Tuesday, Sept. 27, I counted 225 in one hour just as the sun was setting. Today, Thurs. 9/29, I netted and tagged 11 monarchs that were nectaring in nearby fields of asters. Keep looking up, everyone and get ready to smile. Ina Warren.

October 1
It's great to be alive in the Blue Ridge Mountains! And especially during the monarch migration! Sat. 10/1, from noon to 6pm, an estimated 300 visitors stopped by the Tunnel Gap overlook on the Blue Ridge Parkway, south of Asheville, NC, to monitor monarchs. Most of the monarchs were too high to net so we discussed the importance of Waystations and viewed life cycle posters from our Monarch Watch posters. I had a live 'larva box' of munching caterpillars with chrysalides on the lid for all to see. We netted and tagged 10; and from 4-6pm the monarch numbers increased to 350 per hour as the winds increased and temps fell. Special thanks to the Rubinos, Barrigars and Abernathy's who helped supply nets and answer questions all afternoon. Our most frequently asked question: What is milkweed? Keep looking up! Ina.

I made a trip up to Wichita Falls from Graham Wednesday. Leaving out of Graham on Hwy. 16 I was encountering5 to 6 Monarchs crossing the highway per mile (these were the ones directly in my line of site, not off to the side of the road). It thinned out somewhat the further up the way I want, but where Hwy 281 crosses a river (I think the Little Wichita just north of Scotland) there were about ten or twelve Monarchs flying around. We have been seeing one at a time now and then for the past few weeks, but there seems to be a greater number now, although nothing like the year there seems to be scores and scores landing on the leaves of the shrubbery at the courthouse. The cold front blew in here last evening, wind gusts 40 or so. Don’t know if that has anything to do with my seeing the ones a few minutes ago or not.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Got a call from Mertzon, TX 76941 saying they had ~100 monarchs in their backyard. This is ~40 km sw of San Angelo.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Our family ranch has served as a roost for Monarch Butteflies each of the last 4 years on 1 or 2 days either side of October 1st.

The past 2 years the numbers were lower than 3 years ago, but this year was so incredible the numbers were hard to even estimate. My conservative estimate would be 10,000. It was easy to count 200 in such a small area, and then figure 50 times that is 10,000. Could easily have been 20,000-30,000!

They actually filled the willow trees and the tall grass that lined a 1/4 to 1/2 mile section of Chyna Creek. We have some incredible digital pictures where you can easily see several hundred in flight, and a short video clip that could easily show 1,000. It is one of the events we most look forward to on our ranch each year.

A strong cold front blew through Wednesday evening and most of the Monarchs were gone Thursday morning when we visited the area.

Would be willing to submit a few photos for posting on the web sight if you are interested! --mike--

This afternoon we sighted several monarchs in our backyard flying in a south to southwest direction.  In a period of about an hour we spotted at least 100.  We did not really have time to count as we were trying to catch and tag at the same time.  This may not seem like many to some but is more than we have seen in a long time.  Many were flying very high and landing in the oak trees for a brief rest then moving on.  We were able to capture and tag 25 that dropped down to nectar in our newly designated Monarch Waystation (#33).
We counted 30 Monarchs in a ten-minute period. They were flying overhead late in the evening.

Great sights today - saw 3 migrating monarchs at school and 2 more on the 10 min. drive home , but then saw 44 in the next 1 1/2 hours - way up high above the trees - 2-3 at a time with about 5 min. inbetween - awesome to see so many - never seen before -

Spending the weekend on our property we took a walk through our woods this afternoon and as last year the woods were full of floating Monarchs. There were some trees where they were bunching up together. It was impossible to count the floating ones, but it was a wonderful sight seeing all those floating and fluttering butterflies. I am going back in there in the morning. There was a fairly powerful storm system last night it might have been part of this sighting as there are many more then last year.

September 29
Last p.m. (9/29) I observed many monachs coming into roost around Zoo grounds. This a.m. (9/30) probably had over 1,000 roosting about the zoo. We were catching them 2-5 at a time.

October 4
We have seen a steady flow of monarchs in the butterfly garden here at the Oklahoma City Zoo for the past 2 days. Today (10/4) I went down and found 25 nectaring on one butterfly bush. Saw two mating and found one monarch caterpillar 2nd instar maybe. We had 2 volunteers tag 25 in about 30 minutes, so we are officially out of tags here at the Zoo. Since Friday (9/30) of last week we tagged 225.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

While on a 2 hour walk from Elizabeth Airfield to and along the beach and back, we saw well over a thousand monarchs nectaring on fall wildflowers including thistle and goldenrod. The time was approximately 3-5:00 p.m. the weather was sunny and clear. Wind was 6-7 mph out of the SE. There were at least 12 on one plant approximately 3' high which we photographed. There were 5-15 monarchs on nearly every flowering plant we passed, some even more. Looking across the fields of beach grasses we could see monarchs hovering everywhere. Incredible sight!

Saw at least 100 monarchs nectaring in goldenrod and New England aster on Eastern Point in Gloucester.  Some were flitting around the light house area right on the ocean.  I tagged 12 by carefully catching them by hand as they sucked up the nectar.  The security guard at the lighthouse said that there were more the day I was there than in the previous week.  Don't know if this is peak yet, but a good show compared to other falls when we have seen very few.
Saw 30 monarchs in a 30 minute period - just after lunch (during recess)

While biking the national park along the seashore at Sandy Hook, New Jersey, we counted 32 monarchs all traveling from the ocean side of the park to the bayside (west to east) between 10:00am and 11:00am. The weather was a perfect 75 degrees with slight winds and sunshine. Between 9/19/05 and 9/30/05, on my way home from school, I travel a highway along the ocean and record between 10-22 monarchs daily. They were each flying from the ocean to the bayside (east to west) at approximately 4pm. In the mornings, aorund 7:30am (which I thought would have been too early for monarchs to get up!), I have noticed several flying from the bayside toward the ocean!

This morning, while taking my son to school, I noticed a beautiful Monarch.  I live at the edge of a small town, against a wooded area, near Bayou DeView in Poinsett county in Northeast Arkansas.  Upon my return, when I exited my vehicle, I saw another, then another.  I stood in the yard for only a few moments before reentering the house to get ready for work, but saw five or more just in that part of the yard, at the edge of the trees.  On my way to work I spotted another as I drove on Hwy 214 crossing the bayou.  I then spotted two more as I approached my workplace at Newport in Jackson county.

My grandsons were playing outside and called, excitedly, for me to come out and see ALL the Monarch butterflies.  I assumed that they were exaggerating but I went out anyway. Was I surprised!! In two of my trees there were a huge amount of Monarch butterflies sitting on the different limbs. On one bare limb were at least 20 and they were opening and closing their wings in unison.  It was breathtaking.  I got my camera and took some pictures but it was dusky out and I'm not sure if they will showup or not.  The other limbs were full too and the Monarchs were flying all over.  I am 50 years old and have never seen anything like it.  Later that night, in fact 1am, I made my husband come out and showed them to him with a flashlight. He was also amazed.  Very awesome!

Today my sightings were 18 Monarchs.  Mostly solo sightings butsome were groups of 2-3.  The individual size of the Monarchs ranged from medium to large.  The sightings this year are a huge improvement over last year.  Again our butterfly bushes are getting great interest from the Monarchs,
We were outside planning our tulip garden. We looked up and saw two monarchs flying overhead.  They were flying in a southerly direction.Mrs. Koontz's fourth grade class

We counted counted 22 monarchs in 25 minutes," wrote St. Paul Elementary School, in St. Paul, Arkansas. Here are the students words:

"My teacher Mrs. Anita Lawrence of the 6th grade has given us the wonderful opportunity to see these cool butterflies." "I saw a unbelievable sight of 22 monarchs in 25 minutes." "They were every where."

After spotting several Monarchs this morning, upon my son's return home from school this afternoon, I asked if he had seen any butterflies to day.  Yesterday he had been driving a lawnmower (not mowing) around a field by our house practicing for a "lawnmower race" and he said, "YES!  Yesterday, they were EVERYWHERE!"

Zillons of Monarchs have been roosting at my mother's home out in the country since late last week. Sunday, after church, my children and I drove out to see the multitudes of butterflies. One of her pecan trees was just covered with Monarchs. However, the majority of the butterflies were in her backyard garden. When we stepped out into the backyard the Monarchs would take flight and there were so many flying up that the sound of the fluttering wings was louder than you might think a butterfly flap to be! The children were thrilled to see so many!
Peak migration observed on coastal Connecticut along the shores of the Long Island Sound at Milford Point. The monarchs were lively and nectaring on golden rod.

I just talked to a friend - their place is about two miles east of Sonora just off I-10, and he's been seeing hundreds if not thousands for a couple of days. I am going there this afternoon and will let you know what I see. I appreciate the info and will use for the article I am just starting. We are 6 miles north, and I was out of town over the weekend but noticed yesterday at least 10. I'll take a closer count today at home.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

We tagged 25 monarchs on Saturday afternoon at a pecan orchard about 30 miles SE of Midland. We could have tagged many more; our count was approximately 20,000.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I just pulled up a letter in the Odessa American that said that they haven't spotted but a few stray Monarchs here in west Texas but I have to report that right now as I write this letter, I have a thousand or more nesting in my oak trees. They starting flying in two days ago and I expect more before they move on. Now the last time we have seen this many, was in 2003. I had planted Lantanas in the front flowerbed, hoping that we would see them again and I am not disappointed.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch
My class and I counted approximately 6 monarchs heading south over our school parking lot in a span of 5 minutes.

A big weekend for monarchs in Northeast Arkansas!  There weremonarchs in all parts of town.  I've never seen so many flutteringwings in our school garden as I did on Sunday; there was a butterflynectaring on nearly every flower.  Forty-nine were tagged, but thatdidn't begin to include all that kept coming.  About two thirds ofthose tagged Sunday were male.  We have had a large, steady stream ofmonarchs arriving since then.
My brother stated that he saw about 200 Monarchs nectaring on goldenrod in the pasture yesterday and today.

Seeing a steady flow of Monarchs in my butterfly garden.  Unseasonably warm, 88 degrees with a strong southerly wind keeping some of the Monarchs tagged yesterday from venturing on. Still, I was able to tag 33 new ones today.  They were so wind-blown and intent upon nectaring that I was able to easily, gently pick them up to tag them.  A first for me!  A cold front with strong northerly winds is expected tomorrow night.

On 9/30, 10/1-10/5, we saw hundreds of monarchs in our garden in Cape May and all around town, including Cape May Point.   Most were notably new; vibrant in color and perfect in form.  Interestingly, many were traveling in pairs and today (10/5) we saw a pair mating.
Monarchs were everywhere on Saturday. Several locations within a 30 mile radius reported hundreds. We tagged 25 monarchs in a pecan orchard about 30 miles from town that had 20,000 roosting.

For the past 2 evenings (Oct. 3rd and 4th) we have had hundreds of Monarchs roosting in the trees in our yard. Don't know how long they stay. We have had Monarchs come to asters and butterfly bush before, but never this many and have not seen them roosting before. It is a wondrous sight! I have taken pictures. Hope they turn out, as the light is dim. Seems a little late for them, thought they were usually here mid to late Sept. Wonder if anyone else here in central Missouri has them roosting?

A friend told me about finding around 200 Monarchs roosting in her fruitless mulberry and silver maple trees this evening about 51/2 miles NW of Kingfisher. She stated that she had not noticed a roost like this in years.

While walking in Cape May Point at 6:40 pm we happened to notice at least several dozen monarchs flying overhead. Upon further inspection we realized that they were picking their bed and breakfast location. There were hundreds of them (perhaps even thousands--not too good with estimating #) in three trees; 2 were deciduous trees--unsure what kind, and one was a pine. The second evening we went back again around the same time and there were monarchs going to roost in the same location.
today class saw 12 monarchs BETWEEN1:40 AND 1:50

Saw 3 monarchs gliding across Massachusetts Ave. (the main street between Boston and Concord) within a minute or so.  2 were flying to the west and one to the south with a northeasterly wind.  It's unusual to see more than one monarch at a time during the summer in eastern MA.

On a beautiful Sunday afternoon, October 2, 2005, my husband called me to come out to the back yard. I saw the most beautiful sight, a plethora of Monarchs! Probably 150 to 200 of the beautiful butterflys flying in and out of our trees. Above us they seemed to be just floating above our heads. We saw small ones, just smaller than a quarter flying in an out of our honeysuckle that grows through our wrought iron fence. I took a few good pictures until my cat followed me, and then the Monarchs seemed to be bothered by all the movement, even though I tried not to scare them. Early evening, I saw many, about 50, flying into and around the privet and honeysuckle.

This is a FIRST of Ms. Wight!!! Hannah Wright (5th grade) saw 30 monarchs roosing in her trees in her front and back yard throughout the weekend. They were flying 20 ft above the ground. They flew from one oak tree to another and another. They are also in the fields. They stayed Saturday afternoon through Sunday night. They may still be there I have not checked yet. I think most of them are females. This made me feel special to think that I'm the chosen one. E-mail me if you see any roostings.

My son and I have tagged over 100 monarchs the past week near Lawton, OK. The weather interrupted us today and we only got two. It turned windy and quite a bit cooler. We are wondering if there will be more coming through after this front as we have about 40 more tags to use.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Howdy. Hundreds of monarchs in my trees this past week.Spectacular. Many more than in previous years. Feeding on the last of the vitex.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

My sister and brother-in-law came through a monarch flight which they estimated to be in the hundreds for a 15 mile stretch before and in Ozona on October 4th in the morning.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

As I drive my many daily trips 13 miles from Buffalo Gap To Abilene, my dates and times were as follows.

Monday Oct 3
Morning 25 to 30 - Afternoon 30 to 50

Tuesday Oct 4
Morning 25 to 30 - Afternoon same as above

Wednesday Oct 5
Morning 30 to 40 - Afternoon 40 to 60

Thursday Oct 6
cold front and heavy rain arrived last night, no movement noticed.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I have been watching a significant number of Monarchs fly through here in the last few days so this morning I sat for an hour with a pare of binoculars over a field of new wheat planting. I counted 71 flying across the field. I don't ever remember seeing this many. We are located about 15 miles north west of Syracuse, NY (43°7.388'NL 76°23.498'WL). We have not had a frost yet and the weather has been very warm for this time of year. The weather is suppose to change tomorrow so I don't expect to see them again.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I accidentally stumbled into the resting place of 1000's of monarchs10/2 8:30 a.m. in Lee Pfluger Park, Eden (Concho County) Texas. Iestimate that there were in excess of 20,000 butterflies and perhapsmore on the live oaks, the ground, the brushy area at the park'ssouthern boundary (approx. 100 meters.) I did not attempt a count andthis is a very rough estimate. On 10/3 I found another monarch restingplace on the park ground hosting probably 1000 butterflies.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Between 4:30 to 6:30 p.m. at our cabin 6 miles east of Ft. McKavett(Menard County) Texas my husband Ed and I counted 30-50 monarchs flyingover every 10 minutes.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

For the past few weeks we have sighted monarchs daily - this is about the only time of year we see monarchs in our area.  Few, if any are sighted until the end of August, and on the milkweed planted in a butterfly garden, larvae are only present during September.  Unfortunately, few of those larvae end up becomming butterflies because deer and other animals and birds eat them, despite the taste!  My classroom brought most of the larvae inside and we fed, nurtured and released 12 monarchs.  Students are reporting seeing 1 - 2 monarchs daily, all in flight.

Around 6:00pm I watched Monarchs floating east to west over my property at the rate of approximately 40 /25 minutes. I have never seen so many. Any time since that day that I go outside to check up on the population, I find 6 or more in my little annual patch...nectaring on Mexican Sunflowers. What a wonderful year to watch butterflies!

Hundreds of Monarchs are coming through Camp Wood, Texas.  Prior to today, one a day was a big sighting.  Yesterday a Norther blew through.  Today is all blue skies and 78 degrees.  The Monarchs are larger than last year.  They are flying at different heights-some high, some close to the ground.  All are going SW.

Beautiful, spectacular fall day.  Hundreds of monarchs descending today on our 171 acre  true remnant  of post oak/ little bluestem savannaht here on the University of Dallas campus, 1845 E Northgate Dr. Irving, Texas, near Texas Stadium,  not far from DFW.   We have many stands of pure natives now in full bloom for nectar:  much, much liatris, goldenrod (of course) also, climbing hemp vine (mikania scandens.).  This year's been bone dry & not much else now except broomweed and bitterweed. (We've a lot of milkweed here too, esp. bluevine and matelea biflora) I've been watching the migration closely for 5 years now, since I've worked on this campus.A large roosting area on the north end of campus has been in use at least 5 years now--in a stand of mature post oaks, very next a large 10 acre  expanse of mowed lawn of Holy Trinity Seminary.  Many thanks--Karen Gempel kgempel@udallas.edu <mailto:kgempel@udallas.edu>972-721-5243.

General Obs: All day constant stream of individual monarchs moving south through area; have also noted high numbers of 2 species of dragonflies moving south as wellDetailed Obs: From 12:00 noon to 12:39 PM today I observed 43 monarchs passing through certified wildscape (Texas) and habitat (NWF) yard; rate was over 1 monarch per minute!  Weather was cloudy to sunny, light S wind, 68F

Saturday, October 2
Hundreds of Monarchs in Portsmouth and North Hampton, New Hampshire stopping to feed along the coast.by Sunday afternoon, they had all left town!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monday, October 3
My friend in Hilton Head, South Carolina said they there were 500 monarchs in her yard!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We've had hundreds of monarchs flying and feeding in the Gardens- their favorite, as usual, is Mexican sage (Salvia). Great day for the State Fair and Texas!!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

The Monarchs are numerously in my back yard in the northwest quadrant of Del Rio this afternoon.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

This morning (Saturday, October 8) at 9:30 Monarch's were common in Kimble County over our house, 12 miles n.e. of Junction.10-20/minute were flying south over our house in a path about 100 yards wide. While driving west on the dirt road in front of our house (and thus crossing their path), it seemed like this density was consistent for about a tenth of a mile. I saw a couple of other such groups when driving in to Junction. I don't recall last year, but I think that year before last (or maybe the previous year) we saw them in these numbers.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Observation Time: 8:30 AM to 9:58 AMObservation Site: McKinney, TX Cert TPWD Backyard Wildscape and NWF Backyard Habitat that borders horse pasturesWeather: 56 F, Sunny, Clear skies, Light/variable breeze from the N/NE and WObservation: Observed 63 Monarchs this morning headed south in under 90 minutes; probably as the day gets warmer we will see more coming through, and rate per minute will pick up
We saw uerflies in the backyard, on the soccer field and on the way home from school.

I was just in Lake George NY this past week Oct. 5-7 and I have never seen so many Monarchs in my life. It was still very warm and sunny but I was truly suprised to see that many still that north! At my neighborhood, Douglaston Queens, a steady steam have been arriving at my neighbors butterfly bush shrub as well as generally seeing them in the area, along the parkways etc.

I went out around 7:30 and netted another 5, so I tagged 15 this morning. Just got back from sitting in the yard for 49 minutes with a stopwatch. In 48.5 minutes, I counted 72 monarchs. The most I saw in a single 5 minute segment was 12.

It's light winds to 5 mph from ESE up to 7-10mph and coming out of theeast by the end of observations, 75.4dF, relative humidity 49%, cloudless. Monarchs still moving to the SW between 12-35' in the air.

October 10
After a steady but light stream of 72 butterflies in just under 50 monitored minutes yesterday and continuing most of the day, I'd expected a better showing in the trees last night, but we had a major rain storm at midnight and got 1.8". This morning there were only 6 monarchs in 6 trees. 3 were clustered up under some large dead branches, the rest scattered singles.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Yesterday, October 9, had a huge movement of Monarch butterflies through Junction and Kimble County. I first started seeing them around 8:30 a.m.with constant numbers until noon. Most of the butterflies were not visible to the naked eye (except early a.m.) but when I used my 8.5x42 binoculars the numbers up high were totally unbelievable, had to be in 6 figures 100,000+ but possibly in the millions. I looked across the county from east of IH10 westward to the South Llano River State Park and the numbers were the same everywhere. At times, through my binoculars I know I was observing 50-80 butterflies every place I looked up into that beautiful blue sky. It was awesome and I have never seen anything like that with the Monarch migration.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

At Balcones NWR from about 9 am to 11 am, approximately 75 Monarchs flew over us on our walk on the creek trail. I also had a Monarch emerge in the yard on Saturday.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

In the past week, we have seen many migrating monarchs.  The peak seemed to be on Monday, Oct. 10, when one student saw 30 in 25 minutes at her home.  Many other students saw similar numbers on that date.  They came through pretty steadily from Sept. 28 through Oct. 12.  We still have a few chrysalises in classrooms here.  We hope they emerge soon.

Between the hours of 11 am and 2:30 today in two ten minute trips, I have counted close to fifty monarchs at my office located near I-635 and Greenville Avenue.

Since Saturday, 10/08/05, we have had absolutely wonderful weather: ranging from the 60's at night to the low 80's during the day, light clouds to full sun, some light scattered showers since saturday.

I have not really noticed the wind much but it does seem the monarchs have been flowing with the wind quite well (if that makes sense)....they are not fluttering the wings too much...just gliding along. I guess that would mean the wind has been out of the north (poss. NE to NW as well).

My office is at the High Point Center at 12225 Greenville Ave. Dallas. Behind the building there is a nice park with lots of trees, stream, and a pond with ducks. I checked on Monday to see if there were any monarchs roosting in the trees and didn't see any. There were a few monarchs checking out the crepe myrtles. I usually see the butterflies on my breaks which are usually between 10am and 3:30pm.

I am on the 33rd Floor in a Downtown Dallas office building. For the passed 45 min. or so, I have seen approximately 100-150 Monarchs floating by!

October 13
I saw more today outside my office window. I am right by the Thanksgiving Square complex. The weather is slightly overcast, humid, wind from the N NW.

This is exciting. I have always wanted to see groups of Monarchs.

There are hundreds of them flying over my home right now 5:30pm coming from the North - Northwest going South - Southeast. We have not seen but about 4 butterflies this whole summer. So to see so many butterflies at once is wonderful breath taking.....I wish everyone was here to see them.

I HAVE NEVER SEEN THIS BEFORE . THERE WAS THOUSANDS OF MONARCH BUTTERFLIES.   SOME WERE FLYING REAL HIGH OTHERS WERE LOW AND SWIRLING AROUND AS IF THEY WERE MATEING. THEY WERE HEADING SOUTH MY HUSBAND AND I WATCHED THEM FOR ABOUT 45 MIN. IT WAS COOL.

I spent the weekend near the community of Old Glory in Stonewall County, just off Highway 283.

We were outside most of the time, and individual monarchs flew past steadily. Occasionally groups of 3 or 4 flew past. There was one roost in a mulberry tree and it included several dozen monarchs -- difficult to count accurately, but I believe it was about 125. Also, one group of about 40 monarchs flying more or less together.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

We were in Vance, Texas, near Camp Wood all weekend.. There werethousands of butterflies there all weekend.. More appeared to be presentSunday around noon.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

How close do the Monarchs have to be for it to be considered a group? I live in Haltom City, Texas 76137 and have seen close to 100 Monarch butterflies heading south during this past weekend (Oct. 8-9). No more than a few minutes would go by with out my wife and I seeing quite a few. They are not grouped the same way a flock of birds do when flying in groups, and I am not sure if Monarchs fly in groups that way or not.

I don't know if this information helps, but it is a beautiful site to see the abundance of Monarchs pass through.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

For the last 30 years I have been going to Co. Rd 118 because it's oneof the monarch's layover places. There used to be more trees at the beginningof the road , so we used to see thousands, if we were there at the righttime. Those trees are pretty much gone now, so The Monarchs have movedfurther down the road, closer to 2001. My Husband and I were thereyesterday and saw a few hundred for sure.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I live in Collin County Texas and have just seen 17 Monarch butterflies overhead during the last hour. It is breezy here and they seem to be floating on the wind. I guess I might have noticed them before, but they are flying high above the treetops and only now and then do they drop down and get close enough to really be sure of their identity. They seem to fly over singly and not in groups about every three to five minutes apart. While I realize my sighting is not in the thousands, it is a double digit sighting and the most Monarchs I have seen here in years.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Monarchs began moving through in good numbers late Friday in conjunction with a cold front that blew through. The Dallas County Lepidopterists'Society went ahead with its scheduled field trip on Saturday, October 8th, despite the cool temps and cloudy conditions, mainly because I knew that even though we wouldn't see many other species on the wing the monarchs would definitely make a show. They did not disappoint. All day Saturday and Sunday monarchs streamed through the area. I counted over 250 in my own yard at any given time feeding on Gregg's Mistflower and Tropical milkweed. By early Sunday evening and all day today the wind has turned from north to a strong breeze out of the south, which has definitely slowed the progression a bit. Another cold front is expected this week which will no doubt push things along again.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Yesterday and today, the large flight of Monarchs was impressive. 350-400 came thru my yard in a 6 hour period, today 150-175 came thru. They were feeding on a small "sunflower" type plant. I am in central Johnson County, near Cleburne. Common Buckeye's were numerous also. A high count of 17 around noon, today.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

We were down at the White Shaman Preserve this weekend, about 40 miles NW of Del Rio, and were privileged to witness, in an abundance we'd never seen before, the migration south of the Monarch butterflies. The year's first cold front had come through, windy and wet, on Friday.Saturday dawned bright and clear with a gentle northerly breeze. Sitting on the porch of our cabin with our morning coffee, looking out at the mountains to the south in Mexico, we noticed the Monarchs coming over and around the casa in greater and greater profusion. Seeing them in the distance, we took our binoculars, and focusing over the sage and thornbrush in the middle distance, were witness to an amazing sight. The entire desert was covered with an undulating blanket of sparkling Monarchs flowing ever south. At any moment there were probably hundreds in my field of vision, and they must have been coming through by the tens of thousands. We sat and watched in awe.

The next day, a stiff breeze had returned from the southeast and while we saw the occasional Monarch, it was nothing like the day before.Finishing some fall cleaning chores about noon, I hiked off and descended into a steep rock cleft in the landscape that we call the Tinaja Canyon. Arriving at the sacred pool, I normally would have bathed but today decided not, perhaps fearing the chilling wind. I bouldered on down canyon to a grove of oaks, placing my feet carefully. I somehow sensed movement above me, perhaps the light changed or their wings pressed the air, and I looked quickly up to find the air full of hundreds of Monarchs, as though someone had shattered stained glass and thrown it dancing into the sky. I gasped and almost fell and quickly lowered myself to the rock canyon floor to watch, and then noticed how the trees were still dripping with butterflies, the creatures appended to every limb. A sudden whirling zephyr rushed through the canyon and instantly the Monarchs were formed into a golden whirlwind, the bright sunshine illuminating them against the shadowed gray stone cliff face.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

On October 7-8, I was bowhunting about 12 miles east of Menard on a property that backs up to the San Saba river. We walked down to the river after an unsuccessful hunt. There were thousands upon thousands of Monarchs on the trees lining the river. By noon on Saturday, all of the Monarchs were gone, just the occasional butterfly flying through.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Many thousands of monarchs passing through Maverick County.I've been outside since 10 a. m. It was heavily overcast, but low clouds at that time with distant small showers visible on the horizon.No wind. Air warming. We're on the runway with Papalotzin getting the plane ready to take it into town for our Hoopla in the Park.

Monarchs in every direction elating in widening gyres, up through the moveless air, sometimes as many as 30 to a vortex. Making no effort to move in anything but spirals up into the sky. I suspect the concrete runway was providing a big thermal updraft.

At 11 a breeze 5-7 mph developed out of the SE to ESE and Boom! We were in migration mode again. At any one segment of the sky there would be too many to count. It stretched as far as we could see across the 1.5 mile runway. With 100s visible at any one moment. I don't know how high into the sky they went.That flow continued till 1:30ish.

Now this afternoon migration has ceased again.There was a goodly shower between 5:30 and 6:00 a.m., so monarchs by the hundreds are puddling in the mud on all the country dirt roads. I saw monarchs on sunflowers, tips of branches, in the road and many flying to all compass points. But no migration.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We are still seeing extraordinary numbers in Sonora. I counted 100 in flight today (Tuesday 11th) just while driving a couple miles through town. Yesterday I counted about 30 flying over in just a couple minutes, and my view was limited by trees and buildings. On Friday evening, I got a call that hundreds were in the trees in a yard in town and Saturday morning there were hundreds if not low thousands in the trees at the cemetery. At any given moment, you can look up and see monarchs. Another person reported bushes covered in monarchs as well as hundreds behind the Presbyterian Church. Spectacular!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Watched in awe from 5:15pm to 6:05pm, as I counted 130 healthy Monarchs heading in a southwesterly direction over our school and rear parking area.  Weather was 79*F, partly cloudy with intermittent sprinkles.  All seemed determined on their path, coming in small groups of no more than 4, cruising at various altitudes and possibly towards an overnight roost nearby.

While sitting at lunch, a few of my co-workers sat and watched about 50 monarchs moving from the north to the south in downtown Dallas... There were some traveling in groups of 3 or 4... and then there were many traveling on their own... About every 15 seconds there would be one pass by... They are just beautiful!!

I saw about 200 Monarchs Oct 11, 2005 flying over Cedar Hill, Texas. I would walk out every couple of hours and begin spotting them.  2oo is a close estimate for the day. I look forward to them each year.  I will be looking again today.

I work in Plano--on the 8th floor of the building so a good "view"--and saw many monarchs migrating yesterday and today (Oct. 11th and 12th). I estimate a hundred or so. Three monarchs that have been feeding for several days in my backyard have gone.
I've seen hundreds of Monarchs in Dallas & Plano since Saturday 10/8/05

I'm a bit envious reading all the accounts of 1000s of monarchs in Texas. But we did have fun in our own back yard yesterday afternoon here in Elizabethton in northeast TN (36.4N). Between 5:25 and 6:30 p.m. we counted 92 flying overhead/through our yard. We were able to net and tag 20 that decided to drop into our butterfly garden on their way.

At Congress Ave. and Third Street, a constant stream (3-20 visible in field of view at all times) passed among the traffic waiting at the light. Looking up in the clear blue sky with binoculars, revealed more and more streaming south by south west.

We have seen numerous Monarchs over the last three weeks.  These sightings have peaked over the last week.  I have seen numerous Monarchs at Oak Creek Reservoir, which is between Sweetwater and San Angelo, Texas over the last two weeks as well.  Did Katrina and Rita hurricanes affect the migratory pattern?
We have observed over 300 Monarchs migrating south just east of the Dallas North Tollway. It brought a pleasant break to our busy workday morning! It was amazing!

Great evening sunset!  Observed from 6:00 - 7:00 p.m. and saw 168 Monarchs sailing on northeast breezes about 3-5 mph looking for their evening roost.  It was a clear day, low humidity with temps about 79.  A handful decided to roost in my ash trees but many checked them out and pressed on south for better places.  My hyper puppy in the backyard didn't encourage a restful stay.  I did observe an interesting thing, dragon flies seemed to be accompanying the monarchs.  I'm not familiar with dragon flies so I don't know if this is a common event or totally unrelated.  It was a beautiful sunset and the Monarchs are very good at timing their roost choice just before the sun slips under the horizon.  It's been two years since I've seen this many and it was fun to have them choose our ridge to fly over this year.

We saw 20 - 30 monarchs fly through our playground at Spring Valley Elementary School in a thirty minute period. The children were very excited to see all of them heading in the same direction. We are mailing our symbolic butterflies today so this was a perfect day for them to fly by!!!

Today (10/12) we (Travis County biologists) witnessed Monarch flyovers above our Jollyville Unit (BCP Preserve) and all around the 2222/620 area (4 points) at the rate of 15-20 every 15 minutes, anywhere/anytime we looked up! I can only assume there were hundreds, if not thousands in the area. This was occuring over the entire area while we were there, around 9am-11:30am.

Today we saw Monarchs flying by heading south to southwest. They seemed to come in groups and some of these groups were fairly large. At times there would be between one and two hundred flying overhead at one time. We have already seen more Monarchs this year than last year.

Monarchs, along with other species, have been seen in moderate numbers for the last week in our area. Today, however, has been an exceptionally brilliant day for viewing monarchs with numerous sightings.

Between 4:20 and 4:30 PM, my husband counted 97 and I counted 110 monarchs. We used binoculars (9 and 10 power) to observe the high flying monarchs. I can't believe they get so high. They are so cute with with outstretched wings gliding head first with the wind than being spun around sidways with the winds then backwards, forwards once more. They are amazing. They seem so fragile, yet are tough enough to be blown forwards, backwards, and sideways with the wind as they head inexorably to Mexico.

In earlier migrations we have found hundreds of monarchs in single trees.  This year there seem to be smaller roosts under the canopies of almost every large live oak or live oak grove.  It's hard to get a good count, but we normally see several dozen per roost.  They are still there late in the morning and don't seem to be in any hurry to move on.

We visited Grandview Prairie for the past three weekends. We saw over 50 monarchs on October 7 and again on October 8. We were there on the 15 and only saw 20 or less. We have only managed to tag 35 monarchs this year. We have had a severe drought in our area and there are few flowers.

Monarchs by the thousands are clustering in trees all over the Radar Base,drifting idly about. Hanging around.It will be interesting to see if a wind develops later in the afternoon. If not, thenthe number of monarchs in the trees tonight is going to be astronomical.

Late afternoon
Papalotzin delayed their early afternoon departure for Mexico for an additional 30 minutes to film the amazing fallout we're having today. We found one salt cedar by the runway that had between 500-600 monarchs in it, clustering and idly floating up in the small arc created by its feathery branches. They would startle and take off as cars passed, but settle back into the tree.On the way back from town just now I could see 6-10 each second! Some in dedicated flight, but many others just spiraling around desultorily chasing one another.What a day! It's a monarch party!

Friday morning, Oct. 14
I knew the roosting monarchs were in trouble when I awoke at sunrise and looked out my window. The back and side yards of my rental house on Chincoteague Island were already under several inches of water. I raced to the beach road on Assateague Island to access an interdune area where thousands of monarchs had roosted Thursday night in the seaside goldenrod along the shore of Tom's Cove. I approached the area where most of the monarchs had been clustered late Thursday evening. They were still there! They had crawled up to the tips of the goldenrod flowers, some within a few inches of the flooding tide. I stayed until the tide ebbed to make sure they would make it. They could not take flight; the winds were NNW at 20-25 mph with higher gusts. Any monarch that relinquished hold on the flowers was immediately caught in the wind and blown out to sea.

These I believe to be the Mid-Atlantic monarchs; they are pristine, with no wear or scars on their wings. Their wings are huge and their abdomens fat. They have not traveled far to arrive here. I wonder if they sense how perilous the next 24 hours could be . . .

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monday, Oct 17 was a good migration day here in northern Montgomery County, Maryland. Migrating monarchs were seen over highways, parking lots, fields and back yards. Some folks in this area still have late instar larvae and chrysalids in their gardens as well.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I went outside into the courtyard of the building where I work in South St. Louis City on the morning of Oct. 5th to take in a few breaths of the cool morning air, as I had done for the last few months. This was not a typical day, however, as I suddenly found myself amidst a swarm of fluttering Monarchs. I stood in awe at this spectacular sight not believing what I was seeing. I stood still as the fluttering wings abated, it was at this moment that I noticed that there were not merely hundreds of these beautiful butterflies around me, as I originally thought, but thousands. There was at least one monarch resting on every leaf in the tree-filled courtyard as well as each leaf on the thick vine that drapes the fence dividing the property line behind the building. I have never seen anything as anomalously beautiful as this before in my life and feel grateful that I was there at the right time to be graced with such beauty.

Millions and millions of fluttering orange filled the air when we approched them in the trees near a nature preserve.  We were the only ones that knew they were there, and the only ones to see the magnificant site!!
As we drove from Knippa to west of Uvalde (from 6:15 p.m. to 7pm) on Highway 90, we counted 220 monarchs flying.

Gentleman called to say that he had 10-20,000 monarchs for only the second time in 12 years in San Angelo. They came through last week with the cold front...

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I spent Monday, 10 October, on our property out in Val Verde County. There we enjoyed the company of millions of monarchs that were in the trees along the Devils River. For a distance of at least a mile and a half, north from the junction of the river with the Dry Devils River, in the gallery forest along the west side of the river, there were more monarchs than I can image ever assembled together north of the wintering forests in central Mexico. They were mostly resting on trees, and looked as numerous as the leaves in the trees, with many just quietly flitting all through the woods. They were there when we arrived at 8 am and still there when we left at 2 pm. It was very magical. I have no idea if this is some regular stop or congregating point in their migration-perhaps this is an annual event?-but there's really no one there to ask. I can't begin to estimate the numbers of monarchs that were present.It was a very spectacular event in a very quiet sort of way.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

We are pecan growers about 5 miles N. of Hondo, in Medina County,Texas.Thousands of Monarchs have stopped in our orchard for years on their waysouth. They arrived again yesterday, Sunday, Oct. 16, 2005.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I was in Gonzales yesterday to film Blue-faced Ringtails. On the way there, travelling I-10 from Kerrville to Luling i had 44 Monarchs -- those of course are only the eye-level bugs -- or about one every three miles or so. At Gonzales, in two hours of work i casually noted 12 more without scanning the skies.

Today, back at home in Kerr County, i noted that there apparently a group had set down in the cypress trees aong the river in front of my house. No huge, trees-dripping, kind of thing. But i walked about 200 yards of trees and counted 102 Monarchs dropping from the branches and leaving (at about 12:30 p.m.). Will be out the rest of the day filming and will report back.

Later that day

This past week October 10 -13 my children and I began looking and were amazed by the number of Monarchs we saw going through Plano, TX. Well over 20 or 30 during any given 20-30 minute walk.

On Wednesday, October 12th around 3:30p.m. we were driving south into Carrollton, TX from Plano (20 minute drive) and decide to count the Monarchs to see where there were more. We noticed there was a significant drop between Plano and the Carrollton area we were in. In Plano there were at least 10-20 visible during any portion of the drive.As we enter the Dallas Tollway that number decreased (my kids couldn't see any as I was trying to drive with the flow of traffic -- 60mph).When we exited the Tollway at the Carrollton/Plano border, we could only see a few (less than 5-10) and at one stoplight, we noticed many birds so that could explain the decrease of our sightings.

Anyway, this was a great nature lesson in the migration of the Monarch Butterflies.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn,

We experienced a very significant change in monarch numbers in the lastday:

On Wednesday night/Thursday morning we had thousands roosting in our trees. - the skies were full of monarchs morning to dusk.

Startlingly, last night-this morning there were none to been seen roosting or flying. This afternoon and evening I have seen NONE. Was that the "end" of the migration- (I think way too abrupt) or maybe just a shift in the path? I thought you might be interested in the extreme contrast.

We have owned a mountain home in the village of Valle de Bravo in theState of Mexico for many years and it is only 10 miles from our place towhere the butterflies cross the main highway to their nesting areas inthe mountains. We have noticed dozens of Monarchs over the past few days in ourbackyard in Rockwall, TX but, yesterday, whiile sitting outside for justa couple of minutes, we saw 30 to 40 before we had to go on with ourerrands. I spent my elementary years in Wichita, KS and this reminds meof those days.

A steady streamof Monarchs has been going through this area. Almost without fail, theyspend the nights in the native Texas Pecan trees by the Nueces River.The ranchers who have been here for years and years think nothing aboutseeing the Monarchs and expect them to be in the Pecan trees. Theythink (whether right or wrong) that there is something on the leaves ofthose Pecans that feeds the Monarchs. I did see several light on alarge Pecan--not native. They did not stay but moved along to theNative Pecans.

This migration this year has been a huge one. The only day I have notseen them was yesterday when we had a tremendous rain storm, and I don'tknow what the butterflies did yesterday.Happy butterfly time.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

After seeing just a few monarchs each week this fall, we had a peak of 16 monarchs on Sunday.  Over the course of the week, we saw a total of 50 monarchs!
I saw about 50 Monarchs in a beautiful Marigold garden on the campus of College of the Ozarks. It was amazing!

Today was a magnificent day for monarch watching in Cape May.  The goldenrod is still blooming and now the montauk daisies are blooming in our garden.  At least 3 dozen came through during the afternoon.  We went to Cape May point briefly this afternoon and then went along the ocean dunes area where goldenrod is abundant. Sure enough, many monarchs were nectaring.  Had to have seen several hundred all in all.  What a great migration this fall!

Another mild cold front (the high will still be in the 80's) has blown through and brought more monarchs. Other than a couple day drop in numbers around the middle of last week, there have been over 200 monarchs in the yard at any one time Since October 9th feeding on Eupatorium greggii and Tropical Milkweed. Today there's easily 400.

October 21
What a difference a day makes. Yesterday there were easily 400 monarchs in my gardens but today there are only about 15. Cold front blew in yesterday.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Altus said this was most monarchs she had seen in several years!!!

She was able to leave school and join me across the Lavaca Bay Causeway at 2:30. We did a one way count along the peninsula at the north end and had 214 monarchs in twenty minutes. We left at 5:30 and the number had never decreased in the three hours we were there ... monarchs always coming out of the NE to either fly by or to stop at goldenrod or sunflower to nectar.We got home with what we think are over fifty that we netted.There was at least one cluster of a dozen forming for the night that we could see. The other side of the peninsula had the wind and about 10% as many monarchs.

October 22
Numbers at least triple yesterday. Three trips across the causeway ... 3.1 miles @ 50 mph 4:30 -- 46 monarchs, 5:00 -- 32 monarchs, 6:40 -- 46 monarchs facing W and moving SW with N wind 6 to 10 mph, clear, 82 dF Monarchs moving off the bluff in front of Alcoa at a rate of three to ten a minute all afternoon and "flowing" SW across Lavaca Bay towards or just north of Port Lavaca.

Larger numbers loosely clustering for the night on the willow on both sides of the peninsula. The false willow is blooming and is "bitter" to me. The monarchs crawl down into it and will flush when you get too close. At 6:40 a good deal of the seaside goldenrod seemed to be occupied for the night by large numbers of monarchs. A few more were still arriving from the NE when we left at 6:40.

October 23
The wind changed to ENE about noon and back to the N this afternoon when the front came in. There was a good liftoff this morning of last nights monarchs but the faucet was slowly being turned down. Trips across the causeway and the count of monarchs flying SW across the 3.1 miles, in about 4 minutes.

10:00 am ... 30 monarchs
10:30 ... 32 monarchs
11:00 ... 26 monarchs
11:30 ... 23 monarchs
4:30 pm ... 15 monarchs
5:30 ... 10 monarchs

We did see a few monarchs all around the area here in Port Lavaca and around Aloca in Point Comfort. Their actions for the night aren't what we are used to calling "clustering" ... they are nectaring on the False-willow in loose groups until sundown and in the morning the groups will look about the same. One in ten of the willows must be blooming just right and they are drawn to those ... the rain we had recently must have set off this bloom.

Clear, light wind, N to ENE to strong N, 82 dF. This front will drop our temps to 71/50 ... chilly.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

71.5dF
10:15 a. m.
broken overcast, breeze from the east to ESE 5-10 mph

continuous streams of monarchs just above tree height or lower (15-20' agl)They are dropping into every wind shadow, then popping back up into thebreeze to continue SSW.

I did 5 five minute counts with no intervals:

1 10 monarchs
2 10 monarchs
3 7 "
4 12 "
5 11 "

This would give us 600 monarchs passing over just one plot 50' x 50' in anhour's time. Not what I could call a stream or river, but a definite movement or flow.

Another massive flight of MONARCHS came through this week on October 17-18. 3,000 were counted at roost sites/shelteredspots in Cape May Point in the dunes and in backyards. Many of them migrated out of the area on the 19th, but some can still be found in gardens with blooming Butterfly Bushes and in the dunes where SEASIDE GOLDENROD is still blooming.

The monarchs are pouring across the bay in big numbers both yesterday and today. I have had no time to count them or spend much time with them but likely several hundred to a few thousands have come on to the front beach the last two days. They often end up traped on the balcony here. I see 3 out there right now. They eventually figure out how to get out.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

October 22
Last Saturday we stood among hundreds of Monarch butterflies that were flying onto land from out over the Gulf of Mexico.

We were riding motorcycles from Perdido Key, Florida, heading into Orange Beach, Alabama, a distance of about 5 miles. We saw the monarchs all along the way. At first, we encountered some butterflies as we rode, but we noticed so many that we finally stopped underneath a bridge and stood at a seawall at Perdidio Pass to watch.

As they came in off the Gulf the monarchs were flying low over the water. When they encountered the seawall they flew up and over, then continued heading north. (Tide being what it was, the distance from the top of the water to the top of seawall was approxiately 5 feet.

We saw approximately 25 butterflies every 5 minutes at the part of the seawall where we were standing, so over 200 butterflies in total. The same thing was happening along the 300+ feet length of the seawall. (It was very difficult to make them out at all because they were flying close to the water, and blended in.)

During our ride along the beach, some were, of course, being hit by cars but most were flying above that level heading north.

It was one of the most remarkable sights I have ever seen. We wondered why they were going north. Could Hurricane Wilma have blown them off course and back over land? (At the time, the ocean surf was rough and pounding the beach because of Wilma.)

The sighting occurred between 3:30 - 5:00 pm. It was a sunny day.

On Sunday evening, just at dusk, we saw maybe 5 butterflies as we drove the same 5 mile drive to Orange Beach). We saw none when we stopped at the same place. Fascinating!

October 27
Received a report from a friend who lives in a condo on Perdido Key that, as of Monday, the butterflies were around in sufficient numbers for people to notice. She reports that her condo is landscaped with lantana and that seemed to be attracting them. I have asked that she try to do a count to provide you with some additional info.

Oct. 9-300-325, weather sunny upper 70's.

I believe that this is the end of the migration for this year.

The monarchs were not flying this afternoon but there were so many of them on the goldenrod and false-willow we decided to count those that we could. We counted along both sides of the peninsula and had over six hundred. This is the most monarchs we have ever counted at this site just nectaring.

It was very strange that almost none were attempting to cross the bay this afternoon. The only thing we could tell was that the surface of the bay was so very slick ... possibly hard to tell distance! When crossing the bay on the causeway from forty feet up there appeared to be two suns ... one in the sky and one in the water. The only other thing we could tell was that there was no help in the form of vertical lift, the high pressure was parked right over us this afternoon.

October 30 &31
Almost no monarchs on the peninsula on the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway the past two days (30th and 31st) with a strong prefrontal southeast wind blowing. Had to look hard to find 3 on trips over there.

November 1
Strong front blew in from the NW about seven last night with T-storms and gusts to 43 mph. Count has been improving all day: Wind was still strong but out of NNW this morning, clear, 64 at 9:30, 74 at 4:00, wind was10-15 mph out of NNW at 5:00 ... 47 in the morning!

9:30 am 3 monarchs on east side of peninsula.
11:30 am 8 monarchs on east side of peninsula.
4:00 pm 45 monarchs on east side with more arriving
4:15 14 on west side ... 6 clustering on same old brush

Hope the wind is right tomorrow and doesn't switch to the east too quickly.

I live on Eleuthera in the Bahamas and in the wintertime we have tons of monarch all around our yard, but in the summertime you can't find a single one. I'm almost positive they cross the Gulf Stream every year to get to the Bahamas. I saw the first three monarchs for the winter yesterday (October 31st).

I have sighted several Monarch Butterflies. This is the first time I have seen them on our island. We are located on Exuma, Bahamas.

I first saw the monarchs October 24th thru the 31st and have been sighting them daily feeding from flower to flower. They seemed quite normal. Our yard has a lot of different flowers and palms.

The previous week (Oct. 17ththru Oct. 21st) we had high winds and the butterflies appeared after that. I have seen probably 12 to 14 just in my yard.

I lived in Michigan for many years before moving to Bahamas, so I'm quite familiar with the Monarchs. We have had a home here in Exuma for 18 years and this is the first sighting.

This time of year I see many migrating birds and spotted 4 Sandhill Cranes on a remote island yesterday (Oct. 31st) while diving for lobster. I have not seen milkweed on this island at all but I will look more closely for it in the future.

I happened to spot a number of monarchs, perhaps a hundred or so, in theSandia mountains east of Albuquerque on October 14. I was treated to a special show of monarchs migrating across Lavaca Bay this morning. The bay was calm with just a light ripple every few minutes when there was a touch of breeze out of the southwest. Somewhere between 10:30 and 11:00, I stopped my counting of monarchs that were nectaring on goldenrod and sunflowers because I had become fascinated with the number of monarchs that were flying just off the west side of the peninsula to the Lavaca Bay Causeway and over the bay. Their flight was parallel to it and the causeway and they proceeded southwest across the bay. They were about three feet above the surface of the bay, seldom more than six feet, three to five in sight most of the time for the hour I watched from the shell shoreline where the causeway begins. I would guess four to five hundred monarchs passed within 200 yards to the west of me in that one hour. Ps. My count of those nectaring had been 111.

About 7:30 am this morning, my friend from Cambridge, Ontario called from Angangueo, Michoacan to say he had visited the monarch sanctuary near El Rosario and was overwhelmed by the thousands and thousands of monarchs arriving.

Contributed by Don Davis

The Monarchs continue to pass through Tequisquiapan. Today at 2:00 PM we saw a large group flying over the city, I calculate at least 1000 flying by.

Temperatures have been as low as 2 degrees C in the mornings and it gets up to 27 C in the afternoons.

The Finish Line!
This is where the monarchs go for the winter.
They travel here from across eastern North America.

Directly from the monarch's winter home in Mexico,
Estela Romero sends these notes...
On this day we saw 7 Monarchs just during recess.  We had begun seeing them earlier in the week but just 1 or maybe 2 at a time.

Tonight there must have been about 500 Monarchs in clusters all over the maple trees around my house. They've been gathering for a week now, each night a bunch more. They choose different branches each time, but cluster tightly together in groups of 10 to 200.This is the first time in 23 years that I've lived here that I've seen Monarchs gather like this.

We can`t remember a year with so many Monarchs.For about 2 weeks they have been migrating south .My husband saw a whole Roost while golfing Sunday morning .Hundreds where waiting for the warming sun .He did see them all take of .Awesome . Anybody we talk to has the same thing to .SOOOOOOOOOOOO many Monarchs going Home .

Today I was contacted by Dennis Barry, who has seen large numbers of monarchs ("thousands") roosting in Thickson's Woods on the north shore of Lake Ontario at Whitby. They are roosting in a "hole"or clearing in this small but ecologically significant remenant of forest (http://thicksonswoods.com/, a spot favorite with birdwatchers. I recall hearing a few years ago of monarchs roosting in such a habitat by Dr. Kingston Leong of California.

Fortunately, my work took me past Whitby to Oshawa today, and on the way back to Toronto to visit this site. At 2:30 pm, scores of monarchs were flying inside this opening in the forest (the sky was becoming overcast and they may have been looking for a site to rest). There were many trees and tree branches in this opening, and the monarchs were settling on these as well as on tree leaves.

The property on the lake side of the property is privately owned and there are a number of homes.I came across one amazing garden filled with flowering plants and a few buddleia shrubs. There were many monarchs nectaring here.

Wednesday 23rd Yvette saw the same thing regarding Monarchs as reported at Thickson’s Woods at Whitby, Ontario - scores, if not hundreds of fresh looking monarchs settling to roost in openings in hedgerows along a trail near Sandbanks where she walks the dog. It was late afternoon but it was clouding over. Should be lots around for the next couple of weeks.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We have sighted the monarch butterfly consistently during the last 2weeks in east end of Hamilton. That location is approximately one miles from the city of Stoney Creek. It has only been during the last couple of days when we have seen increasing numbers; in the hundreds in our backyard.
Several hundred monarch butterflies roosting in black-walnut trees at approx. 7 pm. in evening. Also feeding at the butterfly bushes throughout the back yard.

Monarchs have been in my yard all day long and I finally went out with a cup of coffee and sat and did an aerial count of those passing overhead. I counted 142 in approximately 15 minutes as they were passing over, most of them were quite high but a lot dropped down into the yard to check out the flowers. This is the first bunch I have seen migrating this year .... so far!
Aprox 1000 in my yard roosting on a cloudy ovecast day.
100's of butterflys are roosting in our pine and maple trees - they have been here for 3 days/nights.

I live in a small village called Port Dalhousie which is part of St. Catharines, Ontario Canada. I spotted a couple of monarchs yesterday in my back yard and said to my husband I hope they land in our yard by the hundreds as they did a few years back.

Well,this time,( today....4:31PM, August 28th, 2006) they picked the neighbour's back yard and they are there now by the hundreds. Why Port Dalhousie? We assume because it is the first land they can light at after flying across Lake Ontario!? It's too bad that Monarch watch doesn't have a site that someone can access without being a MEMBER! OR I COULD HAVE ADVISED THEM HOURS AGO and sent them photos.

Report from birdwatcher Norm Murr:
For you Butterfly folks, we observed about 2000+ Monarchs on The Spit today with about 1000 of them being on the base in the morning and I was told by Dan Derbyshire that he saw about 5000 Monarchs at the lighthouse in the early morning.

Contributed by Don Davis

I was out walking my dog and noticed more than a few Monarch fluttering about, and wondered if I might see more.  As we made our way through an area very near to Pearson Park I began to see more and more Monarchs until we got to an area where hundreds and hundreds of them were flying about and beginning to settle, individually and in clusters, in the many trees there.  This was at about 5:00pm, Sunday, August 27th 2006. I will make a point of going back on Monday to see if they are still there.

August 27
Sunday morning they were flying around in large numbers. during the afternoon they began to roost in a black walnut tree on the south of the house (but on the north of the tree). By evening they numbered above 100, possibly 200 and had moved to other black walnut, maple, & beechnut trees, still south of house & on north, low hanging branches.
