This morning 8/28/2006 they moved to a Norway maple & pine on the east of the house. This afternoon to a bunch of black walnuts on the north of the house. Roosting & occasionally flying. Damp cloudy humid both days.

August 29
There are several hundred, maybe 1000 now. They are roosting on at least 5 or 6 black walnut trees. They fly around some but then come back to roost. It has remained cloudy until this evening. We have taken many pictures but there is no way to capture it all! We are wondering why and how long they will stay!?

We've been tracking Monarch butterfly flight every day in the fall for the past 16 years. The flight now at the Tip is about 500 - 1000 a day. It will pick up substantially in the next week or two.

Contributed by Don Davis

As my wife and I rode down the Genesee Valley Greenway. About 2 miles south of Scottsville, NY we were suddenly surrounded by thousands of Monarchs. That was Monday evening (8/28). We went back last night (8/29) with a camera since it had rained all day and they were still there. Magical!
I was sitting on the shore of Lake Ontario and watched hundreds of Monarchs appear from the Lake,land on the flowers, and then continue South.

We are looking forward to a busy season. A friend of mine, who lives in NY near Rochester, called and said that there are thousands of Monarchs along the lake shore up there. He was very excited that the Monarchs were already roosting in large masses.

Contributed by Louise Zemaitas, monarch coordinator on Cape May, NJ.
First day to see monarchs roosting this year. Approximately 500 in the trees. Wind of 20 mph from the south.

At 7:30pm on Aug. 30, 2006 I observed a large number of monarch butterflies roosting in trees along the edge of our woods. Several butterflies were swooping and fluttering overhead as well. It was cloudy and also starting to get dark so it was difficult to estimate the number of butterflies. I observed clumps of 8-10 buterflies on several lower branches. I am guessing that many more butterflies were present, but it was too gloomy for me to see them .

Monarchs were roosting in the lower branches of the very tall cottonwood trees in the yard After crossing Lake Ontario from Canada. Aprox. 400. Previous years they have roosted in the pine trees on the same property.

Large numbers of monarch butterflies are everywhere throughout Sarnia-Lambton Area. They are flying into the area from Southern Lake Huron. Each day since August 24th more appear. Throughout the day, dozens of monarchs are in my yard feeding on every flowering plant they can find, especially butterfly bushes. This year has been the best showing of monarchs for many years.
We have observed well over 100 monarchs roosting is clusters of 20-50. They have been here for at least 2 days.

I watched the sky with binoculars this afternoon--very patiently--to see if I could see any migrating monarchs. I stared and waited, wondering how high a monarch might fly today and what it would look like if I did see one.

I watched nothing for at least 5 minutes--and then there it was. I could hardly believe my eyes! Yet the sun hit the monarch's orange wings and I could see it cleary. It was way, way up high, and flapping occasionally as the wind carried it westward.

I waited another 5 minutes, staring at nothing. Then the next one appeared. I have no idea how high either was flying. When I put the binoculars down to check the butterfly vanished. Two tiny butterflies in ten minutes, but I couldn't have been more excited.

Next, we went for a drive to see what we could find. There was goldenrod all along the roadsides--in full bloom--but no monarchs were seen nectaring. We went in search of farmers' fields that might be blooming with red clover or alfalfa. Nothing...

Suddenly we spotted a brilliant yellow field across the river, aglow in blooming golden sunflowers. Would it attract migrating monarchs we wondered?

There, on flowers the size of dinner plates, we found hungry monarchs flitting about. Wandering below the giant plants we took these pictures.

We went out in search of something beautiful this afternoon and look what we found!

I was in a flat, sandy prairie yesterday (8-31-06) where there were large areas of Whorled Milkweed (Asclepias verticillata) blooming. Hundreds of monarchs were nectaring on the milkweed - I counted about 150 in one 6 meter square area of milkweed.

We went to mow our back yard and noticed as we came upon the trees there are thousands of monarchs perched in the trees! We have NEVER seen anything like this in our lives! It is the most amazing and beautiful thing! We have 4 or 5 trees that they seem to favor and they are just clustered in them.... this started about a week or so ago when we noticed a few and thought, "how nice!" Then gradually more and more came and we realized something amazing was happening! We are hoping this in not going to be one of those 'once in a lifetime' things as this is the first year we have lived in this home.
We were visiting in Lakeville, and some young kids were excited because of all the Monarchs that were roosting in a nearby Ash tree. We could count about 15 in the roost with many more flying around.
On 8/31/06 we watched group after group of monarchs landing in a tree. This continued over the next two days. Then on the morning of 9/3/06 they all flew off.
around 40 monarch butterflies were feeding at my butterfly bush. this has never happened in 14 years that I have had the bush. I may only get a dozen Monarch's the whole year. But today I had 40.
We observed tons of Monarchs on the branches of our trees.
Today we saw numerous monarch butterflies in our yard. They clustered around our butterfly bush and also the blooming sweet autumn clematis. We have never seen so many in our yard.

There are hundreds, perhaps a thousand Monarchs, but less than last year. Though I only saw them in the morning last year as I just had moved here. The area is mostly farmland so there are not a lot of areas with clusters of trees, but there happens to be a small wood lot next to this school (on the west side) They seem to like certain trees better than others, I'll have to check out species once they leave.

I first noticed the monarchs last week when I was mowing around the trees. As of today, 9-5-06 they are still at our farm and we estimate them to number several thousand.

They roost in the cedar trees and pine trees at night and when they get warmed up in the morning they fly. They have come to this farm for many years but this is the first time we have noticed so many.

On Monday, September 4th, my wife and I spent 5 hours tagging monarchs.  They were more plentiful, but not at peak migration yet.  We walked a lot of miles up and down a large field of clover and alfalfa.  We ended up tagging 40.  Last night on Sept. 5th, we went to the same field and tagged 48 in 70 minutes.  The monarchs were all over, and we hardly had to walk at all.  At one time I had 3 monarchs in my net waiting to be tagged.  It looks like the migration in this area of Wisconsin is starting to heat up.  It is about 1 week later than the past 5 years.  We are going to have a cold snap this weekend (temps in the 60s) so it will be interesting to see what happens to the migration.

I was very busy counting a massive Cedar Wxwing flight, approximately 15,820 Cedar Waxwings moved through the area, but I did make an attempt to count the Monarchs as there were thousands moving that day also.  I estimate over 20,000 Monarchs moved through; at any given time I could do a 360 degree scan and count 300+ Monarchs.

There are literally THOUSANDS of Monarchs in a variety of trees in my aunt's orchard! They are beautiful! I first thought they were bats because they are so numerous. What an AMAZING sight to see! Wow... My three young sons were mesmerized as well. What a blessing of beauty!

It was one of the most magnificent things I have ever seen. We were watching a storm come in from the north. We noticed several monarchs flying and as we looked higher there were billions of them. It was a beautiful site.. difficult to express how exciting it was to see. There were billions of them traveling the same wide path, following each other... it lasted for some time. I was glad that one of my riding students was there to witness the experience with me. I, nor anyone I know have experienced anything like it.

Today in the portlands (Toronto waterfront) here in Toronto between the hours of 9am and 11am I watched in amazement as 1700 Monarch Butterflies moved though the city !

Some stop to nectar on blooming Bamboo which got me thinking of the mess my next door neighbour here in High Park has in his back yard (which is full of Bamboo). When I got home, the back yard had 57 monarchs flying and now going to roost for the night .....

Edit's note: Contributed by Don Davis:Craig McLauchlan is an outstanding birdwatcher and Toronto naturalist who lives in the High Park area ofToronto
Folks, Wow; walking the dog in our back yard tonight I stumbled on a roost of several hundred (~300) monarchs in the trees and flying about. Awesome! Thank you for your work! Royal

On Aug. 29 I drove across highway 21 along the shore of Lake Huron. There were hundreds of Monarchs flying toward the lake for miles either side of town. (There were none the following Tues. on Sept. 5.

We saw thousands of them last night for the first time in my life. IT was a special moment that was shared with my two boys and their great-grandmother, who had never seen anything like it either. They were in here trees just north of Sidney, Ohio. When they were running around the trees and stirred them up it turned the sky black. We played with them for over an hour catching them and releasing them. IT was really special because one of my boys' favorite movie is the "Little Einstiens" video about the migration of the monarch butterflies.

The monarchs are still coming through Central IL in droves. I am so glad I planted a large bed of tropical milkweed because they absolutely love this plant. Starting at 8:00 am and continuing until about 4:00 pm, there is an average of 30 monarchs at this flower bed at a time. After I tag one, he/she moves on, but there is soon another one coming from the north to take its place.

September 6
During a two hour walk in the afternoon on the «ILES DE BOUCHERVILLE PARK»a 500 monarchs active feeding on yellow flowers, the french name : «VERGE-D'OR»

September 7
I made the same trail as yesterday on the ILES DE BOUCHERVILLE PARK near Montréal, but in the morning and have seen about the same activity and number of Monarchs as yesterday : 500 feeding on «VERGE D'OR» (I have some photographs illustrating the butterfly on the flower)

September 10
Today, only 4 monarchs along the same hike as I made the 6th and the 7th of september.

Like everybody else, I can say THOUSANDS are coming.I have never seen so many and so early going south.The weather is great light winds and lightly overcast.I also notice how they take advantage flying close to the houses and getting a huge uplift and a push that almost sends them to the next spot.Many stop at my place since i have a garden wall out of Goldenrod and Milkweeds,6 feet tall.Full of life with Birds and Insects.Also many Butterfly plants. The best are the sedums right now in full bloom.

We had rain for most of the day and the sun just now came out (3pm). I went out for the daily count and there are hundreds, maybe thousands on the apple, honeysuckle, and walnut trees. I took lots of photos and some movies. It's staggaring to see so many and I couldn't be happier! Let me know if you want photos! Here is a short movie of roosting monarchs "flashing" as another lands.

September 14
In traveling southeast from Altoona, Iowa, to Fort Madison, Iowa, we counted more than 100 monarchs crossing the highways. Along the Mississippi River late in the day, numerous monarchs could be seen traveling south along the river. The monarchs seemed to be plentiful in southeast Iowa and in northeast Missouri.

September 13
In the wake of three days of rain, dampness, and cool weather, today was sunny and mild, and the monarch butterflies were on the move once again. During a morning and an afternoon visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, 643 monarchs were counted, the largest number to date this autumn. In both visits, a large stand of sawtooth sunflowers in the northern part of the refuge was the main attraction for nectaring monarchs. In a flurry of activity in late afternoon, 266 monarchs were observed in 35 minutes as they flew here and there among the large stand of sunflowers--some of which now reach 8 to 10 feet.

September 9
The first "Monarch Madness" program was held Saturday at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Park staff members worked with participating children and adults in tagging 51 monarch butterflies under a program supported by the University of Kansas Monarch Watch. The morning was cloudy, damp, and foggy at the start, but by the time the prospective taggers took to the field in late morning, they stirred up plenty of monarchs in the habitat near the prairie center and along the refuge's savanna trail. Another 111 monarchs were observed indepedently during the morning, including 85 over the noon hour in the north part of the refuge. As the day warmed up and cleared off somewhat, the monarchs seemed to be migrating into the refuge from the north.

September 6
Monarchs were on the move this morning at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. In two hours of observation, 238 monarchs were counted. They were nectaring on tickseeds, thistles, and goldenrod. This is the largest number observed this fall, indicating the next week likely will be even more active with migrating monarchs.

September 3
Rainfall late Saturday afternoon dampened the prairie grasses at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, slowing the monarch activity on Sunday morning. In the first hour Sunday, two monarchs were observed, one of which was drying its wings atop a sawtooth sunflower. As the sun came out and began to dry up the prairie, the monarchs began moving again. Sixty-one monarchs were counted in the next hour. Among the monarchs nectaring on tickseeds was a viceroy butterfly.

September 2
The numbers of monarchs observed seemed to confirm the early phase of the monarch migration has begun over central Iowa. Monarchs could be observed flying into the refuge from the north, and the butterflly activity continued to grow at the refuge. In two and one-half hours, 195 monarchs were counted. Once again the tickseed sunflowers and common thistles were the favored wildflowers for nectaring. The goldenrod is in full bloom but has yet to be attracting the monarchs as it has in other years. An occasional monarch could be seen stopping on an ox-eyed sunflower or cup plant.

September 1
Monarch activity at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge continued to increase as 155 monarchs were observed in a bit more than two hours. The most popular nectaring flowers were tickseed sunflowers and common thistles. Numerous monarchs were found in a large stand of tickseeds where the butterflies were flying to and fro as they moved from flower to flower. Often two or more monarchs were chasing each other in the air above.

August 30
Sixty-seven monarch butterflies were noted during a visit of one and one-half hours in the morning at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Many of them were spotted on the northern edge of the refuge, suggesting they were part of the early movement of monarchs beginning their migration to the south. They often were seen coming up out of the big bluestem grasses where they likely were staying overnight. Field observations at the refuge during the summer months did not reflect as much monarch activity in this northern area.

Greetings from St. Joseph's School  Several students have seen 15-20 Monarchs. Our art teacher has sighted at least 50 Monarchs roosting in her backyard.  One of our maintenance workers sighted "thousands" in the trees near his farm about ten miles south of Lincoln.

A friend's brother who lives about 1/2 hr from my home in Oxford, Ohio called to say they were seeing lots of monarchs arriving in their back yard around 4pm on Sept. 13. We arrived about an hour later to see monarchs flying around everywhere we looked. We counted a few clusters of 100 monarchs already roosting with multiple other clusters forming on a pine and 2 ash trees. We estimated at least 500 to 600 already roosting and another few hundred flying around looking for just the right tree or branch. The migration is definitely here and right on time. Our peak dates start on Sept 14.

This is the first time I have monarch clumping at night in my trees. Saturday the 9th I must have had a least 400. Then the tempature dropped and we have had a lot of rain. Today, the 13th is the first sunshine and I went out about 6:30 pm and have maybe 200 roosting. This is one of the coolest things I have ever seen.
Students have reported seeing Monarchs on a daily basis for the last two weeks.  The numbers seem to be less each day as the peak migration may have occurred.

Sunday (Sept 10th) was without a doubt an amazing sight to behold at the park (Holiday Beach Migration Observatory ). The entire day was cloudy, winds from the South at 10-15mph and temperature remained between 55-60 degrees F. Every Monarch that flew into the park, remained at the park in small roosts between 100-200 butterflies per tree: every other tree in the SW corner of the park was filled with Monarchs. This was amazing to see but the bad news was that ALL of the Monarchs were out of my reach! Yes, these Monarchs were gathering in the cottonwoods 50-60 feet above the ground. An occasional five or ten would flutter off the leaves, then return to their roost - always beyond the reach of my net. If I only had a cherry picker or one of those machines the hydro workers use to maneuver about the lines and trees.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

There were some good butterflies seen on Sept. 11th, 2006 at Point Pelee National Park:
Monarch Butterfly - 800

Contributed by Don Davis

There are Monarchs all over the place in Ottumwa, IA this past week. Many nectaring and the rest heading south. We are in South Central Iowa. My daughter and I tagged 100 Monarchs last week. We should have waited as there are many more moving through the area now!

Seeing many Monarchs here nearly getting hit by cars! Tons of them. They should have Monarch Crossing Signs to put up for this time of year!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We predict peak is close but notice fewer butterflies here than usual! We have been looking for migration and are seeing a few more each day.

We have collected 38 Monarch caterpillars and have observed and predicted with amazement as metamorphosis has occurred! We have released 7 so far, 5 females and 2 males. We are at peak hatching and we know the weather is to change here soon. We are tagging today and releasing more. Heavy female year.
We noticed Monarchs migrating through our playground at the rate of one per minute. The children were very excited to see this!
Highest sightings this season. At least over 20 today.

September 26
slight NW wind cooler temps counted 36 monarchs in 4 hours - raptors were also hard to find

September 25
good NW wind sat on north side of the blueridge for 1½ from 1:30 - 3 PM - 135 monarchs - back home flying high 34 more - many raptors sighted - 2 eagles 8 osprey - my neck hurts from looking up -

September 24
weather going from sunny SW to dark rainey back to sunny SW most of the afternoon - counted 38 - every 5-8 minutes on the Delaware River(fishing)a new hatchling and others on my flowers at home - great day to be a butterfly

September 23
after rainy AM late afternoon brought steady migtation flying low- time between monarch 5-8 minutes 3 til 6PM observed 15 but wasn't always outside

September 22
Slow start this AM with temps in the 40's - this afternoon with easy SW breeze temps mid 60's brought migrating Monarchs in low and stopping at the flowers - counted 34 but I was busy in the yard - seemed like every 4-5 minutes one would pop up - 70 broadwings in a group an eagle - 3 osprey

September 21
not much time outside - 2 monarchs on the flowers - winds were bad for my situation - temps in the 40's in the AM - high skys and windy

September 20
NW wind probably took most migrators to the north side of the Blueridge - a trip to Hawk Mountain 19529 - saw 12 monarchs on the north face(1½ hours) - 4 more on the ride home and one on my flowers. (1 hatchling still trying.) Weather got crazy after 4 PM dark clouds gusting in many directions. Hummers still on the feeder and flowers.

September 19
slow start this AM with S winds fog mist and rain - wind and weather changed to SW winds(slight) cloud filled blue skys 16:30 - 18:30 - 24 migrating - 8 feeding and 3 in the AM migrating = 35 ....hitting Hawk Mountain tomorrow NW 6-15 knots, I'll try to get their Monarch numbers if you want them

September 18
Nice warm(80)sunny day - S wind to 5 knots changing to SW calm breeze - kept birds and Monarchs on the southside of The Blueridge - bought a golf clicker (PROcount - from Dick's $3.99 then WalMart $1.49-same item, go figure)has two separate areas that go from 00 to 99 and beyond - driving saw maybe 20 migrating Monarchs, in the yard on the flowers - 12 and the remaining 17 from several points (3) from 5PM til 7PM = 49 the Monarchs were using their wings to head SW - no free rides today-got to love em - they're so cool

September 17
warm calm day after rain and NE E winds for several days - high flying and feeding Monarchs - over 50 spotted on the south side of the blueridge mountains(my yard and two trips to the mountain to observe the migrating raptors) on their way to Mexico - Hawk Mountain has been giving Monarch counts on their web site

I was walking my dogs about 6:00PM on Sept. 1 and noticed 2 monarchs flying around. I had not seen many all summer. Suddenly there were 3 more and then as we walked closer to a weeping willow tree, a large bunch of monarchs took to wing. Without being able to count them, I would estimate several hundred butterflies were scattered in the trees. In all, they were roosting in about 10 large trees. They were hard to spot when they were roosting, but the minute we walked under the trees, they would fly around. The weather was cool - upper 50s over night. On Saturday, Sept. 2, we had cool, rainy weather. The monarchs stayed around all day. On Sunday, there were less, and then by Monday they were gone. Interestingly, on Wednesday, Sept. 6, a friend who lives about 1/2 mile south of me had a very large group of several hundred monarchs roost in trees around her house and stay until Sunday, Sept 10.

HOORAY!!  A wonderful wave of butterflies flew through Kansas City this afternoon!  As I was driving home at 3:15pm, I observed 68 butterflies in 8 minutes crossing above the highway.After I got home, I was able to observe for 20 minutes and counted 96 Monarchs.  It was so exciting!  It's been a few years since I have seen so many at one time.  They had cool temperatures in the upper 60's, a nice Northern breeze and cloudy skies.  The majority were flying high above the trees.  They're on their way!!!

9/13/06
I saw over 100 butterflies near Geist Reservoir. They were fluttering and fanning their wings. They were on bushes, not feeding. The weather was humid and had rained the night before. Later at home I saw the monarchs. They were gathering on an ash tree in a sheltered area near Fort Harrison Park. They seemed to congregate on two branches of this tree. Again fanning and quiet. Occasionally fluttering in the small secluded area of my back yard.

9/14/06
It rained overnight. I wondered "Where do butterflies go in the rain?" Sure enough the next morning there they were, on the same two branches. Coloration dull. At around 9:00 saw some fluttering brighened wings but no sun to reflect.

9/15 - 9/16
The monarchs have gone. Saw only one butterfly on the 16th.

A spectacular migration was witnessed at the Rockfish Gap Hawk Watch site on Friday, September 15:

"It's difficult to adequately describe the most impressive flight of Monarch Butterfly I and the observers have ever witnessed. When I arrived at 4:15 EST, driving up to the parking area, I noted quite a fiew low-flying Monarchs. At top of the parking area they we litterly swelling up and over the hillside. When I scanned the sky, it was filled. As far as one could see, Monarch Butterflies. Not a single one here and one there, butclusters filled the sky, quickly moving through by the brisk NW winds, acontinuous flow. The (hawk) counters noted this incredible flight had been nonstop all afternoon. Just in the first hour I was there literally thousands had passed through. This is not an exaggeration but a conservative estimate!

Forwarded by Dr. Lincoln Brower

When a northwest wind hits the ridges of the Appalachian Mountains the air lifts upward. Monarchs can fly effortlessly along the ridges, toward the southwest.

September 26
Since Sept. 18th, the numbers of observed Monarchs are decreasing by the day. Today I only spotted one flutterbye, but I couldn't miss this one. I was taking a break at work around noon, and this orange and black came down right in the area I was sitting-all sorts of really neat aerobatic dances for apx 30-45 seconds. That was a hoot to see. Granted, I was inside for 12 hours at work today, so I may have missed a pretty fair number of them. I'll keep looking.

September 24
The last several days have been very slow for spotting Monarchs. I've only seen around 15 in the last two days. I've a feeling the real masses that usually pass through here are still forthcoming.

September 22
On the 19th my fishing partner and I spotted about 10 or 12 Monarchs flying just high enough to avoid being hit by vehicles when we were enroute to my lake located about 20-25 miles NE of Ponca City. We saw them in the midafternoon. I also saw 3 or 4 at various times through the morning hours.All that I saw today were flying 5-15 feet in height with their southern goal on their little Monarch minds obviously. The 19th was a gorgeous day with highs in the mid seventies with light and variable winds. The 20th and 21st we had very high southerly winds from 15-35 mph at least. Naturally no Monarchs were spotted those two days. Today brought much better weather with almost no wind at all and mid seventies again. I spotted a dozen this AM from 10:30-11:30. Looking forward to trying to see some more in the morning.

September 18
I have good news from northcentral Oklahoma. The migration south is on full-force here! With the passing of the latest cool front and today a prevailing northerly breeze, the numbers of the beauties are increasing dramatically with each passing day. This morning I had time to sit in my back yard for about on hour in which time I observed 43 Monarchs heading south. I was delighted to see an entertaining group of three traveling together and doing all kinds of aerobatics on their slow meander to the south. Most all that I saw were flying at a height of 6-15 feet but a few were up there at apx. 15-25 feet high, and those were the fastest passers. The lower ones generally were flying much slower. Temp here this AM was in the lower 60's. Heads up to the friends of JN in Perry, Oklahoma....you should be seeing them very very soon!!

A morning filled with Butterflies! On my 20 minute morning walk I observed 50 Monarchs. Returning to my yard, I sat down and for an hour observed a wonderful flight - 175 Monarchs in one hour.The temperature is cool, in the upper 50's, light to moderate Northern breezes, clear skies. Most of them are sailing high above the rooftops and treetops, but a few have dropped down to feed on the flowers. As I write this at 11:10 am, I can see 5 in my yard now!

Our 2nd migration pulse.
Today a moderately big migration brought in at least 100 monarchs to our garden at home (and at Sweet Briar College). At 7 PM, as the sun went behind the mountains, at least 60 monarchs were clustering for the night in an oak and a Magnolia up on the hill behind the Buddleas. Really pretty to see them......

I was so excited to see the Monarchs pass over my home today.  I had to find a way to tell others. I counted around 50 Monarchs flying above us, from the Cleveland, OH, area over Kent and heading south. I stopped counting at 50 but they continued to come between between 4:30 pm to 5:30 pm.  I've never seen them migrate south before and it was quite a thrill.  I just left the computer for a second to check and they are still flying above us.

Sitting in the parking lot at work during lunch (12:30pm CT), I counted 45 Monarchs in 25 minutes. All were trying to fly SW. It was partly sunny, but very windy (10-15 mph from the NW, and 65F). They better hurry as the temperature is predicted to fall down to 30F by Wednesday morning at 7 am. I still have one "cat" on Asclepias incarnata outside @ home in Marengo- 20 mi. from work. I may bring it in the house. The other "cat" that I had is gone & assumed it formed chrysalis, but couldn't find it. I hope is has buried deep into the nearby mum foliage & will survive. After the chilly day it is suppose to warm back up into the upper 60's.

On Saturday, 9/16/06, there were Monarch Butterflies in the hundreds roosting in my hedge row and flying around my yard (1 acre at the edge of town. On Sunday (9/17/06) many were still there...some had left. Today (9/18/06)after a large rain there were a few flying around my yard. It was a beautiful sight! The first time I have seen it happen.

A couple of weeks ago, we were out in a meadow in northern Vermont, which was filled with milkweed and asters. We searched and searched, but only found 1 or 2 chrysalids. To our surprise, when we visited this past weekend, the meadow was a-flutter in nectaring monarchs! We counted 25 in just a few minutes. We wondered if they were 1) the monarchs that had emerged on that milkweed, 2) passers-by, or 3) some of both!

Another beautiful day for Monarchs!  From 1:30 to 2:30 I observed 67.  From 2:30 to 3:30 I observed 48.  Temperatures were in the 60's, with winds variable from gentle to strong.  Until 4:30 there were very few butterflies, then from 4:30 to 5:00 I observed 40 butteflies and almost all of these came into my yard to feed on the flowers.
I believe there was 1000 to 3000 that were in the treeline down the edge of my yard. I checked again on 9/18/06 and most were gone but they chowed down on my leaves.
Several hundred monarchs roosted in the old maple tree in our yard.

As I was driving from one of my schools to the other, only a mile or so, I saw at least 50 monarchs crossing the street within a 10 minute period. They were flying low and not stopping to eat. They were definately not "riding" the wind, which may be why they were so low. We can always count on them coming in on the cold fronts that move through Kansas. On 9/16 it was 69degrees here. 9/17 was about 10 degrees lower. Yesterday, 9/18 was when I saw an immense influx. They were ahead of some very chilly weather as it was in the 40's last night for the first time this season.

Our students spotted approximately 150 monarchs yesterday. The day began bright and sunny with temperatures approximately 81 degrees. However, over the course of the day it began to rain and did so throughout most of the evening. Most of the monarchs were spotted after school in the heat of the day. The temperatures dropped as the rain went through our region. Most of the monarchs were seen in flight while 40 were on flowering plants such as butterfly weed, butterfly bush, zinnias, and in cornfields. Some were seen sitting in warm places such as driveways, siding, decks, and grills.

Crowds of Monarch Butterflies (at least 386) headed southwest. The butterflies were dense enough at times to be a real distraction to finding and counting hawks!

Mahogany Rock is near milepost 239 on the Blue Ridge Parkway, roughly 25 miles south of the VA/NC line.

Observed by Jim K. and forwarded by Lincoln Brower and Elizabeth Hunter

We had sunny warm weather over the weekend after a few days of rain and I saw monarchs steadily throughout the weekend, no matter where I went: Prospect Park in Brooklyn, Central Park in Manhattan, midtown through traffic, as i walked over the Brooklyn Bridge. Maybe I was out and seeing them more but it seemed peak to me.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Mon., 9/18, 10:00am, Temp. 60's, and northerly breezes.  I traveled south by car for about 30 miles. I counted over 100 Monarchs drifting and fluttering along, going in a southerly direction. On Tuesday, 9/19,  I watched 3 Monarchs necturing in my backyard butterfly garden.

There has been a steady stream of Monarchs all day through my property in Rochester, Vermont. I have someone staying up there and they called me very excited to say that the Monarchs are coming though about every 2-5 minutes. My land overlooks the White River and they seem to be following the river through the valley.  They have each stopped to drink from my Butterfly Bush and my other flowers, rested for a bit and then disappeared over the hill towards the river. May their Journey South be a safe one! Mary Ellen Brosnihan

We were the absolute luckiest people on the planet this evening! Several hundred monarch butterflies decided our yard was an ideal roost. With several large trees and tons of ziennas and mairgolds and spider flowers the monarches spent more than 1 and 1/2 hours landing in an ash tree. It was amazing, they came in from every direction and waltzed around looking for the perfect spot. I have seen roost trees before, but not in my yard! It still leaves me breathless, even got a few pictures!
Several hundred Monarchs observed heading south over last 2 days.

Two friends in Des Moines told me they also saw substantial monarch movement through the area yesterday (September 20). A light rain came this morning, so I don't know quite what to expect now from the monarchs.

The number of monarchs tagged at the Haskell - Baker Wetlands last Saturday was 2671. A bit lower than the nearly 2800 tagged in 2001. However, there were more participants (>500) this year and most of them were new to tagging.

September 21
While cleaning up late yesterday, my crew found 4 more data sheets from the Saturday tagging event with 88 additional records of tagged monarchs. These additional tags bring the total to 2759. This number exceeds the preliminary estimate for the tagging in2001 of 2650 monarchs tagged. However, as I recall, a subsequent count showed the number to be close to 2800.Now, if I could only found the exact number for 2001 we'd know whether the number this year set a new record.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

(Sept.20) There were perhaps a couple thousand monarchs near Long Point(on Lake Erie) - but they were spread out all over the place and not a single cluster. None on the goldenrod and the winds blew them inland.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

The Monarchs arrive in my yard every fall. The last two years were the most populated years. Sometimes the Monarchs stay for 2 to 4 days, roosting in my trees. I would estimate that there were between 500 to 1000 monarchs roosting this year. I first noticed them on Saturday, September the 16th. The weather turned cooler late on the 18th and, the next day, the monarchs were gone.

I have had them in this same area of my yard every year for at least the last 6 years. It is an overwhelming sight that I always love to share.

Each year the monarchs roost in hemlock trees and this year they were also in nearby cypress, willow, flowering crab, and pin oak trees. The only flowers close by are zinnias. I always notice that when the roost is disturbed in anyway or by a new arrival of a monarch they flutter their wings for a short time and then settle back down with only closed wings.

(I took this picture on Monday, September 18th.)

On a trip to a berry farm to pick raspberries we saw large numbers of monarches necturing on alfalfa growing in fallow ground between the berry patches, and roosting in nearby trees as well. It was about 2:00 in the afternoon on a bright, sunny day, with temperatures in the mid 70s. I'd estimate one monarch per every two square yards, along with several other species. Upon our return from picking,  about an hour later, there were slightly fewer in the alfalfa and the ones in the trees had gone.Interestingly, there were no butterflies in the raspberry rows - just in the alfalfa.
Hundreds of monarchs nectaring singly along the Concord River. Saw one group of 6. Some flying in a southerly direction.

I am not sure if this means anything to you, but I run a painting crew in Overland Park KS and today was amazing! Over lunch (1 hour) my crew and I counted 135 Monarch flying s.w. some close enough to touch some 30 feet in the air, and a lot stopping at a lilac bush in the back! We were so intrigued that the counting went on for the rest of the day, every few seconds you would hear a new number called out from around the house. I have worked outside all of my life and never seen this, or just never caught it. I was so captivated I thought I should let someone know,maybe to help track a flight plan...

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Yesterday was a big day at Monarch Waystation #1 with 20-60 monarchs present most of the day. A walk past the butterfly bushes that serve as an entrance to the garden would often put 15 monarchs and numerous other butterflies to flight. It was quite a sight.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Last evening (9/21/06) about 5:15 pm we were taking our evening walk and we saw at least 50-100 Monarchs in the sky moving southward. What a gift to see them in migration. I haven't seen this since I was a child lying on a blanket in my backyard and just happened to see hundreds of monarchs flying overhead. Back then I had no idea what was happening. I see yesterday's sighting as a gift for the day!

Cape Elizabeth had more than 1 per minute sighted today along the rocky shores. Northlerly winds, sunny, low 60's this morning had them basking on rocks and leaves and nectaring on composites. Observations for 2 hours never saw less than 1 per minute. First time for this Texan to see this end of the migration from down east. what a treat!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We took a walk around our nature center today, and we counted 30 monarchs. That was in our little area by the pond, as we walked around the pond to the "preserved prairie", we couldn't keep up with the count. There must have been hundreds today. It was such a warm, sunny and breezy day. We found flowers (black eyed susans & milkweed) on the ground and raised them high abover our heads and the butterflies were coming to us. It was an amazing sight. Good day for monarch sightings!
There were about several thousand Monarchs flying over my backyard.

Approximately 100 monarchs were sighted at Gilgo Beach in Long Island, New York. The butterflies stopped and roosted before crossing the Atlantic Ocean. I assume they try to stay close to shorelines? (Take a look at the Atlantic Ocean at Gilgo Beach: Link to Web cam)

Given the inconsistent rains and colder weather in the last week, I went searching at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge for migrating monarchs that might have been slowed on their trip south. In the north of the refuge, I counted 16 monarchs in an area where most of them were clinging to tall sawtooth sunflowers as the plants waved in a strong wind. To the south about three miles, I went walking along a savanna trail that sits at the edge of the prairie and a wooded area of oaks, hickories, and other trees. There on a hillside in an area protected from the strong wind, I enjoyed a "monarch moment" as the butterflies dipped out of the trees onto various wildflowers for nectaring. In the next two hours, I counted more than 200 monarchs in the quiet surroundings. Overall, the count for the day was 251 monarchs.

We were in Riverside Park at 12:10pm on a sunny clear day. Temperature was in the upper 60's with a gentle breeze. Monarchs were fluttering around the Buddlea bushes. They were arriving from a Northerly direction, one or two at a time. They arrived in the garden area almost always coming through one particular line of trees. About 30 came through during the hour we spent there. They fluttered around the flowers, nectaring for short periods before heading off in a Southerly direction. Some went towards NJ across the Hudson, others followed the West Side Highway downtown.We tagged 17. 15 of those were males. Only two were females. I wonder what that means. On Wed. when we were tagging, there was a fairly even split between males and females.

A woman I know who lives between Black Mountain and Chimney Rock, NC who has had monarchs roost in her yard in previous years called me about 3-4 p.m. today. She said that there was a major migration going on through her yard this afternoon (she and her husband watched for an hour before they had to stop and get on with their work for the day). During the hour they watched, she said they were passing at a rate of 30 per MINUTE!!!! They were still migrating through when she called me. She said it was the most she had seen since 2002, when they roosted in her yard.

Forwarded by Elizabeth Hunter for Ruth S.

Today while driving past our local Mall I spotted over 100 Monarch's on Golden Rod and other wildflowers. I have never seen so many Monarch's in our area at one time.Also today outside on my butterfly bush I had six at one time.

On this Saturday, the monarch migration continued over central Iowa at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge and in the city of Des Moines. At Neal Smith, 150 monarchs were counted in 2 1/2 hours, and family members observed at least 50 more in Des Moines. Monarchs also were seen in our butterfly garden and flying across the highways in the area. Based on my observational records of monarch movements over the years, by the date of September 23, the migration has been virtually completed in the area in four of the five most recent years. It now seems clear this year's migration was slowed by the cold weather and continued rainfall. On Saturday morning, the monarchs came flying into the refuge from the north one at a time, then sought out nectaring areas. The native purple asters were a definite favorite. To the south near the refuge's savanna trail, other monarchs were lingering there in the warmth of a protected area.
Lots of movement of adult monarchs heading south and west, here in the Woodbridge and Sewaren areas. Been tagging many of them, but ran out of tags.

Huge sighting today in ASHLAND, MO (South of Columbia, MO)!Visiting friends at their home on the Southside of Ashland and observed "67" Monarchs in flight from 11:45AM to 3:00PM.  Most of these were observed at heights of 25ft. to approx. 75ft.  It was an awesome view!!!!

We had warm weather that suddenly turned cool, we noticed several hundred to a thousand monarchs clinging together and at the tops of our spruce trees and in our woods, they remaind there for two nights then this morning the weather turned warmer and the sun came out. They became more active and are flying around. This is the first year we have noticed this and we have lived here 17 yrs.
About 5:30 p.m. monarch butterflies were passing over our house at a rate of 40-50 per minute. I checked at about 6:30 p.m. and did not see any.

We have a butterfly bush in our yard and we are in a valley in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Western North Carolina. for the past two days we have seen hundreds of butterflys. Today (September 18)seems to be a lot less. Perhaps the peak has passed.
Hundreds of butterflies located at Salisbury State Campground in Salisbury, MA. I was able to get some beautiful pictures that look delightful on the computer screen. They were amazing to watch.

Yesterday was beautiful in northeast Ohio. The butterflys were on the move. The temperatures were in the 60s and it was very sunny. My students spotted over 200 butterflys in our area. They actually saw a lot during gym class over our football heading in a southerly direction. They also saw about a dozen during their recess/lunch time. A lot of them are flying near treetops. My students also see them eating on their grapes and other nectar producing flowers. Some were eating on pears on the ground. Basking seemed to happening in low numbers on shingles, rocks, hoods of vehicles. Most of the butterflys they saw were flying. It was a good day for them to fly!

I have no idea what's happening anywhere else (non-Essex County) this year, but we have been having an amazing early Autumn Monarch emergence and migration. Today in our ~5 acre meadow (unmown) there were over 200 Monarchs counted as they nectared on Goldenrod and skimmed low across the grasstops. There were also many, many uncounted Monarchs moving high up and southward. Every Goldenrod plant seemed to have one or more (sometimes 6!) fresh Monarchs. They have simply outnumbered every other species that I have observed in our 'patch' in the last month. Spectacular!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I have seen a high number of monarchs passing by during the past week in Eastern MA. Probably, the highest in this year so far. Today I drove downtown Beverly and saw them as one per minute. They were all fluttering toward West. Cloudy with high humidity at ~80F.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
7 Monarchs in one 10 minute period heading in a westerly direction.

Last week, we took our entire sixth grade to camp in Southern New Hampshire. Monarchs were everywhere! One spent about a minute resting on my shoe, opening and closing its wings.

From there, we went north to spend the weekend in our cabin in East Corinth, Vermont. Our land has loads of milkweed, and we were not surprised to see many monarchs. On Sunday, we watched in awe as hundreds of monarchs flew together down the valley, southward, on the wings of a fresh wind. It was like watching a parade!

9/25/06
An average of about 200 monarchs per hour going south from 10am to noon, dropping off to around 150 per hour from noon until 2pm. Observation site about 300 feet from Atlantic Ocean. Weather: high clouds, slight onshore breeze. Beach Goldenrod not in bloom yet, but close.

9/29/06
Saw 48 monarchs heading south (1 confused one going north) between 1:30 pm and 2:30 pm with majority (32 monarchs),between 1:30 and 2:00. wx scatterd cumuliform clouds 4k to 6k, wind nnw at 15 to 20 knots.
Saw hundreds - no exaggeration--of monarch butterflies at Fire Island National Seashore. Absolutely amazing. I've never seen anything like it!

How amazing! We saw what must have been thousands of Monarchs flying south over Highway 400 (just a few miles west of I-44). Later in the afternoon we went to a nearby park and photographed many butterflies. (The park was Schermerhorn, just outside of Galena, KS.) There is a trail with a Prairie Grassland area-- this is where we saw about 100 playing and dining on some wildflowers. The temperature was in the low 70's and it was sunny.

It was wonderful. We decided to have lunch on the beach in Misquamicut, R.I. Hundreds, possibly thousands of beautiful monarch butterfies were following the coastline south. We attempted to take some pictures will our cell phone, but I don't think we were successful. An occasional monarch would land on the high tide seaweed line and rest for a few minutes. None of us could believe that these fragile insects could fly so far!

Denise Gibbs, of the The Chincoteague Monarch Monitoring Project reports:

10/2/06
Monarchs migrated down the island by about 1,300 per hour for most of today. Winds were from the NW at 10mph, full sun with temps in low 70's. It was quite a show!

9/29/06
This was our best monarch migration day yet! The Cape May monarchs finally arrived here. With winds WNW at 15mph there was a steady flight of monarchs all day, right up to about 7pm. The 4 pm census indicated about 1,000 monarchs per hour were passing through. Get ready, all you monarch watchers at Kiptopeke!

9/25/06
Migrants were on the move for most of today during NW winds at 10mph. Monarchs averaged about 140 per hour between 9am - 3pm. Other migratory insects seen in huge numbers were common buckeyes, green darners, black saddlebags and wandering glider dragonflies. Tree swallows numbered in the thousands and there was a steady flight of peregrines, merlins, bald eagles and osprey. Quite a day!

About the ProjectDenise Gibbs is the founder and director of the Chincoteague Monarch Monitoring Project. The study takes place at Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge, on Assateague Island, Virginia.

I was in Cape May on Saturday and Sunday and was amazed by the roosts! I had never seen that before- I can't imagine how great it would be in Mexico or even California. I met monarch enthusiasts, even some monarch watchers. I would say there was between 500-1000 butterflies on one empty lot- Louise said they were there for the English ivy that was in bloom- they were also hanging out on the cedar trees.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I was in Cape May today and I was amazed to see all the Monarchs flying into town! They were everywhere!

As I drove to Cape May via I 76 E, Atlantic City Expressway and Garden State Parkway, I saw Monarchs traveling too! As I approached Cape May, I thought I was looking at birds in the distance - they were butterflies! I was at the Cape May Bird Observatory and heard Louise Zemaitis talking about the numbers of butterflies. She was also telling people where they were roosting. I drove there and saw her talking with a man and his kids. We were in awe of the butterflies flying around and roosting in the pines. This defies description...it was nature at its best and most beautiful!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

The Monarch Monitoring Project in Cape May, NJ is conducting its 15th year of research and education. Details of our project may be found on the Monarch Monitoring Project Web site.

9/28/06
SOME BIG NUMBERS! Road Census data (sampling migrant monarch numbers along the mid-Atlantic coast) through week 4 is now posted on our website.

9/25/06
Louise Z. recorded a significant flight of monarchs today at Cape May. On three census runs she counted a total of 1,794 monarchs.

I have never seen so many monarchs in Manhattan (NY).  I stood at one row of buddleia bushes and about 50 m. from the Hudson River & tagged 33 butterflies from about 12:15 to 13:40 h today.  The wind picked up about then and the number of butterflies dropped off, so I called it a day.
Today we sat in our backyard and in about a 30-45 minute period spotted approximately 90 monarchs all flying in a south-westerly direction.

September 26
I still continue to see lots of Monarchs come through my yard, but not as many as the past couple of days. From 1:00 pm to 2:00 pm, I observed 45 Monarchs and almost all of these came to feed on the flowers before flying off to the S/SW. A cold front is expected to arrive in the next 24 hours.

September 25
Another nice wave of Monarchs today. From 11:30 to 12:30 I observed 74 butterflies come through my yard with many stopping to feed on the flowers.

There were quite a few butterflies migrating this afternoon. As I sat on the Ventnor Boardwalk, I counted butterflies coming along the beach and the rooftops of the beachfront homes. Butterflies were coming in small groups of 2-5. I tallied butterflies for one hour beginning at 4:50pm and totalled 272 butterflies!

The influx of monarch's into Cape May continued today.  Counted over 50 in one minute looking just straight ahead...couldn't begin to count numbers if I turned my head.  They were everywhere; many roosts at Cape May Point. Some with numbers in the thousands.  Also noted many more painted ladies and even dragonflies (in the 1000s)today.  All around looks like a GREAT migration this fall!

We have seen huge amounts of monarchs over yesterday and today, all appearing to be flying south. It has been amazing seeing them in large number like this, I can't remember ever having seen so many in so short a time.
I looked out my window and I kept seeing Monarch butterflies. Every 10-15 seconds, 5 or 6 more go by. I find this fascinating to think they are headed to Mexico.

The monarchs are resting along the ocean in flowering bushes. We are seeing groups of 50 or more heading south. We also see single monarchs, pairs and small groups flying over our playground which is on an island between the bay and ocean. This has happened the last several days.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

Brian C. just called me from Gooseberry. He had seen about 30 Monarchs in 20 minutes pass by his school so decided to drive down there in late afternoon to see if anything was going on. The rest of this is capitalized because this is how he was talking:

”GOOSEBERRY IS COVERED WITH MONARCHS!! THEY ARE ALL OVER THE TREES AND FLOWERS AND FIELDS AND TRAILS!!! ON THE CEDAR TREE BY THE TOWER (UP THE HILL) THERE MUST BE THOUSANDS OF THEM!!! I'VE NEVER SEEN ANYTHING LIKE THIS BEFORE!!!! I ESTIMATE AT LEAST 13,000 MONARCHS, THIS IS WITHOUT GOING INTO BUSHY AREA!!! THEY ARE HANGING ON THE TREES, LIKE HUNDREDS HANGING ON A TREE!!!

Brian has been going to Gooseberry for years. He started out at Allens Pond where he saw about 350 Monarchs on goldenrod, mostly nectaring, there were some migrating. A couple was at Westport Town Beach this morning
Saw clusters of 25 to 30 Monarchs flying. By the end of the day, I had seen several hundred.
Today we saw 35 monarchs in five minutes. It was a very bright sunny day with a temperature of 79 degrees. Most were flying lower to the ground, but we did see some that were above the tree line.

There are tall, thick stands of purple New England asters in our yard and monarchs were feeding. There seemed to be dozens of them. Weather was warm (about 75 degrees) and sunny. Looking up into a large hackberry tree, what seemed to be leaves were actually dozens of monarchs roosting! An incredible sight. Rob Roy is not far from the Wabash River on the western side of central Indiana. The monarchs seemed to be drawn by the late-blooming purple asters.

Sept. 19, Harvey's Knob, VAOn the Blue Ridge Parkway at Harvey's Knob, the Hawk Migration Association reported:

"Monarch butterflies were moving in large numbers today and our watchers made a very conservative count of 673."

They counted 355 monarchs the day before (9/18) but assumed they probably missed quite a few when they had a big push of nearly 400 broadwing hawks in one 50-minute period.

Observations forwarded by Elizabeth Hunter Hawk Migration Association

Sept. 20,At Rockfish Gap, VA, near Waynesboro, VA, the Hawk Migration Association reported:

"500+ Monarch butterflies (& that is being conserative)"

At the same time, they were counting something like 1,375 raptors including their first Golden Eagle of the year. They also reported 214 monarchs for the previous day (9/19/), but since they had 2,349 broadwing hawks that day, they may have missed a lot of monarchs!)

Observations forwarded by Elizabeth Hunter Hawk Migration Association

Monarchs are still streaming through Lawrence. I saw at least 28 as I drove along the road atop the Clinton Lake dam this morning. The road is roughly 1.5 miles in length. More monarchs are passing by my window this morning - at a rate of 1-2 per min.

The predicted arrival of monarchs from the north for Lawrence is the 8th -11th of September with an anticipated peak around the 20-23rd. The first monarchs arrived on the 11th but we are seeing a broad peak that started around the 20th but will probably continue through tomorrow. After Weds the weather is likely to be less favorable but we expect to see some monarchs through the first week of October and a few stragglers later in Oct.

Some monarchs are always late to join the migration. This morning I found 9 fifth instar caterpillars in Waystation #1. Given the cooler temperatures these individuals probably won't emerge as adults until after the 15th of October.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Hundreds of butterflies in sky, flying southwest. Some in groups and others alone.
About 12:30PM - sighted at least 50 individuals moving across the parking lot heading west.

The Monarchs are here!  I just saw more than a hundred of them in the Queens/Nassau border areas of Lake Success, Little Neck and Douglaston, New York. The weather is sunny with the temp. at about 70. Thought you'd like to know!

I walked out of school at 3:00 pm and there they were! I observed approximately 100 monarchs traveling south.  I was so excited since I had just read to second graders about monarch migration. I was pointing them out to anyone who would listen, explaining what was happening and where the monarchs were going. It was incredible.
school: Ps161m don pedro albizu campos school

comments:
Monday, Sept 25 at Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge on Assateague Island, Virginia:

Migrants were on the move for most of today during NW winds at 10 mph. Monarchs averaged about 140 per hour between 9am - 3pm. Other migratory insects seen in huge numbers were common buckeyes, green darners, black saddlebags and wandering glider dragonflies. Tree swallows numbered in the thousands and there was a steady flight of peregrines, merlins, bald eagles and osprey. Quite a day!

Monarch numbers are posted daily on the Chincoteague Monarch Monitoring Project website.

Denise Gibbs
Chincoteague Monarch Monitoring Project
Between the approximate time of 3:15 pm and 3:45 pm we sighted well over 1,000 monarch butterflies cross the north horizon, heading south.
Thousands of butterflies spotted feeding on and densely covering wild asters and goldenrod on Prout's Neck in Scarborough, Maine along the immediate rocky coastline. E-mail me for photos.

While sitting in an outdoor cafe in downtown NYC on 2nd Ave @ St Marks, I observed over 170 Monarchs from 2:50 pm until aprox 4:00 pm. The heavier traffic flow was in the first 1/2 hour (112 Monarchs). Amazingly, they seemed to stay all along the Avenue and many appeared as high as the 5 story buildings.

I had the pleasure of sighting at least 36 butterflies flying down Riverside Drive at 4:30pm.  At first I thought they were fluttering leaves...until I looked closer with my binoculars...I was truly delighted and happy to share this with others following the migration.Be well....
In northern Manhattan, in front of the Children's Hospital of New York, I looked up and counted at least 30 monarchs.  They stayed in our area for about 30 minutes.
Thousands of butterflies in the hedge trees and along the dry creek bed.

While riding the Metro-North Hudson Line (on the east side of the Hudson River) to work in NYC, I caught sight of a very large, apparently red butterfly flying south along the Hudson River (or following the parallel train line). When it paused in flight I confirmed that it was a butterfly. Then there were at least four or five more, and I could see that they were Monarchs. They were all doggedly flying south at different locations along the train line. None appeared beyond the point where the tracks turn inland towards the City. I think they must be following the course of the river. Incredibly exciting!Today was the second time I have witnessed this; the first was one day last week, perhaps Thursday or Friday (9/21-22).

Today, Sept. 27 there were hundreds of Monarchs on Toronto Islands. I estimated that I saw about 4000 individuals, and there were certainly many more that I didn't see. Many were nectaring on asters and goldenrods, but some were also migrating west. At the old natural science school at Centre Island I estimated about 2000 individuals, most draped over a couple of large dogwood bushes at the edge of the woods here, where they had likely roosted the previous night. There were also 3 Common Buckeyes on the islands.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

After a quiet week with relatively low counts, the monarch numbers were way up today at the Northampton gardens. They seem to be "on the move" everywhere! You could count two dozen at a time on Tom's double verbena patch.Is this a new migration wave? [Counts were similarly high 1-2 weeks ago, butthen dropped off markedly this past week.]

My students and I have been counting Monarchs flying S-SW over Park School in Brookline since last Friday. They and I have logged 14 hours of watching and in that time we have seen 1548 Monarchs, which translates to 111 per hour. About half of our Monarch total - 750 - was seen today in 4 1/2 hours (167 per hour). We've also seen 3 species of migrating dragonflies, a Peregrine Falcon (and quite a few other hawks), a number of Common Nighthawks (11 today), cormorants, Great Blue Herons, etc. If only Monarchs would do this more often!

Reported to the MassLep listserv.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

Beverly on Rt. 97 just past the Wenham line in thevicinity of Beverly Municipal Airport and nearby Wenham Lake

Here Icounted 1,000 or more Monarchs. Many were roosting in trees and manymore were nectaring at asters and goldenrod. Some individual asterplants had 10 to 15 Monarchs clustered upon them. This had to be thebiggest congregation of Monarchs in many years in Essex County,especially in areas near the coast. In one of my previous posts Ireported a huge abundance of them in Maine and so predicted this greatinflux we are witnessing now. As long as the days are still mellow andwarm and nights cool but frost free, we should still see theseimpressive aggregations for at least another week or so.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

A steady stream of Monarchs was flying over my house in Medford thisafternoon between 3:00 and 4:00 while I was mowing the yard. - Maybe10-12 per minute heading south. The procession ended with someincreasing clouds. Itwas neat to witness a small bit of this incredible migration.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

Still thousands onthe island. Not much leaving tonight as wind seemed to be coming from the westso they were not wanting to fly out into the wind over ocean. Still hugegroups on the trees, starting with around a hundred on one tree in the parkinglot near the gate, and many taller trees down the path varying with 500-700per cluster. Some tucked off side trails so really hard to estimate, but Iwould guess easily 4,000-4,500 still on the island, very conservative.Clusters were growing right up till the light faded, so really hard to get atally. More small clusters near the lighthouse on side cuts. Yikes. Best Ihave ever seen in the state, but wish I could have been there for themorning!

This morning I observed by far the heaviest directional monarch movement of the fall in our Reston VA location. During a 90 minute meeting, 11 AM to 12:30 PM today, I watched a stream of monarchs approaching our building from the ENE, stopping at times to nectar at goldenrods, asters and Eupatoriums, and then continuing on a mostly westerly bearing. Monarchs were passing at about 1 per minute-- a high rate for a location not part of any type of funneling landform and in the middle of northern Virgnia's suburbs.

Winds are from the SSE at about 7-12 mph. An approaching front from the west should bring possible thundershowers late today.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Spent the afternoon around the lighthouse area. Literally, thousands of monarchs in flight. Did a 1/2 hour count. Here is the breakdown.

1:40-1:45 77
1:45-1:50 160
1:50-1:55 200
1:55-2:00 202
2:00-2:05 130
2:05-2:10 140
and many more that I missed.
Thousands of monarchs in flight along the western coast of NJ. The Miami Beach area is about 7 miles north of Cape May.

Yesterday afternoon I went out to my car at approximately 4:30 PM. I noticed a monarch drifting by (heading SW)so I decided to linger for a while and during the next 30 minutes counted 11 monarchs - all heading SW. This is the FIRST time in the 30 plus years that I have lived in Concord that I have witnessed monarch migration here. While I am normally in Cape May at this time I think the observation is significant. There are no leading lines here and no particular reason for monarchs to aggregate in this area. I think the likely reason for my observation is that monarchs were moving across a very broad front and probably in very large numbers. Given the date and this movement, I'm inclinedto think that this year's migration may be unusually massive and sustained.

Summer monarch production in this area was above average . . . in fact I saw more monarchs here in July and August than in any previous year. It will be interesting to see how the season plays out in Cape May. I'll be
school: Founder, cape may monarch migration project

comments: Observed approximately 300 monarchs flying through in a north to southwest direction.  Approximate time was 4:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

Not only are there the thousands reported for Gooseberry Neck and other places, they're still up here on the North Shore too!

This evening 9/26 Joe Stichter walked out across the marsh road to the end of Nelson's Island in Rowley (part of Parker River NWR). Between about 5:45 and 6:30 p.m., as the western sun warmed the area, he saw 2,000 to 3,000 (estimate) Monarchs, all clustered on every available stalk of seaside goldenrod which lines the edge of Nelson's Island. There were more on the many asters in bloom. An amazing sight. Then, as the sun began to set, he saw them all begin to rise and move en masse toward the tall oak and other trees back on the land---presumably they are now there roosting in the trees overnight.

I was amazed to see 70 monarchs on the way to my parents house.  It was only a 10 minute drive.  My family and I truly enjoyed counting all the monarchs we saw and were very eager to report our findings.  I hope this isn't the peak time but am wondering if maybe it is.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

Doug Savich called on Sunday 9/24 to report that he saw about 2,000 Monarchs on Eastern Point, Gloucester, that day.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

On Friday, 9/22, Dorothy Saffarewich drove for an hour around Nahant, and counted about 50 Monarchs, just from the car.

At the Peck School on South St., bordering US Rt.287 south, I counted 30 Monarchs in one half hour between 11:45am and 12:15. I've noticed them everyday for the past two weeks, somedays there are fewer but on this day there were the most so far. I wonder if they follow the High-way? We expect rain for the next two days.

Between 3:45 and 4 PM this afternoon we counted 309 monarchs within our limited field of vision. We counted what we could see coming over the top of our house and through a group of trees to the east. The seemed to come in spurts. All were headed to the southwest.

Oh, my gosh! I have never seen monarchs roost before! It was amazing. This really makes you realize how many times that our busy work schedules make us miss the treasures in this world. We live in the Ozarks and our house is surrounded by woods. The roost occurred in two trees - a red oak and a white oak. The numbers started off small and even as I type continue to grow. There are hundreds now! I have pictures if anyone wants me to e-mail them some. 5:50 PM
While I was sitting in my car (for about 30 minutes) I saw at least 50 monarchs flying up and down fighting some pretty strong winds. They are beautiful!

From 3:30pm to 4:30pm US Central time- I saw about 30 monarch butterflies fly right through my back yard as I was sitting in family room looking out the window. I went outside and they were coming from a north/northeast direction. Mostly just one every few minutes, but once I saw 3 come by together. It was really amazing. in the past couple of weeks, I've seen them around on walks or driving around town, but noticed more and more of them today. Really Cool!

4:30 pm US Central time- saw a few more fly through the backyard!
575 monarchs nectaring on goldenrod observed along Island Path road in Hampton Beach, NH.
Our class saw about 20 monarch butterflies flying over our playground during recess at 12:15. It was a sunny, warm day. They were flying at about the height of our one story school.

At approximately 6 PM we counted 400 monarchs flying west to Cupsogue Beach (the most western part of Dune Road), Westhampton Beach, Long Island...We then counted approximately 100 very slow moving monarchs settling in the trees nearest to the path aprroaching the boardwalk...The follwing evening 9/26/06 we traveled just half an hour earlier and none flying west...We found about 50...quite active compared to the previous evening, getting ready to 'roost?'..When we drove back east we saw about 50 approaching the same trees at Cupsogue Beach...On Thursday evening 9/28/06 we saw none at the same spots

My Earth Science classes have been making migration observations the entire week. We count for 10 mins. and multiply by six to derive an hourly rate. We then average each class members rate to calculate a class rate. I then have several class rates averaged together. Here are this week's results:

9-26: 4 per hr
9-27: 8 per hr
9-28: 3 per hr
9-29: 138 per hr!
A good indication of peak migration.

Many observations were made of butterflies at altitudes of 50-100 feet.All observations were made at the same time each day (1015-1200), and from pre-determined observing posts aroung our school. Students are going to count this weekend to compare daily rate changes.

traveling from SW  MO, (Walnut Grove) along Hwy's 123, 13, 7, & 71, we counted over 500 Monarchs drifting from right (north) to left (south) in front of our van.  Unfortunately we hit 8 or 10.  Time was 10:00 am - 1:00 and distance was about 150 miles.  It was sunny, about 85 degrees and there were NE breezes.
Students observed 30 monarchs migrating in a 1 hour period.

I am a member of a local Nature group that shares sightings(NatureNS listserve). This report is based on a sighting just report by an N.S. fisherman, birder and whale watch tour guide, Carl Haycock, from Brier Island, Nova Scotia. Here is a quote from his sighting:

"Wednesday and Thursday,(27/28 Sept.) Brier Island was loaded with Monarch's. I've never seen so many. They were whereever you looked, always floating in through the corner of your eye.

Carl frequently submits reports on NatureNS. Brier Island, because of its geographic location is a regular migrating funnelling route for fall migrations for monarchs and birds and a great whale watching area.

I am a retired teacher and an active naturalist who assists in our local schoolwith nature and science activities. Two classes are presently doing a project related to Monarch butterflies and their migration. There have been several reports and discussion on our NatureNS listserve this past week regarding sig

We have been anxiously watching the maps and skies for monarch migration. The weather has not be very favorable, with lots of rain and southwest winds. But, today, our third grade class saw 80 migrating monarchs in 30 minutes! We have never seen so many. The interesting thing is, the wind was blowing from the southwest. They were still heading to the southwest, despite the wind. We wonder if migration will be even better in the next few days, when the wind might be more favorable. We will keep looking!

There were thousands of monarch butterflies in the largest tree on the back of our lot. They literally covered the branches. Some fluttered around the tree but most rested on the tree. This was the most awesome thing we have ever seen.
We were in the adirondack park,looking at the leaves in their new colors for fall.As we drove we saw about two hundred along the road.

On Wed 9/27, I drove to New York from Jackson, N.J. and had the roof down on my car. I was moved to tears by the numbers of monarchs that I saw. Its amazing that I made in to the city in one piece because I couldn't keep my eyes out of the sky. In NYC for two days; saw many, many monarchs (100s) flying south on both Wed and Thurs. Many were at the 10th story or higher ht. so there were probably more that were hidden from immediate view. It's literally raining monarchs this year!

I was driving into the city on 9/27 from Jackson from around 12 noon , arrived at 2:20 pm ( was late for a meeting, so I recall the time; however, the "wave" continued throughout the day. On Thurs 9/28, the "wave" was just as impressive. I stated in Brooklyn, Wed night and drove back into the city around 11:30 Thur. I couldn't believe the numbers I was seeing once again, while driving. I made a colleague come outside when I got in to work (E 25th and 1 Ave). I counted over 50 monarchs in a few minutes. We stayed outside for about a hr. watching them. Some were as high as 10 stories, others much lower--my guess is there were many we couldn't see.

Hundreds of Monarchs graced the skies of Paducah and Western Kentucky today. While traveling south on I24 from Paducah to the Gracie Kentucky exit(11:00am-12:00pm), I was able to count 385 Monarchs from the car. From Gracie to Clarksville,Tennessee(12:00pm-12:30pm), I saw another 26--making the total for the entire trip 411 Monarchs. Some were actively flying and some seem to be catching a breeze. Most of them seemed to travel in groups of 2,10 and even 50. There were a few lone Monarchs but not many. All were traveling in a SSW direction.
I observed 20 monarchs while I was sitting on the porch from 12:30 pm TO 12:45 pm.

Today has been a great day for migrating monarchs. I counted 33 in a period of 1 hour (3:45-4:45 Central time). The weather is clear and sunny today, with the temperature in the high 60's, and no wind, but yesterday it drizzled all day.

I am visiting my aunt and uncle in Mooresville, NC on Lake Norman.  Today we saw many Monarch butterflies.  Sometimes we saw one or two and other times we saw 5-6 together.  I think we saw about 20 between noon and 4:00pm, they were all flying the same direction and higher than usual butterflies. They all looked very similar.
My two boys and I counted 178 Monarchs flying over our house in Swannanoa, NC in an hour and forty minutes! We are late sending this because I just found out about this project.
My students and I counted 41 monarchs in 20 minutes, flying south, southwest very high in the sky. The monarchs appeared to be in an air current because they were moving quickly with little effort.

September 30
Monarch butterflies are still migrating through this area. There were more today that yesterday. It was not unusual to see 6-7 passing over at one time.

September 29
Starting at 1:33 PM, 71 monarch butterflies were sighted in a 15 minute time period. The butterflies seem to be taking a slightly different path today, probably due to the fact that it is so windy and the direction of the wind. They are still headed SW.

On Monday, Sept. 25, 2006 I counted 200 They were headed west along the south shore of Long Island, NY. This was a casual count between 9AM and 4PM. I was not outside all that time. On Friday Sept. 22, 2006 the amount going past looked to to be about the same, but I did not do a count. They seem to feed on our Mountauk Daisies. They start to bloom in the middle of September and grow all over Montauk. I haven't seen the butterflies on any other flower.

Sitting on our boat on Kentucky Lake today and we've seen several hundred Monarchs flying in a west, soutwest direction. I didn't know it was their migration time, so I got online and found out that this is the peak period in our area. Interesting to watch.

Today at 1:05 p.m. I went back to my dog's favorite frisbee field, and, as we stepped down into the field, I started counting monarchs! I saw one after another, and quickly called my neighbor (who raises them) so she could share in the excitement. She joined me and together we counted 64 monarchs within 65 minutes! They flew in a westerly direction and most flew high (a number of them catching currents and soaring very high). The temperature was 63 degrees and the sky was overcast. The wind was SSE 9mph. This was so much fun to see, especially since I hadn't seen any monarchs yesterday. (It had rained the night before and was extremely windy--I don't know if that's why I hadn't spotted any yesterday.) At any rate--today was worth the wait!
I have just gotten home from a trip to Reelfoot Lake near Tiptonville, Tn. and I have seen so many monarchs that it must be a peak migrtion experience. On this trip I have counted over 110 monarchs.

I observed approximatley 1000-1500 monarch butterflies gathering on trees at Gibson Island Maryland, on Mountan Bar Point. Mountain Bar Point is the very tip of the island where the Cheasapeake Bay and the Magathy River meet. My mom told me when she was a little girl my age (10) the butterflies were always there at the end of September and then began their migration.

During the last two days, 29th and 30th, we watched lots of monarchs cross a path through our property. Lost count and included my friends and family off and on both days. Also in another part of town my grandchildren noticed lots of them at the soccer field. What a magnificent sight to see. This is the first time we had ever seen this. They had a direct route over our house in a steady flow. Thanks for the information on your site. We have learned a lot. Martha

Sitting on our boat on Kentucky Lake today and we've seen several hundred Monarchs flying in a west, soutwest direction.  I didn't know it was their migration time, so I got online and found out that this is the peak period in our area.  Interesting to watch.

I have been spotting monarchs since about 10AM today.  From about 10Am - 12 PM, I have seen monarchs about 6-7 an hour.  I was about ten miles northwest of downtown Charlotte.  From 2-3PM, I have been at my apartment, which is about 5 miles south of downtown Charlotte and have seen about 4 monarchs every twenty minutes.  So that would be about 12 an hour.

I was at a soccer tournament in Charlotte this weekend and on both Saturday and Sunday I counted at least 7 Monarchs in the short time I was at the soccer field.  They were numerous enough that the kids and fans noticed them.

Counted over 200 today while in a parking lot in Richmond. On the drive home saw many in flight heading in a southern direction.

We made several different stops while at the Richmond plaza, so I am guessing it would have been about an hour all together. Some were flying solo, some in groups of two or three. They were spaced about 10 to 20 seconds apart. Another thing I noticed was that they seemed to be flying in the same line or pattern. I could see some in the distance but the ones I counted were flying over the cars in the next aisle to where I was parked. It was like there was an invisible path they were following. When my husband came back to the van I told him about it. We started looking for them on the drive home as well and saw quite a few.

October 4
The past few days I've noticed some more, but nothing like the number on that day I reported.

Monarchs were flying directively SW, I noticed on my route from Charlotte, N.C. to Clemson, S.C, on Friday and Saturday. It was a beautiful weekend of 70-73df with crisp light winds, clear and sunny. The Monarchs were flying too high to catch but quite a nice scene seeing them fly right across the front field of Clemson Univ. where students were out enjoying the sun too. At the South Carolina Botanical Gardens in Clemson, there were hundreds of Monarchs nectaring on Buddleia and Lantana. I caught approx. 20 by the "cupping hands" technique.
