A few were fresh young Monarchs but many were a bit worn and faded - maybe traveled a distance?

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
I seldom see any monarchs around my house, but yesterday I saw about 20 (hard to count) coming & going from my butterfly bushes (Buddlei).
The week of September 25 -29 was a peak week for our sightings of monarch
We observed ten monarch butterflies flying south within two minutes, around 2:30pm, past our yard.

I'm just an average person who was surprised to see "so many" Monarchs flying around Marblehead Neck, MA.  I mentioned it to a friend who told me about your website.  I contacted Dick Albert, weather person at WCVB-TV -- Channel 5 in Boston, and suggested that he mention the Monarch migrating during tonight's weather report.  The Monarch are beautiful!!

We are a group of students from Fire Island School. We are in 2nd, 3rd and 4th grades. Today we took a walk down to beach where we estimated we saw approximately 4,320 monarch butterflies. We are participating in a symbolic butterfly migration project, so we are exicted and astounded by all of the butterflies we saw migrating today.
2:30 pm -- 30 monarchs passing by over the dunes in Beach Haven in the course of two minutes.

Today started with rain and we're supposed to get thunderstorms this evening. But this afternoon was PERFECT for watching migrating monarchs. The sky was a beautiful blue with big white clouds, temp. 63-68 degrees, light wind W9. I met my friend and while waiting for her to come outside, I spotted the first floating over her house and then mine. She & I saw a total of 96 migrating monarchs between leaving the houses at 1 p.m. and returning at 2:30. Most flew overhead, quite a few flew right at us, and many flew down low (a few stopping at puddles in the soggy field.) A few took very high currents and soared. On our walk home, a neighbor out riding his bike (we'd told him about seeing so many yesterday) called out that he'd seen at least 15 during his outing. It was a beautiful day to be outside monarch watching!
Many, many monarchs heading south in pairs and fours over past two days. Approximately 50 every 10 minutes (measured twice) in late afternoon on 10/1/06.

I was driving south in Interstate 295 Sunday morning and as I approached the Varina/Enon highrise bridge I began to see the Monarchs! First one then two-three then lots! I probably saw 25-30 in about a mile and a half stretch of road. What a sight.

In two seperate areas of Madison County Georgia near Danielsville there were many Monarchs flying around and landing on purple flowered butterfly bushes. In one place there were about 20 at about 5:00PM and in another there were about 10 at 12:00PM.
Sighted around 30 butterflies between 11:30 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. These sightings were both around our house and to and from the grocery store about 4.5 miles away.

We saw approx. 16-20 monarchs flying at altitude of 25-40 feet within a half hour, early afternoon. All traveled in a south-southwesterly direction. The weather was mostly cloudy and about 60 degrees.

September 30
While visiting family and walking we observed approx 50-75 Monarchs/hr flying W - SW at about noon to 1:00 pm. The butterflies were typically widely separated (hundreds of feet) from each other. The weather was slightly cloudy and the temp in the high 70's.

October 01
Sporadic sightings (approx 20-30/hr) of Monarchs migrating W-SW on clear cloudless day.
I had the great fortune of watching hundreds of monarchs feeding on wildflowers along a local beach on the south shore of Long Island on a mild Saturday afternoon. Au revoir, little friends!
Viewed approximately 50 Monarch's moving SW during a period between 12:00 - 12:30 hrs.

The butterflies were flying along the beach and above the dunes near the Atlantic Ocean side of Fire Island. They were going by about three to six at a time, with about 10 feet between each group. Some were closer to the ocean, and others were flying a bit north of the dunes.  It was a beautiful sunny day, and they were all heading in the same direction -- west, toward the mainland. We guessed that hundreds, maybe thousands, were eventually passing by. I've never seen anything like it.
While eating breakfast, my Dad and I witnessed over 100 butterflies in less than an hour in Millville, New Jersey  08332

Observed hundreds of Monarchs on our property here at Camp Grady Spruce. Only the larger Live Oak groves and Gum Bumelia groves have the huge "Monarch Fall Outs". They hit two tree clumps harder due to the proximity of the food (Sunflowers, Salt Cedar and Milk Weed.)

October 3
Monarchs still in the large Live Oak Groves. They have been here for exactly a week now. I have seen hundreds on the shore of Possum Kingdom "drinking" although they are not in the water. It looks like they lick the sandy mud.

Approximate 1,000 monarch butterflies where clinging to the stalks of the Wild Golden Rod behind the dunes at the sound end of the Stone Harbor beach. Not fearful to up close observations. At approximately 11:00 AM. Mild breeze and sunny, great for photo's.

Begining around 8:00 am witnessed approx 2000 Monarchs migrating due south until 3:00pm. This was my first time ever being able to see such a sight. I was awestruck by the continual flow of monarchs flying past my deck.

I finally saw a monarch migration! While traveling south on Hwy. 31 south of Henryville, Indiana I started spotting monarchs one after another. I pulled over to the side of the road and I counted around 50 within a 20 minute period. The monarchs were traveling southwest and were landing in a field of goldenrod. I haven't seen this many monarchs at one time since I did research with Bill Calvert when we were in South Texas. Indiana is not known as a great migration pathway so this was an unexpected surprise. Shari James

At 10:00 - 11:00am we watched a strong, clear group of many thousands, as far as the eyes could see, traveling southward down the shore line in Saltaire Fire Island New York. It was our first time witnessing this awesome spectacle!! Weather conditions were light north wind 5mph with clear blue skies. Hannah and Morgan

We were sailing this afternoon on the Rappahannock River (VA)- clear day, approx. 75-80 F -  and noticed a continuous 'flow' of individual Monarch butterflies traveling south - they flew around our sailboat and even between the mainsail and jib sometimes.  They flew at about 15 to 20 feet above the water level and some even higher. It was a fascinating sight!

Monarchs were increasing in numbers in our yard in Mid-September.  There were about 100 on the 15th, 200+ on the 16th, about 600 on the 17th, and about 500 on the morning of the 18th.  All but a couple were gone by the evening of the 18th.  Just scattered Monarchs since then.

Had an interesting experience on Nut Island this week end, not with standing the 30 or so Pheasant flushes, I had the experience of walking in to shrubbery that was a staging area for hundreds if not a 1000 Monarch butterflies on Saturday.

The Monarchs were waiting out a fairly strong direct wind from the south. They were gathering or staging on the most southerly tip of land on nut Island. It was the most incredible and unique experience, I walked in to the middle of the cloud and just stood there admiring the hovering mass. I walked up to them not noticing a thing until I was close enough to reach out and touch some of them.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Although work deadlines have kept me indoors for all but a few minutes every day recently, I have sighted 1-2 Monarchs daily for the past week or so either at the Tufts campus in Medford MA (just north of Boston) or in my home town of Bedford (~15-18 miles north of Boston). One missed my nose by a foot this morning. Others have remarked on the number of Monarchs locally.This is anecdotal only, but unusual in my recent experience.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
For hours the Monarchs passed over my house on Fire Island.  They seemed to be never ending. My father-in-law mentioned that they were Monarchs.  Quite a nice sight.
Lots of Monarchs, feeding on my buterfly bushes, and flying all around.  Brings back memories of Mexico!
I witnessed about 60 Monarch Butterflies headed towards Tenn.' in about 30 minutes time today. This was unusual, since I have never before witnessed them in such high numbers.
83 monarchs, 11 AM to 4 PM

October 2 seems to be the peak for the Monarch in Montauk, NY. Up till now the most I have seen over four hours, is about 200. Today I saw well over four hundred. They stop and feed on the Montauk Daisies. Thay make a beautiful sight on the white and yellow flowers. I have been able to take many beautiful pictures.

Also see October 15, 2006 update.

I am so glad I got to see the migration. I had heard of it, from my mother, for many years, but this is my first. I have heard that in the past there were clouds of butterflies going past. Even though there were not as many, it was beautiful to see and look forward to the spring.

Large number (hundreds perhaps thousand) of Monarchs feeding at yellow wildflowers at primary dune line along Atlantic beaches of Sagaponack and Wainscott, NY on Monday 10/2 afternoon. Temperature approx 68-70F, light breeze and sunny.

On Sunday, October 1, 2006, we were sailing in and around Smith Creek at its juncture with the Potomac River at Kitt's Point, and up the St. Mary's River to St. Mary's College. During our sail, we counted 72 monarch butterflies, all of which seemed to rise from the water. Some followed the boat and even flew in the slot between the jib and the mainsail. About a third of the way up the St. Mary's, we counted a clutch of about 30 rising in concert. Quite beautiful.
The migration was sight between 9-10 a.m. and the count was stopped at 150 +. Very exciting!! Never seen before
Hundreds and hundreds of Monarchs swarming around butterfly bush.

Although we are never fortunate enough here in Murfreesboro, TN to see clouds of monarchs passing through, we definitely can tell they are migrating through our area.  We have been seeing monarchs since late July and early August and the number has been steadily increasing.  We are on Fall Break this week and today while I was out running errands I saw monarchs literally every time I turned around.  While driving down the road I saw a monarch at least every 1/2 mile (probably more often). This must be the peak migration for our area or very close to it.

I was driving yesterday south on Route 22 in NY from about Westport NY to Crown Point and over the Crown Point bridge (over Lake Champlain) into Addison County VT - that whole distance (about 20 miles)is very close to the shore of Lake Champlain.  The fall New England Aster was in full bloom and just about the only wildflower left. There collectively must have been many hundreds if not over 1,000 monarchs on the aster.  Every patch of the flowers were fluttering with monarchs - mile after mile.  What a wonderful sight!  But are they too late?  We have a hardfrost predicted for Thursday.

I am an intern with Gateway National Recreation Area and am doing counts mostly for the park's monitoring program.  On Tuesday, Oct. 3rd, between 1:50 and 3:00 pm I counted 1,498 monarchs nectaring on seaside goldenrod at the Great Kills Unit of the park.
I observed hundreds of Monarch Butterflys moving along the ocean beach in the New Seabury community. They were lighting on the Goldenrod and other wild flowers

September 27: 9-2pm 5 hours; 15 monarchs; hundreds of monarchs being seen in the park currently (only a few fly over Cadillac)

I spent the PM of 1 October and 1/2 day 2-3 Oct. in various parts of Oconee County, South Carolina. There was a big movement of Monarchs 80+ on 1 Oct. and most were gone on 2-3 Oct.

Source: Carolinaleps of Duke University. (Latitude and longitude above are an approximation.)

My brother reported seeing hundreds of migratory monarchs from his home in Hanson MA on Sept.30th. He also noted monarchs at his job site in Quincy MA from Oct.2 through Oct.4, again hundreds. My nephew reported seeing hundreds of monarchs in Duxbury MA.on Monday Oct.2. I had raised and released 112 monarchs from my home in Hanson, MA this season. The last of my monarchs was released on Sept.23,2006. I still had remaining tags from the Monarch Watch program so I traveled to Duxbury with my grandnephews and my grandson where we tagged 36 monarchs out of hundreds nectaring on goldenrod. The kids assisted and were able to pick them right off of the flowers! This is the first time any of us have seen a migration-spectacular!!!Ginny Billings-Milkweedmom

On Tuesday, I saw a stream of Monarchs nectaring on Buddleia flowers that have been planted on the west shore of Randall's Island. I was not in a position to stop to count them, unfortunately.

Randall's Island is in the East River. The west bank faces the East Harlem section of Manhattan. The east bank faces the Astoria section of Queens.

I was in a conversation with the grounds keepers of the island. We were talking about planting sections with foraging & nectaring plants for butterflies.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I spent yesterday and today outdoors in S. Maine, planting a garden at my vacation house. During the two days, at least three dozen Monarchs stopped to nectar on the newly planted flowering plants. There were many dozens more nectaring at the local nursery, where I picked up my plants. Also dozens nectaring on peak-bloom New England Aster on a power line right of way along Rte. 236 between S. Berwick and Portsmouth NH. Some overhead in directional flight. It's been unseasonably warm in New England this fall.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Counted about 20 monarchs heading south yesterday.

I noticed a large number of Monarch Butterflies (hundreds) in the late morning of 9/28/06. They swarmed into the woods adjacent to my house and began to cluster on the tree branches. By nightfall there were thousands in the surrounding woods which comprise the Ozark National Forest. After spending the night, they left the next morning after the temperature rose and presented a spectacular sight as they flew through the forest and across a deep valley.
We stopped in this area while on vacation for rest period. This "park" along the coastline was full of Monarch's--too many to count,just beautiful  All flying about.
While on Block Island, off the coast of Rhode Island 100's and 100's of Monarch Buttereflies where migrating south. A beautiful sight!

This was my best day yet here in my yard ,as far as the number of Monarchs. This also would be the last day of seeing them. They were all over was was left of my yellow butterfly bush. In fact they were crowding the flowers with 4 of them hanging off the flowers at a time. They were flying all over my yard back/forth all day long. I counted about 30 at one time. I haven't seen a one since and the temps are now in the 50's in the am.

We had stopped in a vacant field off of Hebron parkway to look for grasshoppers and other insects for my son's bug project. When we came upon all these Monarck butterflies. they were every where. We counted 20 on one plant alone. We went back the next day to check on them and we were amazed at how many more had come in over night. We stopped counting at around a hundred. This was not out in the countryside but in the middle of town.

They are HERE! Our visitors came a few at a time and them on Thursday, 10/05/06, the Monarch Butterflies came by the 100s to their old Roosts north and north-east edge of the city of Bronte on the Kickapoo Creek (which is dry now). They come back to the same places every year. We have taken beautiful pictures of them. How long they will stay is anyones guess? Probably until the next cool front begins to send cooler gentle winds our way which may be this week end or the first part of next week. But for now, we are enjoying our visitors passing through. They look large and healthy, but seems like there are not as many as have been here before.

At dismissal time (3:00 CST), our students and staff saw 30-40 Monarchs traveling over the school - struggling against the wind and rain. It was so neat! It was in the middle of a rainy, windy day, but they kept on flying!

The next Sunday, Oct. 1st, I saw about 100 of them fly over my house (on the outskirts of Madisonville) in about an hour's time. There were probably many more, but I went inside after a while.

I had a "shopping with Monarchs" experience. I went to the Westbrook Factory Outlets (Connecticut exit 65 off I-95) and saw many monarchs passing between the stores, heading southwest. Throughout the day, I continued to see Monarchs heading southwest on I-95 and Route 1, as well as other locations near the shoreline.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

A light NNW wind changed everything ... 12:15 ...
35 monarchs coming across the Lavaca Bay Causeway with a light tail wind ... slow and easy, six to eight feet above the warm concrete and staying between the rails this time.East side of the peninsula a monarch about every two minutes.West side about five times as many ... three's and five's at a time several times, really good numbers. West side, they were seldom more than 50' feet behind each other. Still found none nectaring.

I wasn't getting an exact count but trying to watch them because they were at window height of the van and doing a great deal more floating today. DID see one come by that displayed a white tag on left rear wing ... floated by about five feet away ... sun was just right.

I might have seen 150 to 200 in less than an hour, then I had to be back in town. Fantastic numbers down here, we wait a couple of years for this. The traffic zooms right on by on TX35 without seeing any but those few that actually get in their way.The tagged one was doing well and went beautifully on across the bay towards the SW. Back door cool front coming and this NNW wind could have been a part of it, then things are changing for Monday.

I got to go back before 5:00 and there was still a trickle of monarchs that averaged 1 a minute going on past 6:00 ...still crossing Lavaca Bay. Their angle out across the bay had changed a bit, almost straight into the setting sun, but the wind was a bit more out of the SE, but still light.After 5:45, I got to watch a few thru binocs coming back to the NE from out across the bay like they had changed their minds ... have seen this before! Altus is going 30 miles NE up the coast with some students in the morning and will get to see what is happening on the bay at Palacios, they will be both on and along the bay there.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I've noticed monarchs the last few days, but definitely heavier activity today, they're coming down from way up high--maybe they are ahead of the front that is supposed to come thru later on. Counted at least 50 during the lunch hour. It's pretty still out, wind at 8mph officially, but here, not even the cottonwood leaves are moving.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Our migration window here in eastern KS is typically from 8-11 Sept to 4-7 Oct. Monarchs are here but generally scarce on or about the 4th of Oct and it usually takes an hour or more to see, and or catch, 30-40 monarchs in patches of late blooming asters.

I just came back from lunch and checked the garden (MonarchWaystation#1) for butterfly activity. Wow! I counted 42 monarchs nectaring on the butterfly bushes, Cosmos, Vitex, asters, tropical milkweed, and verbena, and know I didn't see them all. It would be nice to know where these butterflies are coming from. It seems unlikely that they are coming from the north since tagging has evidently been relatively poor from the Dakotas to Michigan. Nor does it seem probable that more than a few of these are local butterflies since reproduction appeared to shut down some time ago. Sounds like we need some more isotope analyses to determine the origins of butterflies in cases like these.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

10/7/06, 4-5:30 PM, Ft Griffin State Park, on nature trails by the river. Approximate temp: 80-85 degrees. Wind approx 2-10 mph, but no wind on trails where sighting occurred (drops down about 15-30 feet below the level of the park). Slightly overcast.

Approximate count: 2 to 3 thousand Monarchs (conservative estimate), roosting in trees within 50 feet from the shore. Seemed to have an affinity for American Elm and Hackberry trees, on lower branches, about 50% roosted on trees less than 10 feet tall. Other types of trees with only a singleton or two roosting included cedar elm and pecan. I believe I saw one tagged Monarch, but cannot be sure as I didn’t have a net. I lost sight of her/him in the flurry of a few hundred that took flight as I slowly walked down the trail. Looking back as we passed, all resumed a new roosting spot within a couple of minutes. I witnessed this roosting behavior at this site about 10 years ago, but there were many more the last time. This ma

They're here!!! Finally a large wave of Monarchs are coming thru Central Okla.  We were in Norman this a.m., in a field full of trees and Golden crownbeard with about 200 Monarchs.  Thru Norman, we were seeing about 1 Monarch every 1-2 min. Closer to OKC, were were seeing about 1 every 5 min.  Upon arriving home to Kingfisher, we were greeted with about 40 Monarchs nectaring in my Butterfly Garden.  Reported to D-plex.
Driving thru OKC, we were seeing 1 Monarch about every 5 minutes.
Driving thru Norman, we were seeing 1 Monarch about every 1-2 minutes.
Heavy migration this morning. The oak trees were loaded with Monarchs. A little cooler than it has been in the other mornings.
Approximately 2 to 3 thousand monarchs roosting in trees bordering the river at Ft. Griffin State Park. About 82 degrees F, wind SSW 5-10 mph, somewhat overcast Sighted around 4-4:30 PM.

During the third week of Sept. I watched flocks of about 10 to 20 monarchs flying out of the north, south. My sightings were in Southern and Northern Mifflin Co. PA. (Center of PA) Some flew alone, and then a small flock. Some circled around and visited the garden. They were flying about twice as tall as the tree tops, I believe. Once I looked and concentrated my eye, more and more were visible. An amazing sight indeed.
While traveling across Lake Pontchartrain we sighted 300+ individual butterflies.
Sighted approximately 100 per hour coming through a 200 ft break in the Cedars.
How marvelous! My 3 kids and i were leaving a yard sale and noticed lots of butterflies. I looked up and realized they were "traveling!" Hundreds!

Maybe they were just late in getting started this morning, but they are here now!   I counted over 50 in under 2 minutes around 9:15am!   After a few minutes, I lost count (could havae something to do with the 3 year old I was chasing, too) but there were just so many!   There are some that are so high you can barely see them and some are flying low to the ground and resting a bit...but all are travelling south.  It is a beautiful day, few high clouds, slight breeze, and 72 degrees.   I have never seen so many at one time!!

This is the first peak migration I have ever seen.  It was only along the Connecticut River, and I was at Bellows Falls, Vermont.  There was a Monarch every 20 feet--just extraordinary.  The day was warm and sunny.  I finally had to stop so the people behind me could pass--I was breaking for Monarchs and no one knew what I was doing.  Although I know a lot were hit, I only saw one down on the road.

WE WERE AT OREGON BEACH IN COTUIT, AND SPENT THE DAY WITH HUNDREDS, MAYBE THOUSANDS OF MONARCH BUTTERFLIES. MY DAUGHTER ACTUALLY CAUGHT THREE BUTTERFLIES. I WAS ABLE TO GET A PHOTO WITH HER HOLDING THEM.

A three member Roots and Shoots group tagged 20 monarchs in 30 minutes during lunch period.  The monarchs were feeding voraciously on Butterfly Milkweed at the Tulsa Garden Center.  Estimated 80+ butterflies at that location.  Numerous others spotted on way to and from, most moving South in calm, sunny weather.
My 4 year old son and I were waiting outside the local Firestone while our flat tire was being repaired. From 9:00 - 9:25am we counted 52 Monarchs flying right over us!
62 Monarchs most feeding on Beach Goldenrod between 1230 and 130 PM. Numerous pairs. Wx clear, 74, wind 5 to 10 knots from ESE. Sighting is from deck 125 feet to end of dune.
I have seen a greater number of monarchs today than the last few days - 30 or so per hour. Also, many more here in Dallas (on the edge of the Dallas/Garland border) than at my home in Lewisville.

Temps started off in the low 40's warming to the low 70's over the past few hours, sky clear and wind has been light out of the south. Butterflies are determined to nectar with little directional flight.

According to a long-time monarch watcher in the Abilene area, monarchs have been moving through for the last two weeks, but today saw one of the largest migrations he's ever witnessed.

On Sunday, October 8, I was a spectator at softball games played at Mountain State University in Beckley, WV. The softball stadium must be right on one of the migratory routes, as I was delighted to see at least 300 Monarchs flutter past during the course of the afternoon. It was such a treat ! I have never had the opportunity to see so many butterflies in such a short time.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I found a perfect area in the heart of Springfield, VA to net adults to tag. It is a drainage maintenance area near the Metro station I use everyday. On 9/23-9/24, I tagged my 24 Monarchs (one tag fell off and was unused) in 1.5 hours each day. I saw the same sight I had seen from the train both days. On several occasions there were 5 or 6 butterflies on a single plant. I got a picture of 3 on one plant although there were 2 more not appearing in the picture. In12 years I have been tagging I have never seen the quantity before. It seems that they traveled through quicker than they have in the past. The weather was unusually cool and I only saw Monarchs around in quantity for 2 weeks. In past I saw them up to early October. I haven't seen one since 9/26.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Just to let you know you hit the projections on the mark for us in Graham, Texas, latitude 35 degrees. We have had the Monarachs visit us in large numbers for the past 20 years, and we have had two waves of between 500 and1000 in our back yard in Graham. The peak of the first wave was Monday/Tuesday, October 2, 3, with most of them gone October 5th. However, by mid-morning today, October 6th, we began getting a new wave and they seem to be still arriving. I thought might like to know about our experience. We are about 60 miles south of Wichita Falls, Texas and 90 miles northwest of Ft. Worth.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I came to realize very quickly that there weren't just a lot, there was a plethora of monarchs just fluttering above the field (25+ acres?) of milk weed and golden rod. I was flabergasted by this event as I've never seen such a sight.

We had dozens of Monarchs (too numerous to count) both Saturday and Sunday (Oct.7 & 8). The Monarch Waystation is working. We have enjoyed it tremendously. The Chrysallis has still has not hatched.

I drove to Wichita Falls Friday and Sunday and the Monarchs are migrating. I'd say 15- 20 per mile Sunday. Less Friday.We have new growth of A. viridis. The wind was blowing to beat the band so we had to kick them out of the weeds until it warmed up.Lots of Monarchs but no southward movement was observed. A steady light stream of Monarchs, from 20 to 40 an hour, from 9AM to 530PM. Few pairs. Sightings on the dune. Wx clear, wind ENE light. Looks like the tail end of the migration.

Today I left Dover, DE, and spent the day in Ocean City, MD. I saw about 8 migrating monarchs up next to the dunes and ocean--all were flying west. But around 2:30 p.m. on the drive home from Ocean City (between 127th street and up through Fenwick Island and Bethany Beach, DE) I began tallying monarchs. Many were flying west and south, but the majority were feeding on blooming goldenrod at the center of Route 1. I counted a total of 66 monarchs in a 15 minute drive (and that total would have been much higher had I been able to slow down and get a better look!) You could see 5 and 6 at a time clustered on each plant, feeding. The beach temp was about 65 degrees and it was a beautiful sunny day--breeze along the coastal area. Cold front and rain coming, so I was glad to see so many migrating today!

There were too many wild monarchs to count nectaring and migrating the past 4 days as the 4th grade class has been releasing their tagged 19 female and 6 male monarchs. There is a cold front coming through today so we expect to see many more monarchs out in front of it.
We started out with about 10 monarchs and now have about 6 or 7 who are roosting in our butterfly bush and zinnias.  They have been there for several hours.
Mid September the Monarch migration was at peak. Slowing to a few last sightings in the first couple of weeks of October.

It was at 4:15 p.m.  I think it was a feeding/nectaring station – in 5 minutes, we counted over 50 monarchs.  My friends have 5 or 6 very large butterfly bushes (trees), the butterflies were all over the place – and moving from blossom to blossom.  It could have been double that, very difficult to count.  They were not actually flying, so much as feeding.  Last week, when we returned to her home at the same time one week later, there were no monarchs at all.
Small groups of monarchs have been sighted moving SSW.  Each group has about 40 - 50 butterflies.

I've been seeing a lot of monarchs in our local area for the past 2 weeks, but on 10/03/06, saw literally hundreds while driving over the bridge separating deer point lake and north bay. It was an awesome sight and inspired me to learn more about the monarch migration pattern.

Observed from the steps of my classroom portable at Dent Middle School throughout the morning and into the afternoon today. Peak of 25 monarchs within three minutes - heading South and Southwest. We are in the Northeast suburbs of Columbia, SC. Sky was overcast and cool in the morning. Sunny and warm in the afternoon. Sightings tapered off after lunch. Each time classes changed, I stood on my porch and watched them flying overhead. Height was variable. Some flying very low at roof level, but most up at abt 70 - 100 feet. This is the first time I have ever seen such an amazing wonder!

By Dr. Chip Taylor, Monarch Watch:

The Jeffers had discovered a field of goldenrods that was covered with monarchs. It was not just a field but 1000 acres of CRP land (Conservation set-aside) in which the monarchs numbered in the thousands. In the email the text read ""hundreds of thousands" monarchs on a 10 acre field of goldenrods. The density is at least 100 monarchs per square meter." Given the email statement about 10 acres, I asked V three times about the size of the area and she assured me each time that it was a thousand acres. When I asked about the estimate of the number of monarchs, V told me that their best guess is that 40-50 thousand monarchs were using the area at one time.

The monarchs arrived on Saturday the 7th and V and Carl have been making trips to the location each morning and evening since then. V gave this description of the exodus from the field each evening.

About 6:15 the monarchs begin to leave the flowers and head for the hedgerows to the north and east of the field. They do not appear to be using the hedgerow to the south (there are no trees to the west). Movement of the butterflies toward the trees accelerates by 6:30 and by 6:45 there is a virtual cloud of monarchs seeking places to roost in the trees - so much so that to observers they look like flocks of birds coming to roost. By 7PM all but a few of the monarchs are at rest in the trees.

This spectacle will probably end as a cold front moves through the area. The weather for tomorrow is expected to be in the low 60s with showers so the butterflies may not be able to leave the area until the skies clear and the temperature hit the low 60s on Friday.The Jeffers informed me that Jim Edson is on his way to the location so maybe Jim will be able to provide some clarifications and additional details.

There are two fields consists of about 1,000 acres of goldenrod, asters and a few other wildflowers. A drainage ditch with a tree line divided the fields. The monarchs were moving out of the fields to the trees by thethousands. I don't know how to estimate the numbers, but the tree line isabout 0.5 miles long and all of the trees were full of monarchs. I haven'tseen anything like it except in Mexico. There could have been anywhere from10K to 100K butterflies.This is the largest aggregation of migrating monarchs I've heard of in several years.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We have been enjoying the Monaarch's for about five days now.  Monday, October 9, students had a holiday from school.  My grandchildren and their friends were lying on the trampoline looking a the sky around noon...naming cloud figures, when they saw some little black dots in the blue sky overhead.  Soon the number of dots grew larger and larger.  They were so excited when they thought about the Monarch's migrating.  There were thousands flying high overhead.  They were moving ahead of the next cool front that was coming in with mild winds.  What a sight!  We are eagerly awaiting the next influx of visitors.

A hastily scribed note from just ne of Austin... Brush called and I grabbed a pair of binos and saw a portion of the 1000s of monarchs heading over as I type. Highest count with fixed straight up binos was37 in 10 seconds...

Knowing a front was on the way though not knowing ifitwould reach Bastrop Co., I sat up shop around 10:30AM on a ridge here behind my house in Utley and began watching the skies almost continually until 17:28PM. What a day!

Up until 15:49 I had seen only 9 Monarchs all day, but at exactly 15:49 a wave of those passed by with the first puff of north wind. At the peak of their passage around 16:30PM I counted 209 as seen passing through just one bit of sky between two trees in the yard in only 1 minute (all the time I had for thebutterflies) but I am sure I eventually saw at least a few thousand passing over...some so high I could see them only well in the 20-60x scope.

Monarchs 2500-3000 just an estimate...Just walked out one final time before sending this and at 17:51 the Monarchs are still just whizzing by in numbers despite a very light sprinkle...Brush

I just spent about 7-8 minutes (19:03)outside looking toward a bright cloud to the east with 10x bins and noticed even that at this late hour in one small view of the sky at least 400 Monarchs passed by in that short time...Brush

100+ Monarchs are coming through N. Round Rock right now (4:36pm). It'sincredible! I've never seen them in this quantity before.

We got our wind shift for the strong cold front about about 2:30pm andimmediately the sky was filled with Monarchs drifting on the strongtailwind. They are passing overhead in the lower couple hundred feet of the air column at a rate of about 30 to 50/minute in our one little spot atthe Refuge HQ in western Travis County.

The Snouts are now being blown southward onceagain. Hundreds per minute. We've also had a major movement of Swainson's Hawks today and migratingTurkey Vultures. Sprinling of other raptors in the air as well.

More later....I'm headed back outside (3:55pm).

We watched and they began to settle in the dark trees nearby. We returned awhile later to find the trees full of the monarchs roosting for the night. A fascinating sight!

More than 50 monarchs spotted today b/t 12-1pm coming down from up high to feed on the native blooming Liatris mucronata and various species of goldenrod (S. altissima, S. rigida) here at the 175 acre University of Dallas campus (post oak/little bluestem savannah).

At 10:30 a.m., I was watching a flock of Turkey Vultures that appeared to be migrating south when I begin to notice small birds with them.  Closer examination revealed thousands of Monarchs migrating south riding the winds of the front that passed last night.  Using 10X binocs, I found Monarchsfrom 200 feet agl to as high as I could focus (estimate 1000 feet agl). Everytime I changed focus, more Monarchs came into view.  None were seen at ground level.Ground elevation is 1,500 feet.  I live at Rio Hondo Ranch Subdivision, Bandera County, Tarpley, Texas.

We had peak migration this week.  We saw a lot of monarchs all week long.  On Oct. 3, many students reported lots of butterflies.  One student reported 67 in 30 minutes.  Other students had similar numbers.  They had to watch at home, since it was fall break at school.  They were beautiful and we had a lot of fun watching for them.  We waited two weeks, to make sure it was peak migration here.

For those wishing to do something other than eat during lunchhour....This morning there are virtual swarms of Monarch going through western Bastrop Co..And they started early!..Take the bins or a scope as some are waaaaaaaaaaaaaay up there.

Enjoy this beautiful day...I unfortunately can not put the time into the hawks and bugs as I did yesterday

The front blew in this afternoon. The first puffs of air from the north brought many Broadwing Hawks between 5:30 and 6:00 PM.

The most impressive migration though was Monarch butterflies. From 5:35 to 5:50 there were a lot. As the winds came up, the Snouts started disappearing and the Monarchs appeared. Wow! There was an article in the paper a few days ago predicting a big push for the Monarchs--the lady interviewed evidently knew what she was talking about!...Leslie

Woo!Hoo! The largest band of Monarchs are pouring thru Kingfisher, Okla. that I have ever seen. I was driving around the outskirts of Kingfisher about 2:30 p.m., and counted about 1 per minute for the 20 minutes that I was driving. They appeared to be going in a south to southwest direction.

About 4 p.m., after running some errands, I walked into my garden, Monarch Waystation #92, and low and behold the Monarchs were EVERYWHERE!!! I counted around 120+ Monarchs in my garden!!! Large clouds of them moved as I walked around. I have never had so many at 1 time. I think that I've died and gone to heaven.

The winds seem to have picked up from the south. The weather channel shows the temp to be 73 degrees- clear- winds W to SW 12. But, that is for OKC, and I believe it is a lil more than that, as I'm having trouble taking pics.

Where ever they are coming from, most are nice sized in good condition. Some are smaller. Some are a lil faded. Today has been an awesome day!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Have had multiple sittings over the last several days. Cold front came through last night. Several hundred roosting in large pecan trees in back yard. They have been here every year for the last few years.

The monarchs appeared in the thousands along the Dry Frio riverbed on Friday, October 13th.  They were gathering and resting on the tall pecans and oaks on the riverbanks.  They were not nectaring, even though we have a butterfly garden that was full of sulphers, skippers, fritillaries, swallowtails, snoutnose, and marine blues.  The weather was misty and cool.  They gathered together on branches and only flew when disturbed.  It was truly an amazing sight.  We had a front blow through over the night last night (Oct. 15th) and they were gone.  We took pictures while they were here but the light was dim as it was shady amidst the trees.  We will try to  e mail you pictures when we can.  It was truly a "Disney" special experience for all of us.

Witnessed the migration during the day, toward evening found a roost in a grove of oak trees.   There were several hundred butterflies within the grove, which was protected from noise and strong winds.

Fair Oaks Ranch, Northern Bexar County Texas 9:15 CDT 58 degrees overcast skies 150 monarchs per minute looking directly overhead flying at treetop level to out of sight.

I am seeing only about 10 monarchs in 30 minutes passing high above the back yard this morning.

Each class spotting aprox. 5 monarchs/min. for 15 min ea. class for a total of 300 Monarchs. All butterflies were in flight.
We are at the crest of a large hill just west of Austin overlooking greenbelt. We have a steady trickle (1-4/minute)this morning.

Over our Peirce School playground after school more than 280 monarchs were observed flying overhead in a two hour period (from 2:15-4:15 P.M.). This observation was the beginning of a huge project in our second grade classroom involving the Journey South. Thank you for all the wonderful information you provide on this site - a true inspiration for budding scientists!

I was out on my apt deck and happened to look up into the cloudy sky and noticed several monarchs fluttering overhead all heading south. I realized I was watching a migration. A cool front had come into the area yesterday (10/13), so I imagine they are riding the north wind south. Some were lower in altitude than others; being nearsighted I cannot imagine how many I didn't see, but I saw at least 30+ monarchs in 30 minutes of time. Oct. 14 at 10:45 a.m. to 11:15 a.m. The lower flying monarchs were fluttering, but the higher flying apparently were riding wind currents. Some "couples" were circling each other as they flew, like a tag game. It was neat to see as I had never seen. They flew usually spaced greatly apart, but some were close together. The temp. outside was in the 70s, maybe 80s, which is cool for Austin, central Texas area.

Got a called in report of a large number of monarchs "a few miles east and a few miles west" of Wichita Falls, TX along Hwy 287 on Oct 11.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Ba Rea and I traveled from Eagle Pass to Boerne (north of San Antonio) today between noon and 4 p.m. We passed north of the Anacacho Ranch west of Uvalde where we began spotting monarchs at 16 per minute at 55 mph. That was at 12:40.

The flow increased to about 40 per mile at the Border Patrol check point at Cline's Corners.Most miles we were encountering 33.

East of Uvalde between Knippa and Sabinal was the heaviest concentration.Winds were moving at 10-17 mph from 75 to 80 degrees heading on the compass. Monarchs were quartering into that and moving just west of south.We pulled off the road on a hill and ed out the binoculars. Most monarchs were moving over at about 15-30' off the ground, but with binocs, we were able to pick out others up 75-100' in the air.The monarch front was almost 65 miles wide. I got out the map and backtracked along their reverse heading. These guys must have over-nighted just south of Leakey last night. There were thousands on the move.

At Hondo, we turned north to Bandera, then went east out of Bandera to Boerne.At dusk at the Cibolo Nature Center we were still seeing 1 every 2 minutes or so. The were stopping to nectar on the Maxmillian sunflowers, which have made quite a showing this fall. Snow on the Mountain is also blooming widely with huisache daisy and several other composites common.A. asperula was widespread on the roadside after we left Bandera.Definite chill in the air here in Boerne tonight.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
October 13 I had masses of monarchs nectaring at my Monarch Waystation #835- I counted more than 35 at one time, especially on tithona, Mexican sunflower, butterfly bush, and dahlias.

October 31
Went across the causeway at 7:10 and did a 30 minute count starting at 7:50 until 8:20. They kept coming at a rate of about 4 per minute until 9:00 and then the count began to drop off to about 2 per minute until 10:00 when the wind picked up from the E, then I could only find one about every five minutes coming from the NE, left at 10:30. The count for the 30 min. was 155 for an hourly avg of 310 best 5 minute count was 40 at 8:05 to 8:10.

October 29
As yesterday, had a good flow of monarchs in the early morning before the wind picked up from the SE ... same spot ... same way ... best 30 minute total was 153, for any average of 306 an hour, best 5 minutes was 45 and that was at 9:15 a.m. They were flying NE to SW, low to 50' up, steady, migrational flight ... looked like a 3-D monarch interstate in the sky, all going one way, but properly spaced. Numbers fell off quickly after 10:00 a.m. when the breeze could be seen to begin to stir the slick waters of Lavaca Bay and move things out of the ESE ever so slightly. Went back about 3:00 p.m. when the wind was 5 to 10 mph out of the SSE and we had to search to find a dozen monarchs nectaring, nothing flying. 71 dF, clear, another front about Thursday.

October 28
I took up my usual monitoring site, same as on the 24th, on the north approach peninsula to the Lavaca Bay Causeway, and counted five minutes inverals, first from 9:30 to 10:00 and then 12:20 to 12:50. From 9:30 to 10:00 the count was 297 monarchs for an average of 594 an hour, best for 5 minutes was 58. From 12:20 to 12:50 the count was 84 in 30 minutes for a 168 average in an hour, best 5 minutes was 22 monarchs. 594 monarchs an hour eclipsed the previous high of 190 an hour back on the 24th. I was monitoring a narrow 200' wide corridor. The flow turned off by 3:00 pm.

October 24
I went across the Lavaca Bay Causeway this morning and took up station at my usual monitoring site on the north approach peninsula and counted in five minute intervals from 9:30 to 10:00 ... looking out the front and left windows of the van ... sun was reflecting off the bay to the right so couldn't see anything there ... 30 minute total was 95 monarchs for an average of 190 per hour.

October 14
There was another flurry of monarchs crossing Lavaca Bay near the causeway at noon today. For an hour, Altus and I observed about 1 monarch a second between 50 and 300' zipping along with a 20 mph NE wind, over and past everything, heading across the bay, there were times we had three and five out the front window of the van plus a few over the "hood" or some we could see "playing" in the traffic. These monarchs were pulling a stunt we don't recall seeing before ... as they came along with the wind, never a wing beat, they would pull a quick 360 turn and continue for about 100' and pull another quick 360, never a wing beat, over and over. Was this manuver to adjust something in their flight, slow down a bit and mantain control, to orient themselves, or what? It was obvious and most if not all were doing "it". They were not tumbling, but very much in control.

<div align="left"><font size="4" face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">We have thousands and thousands throughout the city right now! For more than an hour they have been streaming in a brisk wind from north to south, right over our motel room.  More than I can count in a framed area.  Kamakaza pigeons and other birds flying out to try to grab one, not with any visible success, they are attacking in masses of 50 to more, redirecting the flow, but still not catching the Monarchs.  They are still coming and now I am see smaller birds trying to attack, now with any apparent success.  It must be over 500 a minute, maybe more.  I am looking from the room door as my frame and I can't count that fast.  Sometimes they reduce for a few seconds and then rebound with even more! (Written at 10 am.)</font>
Fair Oaks Ranch, Northern Bexar County, Texas.9:15 CDT, 58 degrees, overcast skies: 150 monarchs per minute counted, when looking directly overhead. Flying at treetop level to out of sight.

My life science classes have been tagging the monarchs this year.  We tagged 27 monarchs in the butterfly garden today using the last of the 200 tags that we had purchased from MonarchWatch.  For the past week the Monarchs have been steadily coming by to nectar.  We have 2  monarch chrysalis in our classroom that we brought in from the milkweed to observe.   The students are enjoying the monarch adventure from caterpillars eating all of the milkweed to capturing and tagging the adults.

We arrived in Maverick County to a phone call from Keith and Lettie, telling me that their trees were "full" again this year. We went over at 6 and found about 3000 in their yard. They are on a bluff above the Rio Grande with large trees. Multiple houses in the neighborhood were being used: hackberry, pecan, Japanese Yew.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Came home to the Radar Base and found at least 300-400 in one tree by the road and at least 300 in my front yard. The shelter belts around the runway are also being used but only 100-200 there.

We were unable to get over to the 300 yard long shelter belt at the end of the taxiway where there were many thousands in past years.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Thousands of Monarchs in residential gardens all over Eagle Pass.

The Monarchs don't seem to be in any hurry to leave, and the weather report has forecast of sun on Tuesday, with 30 percent chance of rain today, 80 percent tonight and scattered isolated showers all over. The rain stopped around 1 o'clock and the snouts and sulfurs are flying in the roads. Some Monarchs confused by these flights and get down too low on the road, and get hit, but not many.

Another resident, here in Eagle Pass invited us to view their visiting Monarchs last evening. They had about 3000 in their garden yesterday evening.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Up to Thursday (Oct. 12) afternoon's cold front, I had been seeing individual monarchs sporadically over the past two weeks all over town. Thursday afternoon, the cold front came thru pushing thousands of monarchs in front starting around 2:30pm. As the temperature dropped 20 degrees from the low 90's and the rain started an hour later and the monarchs disappeared. Then around 5:00, the skies cleared and with temps in the mid 70's, the monarchs jumped back in the air. I drove downtown Austin and the monarchs were picking their way thru the tall buildings by the thousands.

Friday and Saturday steady streams floated by with 10-15 visible directly overhead at all times. It was fun watching the snouts interacting with the larger monarchs. The snouts seemed to be "harassing" the monarchs. Perhaps, the snouts objected to their mass movement being upstaged by the much larger and more colorful monarchs?!!!!! (For those unfamiliar with the snouts Mike Quinn and others have been referencing, they are a dull tanish orange about the size of the empty space your index finger encircles when you make an "OK" sign.)

Late Saturday afternoon, flew to Dallas. Sunday morning we drove 200 miles from Dallas westward to near Abaline, then back to Austin late in the afternoon. We drove thru scattered showers all day, yet every time the showers let up the monarchs were on the move. The numbers were low, with no more than 5 visible at any one time, and more typically singles moving southward. No snouts were seen the entire 450 mile drive.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Saw 283 moving monarchs throught the Corpus Christi Hawk Watch site.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

My husband and I were out at our regular spotting place (County Road 108) which runs paralel with IH 35 (near Buda exit).Even though the trees have been thinned or cut down (development) we saw between 200-300.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

On Monday (10/16) the day started out cloudy, wet and cool in Norman, OK. By 1:00 p.m. clouds cleared and temps warmed to upper 60's with a light south wind. I walked to a field to see if there was any activity and found about 100 monarchs nectaring in the crownbeard. No directional movement was observed during the 45 minutes I spent watching.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monarchs continue to flock and nectar in my Monarch Waystation Garden #92. There have been at least 200+ yesterday, and today, Oct. 17th. No directional movement, just heavy nectaring. Temp is 70 degrees, clear, light wind S. at 9. A front is expected to come Wednesday morning, high of 64 degrees, sunny to partly cloudy, Winds NW 10-20. There should be some moving out tomorrow. This has been a fabulous experience for me, with the horrid summer that we had with drought and triple digit temps. Hope that some of my pics turned out.

Yesterday, I still had about 100 in my yard.  Today, it's 60 degrees with a light rain, and more forecasted.  Wind from the SE at 16.  They are hanging in the trees.  No large clusters, just 2-3 per cluster.  I easily counted 60 without binoculars. Monday is supposed to be cloudy with rain ending in the morning.  High of 69 with a variable wind 5-15.  Tuesday, 80 degrees, sunny, with S wind 5-15.  Another northerly front on Thurs.  Perhaps, some will leave on Monday.
Observed oveapproximately 1600 monarchs flying over Del Rio Middle School.  The majority were flying over between 8:45 and 9:30 a.m., 700 estimated.

A friend who is a wetlands scientist and herpetologist spent Oct 12-15,2006 at a beach house located on Edisto Island, a barrier island about 40 miles SE of Charleston, SC or 70 miles NE of Savannah, GA. While there, weather was sunny with temps in the 80s on the first day; it continued sunny for the rest of the period but day time highs dropped into the 70s.

She observed monarchs every day, moving south along the beaches, along the salt marsh and just out above the surf. She described what she saw as a regular stream, with butterflies-- both Gulf fritillaries and monarchs--flying in ones and twos. She estimated one butterfly every second or two for the combined species. The butterflies were nectaring at oleander.

She also related that while in town one evening she found a cluster of a couple of dozen monarchs on one shrub.

Contributed by Craig Tufts
Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We were on the coast this weekend. At Port Aransas on Friday, October 13, we saw quite a few monarchs sailing along the beach, fairly high. The next day, at Rockport, we saw even more. They moved along with the brisk wind for the several hours that we were there. I have no idea how to estimate the numbers, but I can't remember when I've ever seen such aconcentration of them in Texas.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

We were on the coast this weekend. At Port Aransas on Friday, October 13, we saw quite a few monarchs sailing along the beach, fairly high. The next day, at Rockport, we saw even more. They moved along with the brisk wind for the several hours that we were there. I have no idea how to estimate the numbers, but I can't remember when I've ever seen such aconcentration of them in Texas.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

We were in Floridabirding at St. Mark's NWR on the Gulf Coast, and we saw more butterfliesthere than we had ever seen. Most were monarchs, but they were not on the move; they were feeding at the flowers in bloom all along the roadsides for several miles. There was at least one butterfly or skipperfor every square foot of bush. I couldn't focus on birds at all.Is it a good year for the monarchs, or have I just been lucky?

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I sighted Monarchs at our ranch on Saturday Oct. 14 and Sunday Oct. 15. The ranch is at N29deg 48.979 min 58.74s, W100degrees 29.439min 26.34s In the evening several of the large live oak trees along the road were full of Monarchs. Other trees off the road may have also had butterflies.During theday there were 5 to 10 in sight at all times as we drove - just fluttering around.This occurred over the entire ranch (1184 acres). There didn't seem to be any general directional movement.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

27 miles north of Del Rio in west Texas
Just thought I'd drop you a line and let you know that the Monarchs were moving through the Val Verde County area over this past weekend. Not sure how to estimate the numbers but they were covering the Live oaks on my property every evening, and filling the skies during the day when it wasn't raining.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

A neighbor told me today that she and a friend were swamped with monarchs on the afternoon of 12 October 2006. The sky was "full" at several heights (they used binoculars) as "wave after wave of individuals flowed south preceded by a northern front. They "couldn't believe their eyes!". Also saw many hawks. Sounds like the experience reported by Brush Freeman-Bastrop-on the same day.

They live about 5 miles west of IH-35 in Georgetown. Sorry to have missed it; I've only seen many isolated monarchs meandering southward. Encountered snouts today, several every few yards while driving about.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Monarchs have arrived in Wimberley in numbers, though far outnumbered by Southern Dogfaces and vastly outnumbered by American Snouts, which began to return on October 3.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

On Oct. 14, son Tim reported that here were 100 - 200 monarchs nectaring in his goldenrain-tree (Koelreuteria paniculata). There are a number of the trees in his neighborhood in Corpus. A quick walk through the neighborhood revealed monarchs in all the goldenrain-trees. He saw the monarchs about noon, just after heavy morning rains.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

The monarchs arrived at our rance 10 miles west of Uvalde on the Nueces River about noon on October 13. There are THOUSANDS OF THEMin the native pecan and hackberry trees along the river. It's a beautiful sight.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I have been driving all over town the last four days ... several times a day ... 197 miles so far (saved my gas money for Oct! 192/gal) ... and have found monarchs moving all day from NE to SW from the far east side of town to the north side of town. The feeling I get is they are crossing Lavaca Bay along the entire shoreline right now, not just at the causeway this week, and the direction of some are coming from the last two days, they may also be coming from the north shoreline of Matagorda Bay after the big winds we had. The flights of monarchs in the heavy fog this morning was pretty amazing, I don't know how they lifted off! These monarchs are large and seem darker than in previous years ... the "darker" is what is different. Does a week earlier make them darker?

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Friday afternoon Dale and I were working at the NPSOT booth at the Wildflower Center plant sale. We observed very noticeable waves of monarchs (and other butterflies as well--moving too fast for us toidentify) moving south off and on during the afternoon. There was a nice breeze from the north so I guess they came in on the wind? A few of them seemed to stop and nectar but most of them did not; perhaps they had already done some nectaring in other areas of the WC (we were on the south side), but it really didn't seem like it--but not sure. It looked like most of them were already up pretty high and flying high--not like when they are hanging around sniffing out plants. I guess it sort of surprised me. I would have thought the WC would have been a good rest stop!

A couple of people commented to us that they had seen lots of butterflies (different varieties including some very small ones) moving south in the downtown areas yesterday afternoon--even in the middle of lots of traffic.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Yesterday 10/12/06 ahead of the cold front around 4pm hundreds ofmonarchs in downtown Austin. After the rain on this same day, at myhouse in south Austin, there were hundreds in the sky heading south. Itwas beautiful.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Thursday I observed about 50+ Monarchs flying over our house in Encino Park, San Antonio, Texas. Some of them were looking for a place to rest the night.The following evening I only observed one.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I live in Hudson Bend on Lake Travis. Yesterday, Saturday 10/14, I saw a massive number of monarchs in the air during my 5 mile walk through the hills of Hudson Bend. This is the first time in my nearly 15 years of living here, that I've seen this many monarchs. Friday evening I was out in my backyard around 6:45 p.m. and noticed them coming down to roost in my trees overnight.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Up here in the eastern Texas Panhandle I have watched an awesome Monarch migration...have just been gobs of them this year...it started the last week in August and is still going on...saw many out at the ranch yesterday (October 17).

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife, who has written for confirmation on the time and numbers.

Up here in the eastern Texas Panhandle I have watched an awesome Monarch migration...have just been gobs of them this year...it started the last week in August and is still going on...saw many out at the ranch yesterday (October 17).

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife, who has written for confirmation on the time and numbers.

I wanted to give you an estimate of the Monarch migration that we saw at the Center. I estimate that there were about 500 Monarchs per minute passing the open patch of sky above us, and estimate conservatively about 20,000 monarchs during the short period they were passing over. I do not believe I have seen a Monarch migration like this in Texas or elsewhere.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We're having a heavy peak migration here or I am in just the right spot. The Monarchs have been flying over at the rate of about 50 an hour around my house and in the general area south of Houston for the past 3 days. We have Monarchs here, but they are lower to the ground and eating leisurely; whereas, the migrating Monarchs are 30' or more in the air with a different flight pattern and if one comes in for a quick snack,it doesn't stay looking for more before it leaves. Texas City, TX was plentiful with Monarchs yesterday and Le Marque, TX was heavy this morning between the rain showers.

Today, right outside the Courthouse in La Salle County, I stepped outside and thousands of monarch butterflies were resting on the trees, I stepped outside and it was like paradise with the butterflies soaring above us. We are 65 miles north of Laredo.  The butterflies are almost home. October 16, 2006 Joel Rodriguez, Jr. La Salle County Judge
WOW....235 Monarchs sighted this week. Flying everywhere. We are excited. Is this our Peak Migration?

The students at Alvarado Elementary South observed approximately 82 monarchs on this day. We were able to catch and tag one monarch. We are ecstatic to continue following the monarch migration to Mexico.

In Southwest Texas, near where Independence creek flows into the Pecos River, there is a gorgeous, crystal clear spring that flows into a pool, that then flows into Independence creek. This place is called Oasis ranch. We spent the weekend of Oct 14 there, and there were thousands of Monarchs flying around and roosting in the huge Pecan trees right next to the springs.
Down by the Pedernales river on a ranch near Cypress Mill, there were hundreds of Monarchs flying around and roosting in the large Cypress and Pecan trees by the River.

Spotted about 65 monarchs over the period of a youth soccer game (1 hour) over Circle C Soccer fields in far south Austin. Starting with a few at 9:00 am and by the end of the game (10:15 am) there were 5 to 6 at any one look into the sky. All were flying south at about 6 to 10 feet in the air.
I also saw 100's of thousands of monarchs and other butterflies flying through the air just ahead of a front that was blowing in.

We have Monarchs here, but they are lower to the ground and eating leisurely; whereas, the migrating Monarchs are 30' or more in the air with a different flight pattern and if one comes in for a quick snack,it doesn't stay looking for more before it leaves. Texas City, TX was plentiful with Monarchs yesterday and Le Marque, TX was heavy this morning between the rain showers.
