A cold front moved through the Lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas this afternoon bringing the first of the monarch migration to Weslaco and Mercedes. I watched until dusk when monarchs began to land in my mesquite trees only to be chased away or snapped up by birds.There were about 20 per minute.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

A massive monarch roost along the Rio Grande. Charlie estimated the roost at ~1000

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Today, just right now hundreds of Monarchs by minute are passing by. The day right here in Olinalá is sunny and warm (around 20ºc) no wind and they pass in between the crowns of the oaks. It must be around 9 meters above ground. You know my home is around 1300m above sea level.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

October 17th:
German film crew began filming on bluff above the Rio Grande in Eagle Pass---1000 in the group of big trees on Simpson St.

October 18th:
A few hundred still in trees on Simpson St.

October 20th:
60 monarchs in trees at my house. 12 mi. N Eagle Pass.

October 21-23:
No monarchs in my trees at Radar Base. Breeze from north for several days now. Cool.

I am surprised at the sudden drop off in numbers. In past years there would have been a few small clusters 40 to 100 night after night, after the leading edge passed. We're still seeing many more queens drifting around, than monarchs in dedicated flight.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

It was very warm, mid-90s, with a strong south wind blowing. I walked outside to be sure water was in the birdbath and was engulfed in a monarch snowstorm. They were fluttering and floating, also many were resting in the deep shade of the old trees that provide a canopy in our back yard. There were probably 100-200 of them. They were fewer in number the next morning but many were clustered together in the trees, roosting I presume. Diminishing each day, we had them in our yard for a week or so. A gift!

Our group counted the following:

start time: 3:22
end time: 3:37
6 flying directionally; 5 checked out a butterfly bush, but didn't land; 5 landed and took nectar

15 monarchs/minute
60/hour

Monarchs - several scattered in the mesquite trees in early morn, 7:30 am, then later in the morning, flying to the yellow flowers in photos. There were many, many all day long, but never saw a large concentration of them. However, we have 200 acres on that side of Hwy 36, and not enough time to seriously look for a large concentration of them.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I would like to report a sighting of more than 200 monarch butterflies in my farm yesterday morning, October 22, this small ranch is located Just outside the city of Saltillo, Coahuila,Mexico to the N.E. we have pecan trees and some pine trees which the monnarchs preferto spend the night, we are situated in the valley at an altitude of 1,500 meters , to our S.E. are located the mountains and a canyon that allow the butterflies to climb above the 2,000 meter level to reach the central Mexico Plateau and their winter home,every year we have them in our farm,this first group arrived with a cold front as they usually do , if the weather is right they usually warm their wings on the morning sun and continue their journey the next day. Saludos

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

The most exciting sighting I have ever seen  hundreds, thousands of butterflies , flying overhead at about 10 to 20 feet, a trail about 8 to 10 feet wide... just above the neighborhood roof lines, right through my back yard, they were flying south.  Mostly Monarch's, but there were also lots of other types of butterflies mixed in with them, they were floating on a wind current.  I watched the trail for about 15 minutes, it then began to lessen in numbers to only a dozen at a time, till only a few.  Simply delightful to watch.  And very interesting to see the way they were just floating in the wind current, it seemed it didn't take any effort for them at all.  I only wish I had a video camera at the time.

Today october 24th all over the city of Saltillo, thousands of monarch butterflies were flying. The day began a little cool but around nine o´clock it got warmer and the butterflies began to fly first at low level but now its aroud 12:30 they are flying very high, but you can still see some about at 15 feet over the ground Finally they are here. Cecilia Ochoa

I went across the Lavaca Bay Causeway this morning and took up station at my usual monitoring site on the north approach peninsula and counted in five minute intervals from 9:30 to 10:00 ... looking out the front and left windows of the van ... sun was reflecting off the bay to the right so couldn't see anything there ... 30 minute total was 95 monarchs for an average of 190 per hour.Had to go home and get yesterday's monarchs out of fridge and tag and measure to take to grandson Jacob's second grade classroom at Industrial Elementary in Vanderbilt for release. Crossed paths with about a dozen monarchs as I drove the thirty miles around Lavaca Bay to get over there, saw much goldenrod along the way.

There's a herd of Monarchs nectaring in my flowering trees this morning. Our house backs onto the San Antonio River just south of downtown San Antonio.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

There's a herd of Monarchs nectaring in my flowering trees this morning. Our house backs onto the San Antonio River just south of downtown San Antonio.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game
Monarchs have been everywhere this weekend, all over the beach. We did a 5 minute count while driving and counted 250.

Buenas tardes!!! Les escribo para comentarles que por fín llegó la distinguida y esperada visitante, el día de ayer 10 de octubra de 2006 regresaba de la Ciudad de Del Río, Texas como a las 2:00 de la tarde y observé algunas cuantas, muy pocas(10-15 en una hora) entrando a México cruzando el puente internacional y el río Bravo, el día de hoy 11 de octubre como a las 10:00 de la mañana me dirigía a la Presa la Amistad a realizar mis recorridos de rutina y pude observar volando en mayor cantidad de (100-120 en una hora) aún cruzando el río Bravo y a través del vaso de la Presa la Amistad, algunas están de un tamaño bastante grande , no se si esto tenga que ver porque sean las de la punta, las que vienen al frente del contingente, no se. Espero que las podamos tener por aquí algunos días cruzando por toda la ciudad. Les comento que el día estaba templado como entre 19 y 25 grados centígrados, con niebla por la mañana y medio nublado por la tarde.Saludos y contentoIng. Roberto Enríquez

El sabado 21, el dia amaneció soleado y por la mañana se veían cientos de mariposas volar por toda la ciudad y docenas alimentandose en los girasoles de los lotes baldios y en las flores de los jardines.

A las seis de la tarde salí al jardín a observar el cielo y !Sorpresa! miles de mariposas descendían del cielo a pasar la noche en la ciudad. Desde mi casa las observe dirigirse hacia la Sierra de Zapalinamé que se encuentra al este, la temperatura en 27°C con viento del noroeste (NW). Las vi durante una hora, en ese momento, Eduardo Aizpuru, esposa e hijos, observadpores del Correo Real desde hace varios años; llegaron a mi casa para que sus niños me platicaran lo que acaban de observar en Loma Linda: de 6:13 a 6:31 contaron 399 mariposas, en otros lados del cielo se observaban remolinos de cientos de mariposas.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Se movieron de lugar siguiendo la carretera 57 y cerca de Arteaga, Coah. en el Fraccionamiento El Llano vieron cientos de mariposas volando desde el nivel del suelo hasta el cielo, en vuelo alto. y contaron un racimo de mas de 100 mariposas en un fresno. Sus observaciones fueron en las faldas de la Sierra de Zapalinamé.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Hoy domingo 22, el clima volvió a cambiar: a las 8 de la mañana el cielo estaba nublado y fresco 16°C me dirigí hacia el sur de la ciudad al Jardín Botánico de la Humanidad, lugar donde se encuentran unos nogales muy viejos y en los que las mariposas forman sus racimos para dormir. Efectivamente ahí estaban las monarcas, ya se estaban levantando algunas docenas, otros cientos que posiblemente venían de oeste de la ciudad, ya daban vuelos en circulos tomando las termales, durante unas dos horas se veían pasar a cientos de mariposas al sureste en vuelo alto. Pero, de pronto empece a observar que empezaron a descender del cielo y buscar otra vez los árboles, al mismo tiempo la temperatura empezó a descender, la neblina bajó y se sentía una brisa muy humeda. me retiré del lugar y empezó una lluvia ligera que aún perdura hasta ahorita que son las siete de la tarde.

Espero que cuando mejore el tiempo se vean otra vez por miles en la ciudad.

Reportan: Lucho Atkins, Laila Atkins y Lety Rufino. LAS MARIPOSAS YA ESTAN EN COAHUILA¡¡¡¡¡¡¡¡¡¡¡¡¡” “Ayer miércoles 19 de octubre vi pasar junto con la neblina a decenas de mariposas que volaban bajo, solo conté por un minuto 75 y eran las que mis ojos alcanzaron a ver, las vimos en Lomas de Lourdes 5:00 p.m. de una tarde nublada”

Courtesy of Correo Real

“Armando Jiménez. “Te reporto que hoy 19 de octubre aquí en Monterrey o mejor dicho San Nicolás aquí en la Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León específicamente en la Facultad de ciencias Biológicas unidad B se vio una impresionante migración se veían cientos en el cielo y otros mas entre los árboles que poco a poco fueron quedando se a dormir en los mismos desde las cuatro de la tarde me di cuenta del el paso de las monarcas hasta que comenzó a obscurecer. La tarde era templada o fresca podríamos decirlo como entre 21 y 22 grados centígrados, nublada y húmeda. La verdad fue fascinante ver tal cantidad de mariposas en el cielo y entre nosotros. “

Courtesy of Correo Real

Nuestro amigo René Flores Garza de Monterrey nos comenta “Después de dos días de un agobiante calor de 36 grados en la Ciudad de Monterrey, temperatura por cierto nada común para estas fechas (será el Calentamiento Global?), hoy 19 de Octubre, llega a la ciudad un agradable frente frío y junto con éstos viento del norte, cientos de mariposas Monarcas vuelan sobre nosotros en su migración de otoño.

Es un fenómeno natural siempre fascinante, al principio traté de contarlas volteando directamente al cielo encima de mí, pero al alcanzar más de cien individuos fue imposible seguir, pues en ese momento eran simplemente demasiados. Era medio día, la temperatura se encontraba en 23 grados centígrados; el cielo con nublados muy altos era el fondo blanco en dónde resaltaban los cientos de Monarcas volando en la zona Oeste de la ciudad de Monterrey.

Después de varios intentos y buscando enfocarme en algún punto, pude contar un promedio de 43 Monarcas por minuto.Saludos y que sigan disfrutando de la migración.”

Courtesy of Correo Real

Alida Madero desde Monterrey reporta “El primer día que vi. mariposas monarca en Monterrey fue el 17 de octubre en el campus del Tec de Monterrey. Se veían una que otra volando relativamente bajo e incluso visitaron mis asclepias en el jardín (en Col. Country, hacia el sur de la ciudad). El día 18 hizo muchísimo calor y prácticamente no se vio nada. El 19 refresco y se volvieron a ver, y hoy 20 de octubre, están pasando en cantidades importantes, pero no muy bajo, de manera que la gente en general no se da cuenta. Si volteo hacia el cielo, puedo verlas volar a diferentes alturas. Quiero también reportar que hemos tenido monarcas ovipositando en el parque la Estanzuela y vimos a las orugas, pero esto fue antes que llegara esta migración, por lo que supongo que son población residente. Saludos Un abrazo.”

Courtesy of Correo Real

Eglantina Canales “Pues hoy yo también las vi., Saltillo está lleno de monarcas, por la mañana del día 20, las conté sobre mi casa a media cuadra de la alameda 12 por minuto, están en Campo Redondo, en el Archivo Municipal y arriba de nosotros en la oficina. Hayalgunas a la altura de los edificios y otras volando muy alto.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Benjamín Ornelas Borrego del ANP Cuatociénegas reporta “Por fin también por acá en Cuatrociénegas ya se están observando algunas. 19 de octubre Susana Moncada reporta 2 mariposas en su casa volando, clima soleado, medio nublado, poco viento. Observé el día 20 de octubre en el ejido la vega alrededor de 150 monarcas perchadas y volando en un huizache el día estaba soleado y viento moderado. el día 22 en la poza azul observamos alrededor de 15 mariposas volando, en compañía de Angela, Esther, Bob y el equipo de filmación de la televisora alemana, el clima predominante fue frío y nublado con viento moderado.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Manuel Gerardo Vega Gaona nos reporta “Continúan pasando por Galeana, N. L. Por miles ayer domingo 22 de octubre nublado y con frío pude ver entre La Cabecera y San Roberto.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Eglantina Canales dice” El sábado 21 por la mañana en El Carmen, km. 27.5 antigua carretera Saltillo – Monclava, las mariposas estuvieron presentes todo el día, por la mañana entre nueve y diez volaron en mayores cantidades contando entre dos y cuarenta por minuto. El cielo estaba nublado y el piso húmedo, algunas mariposas se posaron sobre el pasto. Sobre la carretera a Saltillo se vieron todo el día en forma aislada.

El domingo 22 el vuelo fue espectacular contando entre 50 y 170 mariposas por minuto, de las 10 a las 11 de la mañana con un cielo muy nublado a una temperatura de 16 grados centígrados y vientos dominantes hacia el suroeste, aunque eran muy débiles la estación marcaba 0 por hora.Con una llovizna de casi todo el día las mariposas no eran muy evidentes, pero por la tarde las vimos posadas en sus ramas de siempre en los nogales más altos de la huerta, la tarde era muy obscura y apenas se distinguían de las hojas ya amarillas.

Rodrigo Canales, las vio la mañana del domingo 22 en grandes cantidades en La Chancla, frente a San Miguel, Ramos Arizpe, Carretera antigua Saltillo - Monclava, km. 29 fuimos por la tarde y ahí estaban posadas aunque en menores cantidades, eligieron para dormir un aguacate y un níspero, también había algunas en tejocotes y en fresnos. Entre todas juntaban algunos cientos.”

Courtesy of Correo Real

Gerardo Gudiño reporta “Efectivamente por fin llegaron, ayer 23 de octubre, por la tarde con un cielo seminublado las monarcas arribaron a los terrenos de la UTC, cerca de las 14:33 horas, más de media centena, cruzaron de norte a sur estos terrenos, algunas detuvieron su marcha en algunas flores y plantas de nuestra universidad, otras continuaron su curso, esperemos que las condiciones climáticas mejores para poder tener más avistamientos.”Saludos

Courtesy of Correo Real

Ayer las mariposas monarcas nos alegraron la vida al ta´pizar el cielo de Saltillo.Despues de dos días de neblina y fresco, ayer 24 de octubre de 9 de la mañana a 12 de mediodía levantaron el vuelo miles y miles de mariposas que se habían perchado en las zonas arboladas de toda la ciudad. El espectáculo fue bellisimo¡¡.

Durante la tarde ya en vuelo alto se vieron pasar un numero constante de mariposas en dirección sureste, 30/min aproximadamente.El día de hoy durante la mañana se han visto un poco menos, pero en cada alto de semaforo puedo contar unas 20, desde el nivel de las casas hasta vuelo alto.

El día 23 por la tarde recorrí varios sitios donde generalmente se forman los racimos y las encontré en nogales, pirules y huizaches, tanto en Saltillo com en la vecina ciudad de Ramos Arizpe. Calculo que en cada árbol había un de 2000 a 3000 mariposas.

El año pasado este fenomeno se observó el día 25 de octubre, pero con menos mariposas.Espero un día de estos ven

We're visiting in Charleston, SC and decided to take a walk on Folly Beach.  There were thousands of monarchs and (possibly)viceroys feeding on the tiny yellow daisies there.  It was a beautiful sight!

After a powerful front moved thru with winds to 35 knots yesterday the wind lay early during the night.  I took up my usual monitoring site, same as on the 24th, on the north approach peninsula to the Lavaca Bay Causeway, and counted five minutes inverals, first from 9:30 to 10:00 and then 12:20 to 12:50 ... again looking out the drivers front window and left window of the van ... sun was reflecting off the bay, made it impossible to see to right.  From 9:30 to 10:00 the count was 297 monarchs for an average of 594 an hour, best for 5 minutes was 58.  From 12:20 to 12:50 the count was 84 in 30 minutes for a 168 average in an hour, best 5 minutes was 22 monarchs.  594 monarchs an hour eclipsed the previous high of 190 an hour back on the 24th.  I was monitoring a narrow 200' wide corridor.  I drove backtracking and found the flow to cover about a five mile wide area crossing Lavaca Bay at this point.  Good math problem.  As the wind turned from NW to SE, the flow turned off by 3:00 pm.

As yesterday, had a good flow of monarchs in the early morning before the wind picked up from the SE ... same spot ... same way ... best 30 minute total was 153, for any average of 306 an hour, best 5 minutes was 45 and that was at 9:15 a.m.  They were flying NE to SW, low to 50' up, steady, migrational flight ... looked like a 3-D monarch interstate in the sky, all going one way, but properly spaced.  Numbers fell off quickly after 10:00 a.m. when the breeze could be seen to begin to stir the slick waters of Lavaca Bay and move things out of the ESE ever so slightly.  Went back about 3:00 p.m. when the wind was 5 to 10 mph out of the SSE and we had to search to find a dozen monarchs nectaring, nothing flying.  71 dF, clear, another front about Thursday.

Here in the Lower Rio Grande Valley, we've been seeing a steady stream of monarchs today although the numbers are small - 1 or 2 a minute this morning and fewer this afternoon. The temperature is in the 70's, with clear skies and wind from the NW at 8. The monarchs were heading south this morning but south-southeast late this afternoon.Along with the monarchs, we're seeing a large migration of red admirals.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Saw a group pf 200 monarch butterflies in  Escobedo, Nuevo Leon, Mexico. I saw the group only the day of 20, 21 and 24 of October.

At one point I counted 5 per minute. I was sitting on the beach on Sullivan's Island near Fort Moultrie, just east of Charleston, SC. I was on the beach for about an hour in mid morning, clear skies, no wind, mid to high 70s.I am a teacher but I had the day off. It was an enormous treat!

The monarchs are passing through Tequisquiapan. I found a male that had been bitten by a bird in my driveway today. There have not been as many this year as in previous years. We also usually see a lot of queens before the monarchs arrive, but I have only seen one this year. The weather has been warm in the early part of the day, but late afternoons have been cloudy and rainy. The temperatures are now dropping into the freezing range at night.
10:36 am Monarch Butterfly's going through in mass quantities 100+ per minute travelling due south, East winds 8 to 10 kts bright sunshine temp 12 C Queretaro, Queretaro MexZaragoza / 57
10:52 numbers have diminished to approx 50/minute
Large amounts of Monarch butterflies in the air over the city of Queretaro today.

Between the hours of 8:10 a.m. and 2:20 p.m., we counted a total of 1,659 monarchs flying past Del Rio Middle School.  The majority, 1,210, were observed flying before 11 a.m.  Interestingly the temperature was between 68-74 degrees and it was partly cloudy.  This is due to the fact that it had rained off and on for the past three days; so the monarchs were ready to fly when it finally stopped-accounting for the large morning numbers.

My property has hundreds of trees. I noticed Monarchs chose one oak tree in particular with dense foilage. The entire tree literally "Fluttered" because of the number of monarchs on it. This particular Oak is pretty unique to my property. Why they chose it, I don't know. But while they could have chosen from hundreds of other less unique trees on my property......they chose this specific Oak. It had a good breeze and water in a nearby trough.

I am amazed with the Monarach Migration this year. In the 10 years I've lived in this region I have NEVER seen the quanity of monarchs. By and large most of them are very tiny but there have been some large ones. They have come in WAVES this years. Millions....perhaps Billions. I have been worried since the freeze in years past about their survival but this year certainly eases my mind. They have rembounded in an amazing way.I would guess that this is the FOURTH WAVE of Monarachs in the past month's time. And they still come. They will be arriving in Mexico for a great deal longer. Tell the citziens of Michoacan to be prepared to be amazed by the numbers this year!!!!!!!!

Nov 2: Early morning temp was 52 dF, lowest this fall.  Early morning count just before 11:10 am was averaging 8 per minute.  Between 11:10 and 11:14, 107 monarchs came past me ... my guess was they were in nearby trees and had warmed up enough to want to fly.  Later I counted for ten minutes from 12:40 to 12:50 and had 37 came past my point.  These are very good numbers for the midcoast of Texas in early November but not unheard of.  The warmest it got was 61 dF, we had a N wind blowing 20 to 25 mph, clear.  Nov 3:  North wind continued ... good numbers early.  Observed about 200 thru binocs nectaring on lantana and goldenrod.  Netted a male monarch that had been tagged in Whitehouse, Ohio 40 days and 1,146 miles earlier.  Wind turned to E after noon and flow of monarchs shut down.

Front came in during the night.  Monarchs on the increase before noon with the light NW wind.  Went back and did a count from 12:20 to 12:50 and had 125 come by my point for an hourly avg of 250, best 5 minutes was 25.   Wind calmed after 2:00 and the number dropped to about 1 every 5 minutes by 3:30.  We went back at 4:30 and found several small clusters wanting to form before sundown.  High had gotten to 71 dF, clear.  Wind was out of SE at sundown.  Another front Friday/Saturday and this may repeat.  On Nov 4th we also had a brief flurry of monarchs following the large numbers on the 2nd and 3rd.

Today thousands of monarchs have arrived in Tequisquiapan. They began to arrive around five o'clock in the afternoon. The butterflies were arriving from the north. This is the first large group to pass through this fall. It is such a wonderful sight! All the neighbors were out. Our subdivision is surrounded by pines and eucalyptus trees. The entire subdivision is full of the butterflies tonight. This is the latest we have seen the butterflies roost in the fall. Here is one of the photos my husband and I took.

The second big wave of monarchs arrived last night and there are monarchs everywhere. It is chilly and cloudy today. It rained all night long. It was 14 degrees C from 7:00 to 10:00. at 11:15 the temperature had reached 18.5 degrees C.

I just returned from a trip to the Hudson Bay Lowland and, as it happens, I saw one monarch butterfly. The observationwas at the Attawapiskat airport on Monday August 1 at 9:00 a.m. The butterfly was flying with a good tail wind across the gravel aircraft parking/refuelling area.

Attawapiskat, Ontario, is a Cree village on the Attawapiskat River about 10 km upriver from its mouth on the west coast ofJames Bay. The observation location is the airport there, at 55.93 N, -82.43 W.

Contributed by Mr. Don Davis for Mr. Kenneth Abraham, Waterfowl and Wetlands Scientist of Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources. [Note: Date of sighting was actually Aug. 1. It is dated July 31st here for a technical reason; our spring maps only include data through July.]

Several tens of thousands of Monarchs overnighted in large old Maple trees just south of Charlevoix last night. The sight was an old farmhouse renovation project on the corner of Ferry Rd & U.S.31 south near Atwood Michigan just north of the 45th parallel.

After another chilly night (down to 50 F), temperatures warmed up to about 70 F and in the mid morning, while driving back to Toronto from Cobourg, I noted a strong movement of monarchs, flying high across Hwy. 401 (expressway). Oshawa Second Marsh- Sunday, August 19 Monarch- 50 to 100 per minutemigrating westward

Every where I looked today there were large numbers of migrating Monarchs. Even well out over Lake Ontario. It is the largest migration that I have seen.

Thousands of Monach Butterflies landing in trees.

Thursday, August 23 Thickson's Woods Monarchs

As happened last August, monarch butterflies arecongregating in sheltered areas in the centre of thewoods, particularly in a clearing where a large silverpoplar blew down two years ago. Numbers have reachedseveral thousand. Last year at the peak estimatesplaced the numbers at perhaps 100,000. Thebutterflies are very sensitive to any sounds, soplease be considerate. If you move slowly andsilently, you will have a much more rewardingexperience and the butterflies will be lessdisturbed.. Look for twigs and branches covered withwhat look to be dead leaves.

Contributed by Don Davis

Once again Thickson's woods was one happening place this morning. It was easy to see 10,000 to 12,000 Monarchs roosting in the trees from 7:30 to 8:00 am this morning. By far the most I have ever seen at one time ..

Contributed by Don Davis

Our home is surrounded by a 160 acre hay field in full bloom.  The monarchs began appearing on 8/22/07 and the number grew to the hundreds by 8/26/07.  They roosted in our maple and birch trees.  The numbers began to diminish on 8/29/07 and on 8/30/07, almost all were gone.

When I visited La Crosse Airport last, on August 31, there were thousands of Monarch Butterflies nectaring on rough blazing star. Both the butterfly and the plant were probably at the greatestdensities I've seen. I walked onto the prairie through the pineplantation, and it took me a moment to realize I was walking through anaisle of monarchs. They were actually roosting in the pine trees, likethey do in Mexico. Having been at the wintering grounds in February,this was very evocative of that experience. Unfortunately, I wasn'tprepared for this. It would have been a great opportunity to tagspecimens.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Holiday Beach,Ontario, Canada,

Sept.9

Sunday started out miserably. It rained most of the night. At 5:30 am Holiday Beach was soaked. It was a steamy, hot and humid morning. By 9:30 I saw our first Monarch flutter by. The sun wasn't out and didn't make an appearance until 11:30 but one after two after three then four and five Monarchs were starting to stir. The early migration resumed by noon. This time a bit lower and many more grabbing nectar where they could before the jaunt over the Detroit River. I have never experienced a 2-day migration like this in the park. We left the park at 4 pm and hundreds of Monarchs were still passing us by.

There was a steady stream of hundreds of Monarch Butterfly every hour all day through the whole range of height of flight, even up with the Turkey Vultures.

Rachel A. Powless
Two days at Holiday Beach and we couldn't even keep track of the numbers of Monarchs. It began Saturday, (Sept 8). The Monarchs were high, very high. Down at the passerine station, we were seeing the same marvelous migration. Some did come down to nectar but for the most part, Monarchs were on their mission. Blue skies and orange and black definitively showing directionality. This is a bit early to see this kind of movement. This generally happens mid-month.

Only the second time I've ever seen monarchs roosting and this was in the same location I saw them maybe, 5 years before. I counted 50 on a soft maple branch and multiplied that by the 12 other spots they were covering.

On a warm sunny day, Sept. 13, there were hundreds of Monarchs in the ash trees and cedar trees here. We are 50 meters from the east shore of lake Huron. Today, Sept. 15, windy and cooler, there are few visible.

Found our visitors hanging on our two willow trees between the barn and the house. This is a sheltered location from the wind. Rain was forecast for later in the evening and I guess they were looking for a safe place to spend the night. There were quite a few thousand of them. It was fun watching them jockey around and exchanging positions. Getting ready for the evening, I guess. It didn't rain much at night, but there was a cloudburst around dawn. I went out after the rain stopped but they left without even eating breakfast. I'm glad I was able to see them this year, as I've missed them since I last saw them in Cape May about 15 years ago. A marvelous sight!

SMRR- Lake Erie Metropark
