Sept. 4
Monarchs continued to move in numbers and outnumbered every other migrant except perhaps Purple Martins during the early part of the day. I suspect some number roosted in the park overnight as there seemed to be a modest lift off of them during my early morning wanderings on the Cherry Island trail.

Contributed by Don Davis and Carolyn King

Large numbers flew into town yesterday and today (in the thousands). Many that graced my gardens appeared very tired; spent much of the day resting /basking in my rear garden. At one point I saw a cloud of monarchs with birds flying in circles around and through them. It must have been about 6 stories high (not good with number estimates...<G> I also noted ALOT of dragonflies with the butterflies (not sure if I reported that last year but I recall seeing it then too).  Looks like a great migration is underway here on the east coast.

Noticed butterflies in groups of 10 plus for several hours continuously flying at the oceans edge and 100 feet from the ocean. The general direction seemed to be west. This was at Kismet Fire Island. It was a clear sunny day with a gentle breeze. Absolutely beautiful!

All I can tell you for sure is that for about 2 hours while I was on the beach, looking in any direction there were butterflies visable, all heading west. At any one time I could see clearly ten butterflies sometimes more. Understand that there were many more visable but because there were so many in the distance you could not count them. I am sure there were hundreds,and possibly a few thousand butterflies that passed us as we sat at the beach. People were just standing and staring. It was quite amazing...I have never seen anything like it ever!

This weekend at Holiday Beach, the Monarch movement has not waned. Every day last week up to and including Saturday & Sunday the movement of Monarchs has been incredible. At times on Saturday, some of us down at the passerine station had difficulty distinguishing Broad-winged Hawks with Monarchs. Always, Monarchs, Monarchs and more Monarchs in the mix of our binocs! On Saturday and Sunday night, Carl & I counted many roosts of several hundred on the cottonwood and poplar tree-tops. The movement of monarchs along the shore is unlike any I have seen.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

On September 3, 2007, while sitting on the balcony of our upper level condo on Lake Michigan in Brevort, MI, in the Upper Peninsula we first saw a flock of perhaps 30 monarchs headed west late in the morning. During the noon hour and into early afternoon, we saw individual monarchs pass by, headed west, at the rate of perhaps one per minute. Also, although I did not see this firsthand, a friend living on nearby Brevort Lake told me she had seen a tree covered with monarchs on her property the same afternoon.

My wife was in Cleveland visiting at Cleveland Metropolitan Hospital, on the 9th floor. That's high up! She noticed Monarchs migrating south through Cleveland at her level and above the 9th floor. In an hour's time, she saw a dozen Monarchs glide by the 9th floor window. Could this be the migrants that the Toronto observers saw??? There's not much on the move yet here in Fremont, about 80 miles West of Cleveland. I'm waiting! I guess Monarchs migrate fairly high in the air. The whole environ around Cleveland Metro Hospital is parking lots and cement, with heave traffic. The height of their migration probably saves many.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Twenty-five monarchs were observed at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge during a one and one-half hour visit. Most of them were nectaring on tickseed sunflowers, which appeared to be the choice of many varieties of wildflowers blooming at this time.
Driving home Sept 1st, 11 AM, we stopped at a beach along the northern shore of Lake Michigan about 20 miles west of St Ignace and in 1/2 hour walk we saw 12 monarchs heading west along the beach.
lower Lake Michigan sand dune near St. Joseph, between 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM sighted 25-30 monarch flying south
Sometimes in pairs. About 50 individuals observed during morning hours between 9 and 11 AM.

I just counted 56 monarchs in less than 1 hour directional flying west.  There is a northwest wind blowing and they are definitely using it.  Temperatures are expected to drop into the upper 40's tonight so I believe they are using the wind and warm weather today to get moving through here.  I don't believe this is peak yet but time will tell.  Warm weather is still in our forecast for the coming week.
within the course of one hour, I counted 11 monarch butterflies heading south through my yard.
We saw 12 monarch butterflies in the span of 10 minutes. The time of the observation was 3:40 pm to 3:50 pm.

On August 5, most of the recently emerged monarchs in extreme northern Minnesota were exhibiting southward migratory behaviorand evening clustering behavior:

Photo #1
Photo #2

In a grove of maple trees, next to Grey Couny Road #1, approx 3 km west of Owen Sound bay, a collection of approx 700+monarchs. We visited in the early morning, and my husband photographed the clusters. 44.5697 -80.9305
Absolutely amazing!  Hundreds of monarchs are roosting in our Maple and Birch trees. They have been here for 3 days. This is something new for our rural school!
Thousand's of Monarch's roosting each night in a park on the bluff overlooking Lake Huron in Goderich, ON.  Peak date appears to be 08/19/07.

We drove down Sunday morning around 9:00 am & the temperature by us was about 50 degrees, but sunny. We did not see any flying on the way down, but once we got there, they were all over. What a delight! They seemed very mellow, not at all like the ones I release who can’t seem to get away quick enough. They were just drifting by on the breeze & nectaring on all the flowers. Someone mentioned as she walked on one of the trails by the lighthouse one tree just erupted in butterflies. Wish I had seen it.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
in our back yard I was counting about 30 per hour stopping at our butterfly bushes. they mainly like the white bush

We had up to twelve monarchs in the air at one time Saturday morning September 8th over three small backyard flower gardens in the city.  Since then, even though a couple of cold fronts have gone through, I have seen no more than two a day.

I saw approx 50+ Monarchs (one or two at a time) flying out over Lake St. Clair near Harsons Island from 1300 hrs to about 1400 hrs. What was also neat was that all of them were flying in the same narrow path, heading to the southwest.

Joy abounds. This evening, 9/19 from 5:30 to 7:30 pm, we counted roughly 300 monarchs sailing through Tunnel Gap on the Blue Ridge Parkway. This is milepost BRP 415.6; around 25 miles southwest of Asheville, NC. Most were just beyond netting reach, sailing, gliding SSW through the gap right towards the beautiful Looking Glass Rock. Nice photo of the rock at: http://www.ncwaterfalls.com/prints/brp31_print.htm

As expected, many roosted in the old Northern Red Oaks and Chestnut Oak trees at the overlook. Roosting time for the ones in our view at 7:30pm; temp 64dF; winds stiff from the north. A glorious warm sunny day brought to a close with beauty. Wish everyone everywhere had access to this.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Just would like to report a large cluster sighting that I observed in Enosburgh, VT. Have never seen this before and have a wonderful digital video of this sighting. It was one of the most beautiful things I've ever experienced.

We were on the crest (very top) of our land, with a 360 degree view and sooooo quiet. You could even hear the butterflies landing and fluttering. I don't know how to put a number on them. They were all over and it appeared they were eating (something) on the maple leaves, and roosting on the pine trees. They were roosting on the south side of the trees.

We went up to the site 1 week later and they were no longer there. Not one!

Spotted approximately 100 butterflies at 7:30 pm within city of Syracuse.  They flew in singly or in pairs and appeared to be choosing a place to land. They settled over three city lots, in both evergreens and deciduous trees. The process took approximately 30 minutes. The next morning's temperatures remained in the high 50's to low 60's.  Watched carefully from 7:30 am to 11:45 am. First departure was after 8 am. Observed only 5 other departures prior to 11:30 am.

Our family just returned from a sea kayaking trip out of Killarney. Monarchs were abundant throughout the area. In particular, we found a staging area on West Fox Island that had between 400 and 500 individuals in an area of about 15M x 15M.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
The sightings started in Cobourg 5 miles north of Port Hope.My Husband also noted a roost on the Golf course in Port Hope. The steady stream has been going south for more then 2 weeks. Lots of them.

Hundreds of Monarchs flying and checking out flowers in the garden then and  all finding each other and landing and roosting in a silver Maple tree on the same branches closing their wings, and looking like the keys or dried leaves. It was spectacular to witness and watch. Many pictures were taken.

Dozens -- probably hundreds -- of Monarchs roosting in our out of town yard. One of our Monarchs we have been watching inside our house just emerged today. We will release it in the yard with the hundreds of others. We see these each year. This year they have chosen a different tree than in previous years.

We had a lot of monarchs roosting in a couple of maple trees in our yard on this evening. We estimate that there may have been about 200 of them, maybe more! I counted about 50 in the largest cluster and there were a number of smaller clusters. We have never had this many in one evening. It was wonderful!!  This is earlier than when we usually have roosting monarchs. I would estimate about a week and a half early.
school: Not a school, a mother and 2 children

comments: A friend of mine and another monarch nut was at the Edwin F Hulbert Nature Preserve by Good Hart (zip code 49737) when they saw at least 100 monarchs on 8-21-07 from about 3 to 4 PM. They were in a wooded area and the butterflies were either roosting or flying about through the trees. Good Hart is real near Lake Michigan, where we would expect monarchs to concentrate.

Starting @ around 4 pm hundreds of monarchs came to 1 elm tree, congregating largely on the N side of it. Day was sunny, clear, windy. I'd say we watched about 3 hrs. with about 50/hr coming from every direction. Most were gone the next a.m. I mentioned it to our butterfly curator @ local zoo. She & others sighted the same behavior around cottages @ Lake Ontario the same day.

Yesterday morning (8/23) I observed many Monarchs at Forman Park in Pultneyville NY. This small village is located on the South shore of Lake Ontario approximately 30 miles east of Rochester. During a period of time from 10:15 AM until 11:00 AM I saw 30 Monarchs heading west along the lake shore. Also small groups of twenty or so Monarchs roosting in three trees close to shore and many nectaring on small flowers in lawn.

I am also seeing Monarchs every day in our newly established Way Station in Penfield ( eastern suburb of Rochester NY). Yesterday we also had a Giant Swallowtail. First time I have ever seen one!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
At least 200 monarchs roosting in oak trees on the east side of the John Michael Kohler Art Center in Sheboygan, WI.  5pm.  Was the 6th straight day of overcast skies and much rain.

I had 300 to 500 monarchs nectaring in my Monarch Waystation yesterday (8-24-07)Looks like about the same today. Last night many roosted in the woods in ones or twos. I did find one small roost of about 50. It looks like the migration has started.

I believe this year that monarch numbers are below the average of the last 12 years for my farm. Certainly much better than last year, but the numbers I’m seeing now I often see in the first half of August.

Sept. 17
Today only half of the students (35) made observations. During the 20 minute observation time, they recorded 39 migrating monarchs.

Sept. 16
Students continued to be diligent with their 20 minute observations. Today the students observed 96 migrating monarchs in the 20 minutes.

Sept. 15
This day was quite successful with a total of 76 monarchs counted during the required 20 minute observation period.

Sept. 14
Today the weather was windy and cold. Students were persistent and did see 39 monarchs migrating in 20 min.

Sept. 13
Today the 65 students on Nova Crew sighted 140 monarchs in 20 minutes in directional flight to Mexico. It seems that almost every student saw at least one.
Monarchs seemed to be stopping to rest on their migration. About 500 were in our trees about sunset.
100-200 roosting in maple tree in back yard. Humming birds are in the area also.
Observed many hundreds of monarchs roosting in the trees the past couple days. Roosting mainly in maple and ash trees. Strong south winds are holding them in the area.

Monarchs have been gathering at my farm grove. (Pine,ash and box elder trees)On August 28th a.m. hundreds were here. As a gentle rain began to fall they were drifting/floating around in the rain. A cool front moved through last night but the monarchs are still here this morning, sunny and 60*F.
An abundance of butterflies have been in the area. They are thick in the trees.
We saw probable about 500 out in our back yard and the barnyard.

At 7:30pm I started spotting six or seven monarchs per minute in my backyard, and for the next 30 minutes an increasing number showed up -- thousands landing on branches of trees in my yard and throughout my neighborhood, which gave the effect of beautiful orange fall leaves on the trees. It was such a spectacle and we are hoping to spot more!

This morning my daughter and I saw over 50 of them hanging in our maple tree at 6:30am just as the sun was rising you could see the colors like changing leaves in one section of the tree...absolutely amazing...batteries were dead in the digital...as the sun rose higher they all left.
In the last week the numbers of Monarchs roosting in the trees in my front yard has been growing...this morning there had to be hundreds...15 or more at a time clinging to a tiny branch...
We are in Lakewood, Oh. South shore of Lake Erie. Hundreds of Monarchs have begun roosting in the trees in our backyard. Really COOL!!!!!

Late this afternoon, there were probably 200-300 monarchs gathered in a wooded area near a local school. It was a sunny day, mid-70's, no precip. I have been seeing a few monarchs here and there throughout the day, more than usual, by this is a first for me to see a "roost"...very exciting! They were mostly all resting, with only a few in flight. I am SO thankful to my friend for telling me, and I got some nice pics and video.

We have seen several hundred Monarchs in our trees around the house for a couple of days. The first day that we observed the Monarchs was 8/31/07.  They seemed to be gathering in the trees in several masses to keep warm for the evening.  Yes there was a cool front overspreading the area on that night.  We also saw the butterflies early the next morning and then the next evening at about sundown they began to gather in there masses again.  We see them all summer long because we have quite a few butterfly friendly bushes in the yard, but it is usually just a dozen or two at a time.  This was an incredible sight to behold seeing so many at one time.  So, we had butterflies, en masse, for two consecutive nights, 8/31 and 9/1/07.
There are thousands of these butterflies here. In 35 years I have never seen such an amazing sight and as the days go by more and more keep coming.....

I was visiting my neighbor lady and we spotted several hundred Monarch butterflies. We started investigating and they were all over her trees and bushes. It was truly a phenomenal sight. I truly can't explain just how awesome it was. I took some pictures and they turned out really well.

Last year the monarchs started showing up around the same time.   This year they are gathering at our farm, like last year.    I don't see them arrive, but they gather in the cedar trees (two in particular) and flutter around until they leave.   The trees are on the north side of the grove and last year when they started gathering to move on south they started gathering in the Ponderosa pine trees that are on the south side of our grove.   It was quite a show and I took many pictures.   If they continue to gather this year, probably this next week,  I am calling the school to let the science teachers know as they may want to bring the kids out to see.   I will post another update after this weekend.   Last weekend the weather was warm, 90's.   It has cooled off today and is supposed to stay in the 70's for the next week.

Several hundred monarchs are roosting in our maple trees tonight. This is the first ones I've seen migrating. We cater to the monarchs every summer by allowing milkweed to grow and also planting a good sized flower garden for them to feed in. Many of them have pupated here this past summer and there are still caterpillars in the milkweed.
I couldn't count all the monarchs fluttering by in the yard. Everywhere we turned the treed area was moving.
Hundreds observed in trees in alley one block north of our home.  In one-half hour my children, mother and I tagged 75 with tags from Monarch Watch.

I am so excited because I went outside tonight and I saw many many monarchs! I was trying to count them but it was hard because they were fluttering all over the place. I know that I had to see and count at least 30 or 40 of them. I tried to look in the trees to see if they had roosted and count them that way, but it was difficult to tell what was a butterfly and what was a leaf on the tree. I am fairly certain that today was their first day here.

I found it to be quite amazing because when they were hear last year, it was almost exactly the same kind of weather. It was really sunny, warm and very little breeze. I don't know if this has any direct correlation or not. I will check again tomorrow night and keep you updated.

In a hardwoods, across from my house there have been hundreds of monarch butterflies roosting in the trees. Did they hatch from the woods? There really are very few milkweeds there. Or is this a stop on their migration route? It certainly is a beautiful sight!! I've seen them for about three weeks now.
I observed 100+ individuals in my maple trees on the evening of Sept. 5th. Many stayed in the trees and quite a few came and landed on me as I stood nearby observing them. What a fantastic event!
Hundreds of monarchs were roosting overnight; more on low branches, and leeward side of a windbreak grove.

The Monarch Butterflies are migrating across Nebraska.  We have noticed many of them flying across the roads and highways and Sunday night I went out in the common ground and saw many flying high around the trees.  I followed one with my eyes and it joined a roost of 25 individuals.  There were several roosts high in the Maple and Cottonwood trees.

About six o'clock in the evening, I was outside in my backyard. I noticed quite a few Monarch butterflies and then realized they were all flying to one particular tree in our backyard. They were hanging in bunches on the ends of several branches. I got my camera and took many pictures, which I have to share with you, if you'd like. (Because it was cloudy, they aren't as good as I would like, but aren't too bad either.) We had a rain last night and I was afraid they might be gone this a.m., but when I looked, many remain, although not all. It is still cloudy and wet, but if it clears, I will take some more pictures. Esitmated count: 500-1,000?

We saw monarchs gathering in red maple trees between 7:15 and 7:45pm two nights in a row (9/9 and 9/10) near our home in Canaan Valley, WV. There are large fields around our house with lots of blooming goldenrod and asters. The valley is at a high elevation (at least for the east) at 3200 feet and has large areas of fields and open wetlands in a stretch of the Appalachian Mountains where forests are dominant.

The butterflies were gathering in large maples in at least two areas. We had had many days in a row of hot calm weather. Yesterday and last night a strong cold front passed through bring winds from north and I suspect we will not see them roosting tonight!

What an incredible sight to witness. We became an airport with  Monarchs flying in from every direction, landing in only one of our many ash trees. Twenty seven years living here on our acreage in Giltner, NE., and  this has been our first sight of a gathering. It is the morning of Sept.10th and our leaves are turning colors and when the butterflies fold their wings they match the color of the leaves. I hope we see them again next year.
I saw about 50 monarch butterflies in my backyard.  I stayed in my backyard for two hours and more came.  A few came from the north and a few came from the west. I have a few flowers in my yard.
i saw hundreds of monarchs landing in my cedar trees just at dusk last night(9/13) . took a few pics. mostly just watched them land and settle down.

I walked to the back of the farm Friday evening 9/14/07 along the tree line. What I found there were swarms of monarchs, flying back and forth, and in the trees, they were gathering and hanging there! Bunches of them! In many trees! They appeared to be preparing to spend the night there. I've never seen this before.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I received an email reporting large clusters of monarchs in Walton, Kentucky, about 25 miles south of Cincinnati. They were roosting in sycamore and pin oaks.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
100+ butterflies resting on trees in our yard. First sighted around 6pm on 9/17. Still here at 9:30am on 9/18.
We had about 50 as it was getting dark last night. This morning there were about 100. Light southerly wind and lots of wild flowers and sedum blooming for feeding. I'm happy!

A week ago (approx. 9/11)I saw the arrival of about 50 monarch to our yard.  They seem to like the hard maple, sweet gum and bushes in the shade.  Today early in the a.m., I spotted about 100 roosting andcircling in my yard. After notifying the local school, students who came earlier in the day were encircled with the monarchs.  As I walk through the yard, I feel like it is a fairyland and I am blessed to be able to share this wonder of nature with the children and adults in the community.

A beautiful day filled with many Monarchs as a large group came through the city!  This morning around 9:15 am, I drove almost 20 miles from the north of the city, across the Missouri River and on to the south.  Everywhere I looked, there were Monarchs flying over the highways.  Numerous times I saw them in groups of 3 or more.In Lees Summit, Missouri, I was able to sit outside from 1:15 pm to 1:45 pm and counted 25 Monarchs in that time.  Mostly sunny day, temperatures in the mid-80's, mild to strong breeze from the south.
I viewed the skies for about 3 hours and observed 27 monarchs heading in a southernly direction. Several stopped by to visit my zinnias and butterfly bush.
We were on our local lake when we began to notice many monarch butterflies. They were flying 2 or 3 together. We saw at least one every 30 to 45 seconds.

I was with a group of people on a boat in the Thimble Islands. We stopped to have lunch and thought it was ' neat ' that there was a butterfly buzzing us. Upon watching there were hundreds of them appearing to migrate towards the shore. This would be more North West from our position. Craig

Every time I look out at my butterfly bush in front of my house I have at least 5 Monarchs on it feeding. Some leave and others replace them. Absolutely beautiful. So glad to see them in these numbers again.

Today Fri. the 21st.,the yard was filled with hundreds and hundreds of butterflies resting and circling.  What a surprise,since I first spotted the most on Tues the 18th and then the number decreased greatly on Wed. 19th, so I expected that they were leaving the area.  What a treat to have them for so long. Penny
We were on our local lake when we began to notice many monarch butterflies.  They were flying 2 or 3 together. We saw at least one every 30 to 45 seconds.

We live on a farm in South Central Nebraska (Gosper County).  We have had what seemed like millions resting in our tree claim on our farm.  This is the first time we have had so many.  They do not venture into my yard with flowers or anything, just in the trees (elms and evergreens) in our windbreak.  WHAT A LOVELY SIGHT THEY ARE AND SO ENJOYABLE TO WATCH!

Wow, this morning my hubby and I biked into town (Muncie, IN) passed the Oakhurst Gardens to find a rather large planting of milkweeds (mostly Asclepias tuberosa) that were just loaded with Monarchs! It was so fun to see tagged ones, untagged ones as well as the caterpillars! What fun and so encouraging! I brought some seeds home to add to my garden! Happy Fall!!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We've got quite a number of Monarchs visiting our Joe Pye Weed, zinnias, asters and goldenrod. Last year we had denser concentrations over a shorter period. This year, it seems we are getting them for a few extra weeks. A nice treat! I am seeing them everywhere this year, especially on the major highways. That certainly wasn't the case last year.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

September 23
Migration peaking my Kansas locale. Monarchs began flying early this morning and continued steady through the day. Many resting in my trees even in the early afternoon which is consistent with migration peaks in the past.(Normal peak my latitude is Sept. 23/24). I was able to tag 82 beginning about 3:30.

September 19
Monarch numbers remain steady here in Kansas. I have tagged 217 this week (9/16-22). The heaviest numbers I observed were on the 19th. I could count between 5-7 per mile along country roads. On the 20th and 21st, numbers slowed down, but were back up today (9/22).

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

In the Riverdale section of the Bronx, on the east side of the Hudson River, monarchs were flying along the river's edge in a SSW direction in high numbers for several hours this morning before it began raining... some of the time we counted 2-3 per minute, but frequently as many as 8 per minute between the hours of 9:30 - 11 a.m.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Just returned from a week on Mt. Desert Island, Maine. Monarchs in good numbers were seen migrating every day from Sept 15-21. On Sunday Sept 16, with a north wind, monarchs by the hundreds were dropping from the sky at the southern tip of the island at Bass Harbor Head Light (44 degrees 13.3' N, 68 degrees 20.3' W). They were nectaring in a small meadow on the hillside above the lighthouse. Prime nectar sources were seaside goldenrod, Rand's goldenrod, and 2 other unidentified goldenrod species, red clover, calico aster,and purple-stemmed aster. Each plant supported dozens of monarchs. Around 5PM monarchs perched on spruce trees to bask. I'm sure there was a roost that night somewhere in the spruces. On Sept 20, north of Mt. Desert Island at Petit Manan NWR, monarchs were seen migrating against a southwest wind, hugging the rocky coastline and stopping to nectar on asters and goldenrods growing in rock crevices. Winds were from the south for the remainder of the week, but monarchs continued with powered flight, pushing onward against the wind.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
I saw about 100 monarchs roosting in our neighbor's tree and lilac bush. Last year monarchs had roosted in trees in our pasture nearby.

While walking along the shoreline at Robert Moses State park, we saw 20 to 30 Monarchs per minute traveling northwest. Many flew in directly from the Atlantic Ocean. We continued to watch these monarchs throughout a two hour period and their numbers never diminished.
I've got a report of about 150 monarchs moving generally south in one hour in the morning of 9/21/07 at Lake Michigan shoreline at Warren Dunes State Park just south of Bridgman, MI zip 49106.

Saw 40+ Monarchs this morning with my daughter on our 40 minute walk, many on goldenrod blooms along the trails. Quite a few groups of 2 or 3 were lingering in flight together, seeming almost playful. A beautifully warm, sunny, breezy day. Absolutely wonderful!

Sunday afternoon on the Blue Ridge Parkway near Grandfather Mountain in North Carolina (Lat. 36.08 N ), the sky was blue, but dotted with orange and black. My friend, Aubrie, and I tagged 125 monarchs in four hours before we ran out of tags. Our friends, Carolyn and John were able to count 1033 monarchs during that time. John looked out from the ridge through his binoculars and could see lots more flying. So we know there were many monarchs passing by that were not counted. Around 5:30, while Aubrie and I were still tagging, John and Carolyn noticed that the monarchs were beginning to alter their behavior. Rather than moving on through, the butterflies began to circle back and remain in the area. When our tags were depleted (and most of our energy!) we sat on the grass and enjoyed watching dozens of monarchs nectaring on the goldenrod and asters six feet in front of us. As the light faded and the temperature dropped we watched intently, hoping to discover where the monarchs would roost for the night. The leeward side of a nearby oak tree seemed to be the favored spot. As the chill began to affect us as well, we decided to end our wonderful day on the Blue Ridge and head to our own roosting sites. What a glorious, fun day!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

In two hours, from 1:30 to 3:30pm, I observed 44 Monarchs.  They had to fly against a strong, intermitant south wind, but made it to my flowers anyway.  All of the butterflies I observed nectared for some time at the flowers.  A front is coming in late tonight, with temperatures to fall to the 60's tomorrow and possible rain.
Hundreds of monarch butterflies headed south across pickwick lake. We watched them all day. My daughter and I found your website while doing research on them. Thanks for a great site!

We spent a nice day around Mount Pisgah hoping to see the broad-winged hawk migration. Instead we had a great view of the monarch migration! At early-to-mid afternoon a few would move through a minute at the Glassy Rock Overlook, with very few lighting on the wildflowers. But during the 4:00 hour we estimated about 10 were moving through a minute, with a good deal of those landing. We managed to tag seven. It was beautiful to see them floating in the sky above the valley!

I have not seen the thousands that I saw last year but I did see several hundred. About sunset, several trees were covered with these beautiful butterflies. They look so much like tiny stained glass window panes when their wings are shut for the night.
Sighted about 1 or 2 per minute, sometimes more while sailing just off Ocean City NJ. Sometime 4 or 5 monarchs visible at once. All making good time in a southernly direction.

My Biology II class is working on entomology. We noticed 100+ monarchs on a insect collection trip on 9-21-07. All were actively feeding. This morning we only noticed one monarch feeding. We have not seen any signs of migration yet (9/25).

While swimming in the ocean at Ocean City, New Jersey I watched hundreds of butterflies flying overhead toward the mainland for approximately 30 minutes. They seemed like they were coming in from the ocean and flying in a southwest direction.
9/25/07 10:30-10:40 10 min. observation # of monarchs 7 per min. 0.7 per hour 42

I'd think that today could also be considered a Peak Monarch Migration sighting for this area. I counted 213 of the beauties just today. From 2-4:30 PM, I counted 208! They were heading south at a height ranging from 8-35 apx. They were riding the northerly breeze brought by the passing of a cold front which dropped temps by over 15 degrees during the day. I delighted in seeing one group of 4, one group of 3, and several groups of 2 during the peak time this afternoon. The remainder of them were flying solo. The temp. here was 64 F until it began warming up a bit after 4:30 PM. I'm glad I had the day off work to see this.
There were hundreds of monarchs on the Atlantic City NJ boardwalk Sunday. It was amazing. I came to your site to find out where they were going.
Nate kicked a soccer ball and it hit a tree.  Eight monarchs flew out of the tree.

1st wave of Monarchs waltzing across Kingfisher, Okla. Today, about 4:45 p.m. I counted about 65 Monarchs in 1 minute, high in the sky, heading SW, definitely on a mission. No stopping to nectar today, no slowing down to roost tonight. Front came thru. Temps in the upper 60's, cloudy, with a light NE wind. Woo! Hoo! Come on Monarchs! Be ready Texas!

Read about the migration in the local paper while visiting in Wildwood Crest.  While on Preston Ave I spotted 15-20 monarchs in about a 10 minute timespan.  Enroute home I continued to see clusters as far north as Dennisville, NJ.

I looked out of my patio door to my backyard and counted 17 beautiful monarchs at one time. Several were landing on my clothes line. This was about 1:30 p.m. There are a few now but nothing like earlier. 5:06 p.m.
this morning @9:30 my students notice the butterflies over our schoolyard in East Flatbush, Brooklyn

From Sat. Sept. 22 through Monday Sept. 24, we had those strong south winds and warm temperatures that kept the Monarchs from traveling. the numbers built steadily over those days. On Sat., there were several dozen. By Sunday evening, there were over 100 roosting in the trees.

Monday, during the day, the New England asters, zinnias, and cosmos were covered with them. Approximately 300 roosting that night. Over night, a cold front came through, bringing a breeze from the north. By 9:00 Tuesday morning, the butterflies were gone. This morning, I saw a lone Monarch nectaring at an aster.

September 27
Another report from relatives at Canton Lake in Oklahoma.Monarchs were streaming over the lake again today. They watched as many of the Monarchs dipped down and touched the water (taking a drink?) before flying back up again and continuing south. They will check again in the morning for roosts where I found them while visiting two years ago. I'm not sure they understand exactly where to look..... hopefully they will look all around in the trees at the edge of the lake.

September 26
My mother-in-law is fishing at Canton Lake, near Canton OK., about an hour northwest of Oklahoma City. She called today to let me know that they didn't pay much attention to fishing this morning because they were so busy watching the Monarchs crossing the lake. She couldn't believe what HUGE numbers were flying together. I didn't get an estimate from her. She will check tonight to see if they are roosting in the sight we found two years ago, in a group of trees near the waters edge. Stephanie- Posted on Monarch Watch D-plex.
We are witnessing a 10-15 minute interval of an increasingly steady stream of colorful monarchs along the Eastern Shore of Maryland. What a beautiful sight.

What another amazing day for the JS Monarchs in our area. I really wish I'd have been less busy on another day off work because the Monarchs were coming through here at a rate of 1.5 per minute at least. I counted 71 in a limited time of being free to look and enjoy. I alerted my teacher friend here in Ponca City, and he called me at recess (this morning) to report 20 spotted in a mere 15 minutes! I was telling my barber-lady about the Monarchs, and she said, "I haven't seen any this year". Wow, before I got out of her chair, she spotted 3 of them thanks to me pointing them out to her...some folks are oblivious unless taught how to actually SEE something. That amazes me almost as much as the numbers passing through here right now. Today's high temp was about 80 degrees F with light and variable winds most of the day.

Yesterday (9/25) and today thousands of monarchs were streaming over the Refuge (Flint Hills and Marais des Cygnes NWR)!!!At times, I could look anywhere with my binoculars, horizon to horizon, and see a half dozen in the field of view!!!!

Along with the monarchs were hundreds of pelicans, and scores of raptors.A huge migration day for all species.In the weeks leading up to migration, the monarchs used our wetlands heavily, particularly the Bidens.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Today, Sept 26 at 12 noon in Ada, OK., I saw 2 monarchs heading south at a good clip. The second one was about 1 minute behind the first. About 40 minutes later I saw a third one also heading south.Jim

Still continued to see a nice steady flow of Monarchs coming thru Kingfisher on Wednesday, Sept. 26th.  The band was not as wide, or as heavy as Tues.  They were flying lower to the ground.Today, Sept. 27th, I am seeing less numbers, more singles and doubles.  And they were more sporadic.  Tomorrow, strong southerly winds will begin to pick up for a few days before the next front.  Reported to Monarch Watch.

A beautiful clear and calm day, temperature in the 70's.  For one hour from 12:30 to 1:30 p.m., I counted 30 butterflies.  Almost all of the butterflies were drifting low over the yards and came to nectar on the flowers.From 1:30 to 2:30, I counted 47 Monarchs, with 26 of these coming in an arial burst in less than 10 minutes at 2:00 p.m.  I wonder if this was a group that had roosted together somewhere.  They were all flying at the same level, high over the trees (about 75 feet) and spread out within an area of sky of about 300 feet wide.  They sailed by on a light northery breeze.After that arial display, the remaining Monarchs observed were those that came drifting into the yard to nectar.

I spent an afternoon searching for Monarch Butterflies at the Raven Run Nature Sanctuary outside of Lexington, Kentucky.  I found the insects to be plentiful especially around the Goldenrod plants.  Next time, I will take some sort of numerical clicking device so that I can accurately give an actual count observed.  In addition, I continuously observe Monarchs heading South throughout the month of September.

This may be my last report to this category of PEAK Monarch Migration. Today was a lovely day with little wind and a high temp of about 82 F. The day started out rather slow with the Monarchs not wanting to fly through the dense fog we had this morning. I walked several miles to a Dr. and didn't spot any until about 9:40 AM. (10 from 9:40-10:05 AM) I watched periodically through the day and saw another 82 before dark. So, the per minute rate overall today has dropped somewhat from the past two days-today's was .75 apx. per minute. What a wonderful southern migration it's been around here this year! I spoke to a total stranger this morning and asked him if he'd been enjoying any Monarchs. He surprised me by saying "Yes, I saw hundreds of them in Tonkawa yesterday.(9/26)" Tonkawa is a small town apx. 15 miles to the west of my location.

Sept 26 & 27, Damascus, MD 20882:

There has been a constant flight of monarchs through our region the last2 days. Winds have been calm or light from the south. Monarchs are flying low (between 10-30') and seem unhurried (lots of floating and circling going on). Each afternoon, there were dozens of new monarchs stopping in my yard for nectar. The most popular flowers were Mexican flame vine, Mexican sunflower, yellow sneezeweed (Helenium autumnale), Maximillian sunflower (Helianthus maximilliani), and New England aster.

Heading to Assateague Island, VA tomorrow. Hoping to catch a wave of monarchs after the cold front goes through.

Over the past couple of weeks I have sighted just a smattering of Monarch. But the wind turned strongly out of the north here on Monday night and on Tuesday I spent the whole day wandering about the ranch and saw literally hundreds of Monarchs, all traveling with a purpose on that strong northerly breeze.

Late Tuesday, the wind laid and Monarchs by the dozens gathered in the oaks, mulberry and shrubbery here at the ranchheadquarters for the night. It was quite a sight. The temperature dipped to about 55 degrees up here last night (9/26/07).

Today had the strongest sightings of the year to date.  Total count of Monarchs in flight today was "85"!!!!!!!!!!  The day was in the 70F plus full of sunshine and gentle breeze....perfect for our little Monarch friends.  My sightings began at 10:30AM CST and continued throughout the day until 5PM.  The strongest sighting were from 10:30 to 1:30...it was actually hard to keep up with the count BUT exciteing.  In addition to the total count there were 3 dead Monarchs on the Hwy.54 in Osage Beach (in our immediate area).
We saw over 10 monarchs in a 2 minute period flying near a farm field and road. It was about 80 degrees and calm winds.

It's a clear, sunny day in the Ozarks. Several monarchs within a 10 minute period flew over the bank where I work at St. Robert, Missouri today. Also, this morning on my way to work outside of my house a little ways out of town of Waynesville, Missouri at least ten flew over my house in a period of about five minutes. Years past when I have sat outside my house outside of Waynesville, Missouri it is just like they are coming in a line across a field and then fly over out house. Whether in groups of three of by themselves.

We have had large numbers (5-40 at any one time with hundreds passing through each day) of monarchs at Monarch Waystation #1 from Tues morning the 25th until late this afternoon. The largest numbers exhibiting directional flight were seen on Th morning (27th).

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
1000's of Monarchs. The sky is filled with Monarchs. The tree branches are lined with Monarchs. They started coming into our yard on 9/29/07 and are still here on 9/30/07.

We have never seen a roosting site. This evening my husband came inside and told me to get the camera. We had 85 (yes we counted them) monarchs roosting in a hedge apple tree at the back of our yard. We were amazed at the beautiful sight.

It was a beautiful fall afternoon, about 70 degrees with the wind from the east. My husband was sailing, and I was sitting on our dock at Wolf Lake. He came by to tell me that he was seeing many monarchs, all following the same path. I used the binoculars, and it was unbelievable. We saw 160 monarchs, flying in a southwesterly direction, more or less in single file, in just one hour!!!!!!!!!!
Noticed lots, probably a hundred in an hour, of Monarchs moving across the school property yesterday (9/28). All of them moving in the same direction, south.

Hundreds of monarchs flying south southeast over northwest Oklahoma City, altitude around 100 feet. Wind currently 8-10 MPH at 6:15 PM. There is a cold front moving through, aligned from southwest to northeast. A "dryline" is also moving through now, and winds are shifting from southwest to northwest.
2 Observors.We counted 15 monarchs heading south, over a 3 hour period. 11AM to 2 PM

Today was the best day for Monarchs at Point Lepreau that I have seen during the two years I've been tagging them, and likely as good as any day since we built the observatory in 1995. I was able to catch the seven Monarchs I needed for tagging in about six and a half minutes. Afterward I did a 15-minute walk around the east and west sides of the Point and counted 52 more nectaring Monarchs. During the same period Jean kept watch at the observatory and counted 20 others that were migrating past without stopping.So there was a good flow of butterflies there today, probably upward of 100 actually present at the time, and turning over constantly (all seven tagged individuals flew west immediately). If we had had more tags, we could have had quite a productive day, but our Monarch tagging for summer 2007 is now completed.

Contributed by Don Davis

Spectacular migration day!

9 AM to 10 AM
Wind NW 10 - 15 MPH
Approximately 2,280 Monarchs per hour flying southwest along ocean shoreMost were flying low < 10 feet off the ground and fighting the wind to avoid being blown out over the ocean. At over wash areas - where there is no dune or vegetation to provide any protection from the wind - about one out of three were being swept out over the ocean. Some were able to make it back to shore with great effort.

10AM to Noon
Wind N 10 MPH
Monarchs soaring very high (with migrating hawks and eagles) and not visible with naked eye. When scanning with binoculars you could see 30 to 50 monarchs within a binocular view.

5PM to 6PM - at Tom's Hook, the southern most tip of Assateague Island.

1000s of monarchs roosting in groundsel-trees

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I just received an ecstatic phone call from my in-laws who are at Canton Lake in Oklahoma.

They said it had been quiet with no Monarch sightings Friday, Saturday and Sunday morning but now..... at 2:15 pm Sunday afternoon, an explosion of Monarchs are flying over the lake.

A cool front has come through and with it, more Monarchs than they've seen so far.A steady stream flying directly over the lake, hundreds at a time, coming through in waves. I so wish I was there!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I had a great experience yesterday (9/30) which I would like to pass on to you. A local farmer called me approximately at noon and indicated that he had seen a huge amount of monarchs adjacent to a field in the Neosho river bottom. I went to the location with the presumption that I might see a few hundred or even a few thousand monarchs. The population was much greater. Obviously, I cannot give you an accurate amount or even a valid estimate. I do know that it was very large. The monarchs were located in a woods adjacent to a field of sunflowers that I would say was at least 400 acres. The sunflowers were in full bloom. The wood circles the entire field. In addition, there is a levee which is approximately 15 feet tall.

Sunday, we had a strong southerly breeze that was probably 20 to 30 miles per hour with stronger gusts. I don't know if the monarchs had congregated because of the nectar source, the strong southerly winds, and the protection provided by the woods and levees, or for some other reason. Regardless, it was one of those once in a lifetime experiences. Many were clinging to the leaves of the trees and many more were flying in the wood and the open fields to the North of the levee and tree line. As indicated, it would be impossible to estimate the total. As you probably now I have been to Sierra Chincua and Rosario. While these butterflies were not that dense, there certainly was a large concentration. I know at least in the tens of thousands. I followed the tree line around the sunflower field for approximately ½ mile in both directions and the concentration seemed to be uniformed the whole 1 mile distance. Many of the trees had a dense concentration of butterflies. The butterflies were not hanging from each other in a curtain effect but they were dense. The trees located right on the levees did not exceed15 to 20 feet in height.

While my amateur observation may be incorrect the butterflies appeared to me to be in fairly good shape overall. They appeared to have fairly plump bodies, fairly large wing spans, and overall there wings appeared to be in fairly good shape. Quite frankly, I was a little worried at least about the monarch local population. I did not have nearly as many caterpillars this year in my Waystation stations as last year. I was hopeful that this was due to the fact that we have had lots of rain and lots of wildflowers so they were not concentrating on flower gardens as much. Regardless of that issue, I certainly saw a huge amount of monarchs yesterday. I don't know how long they have been there or how long they will be staying. It rained last night, a front is going through, and the wind may change. I am going to check the location tonight to see if they are still there.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Another BIG wave of Monarchs came through here today. They started early as well; the first one I saw was at 8:10 AM. I was at work most of the day, but I still saw 28 while on a couple of breaks outside. The total I could see today was 255 in 2 1/2 hours total. We spotted many solitary fliers, but also groups of 2, 3, 4, and three groups of 5!! I really thought we'd seen the majority come through here last week. I'm happy that proved to be so wrong. I got a call this morning from a good friend (while I was at work) who said they had counted just over a thousand during their drive. They were 5-7 miles south of Ponca City driving around on country roads. The weather here was fantastic today with very light winds this AM slowly increasing this afternoon from various directions, but predominately from the south on towards evening. High temp today I think was around 83 F.

Raptor movements were quite impressive.  The skies were also filled with Monarchs with hundreds moving ahead on the winds a big cold front brought in at the Selman Ranch near Woodward-NW OKla.PaulFrom OkBirds listserve
We saw 39 Monarchs in Cherry Cove Gap. We got there at 4:15 p.m. and stayed there for around 40 minutes.

Observed 300-400 monarchs flying southeasterly direction at approximately 7:45 am--at first I thought they were tiny birds but as I got nearer I realized it was a "cloud" of monarch butterflies! First time I have ever noticed something like this! BEAUTIFUL SIGHT!!

We observed numerous monarchs soaring overhead for about 15 minutes heading west as the sun set. There were probably 10-15 monarchs visible a minute. We observed them from the roof deck at Ram Point Marina.
Thousands of monarchs. I thought I was in the Butterfly Pavillion. They were beautiful.

The wind was perfect for holding the Monarchs at Cape May Point for a day or so. There were thousands of them waiting for a favorable wind to take them over Delaware Bay. Also, there was a swarm of Dragonflies intermixed with the monarchs - thousands of them, too.

Sunday, Sept 30, 2007. Wind NE then NNE then ENE.
Many (hundreds) of the monarchs that were blown out to sea on strong NW winds on Friday and Saturday were seen returning back to shore this morning. In a fixed position with spotting scope and binoculars, I counted one monarch returning to shore every 2.5 minutes. Later in the day, many monarchs were seen nectaring in the fields of Bidens laevis (large bur-marigold) just behind the primary dune. Their wings were tattered and torn and their abdomens were lean. Between 4-6pm, I walked 4 miles of shoreline at low tide looking for dead monarchs in the sand. I found only one. It's wings were ripped in several places. Local watermen told me monarchs had been landing to rest on their boats on 9/29 during the afternoon hours.

Monday, Oct 1, Wind ENE then E.
Hundreds of monarchs remain nectaring in the Bidens fields even though the wind is ideal to carry them off this island and back on course down the Delmarva Peninsula or the mainland. Some monarchs were netted for examination and tagging. Only a few had fat abdomens; most were still lean. I expect them to stay to nectar until they have built up some fat reserves.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Counted 210 Monarch's in 1 hour on the Blue Ridge Parkway near Asheville, NC. Once over the tree line from the north, they floated lazily down the valley traveling south toward South Carolina. A few stopped to nectar on Milkweek and Golden Rod.

Also, saw 5 Monarch's traveling southwest through Asheville, NC on Sept.28th.

Hundreds of Monarchs moved across central Okla. today.  A perfect day for moving, as at 9 a.m. This morning temp was 64 degrees, winds were from the ENE at 9 mph.  They were flying lower initially,  then would circle around, catch the wind current, and fly as high as my naked eyes could see.  Even with binocs, they were like lil dots that dissappeared into the sky.  I saw at least 10 per minute from about 9 a.m. to 12 noon.  The numbers dropped off after that.  Some flew lower, and stopped to nectar in the yard for a while, and were gone.  But, there was still a steady trickle of them coming until 6:00 p.m. The winds from the south pick up for the next 3 days.  The next front is Sunday.

This morning when the temp reached 58 degrees, I started seeing the beauties flying through here. They started out low to the ground. Most were <10 feet in height. I even had one particularly friendly one land on my knee. When the temp reached 60 F and sunny, most of them began to get higher in altitude. This morning netted 207 in 90 minutes, giving us a per minute rate of 2.3 Mpm(Monarchs per minute). (My figures are always rounded.) This afternoon I counted another 100 in 80 minutes, so the PM rate was apx 1.8 Mpm. Total today was 309 in 170 min, equalling a per min rate of 1.82 per minute. Temp today was perfect with a high in the very low 80's with a light and variable wind.

I got a call this morning from a good friend who said they counted just over a thousand monarchs in just 30 minutes. They were 5-7 miles south of Ponca City driving around on country roads. If those figures are really accurate, that's a rate of 33.3 per minute. They were driving in the wide open spaces. The butterflies were low to the ground, mid-level, and many were quite elevated as well!

I have a quick clarification on the above report. My friend told me that he spotted, counted, and semi-estimated the number of Monarchs they saw on their drive south of our town was about 1000 in a short time of 30 minutes. If those figures are really accurate, that's a rate of 33.3 per minute. I've never had that good of luck. One thing to remember is that they were in the wide open spaces. He related that they were low to the ground, mid-level, and many were quite elevated as well!
Viewed approximately 10,000+ (guesstimate) Monarch Butterflies with about 3 other species among them. Seen on top of Gaither Mountain in Boone Co., Arkansas. Took numerous photos.

I saw 31 in a period of 5 minutes or so.  The temp was 75 degrees.  They were all headed to the south east.  Most wereflying just over our 5 story building but a few were quiet high.

This afternoon I went home for my lunch break and happened to look up. Lo and behold, the monarchs are in full migration. I would estimate at least 100-150 every 2 or 3 minutes were going over and those were the ones I was able to see. Many were very high up and looked like dots where they would circle and play with one another. Others had that end point only on their minds and were flying fast and straight. All were flying from NE to SW. We used to see many fly over our place but it has been a long time since I have seen anything like this. Made me very glad. Something is working.

Monarchs were busy nectaring on seaside goldenrod at Eastern Point on the coast.  I tagged 60 in an hour without a net!  Population is good, but not as high as last year.

I've been waiting for the migration of butterflies and today I saw about 85-100 as they landed on mainly willow trees for the night. This has been happening for several years now at this location. I hope they keep returning.
Mrs. Lawrence's Sixth Grade Class counted 38 migrating monarchs during thirty minutes.
Butterfly bushes today have been full of Monarch Butterflies. Counted at least 12 in one bush and then another half dozen in another bush.
Have had a constant stream come though the backyard   They then settle down for the night in a neighbor's vine covered tree.  Throughout the day they seem to chase each other around the yards
There are thousands of monarchs at my home in the trees. The come through every fall and spring but never as many as this year.

I was just outside at my office, staring up. It was 1:35 & temp is 84 degrees. Within 15 minutes 21 monarchs went by all in a south southwest direction. All were at least 10-40 feet off the ground. On beach in Atlantic City. From approx 2p-5p hundreds if not thousands of Monarchs came from Ocean flying inland.

The monarchs are being carried by a strong north wind.  It is cloudy, humid, and cool here.  From my driveway, I counted over 40 in the span of a minute.  They are being carried forwards, backwards, and sideways, some just barely visible without binoculars.  Above them the clouds are moving north, so they are staying in the south moving winds below.

At Monarch Waystation #182, 6 miles east of the Blue Ridge crest, today, October 7, was a major day of change. Since Tuesday, Oct 2, we've had from 6 to 14 monarchs in view at once in a large Tithonia planting between 6 PM and dusk each evening. This evening there are none despite very warm temps and nearly calm winds.

This morning, activity was as it's been around the Tithonia with as many as 8 monarchs nectaring. At about 9:30 AM, under rapidly warming conditions and a slight wind from the southeast, we walked through pasture and meadow nearby. We at first could see small numbers of monarchs coming off roosting trees and beginning to move ssw 50-100 ft from the ground. Within about 20 minutes, we began to see monarchs passing above us at the rate of 10-15 per minute. Some of those lower in the air column were coming to ground level to feed at bluemist flower, Conoclinium coelestinum. Others, by 10:20 AM, and with a rapidly changing wind pattern that swung around to WNW and picked up to 15-20 mph, were up riding thermals with black and turkey vultures at 500-perhaps 2000 ft. Over the next 30 mins, we continued to see many migrating monarchs and with perhaps every 100 monarchs, 1-2 buckeyes, flying in the same direction but with a really different flap pattern. We got back home from our walk at 11:30 AM and had 4-5 monarchs at the Tithonia until perhaps 2 PM. The winds had died down, the temps neared 90 degrees and we haven't seen a monarch since.

It is likely that thousands of monarchs passed through our neighborhood this AM; this was certainly the biggest push we've witnessed since Sept 12, 2001.

Despite the monarchs departure, the abnormal warm and abundance of remaining flowering plants kept hundreds of other butterflies, numerous bee species, moths, flies and wasps well-fed. Oct 12 is my traditional frost date here. It may reach 65 for a low tonight.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

For the last couple weeks [middle of Sept.]at our woods near Ossian, Indiana we've had a Monarch Butterfly convention. I know they migrate in groups in coastal California and Mexico, but Ossian? What's going on? Any reports of this before around here?

Several hundred monarchs migrating south-southwest in the evening sky. Some taking up roost behind our house in the trees. Cold front moved through this morning ushering in nice cool fall air. Wonderful sight!

Monarch Waystation 599 in Jackson, NJ, Today we saw the largest number of monarchs we have seen here this season.There was a constant stream of monarchs (anywhere from 10-20) throughout the day within my visibility.  There were probably significantly more on our 2 acres. All that I saw were in great shape, happily nectaring on various late bloomers.

I was amazed to find hundreds, possibly thousands, of beautiful Monarch butterflies in my back yard! They look like dead leaves on the trees at first glance, but when they fly, it is just awesome! I first noticed them on 10/04/07. As of 10/08/07, they are still there.
we have been seeing handfuls at a time along the coast in the flowering shrubs for the past couple of weeks. Now we are counting about 40/half hour on warm, breezy days.

I went out by boat to Lovells Island in Boston Harbor last Sunday (9/30) and saw hundreds of Monarchs sipping on Seaside Goldenrod. They were simply everywhere. Several hundred were feeding in salt cedar at Lake Wichita Park--33 50' 32.22N, 98 33' 11.15W--while flights off 200 or more were reported moving through other parts of town.

From about 6:00 p.m. to 7:15 p.m. yesterday (10/8/07) evening we observed at least 200 to 300 hundred Monarchs flying into our yard and roosting in our Sycamore and Oak tree. There were definitely more in the sycamore tree. It is now 9:00 a.m. on Tuesday the 9th and so far they are still all there.

An additional comment on the butterflies. They were trailing strands of what looked like spiderweb. Does anyone know what that is and/or why the butterflies are doing that?

Editor's Note: Evidently this was spider silk that was trailing behind the monarchs. The silk was from tiny, young spiders that were dispersing by "ballooning." Like the young spiders in Charlotte's Web, they were carried away by the wind on silk threads.

"The offspring come out of the egg sack, go to the highest point and raise their abdomen up in the air and release a threat of silk," spider expert David Moellendorf told Austin's KXAN News radio. As the silk gets longer, the wind currents pick up the spiders and carry them away. In this way they disperse to new habitat, just as seeds blow in the wind to a new place to grow.

I saw at least 14 Monarch nectaring on a large planting of Lantana camara today, maybe coming in with the cooler air.  This is more that I've seen so far this season!  We've had 2 or 3 regularly over the last few weeks, but not so many at all at once.

The monarchs have finally reached southwest Arkansas in large numbers.  We counted over 260 in about 40 minutes along a small county road.  It was about 6:00 P.M.  Some were nectaring on goldenrod but most were flying around pecan trees looking for a place to spend the night.
Just driving on the main road for two hours we counted 272 monarchs flying.
Today I observed 35 Monarchs in approximately 15 minutes. All were flying.

I was outside for only about forty five minutes today (10/10/07) and saw around 50 monarchs. I first noticed them this season about a week ago. I just saw a few then, but the past couple of days, they are really increasing in number.

I was doing some yard work on a beautiful day this past Monday and the Monarchs started to float by. I stopped counting after a hundred. The number has decreased over the years. I remember as a child what seemed like thousands of them one fall day playing on the beach.

We are seeing 1000's of Monarchs @ Comanche Springs Astronomy Campus. Would this be a good time to tag 'em? We have created a "Butterfly Garden" with more than 100 shrubs and perennials...
