In my yard, I have several large pecan trees that are full of monarchs. I would estimate that there are thousands of them. We love these beautiful creatures and are glad that we are one of their migratory stops.
Thousands of Monarchs resting at same location as in 2006.
several hundred roosting in oak trees in front yard. Observed about 11 am

Yesterday (10/10) the monarchs were flying over sporadically. This evening from about 5:50 to 6:30 they were flying over in a steady stream. Some looked like birds coming at first because of their size. Some were very high in the sky while others were lower down even coming to feed at the flowers in my yard. I enjoy watching all butterflies, but look forward to the fall migration of the monarchs each fall. I plant flowers and plants to attract butterflies into my yard.
We saw an average of 75 -100 per hour crossing a 1 acre area.

They were amazing. I stood on my front porch and counted 73 between 10am and 10:30am. They just seemed to drop out of the sky. They were flying high on this beautiful day, about 78 degrees, clear blue sky, and a gentle breeze to the south. They are amazing little creatures. I teach Kindergarten and we are out on Fall Intersession. I can't wait to tell my students. I hope they saw them too.
Our 4th grade Monarch butterfly migration watch recorded a total of 110 butterflies sighted between 11:00 to 11:30 a.m. and 1:30 to 2:35 p.m. Thanks to Mrs.Miller's class and Mrs. Baca's classes.
While driving west on hiway to Ft. Griffin State Park, saw close to 100 monarchs flying south over a period of about 1 hour in mid afternoon. Count accuracy was sacrificed to drive safely!
Hundreds of butterflies flying and feeding in the goldenrod along the beaches.
school: Centers for nature education at baltimore woods

comments:
YES!! Our trees are full of them. Last night (10/10)at dusk we sat on our front porch and watched a limb that looked like it was full of leaves suddenly take flight. It was really awesome.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I stopped counting at over 200 Monarchs on Long Beach Island as I drove from Ship Bottom south towards the southernmost tip of Long Beach Island   They are everywhere! (Note: This distance is about 8 miles and about a 15 minute drive.)

Drove down to Cape May from Jackson, NJ this morning. Saw many monarchs moving South and many more seemed to be moving SW.In Cape may, the monarchs were abundant; counted 48 in 10 mintues landing in my rear garden. Checked out the roosts at sunset; I found several fairly large roosts throughout the point. I'm not good on number estimates but would say 200-300 at several sites and many smaller clusters widely dispersed.
I have seen more than 200 Monarchs on Long Beach Island, NJ today. They are everywhere!!

Monarchs are coming through this evening at a rate of over 25/min—almost too many for the 4 of us to count.  They are very large and FAT... There are so many and they are so fat that they look like a bird migration... It was incredible! They are flying in a North to South path at a rapid pace.  They are not stopping or slowing down. I observed from 6 pm CST to 7 pm CST and they never slowed down or thinned out.

August 30th there was six monarchs flying through my backyard that I noticed, compared to an average of three of other days near it.  Day was lovely and warm.  I did not go out of my way to try to notice them, I just saw them on trips past the window in my home.

We observed aproximatly 30-40 Monarchs flying west over the water towards land midday. We observed  the Monarchs over a period of 30 minutes. Wind was light; clear and sunny: temperature was 80 degrees F. Tide was near low. Did not see any dead Monarchs or observe any predator interruption.

There were Monarchs both Saturday and Sunday. We arrived Saturday about 2:00 pm and left Sunday at 12:30 pm.  Sunday morning about 11:30 am was the greatest number.  It was terrific! I would say we were seeing about 6 to 8 per minute. The wind was blowing from the north but not too strong.  On Saturday afternoon, there was a stronger wind coming from the west. Saturday afternoon about 4:00 pm I walked along the dunes which have a lot of golden rod - there were many butterflies in the flowers.  I can safely say I saw more than 200 during the two days. The butterflies were even coming at the car as I drove north to the grocery store!

Saw 112 Monarchs in about an hour. Weather in Justin is very overcast with only occasional patches of blue sky and sun, with temperatures in the high 60s during the time of sightings. Most Monarchs were flying within 20-25 feet of the ground moving in a mostly straight direction. Saw a number of them near my house flying high and circling my yard. I'm hoping that they visit my butterfly garden. There is plenty of milkweed and other flowers blooming.

As I was sitting at a stop light in the middle of town, I noticed a butterfly bush next to the road and it was covered with monarchs.  I would estimate 25 butterflies on the bush.  It was a wonderful sight!
Saw a monarch, so decided to take 5 minutes to count - saw 6 - all going south no more than 25 feet above ground. This was about 11:30 am. Seemed to be as consistent for 3-4 hours.

We counted about 10 monarchs which reminded me that it is about the time of year to start seeing them.

We spent aprox 5 min counting (Shannon is 3). The time was about 3pm central time wind maybe 12mph and they were flying in a definite westerly path. We live right on the coast. I did read that once they reach the coast that they follow the coast line. I had always wondered how it was that they made it to Mexico and thought there was no way they could fly over the gulf.

We live near Pensacola and there is one section along the coast in Gulf Breeze (town outside of Pensacola) that has a 5 mile bridge. At this point if you were to stay in Gulf Breeze you could not go any farther west. You would have to take this bridge to go through Pensacola and on into Mobile. It was amazing last year to see all the butterflies actually crossing by bridge. They literally follow the coast line. Trying to count them was impossible. It was easily in the hundreds.

In the last 2 hours I've seen probably 200 monarchs. No group larger than 5, all flying within 8-10 feet of the ground flying south - southwest. Just a long steady stream of individual butterflies. Quite a few stopped for just a few minutes in the tree line out of the wind. I'll be checking this evening for a roost.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
25 monarchs were seen by students and teachers flying over the school playground.  This is the highest count we had in one day.
We tagged 50 monarchs in a pecan orchard 35 miles southeast of Midland. I estimated 15,000 total.

Started seeing some Monarchs on Friday(10/12/07)and they were here all weekend in the hundreds. Today, they are coming in by the thousands - trees are full of roosting butterflies. As in past years, they seem to prefer the Fruitless Mulberrys, maybe because they are fullest and dark, or perhaps because they are out of the wind. If the butterflies keep coming like they have been all day, this will be one of the best years ever.

On the Blue Ridge Parkway, I counted 76 monarch butterflies in 45 minutes. Time of day was approx. 4pm. The monarch's route takes them up Hwy 151 (Pisgah Hwy)across a steep mountain range, approx. 4600-4900 ft. elevation, near Mt. Pisgah 5000 ft elevation. The night time temp this time of the year, falls to about 30-40 degrees. This was the 2nd time in 2 weeks that I've traveled to the Parkway to see the Monarch's, I was pleasantly surprised on both occasions, I saw plenty of butterflies. Once the butterfly's come up over the tree tops from the north, they gently glide south, down the other side of the the mountain into South Carolina.

I did notice something unusual when I was observing on 10.14.07, I noticed this reaction on about 5 butterflies, they were flying and all of a sudden it almost appeared that they hit something, of course it was only air, they appeared to be knocked back, but then they adjusted their route and continued on....I had never seen this before. Do you have any idea about this unusual behavior?

Today, Wednesday, the sky is filled with a major Monarch migration that covers the area from Camp Wood, Uvalde, Barksdale, and probably Rock Springs. They are coming out of the East and are headed South & South West.

They will spend the night in the Pecan trees along the Nueces River because that is what they always do, though how they know to go there is as mysterious as how they know to go to Mexico.

These Monarchs are larger than the ones that I wrote you about that had been coming since the middle of September.The weatherman Steve on San Antonio 12 says a front will come through on Sunday night bringing thunderstorms and cool weather in the 50's. I hope the Monarchs beat the front.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Sampson Elemenaty has noticed a steady increase of Monarchs over the past two weeks. Three weeks ago we counted five Monarchs in the garden early in the morning. Last week it went up to eight. This morning (10/18/07) at 8:30am there were at least 10-12 Monarchs, a very noticeable increase in our normal population of 2-3 at any one time.

The activity on the 17th was phenomenal. They were streaming in all day and finding places to roost in our big trees. Us humans stayed away from them and didn't disturb them, but my dogs ran under the low-hanging branches a couple of times chasing squirrels, and the butterflies just 'boiled' out of the branches, only to return a few minutes after the dogs had passed. Then yesterday - snap! - there was not a Monarch to be seen. But, it was a good year for them here at this ranch.We were blessed.

October 18
They're gone!! Following peak activity on October 16 and 17, they were completely gone by noon on October 18.

While on vacation in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, I saw hundreds of butterflies on the golf course, floating in a southerly direction.  I assumed they were monarchs.  However, they seemed smaller and slightly different in color (deeper orange). Is there a different variety of Monarch in the Eastern Flyway?
in a 5 mile straight south on commerce street we saw approximately 100 monarchs about 12:30 pm the numbers seem to be increasing this week
began seeing flyover monarchs everywhere 15 - 30 per minute

Time: Mid thur late Afternoon, 10/19/07, Denton County Weather: Clear skies, 75 degrees Front passed thru area earlier this week DENTON County RATES: Aubrey, TX--> Observed 1 monarch every 25 seconds Denton, TX--> Observed 1 monarch every 7 seconds Calhoun Middle School, Denton, TX--> 3:30-4:30 PM Observed 50+ Monarchs (as well as Queens) nectaring and migrating thru schoolyard habitat All afternoon in Denton and Denton County, monarchs were everywhere...not only nectaring low of flowers, and flying at eye level, but they also filled the higher altitudes in the sky Today (Friday) may be the peak in the migration for N TX, but maybe #s will inc thru the weekend! JN

At around 4:10 p.m. today on the way home from work (I teach in Garland and live in Rowlett), I spotted 73 little miracles (monarch butterflies) flying in a southerly direction over the course of about 15 minutes. What a treat! :)
Today at 10:30 - 10:45 my third period class observed 53 Monarchs flying east to west. The temp. was 73 and there was a light breeze. Lots of fun watching them.
Hundreds of Monarch butterflies from the Beach flying south.

I watched for 1/2 hour (from 1pm to 1:30PM) at Bayfront Park in Alabama Port at the Gulf Coast. Butterflies were flying by, all the time, constantly. I counted 56 monarch Butterflies per minute flying south. Many stopped to feed on Golden Rod and other flowers. The weather was sunny and the wind helped to push the butterflies forward.

There are several hundred Monarchs that have been roosting in the trees in my backyard for about 3 days now (10/19 - 21). The numbers are increasing daily. I suspect they are waiting for the approaching cold front and the push of the north winds to aid in their journey. There were other species with the Monarchs initially, but they have moved on. I have shown the Monarchs to everyone that I can get to come over, as this is something that I have only seen once before in my life of 49yrs. Can't get anything done around here until they leave. Too beautiful to miss. I have always been interested in Monarchs since I was a young boy and witnessed a huge layover of Monarchs in North Texas. Trees and bushes covered in thousands of Monarchs on a crisp fall morning left an idelible impression on me.
Thousands in the canopy of my pecan and oak trees. Moved on by Friday (10/19). Magnificent!

Observed constant stream of monarchs, with highest #s mid-am and most in late afternoon. All day, the monarchs were against a pretty significant and at times gusty southern wind. Weather was mild, clear, sunny. JN

This past Saturday (10/13) and Tuesday (10/16) we had a record day for Monarchs. In a little over 2 hours, volunteers tagged 44 Monarchs on Saturday. Tuesday was even more spectacular, with 86 Monarchs tagged! That brings this year’s total number of Monarchs tagged in Cades Cove to 184. In addition, we have captured and identified over 20 other different species of butterflies, including the Dainty Sulphur, a new park record.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

My class and I were outside for dismissal on Friday, October 19, 2007, and noticed butterflies floating and flying overhead. Since we study monarch and viceroy butterflies in our A Beka Science curriculum, I brought my students' attention to the butterflies.  Several times within a minute an orange butterfly or two would float by overhead and they were all headed south.  I began to get suspicious that they were migrating which lead me to your site to make sure I could have possibly seen a butterfly and to make certain I saw a Monarch and not a viceroy.  I was able to get a close enough look at one to be absolutely certain it was a monarch. The others, I can not positively identify.

I was sitting in the line at the local bank at 4:02 pm CDT looking out west, and across the large lawn of the bank property, low and behold, I counted 10 Monarchs a minute for 5 minutes, all flying into the late afternoon early autumn setting sun.  I watched this mini major flyover for Laurel, MS, for 5 minutes before having to leave the drive-thru lane.  I saw a few more as I headed to the east side of town, right thru the oldest residential neighborhood. I have seen about 5 out here at the farm since around 3:15 p.m., all checking outour large red oak trees still in good camo colors for Monarchs.  They traditionally fly up there this time every year to roost for the night. We have tons of Gulf frittilaries, but, they were all hanging around the lantanas, both here and at the bank. I'll keep you posted for if I see more.

Today was fabulous! Started off with 200 monarchs in the trees down the road, proceeded with 60 or so monarchs per minute on the Cunningham Ranch; and during the canoe trip of 15 miles, there was a continuous stream across the river. Probably saw between 500 and 700 to be conservative. Our canoes and the monarchs were fighting a stiff SE wind gusting up to 35mph. Heaviest flow around 8:45 at the trees around the ranch house. 30 in view at any one time. There were easily another 500-600 at the Salvadore Gonzalez country home under massive native trees. This is the spot I call "The Cathedral." Monarchs drifting wall to wall in the 100s as they settle into clusters. It will be interesting to see what the monarchs do tomorrow if and when the front comes through. It could blow them all out of here. I hope there are more riding the wind in.

I live at Robson Ranch, Southwest of Denton, TX and have to write and tell you of the most beautiful sight we had thru our backyard here at Robson Ranch on Friday afternoon between 3-6pm! The Monarchs came thru and paused awhile on my butterfly bush (at times there must have been 50 or more) in full force. Then when you thought the show was over another wave came thru. I called and invited neighbors in to see the beautiful sight with us. This morning when we looked out (Saturday) there were a few more stopping by and kept this up till mid afternoon. Thought you would like to know about them coming thru!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

We went to Trinity Park just now and there are monarchs everywhere - we caught and tagged 18 in less than 30 minutes. If you go along the bushes along University and in front and to the right of the Botanical Gardens they are hanging there. Also, by the big climbing structure there is a dirt road and they are all along that trail

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Monarch visited my hanging geranium off my deck. I was thrilled, as I haven't seen a Monarch in years. It stayed in the plant for about 7 minutes and I was able to get a wonderful photo of it.

Chasing monarchs in anticipation of catching the migration’s leading edge, Carol Cullar, director of the Rio Bravo Nature Center, traveled about Maverick County near Eagle Pass, Texas. “These winds this year are acting like a spigot turned off and on. Rather than a daily flow, we're getting dribs and drabs. Past years have consisted of long, continuous streamers of monarchs persisting for days from the same direction, down the same corridor. This could be the briefest monarch passage we've had in years.”

The following is a collection of daily observations. See what you can learn about monarch migration in Texas through Carol Cullar's eyes. Also, find out what she learned this year!

October 15th through 19
Carol watched, waited--and drove throughout the county to inspect areas where monarchsare usually abundant at this time of year. To her dismay, there substantial sightings until....

October 18
"At 10:45 a.m. Art Oyervides called the Rio Bravo Nature Center to report that he had monarchs streaming above his country store. Clusters formed in the trees behind his house that evening. (Later, on the morning of the 20th, I would count about 200 at that site.)"

October 20
"Today was fabulous! Started off with 200 monarchs in the trees down the road, proceeded with 60 or so monarchs per minute on the Cunningham Ranch; and during the canoe trip of 15 miles, there was a continuous stream across the river. Probably saw between 500 and 700 to be conservative. Our canoes and the monarchs were fighting a stiff SE wind gusting up to 35mph. Heaviest flow around 8:45 at the trees around the ranch house. 30 in view at any one time. There were easily another 500-600 at the Salvadore Gonzalez country home under massive native trees. This is the spot I call "The Cathedral." Monarchs drifting wall to wall in the 100s as they settle into clusters. It will be interesting to see what the monarchs do tomorrow if and when the front comes through. It could blow them all out of here. I hope there are more riding the wind in."

October 22
"They are definitely being blown into Mexico today! What a difference a North front makes! The trees on the bluff where we saw about 3,000 yesterday morning/afternoon had only 2 monarchs an hour ago. Rough winds to 35 mph from the NW. (But there is no moisture to speak of.) Temps 67 now from a low of 57 last night.Our count yesterday was around 6000 in just 2 locations. Either the neck ofthe funnel got split early on and sent 1000s out through Midland, TX, or therewill be a continuous trickle down from parts NE of here. I'd speculated with Randy Laurence that they could be tightly bunched and blow through very quickly, rather than trickle through for the next 3 weeks. I'll know tonightwhat this front did.I just had a long report from a ranch 35 mi. NE of Del Rio where their entire canyon was filled with possibly 10s of thousands last year and this year they had scant 100s."

October 23
" Brrrrrrrrrr! I forgot and left the kitchen door open all night. It's only 39.1 dF here this morning after the front came through yesterday (10/22/07). I'm back from checking roosts this morning at 5:30 am, but nary a monarch in any of the traditional cluster sites within a mile east or west of my house 12 mi. N of Eagle Pass, Tx. I sat outside just before dusk yesterday and saw only 1 monarch keeping low in the trees and trying to move west against the N wind. Also one Queen apparently migrating as well. This could be the briefest monarch passage we've had in years. I'm anxious to hear from Harlen and Altus to hear if they are doing any good down on the Coast."

October 23rd on the Texas Coast
Exactly as Carol predicted, a huge surge came down the coast beginning on the 23rd and lasting through the 25th.

We saw hundreds of monarchs here today: around nine this morning warming up on the sunny side of the live oaks they were roosting in, passing our house this afternoon at a rate of about 25 per hour, then by the hundreds in the live oak groves at roost time. The most we have seen in several years.
I have spotted the monarchs for a week or so from my office, but today (10/23) I have seen on the average of 360 an hour.

The coastal flyway had its first players show up today.

At 1:30 there were about 30 monarchs on the east side of peninsula to the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway.They were staying to the east along the tall grass and salt cedars out of the 25 mph west wind. It seemed some were dropping out of the sky but I think I was stirring them up as I was driving slowly along and they flew back down in front of me.

When I went back at 2:30, the tip of the peninsula was covered with several hundred monarchs. I came home, got my big net and holding cage, and was back by 2:45 to find monarchs all over the place looking for something to nectar on and doing a good job of fighting the west wind. There is some tall seaside goldenrod and camphor daisy/golden beach daisy growing along the edge of the old pavement to what was the causeway before Carla in 1961 plus some short seaside goldenrod and lantana making a comeback where TxDOT mowed ... just enough to stop some monarchs in their "tracks" today. I don't know how to count monarchs where they aren't really "flowing" past a point but Altus got there after school and together we netted75 without stepping off the pavement. I did watched after I got tired and they were "dropping out of the sky"! Some were coming from the NE and as many from the E across the water, but the majority just appeared down in around us. I couldn't pick them up against that high sky when I tried with binocs and there weren't enough. We saw several clusters forming at sundown, one tight one on false willow that I could count with 18, one in the middle of a large stand of salt cedars that may have held over a hundred but I could only see the top of it. At 2:30 when I came back to town I was seeing monarchs in town around the edge of the bay, so they weren't just at the causeway orpeninsula.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

...the big push of monarchs is on...Hundreds of them going thru thismorning in Bastrop Co. Drive 969 from Utley to Bastrop...see a hundredormore easy...coming over my place big time..

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Llegaron unas cuantas monarcas el 18 de octubre. Las fotos que adjunto son del 20 en la mañana; había miles. Se posan sobre los pinos, nogales, truenos (Ligustrum), zacatones Cortaderia). El 21 en la mañana no había, el lunes si pero salí a las 7 am y no vi cuantas. Anoche con el viento no llegaron. A ver cuantas llegan los próximos dias.

More photos...>>

This report courtesy of Rocío Treviño, Correo Real

My cousin said they had thousands in her backyard in San Angelo!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Had 65 Monarchs pass by a stationary viewing point in 15 minutes on my ranch in Center Point. Winds were still from the North, but much lighter than yesterdays gale force winds. Looked like many were lifting off frommy big Live Oaks. The temps fell into the high 30's last night after the winds subsided and there was frost on the ground. The numbers fell off fairly quickly so I was either at the end of their passing or it was a small flight.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

The monarchs are coming through the Kerrville region. Not as overwhelming a site as last year, but in twos, threes and fours. It took me less than 10 minutes to count 50+ flying overhead. This is the first day I’ve seen any large concentration in this area.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game
We visited Gulf Shores Alabama on October 20-21.  There were butterflies everywhere on the state park beach site.  We have some pictures and mpeg files.  I will attempt to download to your site.

I spent the last four days watching monarchs move south and west along the extreme southern tip of the DelMarVa and out across Chesapeake Bay at its mouth.  Tuesday morning at around 10 AM I observed 18-20 monarch per minute passing by the south end of the northernmost island of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel.
As we crossed the JFK Causeway over Laguna Madre, hundreds of Monarchs were crossing over the causeway, too.

Tuesday (10/23/07) saw 20-25 monarchs, the first day this fall I have seen numbers. Yesterday morning (10/24/07) just as the sun was first hitting my yard, I walked along the outer edge, checking butterflies that might be sunning. The trees and high shrubs contained 120 to 150 Monarchs, most perched with wings spread, warming their bodies. Very few other butterflies were active that early. Within a half hour or so the Monarchs begin to move to my numerous crucitas shrubs (Eupatorium odoratum) to feed. At any one time I could see 25-30 individuals close together on a couple sunny sites. Within the next couple hours they began moving about, sampling nectar on my numerous crucitas and/or white mistflower shrubs (Epatorium wrightii); few also utilizing duranta shrubs. This action continued until about noon. Gradually, apparently after adequately feeding, individuals began to move off, all seemingly heading southward, some fly low but most 20 to 50 feet above the ground. This southward movement continued for much of the afternoon. But more individuals appeared from the north, flying over the adjacent treeline to drop into my yard to feed. It seemed that at no time all day did I have less than 100 (est) individuals visible at any time. By late afternoon, with the sun still highlighting a number of crucitas, feeding activity continued at a high pitch. It seemed that fewer individuals were moving off; the vast majority of the activity was centered around the sunny patches of crucitas. During the last ten years that I have been paying attention to my yard butterflies, yesterday's Monarch numbers represented an all-time high. I will repeat my visits again today. Other obvious "migrants" included Cloudless and Large Orange Sulphurs, both American and Painted Ladies, Red Admirals, and Queens.

Report courtesy of Mike Quinn, via Texas Butterfly Listserv

"The Rio Grande Valley (southmost Texas) usually does not get lots of monarch reports," wrote Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife as he forwarded this report: We estimate 125-150 Monarch butterflies are roosting in our neighborhood in Edinburg tonight (10/24/07). I counted 75 in an Anaqua tree in the back yard, and we saw another roost across the street and enough butterflies on the wing to make up the difference. Also seen in Edinburg today were Queens,Sicklewing skippers, a Mimosa yellow, a Pipevine swallowtail and a Fatal metalmark. Photos of some of today's goodness can be seen athttp://www.flickr.com/photos/annetoalP>Report courtesy of Mike Quinn, via Texas Butterfly Listserv.

!Por fin estan las monarcas en el noreste de Mexico! Desde el viernes 19 empece a recibir los reportes de los miembros del Correo Real con la buena nueva de que ya estaban viendo grandes cantidades de monarcas, si ya llegaron a Saltillo quiere decir que en este momento las mariposas surcan el cielo de Coahuila, Nuevo Leon y Tamaulipas. No nos queda mas que recibirlas con alegria, cuidarlas mientras duermen y desearles un buen viaje hacia el sur. Espero en la semana recibir mas reportes que te enviare el viernes. Te mando una foto que tomo Servando Santana el jueves 18 en Lamadrid Coahuila, para que te des una idea de los racimos que se forman.

Gracias a Senora Rocio Trevinio, Correo Real.
Many hundreds of Monarchs being blown around by strong North winds on the beach. They just kept coming though.

I had monarchs through out my yard hanging in groups from the lower branches.  Estimated 50 in the yard.  The Mission, Texas reports--combined with this--suggest a broad front of migratory monarchs push through lower Texas. (Reported from Texas Listserv courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.)

"Incredible numbers of monarchs moving south over the water,  just off the shoreline. I set the scope on an intermediate distance at which I have a very good depths of view and counted big orange flutter-bys for 3 minutes. 194! I just looked again (1:21 p.m.) and they are still coming. There are constantly several going through the yard, too. It's just a massivemigration. Of course I did not investigate every big orange butterfly out there over the Bay for the possibility of being a Queen but since all of them in the yard are monarchs it seems pretty likely the ones over the Bay are so, too." (Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife.)

I witnessed the most incredible sight this morning and it has continued all day long.  I live on the island of Galveston just a few hundred feet from the water.  When I went out on the deck this morning I noticed one butterfly, then another and another.  Then I began to take in the magnitude of what I was seeing.  There were hundreds of butterflies.  To the east, west, toward the water, behind me, toward the bay.  It is one of the most incredible things I have ever seen.  I called everyone I could think of and then after three hours, I was finally able to tear myself away long enough to find this site on the internet.  How long will it last?

I had an interesting day here in Portland,  The Monarchs came though the yard in steady numbers all day and there was a steady stream of Monarchs all day on the causeway leading to Corpus Christi. Other butterflies, too: In the yard, the lantana was coveredwith Skippers, at least one species of Blues and at least 2 Scallowwing. The most interesting of the day was a single Zebra Longwing moved through the back yard and on my banana bait I had a single Mourning Cloak.  TheZebra and the Mourning Cloak are first for me in Portland.
Observed hundreds of butterflies in my yard around 6:00 PM.

Monarchs were seen flying and hanging from tops of pine trees facing the western setting sun around 5:30-6:00pm. I saw several dozen.

I really saw several dozen hanging down at outer tips and I'm sure there were many I couldn't see. The next morning there were lots more throughout the pastured area which is overgrown with wildflowers and grasses. They were basking in the sun and nectaring on any blooming plant. I took lots of pictures, but nothing really can show all the monarchs. Everywhere I walked some would fly up in front of me and light a small distance away. It was lovely!

My wife Altus said there were more monarchs than she had ever seen. Fantastic numbers between 2-4pm falling out in the area. I started out across the causeway when I went back and counted 89 monarchs coming at me in the first mile and then just quit counting. We saw clusters forming up on everything that could support monarchs, starting about 3:30. Some clusters two to three hundred and still growing. You couldn't drive along the beach road at more than a crawl because of the cloud of monarchs in the grass and dead sunflowers along the edge. Some snapshots from earlier in the afternoon that just didn't do justice to the event! Salt cedar and false willow are both blooming. Some queens in the clusters, to be expected, but I could see some buckeyes in with the monarchs ... not sure about that!Nine photos 40/50 kb: http://mcmc.homestead.com/oct2407.htmlOne of my ex-students with TxDOT stopped by at the causeway to be see if I was over there or hewas going to call me to tell me the monarchs had arrived. The wind really stiffened from the NW after 1:00 and is out of the NE right now, not sure what that means for tomorrow.At least we had two great days.

Also, got a call before six from a farm west of town of a large cluster in a hackberry tree.

Earlier today (morning):
At least twice the number this morning and there is a countable flow of monarchs coming from the NE. They are coming off the Alcoa bluff and from across the lagoon but staying low ... sometimes three and five only five to ten feet apart ... this is when it is fun!

Best 1 hour avg on east side of peninsula would give 300 per hour
Best 1 hour avg on west side of peninsula would give 100 per hour

So about 400 per hour are coming down the peninsula and crossing Lavaca Bay Causeway from what I can see. Last year I would have used just the 300.

On my last crossing of the 3.1 mile causeway, I counted24 monachs forty feet up at the level of the traffic. At every traffic light in town monarchs were floating by. After I get something to eat and run some errands I'll be back. 81 dF, wind NW @ 15 mph, ultra clear, humidity 23%.Supposed to be at least one more day like this.

I am assuming that this is part of the peak in their migration. They have slowed down a bit now (5:30 pm), but they are still very dense. Please note there are many small butterflies--not monarchs--also in this group.

I would not even hazard a guess, but I do think I've seen thousands of them today. Some are spending the night in my neighbor's palm trees here in West Galveston right near the Galveston Island State Park. My neighbor took pictures, but the monarchs are folded up and hanging from the brown ends of the leaves and are very hard to see.
Peak migration on UGA campus today

While taking a break at work downtown Houston Continental Airlines Headquarters, I noticed some monarchs flying towards the park accross the street. It just took seconds to realize something special was going on as a monarchs were descending out of the sky every 15-20 seconds from high altitude towards the park. It reminded me of a busy airport. I followed a few of them to one tree where to my surprise - the top of the tree was covered with them.
Time:evening - sunset
Activity: Monarchs were going to roost.
Numbers: Too many to count, arrival rate to tree every 15-20 seconds. Not sure how long, as I had to go back into work.Wind direction out of the North, becoming variable, to calm after sunset. merc 2997 millibars 1014.9. Temp 65F, forecasted low 44F.This is the tail end of the cold front that blew through for past 3 days.

I am on an offshore gas production facility, in the High Island block about 120 miles south of the Tx-La state line. It's dusk, about 7pm and the number of butterflies have increased. They don't seem to be stopping. They just flutter about for a bit and then they're on their way, headed due south. I started seeing them around 3 pm. The winds are from the northwest, about 5 to 10 mph and the skies are clear.

We have had thousands of monarchs on the Island. I live very close to the Gulf of Mexico and have many palm trees near my house. The monarchs roosted last evening and this evening (10-24 & 10-25) in the hundreds on the palm fronds. I have taken several photos of this and would be happy to share. What a grand sight this has been.
The monarchs were swarming and roosting in my trees around 6:30pm CST October 25, 2007. A few stopped over last year. This year there are 10 times more. I have photos that I can send.
At Texas A&M University Corpus Christi. The University is located next to the ocean, this morning the campus green areas were covered with butterflies. Great view.

The monarchs were very slow in getting to Del Rio this year and, when they did start flying overhead, the numbers observed were much lower than last year. The total number observed on our peak migration day (as observed by 6 classes of 7th graders)was roughly equal to the amount we saw during one class period on our peak migration day last year.

Hoy sábado, dentro de las celebraciones de las Fiestas de la Amistad, se organizo un torneo de pesca de alcaldes en La Presa de la Amistad. Aprovechamos la oportunidad para montar un modulo informativo de LA MARIPOSA MONARCA. Resulto muy interesante porque a la hora de impartir la información a los asistentes, las mariposas volaban sobre nosotros a pesar de los fuertes vientos que se sentían recibimos la visita de muchas mariposas. Pudimos ver como el viento las arrastra y lo frágil que son y como había muchos niños todos nos preguntaban si esas mariposas llegarían a Michoacán. Algunos opinaban y querían atraparlas para cuidarlas y después soltarlas, otros corrían tras ellas, fue una buena experiencia. Las monarcas volaban muy bajo a la altura de los automóviles y viajaban aisladas unas de otras, el jueves pude ver algunas en parejas. Me gustaría ver a una monarca con etiqueta.

Courtesy of Correo Real

A las 5:50 de la tarde comenzaron a congregarse monarcas a razón de una por minuto, para dormir en un eucalipto que está en el centro del jardín del rancho, como a la media hora había un racimo de aproximadamente unas cuarenta o cincuenta mariposas.Mi nietecito Rafael, de 6 años, incluso dejó de usar su motocicleta para no molestarlas y ahuyentarlas. Así, él, mi esposa y yo estuvimos observándolas desde que llegó la primera.Esto sucedió en el Rancho "Los Cuijes" situado en el Km. 20, carretera 57 tramo Saltillo-Monclova, 4 Kms. Antes de la “Presa Palo Blanco”La temperatura muy agradable de 27º a la sombra de los mezquites con brisa del NE en pausas y el cielo despejado.Cabe mencionar que es el primer avistamiento que tengo desde el inicio de la espera.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Conté 100 mariposas en 10 minutos, volaban en el Cañón de San Lorenzo, día soleado.

Courtesy of Correo Real

El fin de semana (20 y 21 de octubre) estuvimos trabajando en un proyecto de reforestación en Laguna de Sánchez. Era increíble la cantidad de monarcas que atravesaron el pueblo, realmente iban con prisa y no se paraban ni aún momento, lo que nos hace suponer que debe haber en los alrededores una estación de paso. Platicando con el director de la escuela primaria del lugar nos comenta que él ha visto un lugar donde las mariposas descansan y comen néctar de manzanas. Alan esta trabajando con esta y otras escuelas de la región, tan pronto como tengamos avances en el proyecto de monitoreo y de educación ambiental se los compartiremos.

Courtesy of Correo Real

¡Llegaron las monarcas al Rancho Aguililla!
El rancho se encuentra en 24°58'11"N 100°33'39"W, como a 7 k al sur de San Rafael en el municipio de Galeana.Llegaron unas cuantas monarcas el 18 de octubre. El dia 20 en la mañana había miles. Se posan sobre los pinos, nogales, truenos (Ligustrum), zacatones (Cortaderia). El 21 en la mañana no había, el lunes si pero salí a las 7 am y no vi cuantas. Anoche con el viento no llegaron. A ver cuantas llegan los próximos días.

Courtesy of Correo Real

me reportó que el viernes por la noche en un pino alepo, fuera de su casa durmieron cientos de mariposas.

Ese mismo día observé mariposas de forma aislada en diversos puntos de Saltillo, incluyendo el jardín de mi casa a media cuadra de la alameda.Sábado: Observé mariposas monarca en diferentes puntos de Saltillo de manera aislada, tanto en el centro de la ciudad como en Urdiñola y en el norte de la ciudad.

Domingo: A las ocho de la mañana observé docenas de mariposas saliendo de la alameda, y de los jardines de las casas vecinas a la misma.Sobre la carretera antigua Saltillo - Monclova, entre los Km. 5 y 20 contamos ocho mariposas en 10 minutos. En El Carmen, vimos mariposas aisladas alimentándose en geranios, bugambilias y laureles. Por la tarde las vimos acomodándose para descansar en nogales y catalpas, como ya había pasado el grueso de la migración, solo vimos racimos de 2 a 15 mariposas, una cosa que llamó mi atención es que se acomodaron en ramas a una altura de4 a 6 m. cuando en otros años hacían sus racimos a mas de 8 m. de altura.También vi que se acomodaron entre encinos pero no encontré los racimos porque había poca luz y es un lugar muy denso.

Lunes: Para las siete de la mañana las mariposas ya estaban volando, además de los árboles en que son muy visibles salían de la mancha de encinos, solo pude contar unas 20 mariposas entre 7 y 7 y media de la mañana.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Estoy muy contenta porque tengo casi toda la semana de estar observando mariposas volando les estoy hablando de la semana del 15 al 22 de octubre.Todo empezó como el miércoles donde veía entre dos y tres volando en la carretera a los González casi entre la una y media y dos de la tarde pero el fin de semana fui al rancho que esta ubicado en la carretera a San Antonio de las Alazana en el ejido San Ignacio de Abajo y todo el camino estuve viendo volar entre cuatro y cinco mariposas por el camino eran como las dos de la tarde pero en el rancho hay un gran pino y como a las 6:40 empezaron a llegar a este pino y se perchaban este espectáculo duro como media hora y llegaban entre unas 80 o 100 mariposas y esto lo observe por dos días TODO UN ESPECTACULO que me recordó el paisaje de el santuario en Michoacán. Ah en la escuela también hemos estado observando pero una por una. Profra. Rosario Segovia Ibarra

Courtesy of Correo Real

On Sunday, 10/21, I had even more Monarchs on my blue mistflower - about 40 to 50 at one point (after an equally big day on Sunday).  I invited the people from my church to stop by to enjoy the spectacle of the blizzard of butterflies in my front garden.the strong front that came through on Monday pushed most of them south.

What an incredible day!

The increase was most noticeable starting last night (Tuesday 10-23).The school where I was teaching Tuesday didn't have a single monarch pass by all day long.

At 4:00pm however, I stopped by the Home Depot which is 5 miles further west.I counted 15 Monarchs on a display of Salvia outside the store and another 10-20 flying from flower to flower inside Home Depot's garden center. Getting in my car twenty minutes later I sat in the parking lot and counted groups of 2-5 monarchs flying overhead every 2-3 minutes.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Today the flow of monarchs has been heavy and consistent!

Between 9:00 - 12 noon I was teaching at a school at the NE edge of Katy, Texas. A steady stream of Monarchs flew directly over the school and garden area for the three hours I was there. Sometimes single monarchs and sometime groups of five or more together. The wind was brisk from the NW which made flying tough. At times I would watch individuals get caught in the wind and glide 50 feet to the east before starting to fly again in a SW direction. Some groups flew over very high above the school and some dropped down to just above our heads before catching a draft upward again.

At 12:30 I drove to I-10 and continued to see a steady flow over the road flying SW with the wind trying to beat them back.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

...incredible numbers of monarchs moving south over the water, just off the shoreline. I set the scope on an intermediate distance at which I have a very good depths of view and counted big orange flutter-bys for 3 minutes. 194!

I just looked again (1:21 p.m.) and they are still coming. There are constantly several going through the yard, too. It's just a massive migration. Of course I did not investigate every big orange butterfly out there over the Bay for the possibility of being a Queen but since all of them in the yard are monarchs it seems pretty likely the ones over the Bay are so, too.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I have seen less than 5 a day for the past week or so.

Today (10/25) , however, I saw 78 from 61st street to 1st street on Harborside Drive as I drove east at noon. All seemed to be going west.

I saw over 120 from 1st street to 25th street on Seawall Blvd at 1 pm . I was traveling west and they were either going west or north (away from the water).

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Refuge staff have reported numbers of monarchs in the thousands on McFaddin National Wildlife Refuge near the Gulf of Mexico beach on Wednesday and Thursday of this past week (October 24th and 25th).

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Got a phone call from someone reporting 1000s of monarchs in pecan trees last night (10/25) along the San Bernard River in Brazoria, Texas. They were gone this morning.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Got a return call from Petra saying there are "even more monarchs today"than there were yesterday at Port O'Connor, TX.

15/minute through her backyard, but more are flying "really high".If she looks through her spotting scope out over the bay, there are too many to count. Today's air is dry with no heat waves.

She said it was like the "flood gates had opened." She even go goose bumps looking at them this morning.Everyone in town is talking about them.

She said it was the most she remembers seeing along the coast in her 15 years of living in Port O'Connor.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

The monarchs were all moving to the south. It was clear to see they were all flying in the same direction. The time spent observing was about 2 hours and I would say we probably observed about 4,000 butterflies. There was always a continuous flow the entire time. We observed from about 10:20am to 12:30pm. There was not much wind on that day and not recent storms. It was clear, cool in the morning low 40's but quickly warmed up into the high 70's. There were two people observing.

I saw my first good wave of Monarchs in Houston the day a very strong front pushed through. They were in groups of about 20 at a time and being pushed south by a 25 MPH wind, and just kept coming and coming. Beautiful!

Flow continues 25 Oct 07

Best hourly avg 800+
Best 5 min 331 at 1:30
Really large cluster/roost

The morning warmup took quite awhile and new arrivals were there before yesterday's crowd wanted to go.http://mcmc.homestead.com/oct2507am.html

By noon it was a parade of monarchs coming by and over.The times I went across the causeway I wondered why there wasn't a wreck. There would be what I would estimate to be a hundred monarchs in a space the size of my bedroom enjoying a pillow of air. I've only seen it like this one other time ...

Some really nice clusters/roosts formed just before sundown.Altus is really good when it comes to spotting a large amount of orange! Not sure why most had their wings open, just did.Biggest cluster we have ever seen, in the middle of a "round", formed by mostly salt cedar, a couple of mesquite, and a hackberry ... that amphitheatre we always hear that they will find ...http://mcmc.homestead.com/oct2507pm.html

The wind is changing and so may be the fun, may be one more day ...

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monarchs were passing relentlessly through (Anahuac NWR), quite a few having spent the night festooning some of the trees in the Willows.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Early liftoff of clusters ... area cleared before 8:00 but new flow had already opened.

Best count so far 12:00 to 12:30 half hour of 1156 for hourly of 2312.
Best 1 minute count was 43.
Best count crossing the 3.1 mile causeway, 194 in 5 minutes.
It was like this at 8:00 and was getting better at 12:00, the calm wind may make a difference this afternoon.

Same location near TX35, Alcoa Bluff, and north end of peninsula to Lavaca Bay Causeway, ... same place, same way as last year.I can see a width of about 300' and an altitude about 200'.

I crossed over to west side and got into the stream ... they were coming from 65 deg and leaving out across the bay to245 deg. I could see twenty coming and twenty lined up out across the bay. Checked with binoculars, there are a few above 200', the most action is in the lower 100' and I can see that without binocs. Many other butterflies showing up today now that it is calm. Calm, slight whisper out of NW, 76 dF, 18 % humidity, deep clear sky. This is all about to change.

October 28
Wind has turned and the monarchs have slowed to a trickle.This afternoon it was 74 dF, wind NE 10-18 mph, humidity 38%, clear.

Best trip across the causeway 5
Best hourly average 40
Few nectaring

We spent a time this afternoon driving slowly along county roads west and northwest of Port Lavaca and along the west shore of Lavaca Bay, about four west of the causeway. and there was about one monarch about every three to four minutes flying by at about three to six feet heading more west than southwest. The closer we were to the bay, the more we would see. We were really looking to which of our friends might have had clusters in their trees and never knew it.

No change, monarch or weather wise, seen until Thursday.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Stopped at Surfside after lunch to show a business colleague the local beach and Gulf and there was a virtual river of monarchs streaming by over the dunes. Have never seen so many.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I had trouble at getting to the hawk watch today.

The real migration today was the monarch butterflies. I thought that I had seen lots of monarchs west of Cameron La and near Sabine but those were amateur shows compared to the point today. I would think that the westerly winds held the butterflies back and now the north wind moved them to the point when they got going. Once it warmed up a river of monarchs flowed from east to west past the tower along the bay and in the scrub between the parking lot and the dropoff. They continued out the point until the got near the road that goes left instead of going straight to the Spoonbill. They all stopped in these trees.

Hundred and thousand of monarchs were passing constantly with clouds rising whenever there was a disturbance. In mid afternoon there was a short term change in wind direction and the migrants started moving away from the bay and past the tower. After a bit the wind went back to the north and they

I needed to run to High Island this afternoon. Butterflies and dragonflies were amazing!! Salt Cedars on the beach are covered with monarchs. Pretty neat day.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Imagine a river of American Snouts that are Monarch sized, crossing the causeway, about two hundred yards wide. Happened at 2:30 this afternoon near the Port Lavaca end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway. Tens of Thousands (think I spelled that right, 10's of 1000's) of monarchs, looked like those clouds of "black birds" that come by in winter. Hundreds if not thousands of dead monarchs being whipped up by the traffic from the surface of the causeway deck.

I had just finished a count at 2:15 and the avg for an hour was just under 4000 for an hour. The trip over the causeway before that I counted 410 monarchs.

Wind was calm from NNW, but is 5 from NNE now, that may bring things to an end tomorrow afternoon if we have an east wind I hear there is another front about Monday or Tuesday.What a day, and I still get to go back ...

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Today I stood on the balcony of an 8th floor condominium on Pensacola Beach and watched hundreds of Monarchs float up on the air currents. They looked like beautiful stained glass windows circling around and around slowly coming toward me and then passing overhead. What a show!
There were quite a few monarch butterflies in the field near the school flying over our heads.  The children counted around 20 butterflies in 10 minutes.

We are in Port Aransas, TX on vacation. Since Wednesday evening, 10/24/07, (through 10/28) we have observed hundreds of flying Monarch butterflies. They appear in most cases to be flying from the south (from the Gulf) toward shore, but this is probably an illusion.

10/27/2007 Just a few; 10/28/2007 In a 20 x 70' yard space across from Pensacola Beach there were no less than 10 continually in flight or feeding off a white small flower (even with a brisk wind in the areas); then walking along the Gulf side they were also all over the Ft. Pickens Beach area and going out very low over the water. Walking to and from the areas meant also seeing continual butterflies in flight - looking any direction. *Profile will show me as from Colorado but I am vacationing in area as grandchildren live on the ocean side of Pensacola Beach and it is only a football field width to also observe the Gulf side.
my butterfly bushes has 8 to 20 monarchs on it daily for the past few days i have three bushes

A friend reported that this morning she was sitting on the beach at Chincoteague NWR, Assateague Island VA and was seeing at least 1 monarch a minute coming off the water. The winds were, she reported, out of the west at about 30 miles per hour and she was feeling terrible seeing the monarchs struggle to get from the water to the seaside goldenrod beyond the beach to safety and nectaring -- she was trying to help a few get there, and having trouble getting a hold of them. Megan did say that the goldenrod was in pretty good bloom -- finally -- sure was late this year! It was sunny and only about 58 degrees today, the weather has been very rainy and foggy during their vacation up until today. Also she reported there were "quite a few" monarchs -- no number estimates -- nectaring in the golden rod, I would think they will stay there until they get their energy back and the winds die down.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Today at 3 PM Central time, as I took my walk around a peninsula that juts into Lake Livingston, Texas, on its north shore, I saw a field full of monarch butterflies. There were hundreds. They were hovering upon small flowers, purple petals about a yellow pistil. The flowers were about 6 inches to a foot off the ground, in this field 100 feet from the lake's edge. In addition to the monarchs, there were small and medium-sized butterflies and some appear to be mating, as they rise in couples (the medium sized ones). It is a comfortable, cool day, with sunshine. I have photos, if they will help. The maps I found at your site do not show a sighting of monarchs in Texas this far east, which is 75 miles north northeast of Houston. (Lake Livingston is 4 miles northwest of Onalaska, Texas.)


These butterflies were also present in large numbers:Buckeye


These butterflies were also present in large numbers:Gulf Fritillary

At 11 am this morning monarchs were sighted in the city of Queretaro, Queretaro by Raúl Zubieta! This is less than 70 miles from the center of the monarch overwintering region. We have alerted Estela Romero and others in the town of Angangueo, Michoacan where they are waiting for the monarchs arrival. Raúl Zubieta is a student of Drs. Isabel Ramirz and Lincoln Brower. He is surveying the monarch migration route across northern Mexico this fall.

[Note: While this is not a "PEAK" migration sighting we are posted it temporarily on this map because it is such an important highlight.]

My husband I witnessed the greatest migration on the Texas City Dike on Thursday 10-25-97. The monarchs were all along the road, in the shrubs and palms and rocks. It was incredible. The wind was blowing out of the north, northwest and I believe they were taking shelter. My husband was on the TC Dike around and 11:00 am. when he noticed how many monarchs were flying about. It was a few hours before he finished his errands. We live about 30 minutes away so he came home to tell me about them. We arrived at about 1:30 and did not leave until around 3 or 3:30. They were still coming in across the bay. About 4 weeks ago we were on the TC Dike and found the common Buckeyes migrating. There were thousands of the Buckeyes but there had to be a million Monarchs. It was an incredible day. I had heard of this but never dreamed we would witness such an event. A friend went out the next day and said the monarchs were there but not in the great numbers we saw them.

A friend who stayed at crystal beach this weekend told me it was one of the most touching things to see all the butterflies. She said the beach there has clouds and clouds of these butterflies.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Bolivar Flats was the real treat of the day as I arrived at 5:30 and stayed until almost 7:00, as the only human. The Golden rod and sea ox-eye were covered in Monarch, Gulf Fritillary and several other orange and yellow butterflies!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

With the weak cold front and NE winds overnight, today was a “big day” for tagging at St. Marks, and we mobilized our volunteer tagging crew. I haven’t tallied the total number counted on early-morning roosts yet, but we tagged and released for parts unknown 912 monarchs sporting blue-colored tags. Hundreds more untagged monarchs were seen moving through the refuge by noon.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Hoy amanecimos en Monclova unos 8°C, ahora si hizo frío, (cuando estamos a unos 25-30 grados, nos ponemos suéter, pues aquí las temperaturas son alrededor de los 40°C). Ya a media mañana, fue cambiando el clima, y empezaron a salir mariposas de muchos lados, salían con el calorcito del sol y volaban por encima de las casas, se paraban en las flores y volvían a volar, había por decenas en los lugares en donde hay más árboles, principalmente nogales, pinos y álamos. Ayer hizo mucho viento fuerte y helado y no se vieron (onda fría 3 y 4). Me llamó la atención que cuando las libélulas -que hay muchas- volaban cerca de las flores donde comían las mariposas, éstas las ahuyentaban del lugar volando agresivamente -contra las libélulas-, no se si jugando, peleando por el territorio, la comida, no dejarse comer... o nomás de puros puntos...

Courtesy of Correo Real

Para informarles que el viernes, aproximadamente siendo la 17:00pm, viajando de Saltillo a Monclova, en el puente de las curvas, con abundantes huizaches, pude observar un gran numero de monarcas concentradas ahí.También les informo que ya llegaron las mariposas monarca, al gran bosque urbano, desde el 15 de octubre, empezaron a visitarnos, pues es un lugar muy apropiado para ellas, con los recorridos que aquí se realizan, los niños logran disfrutar y a la vez conocer más sobre ellas, y protegerlas.Visiten el gran bosque urbano, es muy hermoso.

Courtesy of Correo Real

We vacationed last week at Bolivar Peninsula, Texas. One day (Oct. 25th), while surf fishing, we noticed millions of butterflies coming in to land on palm trees in the yard where we were staying. It was incredible. The palm trees were literally covered with beautiful monarchs. It was getting near sunset. A chilly night was predicted. The monarchs were quickly filling up the leeward side of some palm trees. When there were no leeward spots left, they would begin to fill another tree.

Saw several hundred monarchs the evening of the 28th and the morning of the 29th. May be the tail end of the main flight south. Many appear to be having trouble keeping up and we saw about 30 dead on the ground after they moved out in the morning.

I saw a bunch flying over the causeway to North Padre Island on Saturday, October 27. No idea how many, but the air was just full of butterflies!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I was on Matagorda Island last Friday and Saturday (Oct 26 - 27) and all day long, both days, the Monarch migration was remarkable along the first 100 yards of beach and grass/dunes on the Gulf side of the island. There were literally MILLIONS and MILLIONS of Monarchs steadily moving southward. It was impressive.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

First of all it was without a doubt the most beautiful thing I ever witnessed. At approximately 3:30 pm the first of the beautiful monarchs approached the 53rd Street beach at Ocean City, New Jersey. Initially, they came by the 2's and 4's and then they came by the hundreds and I don't think I'd be wrong by saying the thousands! You couldn't see them in the distance. It wasn't until they were shore line that they became visible heading toward the bay. It was a spiritual sight I will never forget. My thanks to the monarchs.

La semana pasada los días 23 y 24, vi mariposas por diferentes rumbos de la ciudad. En El Carmen se vieron durante toda la semana del 22 al 27 en forma aislada, no me reportaron ningún sitio de descanso. Hoy lunes conté 129 mariposas en el tramo de la carretera antigua a Monclova, desde la curva de Altamira hasta el paso a desnivel del Periférico Echevarria, la lentitud de los traileres me permitió contarlas fácilmente. En Altamira siempre las había visto saliendo a los lados del puente, que esta ahora en ampliación, las mariposas volaban de poniente a oriente, posiblemente descansan en el Arroyo del Pueblo.

Courtesy of Correo Real

El domingo 28 me he fascinado contemplando el paso de la mariposa por la Huasteca, entre las 11 y las 2 pm, disfrutamos esta maravillosa migración un grupo de amigos que salimos de la ciudad, recordé la leyenda que alguna vez me platicaron, guardare para siempre esta fotografía, ¿cuantas vimos? muchas, muchas y todas viajando presurosas defendiéndose del fuerte aire.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Andando en el monitoreo de la cotorra serrana pudimos observar el paso de miles y miles de monarcas del 19 al 21 de octubre. Pueden ver un mini video en el youtube, solo busquen mariposa monarca .

Courtesy of Correo Real

Ann and her husband called from Smith Point to report "100 monarchs per minute passing for 6 hours on October 26th."

After asking them several times for confirmation sake about the numbers, date and duration, that allowed as how "that was just in the front yard"!!! They walked around to the backyard and there were just as many if not more. They said there were so many butterflies that they would hit you!!!

They said they have lived year round at Smith Point for 13 years, and that last time they had a huge push through their yard was in 1995 when they had 15,000 on November 4th!They said that the flow had tapered off and now (10/31) they only had about 1000 monarchs in their yard...

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

This has been about the most monarchs I have seen in 24 years, and only the second time they have chosen the station (Perry R. Bass Marine Fisheries Research Station) as a “rest stop” . I also had several thousand monarchs in my front yard for the night on the 26th.

Here are some better details on this years monarch sightings at the station.

The monarchs were first noticed on the evening of the 24th, when roughly 10,000 were found congregated in some tall brush and weeds on an elevated area on the station grounds.

The monarchs remained in the area the next morning and throughout the day and had spread to a group of small Chinese tallow trees, and the number had increased to about 20-25,000 individuals (again, roughly estimated). Also about 4:00 pm on the 25th a flight of monarchs was observed moving from northeast to southwest across the station, numbers would be difficult to estimate but the flight continued for 20-45 minutes and was relatively dense.

Monarchs were not observed congregating on the station on the 26th, but some individuals were observed in the area. The research station is located on the north shore of Matagorda bay where FM 3280 dead ends at the bayshore.

Also on the 26th I observed monarchs (estimated 5-10,00) congregating in trees (Chinese tallow and chinaberry) at my residence which is approximately four miles north of the research station.

Keep in mind that my estimates are very rough and I don’t have any prior experience with estimating butterfly numbers so the actual numbers could very easily be half or double my estimates.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Efectivamente las mariposas estan aun pasando por Saltillo, mi esposo me informo ayer por telefono que lunes y martes vio durante todo el dia grupos de docenas de mariposas volando al sur. Ayer recibi reportes de San Luis Potosi y del sur de Zacatecas.

There were literally THOUSANDS of monarch butterflies by the Dirty Pelican Pier early this morning (10/29/07). Saw them flying on the beach just south of High Island last night coming back from Beaumont. Thanks to friends, I learned they'd be around at least until today & didn't miss out. Apparently they 'roosted' (if that's what butterflies do) in the bushes, salt cedars, & grasses along the shore overnight & this morning, as the sun dried the dew from their wings, they took to the air. The sky was filled with them.

Breathtaking sight. Gosh I LOVE our peninsula!! You never know what you might see.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I was on the coast south of the town of Cameron in SW La. on October 26, the Friday afternoon of the La. Ornithological Soc. meeting.I spent about an hour near the jetties at the mouth of the Calcasieu Ship Channel and observed large numbers of monarchs feeding on the goldenrod and sea oxeye blooms. Others were flying slowly southward--some high in the air and some low. Buckeyes and Gulf fritillaries were also present, but monarchs were by far the most numerous. I didn't count the monarchs, but I'd estimate that I saw50-80 during the hour that I birded at the jetties.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I was impressed Sunday with my visit to Smith Point. I left my house at 7:15am and didn't see a Monarch during the two hour drive.

Foggy in patches and the fields down Hwy 562 to Smith Point were wet with dew.I arrived at 9:00 driving to where the road dead ends at the water. At first and I couldn't find any monarchs but then at 9:10 I began to see the first few in the air over the trees near the water.I watched as two flew in circles then three or four more on the Lantana near the road.

At 9:15 I began counting and saw 10 per minute crossing in front of me along the bay.9:20 15 per minute

At 9:25 I drove around the corner to the hawk watch tower and counted 20 per minute crossing in front of the tower and over the water.

For the next three hours I counted an average of 25 per minute crossing just out from the beach over the water. Some were close and some so far out that they could only be seen with binoculars.Behind me approximately another 5 monarchs per minute passed the tower not he field side.A few high points were between 10:15- 10:20, 11:00- 11:03, and 12:00 - 12:05 when I counted 50-60 monarchs per minute.

I left Smith Point at 12:30 and was surprised to find that as soon as I turned down the road, the Monarchs were no where to be found. Only one or two monarchs on the way back down the long road to the freeway. The migration at Smith Point is happening just at the coast.

A few observations I found interesting:
1. Monarchs flying very low (only approx. 3' above the bay water).
2. Monarchs skipping over the water then touching the water and then up again. Are they trying to drink? not salt water!
3. Every few minutes I would see a monarch touch the water then get waterlogged and unable to fly. flapping/ flapping/ flapping---- Then.....a fish would jump up and eat it.

All the monarchs I could see, looked in good shape. I am heading back down to Smith Point on Thursday this week

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Good news from Port Hope on Lake Ontario. I was out golfing again on Tuesday morning. It was sunny and breezy and a steady stream of monarchs passed. Every 20-30 seconds a monarch floated by us. It was very uplifting to see them all gliding along. I hope you have many other good reports. I will keep going with my observations.

We sighted approximately 20 monarchs feeding on goldenrod in a woodland clearing about 10:30am. Temperature was cool, about 50 degrees following an 80 degree week.We also spotted about 6 monarchs feeding on 4ft. high thistles and yellow coneflowers at about 11:30am in our garden area. The photos we took were absolutely gorgeous in the filtered sunlight.

At the Cranberry Marsh Hawk Watch, at the south end of Whitby on the north shore of Lake Ontario, Doug Lockery reports that they counted 86 monarchs over a two hour period today.

Contributed by Don Davis

September 7
The movement of monarch butterflies was continuing Sunday morning at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge near Prairie City, Iowa. During observations, 406 monarchs were counted nectaring primarily on tickseed sunflowers. Many were flying into the refuge from the north and stoppiing soon on the tickseeds. Others were seen in other parts of the refuge primarily where the tickseeds are blooming.

September 6
Once a dense fog cleared in late morning at the Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, migrating monarchs began showing up to nectar on the wildflowers--especially the tickseed sunflowers. The tickseeds are a favorite nectaring source each fall for a period of 7 to 10 days as their blooming period coincides with the monarchs' migration. Shortly after noon in the northern part of the refuge, a wave of monarchs began arriving in the tickseeds in that area. More than 100 monarchs were counted as they flew from flower to flower. Overall during a morning visit, more than 225 monarchs were counted--another clear indicator the fall migration was under way.

September 5
Sightings of migrating monarchs had been limited up until today at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. After a dense fog had lifted, we arrived at the refuge's savanna trail area where the open prairie meets a hillside stand of oak trees. What we observed over the next hour and one-half was a spectacular showing of migrating monarchs as they flew out across the prairie and were found nectaring on wildflowers amid the stand of oak trees. We counted at least 250 monarchs, but the numbers surely were greater. This was another of those "monarch moments" when the beauty of nature creates a breathtaking environment. Later, in our butterfly garden in Altoona, we were greeted by another 30 migrating monarchs!

It has been a good warm sunny day here at waystation 553 in Midhurst, Ontario (about 55 miles north of Toronto). Migrating monarchs have been passing through and feeding all day long. There have usually been a couple in the garden at any given time with five at one time on our Mexican sunflowers (Tithonia rotundifolia). Today has been the most monarch activity we have seen this year, not counting when we have released butterflies.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Literally thousands and thousands hanging in our trees on our 6 acres with 4 acres of timber. They were there early morning on 9-7-08 and still there in the evening. The weather is rainy and cool. Beautiful siting!

This was a wonderful day for observing migrating monarch butterflies. On Monday, their movement had been dampened by rainy weather, but things changed. This day began with temperatures across central Iowa in the low 40s, but the sunny weather stirred up monarch movement once again. During two hours of observations in the mid-afternoon at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, we counted the largest total yet for this fall--545 monarchs. In the first 30 minutes, we counted about 250 monarchs nectaring on tickseeds in the northern edge of the refuge. What a delight to see them racing here and there over the wildflowers.

September 11
Rain had fallen earlier, and a light mist was dampening the area in Neal Smith Wildlife Refuge. But as the mist subsided around 11 a.m., monarchs began flying over the tickseeds in the north of the refuge. The sun began coming out from behind the clouds, and monarch activity picked up. By noon, 100 monarchs were observed, and then in the early afternoon, the pace of movement picked up considerably in other parts of the refuge. In three hours of observing, 300 monarchs were noted--providing a lesson on how the butterflies deal with moisture, strong winds, sunlight, and clouds.

September 13
Following a day and one-half of rainy weather, we visited Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge in the late afternoon looking for monarchs. The day still was cloudy, but we began seeing some monarch activity in the north of the refuge. To the south where the prairie meets oak woods on a hillside, we discovered monarchs flying out from the oaks to nectar on the prairie wildflowers. Then they returned to several roosts on the hillside oak trees. Great viewing. We counted 190 monarchs, but the numbers in the roosting areas surely were higher as the monarchs were swirling around our heads and stopping on the oak branches.

September 14
Three hours of morning observations turned up 220 monarch butterflies--many of which were dealing with a strong northwest wind of 20 to 30 miles an hour. The monarchs were stopping on oak trees in the south of Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, and struggling across the prairie for nectaring on wildflowers. The sun came out from behind the clouds for a time, and the monarch activity picked up. While observing the monarchs, I found one caught in a spider web. I took it out of the web, cleaned its wings of the webbing, held it up to the sky, and watched it fly hundreds of feet up to the top of an oak tree!

September 15
A sunny day on the prairie brought out strong monarch butterfly activity at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Most of the monarchs appeared to be moving away from their favorite wildflowers of the past week--tickseed sunflowers--and were turning instead to sawtooth sunflowers for their nectaring. During three hours of observation in the afternoon, 384 monarchs were counted--especially on the taller sawtooth sunflowers.

This afternoon, while on my way to do a talk in St. George I stopped in at Point Lepreau with the hope today’s strong westerly winds might have blown some inland Monarchs to the Bay of Fundy coast. I wasn’t disappointed.

Although I traveled from Saint John to Fredericton and back to Lepreau during the morning, I didn’t see a single Monarch until about 1:30 PM when I arrived at the very tip of Point Lepreau, which is the usual accumulating spot when conditions are right. I immediately began seeing Monarchs nectaring on the thistle, goldenrod and asters that bloom in profusion near the bird observatory.

I would estimate I saw between 200 and 300 Monarchs during the three hours I was there and caught and tagged 78, which is the best one-day total I’ve done in the three years I’ve been tagging. While I was taking butterflies out of the net a constant trickle of them was passing, all headed southwest, into the teeth of the wind.

This fall the Monarch migration along the Bay has been slower than in 2006 or 2007. Richard B. and I had made earlier visits to Point Lepreau on August 15th and September 2nd and saw very few and I had not seen many elsewhere until today.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Today was my best day so far this year for tagging in the Oshawa area where we were able to tag 140 adults. The weather was sunny with a slight breeze and a temp around 20 C. The gender ratio was 2:1 males: females, most recently enclosed.

Hundreds of monarchs sited flying west, hugging Lake Ontario north shoreline.  Hundreds also resting in trees.  Strong westerly wind - aftermath of Ike, which blew through yesterday.  Temp.:  60 F.

I counted approximately 350 monarchs flying west along cliffs on the north shore of Lake Erie today from 2-3 pm. I also sighted an afternoon roost of about 100 monarchs. They were roosting on old Queen Anne's Lace. Not nectaring, just resting. Tagged 47 for the day, and 25 in 15 minutes. The area is known as Hawks Cliff, right along the north shore of Lake Erie, just east of Port Stanley.

I suspected with the bright sunny weather today and winds that there might be a strong monarch migration. As well, almost all of the remaining chrysalises in my rearing cage at home emerged today en masse. East of Toronto, Doug Lockery and crew at the Cranberry Marsh Hawk Watch reported "thousands of monarchs and dragonflies", as well as a strong hawk migration with perfect northwest winds. After this week, what will be left will be stragglers.

Courtesy of Don Davis

While driving north on 291 Hiway in Lee's Summit, in 10 minutes I sighted approximately 50 monarch butterflies flying south today. What a sight! They were not in a cluster but every few seconds I saw a few more. Thrilling!!

The migration today was excellent! An orange burst of Monarchs this morning! In one hour I observed 160 Monarchs, and 60 of these came in 18 minutes. I observed from 9:37 am to 10:37 am. Skies clear, very little wind, temperature is 64 degrees F. I continued to observe a constant light flow of Monarchs for several hours until 3:10 p.m, when apparently the flow of butterflies has stopped for the time being. From 2:50 pm to 3:10 pm, I observed 27 Monarchs. All of these were low flying and stopped to nectar at my flowers. The ones I saw earlier this morning flew at tree top level, about 40 feet high, and very few stopped to nectar at the flowers. Hopefully, more are on the way!

I paid attention to the Peak Migration map on Journey North and figured that the migration had been "held up" at the Iowa/Missouri border for awhile due to the heavy storms from the hurricanes the past 5 days and that with clear skies they would soon be in Kansas City and here they are!

The day was mild and sunny, and it was a welcome environment for migrating monarch butterflies. They were continuing to be quite active at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. During four hours of observations in late morning and early afternoon, 510 monarchs were counted. In one area of sawtooth sunflowers, nearly 150 monarchs were observed in one-half hour moving from flower to flower and hanging on to the blossoms while a light wind moved the plants to and fro.

Our third grade class was amazed to count any where between 8-12 monarchs every square meter in our butterfly garden. The monarchs were clinging in huge clusters on our purple Meadow Blazing Star Flowers collecting nectar. The kids noticed that the monarchs likes thess better than the black eyed susans. The numbers have begun to dwindle every day sine this time. Yesterday we saw an injured monarch trying to keep pace with others in their race to migrate.

The number of Monarchs has been growing over the last few days here in Oshawa/Whitby and in East Point Park in Scarborough, and I have been able to tag well over 100 Monarchs in each of three of the last four days. The total tagged now (715), is almost equal to the total at the same date last year (775). I have also been able to give more time to the tagging process this year.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
