Saw over 100 monarchs flying through our "corridor" between houses.  Only a handful even stopped over on the butterfly gardens.  Most flying above housetop level.  First sighting at 10AM (temp 70).  Last sighting 6:00PM (temp 74).
I see lots of monarchs flying south outside of my office window.  At least 10-15 an hour.

Observing 1 or more Monarchs per 5 minutes in purposeful southwesterly directional flight.  Approx. 75 degrees temperature, gentle breeze from northeast, quite sunny.  Individuals are not nectaring in garden nor resting.Thank you.

On the 15th, I counted 14 Monarchs in 15 minutes; today it was 27 in 15 minutes.  But as I was writing this, a friend called to say that as I was absent from the beach, she had counted them for me and she got 25 in 5 minutes (at 5:00 pm).  All mine were flying due west along the northern shore of Lake Ontario, some in groupings of 4 or 5.  Some groupings had a lot of 'interaction' amoung the individuals.  This was not a good summer for Monarch sightings but this week has shown that they have bred quite successfully when they were here.

I saw 19 Monarchs on September 17th from 4:00 pm to 4:30 pm. Today (9/19) I counted 46 on the same route, Ocean Parkway Jones Beach. Ocean Parkway is on my route home and it usually takes about 30 minutes to drive from Jones Beach to Robert Moses Causeway. I also noticed an unusual amount of insects and dragonflies flying about that day. The very next day the count went down to 2 Monarchs. Maybe it was breeding season for some of the insects in the area.

My office is on the eighth floor of Mission Towers and for the last few days my colleagues and I have been treated to the sights of dozens of monarchs streaming by. There are also many smaller yellow butterflies to be seen. I'm sure there are many hundreds maybe even thousands going by. It seems like there were more yesterday than today.
We counted 22 Monarchs flying through during our 15 minute recess.

While playing golf my husband counted over 20 Monarchs in 3 hours floating South.  He did not say if the counting interfered with his game! The morning weather was balmy, upper 60's, and sunny with very little breeze. I have a monarch in a net cage.  He unfolded from his chrysalis this morning. When he was a late stage caterpillar on butterfly weed in my garden, I put him in the cage with a piece of the weed and he formed his chrysalis the next day. I plan to release him tomorrow morning. I have great pictures of my little science project!

This morning just before noon, I spotted 18 Monarchs flying past the reservoir here in Fairfield.  They were all heading West.  I could only observe for about 15 minutes but was happily surprised to see so many in just a few minutes.Later, I watched for them at a local park filled with trees for about 15 minutes.  Nothing!! My feeling is that they were at the Reservoir because it was near the countryside where the milkweed is abundant and so was water to drink.  Next time, I'll stay at the Reservoir to count.

Today was an amazing time for observing migrating monarch butterflies at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. As we entered the refuge, we noted monarchs moving in from the north and stopping to nectar on sawtooth sunflowers. We counted 125 monarchs in 15 minutes. The monarchs were seen, too, in many other areas of the refuge, floating across the landscape, flying quickly from place to place, and seeking nectar primarily on sawtooth sunflowers. During 3 1/2 hours of observations in the late morning and early afternoon, we counted 1240 monarchs--the most yet by far during daily visits to the refuge.

there is a large weed patch by the road and it has a good variety of weeds in bloom now.  I just saw 5 - 6 monarch's at this weed patch.  The weather is sunny, calm and 76 deg.  Another beautiful day in the Ozarks.

Monarchs have continued to trickle through the area yesterday and today.  Today there was a nice flight in the early afternoon hours.  I counted 50 in one hour from 11:30am to 12:30pm.  Partly cloudy, very little breeze from the south, then north, temperature in the mid-70's.  Most of these Monarchs came into my yard to feed on the flowers.
Butterflies flying south along the beach - didn't count the timing of them per minute - it wasn't a lot - but continuous none the less
Between 12:00 - 1:00 approx 500 Monarchs moving from East to West at Hawks Cliff, near Port Stanley, Ontario, on the north shore of Lake Erie. Most just drifting on the 'thermals'.

Friday was another banner day for viewing the movement of the migrating monarch butterflies at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. The mild, sunny weather continued to foster a strong migratory pattern, although a wind from the south southeast slowed some of the monarchs' movements. During 3 hours of observations, 540 monarchs were counted.

Finally observed 25 or so Monarchs on their migration south. I say 'finally' because the numbers of monarchs in my area this year has been down. Normally I can see on average 20 every day around our home in the fields or in the woods behind our home. So to finally be able to see as many as I did today was a treat, sadly though they weren't going to stay around. Hopefully maybe next year will be different,our weather this year has been odd. I'm not complaining though, we really didn't have a really hot summer. It was almost like a extended spring of sorts.

September 20
We have a large tree in our backyard, just off our deck. This tree has always been covered by ivy vines. This year the ivy has blossomed and today I noticed the blossoms are attracting many butterflies - mostly the monarch - and also bees (just a few were noticed). It is wonderful to see them and challenging to try and capture a good photograph of the event. I have no idea how long they will remain but I will keep watching. I have lived at this home for over 30 years and this is the first time I have witnessed this with the butterflies and with the ivy blooming out.

September 21
we had even more butterflies and bees all enjoying the nectar from the ivy blossoms growing up a large tree. It is so wonderful! I'll estimate that we have several hundred butterflies and even more honey bees! The hum is quite loud - not extreme- but you can definitely hear them. Almost like a giant bee hive. I teach photography and I climbed a ladder and photographed. WOW what fun!

Migrating monarch butterflies continued to pour in from the north at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. In a half hour startng at 9 a.m., we counted more than 350 monarchs coming in to nectar in stands of sawtooth sunflowers and flying and floating across the big bluestem grasses. The day was calm, sunny, and warm, and monarchs were spotted elsewhere, too, in significant numbers in the refuge. During 3 1/2 hours of observations, we counted 1002 monarchs.

We have been seeing many, many Monarchs on our playground for the last week.  Several are sighted each recess period.  We have also raised and released six of our own Monarchs with one more set to emerge from its chrysalis on September 22nd! Happy Migrating!!

We sighted several hundred monarchs this afternoon.  We watched at least 1 1/2 to 2 hours. It was a wonderful site watching these beautiful creatures pass overhead.  My husband, daughter and I were so very excited, because we had never saw them migrate before.  My husband had heard of the migration, but we had no idea how beautiful it was to see.  It was a sight that I will cherish always and hope to see again one day.

Monarch butterflies continued to fly in from the north at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. During nearly four hours of observations in the morning, 527 monarchs were counted. In addition to the movement in from the north, a number of monarchs appeared to be coming up out of the big bluestem grasses where they had spent the night. Back home in our butterfly garden in Altoona, Iowa, 10 monarchs put on a beautiful show in the afternoon when nectaring together on the purple asters.
Saw 13 monarchs within 5 minutes along a one mile stretch of sunflower crop - in bloom.
Yesterday (September 21) I saw about 20 monarchs in the garden.  They were stopping over on the way.  This morning I have seen 3 on their way.
I saw about 34 Monarchs flying south in the morning on a cool windless day. I watched for about 30 minutes. They were high above the treetops.

We spent 1 ½ hours at Pilot Ridge Overlook on the BRP (mile 301.8) near Grandfather Mountain on Saturday, September 20th. Between 3:30 and 5:00 we counted 42 and tagged 13. We went back again on Sunday, September 21st. Between 1:00 and 5:00 we tallied 214 and tagged 57. Several folks stopped and asked what we were doing, so we did our best to inspire more monarch conservationists. Not our biggest count ever, but it was pretty good! And it was fun!We saw lots of broad winged hawks as well. Difficult to count because they were kettling, but we estimate that the largest group held around 150. A few smaller groups probably numbered a couple of dozen.

We went back to Griswold Naturre Preserve and saw over 200 monarchs resting on the Golden Rod. The plants were dripping with monarchs.It was the most amazing thing to see that many butterflies in one small area.

Hi! I was helping a friend mow their yard in the country and I went by a corner of the lot and there were hundreds of Monarch butterflies all over the pine trees. It was awesome. I cannot remember ever seeing this many butterflies at once. Just wanted to make a comment since I thought it was soooo cool. Thanks! Kelly

(The observer was visiting the site and discovered the roost some time later.) The dates on the roost map are coded to show the dates the roosts first formed.)

My husband was working in the yard today. He saw approximately 50 butterflies in 6 hours on their way through to the South. They stopped briefly at the butterfly bush for a sip of nectar. But are mostly on a dead head. Can't wait for tomorrow to see what it brings. My favorite time of the year.

A great summer of butterflies here at Monarch Landing appears to be extending into the warm fall. Yesterdays 26C(Sept.24th) had lots of species still flying. The monarch migration peaked here (Erie's Central Basin) last Thursday Sept 18th with an estimated 4,000 plus monarchs passing these shores on the day. Perhaps 20% of our best years. Good numbers were seen Friday , Saturday and Sunday however each day the magnitude decreased. Sept 24th there were only perhaps 5 to 10 Monarchs all day.

Contributed by Don Davis

Looks like a second surge of migrating monarchs is passing through the area (from the NE states).  Went to a monarch tagging on 09/20 and there were 0 tagged at a waystation, however when we went out 9/25, we were able to tag 5 monarchs in the span of 15', including a M & F on the same bush.Plan to use the rest of the tags this weekend as my partners saw several today moving through the area.

Big day for Monarch Butterflies. over 100 counted. Later in the day, they were coming by too fast to really count, so I began to ignore them.

there were hundreds flying over our house! we watched for about 30 minutes at about 9:00 am.   Then on Saturday late afternoon my husband and son went on a bike ride, and down by the creek they saw many roosting on the trees by the bank.

As I was sitting on my deck, having coffee this morning, I noticed a few Monarchs flying around. Then I kept seeing more, coming from the north. In an hour's time , I counted at least 300 gliding along, going southwest. It is awesome to see so many and getting to witness this natural phenomenon.

This was the first time I have seen a migration of Monarchs. It was one of the most peaceful and graceful sightings of nature I have encountered in my life. The sighting lasted for over 1:30 minutes long and still going.

I wish I could give you an estimate. All I know is that there were THOUSANDS, this started about 2:00pm and they had seemed to rest here overnight, cause they were on the front porch at 2:00am. That's why I googled the migration. The next day a cold front came through.
I saw approximately 40-50 monarchs flying overhead on the Mississippi River, approximately 2 miles north of Helena, Arkansas.

Sightings at DRHW- Lake Erie Metropark in Brownstown, Michigan

September 11
This was by far the best day for Monarch migration so far this fall. They got underway before the hawks even really got going with steady numbers seen by mid morning. They did taper off a bit in the afternoon but overall it was a very fine day for migrating Monarchs. Observer Hours: 9.5

September 23
Monarchs had one of their better days but I’ve yet to see any large movements of butterflies this fall. In all I would say they are down considerably from the last few years.

There's a nice flight of monarchs going over tonight- many dozens up to a hundred per minute. They are coming down to feed in the flowers but are flying anywhere from a few feet above ground to hundreds of feet up.

Saw lots of Monarchs migrating while traveling from Stillwater to Tulsa.

(Editor's Note: The latitude and longitude for this sighting is midway between the two towns.)

Helena and her Daddy saw monarchs migrating south while we were at a soccer field on the north edge of Stillwater, OK.  At 6 pm, we saw approximately 30 per minute, and this rate continued until about 6:30 pm.  By 6:45 pm, the rate slowed to about 5 per minute.

This morning between 10:55 AM and 11:25 AM I walked the Long Beach barrier beach in Stratford and, in a distance of about 1 mile and counted 126 Monarchs. They were nectaring on Seaside Goldenrod as they slowly moved along. I was careful not to double count. The air was almost still and the temperature was in the low 60's with mostly cloudy skies. There were several women with a group of young children there and they were netting and banding Monarchs. I don't know who they were affiliated with.
Witnessed over 100 Monarchs fluttering over my house and giant Sycamore trees last evening.  Most were very high in the air.  Some were lower.  They were headed southeast.

They're coming through!!!  They did not cover the sky with my naked eye, but large numbers came through Kingfisher this a.m.  At 9:50 a.m. went out to check the garden, and I only counted about 12 Monarchs.  I looked up into the sky for a few minutes, and low and behold they were there.  High in the sky, circling around trying to catch the light north wind current, and then vanished from sight.  From 10:00- 10:20 a.m., I counted 1-4 Monarchs, mostly singles, every 5 seconds.  At 10:45 a.m. and at 11:00 a.m., I was still counting at least 1-3 Monarchs every 5 secs.  What a sight to behold.

Monarchs, raptors & White Pelicans are all going over,noon until 3:00 p.m. very very high.They are only tiny little dots or orange specs in my 10x Swarovski.  There seems to be about 10 Monarchs every 5-10 seconds.
Saw 5-6 Monarchs in flight.

Finally the migration is beginning to come to our area.  Today from 2PM to 4:15PM I observed a total of 10 Monarchs......they were not flying together BUT solo flights during this 2+ hr. duration.  All flying in a S to SW direction, temp.70 degrees, humidity @ 40%, wind was calm...no wind, the height of their flights was all between 10-25 ft..  Overall a totally beautiful day with full sunshine and great visibility (10 miles).

I went out this afternoon for a few hours of photography at Lexington WMA and to watch the Monarchs. Hundreds of Monarchs were dropping out of the sky and tanking up on nectar at around 4-5 PM. They were mostly on aster and a few on goldenrod. After 5 PM, most were observed flying south, some at eye level and a few way up and barely visible. The higher they were, the faster and straighter they flew more than likely aided by the wind.
Just stepped outside for a few moments and saw at least a dozen monarchs in less than five minutes time, all headed south.  All were flying at approximately 15-25 feet above the ground.

THEY'RE HERE!!! Woohoo! I was outside from approximately 4:40 until 7:20 p.m. and observed the following numbers:

4:40 - 6:15 p.m.
From 4:40 until approx. 6:15 p.m. I saw them at the rate of about 1 every 5 minutes, which doesn't sound like a lot...but I had not been seeing any at all, so that was a huge increase. They were flying, slightly higher than the tree tops, in a south/southwestward direction.

6:15- 6:50 p.m
The numbers picked up sharply around 6:15 p.m. until about 6:50 p.m. From about 3 to 5 per minute beginning about 6:15 p.m. until about 6:40, and then 5 to 10 per minute until about 6:50 p.m. They were still slightly over the tree tops but occasionally dipping down a little lower....but still not coming down to nectar on the flowers. They were still headed west/southwest, although perhaps a little more westward than earlier.

6:50-7:10 p.m.
From about 6:50 until about 7:10, the party was on! I stood in our driveway, with our woodland about 75' to my north and the neighbors' woodland about 60' to my south. The monarchs were coming through at the rate of about 25 per minute from 6:50 to 7:00 p.m. and then at about 50 per minute until 7:10 or so.

7:10 to 7:15 p.m.
Then they tapered off pretty rapidly to about 5 to 10 per minute from 7:10 to 7:15 or so and then 1 to 4 per minute until about 7:20. Then, that was it. It was over. The last wave, from 6:50 onward, was clearly seeking a tree to roost in. They flew down into the trees and sort of flew from tree to tree as they went from our woods to the neighbors' woodsand I lost sight of them. (There were approximately 300+ monarchs.) I think some of them stayed in the oaks and pecans on the edge of our woods, but it was too dark to tell for sure. I'll check those trees at first light in the morning.

It was an amazing couple of hours, especially as sunset approached. It was about 82 degrees at 4:30, and there was alight wind out of the north, about 5-7 m.p.h. By 7 p.m., it probably had dropped to 73 or 74 degrees and the wind had virtually stopped blowing.

During the very late 1990s and very earliest 2000s, we had hundreds, if not thousands, roost on a very tall and mature dying elm on the edge of our woods. They covered the almost bare limbs to the extent that the tree looked like it had leaves again. It was an exquisitely beautiful sight....and we have not seen those numbers here in over half a decade.

6:00 a.m. (October 1)
I think mine may have chosen the neighbor's woods, and that area is so snake-infested, I cannot get near those trees to see if they did. Of course, maybe I'll find some roosting in our trees when the sun comes up....DHthought they did, but I think they flew "through" our trees on their way next door. It is 46 degrees on my back porch, as of 6 a.m., so I think I can get out and check my own trees before the snakes start stirring.

Apparently our overnight low temp. (42 degrees) kept the monarchs hanging in their trees for a few hours this morning until it warmed up. I didn't see any the first hour or so after sunrise, but finally began seeing some activity....monarchs coming up out of the crowns of the trees where they'd probably roosted overnight.

9:30 a.m
By 9:30 a.m., they were leaving the trees, nectaring in the pastures (and our yard and garden!), and flying southwestward. For about a half hour, I saw them at the astonishing (for me!) rate of 25 to 50 per minute (or maybe even a little more). At that point it was about 55 degrees, no wind, endless visability except for low fog banks over parts of the Red River. They stayed low, nectaring, as they flew towards the southwest. That lasted 20 or 25 minutes, and then it dropped to about 10 to 15 per minute.

11 a.m.
By 11 a.m., the temperature was up to about 60 degrees, still great visability and no wind. I guess most of the monarchs were flying high by then, because I was only seing 1 to 5 per minute.

So, a pretty good start to the day. I plan to be in and out a lot this afternoon, so maybe I'll see more. Tonight I plan to be outside from late afternoon to sunset to see if we have a repeat of last night's numbers. I think I'll just take my dinner outside and eat on the patio, 'cause last night I stayed out so long watching themthat I skipped dinner (and woke up starving this morning!).

From 10:15AM to 10:45AM we saw 299 Monarch butterflies pass over our house. While most were flying south, some where flying north. Others seemed to be flying around in a circle. Several landed in our yard and ate from the flowers in our grass.

I have been keeping track of how many monarchs we have seen in a 30 min period since 10/01 in order to compare with the amount we saw. Each day I have counted about 30 to 40, and all of these days have seemed to be significantly less than what we were observing on 10/01.

The migration is definitely on here. I am seeing about 100 monarchs an hour coming through, mostly in small groups. Winds are light and westerly, temperature in the 70's. BFs are traveling below 40 feet and some just above the ground. I have about a dozen at a time in my yard stopping to nectar before going on. Some are not stopping and are continuing to move south. They appear to be having trouble catching currents to help flight.

This morning as my husband was finishing up his bike ride, he spotted a large number of monarchs headed south. In the course of about five minutes, he saw approximately 30-40 monarchs pass by him. He also spotted several others as he made his way home later.
About 5:00pm, my Dad and I watched the sky, and in about 15 minutes time saw 27 monarchs 30- 40 feet of the ground flying south at a pretty good pace.
Our classroom saw 21 monarchs in 30 minutes.
In 20 minutes we saw several hundred on 10/01 in the morning flying over.

The Pottsville High School Environmental Science class conducted a 15 minute count today between 1100 -1200 CDST.  A total of eight monarchs were observed flying SSW at about 20 feet in altitude.  The weather was very sunny, light easterly winds, and 78 degrees F.  The same students have been seeing Monarchs all week during and after school hours. It is our opinion that we are seeing an increase in activity from the previous week.
We saw about 30-35 flying south near Joe Pool Lake!   This was our first sightings since the spring!!  :)
I saw at least 15 moving south through the center of the city. I acually saw three at one glance. Estimated observing time about thirty minutes. They are really on the move today.
Hundreds of monarchs are stopping along our coastline to feast on seashore goldenrod which is in full bloom.

Here's a summary of counts and observations for Sept 30 thought Oct 2, 2008.

Note all count observations taken for ten minutes at 10 am and 20 minutes at noon.

Sept 30: Singles 12 per hour
Oct 1: Singles 16 per hour
Oct 2: Close singles (I saw 3 at one glance). 30 per hour

I definitely noted the aerodynamics of their flight as they would funnel southerly close to our 20 x 150 x 750 building. Wind NE 10 mph. They glided along side and caught the up-draft on the west side of building and shot up 40-50 feet by the time they reached the south end of the building while hardly batting a wing.

Had quite a few monarchs moving just west of Tulsa yesterday at about 5:00 PM.  Basically trying to dodge them while driving.  No large concentrations, just a constant background of 30-40 in view at any given time for a distance of about 8 miles.
There were lots of butterflies all over our yard and everywhere!
We were outside about 15 minutes and saw 44 monarch butterflies.
Noticeable directional movement southwest through downtown area.  About 1 Monarch per 2 minutes average throughout day.  No other Monarchs observed through 10/03/08!
A large number of monarchs are in the Wilmot, AR area. This is the same area that had thousands roosting in the past couple of years.

Our 3rd grade class has been  eating outside for a week waiting to see migration. Today in 30 minutes we tallied 12 monarchs slowly soaring south over our heads.  This was the first day we have seen amounts in double digits.  There was a mild southern breeze and the monarchs flew about 6o feet above the ground.

While outside in our school butterfly garden, we saw about 25 monarchs in 5 minutes sipping nectar. This is definitely more than the 2 or 3 we have been seeing. There were 3 monarch caterpillars in the perennials.
I have a butterfly/bee friendly garden in my front yard. There are over 50 monarchs at any given time over this past week in our garden.
The verbena and the zinnias were covered with Monarchs in the community garden this afternoon...More than I've ever seen at once there...maybe 15-20.  They were busy nectering.

I have a senior level biogeography class monitoring monarchs this fall. We have transects and stations throughout our city. Unfortunately, we haven'tseen many butterflies. The class complained about the numbers of hourswithout sightings, so we stopped the official count last week, only to findthe maximum numbers on Sunday.It was the largest number of migrating monarchs seen in a day so far this fall.

Over the weekend, folks at the JMU field hockey matches reported seeing monarchs everywhere. Yesterday, at the JMU golf challenge, golfers reported seeing about 2 dozen during their 18 holes (3.5 hours). I saw an average of 10 per hour (in my yard/garden...I'm a power gardener) and that lasted for 5 hours.
My sister reported seeing approximately 20 monarchs flying over the boardwalk in Ocean City, NJ. She said she saw more later in the afternoon. Nice weather, high 60s to low 70s.

10 to 15 Monarchs were observed feeding at my butterfly bush this afternoon. Being an avid gardener, I was taking a stroll around the yard and stopped at the bush when I noticed a couple of monarchs.  As I took a closer look, I noticed that it was covered with them.  More than I've had before. Some of them took flight, fluttered above it for a minute or two then, returned to the bush for another sip of nectar.   It was quite a thrilling site.

100+ Monarchs nectaring in my butterfly garden, and roosting in the trees.  Held over due to strong southerly winds.  Loving the more sheltered areas nectaring on Gregg's blue mistflower, Mexican sunflower, golden crownbeard, trop. mw, Mexican flame vine, and Salvia indigo spires.  My favorite time of the year.

Not only were 3 of the 4 Monarchs from yesterday visible on the milkweed this morning, but, many Monarchs seen all over town today in all neighborhoods on the east side of town, central and west side. Most were flying westerly. Some were seen nectaring in the central downtown area and near the trainstation:-)

I'll know more about the thirsty ones that have been hanging out here in the morning. The weather was sunny and cool, 67 degrees at 8:55 p.m. (now) with clear skies. This is our best flower season for nectar and all insects are getting their fill, as well as the hummingbirds, spiders and lizards.No humidity, the best month of every year is here with us now!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We were fishing on Lake Erie approximately 7 miles out from Beaver Creek. There was a Northeast wind of 10-15 mph. Around 11:00 AM I looked up and noticed a Monarch riding the wind. I continued to pay attention and over a period of a few hours saw almost 200 Monarchs migrate through. They were flying anywhere from 10-80 feet above the lake. They flapped a few times then would glide for 20 or more yards. A few seemed to be playing in the wind, gliding then doing a 360 then continuing on in the original direction.

Right after sundown we saw dozens of monarchs landing in the cypress trees on Tranquility Island in Louise Hays Park in Kerrville. They were coming from the north but then moving in somewhat circular patterns between the rows of trees, so it was hard to get a good count. I will go back early in the morning to try to get photos.

About 100 monarchs eagerly nectaring on New England aster at Eastern Point, Gloucester MA on a clear sunny day after a week of rain.  They were joined by clouded sulfurs, a red admiral and painted lady. A glorious fall sight!

In Grapevine, Texas (between Dallas and Fort Worth) we have a big influx today with the arrival of the cold front. They all seem to be nectaring heavily and are fairly easy to catch since they are fighting to hold on to the plants with all the wind.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We’ve noticed a few thousand west of Jacksboro on our property in trees this weekend.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We've been tagging and releasing this morning for an elementary science monarch program, and saw 100s pass overhead during our morning program in Denton, north of Dallas/Fort Worth!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Migraation started this morning!  I spotted 34 Monarch's within a minute and seeing about 5 every few seconds.  We also have pictures of a chrysalis where you could make out the Monarch inside and many caterpillar's on milkweed.  WOW!

During a 1 hour period from 9:45am to 10:45am I saw 68 Monarchs. I saw the first 26 within the first 15 minutes during a drive home. The remainder were seen in my neighborhood. Most were seen in singles but in some areas there were as many as 5 or 6 at a time. The majority of the Monarchs were seen in flight moving south to southwest. Some were seen nectaring on wildflowers in the Aster family. The weather was sunny with clear skies and little to no wind. Temperatures were in the low 70s.
Traveling from Dallas to Houston, we pulled over to eat our lunch in Corsicana.  Over two minutes, we counted 17 monarchs.  What a thrill.

Including my two other reports today (King George and Dahlgren)I saw a total of 25 monarchs --22 total in my yard on Mathias Point along the east bank of the Potomac River (river is 3 miles wide)21 of butterflies were seen between 3 and 5:15pm Monarchs 17 to 25 stopped to feed- #17 on a pink Ohio buckeye tree flower (tree confused-put out a few flowers this fall),#'s 18 & 19 & 25 on purple butterfly bush, rest were on lilac colored asters. A yellow hornet began attacking the ones on the asters--I knocked him off 3 different monarchs--unfortunately couldn't kill it.I had not seen this behavior before. One monarch appeared stunned by the attack and did not fly on. A neighbor burned a tree with hornet's nest in it this week--don't know if this caused behavior observed.

I am seeing a huge migration through Avery Ranch (NW Austin 78717) today. They are so beautiful, they keep stopping to feed/rest in my garden.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Between 4:15 and 5:30 80+ monarchs flying at high altitude. Only eight came down to nectar site in front yard. Location is six blocks south of White Rock Lake in Dallas.

We don't get many reports from east of Austin. The caller said they were coming though one a minute this afternoon. More came though this morning.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Just a note to let you know that I've got around 450-500 monarchs in my yard right now (1.5 acres) feeding mostly on Pentas, Gregg's Mistflower (E. greggii) and Mexican Flamevine (S. confusus).

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game
Today in northeast Oklahoma the weather was very clear and the monarchs floated by all day. I was at the same location for about 12 hours and would estimate over 500 crossing my path.

10/8--> saw 100s of monarchs passing overhead during our morning elementary school citizen science monarch program with 4th grade; skies were clear, winds very low. We released tagged individuals as well.

10/9--> today winds have picked up I'd say at least 15 mph at times; During our morning monarch release at school we saw increasing amounts of monarchs by 11:00 when temps began warming up. Saw 3 wild monarchs passing thru from 9:30-11 am, and we released more monarchs as well.

Wed may have been the peak, but as the winds from the South sloooowww down I suspect we'll see more #s...JN
6:56 pm - 7:04pm: We counted 100 Monarchs flying over our yard in 8 minutes. Most flew directly over our trees/roof without stopping, while a handful flew lower (tree level). None stopped.

Last Saturday on a sunny morning, temps in the 70's, between 8:30 and 9:30 noticed about 30 monarchs coming across the soccer fields.  Did not find a roost, but did find their breakfast site!  Abundant wildflowers in a "valley" on their SW route- ageratum, asters, goldenrod.  Most I've ever seen in a hour.
We saw 24 monarchs in about 25 minutes - all heading south!
The last few days I've spotted numerous monarch in and around Bartlesville.

I'm in North Tulsa, just N of 244. Monarchs are flying by at a rate of about 4 per minute now. I don't have binoculars but i'm seeing a lot of birds flying high and acting as if they're chasing something, are they eating butterflies?
About 4 o'clock there was a group of between 75-100 monarchs feeding in my neighbor's yard on some type of plant with purple blooms; it appeared to be some type of mint, maybe

For the last 3 days we have seen a pretty good number of Monarchs passing through Benbrook, with the largest number so far coming through this morning and late afternoon today. The beauties have been fluttering into my yard feasting on the numerous flowers in my garden and also the hummingbird feeder. What a blessing!

Today was a beautiful day, in the low 70's with a very brisk SW wind. I had a couple of Monarchs in the yard and tagged them. Then I visited Harkness Park again and there were hundreds. They have a beautiful cutting garden with lots of flowers still in bloom. The Monarchs were on an assortment of flowers, but they were really thick on the tall cutting dahlias. Especially the single yellow and white ones. I tagged over 30. It was so easy, I didn't need a net, just gently plucked them off the flowers, tagged and released..no stress at all!  Maryann From Gardenweb Butterfly Forum
Tons of Monarchs observed in the open country feeding on Cowpen Daisy's. They showed up heavy last week and are still coming in. YMCA Camp Grady Spruce Outdoor Education program.
school: Ymca camp grady spruce outdoor education program

comments: We starting seeing one or two monarchs yesterday and this morning we were seeing a dozen  or more everytime we went out.There is no milkweed blooming though due to drought conditions in area? Will they keep going? We observed monarchs flying low over Hwy 306 and FM 2673. We also sighted monarchs at the Hidden Valley sports Park and Canyon Lake Dam areas. But no milkwweed is blooming anywhere in these areas. It was abundant during spring migration but is non existent now.

My sister called from McKinney, TX, about 40 miles north of Dallas to report that the monarchs were passing through there mid-morning by the "hundreds!"

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I've been working as a Hawk-watcher at Hornsby Bend, in Austin, so I've had the opportunity to watch the Monarchs coming through over the past few days.Yesterday, I counted over 171, with a peak of 37 between 10 and 11 AM.

Today,(10/10) I counted 544, with the peak occurring again between 10 and 11, when I counted 275 Monarchs. Please note, I am supposed to be watching for migrating hawks, so I'm scanning the sky with binoculars. What I did was to count Monarchs as I scanned for birds, as well as those I saw passing closer (non-magnified). Since I was looking for birds much of the time, I know I missed many butterflies.

What was interesting was the pattern of flight abundance: both days, Monarchs were most abundant in the morning, and the flight tapered off as the afternoon progressed. I haven't seen anything about the migration this year, so I'm not sure if I should expect these numbers to continue, or not. Either way, it's been very nice to see all these critters!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I saw some today on the way to New Braunfels. Just south of theintersection of RR32 and Purgatory Road, 2 or 3 miles west of Wimberley,there is a field on the west side of the road with masses of Maximiliansunflowers. I stopped to take a photograph, and the sunflowers werealive with Monarchs. There could easily have been hundreds browsing onthe sunflowers.

Got a report of monarchs "all over the place" over in Coleman Co., TX...

I had a 150 or so Monarchs Wed. a.m., passing here in Utopia.There were about 300 passing here on Thursday 10/9.Today only a half dozen passed but there were 2 dozen at the library garden whereas previous high there this fall/week was 5.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game
At sunset at our house outside of Junction 100's of Monarch's were flying around, the event was less visable the next day, and today I did not notice any.
In St.Simons I saw at least 100 to 150 monarchs in 10 minutes!They were flying everywere, going in and out of trees.

Hundred have been "Waying in" on the cosmos at our garden in Jonestown.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department

I have a good friend who is vacationing at Holden Beach on the North Carolina coast, close to the city of Shallotte. The home she's staying at is right on the beach and she called today to report that there were several dozen Monarchs nectaring on some flowers next to the house and around that area, along with other butterflies. She didn't count them but was amazed at how many there were. From her description it sounds like some migrants might be moving through there.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We had hundreds if not thousands of monarchs come through our grove this fall!  It was beautful.  We could stand and count 40-200 many days.The monarchs were here from Sept. 9-23.On the 22nd several children tagging noticed that that particular day they tagged mostly males.

I have been an Interpretive Park Ranger on Spectacle Island, part of the Boston Harbor National Recreational Area all Summer.  I have reported a few sightings of Monarchs during the Summer including our earliest which was in June (probably an adult from overwintering chrysalus). Since the Monday after Labor Day, I have been the groundskeeper on Spectacle Island.  On Monday, October 13, 2008, a large number of Monarchs had arrive in the last few days.  I saw approximately 100 to 125 in fields of asters.  Unfortunately I do not know the spoecies of asters but I will find out.  Last year when a large number were seen by me and a High School Field Group at Lovells Island (another Island in the BHNRA)in the Seaside Goldenrod, it was the same time.  The Seaside Goldenrod has seemed to have prematurely died back.  I won't be able to make any more observations this Season as the boats have been discontinued as of this past Monday.  Good Luck, Carl Johnson
school: Retired from south boston high school

comments: Was just outside at 5pm, it has been raining lightly all day but has recently stopped.  Very overcast but the sky is full of monarchs heading south.  Very cool. There were at least 40 visible at any given moment.  I was scanning the sky in all directions and you could see them very high up and then some were flying as low as 10 ft.  I stayed outside for about 15 minutes and it was just a steady stream. There were a great deal of birds flying around as well and I was hoping it wasnt going to be a feeding opportunity for them, but I never saw a bird actually go after any of them.  Frisco is about 20 miles due north of Dallas for a geographic perspective.

Flock of the little critters.  Hundreds drift with the southerly wind current.  I am sitting in a classroom 13-stories up with about 31 classmates watch these little guys flutter past the window at a high rate of speed.
It was overcast and cool this afternoon. At 5:30 I went outside and saw the butterflies flying fairly high from north to south. I watched for at least 20 minutes and they were still going by.

Amazing and my first time. Hundreds have flown over my house in just an hours or so. Just awesome they way the drift and the heights they can fly and still be seen. Thank you for this website, totally cool, even if I'm far from school age.
Thousands of monarchs flew through our backyard at about 3:30 this afternoon. It is now 7:00 pm and there are still a few stragglers coming along!
We were in FAR, FAR North Dallas around 5:30 - 6:00pm and we saw hundreds of butterflies going South, pretty spread out, at first we thought it was only a few and watched about 20 minutes.
I am a pilot based in Atlanta Ga.  I have seen many Monarchs flying around the Atlanta Airport.  As we are taxiing for takeoff they just float by harmlessly and just continue on their way to Mexico

Oct 15 I noticed a flight at 4 p.m. after returning to the ridge from a couple hours in town down in the valley where there were lots of nectaring Monarchs but I didn't see indications of a flight.... There were 200-600 per minute for about 2 hours, with some still passing SW at 7 p.m., almost dark.  At least at minimum there were 20,000 that passed over in 3 hours, probably many more.

With the frontal passage (2:45 here) and the wind turn, there are thousands of Monarchs passing over Utopia, most quite high, and on the winds doing 20+ MPH.Bearing SSW to SW best they can in the wind.

I panned with binocs. Going across 90 degrees of skies, one binoc width, it took 20-seconds to count one hundred.One field of view pan. There are a hundred of these FOV's in the sky, and it is full of Monarchs as far as I can see.Sometimes there are 25 in a FOV at once.going back outside to be awed.

Well it was 20,000 Monarchs at least, just that passed around me,4 p.m. to 7 p.m.. At times it was 200-600 per minute, for over an hour.I don't know how wide the river was, I could see them a half mile on either side of me. It was very likely many many more, and the number estimated I feel is a conservative minimum. WOW !!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department

I've had 3 reports from friends about "many" monarchs streaming through the Dallas area with the cold front.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I've had 3 reports from friends about "many" monarchs streaming through the Dallas area with the cold front.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

The cold front just came through Grapevine, Texas (between Dallas and Fort Worth). It rained all morning. The temps have dropped to 66 degrees with 3.1 mph N/NE winds. There are monarchs everywhere!I counted 35 over my house in one minute and it has continued like this for an hour now. They are all flying southwest. None are nectaring, just soaring with the front. Beautiful!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Yesterday I counted 196 on my commute home of about 15 miles.  The majority were flying quite high, making them harder to notice. Since I was driving, I could only count when I was stopped so there must have been hundreds and hundreds more.  A cold front came through last night and I thought they would be gone this morning (Oct. 16) but at noon I counted 8 more. Not like yesterday.  My friends think I'm nuts, but I wait for this with anticipation every year.
4.45pm cst Many passing by ( 75-100), south west direction at high altitude. My grandfather was moved by the beauty of it all.

Wednesday morning, while sitting on a third floor porch watching the ocean, we started to notice the monarchs. Often two or three at a time flying along the coast. They flew close to the building. In ten minutes, there were about 100 monarchs. This took place in Garden City, SC.

We have just become interested in this spectacular event!!! We began watching for monarchs on Monday, October 13. We saw approximately 20 -25 at that time. (The 4th grade GT class saw three monarchs at 11 a.m. The 5th grade GT class saw 10 monarchs at 1:30 p.m.) While I'm not certain how many monarchs were here before the 13th, we've only seen one this week (as of October 22nd).
This afternoon between 4 and 4:30 we were seeing 15+ monarchs in 10 minutes, flying 20-40 ft above our trees in the back yard.
I have noticed between 10 and 20 monarchs feeding on my butterfly bushes each day this week- thank goodness I still have lots of blooms available!

Anyone looking at the Crucita [Eupatorium odorata] in Falcon's garden late this afternoon would assume the flowers are orange, thanks to 100's of Monarchs that came in on today's north wind.  The ones that couldn't find an empty spot on the Crucita settled on the Betony! [Eupatorium betonicifolium]

 Photos showing an entire shrub do not show enough detail, so I zoomed in on a trio to show you how tightly they are grouped on the flowers.   http://www.flickr.com/photos/franzabirder/2947479897/

 This is the 1st time I have seen a main migrating body of Monarchs in the park   What a thrill.  I hope they will still be here when tomorrow's tour group from the Butterfly Festival arrives!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department

Today was another good Monarch day. As before, I was out doing the hawk-watch, but counted passing Monarchs as well. A couple of hours, my butterfly count was not so good, because I was concentrating on trying to find birds, but I still logged 478 Monarchs for the day. I know there were many more than this. My highest hour was 10 - 11 AM, when I counted 161 butterflies. In 7.5 hours, the average was 64 butterflies per hour.

An interesting sight for me was a group of about 14 Monarchs in a "kettle", much like the hawks. It was quite windy all day, so I was surprised to see the butterflies doing this.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department

In past seasons, we have seen a heavy amount of Monarchs passing by our home. During the past week, I have seen a few every day but this evening we noticed a lot more. I counted 70 in the time span of about five minutes.

My fifth grade class in Carrollton, Texas was at recess on Friday, October 17, 2008, and saw a mass of around 250-300 monarchs migrating at 1:15 p.m.The monarchs were flying due south in a huge group with a few "outliers" that were closer to the ground.  The first student who saw the monarchs was on top of the playground equipment and immediately yelled to alert his classmates about the butterflies.  The rest of the class was able to observe this magnificent sight, and then recorded the experience in their science notebook.

Las monarcas ya están aquí!!!!!! Tengo dos horas viendo a las mariposas son cientos, pero no llevan vuelo direccionado, sino están en remolinos o unas volando al este y otras al oeste, van desde una altura de 6 metros hasta solo visibles con binoculares. No las puedo contar porque son muchas y están dando vueltas. El viento no las está ayudando ya que sopla principalmente de 4-13Km/h from SE aunque a ratos varía de dirección e intensidad. El cielo está también variable amaneció muy nublado y en ratos se asoma el sol, pero vuelve a nublarse. La temperatura es de 16ºC en este momento.Igual que el año pasado las mariposas monarcas fueron notorias en día 18 de octubre.Me están hablando por telefono de diferentes partes de la ciudad, que tambien las están viendo desde las 11 de la mañana.Están bajando a mi jardín algunas monarcas pero también Julias y Malaquitas que no son comunes de la zona.A la tarde voy a buscar racimos.

Courtesy of Correo Real

San Pedro Garza García, Nuevo Leon.
Hoy 18 de Octubre es el primer día que veo pasar mas de 150 monarcas por minuto acá en Olinalá. La gran mayoría volando muy alto y unas cuantas bajo (a la altura del techo como a 7m.) junto con libélulas, azufres, picudas, pero estas últimas tres en pequeña proporción. Es el primer día de sol y poco mas frío en el termómetro de mi jardín marca 16ºc. Seguiré reportandote.

Courtesy of Correo Real

100's of monarchs going over my house in Utley today. And they [darn] sure are not Queens either.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department

I happened to look out the kitchen window to the north at 11:36 this morning and saw a migrating monarch zip by. Grabbed my cell phone and clipboard and ran to the front yard.

My highest count was 7 in one minute.
The first 30 minute segment I had 87.
Second segment of the hour: 72
For an hour's total of 159
Average of 26.66 per minute, but graphed would have created an undulation (1/3/4/3/5/7/1/2/4/4/6/5/4) so that they seemed to come in waves.

Sighting in Pawleys Island, Sc. While fishing off the bank I noticed Monarch butterflies flying south. They were not in largequantities, but were many of them flying, all in the same direction. I came home and looked up this wed site, registered and now am reporting the sighting.

While vacationing on Hilton Head Island Oct.13-17, we witnessed a large Monarch migration on the east shore of the island during the morning hours of Oct. 16th. Thousands of Monarchs flew south along the coast for several hours.  We also saw several on the morning of the 17th, but not in nearly as large a number.  It was a beautiful sight!

Las monarcas me encontraron!!. El sábado 18 de octubre a las 17:00 hrs., estaba entrando a mi casa en Cd. Victoria y me detuve a observar la floración de un árbol de mamey que tengo en mi jardín.Me llamo la atención una mariposa amarilla que estaba volando entre sus hojas y un colibrí haciendo de su vuelo un espectáculo natural, de pronto una monarca se acerco y robo mi atención, la seguí con la mirada y cual fue mi sorpresa que al subir la mirada, en el cielo había muchas volando en grupos de 3, otras aisladas pero integradas a un grupo, salí de mi casa para poder observar mejor y el espectáculo fue un regalo para mis ojos, en este momento se unió mi colega Blanca Zapata y entre las dos contamos todas las que pasaron durante media hora solo para tener una referencia de la cantidad que eran. Contamos en media hora aproximadamente 537 monarcas (17:27 a las 17:57 hrs.) , el 85% volaban a una altura promedio de 6m, el 15% restante a mas de 12m. El conteo lo hicimos tomado como referencia un cable de luz (todo lo que pasaba por ahí de norte a sur) y en un espacio de 30 m. de ancho, la distancia que hay entre los postes. La temperatura era de 28 grados centígrados, no había viento y realmente era una agradable tarde.Las monarcas siguieron pasando y las observé hasta las 7 de la noche. Aprovecho para comentarte que tenemos una red de observadores en Jaumave dirigido por mi colega Arabella Farach, ellos ya tienen los reportes que te van a enviar por este medio. Estamos tomando fotos y video que les vamos a compartir.

Courtesy of Correo Real

18 de Octubre, Saltillo Coahuila
Espero que mi noticia cause alegría, ya que el mediodía del sábadoobservé un total de 80 mariposas por minuto, esto fue en el parajeconocido como la colonia Lomas de Lourdes espero volver a observar esta maravilla natural.

Courtesy of Correo Real

18 de Octubre: Monterrey, Nuevo Leon
Estoy muy emocionado, hice conteos de monarcas de mínimo 60 por minuto. Nuestro monitoreo empezó desde inicios del mes de octubre y no había encontrado nada, hasta el día de hoy. Estuve desde las 6:10 AM en la entrada de Huasteca, de ahí me moví a la zona del entronque Villa de García-Carretra Saltillo, (llamada por la libre a Saltillo) se observaron cientos o miles de mariposas a las 8:45 AM. Después me dirigí al Punto b: otra zona con muchos cientos y miles de mariposas, el lugar es por faldas del cerro del Topo, por la zona de CROC de Almazán, hora de observación de 9:15- 10:15 AM. A las 10:26 AM ya estaba en San Nicolás (punto C) a la altura de la colonia Anáhuac, ahí se percibían miles de ellas a diferentes alturas, perron y bello el evento .....Esperar todo el año desde marzo hasta estas fechas y ver cuando están llegando es muy reconfortante, bueno para uno que se dedica a esto, pero yaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa llegaron las primerassssssssssssss monarcasssssssss a Garcia, Santa Catarina y Monterrey, San Nicolás y bueno déjeme hablar con mis contactos en campo y en ciudad para ver que mas encontramos El día amaneció con temperatura de 19-20 grados y empezó a elevar la temperatura como a las 7:40 AM hasta calentar después de las 10:00 AM. Entonces empezamos a ver más mariposas.

Courtesy of Correo Real

18 de Octubre: Monclova, Coahuila
Hola, esta semana, han estado pasando las mariposas por Monclova, de forma espaciada durante el día, volando según la hora a diferentes alturas... menos jueves y viernes, que amaneció con llovizna y fresco por el frente frío que nos llegó.... TAMBIEN LAS MALAS HAY QUE DECIRLAS.....Viajamos a la Cd. de Saltillo y en el camino, por toda la carretera observamos mariposas, y había mas entre el kilómetro 60 y 70, que es una pequeña serranía intermedia, pero aquí viene lo bueno, había muchas muertas por la carretera, atropelladas por el trafico vehicular, comentábamos, de esa manía de las mariposas de volar por la carretera, tanto volar para venir a quedar atropelladas..... Sin embargo creo que debería haber otra forma de protegerlas en las carreteras y autopistas, es bonito el slogan de si ves mariposas volar a 60 debes viajar o algo así.... pero las carreteras cada vez las hacen mas rápidas y los conductores viajan, mínimo a 120 km x hora, y aún así muchos otros rebasan a mas de esa velocidad... es peligrosísimo en carreteras rápidas, con trafico intenso, rápido y pesado, viajar y/o bajar la velocidad a 60 km x hora Creo que la concientizacion entre organizaciones, empresas, escuelas y dependencias oficiales debería ser mas estrecha, para que en un tiempo prudente rinda frutos.... Declárome mariposida, al menos unas 5 creo que me lleve de frente....

19 de Octubre: Guadalupe, Nuevo Leon
El día de hoy, desde las 9 AM hasta las 12, encontré rumbo al municipio de Villa de García muchas mariposas monarcas, de perdido unas 30 a 35 por minuto, realicé el recorrido desde la carretera Laredo o Colombia hasta el entronque de Villa de García y si confirme algo que tenia duda desde el año pasado, que era que llegaban de Saltillo por el lado de entre el cerro de las Mitras y espaldas del cerro de Topo Chico, o sea que entre esas paredes llega una ola de mariposas monarcas y si lo confirmé. El día de hoy, estuve, desde la mañana hasta las 6 pm, fui hasta las faldas de la sierra o bueno valle en donde están las grutas de Garcia y si vi mariposas en el recorrido, pero muy poco adentro del cañón ( de momento no se el nombre de esa sierra pero la confirmo mas delante) pero a las faldas de esa sierra si era imperante la ola de monarcas dirigiéndose hacia el corredor así lo llaman de Topo-Mitras, muy interesante en verdad....

La gente que esta en mi equipo y que me esta apoyando en el monitoreo , vieron ya monarcas pasando por Puerto Genovevo, Santiago, desde las 11-12 PM hasta en la tarde y con buenos números.Estoy por confirmar datos de los profesores CONAFE que me están ayudando.

Courtesy of Correo Real
While kayaking on Inks Lake, we counted 57 within a 30-minute period flying 10-20 feet above the water. We saw several more throughout the day but did not take count.

My children and I counted about 13 Monarchs a minute traveling along the same path though our backyard.  This occurred just about all day long.  Although we have nectar plants, no butterflies stopped; they just kept traveling.

We're experiencing a goodly flow of monarchs drifting through on very slight air movement (noon). They are all moving due South. No front here yet, maybe later this evening. 86dF.

From 11:46 through 12:23 (37 minutes) we had 115 monarchs moving through a 60' wide space. The first minute we had 11 monarchs, the the next busiest was 7. Just over 3 per minute average. What I don't know is when the flow started.

The front came through here at 4:22 p.m. Lots of bluster and all the monarchs that had been drifting around got blown south.Doubtful that we'll have even small clusters in the trees tonight.

Randy L reported that he had a pasture on the Fournier Ranch at the north end of Quemado Valley with more than 1,500 nectaring on Coreopsis at sunset.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Light flow of monarchs continued across the area. On the peninsula to the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway, monarchs were coming from 60 deg (ENE) and leaving out across Lavaca Bay on a heading of 240 deg all day. The best flow was between 10:30 am and 2:00 pm before the wind switched from light N to 10 mph E. The best count was an average of 18 per 10 minutes starting at 10:30 (which would have been 108/hr. had it sustained) and 12 per 10 min starting at 12:30. Later in the day, it was strange, but there would be a burst of threeto four in row, ten to twenty feet apart, nose to tail, then nothing for several minutes but the next right down the same path in the empty sky. Altus saw several crossing the roads and streets in Victoria, Moulton, and then on the drive back to Port Lavaca this afternoon, even had one want to be a hood ornament at a traffic light in Victoria ... stopped, then flew on 'tho.

De paseo con mi familia por los campos de girasolillos de la Universidad Autónoma Antonio Narro contamos 300 mariposas alimentándose en esas flores, esto fue el domingo 19, día soleado con una temperatura de 30ºC

Courtesy of Correo Real

El sábado estuve viendo grupos de mariposas monarcas, volando como a 25 metros de altura, eran grupos de 25 a 30 individuos, volaban rumbo al oriente de la ciudad, esto fue a las 2: 30 PM de la tarde en la colonia, fraccionamiento Las Torres, pude apreciar, casi durante dos horas, estos grupos, lástima que no tenia cámara fotográfica.

El sábado 18 vimos una gran cantidad de monarcas eran muchas y difícil de contar, calculamos alrededor de 100 por minuto, a temprana hora volaban bajo de 4 a 6 metros. Para el mediodía empezaron a verse más arriba. Y muchas de ellas se veían como puntos en las nubes. Fue algo verdaderamente espectacular. El domingo 19 solo observamos grupos aislados de 5 a 10 mariposas.

Courtesy of Correo Real

¿Como están? Quiero comentarles que el Lunes 20 aproximadamente a las9.45 a.m. en la zona conocida como la alameda aquí en Santiago, me encontré algo maravilloso, vi como se iban elevando en remolino las monarcas eran aproximadamente unas 150 estaba calentando el sol y salían de los sabinos era un espectáculo. Por otra parte en mi casa tengo 10 asclepias y ya tienen 2 orugas que las veo crecer, y en la estación que tenemos en Ecología me encontré ayer Martes 21 una monarca a las 1.45 p.m. También cada vez que salgo de mi casa a la Villa de Santiago o al Cercado me encuentro con ellas el Domingo de 6:15 a 7:45 p.m. conté 55 monarcas de Margaritas al Cercado. Quiero mandarles un saludo a todos los interesados en esta especie

El día de ayer jueves 23 de octubre, Efraín Lucio Montiel, me reportó una gran cantidad de mariposas descansando en árboles, especialmente eucaliptos, esto en El carmen Ramos Arizpe Coahuila con coordenadas ya enviadas. Por la mañana de este viernes 24 de octubre contamos entre8:45 y nueve en lapsos de un minuto las siguientes cantidades de mariposas volando 28, 22, 20, 3, 9, 24, 34, 20. Entre nueve y nueve y media sobre el trayecto el Carmen- Saltillo en la carretera antigua Saltillo – Monclova conté 7 mariposas y en la ciudad de Saltillo se ven de manera frecuente en diferentes rumbos de la misma.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Ahora si pude observar el paso masivo de mariposas por Monterrey.Se observaron pasar por las grandes avenidas del centro y norte del la ciudad durante el viernes 17 y sábado 18 de octubre

El viernes las observe por la tarde, a las 5 PM y pasaban a razón de 58 por minuto, el vuelo era alto y de altura media, eran miles, el día estaba nublado y el viento corría del norte a aproximadamente 5 km por hora.

El sábado 18 solo las observe por la mañana antes de las 10 AM, después ya no habia. También eran cientos y pasaban a razón de 39 por minuto, el dia estaba mas despejado pero con viento del norte.Tuve suerte pues solo esos días las vi masivamente, después de ese fin de semana he observado algunas pocas, creo que ya se fueron, así que doy por hecho que ya pasaron todas por Monterrey.

Suerte para ellasGracias por mantenernos informados

Courtesy of Correo Real

Samspon Elementary and Copeland Elementary 3rd graders noticed a big increase in the number of Monarchs in the garden this week! Monarchs were especially busy drinking nectar allowing us to sneak up and  tag rather easily. We observed a mixture of very large Monarchs in great shape, some with tattered wings, and others very faded. We tagged at both schools more this week than any other.Today was a record high with 8 Monarchs in the butterfly garden at once. They came and left all day long in waves each group of butterflies seemed to only stay for 15 minutes or so then move on. 10-15 minutes of quiet then another group would move in.

23 de Octubre, Parque Estanzuela, N.L. ,
Las mariposas andan por el parque Estanzuela y las colonias o zonas de Valle Alto y ese corredor de la sierra. El día 23 de octubre, anduvimos en busca de ellas por la carretera nacional y las vimos por la zona de Mundo de Adeveras, números de 40- a 60 por minuto, disminuyó hacia cola de caballo, las perdimos. De ahí nos fuimos hacia Ciénega de González, muy pocas, llegamos hasta los condominios y fueron muy esporádicos los avistamientos.

Courtesy of Correo Real

24 de Octubre, Cienegilla, N.L. ,
Día 24 de octubre estuve en la zona de Santiago, arriba de Laguna de Sánchez exactamente en Puerto Ondable, ahí registramos 57 mariposas de 9 am a 4pm. ¡peroooooooooooooooooooo! sorpresa bajando, nada por Ciénega de González, nada en Puerto Genovevo, pero al llegar a la Cienegilla hasta 1 km antes de la carretera, oleada de mariposas de 5:38 p.m. hasta las 6:40 p.m. Empezaba a oscurecer, en ese lugar se registraron de 186 a 210 por minuto, mientras descendiendo hacia la carretera, disminuía el numero de mariposas. Por la sierra Valle Alto, Estanzuela es el corredor hasta Cola de Caballo. El año pasado lo detectamos sólo que las fechas son diferentes. El clima tiene mucho que ver, en la mañana, como a las 6 a.m. mucho frío, pero empezó a acrecentarse la temperatura, y se sentía en el transcurso del día, oleadas de aire caliente con mezcla de frio.Animo a todos, andamos detrás de las monarcas, el Parque Nacional Cumbres en acción.

Courtesy of Correo Real

28 de Octubre, Santiago, N.L.
Quiero comentarle que hoy 28 de octubre eran las 9.15 a.m. pasaron miles de monarcas por el Palacio de Justicia . Después de las 10.30 se acabo el espectáculo y bajo a 10 x minuto. También quiero reportarle que en toda la carretera nacional de Santiago N.L. estuvieron pasando las monarcas con un promedio de 30 por minuto y aquí les mando unas fotos de la plaza principal, espero que les gusten.
Alejandro Sepulveda Bolaños
Dirección de Ecología Municipal

Courtesy of Correo Real
Today I saw about 50 monarchs when I arrived at my house. They passed by in  about 20 minutes. Unfortunately I wasn't able to get pictures. I hope I see more this evening.

My husband is traveling. He told me that on Tuesday (10/04) when he was driving he saw thousands of monarchs migrating at he level of the state of Hidalgo with Queretaro about 10 miles southeast of my house.

We went up to the lower parking lot of EL Rosario. i got the impression wewere the first carload of tourists to arriveand everyone was extremely friendly, but DonBruno´s wasn´t even open in Angangueo, nor the restaurant.We found los arcos open on the square across from thechurch in el centro at angangueo.half way up to el rosario there were thousands of monarchsstreaming up the mountain and flying all around, but wewere told they were forming clusters on the small hilljust behind angangueo, but not so much up in the reservesas of yet.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Beautiful day down here in Zitacuaro; sunny, 76 degrees. We went back up to Ocampo and took the road toward the lower parking lot for El Rosario. Stopped about 1/3 of the way up and just sat on tree stumpsby the side of the road watching the flow up the draws. From about10:30 to 1:30 it was more or less continuous with 30 monarchs a second. We were due south of Angangueo and will do some triangulationwith maps when we get back to the US.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

October 31; We live on one acre in Texas. A few days before this, (approx. 10/27) my husband saw hundreds or maybe thousands of Monarch butterflies in trees of the vacant property next to ours. We are right now (1/28)watching the special on KERA in the Dallas area about their migration and thought you might want to know abpit a place in Texas they passed through. They were here (or maybe different ones of them) about a week or so. They were beautiful! I tried to take pictures, but could not manage to get any. Report from the Monarch Butterfly Research Project in Rapid River, Michigan:

August 31
Haven't seen many monarchs at all the past few days. We did have a strong northwest wind over the weekend, but rain all day Saturday. Low of 45 degrees last night. This mornings roost count at 7:00 am was 12. My observation time: I was watching for 45 minutes.

August 26
We had a small group of monarchs move through. North winds the night before and during the day. Morning roost count at 7:00 am was 94. 10:00 am route census was 19. 3:00 pm route census was 13. My observation time: I was watching for 2 hours total.

August 23
This mornings roost count was 244 around 7:00 am. As the temperatures warmed up to around 60 degrees the monarchs were leaving the roost and flying south over Lake Michigan towards Wisconsin. My observation time: I was watching for 2 hours and 30 minutes.

August 22
Counted 463 monarchs this afternoon at 3:00 pm on Stonington Peninsula. I'm sure there were more in the area. Perfect conditions, strong northwest wind, temperatures in the high 50's. They were gathering all day and appear to be staying the night. They will probably move south tomorrow with predictions of a light north wind. My observation time: I was watching for 8 hours

August 21
On Stonington Peninsula at 7:30 pm there was a group of 75-80 monarchs roosting on a cedar tree near the lighthouse. We had very strong northwest winds all day long which helps flush them down our peninsula where they gather at the point.

August 18
Nothing much to report so far. This has been a crazy summer up here with cooler temperatures. We didn't see many summer monarchs at all and so far haven't seen any large groups migrating. We started counting on August 8th and go through the month of September. Hopefully we'll see more monarchs moving through soon.

When I returned home late morning from errands Saturday, Aug. 29, 2009, my husband said he saw 7 monarchs flying around our backyard. I ran out and I counted 10-12 monarchs sipping from the butterfly bushes and lined up four across on our pin cushion flowers feeding. I have never seen more than six monarchs in our yard and that's usually in late September, so this was great. All were extremely bright orange and in great condition. But it's sad to note that they vanished the next day. In past years, I've had a group of five or six that remain and feed for at least three days. Two days have passed since Saturday and all I've seen since is one monarch, a tiger swallowtail, and a few cabbage whites. So this is very sad that they actually left after only one day. I still have 9 chrysalises and 3 caterpillars though. I hope these stragglers make it to Mexico eventually! My observation time: I was watching for 5 hours and loving every minute of it. Both of my neighbors on either side came into my yard and enjoyed the beauty of the monarchs. We all began to mourn their eventual leave-taking.

Joan reported this morning that on the evening of August 23rd, before a storm, monarchs seem to drop out of the sky and land on their buddleia (77 F temperatures). On August 24, they counted about 500 monarchs in a nearby clover field, and on the 25th, about 7-800. The next day, August 29th, they counted 3 monarchs. I remember there being a major migration last year about that time.

Rod had been looking for monarch larva for a few days and has found none (8/31). They have also had a rough year in their small breeding operation, with skunks eating some luna caterpillars and someone spraying next door and killing some monarch larva.

Rod counted 18 monarchs yesterday. (8/30) Rod has also heard that local boaters have seen monarchs out over Lake Ontario.

I saw one migrating monarch yesterday right in the downtown core of Toronto and in the hospital district of the city on University Avenue, attracted by the wide median filled with flowering plants and trees.

The Monarch's weren't very heavy in numbers compared to the thousands of dragonflies, but the best day so far was definitely Tuesday August 25th. I think we might have had perhaps 200 by for the whole day. Numbers are definitely down here at Monarch Landing. I did a quick survey for caterpillars on the 23rd and found 40. Perhaps a third of these were fourth or fifth instars. I was going to predict the peak migration after these emerge. . .perhaps between the 19th to 23rd. However I have been monitoring a few crysalis and they are very slow, probably because of the very cool nights. I have one that will probably emerge tomorrow, (9/2) (they are outside) but it has taken him 15 days so far.

comments:
We have traveled to Lake Michigan - St Joe River area - going Salmon fishing. Gone out into the Lake 5-7 miles, 110' water depth. OK, I know no one is interested in those stats - HOWEVER - while out that far, we have seen MANY, MANY Monarchs - all heading WEST over the water!! We see singles and as many as 3-4 in a loose "group"!

Yesterday, Saturday, September 4th, we were out in the a.m. as well as later in the evening from 6-8p.m. The Monarchs that we saw that late in the evening, WHAT DO THEY ROOST ON???? I have seen 1-2 Monarchs on the water - flat out and then they will make a "kiss" sound as they rise into the air!!!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

September 6
The monarch migration is continuing to be strong across Neal Smith national wildlife refuge. During three hours of observations on a cool and sunny day, 368 monarchs were counted.
368 monarchs (in 3 hours)

September 5
Monarch butterflies are continuing to be on the move over the prairie at Neal Smith national wildlife refuge. In the northern part of the refuge, a large stand of tickseed sunflowers has been attracting the monarchs as they fly south over the Iowa farmland and approach the wildlife refuge. This morning, a visit to the heart of the stand turned up 160 monarchs in 20 minutes as they moved from flower to flower. Overall, the count of monarchs was 332 during two hours-plus of observations.
332 monarchs (in 2+ hours)

September 4
As the days go by, monarch butterflies will begin to spend more of their time nectaring on other wildflowers, but in the early days of the fall migration, they continue to favor tickseed sunflowers. That pattern continued this Friday at Neal Smith national wildlife refuge. During two and one-half hours of observations, we counted 307 migrating monarchs. Most of them were nectaring on tickseed sunflowers, but on one hillside, some were stopping on the goldenrod blooming so profusely on the prairie.
307 monarchs (in 2.5 hours)

September 3
This was an amazing day for observing the migration of monarch butterflies at Neal Smith national wildlife refuge. During two and one-half hours of counting in the morning, we saw 526 monarchs. They were continuing to visit the stands of tickseed sunflowers, and they were putting on a wonderful display of their colors against the yellow background of the flowers.
526 monarchs (in 2.5 hours)

September 2
During an afternoon visit to Neal Smith national wildlife refuge, 110 monarchs were observed in one hour and one-half. Once again, the monarchs were nectaring primarily on tickseed sunflowers. They were racing to and fro among the wildflowers in the north part of the refuge.
110 monarchs (in 1.5 hours)

September 1
The monarch butterfly migration is under way across central Iowa. The sky was mostly clear, the weather was cool, and the number of monarchs observed today differed sharply from two previous days over the weekend. In two hours and 40 minutes, we counted 251 monarchs at Neal Smith national wildlife refuge near Prairie City, Iowa. They primarily were nectaring on tickseed sunflowers, the favorite wildflower for the monarchs at this time of the year. Cool weather to the north--38 degrees overnight at one point in northern Iowa--appeared to have contributed to the speeded up monarch movement.
251monarchs (in 2.5+ hours)
Neighbor sighted a "cloud" of about 200 monarch flying over Chittenango Creek( flows into Onieda Lake).  They were low flying in a Southerly direction. This was about 10:30 AM.

I have been seriously looking but haven't seen any Monarch Butterflies for several weeks (9/08). The peak for butterflies in my jurisdiction appeared to be between August 15 and 18, 2009.

I released my second last adult butterfly (raised in captivity) today (9/08). The last will emerge tomorrow a.m. and will then be released. Temperature permitting they might make it to their southern destination. It's been warm recently (day highs in the mid-70's / night lows in the low 50's) and is scheduled to last for the next few days. Will they make it?

From early July to present, my daughter and I have raised >25 caterpillars to maturity. There's been three periods of larval stages at my location --> (1) early July; (2) late July-early August; (3) late August-early September. Highest number of caterpillars observed has been during stage 2 period; highest number of adults observed in wild during Stage 2 larvae emergence to adulthood.

As in past years the peak migration here appears to be past by the third week of August.
Dozens of Monarchs observed heading south past our Monarch Waystation (a few stopping for fuel) around noon today.  What a sight!

My son and I were doing school and he noticed some monarchs out back so we decided to go watch. We watched for 1 hour and 20 minutes and counted 1,018 monarchs all headed south!!!!! It was totally amazing! WHAT A DAY!!!!

Observations by Mr. Jim Wilson forwarded by Mr. Don Davis:

I spent the past two afternoons at Point Lepreau in search of Monarchbutterflies (to tag). On September 10th Joanne Savage, Samantha Perrin and I arrived shortlybefore noon and spent until 3:45 PM at the Point Lepreau Bird Observatory (PLBO). The main purpose was to catch and tag as many MONARCH butterflies as possible. The day was sunny and warm with almost no wind and the date was about the theoretical peak of the Monarch migration at this latitude. However for awhile we were afraid that we might not see ANY Monarchs at all- they were almost non-existent. By 3:30 PM we had seen only three but had managed to capture two for tagging.

We returned September 11th at 1 PM and searched for Monarchs until 4:30 PM. My wife Jean joined the group, as well as Roger LeBlanc and his film crew who have been working on filming various nature topics around the province this summer. Once again, Monarchs were super-scarce. In three and a half hours of scouring all the sunny nooks around the alders and blooming flowers in the extensive open area of the tip we could find only three, all of which were captured for tagging. One year ago I visited for three hours following two days of heavy westerly winds and saw 200-300 Monarchs and was able to capture and tag 80, working alone.

This summer we have had virtually no westerly winds at all, which I feel are responsible for bringing many of the migrating Monarchs we see annually to the coast of the Bay of Fundy.

But despite the quiet "Monarching", they were two lovely afternoons spent at a location that's as spectacular as any along our coastline. We're veryfortunate to have continued acc My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

HawkCliff Hawkwatch of Port Stanley, Ontario, Canada

September 27
For those that are interested in the Monarch migration ...Not much in the way of passerines reported...but incredibly a strong push of Monarchs today with clusters of 10-11 at a time being seen...despite the SW gales! We've seen this before on rainy, humid days even with strong winds...it doesn't seem to deter the Monarchs.

Weather:
Wow! Gale force wind warnings were up starting after midnight and wind speeds continued to climb throughout the day. Winds were initially very strong from the SSW then gained strength and shifted to SW and eventually WSW. This is the first time I think we've ever recorded multiple hours of >75kph winds...with gusts hitting 100kph. There was a lot of cloud cover and the rain moved in during a couple different hours...but the sky would then break out once more. Temp was much cooler reaching just 15C thanks to the intense low passing eastward with an associated cold front .

September 9
For those interested in the Monarchs, today (9/09) was a slow flight day with very few passing the hawkwatch. LOTS of Ruby-throated Hummingbirds today, with 200+ as a rough count during a 9 hour observation period.

September 5
The Monarch butterfly migration was in full swing with several passing the hawkwatch every minute...and at all altitudes from ground level to heights requiring binoculars to spot them.
Observation Start Time: 07:00 End Time: 14:00 Observer Hours: 7
A beautiful day with light NE winds eventually swinging all the way around to SW. Temp still warm to a high of 21C under clear blue skies to start with clouds building in as the day progressed.

I've been seeing Monarchs for a couple weeks, but only a few here and there.  Sunday, 9/13/09, we drove about 20 miles east to Clay Center, Nebraska, and as we were driving there were many Monarchs flying south across the highway in front of us.  Yesterday, 9/17/09, I was in the backyard sitting in my hot tub about 1:00 p.m. and in the approximately 1/2 hour I sat there, I saw at least one or two a minute flying in what appeared to be almost the same fly route from west to east across my back yard.  There are large trees in my backyard and I had a roost two summers ago, but these appeared to land on some leaves and then fly on.
