Over 1000 butterflies have landed in my mother's 3 acres of orchards. Steady trail of monarchs flying in during day. Between 5pm CDT - 7pm CDT each night from 9/4 - 9/11/09. Asked local butterfly observatory to come and tag them. They said this was most butterflies they have seen in 5 or more years. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

Last year the peak migration for the Monarchs passing through Lincoln, Nebraska was on Sept 24th, 2008. It was an incredible day! Since I'm aware of the date getting close to last years, I spent the afternoon today on our backyard patio and watched the Monarchs traveling south and into our gardens for a sip or 2 of nectar before continuing on their long journey. During a 3 hour period I recorded 87. It will be interesting if tomorrow's #'s will average any higher, or if today was "THE" day. Our weather is suppose to change drastically Sunday evening with T-storms...bringing with it our 1st major cold snap of the season. Tomorrow will be the last day that will be in the high 70's to low 80's for the next week. The temps will average in the high 50's to low 60's for the following 5-6 days. I personally don't believe the peak migration will pass through after tomorrow. I believe it's happening now...at least the leading edge of the peak migration is definitely passing through for sure! My observation time: I was watching for _3__ hours and _0__ minutes.

Since our first wave of migrating monarchs during the last week of August, the nights have been too warm to stimulate another movement southwards. Finally, Sunday morning the 13th was a cool 9 degrees centigrade. This resulted in a movement of monarchs through Point Pelee National Park on Monday and Tuesday, 14th and 15th. Along a one kilometre stretch of our west beach where we may normally observe 5 or 6 butterflies, we were seeing 40 monarchs at any one time. So we know that thousands of butterflies moved through the park during these two days. My observation time: I was watching for 0.5 hours each of the two days. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

Today, September 20, 2009, from 3:20 pm to 4:45 pm I counted 145 Monarchs traveling south over our farm. This is the first day I have seen them in significant numbers. My observation time: I was watching for 1 hours and 20 minutes.

Migration rate: 108 monarchs per hour

Today, September 20, 2009, from 3:20 pm to 4:45 pm I counted 145 Monarchs traveling south over our farm. This is the first day I have seen them in significant numbers. I was watching for 1 hour and 20 minutes. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

Today I spoke with Tammy C at Point Pelee National Park. In the last week of August 2009, there was a movement of monarchs through Pelee. On August 28th, visitors were delighted to see about 1000 monarchs at the tip. The number counted on August 29th and 30th was about 700, and on August 31st, about 300. Since then the daily counts have been low, with numbers such as 1,2, 8, etc.

Last year, the largest cluster reported at Pelee held an estimated 600 monarchs.

Courtesy of Don Davis

I recently traveled through Kansas on my way from AZ back to OH. I pulled off at a rest area along US54 at the Cimmaron River 12 miles or so east of Liberal, Kansas. Saw several monarchs flying about the sunflowers near the rest area. Went off exploring a little bit and noticed monarchs collecting on a dead branch of a tree in a small forested area. I would guess there were perhaps a dozen on the branch and probably one to two dozen more fluttering about the other trees in the area. This was about 3pm local time on Friday the 18th of Sept.

Through most of Kansas I was seeing monarchs crossing the road heading south. In the busier sections maybe one monarch per mile (more western KS) and heading east that declined to perhaps one every five miles.

It was east of El Dorado that things seemed to really slow down. Busiest section seemed to be roughly between Liberal and Greensburg.

Although I am seeing only an occasional monarch in my yard or neighbors' yards, I was at a nature center near Lincoln yesterday (9/19)where we did an official butterfly count. We counted 100+ monarchs during a two-hour hike through the tall grass prairie. The butterflies were nectaring on sunflowers, goldenrod and New England Asters. The report from the naturalist was that the butterflies have been coming through in steady numbers for the past two weeks.

Monarch butterflies were streaming throughat all heights throughout the morning.

As we stood upon the hill outside our school building, we observed 12 monarchs passing by overhead over the course of 2 hours.  It is an open spot which was a great motivation for us to continue to keep track of the monarchs as they travel south. My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours and ___ minutes.

During my lunch hour, from 11:45 a.m.until 12:20 p.m. I was at Packard Park, which is on the shore of Lake Michigan, in South Haven, Michigan.  I observed 73 monarchs flying single, from the north to south.  They ranged in ascension from 5 ft. to upwards of 50 ft.

Starting in early August it was not unsual to see 1-4 monarchs daily getting nectar and laying eggs on our tropical milkweed. I have enjoyed watching the caterpillars grow and have brought about 75 in the house to complete their metamorphosis. Three dozen butterflies were used for a public release during a nearby dedication.  Now,the monarchs are focused on our tithonia torch flowers and are not interested in the milkweed, of course. The past two days during a very short period of observation time each day, we observed 13 monarchs on our flowers; 8 one day, 5 the next. Most of the last of our caterpillars are now pupating in our indoor sanctuary. We have observed three small caterpillars still on the milkweed as of 09/24/09. sitting outside and began seeing butterflies that seemed to go to the house across the street and then cross and go between our house and the neighbors.  they all followed the same path and I saw about twenty butterflies in about an hour.  this is a first for me. Large numbers of monarchs moving south through Clearville Park (north shore of Lake Erie)towards roosts at Rondeau Provincial Park and Point Pelee National Park on Sunday September 27th. Conditions sunny 70 deg F. Estimate 250 per hour. Many were seen roosting in trees at Clearville Park at the end of the day. On Monday and Tuesday Sept 28, 29 heavy wind and rain storms occurred. Some dead butterflies observed in leaf litter under trees after storms had passed. Migration picked up again on Wed Sept 30. Conditions sunny 63 deg F. In the afternoon estimate 100 per hour moving south. This slowed to a trickle (less than 5 per hour) on Thursday October 1. Conditions sunny 58 deg F. The weather has turned much colder and cloudy so remaining butterflies will be challenged in their journey south. I will continue to monitor and report further sightings. My observation time: I was watching for 3 hours and 0 minutes.

After a morning of rain it's turned into an almost perfect migration day.  There's a 24 mph WSW wind (with gusts to almost 30) which they are flying into.  Despite the wind there is still an average of 2-3 monarchs a minute passing through the clear cut at the back of our property - some stopping to nectar.  My Black Adder perennial is COVERED with monarchs.  There were 4 on one flower alone!  I put in a Monarch Waystation with dreams of them coming and it has actually come true.  The only thing to top this would be to have a roost in our trees tonight and/or a trip to their winter site in Mexico.  So amazing and truly a miracle! My observation time: I was watching for 2 hours.

went out to get mail and noticed about 25-30 monarch looking butterflies on my purple butterfly bush.  haven't seen many butterflies of ANY kind this year until sep 26.  wasn't sure if they were monarch, emperors or viceroys.  looked up pictures on websites and confirmed that they were monarchs.  they were not going to the yellow butterfly bush about 20 feet away.  a friend across the street could even see them swarming.  we were outside for about 20 minutes watching them.  did not see but 4-5 around the purple bush until today, 2 oct.  there were maybe 10-15 today.

Monarchs were making good time today traveling S/SW while driving from out in the country near Seminole to Shawnee.  I saw 1 Monarch about every 2 minutes for about an hour.Marilyn My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and ___ minutes.

My son and I were hiking today and stopped at the river front.Much to our surprise we noticed many, many monarchs traveling down river in large groups. we stayed about 20 minutes and they were consistently flying by as if on parade. It was a fun experience! My observation time: I was watching for 0 hours and 20 minutes.

The previous two days I saw none in 45-minute walks on Gooseberry, but both days the temperature was around 40 and it was early morning.Also saw American Painted Lady and a couple of Cloudless Sulphurs. Yesterday there were heavy rains. This morning I did a one hour circuit of Gooseberry Island in 40-degree temperatures and saw four monarchs in flight. (This is the same path I took a few days ago when I saw 147.) Interesting they were flying because it was less than three hours after sunrise - sky clear - and yet they apparently were still able to raise body temperatures 15 degrees. Amazing little beast! My observation time: I was watching for __1_ hours and __0_ minutes.

Peak for our area was Friday and Saturday, October 2-3.  There was a noticeable drop off of activity on Sunday. Though monarchs were still in migration mode, the numbers were less than 25% what I saw the two days before.

Weather here has been wet and getting colder. 6 monarchs seen in flight or dropping to the ground to feed on clover at Clearville park on the north shore of lake Erie. A major roost exists at Rondeau Provincial Park and Pt Pelee National Park just to the south of Clearville Prk. Weather for the next few days supposed to be cool but sunny so Monarchs should be able to make it to Ohio.  My observation time: I was watching for 1 hour.

Today Meg and I decided to go canoeing at Falls Lake hoping to see some remaining shorebirds. We launched at the boat launch on Redwood Road and paddled against a strong southwestern wind across the lake and landed at the old railroad trestle. Very quickly we started seeing Monarchs flying up then across the lake heading southwest. Between 12:30 pm and 2:30 PM we tallied 60 Monarchs, ended the day at 4:45 with 85 Monarchs! Given the flyways for Monarchs in NC are clearly either along the coast or across the mountains I think 85 makes it an exceptional day in the Piedmont!

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

That's weird....I just missed Randy, I spent 10/4 from 9am - noon tagging monarchs on the east side of the Falls Lake RR trestle in Granville County. I tagged 30 but estimated a total of 100 nectaring on Baccharus, goldenrod, rabbit tobacco?, honeysuckle and a couple other things I couldn't ID.

At the trestle at 1030 in 15 minutes I counted 10 flying overhead sw. On a good day they fly from 9am to 5pm or so, about 8 hours. With my estimate of 40/hour and Randy's of 30/hour, even with the average that's more than 200 monarchs a day during peak migration.

I found these sites last year with Baccharus clearly being the most visited nectar source, and noted peak migration range anywhere from Sep 29 - Oct 12, about 8 or 9 full peak days on a given year totaling close to two thousand monarchs maybe!!

The ones I watched flew directly SW, over the trees. I would have expected them to fly low and follow the mostly sw rail line and essentially a nectar highway, but they flew high and continued on from that point.

The only milkweed patches I know of up in that region don't produce nearly these daily numbers so they are obviously all mostly migrating monarchs. Keep hoping to get a recapture of someone else tagging north of me so I know where they came from.

Oddly, enormous patches of baccharus or other such nectar AWAY from the lake south of I85 hold nearly ZERO migratory monarchs. But this trestle from the east, the Ellerbe Creek trestle from the west (same rail line) and one powerline cut near US15 have had last year and this year, held serious numbers of migratory monarchs. Which is why I bought extra tags this year!! The right nectar along the right flight path, location, location, location!

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

It was fun to see so many at one time. We watched them fly by for about 20 minutes and it was a nice experience for us. Something we may never get to see again.

October 10
Today, Saturday 10/10/09 I counted 200 monarchs in 15 minutes. I was standing outside the Nature Center / Office on Eaton Hill and could see 100 feet to my left and approx 50 ft to my right. Monarchs were flying over at a near constant pace. Taking a trip down the hill to check some favorite trees, I found hundreds in the pecan trees and saw several resting/drinking? in the fresh cut grass of the draw. We have had a good rain recently, and the normally dry draw has water standing in places.

October 5
Monarchs everywhere! Driving thru Sonora, near the Middle School, up on Eaton Hill, and at the cemetery. Throughout the day, monarchs were spotted above and around. The sun came out soemtime after 1:00, and I counted 50+ monarchs in about 3 minutes. Some were low and some were quite high in the sky. Around 5:30, at least 100 were seen at the cemetery.

Yesterday, Oct. 5 was an excellent monarch migration day on Assateague Island, VA at the Chincoteague NWR. The wind was WNW variable between 15-20mph. Monarch flight was constant from 8am through 6:45pm. Monarchs followed the primary dune to the elbow on the hook of Tom's Cove, turned around at the narrow part of the island and backtracked up to the seaside goldenrod interdune areas to nectar and roost for the night. No counts were conducted but one casual site count yielded 620 monarchs per hour during late morning. About 100 monarchs were netted and tagged. Monitors at Kiptopeke State Park be on the lookout for this big wave of monarchs today or tomorrow. Several tagged monarchs are still here, nectaring on the seaside goldenrod even though winds are favorable to leave. All but 2 of the 100 tagged had extremely lean abdomens, most likely from their ordeals of being blown over the ocean and having to struggle by flapping nonstop to get back to shore.

October 8
Thursday, Oct 8 was one of the best monarch days I have had (this is my 13th year observing the migration at this location). Notice I said monarch day and not monarch migration day. The WNW wind did indeed bring thousands of monarchs to Assateague Island during the morning hours. But with seaside goldenrod (Solidago sempervirens) and large bur-marigold (Bidens laevis) in peak bloom, monarchs settled in for an all-afternoon feeding event. Those that did attempt to migrate were blown out over the ocean during 30+ mph wind gusts (around 6pm when winds decreased, many monarchs as well as green darners, black saddlebags, wandering gliders, and common buckeyes were observed returning to shore, flying low-- just over the waves). Nectaring monarchs were still clinging to the seaside goldenrod at sunset. Just after sunset, I counted 1,000 individuals roosting in about one acre of goldenrod (there were more, but I stopped counting at 1,000).

October 5

The students were working in the claassroom when one student spotted a monarch on the window sill of our classroom. It flew away and landed on a grassy area near the playground. All the kids were excited to see the Monarch. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and 20___ minutes.
I am right on the beach at a NASA test range at Wallops Island, Va.  Yesterday there were no Monarchs. Today I have seen at least a hundred. My observation time: I was watching for 4 hours.

We do not normally see the monarchs around our area, mostly it's the eastern swallowtail, but in the last few days, we've seen over a dozen monarchs at our butterfly bushes (we have 4 bushes).  Last evening & this morning there were 4 on one bush!  They are so beautiful to see flitting around the bush!

Observed several hundred monarchs throughout the day ahead of a fast moving cold front. Strong NW winds were helpful in their southern trek. Air temps dropped 15-20 degrees behind the front. Today I believe will be the last of any sightings for this years migration. Over the period of this past week I would estimate counting 500+ monarchs. Many stopped and fed on some ragweed nectar, and spent the night for much needed rest.This week is one that I will remember for a long time to come. I ponder though on how much of the monarchs winter habitat has been removed due to mankinds desire to build larger homes.  My observation time: I was watching for 6 days.

We must be having a second peak migration!  Late this afternoon we counted 142 Monarchs in less than an hour.  It was a cool day and they came very late in the afternoon after 4:30. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and 55___ minutes.

swarm of more than 100+ monarchs at Sachuest Bird Sanctuary 10/10/09...no significant numbers observed the following day (10/11/09)

While driving today, monarchs kept appearing over the road. In 10 minutes I saw 20. After I reached my destination, I stood in the parking lot for 5 minutes and saw 8 more.The weather was clear and 70 degrees. This has been a nice day, finally a break from the rain and the rain is to return this evening.  My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and 15___ minutes.

Hundreds of monarchs flying through my neighborhood in small groups of 2 - 4 at a steady pace.  I have been watching for 25 minutes.  The average number per minute is 20.  The weather conditions are mostly cloudy, no wind and the temp is 61 degrees.  My observation time: I was watching for 25 minutes. From 10:55 - 11:20 AM CDT.

On Friday, 10/9, a storm front was moving in from the west. The day began sunny (70's), with a very strong wind. About 8:30 am we noticed a flurry around the butterfly bush outside our classroom window. There were many painted ladies, skippers, and 12 Monarchs fluttering and nectaring repeatedly. We went out and stood right beside them, but they were busy eating, so didn't fly away! I caught 4 and brought them inside to talk about how they were 'wild' ones (unlike the ones we raised in boxes). We imagined where they had come from. I only had 2 tags left, but we tagged 2.

Today (10/12)it was cloudy and in the 60's, but the Monarchs were back! There were 8 today, but none tagged. We haven't ever had this many visit at once before! My observation time: I was watching for 4 hours.
Hundreds if not thousands of Monarchs headed south observed at 4590 sw drive here in Abilene, Texas 79606 My observation time: I was watching for 1 hour.
I saw more than 20 monarch butterflies in my mother's 2 butterfly bushes on her lawn.  When I left her home they were still drinking nectar from the bushes. They were absolutely beautiful!

My husband and I were down in Cape May New Jersey overnight.  Arriving at 2:30 at our Hotel on the beach,  we were struck by the non-stop travel along the shore line of Monarchs traveling in small groups, with one other butterfly, or singly following others. We watched until dusk. Next morning, Monarch's were still passing by on their way south. Awesome!! My observation time: I was watching for _4__ hours and __30_ minutes.
Driving from Ozona to Big Lake on Hwy 137, I tallied over 200 migrating monarchs streaming across the roadway. I saw numerous road kills, too.

From 1:05 pm to 1:10 pm we witnessed 98 monarchs flying overhead base housing at Dyess Air Force Base in Abilene, Texas.  It was a wondrous sight. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __5_ minutes.

Here in Raleigh it cleared around 11:30, and as I was in a meeting at the NC Museum of Natural Science's education center (open-air with screens) at Prairie Ridge, from 8:30 to 4:30, we witnessed Monarchs sailing and fighting the wind to the SW all day. I guess we must have seen 100 at a minimum. Certainly, it was nothing as compared with some flights in the mountains, but it was quite a parade, mostly in the afternoon.

Yesterday (10/8) at the Dixie Classic Fair in Winston-Salem I was taking a lunch break in the shade at the north end of the fairgrounds and watched Monarchs trickle past at about 3 per minute, traveling at about 15 ft off the ground and heading straight south along the east side of a large building. I later followed a couple of them and after they traveled past a set of food booths, they stopped at a planting of asters and mums before continuing south - no deep fried Snickers bars for them.

Today I had to find them by going to the aster/mum bed and working my way north, finding they were entering the fairgrounds about 100 yards further east, probably due to the more westerly wind today.

My husband and I were on Asseateague Island, VA on Saturday from about 9:30 am -3:30 pm. We observed about 50 plus monarch butterflys an hour. They were so pretty, many different sizes, then after a short time of watching, we noticed dragon flys with them also. The butterflys traveled in groups of 2-6 it seemed, and 2-3 dragonflys with them. They were traveling from the north end of the beach to the south end of the beach on Asseateague Island. We were fishing on the point of land called "the hook". It was amazing. Hope this helps. I always heard they migrated but never, ever saw this. I hope we can see it next year. In the space of around 30 seconds, I spotted 48 monarchs.  It was around 3:00 in the afternoon. Most were flying rather high, but a few were low as if looking for nectar.  It has been so rainy here (2" alone yesterday) for a week but this afternoon the sun is breaking through.  It would seem they have been waiting for the weather to be dry enough to continue their trip.  Our building is close to the AR river where I think they roost at night.  I have never seen as many at one time as I am seeing now.  I went back out an hour later and still saw them, just one after another.  Sometimes in a group of 10 or so and sometimes a smaller group of 2 or 3.  Of course, some were alone but there was always another close behind. My observation time: I was watching for 30 minutes.

We observed our monarch Waystation for 2 minutes daily over a 3-1/2 week period

We monitored about 3 times a week for 2 min, averaging the data each time we monitored with the class, then graphed our class data over time, then divided our graphs up into your weekly reporting periods. By comparing the weekly periods, we were able to discuss the data...including looking at outliers such as rainy, cool or extremely warm/sunny days.... and decide which week was the peak for St. Louis.

Unfortunately the winds were gusty out of the southeast making it hard to fly.  It looks like they are at their peak right now in our area. My observation time: I was watching for 8 hours.

Me alegra reportarle que hoy 16 de Octubre vi bastantes monarcas en la parte de la pedrera de Contrissa. Fuimos a realizar sitios de inventario y toda la mañana vimos una media de *10 mariposas por minuto* volando de norte a sur, lo mejor llegó cuando en plena pedrera grande de Contrissa, alrededor de las *dos de la tarde*, vimos volar bastantes más de *30 mariposas por minuto* y otros ratos de 20 en adelante en buenas condiciones, hacía algo de fresco y viento moderado, estas son lascoordenadas: 25.41000, -100.87000, altura 1800 msnm

Los días *12 y 13 de octubre*, por la carretera de Cuatro Ciénegas a Monclova, Perla Vázquez y yo observamos numerosas mariposas, al principio pensamos que todas eran Monarca pero luego nos dimos cuenta que volaban con otra especie muy parecida, no sé si son las reina, al principio contamos de *8 a** 10 por minuto*, pero entre *Lamadrid yNadadores* aumentaron a aproximadamente a *30/minuto* después de San Buenaventura y ya en Monclova no la vimos. Creo que en *una hora* de viaje observamos aproximadamente *150 mariposas* siempre volando. Tristemente también observamos varias muertas en la carretera. El clima en estos días fue caluroso más de 30°. El cielo despejado

El *viernes 16* como a la 7:30 AM observe grupos pequeños de no más de*20* individuos posados en mezquites del *Rancho Pozas Azules* de Pronatura, precisamente del camino de la casa a las pozas. La temperatura era como de 20° centígrados, bastante nublado y viento suave. También vi revoloteando 2 ó 3 cerca de las pozas. Una buena noticia es que las Monarca tienen un excelente refugio en la Reserva Pozas Azules.

Finalmente el día de ayer y hoy (*17 y 18*) las he visto en las calles de *Cuatro Ciénegas*, volando solas o en tríos.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Hoy visitamos la Universidad Autónoma Agraria Antonio Narro en compañía de mis niños y observamos *cientos de mariposas*, alimentándose aunque el área cubierta por girasol es menor que la del año pasado, apenas abarca unos 100 m2 siendo, que el año pasado había como unas 4 ha. Al atardecer revoloteaban entre los nogales de la biblioteca, con toda seguridad ahí formarían sus racimos para pernoctar igual que en otros años. Día fresco 16 grados.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Hoy domingo 18, en pleno proceso electoral, salieron las mariposas a votar por la vida. Por la mañana, amaneció fresco, unos 20º salí como a las 9 a cumplir mi obligación ciudadana.... y de regreso miré por encima de las casas y vi varias mariposas volando, unas 5, luego seguí mas adelante su ruta y había más!!, y le seguían más!! miré mas alto, y había *cientos*, todas volando a muchas diferentes alturas, como si un controlador de vuelo le diera a cada una su altura, hasta bien alto se miraban como puntitos volar,

Mas tarde junto con Imelda y Alexandra, nuestra hija - como a las 10:30 a.m., les dije lo que había visto y, nos pusimos a observar y seguían pasando *cientos, miles*. Aprovechamos que estábamos por iniciar la Escuela Dominical y les mostramos a todos el cielo... (Al Pastor, su esposa y diversos asistentes) y les platicamos un rato de ellas, y se quedaron un buen rato viendo hacia arriba.... maravillados de su vuelo.

Ahora volaban más alto, y hacia mas calor unos 28º, y seguía nublado, de esos nublados brumosos-neblinosos.También por la tarde como a las 5... Seguían pasando, pero era pocas... una que otra.... a lo mejor ya buscaban donde descansar.

Courtesy of Correo Real

El sábado pasado en el campo Romania, ubicado en la orilla del río Sabinas, poco antes de su desembocadura en la presa Venustiano Carranza (*Municipio de B. Juárez)* vimos alrededor de *20 *mariposas volando por la tarde y al menos un *centenar posadas en los tamarix* a la orilla del río.

El domingo a medio día vimos como *cincuenta mariposas posadas* en un arbolito que no pude identificar, fuera de una casa en Cuatrocienegas. Doña Licha y Don Prax le llevaran unas ramitas para ver si usted logra identificarlas.

Hoy lunes por la mañana fuera de las oficinas de Pronatura Noreste en Cuatrocienegas junto con Isabel Moran, Doña Licha y Don Prax vimos pasar a las 9 a.m. alrededor de *80 mariposas por minuto*.

De regreso de Cuatrocienegas a Saltillo hicimos las siguientesobservaciones:

A las 9:40 en el aeropuerto de *Cuatrocienegas *pasaban *ciento*s, no las podíamos contar, volando desde el suelo hasta muy alto. Temp. 16 grados y mucha nubosidad. Cruzaban de norte a sur.

A las 11 a.m. en *Castaños, Coahuila* entre las dos y griegas de la carretera volaban *cientos, incontables*, el paso de las mariposas llegó hasta la gasolinera (1 km) cruzando de poniente a oriente. Temp. 20 grados y con viento del norte.

Entre el kilómetro 153 al 146 de la 57 tramo Saltillo-Monclova, antes de Santa Teresa, (municipio de Castaños) vimos otro paso impresionante de mariposas, tuvimos que disminuir la velocidad porque iban casi al ras de la carretera. Temperatura 18 grados, soleado y sin viento. Lamentablemente muchas atropelladas.

I drove over to Perdido Beach, Alabama, a tiny community on a bay, near the Gulf of Mexico - about 20 miles west of Pensacola. I stopped at a boat ramp access to the bay to enjoy the view and was surprised to see many monarchs resting on tall weedy bushes with little flowers - probably at least 100 or more butterflies. It was an amazing sight, as we usually only see a few at a time, flying. I am guessing that they were resting before heading out across the water to Mexico. There were other bushes of the same type inland, but the monarchs were only on the ones near the water. Many had their wings open, to soak in the sunlight, I assume, as it was windy and a little chilly. My observation time: I was watching for 15 minutes.
As we walked through our pavillion we were lucky enough to spot thousands of beautiful monarch butterflies.  My observation time: 1:13 and we watched for five minutes.

AMAZING MIGRATION DAY!!!

Monarchs everywhere today!
Sightings of 3-5 monarchs per minute on and off through the afternoon. This is a lot for my area. They were flying very low through our neighborhood, along streets, over HWY. 290!I ran up to check out the school garden and counted 20 in the butterfly garden all drinking nectar! I find it interesting that only one of the Monarchs we've tagged at that school is still with us after a week. All others we've tagged have not been spotted again after the day of tagging. The monarch we tagged that stayed was VERY faded at the time of tagging. I guess maybe he has gone as far south as he wants to. It is a very pretty butterfly garden... if I do say so myself!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Thousand flying swiftly over the valley in front of our back yard!!!!! My observation time: I was watching for 1 hours and 15 minutes.

Sunday, Oct. 18th, around 6:30 p.m. sitting out back in the shade. Looked up. The sky seemed to be full of glitter. Between 50 and 100 feet above our house, there were thousands of butterflies on the move. The wind currents were moving them from the southeast to the northwest. They were between 50 and 100 feet in the air. Most were riding the currents and not moving their wings. There were so many we couldn't count them. Only saw 1 monarch on the bottlebrush. These were not Queens, they were huge Monarchs. We sat there for the better part of an hour in amazement. I have never seen anything like this before...totally spellbinding. We have looked other evenings but have not had a repeat performance. Will continue to watch for them. My observation time: I was watching for 1 hour.

I am a Lindheimer Master Naturalist and a Comal Master Gardener. Yes, we do have Hackberry Snouts hatching and they are everywhere. These butterflies WERE NOT Queens either. The butterflies I observed were LARGE and could be readily seen with the naked eye. These were NOT snouts. We got the binoculars and definitely identified them as Monarchs.

9:30 am.  We are watching about 30 monarchs per minute fly over our house in Saltillo - heading souh.  We've been watching for about an hour now.  How beautiful.        My observation time: I was watching for 1___ hours and 0___ minutes.

Watched monarchs Sat and Sun Oct 24-25 streaming across Lake Cherokee. Everywhere you looked there were butterflies. My observation time: I was watching for 6 hours.

I feel pretty comfortable they wereMonarchs.Weekend of Oct 24-25 -- those fellas were streaming southwest -- fighting a wind from the north/northwest...about 10-20 ft above the surface of the lake. I marveled at their ability to make headway against the cross-wind. And you could look in any direction and see a monarch. We fished for about 3 hours each day and during that period -- a steady stream. Was pretty awesome sight...

October 30
This morning I only saw one or two. By this afternoon, I couldn't find any. I guess they are on their way south. My observation time: I was watching for 4 hours

October 26
I observed about 40 to 50 Monarch butterflies feeding on a bush in my back yard (10/21 estimated). They have been feeding here for about five days now. My observation time: I was watching for 15 minutes.
Thousands flying 10' - 30' above ground along Gulf shore. My observation time: I was watching for 20 minutes.

We are on a trip to Panama City Beach.  Along the way we stopped at Bald Point State park.  We went on a trail within the park and saw some golden rod, but only about 25 Monarchs there.  Outside the entrance station, there is a little picnic area and the salt marsh bushes had 75 Monarchs in that area. Next we stopped at St. George State park which is on a long, thin barrier island.  We didn't see any Monarchs until we noticed some golden rod right outside the entrance gate to the park.  There was a large patch of flowers there and 100's of Monarchs. We then headed to St. Joseph Peninsula State park and it was later in the day and we did see Monarchs there, but not too many.  So we either didn't find where the Monarchs were nectaring or it may be early in the season yet for them. Our last stop before heading home was St. Andrews State park in Panama City.  We saw lots of Monarchs and many other butterflies here (Gulf Frits, Buckeyes, Long-tailed skippers, two species of Sulphurs and some Skippers).  The main area they were in was along the trail by the tuppentine still.  Part of the trail is along the Grand Lagoon water area.   My observation time: I was watching for _8__ hours and ___ minutes.

Our last stop before heading home was St. Andrews State park in Panama City. We saw lots of Monarchs and many other butterflies here (Gulf Frits, Buckeyes, Long-tailed skippers, two species of Sulphurs and some Skippers). The main area they were in was along the trail by the tuppentine still. Part of the trail is along the Grand Lagoon water area.

While camping @ Fort Pickens Park on Pensacola Beach, FL last weekend observed monarchs at rest in groups up to 30 to 50 at a time and were able to observe 5 to 10 flying during most daylight hours all weekend. I can email photos if this will be helpful. My observation time: I was watching for 6 hours.

October 26
The monarchs and 2 other species appear to be in full migration here along the northern edge of the Gulf of Mexico. I am staying at Ft. Pickens campground located on the barrier reef island called Santa Rosa. The campground is near the pass for ships to enter Pensacola Bay. This island was devasted by a hurricane in September of 2005 and I have not been here to make observations since that time as the park has been closed. For the last two weeks I have observed the butterflies increase in number dailly and estimate the height of migration to have been about six days ago around October 21, 2009. The butterflies are found mostly on bushes with white blooms that I don't know the name. Will send photos, if possible. My observation time: I was watching for 3_ hours and _30__ minutes.

Como bien lo mencionó la Bióloga Eglantina el día de ayer en Los Lirios, Sierra de Arteaga, nos toco ver un espectáculo de miles de mariposas volando y alimentándose en una área de girasoles silvestres, los colores, el clima y la compañía, hicieron este momento memorable.

Hoy 22 de octubre, de nuevo tuve la oportunidad de ver la "Gran Migración" pasando prácticamente por la ventana de mi cuarto, ya que en el Fracc. Villas de Aranjuéz a las nueve de la mañana estaban volando cientos de mariposas a diferentes alturas, me tocó verlas levantar el vuelo de lo arroyos colindantes al fraccionamiento y alimentarse en los girasoles silvestres.

Lo espectacular fue a la doce mediodía, al pie de la Sierra de Zapaliname, exactamente en los edificios del deportivo de la Secc. 38, miles de mariposas monarcas volando, el detalle fue que en la oficina donde estaba tenían un cuadro de adorno con mariposas monarca y cuando le pregunté a la persona que si ya las había visto afuera me respondió que no, la invité a que saliera y me dio gusto observar que cuando ya salía de mi diligencia, estaba un grupo del personal observándolas y comentando respecto a ellas.

Me intriga ver como a la gran mayoría de las personas les pasa desapercibido este espectáculo de la naturaleza, debemos de fomentar mas su observación y sobre todo la admiración a esta especie, que de nuevo nos esta brindando en Saltillo “Los grandes vuelos migratorios"

El sábado 24 fue uno de los días de festival estatal de mariposas de NL, y estuvo nublado, fresco y húmedo, y las monarcas estaban en racimos en los sabinos junto al arroyo que sale de la Estanzuela y sólo se movían un poco para libar en los Eupatorios y otras nativas que están floreciendo por la zona. Ayer miércoles 28, estuvo despejado y tibio y vimos por la misma zona, incontables monarcas volando a diferentes alturas, bordeando la Sierra Madre Oriental, así como libando de nuevo en Eupatorios, algunas enredaderas y asteraceas que están floreciendo en estos días.

Además te comento que hubo muchísima reproducción de monarcas pre migratorias que han emergido en estas últimas semanas. Ayer mismo nos toco ver todavía orugas, y crisálidas en diferentes etapas de madurez, así como una emergiendo de su crisálida.

Courtesy of Correo Real

El día de hoy, en el tramo carretero de Castaños a Saltillo a la altura del ejido Santa Teresa, sobre la carretera 57 a las 8:30 a.m. conté 156 mariposas que sobrevolaban a una altura aproximada de dos metros y medio. También pude ver que hay una cantidad no muy grata de estas mariposas que han sido arrolladas por los vehículos que no disminuyen la velocidad. El progreso carretero es el principal depredador que no se puede detener. A los viajeros se les recomienda cuidar a las monarcas, bajando la velocidad.

La migración de la costa del este, ya está en México, te mando el siguiente reporte que acabo de recibir:

"Un espectaculo resulto la migración de la monarca en Tamaulipas, MILESSSSSS durante tres días (28 al 30 de octubre) en la carretera Ciudad Victoria-Jaumave, los cañones de la montaña estaban llenos. Volaban muy bajo como a metro y medio del piso y se observo la mayor presencia entre las 8 y 14 horas."
Dra. Gloria Tavera
ANP Laguna Madre

Editor's Note: Because the thousands of monarchs were seen in the canyons on the highway between Ciudad Victoria and Jaumave, we are using the latitude/longitude for the town of La Jova Verde, Tamaulipas.

Los días 5, 6 y 7 de Noviembre se vieron grandes cantidades de mariposas monarcas en diferentes puntos del estado de Querétaro, prácticamente todo el estado estaba siendo recorrido de norte a sur por las mariposas, es decir una franja de 100 Km lineales aproximadamente. El paso de las mariposas se registró en la ciudad de Querétaro, Bernal, Jalpan, Santa María de Cocos y San Antonio de la Cal. Se observaron miles de mariposas en los alrededores de Bernal y San Antonio de la Cal, así como gran cantidad de racimos en una zona de bosque de encino en el camino que lleva a Santa María de Cocos, zona cercana al Sótano del Barro.

Hoy entró un frente frío, el cielo está nublado y sopla un viento del norte con ráfagas que varían entre los 6.5 y 14 km/hora, la temperatura al mediodía era de 19 grados y para las dos de la tarde descendió a 17.5 grados Centígrados con un factor de viento de 14.3 grados centígrados. A esta hora salí a recoger nietas al colegio e inmediatamente empecé a ver a las monarcas volaban de bajo a mediana altura, salían del arroyo Ceballos y de los árboles del Parque Maravillas enfilándose hacia la Sierra de Zapalinamé al sureste de la ciudad.

Empecé a hacer mi conteo del camino, únicamente las que pasan enfrente de mi parabrisas, y en 20 minutos pasaron 93 mariposas de la manerasiguiente:

1:55-2:00 = 12
2:00-205= 24
2:10-2:15= 35
2:15-2.20= 22

On this date and the next date were the peak number of migrating monarchs seen, tagged and released in my yard, Monarch Waystation #271. I was not watching constantly, puttering around the house and glancing out the window with net ready at the door. Oct 4: tagged and released 6 monarchs between 12:50 pm and 4:20 pm.  October 5: tagged and released 7 monarchs between 1:47 pm and 5:35 pm.  I swung and missed 1 monarch on each of these days. There were 1 or 2 clusters of 2 or 3 monarchs in these time periods.  All of them flew south over the house once released except for 2 that flew to the nearest tree. My observation time: I was watching for about 4 hours on October 4 and about 4 hours on October 5.

I just got back from a long anticipated trip to the mid-coast of California to observe the monarch over-wintering sites there.  My kids (ages 5 and 8), my husband, and I spent 3 days over Thanksgiving vacation at Pacific Grove's Monarch Grove Sanctuary on Ridge Rd.  We were stunned to find only 760 butterflies, down from 19,000 that were seen on Thanksgiving day last year.  We went to Natural Bridges State Park in Santa Cruz on Friday, and found the same thing--only 1400 butterflies instead of the usual 50,000.  It appears the numbers are down all along the California coast.  In talking with naturalists and various other officials, much speculation is going on as to what has caused the drop in numbers.  Most are hoping that due to the unusually warm Fall weather, the monarchs are delayed in their migration--the next few weeks will tell if this is the case.  Every year, since the early '90s, the numbers of over-wintering monarchs have dropped in all sites along the coast--many are pointing to the loss of milkweed habitat to agricultural expansion, the use of Bt corn and Round-up ready soybeans, drought, and climate change.  It appears some whales in Monterey Bay did not migrate this year, as they usually do.  I don't know what is going on, but I am very concerned and I hope this is not the beginning of the end of the western migration.  Folks out there--PLEASE PLANT MILKWEED!   My observation time: I was watching for __25_ hours and ___ minutes.

Today and Tuesday 8/17/10 brought 4 dozen monarchs to my liatris.  cool breezes seemed to help.  Hatched record numbers for me this year-185 to date with about 100 to go! My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

The peak migration for the Monarchs passing through Lincoln, Nebraska was on Sept 24th, 2008. It was an incredible day!

I spent most of the day outside after a morning of pea soup fog lifted. I cleaned and filled the birdbath like I usually do by about 10am. By 11am I had cleaned and refilled our 9 feeders. We still have 2 females that have kept their bickering to a minimum and I have enjoyed watching them until about noon while having a couple cups of coffee on the patio. The temp reached near 80, with just a slight breeze. I decided to take some more pics of the few butterflies we have left...until I started seeing a sea of Monarchs heading south...I counted 131 that went over our house from 2pm til about 6:30pm! That doesn't include the times I went inside the house for this, that and the other. DH had to go to Omaha to work today for another training class for Oracle related to his job here at the electric co. He said he saw dozens cross RT 80 when he was coming home in the afternoon. I knew the Monarchs migrated, I just never witnessed it before. This is my 1st year to actually pay attention to a wonderful experience such as this...I was in awe by it all!

My wife and I tagged 75 monarchs in 1 hour and 45 minutes today.  Last year it took many, many hours and many days to tag this many.  We tag the monarchs through the Monarch Watch program.  The weather was sunny and 82 degrees with a very slight breeze.  The  monarchs were found in fields of purple clover and alfalfa fields.  This was one of our easiest years of tagging that we have had since we started in 2001.  We have had 17 of our butterflies from previous years found in Mexico. My observation time: I was tagging for __1_ hours and 45___ minutes.
saw 50 over a 30 minute period flying over our lake all going in a southwestern direction

My son saw two to three hundred monarchs on Green Island in Georgian Bay. They were not roosting (it was the middle of the day). They were flying around in groups of about 10 all over the island. This particular island of the group of islands called the Minks is the one which they seem to prefer. He saw many monarchs roosting there a few years ago. At that time, he also saw migrating monarchs on the Limestone Islands (45.387239, -80.532017). He has been told that this is part of the monarch and bird migration route. It is a provincial park which is protected from campers etc. because of its ecological importance.

I am in northern Minnesota and just thought you'd like to hear that I am seeing hundreds of monarchs here. The southern migration has started! We have been biking on the many paved bike trails around Bemidji with one of our sons.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Since August 18, 2010, large numbers of Monarch Butterflies have been passing through our area on the south shores of Lake Huron.  They are regularly seen flying over the beach area, feeding on the backyard flowers and flying over the nearby farms fields and roadways. Stream of butterflies battling south. Roosted overnight in cedar stand on 3 acre island & neighbouring islands. Fed on goldenrod. Still seeing them today (Aug 26).

100's & 1,000's of butterflies in a clover field 2 days ago (August 26th)along the lakeshore road east of Newcastle & Bond Head (Reported August 28th.)

For the last 3 days we have been eating outside and watching the Monarchs as they flew around and then rested in a dead birch tree.  We have counted up to 10 at once resting in the tree. What a great day yesterday (August 26th)! Coming home from the park- Monarchs crossing the road- every ¼ mile travelling due West. Sunday was hot  28 celcius and breezy.  We were kayaking in the Fishing Islands, north west of Wiarton. We are finishing our vacation here in Parry Sound and we have been able to tag 154 Monarchs during about a total of 7 hours of tagging in the last few days. We have also recovered many larvae, mostly 4th and 5th instars, as well as 10 eggs. This is remarkably better than last year's experience when larvae were scarce and no adults were tagged.Encouraging news from this part of northern Ontario on Georgian Bay!

My wife and I collected 31 caterpillars today for school in less than 2 hours. We were surrounded by monarch butterflies at times. They were all over the place. I found one that had just hatched sitting next to its chrysalis. We then watered the monarch waystation. There were 12 monarchs nectaring on the zinnias in the waystation. We also tend another garden next to the school and there were 4 monarchs nectaring there. Monarchs have been flying all over the town throughout last week. If you drive to the store, you probably see 4 to 5 without even trying. It is a banner year in Northeastern Wisconsin.

It's been really hot, humid and windy from the SW for the past week. A cold front went through last night making for GREAT monarch watching today. I went out on our boat to the middle of White Bear Lake to count migrating monarchs. I was NOT disappointed!

With light winds from the NW and partly cloudy skies, I counted 173 monarchs in 2 hours flying from the NNE to SSW. It was AMAZING! Then when I landed the boat on the south shore, there were another 35-40 monarchs on the beach. I've never seen this many monarchs in this area since I've been watching for the past 8 years.

Multitudes of magnificent Monarchs methodically meandering on the Mexican migration.  7:30pm, 60 degrees, winds 15 mph out of the NW.  Stepping out to the deck, there were dozens of Monarchs drifting in and out of the tops of the whispering, sunkissed pines, visible in one sighting.  This went on until dusk, about 45min.  It may be that we're on the back of a low pressure system, or that the migration path has once again swung over our area, or the population is significantly up.  Whatever it is, in the last 1-2 weeks, we are experiencing a migration unseen in close to a decade.  A sore neck tomorrow, but well worth it.  billiam    My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

A large group of Monarchs were migrating through St. Ignace near the Mackinaw bridge and crossing the straits to lower Michigan on Sept. 6th.  They were flying through all morning and afternoon. There was a constant stream of new butterflies to replace the ones that passed you by, and they never let up all the time I was there. I saw hundreds of Monarchs if not close to a thousand that day. My observation time: I was watching for a combined 3 hours and 30 minutes both in the morning and afternoon.

Wednesday was a spectacular day for monarch watching over central Iowa. The weather was cool, the wind was slight, and the sky was clear, so the migrating monarchs were flooding down from the north. More than 1,000 monarchs were counted during afternoon observations. At Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, the monarchs were everywhere--especially where varieties of sunflowers could be found. During three hours of observations, 868 monarchs were counted. In addition, another 290 monarchs were observed along the roadways to and from the refuge, and at the end of the day, other monarchs were flying into our butterfly garden in Altoona.

Last weekend I saw the monarchs migrating-->  about 60 per hour.Then yesterday another wave came thru.  They just kept coming and coming.  Again about 60 / hr. My observation time: I was watching for 1 hours and _10 minutes.

Monarchs were observed migrating south after the cold front that came through on Friday.  Saturday and Sunday both were huge travel days for the Monarchs here in East Central Iowa. Many, many monarchs have been migrating through Shawano, Wisconsin the past two days (9/5-6). My wife and I were in the school gardens on Saturday and saw monarch after monarch migrating in a southern direction. Today, while playing tennis for 2 hours, my opponent and I watched monarch after monarch fly over the courts, through our games, and around us. It was distracting because they were coming one to two at a time and both of us kept watching for them. One time I threw the ball up to serve and when I looked up at it there was a monarch right above it by a couple feet. These were headed in a western direction rather than a southern direction. The wind was blowing from the south so that may explain their direction.

Earlier this week (Sept. 1 and Sept. 2) I was teaching my second graders about monarchs, their life cycles, and the migration. It was pretty neat because we had monarchs drifting by our classroom window during this time and the kids could see them. All of them were headed in the same direction (west again) and they looked like they were flying with a purpose. Same thing at recess, monarchs kept coming.

This was another wonderful day for observing the monarch butterfly migration over central Iowa. The monarchs were everywhere at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge and elsewhere. During four hours of observations at Neal Smith, a record 1,744 monarchs were counted as they nectared on the flowers and sought to continue their movement south. A brisk wind from the east southeast slowed the butterflies' flight. About 9:30 a.m., 265 monarchs were observed and counted in a large stand of tickseed sunflowers in the far north part of the refuge where they likely had spent their overnight hours. At other points in the refuge, monarchs appeared to be seeking out nectaring places as they continued their migration.

Hawk Cliff at Port Stanley, ON (Lake Erie)

The movement of Monarchs today was amazing.  A couple of individuals at the cliff edge decided to start counting how many a minute were passing.  Over the course of 3 hours they were reaching 100-130 Monarchs a minute!  This didn't even include those crossing the entire hawkwatch area ...just those right along the cliff.  If we're lucky many of these will roost in the trees in and around the hawkwatch and be there early tomorrow morning.
