At 11:00 AM this morning I counted 64 Monarchs in 10 minutes at Clearville Park on the north shore of Lake Erie. All butterflies were in flight moving south-west parallel to shore. Some were dropping down looking for nectar plants. It has been cool and windy here for the past few days. Temp was 62 F, partly sunny with a strong west wind. At 4 PM I counted 10 butterflies in the space of 10 minutes, all moving south west. Temp was 61 and cloudy.      My observation time: I was watching for 20 minutes.

Unbelievable this AM.  I was out in the barn and decided to look up at least 100 monarchs overhead in a 30 min time span.  Could have counted longer, but there were chores to do.  Very cool night last night 44 F, but bright sun this AM and getting warm fast. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __30_ minutes.
thousands of Monarchs flying more or less South right at or below tree top height...amazing My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___30 minutes.

Yesterday (9/10/10), we saw many monarchs, starting with a trip to town early in the afternoon. Within a half mile of our house, I spotted over a dozen butterflies crossing the roads. It was sunny, about 67F with a slight breeze. Then later in the afternoon we noticed more and more monarchs flying about and landing in the goldenrod weeds in the hedgerow on the east side of our house. I checked out the adjoining farmer's field of soybeans, where there were more goldenrod weeds, and I found even more monarchs. I guess I must have seen maybe 100 or so. Unfortunately, in the evening when I looked for any roosts, I didn't find any.

Migration is about 40 - 60 per minute, down from last hour.  This bunch more leisurely, even taking time to chase each other in circles as they make their way in a South/Southeasterly direction on light warm breezes.  they are flying about at treetop height (40-70 ft) with some coming down to check me out as they pass over.  Very sorry that my butterfly bushes are done blooming for the year. My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours.

WOW !  This morning was amazing.  I was sitting outside in my back yard this morning as the butterflies slowly began to flutter past - at first just a few - then, looking up, directly across my driveway and STRAIGHT OVERHEAD - then by the dozens -- then seemingly by the hundreds !  We have a large Rose of Sharon bush in our yard still in bloom with plenty of flowers - many of the butterflies stopped on it for a while - it looked alive with moving hues of golden orange !!  This went on for easily an hour or more this morning.  What a beautiful sight ! My observation time: I was watching for 1 hours and 20 minutes, around 11:00 a.m. EDST on Saturday, September 11, 2010.

About 10:30 this morning, breezy, cool, warm sun -- suddenly so many monarch butterflies.  Never seen anything like this in my 50 years of life!Looked up and saw a couple. Then a few more. Then more and more and more......   I traveled a mile west, and saw them there too (St. Clair Shores).  Did some shopping, came out and saw more!   My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and 30___ minutes.

The Monarch Butterfly Fall Migration started here on August 28. It has continued ever since with some days being heavier than others. Today, between 12:30 and 1:10 PM, I counted the Monarchs as they flew southward over the bank on the east side of Lake Huron. They were clearly following the lakeshore about 20 meters inland from the water's edge, where there is much vegetation. I had a good view from the top of the bank where I could see over the vegetation and out to the water's edge. I took three measurements. The rate of Monarch Butterflies passing was 7 per minute (equivalent to 1 every 11.6 seconds or 420 per hour). My observation time: I was watching for __0_ hours and __40_ minutes.

I witnessed 34 Monarchs flying southbound within one half hour.  Mostly one at a time, but at one point, three were flying together.  I live in a crowded suburb of Detroit and have either never noticed or witnessed this before.  It was stunning! My observation time: I was watching for 0 hours and 30 minutes.

we saw about 100 monarch  spread out over the course of 20 min at about 10:30 in the morning some high in the air and some low flying over the houses.  My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and _20__ minutes.

Standing in front of The Beach Plum, Rt 1A North Hampton, New Hampshire, across the street form the ocean, the Monarchs were flying from the ocean side over the road, and heading South-Southwest directly over the Restaurant. I counted 25. My observation time: I was watching for _0__ hours and _15__ minutes.

Driving around town today, I noticed a lot of monarchs flying south.  I was seeing about 1 monarch every 5 to 10 seconds, sometimes more.  I probably saw about 150 between noon and one o'clock.  It was amazing! My observation time: I was watching for __1_ hours and _0__ minutes.

Heavy migration through our yard today.  I tagged 11 monarchs and nmissed as many. Many migrated through and didn't stop.  Have never caught so many in my yard in one day - some years I haven't caught 11 in our yard!  They were edgy - stopping only for a quick sip and heading out.  Strong NW wind much of the day. My observation time: I was watching for _5__ hours and __30_ minutes.

There were hundreds of Monarch butterflies all over Fairfield, Iowa today.  I first noticed them sunning themselves on the hot gravel parking lot near the University campus and generally flying South-SW all day...especially over the noon to 3PM hours.I counted 30 per 5 minutes at the peak today...that was over 300 per hour...amazing...i've never seen so many at one time before.  No matter where I was doing my erends while driving around town...there the were!!! All over the sky. The wind was perfect... helping them fly south..the wind was coming out of the North and they were so happy fluttering throught the sky. The weather was perfect..a sunny, blue sky, a nice, strong breeze to help them  fly south...just perfect!I have not seen the roosting but I'm usually not out at that time.  Not sure where to look or what time of the day...It was a most wonderful and most amazing day!! It was soooo exciting! My observation time: I was watching for __1_ hours and _30__ minutes.

I hardly ever see Monarchs anymore.  Today I was dropping my son off at work and I saw a huge one fluttering around my truck.  As I drove to the grocery store (about 4 miles away), going towards home, I saw so many Monarchs. Most were in small groups and noticing them I began counting.  I saw 55 in 4 miles.  I also stopped at Home Depot and there were 3 in the garden center.  I was so amazed. I was sad today with the anniversary of 9/11.  It was such a welcome surprise on this day.   My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

The monarchs are here!!While at Robert Moses Beach on the South Shore of Long Island/Atlantic Ocean, I spotted over 575 monarchs. This is the most I have seen in many years and I can't recall seeing them so early in September. Many monarchs were flying in pairs, something I have never seen before.They were all very healthy looking and flying strong. Today was a sunny day with temps in the high 70s and a light SSE wind. With the migration being 10 days earlier than in previous years,their usual feeding source of golden rod like plants, have not yet bloomed.At dusk as the clouds rolled in, they were flying to the pine trees to roost for the night. Unfortunately due to lots of poison ivy around the trees, I could not get close enough to the trees to take any photos. My observation time: I was watching for 4 hours and 30 minutes.

The beauty of the monarch migration played out today across the hillsides and prairie of Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. A strong wind of 15 to 20 miles an hour from the northwest spurred the monarchs south in record-setting numbers on a clear day. The sight was amazing as they moved across the landscape in ones, twos, and threes or more. Some were flying low--10 feet or so above ground. Others were hundreds of feet above in a beautiful blue sky. They floated, they sped, they chased each other. Some stopped briefly on the wildflowers. In four hours of observation, 3,085 monarchs were counted. Many were counted from a single spot on a hillside as they made their way south across the prairie.
We saw over 50+ monarchs near the high school soccer fields. We were able to catch and tag 21. My observation time: I was watching for 2___ hours and 0___ minutes.

While driving yesterday (Sept. 11) about 11:20am I observed at least several hundred monarchs floating overhead. It was an awesome experience.  I have never seen anything like it before.  Totally unbelievable. My observation time: I was watching for 0___ hours and.15 ___ minutes.
More butterflies floating now that the rain ended and the sun is out.  approx 50 My observation time: I was watching for __0_ hours and _15__ minutes.

Hundreds of Monarch butterflies were seen flying at high and low levels over our house while we were sitting on the porch.  The numbers were enormous and the sight magnificent. My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and 30___ minutes.

Last evening (9/11) there were hundreds of butterflies fluttering among the tree tops on the Orford Bluffs overlooking Lake Erie. Today there were an astonishing number of butterflies in the air and moving south west at the top of the cliffs through Clearville. They are all moving towards Pt Pelee National Park -50 miles to the south west from Clearville. This is where the Monarchs leave this part of Canada and cross Lake Erie to Ohio. At noon today we counted 310 per hour flying through the park at tree top level, all flapping their wings and moving in the same direction - south west. Very few drop down to nectar. The numbers this afternoon were a little less at 250 per hour. Temp was 65 F, sunny, winds calm.  My observation time: I was watching for 2hours.

Cranberry Marsh in Whitby, Ontario:

Over the first 7 hours 483 hawks were counted, along with at least 600 Monarch butterflies.

Forwarded by Don Davis

Just been down to Owen Pt ï¿½ about 10,000? Monarchs in 15-20 clusters plus lots of loose ones. Most quite high and well off trail.

Lighthouse has about 500 in 3 clusters. Lighthouse monarchs are much lower, closer and in open so much more photogenic.

All are facing east so first light (if we get any sun) has potential for some nice pictures. Iï¿½m coming back early!Thanks a lot Bill for the phone calls. This is pretty fantastic. Best Don T has seen on the mainland in 20 years of working here.

Forwarded by Don Davis
hundreds flying south, some taking there time,while some not wasting any time. My observation time: I was watching for __8_ hours and __0_ minutes.

We were traveling North on I-99 to State College.  We saw Monarch after Monarch on their southbound journey.  I would estimate about 100+/hour.   My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and __0_ minutes.

This weekend there were butterflies all over drifting through the air. They seemed mostly clustered around bushes on the  sand dunes. My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours and __0_ minutes.

Looking out window over Waukegan Harbor observed hundreds of Monarch passing from North to South and going up over the harbor, also spotted many dragonflies moving over the water with the Monarchs My observation time: I was watching for __1_ hours and ___ minutes.

Last count said hundreds, I now need to update to thousands of both Monarchs and dragonflies My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and ___ minutes.
This past weekend (Sept 11 - 12) - we saw monarchs by the hundreds on fire island in the Ocean Beach area! My observation time: I was watching for _3__ hours and _45__ minutes.
Just amazing. 100's in my backyard the past few days all perched on flowerbeds with a mix of other smaller butterflys. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

While gardening i observed at least 58 monarch fluttering past, with many stopping in my garden to drink from the butterfly bush and various other flowers. this was between 3:30pm and 6pm My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and _30__ minutes.

From 1 pm though 3:30 pm, thousands of monarchs with many many dragonflies spanning a width of over 300 feet in organized fashion in a southwest direction My observation time: I was watching for 2 hours and 30 minutes.

We saw hundreds of monarchs resting on their long journey South. It was an amazing sight!

"How does one become a butterfly?" she asked pensively. "You must want to fly so much that you are able to give up being a caterpillar." ~Tina Paulus My observation time: I was watching for 1 hours and ___ minutes.
Sighted hundreds overhead and all around us while driving on Harper Ave. from 11 to 13 Mile Road about 2 PM.  My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and _10__ minutes.
Saw 120 monarchs flying SW through our work parking lot (about every 30 seconds) My observation time: I was watching for __1_ hours and __0_ minutes.

I saw about 30-40 monarchs flying south near Holy Rosary Church on Sunday September 12. It was around 9:00. Ever since i've heard about monarchs migrating, I've seen so much butterflys around. My observation time: I was watching for __ hours and ___ minutes.

The first big push of Monarchs through Walpole Island First Nation took place Sunday. An estimate would be 5-7 thousand. It was continuous streams of Monarchs overhead all day. Taking the ferry back to the states, our attendants were indicating that many Monarch were landing on the 2 ferries hitching a ride over! The Monarchs were flying high and riding the winds. It was quite extraordinary and there sat my net as we banded hummingbirds. Of the three roosts we are now aware of, we were able to check two of these hidden treasures and there were no roosts this weekend. It is good to see all of these Monarchs once again. Walpole Island is located north of Detroit, MI on the Canadian Shores of Lake St.Clair. A very beautiful place and much more lovely on Sunday with the Monarchs.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

After slowing down for two days, the migration of monarch butterflies picked up again at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Today was a clear, warm, and beautiful day with a slight breeze. The monarchs were coming into the refuge in the north and stopping along the way on sawtooth and tickseed sunflowers for nectaring. In 2 1/2 hours in the late morning, 640 monarchs were counted.

For the record, 217 monarchs were observed Sunday (9/12) in two hours in the morning and 63 monarchs were counted Monday (9/13) in one hour in mid-afternoon.

I don't know if this is because of the migration across Lake Ontario or not, but we were golfing in Penfield, NY, just outside of Rochester, and at every hole we would see 2-3 monarchs. I have never seen so many....to the point that even my husband and son commented on it. Some were just resting on the greens (two or three at a time), but others were soaring back and forth over the fairways. Then a torrential downpour came as we got to the 12th hole and when we were able to go out again, they were all gone...probably drying off in the trees. I don't know if we get them as they cross Lake Ontario, but I would think that we might. It wasn't as exciting as seeing them clustered by the thousands in trees, but it was still very cool!Waystation 3277

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Sitting at a picnic table in Southport Park, Kenosha Wi. Enjoying the wonderful view of Lake Michigan, A lone Monarch appeared. A couple of minutes later three more appeared. At the waters edge they appeared out of nowhere after completing their flight over Lake Michigan.  In short time that I watched I estimate I saw about fifty Monarchs in 30 minutes.
There was a spectacular hawk and monarch flight today at Rosetta McClain Gardens in Toronto. Monarchs: Hundreds streaming by going west like the hawks.

A nice 2nd wave (peak?)came in today when I observed 216 monarchs migrating south along the Lake Huron shoreline at Harrisville State Park. Some were resting on the beach while some were on goldenrod plants. My observation time: I was watching for __4_ hours and _0_ minutes.
At the beach today @ surf city LBI NJ and observed hundreds of butterflies coming off the ocean heading inland. My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and __30_ minutes.

Many monarchs observed on LBI attempting to fly SE against a 10-15 mph westerly breeze My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __15_ minutes, estimate seeingapproximately 50-65 monarchs per minute

I observed thousands of monarch, large dragonflies and other species of butterflies coming on shore for most of the day. The numbers were incredible. I have never seen anything like this before. My observation time: I was watching for 5 hours.

While visiting Assateague Island the week of Sept 5 through the 11, saw several small waves of butterflies along the beach. Wed the 8th was probably the largest amount of waves. They were all over the place -- all day long -- heading south. I had never seen the actual migration taking place but had heard/and or read about it; so it was exciting to actually see them migrating. Iwasn't sure how far they migrated, but I knew it was pretty far south. It was fun to be a part of this year's migration. Primilla Young My observation time: I was watching for _5-6__ hours and ___ minutes.

Today has to be a peak day for migration in this area! While my counts are never more than singles or on a good day several in a group, I saw them everywhere today. The first was checking out the gardens at daybreak, then I found 6 more in a still blooming patch of Ironweed. Three were tasting pears beneath our pear tree and through out the day driving to the lakeshore of Lake Michigan, I saw single Monarchs drifting across the freeway and down the lakeshore despite high winds. Final tally was only 25 for me, but there had to be a lot moving through that went unseen. My observation time - dawn to dusk.

Long Beach Island, NJ, is currently seeing one of the most abundant showings of migrating monarchs in years -- if not decades. Light westerly winds have blown them over to this barrier island. There are far too many to even estimate a count. I have been rough counting them since the early 1970s and have to harken back to those early years to recall seeing so many. I know of no local roosting points with this migration -- due, in part, to the loss of weeping willow trees, a tree species commonly used by roosting monarchs in our part of Jersey.   My observation time: I was watching for __6+_ hours and ___ minutes.
I saw approximately 100 per hour flying northeast to southwest along the beach (Tobay Beach, New York). Many stopping to feed My observation time: I was watching for__2_ hours and _15__ minutes.
I watched for 6 hours and counted 100 monarchs.

As I was volunteering at Olbrich Botanical Gardens this a.m. I observed at least 100 Monarchs feeding on one of the white flowering trees (can't remember it's name) that sits near the center of the garden.  They were everywhere in the garden, but were really loving that tree.  That prompted me to look into their migration, and here I am! My observation time: I was watching for _3__ hours and ___ minutes.

We drove down from Jackson to Cape May yesterday (9/14) (going south).  From 4:15 to 5:15 I counted 54 monarchs while we were driving, all flying south. When we arrived the garden was 'teeming' with monarchs, buckeyes and a few red admirals.  We had a small roost last night--about 100 or so monarchs.  All day to day the migration here has been AWESOME! I sat on the porch this am as they dropped down out of the sky to nectar in our gardens, On the beach this afternoon we watched the show...I have to say for the first time the buckeyes are out numbering all the others about 15 to 1. We watched literally thousands of them stream by.  Still there were an impressive number of monarchs (in very hearty shape I might add!!) and I am looking forward to seeing if we can find any of the larger roosts here in Cape May this eve.   My observation time: I was watching all day!

My husband and I observed Monarch Butterflies seemingly coming out of the ocean. We were on Long Beach Island in New Jersey. We saw at least 500 or more Monarchs in a 3 hour period. My observation time: I was watching for 3 hours.

Our backyard had been host to dozens of monarchs! They pause a bit on trees and bushes, but move on, no roost tree, yet. They especially love the zinnia, they spend lots of time on the still bright flowers.  My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

on September 9th, 10,000 to 15,000 monarchs were counted by members, just east of Port Burwell.

The numbers were estimated by counting and extrapolating over a three-hour period from 1 to 4pm by our Otter Vally Naturalists, so actual numbers were likely higher. Numbers passing by, not a cluster. And this was at Ron's Monarch Landing property.

The Port Burwell Provincial Park and Port Burwell Memorial Park are within the town.

We had a big cluster observed in the same evening in the Memorial Park and then watched them take off the next morning.

Monarchs are still passing by today (9/15) in strength.

About 3pm a large flock/swarm of mixed butterflies & dragonflies came from the ocean and landed on the island.  My normal "density" of Monarchs at peak migration is about 20 in the yard (60x90 ft)at a time.  The swarm reached densities of over 200 in the yard and in surrounding areas up to 100 yards in all directions before dispersing over a 45 minute time frame to roosts.  I identified mostly Monarchs with about 10% of other species - mostly Painted Ladies & Buckeyes.  There were also Crescents or Fritillaries & possibly some Coppers & Brown Elfins.  I saw one male Tiger Swallowtail.  My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and ___ minutes.

There is a constant stream of monarchs everywhere on Dune Road. We have taken pictures of groups of them, feeding we guess, on a particular bush that has small yellowish flowers. There were always at least 20-30 on this particular bush all day, many coming and going all the time. We noticed that every bush of this type was similarly covered along Dune Road. In the evening we saw them resting on the black pines. My observation time: I was watching for 10 minutes.

At cape may point we saw hundreds of Monarchs  waiting to cross the Delaware bay.there were many with tags . we have video and photos of tagged butterflies.with permission to take photos on private property,we hung out for a while and to our surprise the biologists arrived to tag more  so we video that too . it was a great experience to be involved with a tagging.:]  The weather was steady 20 mph west wind ,blue sky 75 deg. My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and _30__ minutes.
In two hours of observation at Neal Smith National  Wildlife Refuge, 568 monarchs were counted.

Saw at least 50 monarchs within an hour at the Jug Bay Wetland Sanctuary.  This is an indication for me of the importance of wetlands to migratory species. My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and ___ minutes.
5000 Monarchs moved through Hawk Cliff on Sept 15 between the hours of 9:00 and 1:00 My observation time: I was watching for __4_ hours.

I went to retrieve our mail.  Our mailbox is along a highway and a truck drove by stirring the air. When what to my wondering eyes should see, but hundreds of monarchs rising our of our goldenrod.  What an amazing sight!

The "monarch march" appears to be in full swing. We did not have a large number of monarchs this summer as we had in the past, but beginning last week we saw them start floating in. Yesterday they were on the property by the 100's-too numerous to count. From early morning to dusk. This is right on time with prior years, since 2005. We've seen this activity as late as end Sept early october in 2005 and 2006. But in the last 3 years our journal indicates September 15th being "the" day of the big march. My observation time: I was watching for  10 hours. I don't know quite how to answer this as we formally and informally watch throughout the day-from 8am to about 6pm.

This afternoon while boating Rondeau Bay we saw 39 sharp shinned and 4 Coopers hawks migrating through on the sand point across from Erie in less than an hour. Also about 1,000 monarch butterflies passed by.

Forwarded by Don Davis

September 17
With the northerly winds that Mona spoke about earlier, and a bright sunny day here in Toronto - not overly warm at ground level but the sun exceptionally warm - an excellent southward movement of monarchs south through city streets and roads, transit and subway lines, hydro right-of-ways and so forth. Probably thousands again on the waterfront.This was most visible where I was - in east Toronto (formerly the City of Scarborough in what was Metropolitan Toronto), just a few kilometers north of Lake Ontario.

September 15
I dropped down to the Toronto waterfront after work today and to the renowned Leslie Street Spit - a huge carpet of goldenrod this time of year - and encountered thousands, if not tens of thousands of monarchs there. Captured about 200 in 1.5 hours, sometimes capturing 4 at a time on a goldenrod stem. Then about 6:15 clouds moved in and with the approaching rains and cold front, they roosted and disappeared ever so suddenly about from the goldenrod. Found a number of small roosts on Manitoba maple and poplar, but there must be a larger roosts in the park. My observations were only from the base of the park near the main entrance. Cyclists who had been much further out report "tons" of monarchs and trees with roosts out there.

I work on the 22nd Floor in an office building at King & Simcoe. Between approximately 10:00am-10:15am, I witnessed more than 20 monarchs fly by the window at that height.  They were all headed south out over Lake Ontario.   My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __15_ minutes.
my husband and I observed over 60 monarchs flying over our house between 5 and 6pm on the 15th  My observation time:1 hour I was watching for 1 hours and ___ minutes.

This past Sunday, the 12th, we starting seeing monarchs-one by one-fly past our window through the backyard.  We live literally 1 block east of the Mississippi River, by the way. The weather was beautiful that day, not too windy or cool, mid- 70's. We observed them morning through evening following the same path through our backyard, heading south, but noticed they often came from 2 or 3 different northerly directions.  One flew by every 3-5 seconds.  It was awesome. We also noticed large gangs of bluejays who were hollering all morning.  Will they eat monarchs? In the evening the neighboring unhabited lot directly south of us provided overnight rest in its' many large coniferous trees. I saw only a few more the next day bit I was not watching as closely cuz I couldn't. Hope this helps. I will never forget that day. "For since the creation of the world God's invisible qualities-his eternal power and divine nature-have been clearly seen, being understood from what has been made, so that men are without excuse." Romans 1:20 May the Creator be forever praised. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

Today had been cloudy and cool with temperatures in the 60's F.  At 5pm the skies began to clear and the sun warmed the temperature to around 70 degrees F. That's when the Monarchs began to appear, most sailing serenely at tree top or above, enjoying the sunshine.  There was no wind.  In 105 minutes, I counted 135 Monarchs.  I'm sure they have been held up by the recent storms and heavy rains.  It was so wonderful to see the migration again! My observation time: I was watching for __1_ hours and _45__ minutes.

After several days, the wind returned to the north northwest at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, stirring up more monarch butterfly activity. In two hours and 45 minutes during the morning and early afternoon, 650 monarchs were observed in various areas of the refuge. Some were nectaring primarily on sawtooth sunflowers while perhaps half of them were speeding or floating to the south over the fields. The day was cool and mostly cloudy with a wind of 15 to 20 miles an hour. On occasions when the sun came out, the monarchs were more active. At one point in the northern part of the refuge, the sun brought  on a flurry of monarch movement.

My daughter Mindy reported seeing about 20 monarchs an hour today migrating through Delaware County, PA as she was driving.  Mindy started collecting and raising monarchs with me when she was old enough to walk... Mindy was watching for about _1__ hour, not constantly but as driving for work.

I live on the 11th floor right by lake ontario. I watched at least 30-40 monarchs pass by my window today. It was an amazing sight. The largest group I watched consisted of about 8 monarchs. Usually though I see 1-3 passing by at once.

Counted 25 in a 12 minute period while I was sitting in my car on the South Beach in South Haven, Michigan.  All were heading South.  Breeze, calm.   My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and _15__ minutes.

on break from job...30 mins..slight wind from SW...mostly sunny, few high clouds...50 to 100 Monarchs singly and in groups of 3-5...about 3 to 5 storys up on courthouse..I do not know the feet measurement... My observation time: I was watching for _.5__ hours and _0__ minutes.

The same day there were so many at Presqu'ile (9/9), I had to drive to Toronto and stopped at Wicklow Beach. Within seconds of getting out of the car I became aware of large numbers of Monarchs flying west (as well as good numbers of Sharp-shins + a few other raptors). Standing at the boat launch and looking out over the jetty and lake, I estimated that about 100/minute were passing at all heights and distances out. That figure does not count any birds north of the parking lot (and there were some) where trees obscure the view. While I didn't see any clusters roosting, the numbers moving past were amazing. When I got home I heard about the Presqu'ile flight, so clearly there were 1000's in Northumberland that day.

Forwarded by Don Davis
Every 30seconds a Monarch went by all Sunday long.

Clearville Park is located on the north shore of Lake Erie at the Orford bluffs, just east Of Rondeau Provincial Park. Today at 4:00 PM - 400 butterflies per hour observed flying parallel to the lake shore and towards Pt Pelee which is 50 miles to the south-west. Pt Pelee is where the butterflies cross the lake to Ohio.  My observation time: I was watching for 1 hour.

Clearville Park is located on the north shore of Lake Erie at the Orford bluffs, just east Of Rondeau Provincial Park. These are today's Monarch butterfly counts at Clearville Park: 9:00am to 10:00am - 2500 per hour travelling to the south-west along the lake Erie shore. Temp 60 F, sunny, wind - calm. 10:30am to 11:30am - counted 5000 monarchs in 1 hour all flying parallel to the Lake Erie shore and towards Pt Pelee which is 50 miles to the south-west. Pt Pelee is where the butterflies cross the lake to Ohio. Temp 62 F, sunny, calm winds. 6:45 PM- Butterflies are now dropping to the ground and flitting amoung the trees at Clearville Park. Some trees have  roosts in them. 86 butterflies counted moving between tree tops in the space of 10 minutes.   My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.
hard to miss hitting a few as I drove around town today My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours and ___ minutes.
Standing outside at the end of the day within a ten minute time span we saw 37 monarchs fly over our playground! My observation time: I was watching for 10 minutes.
Actually they have been here about a week to a week & a half. My observation time: I was watching for _240__ hours and ___ minutes.
Driving along Atlantic Ocean on Coopers Neck, Southampton, NY, spotted hundreds of Monarchs in the air and clustered on one particular type of bush all along the road.

No roosting since the very windy day reported previously, but the butterfly gardens here at the Nature Center are full of Monarchs.  It's not unusual to see 40-50 of them at any given time. Our gardens are heavily stocked with Butterfly Bush - mostly the dark purple ones - and they are certainly a magnet for Monarchs.   I've been tagging, but I'll run out soon - makes me wish I had ordered more tags.  We also have 22 chrysalis' hanging in the Nature Center that should emerge in the next week. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __30_ minutes.

Finally a very low count season send us some migration for the butterflies. temperature today 86 degrees, wind from SW, about 12mph. Our first batch of monarchs found our field of wildflowers this afternoon at 3:00pm. count roughly 75 in one hours time. This year we have had the least sightings of monarchs and larvae found in 3 years. I really thought they may miss us on the way south also. I have watched all summer, and walked the last 2 weeks waiting for today, most spotted before were 2-3 a day. For us no roost yet, but I heard 20 miles from us the cedar trees have been full the last 2 nights.  My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and _0__ minutes.

another large migration of monarchs going through my back yard today. most were stopping to rest and draw nectar from ironweed and sweet autumn clematis. My observation time: I was watching for __4_ hours and ___ minutes.
Walking along the boardwalk in Ventnor City, I saw over 50 flitting across the boardwalk from the beach to the town, within the space of a mile.

IN Beach Haven this week, I had noticed  many more Monarchs than I had seen all summer, maybe 35- 50 per day . Very unusual. Then yesterday, about 4 PM, I was watching from the front porch as porch  HUNDREDS of Butterflies appreared overhead. ! All in formation, flying south. From eye level to the tree tops, from the Bay to 3 blocks away at the Ocean, the sky was covered with Monarchs flying from the North. Then , more came, and more and more and more. First hundreds, then THOUSANDS, then tens of thousands. The sky was covered. What a sight!!!!!!!!!  For about 20 minutes, the Monarchs were so thick , then for the next 40 minutes they kept passing but thinned out to 35- 50 at a time . 24 hours later, they were still coming, but only at a very slow rate of 10 or 15 every minute.  My observation time: I was watching for 1 hours and ___ minutes.

The migration continued today from the morning hours until 2pm. A beautiful day!  Temperature in the 70's F, little or no wind.  Today the Monarchs flew at tree top level or below.  I counted 53 Monarchs in 60 minutes. My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and ___ minutes.

As I was driving to work this morning, I saw 22 monarchs in about 10 minutes.  I was going south on Missouri 291 between Salisbury and 39th Street.  The monarchs were flying over the highway from east to west. It was 9:48 when I pulled into the parking lot at work. I also saw 50-100 birds flying overhead in a swirling pattern. I'm not sure what kind they were. My observation time: I was watching for _0__ hours and _10__ minutes.

Monarchs continued to be observed at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. Mostly they nectaring on sunflowers in areas of the refuge. In 2 1/2 hours in the late morning, 515 monarchs were counted. The day was mostly clear with a wind of 5 to 10 miles an hour from the south southeast.

Beginning of my vacation in Brigantine, NJ (9/11/10) I saw Monarchs pass me by all day long. Everywhere I traveled in Brigantine, Monarchs were there. Left for home today (8/18/10) their presence still in the area. I will miss seeing their beauty.
Residential housing community.  Monarchs are floating all over the neighborhood--at least 5-8/100m. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __25_ minutes.

I just started counting this morning as I saw them flying overhead.  I was sitting on my patio and counted 150 in a little more than 1 hour. They came in waves.  It was fascinating to watch.  I saw more of them later in the day but wasn't able to count them. I'm going to keep watching!  I just looked up your website and thought that I would pass this info on.

I noticed consistant movement of monarchs low to the ground as well as higher in the sky. i would estimate at least 2-5 monarchs every 1-2 minutes. My observation time: I was watching for _6__ hours and ___ minutes.

Thousands of monarchs came into town today, dropping out of the sky so rapidly and in such large numbers that I didn't try to count them.  I watched from about 10:30  until 4:30 and peak activity seemed to be from 2-3.  Our block goes from East to West and our porch faces north....Needless to say we didn't do much other than watch the butterflies all day. Quite a show! My observation time: I was watching for _6__ hours and ___ minutes.
Thousand of butterflies picked up and left this morning....What an awe-inspiring site!  Watched from 7:30 until about 9. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

Although thousands of monarchs left this morning, there are still thousands in the state park nectaring.  My guess is the ones we saw coming in on Wed were the ones who left this am.  The ones who arrived yesterday, may hang a around a day or two since many of them (at least the ones that dropped by our cottage garden) appeared to be very fatigued. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

I started watching at 9:40am until 11:00am.  In the first hour I counted 146.  Total count 252. It is very overcast this morning.  I watched one Monarch that just seemed to fly around overhead as if he were waiting for others to catch up to him.  I thought this was interesting.  I plan to watch again this afternoon. My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and 20___ minutes.

Clearville Park is located on the north shore of Lake Erie at the Orford bluffs, just east of Rondeau Provincial Park. Today started out sunny but turned partly cloudy and then mostly cloudy around 11:00am. Temp was 64F, winds calm. 500 butterflies counted in 10 minutes all flying in the same direction - south west toward Pt Pelee which is 50 miles away. Pt. Pelee is were the Monarchs cross Lake Erie to Ohio. All butterflies were above 100 feet altitude with many butterflies much, much higher than that. Very few at ground level this morning. Some were so high they appeared as specks moving against the clouds. My observation time: I was watching for 10 minutes.

We saw quite a few on the 17th in the afternoon and then many more between 9AM and 11AM yesterday morning.  Very cool to see them during this peak migration period!  I would say we say we saw over 200 on and off during the 2 hour observation (which also included a stop in the action for breakfast). My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and ___ minutes.

We have just moved here to Fairfield, NE and have never witnessed this. I had no idea I would be seeing them..There weren't a lot but enough to make me curious. A half dozen at a time but continuous through the day.. My observation time: I was watching for 8 hours.

Saw 7 on my ride home from school which is about a mile at 1:00 pm in the afternoon. All were on Old Montauk Highway in Montauk, NY. My observation time: I was watching for _0__ hours and __3_ minutes.

Arrived at this southern New Jersey beach town in early afternoon of Friday on a 75 degree day and was amazed at hundreds of monarchs gliding throughout the town, stopping to nectar on impatiens and blackeyed susans still in bloom. I understand the day before had rain and hard winds.   The numbers continued throughout Saturday also.  I saw much fewer, however, on Sunday, even though the weather was the same.   My observation time: I was watching for ___1 hours and ___ minutes.

Hundreds of monarchs gliding through this southern New Jersey beach town on beautiful mid-70s day after rainy high winds storm along east coast night before.  They were nectaring on impatiens and remains of blackeyed susans.   My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours and ___ minutes.

Well, I thought my life was complete when I saw a Bald Eagle fly through the tree tops on my street this week.

But, this is heaven . Yesterday (9/17), at the Beach house, Armit & I witnessed the Migration of Monarchs . I had noticed all week many more Monarchs than I had seen all summer, maybe 35- 50 per day . Very unusual. Then yesterday, about 4 PM, Armit was on the front porch and called in to me to come see the butterflies. There were HUNDREDS! All in formation, flying south. From eye level to the tree tops, from the Bay to 3 weeks away at the Ocean, the sky was covered with Monarchs flying from the North. Then , more came, and more and more and more. First hundreds, then THOUSANDS, then tens of thousands. The sky was covered. What a sight!!!!!!!!! For about 20 minutes, the Monarchs were so thick , then for the next 40 minutes they kept passing but thinned out to 35- 50 at a time .

24 hours later, they were still coming, but only at a very slow rate of 10 or 15 every minute.

I am so lucky to have witnessed this migration.

Almost as amazing was how many people went about their busy lives, never looking up to notice the sky had changed from deep blue with white clouds to deep blue with solid orange wings!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

My boyfriend & I headed to Cape May yesterday, 9/19/10. In speaking with Louise Zemaitis form the MMP and an employee of the NJ Audubon we found out that thousands & thousands left the Cape around 8:00 am that morning. We missed it by a few hours. Denise, you may be seeing them soon and anyone down south. Monarchs were the most plentiful that we've ever seen. There were thousands at the State park, especially in the nature trails where there are wild sunflowers growing. Butterflies were everywhere, but thousands in the nature trails.

We were shocked when we saw a monarch watch tag on one of the thousands of butterflies. The tag number NMY940. I'd love to know who tagged this one.

A gentleman walking through the trail stopped & showed me a picture he had taken of a monarch with a tag on it as well, but it wasn't legible on the digital screen of his camera. I did see one more tagged monarch, but couldn't get close enough to see the number.

It was around 84 degrees, sunny with a light breeze. It was an absolutely incredible day.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

This morning I visited some of my field sites and tagged 20 monarchs as the numbers are starting to increase!!! All on Bidens, probably saw 50 total in just a half hour. Last year Baccharus was the main nectar source, but I guess since this year migration is a tad early they are all over the Bidens.

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

I was visiting my brother in Lindsborg ks, we were having a bbq in the yard. The wind had been coming out of the south, at around 6.00 pm it changed and started coming out of the North.Within a few min we begin to see the monarchs coming out of the north. Some were low but the majority of them were very high up and there were hundreds of them. Several family members and myself watched them for better than 20 min. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __20_ minutes.

Today 10 birders joined me the Toronto Ornithological Club (TOC) outing along the Durham waterfront. We found 71 species of birds, one turtle (a very young Painted), several dragonfly species (nothing unusual) and many many hundreds of Monarchs + Viceroy, Red Admiral, Clouded Sulphur and Mourning Cloak.

Courtesy of Carolina Leps
Monarchs passing in numbers too numerous to count without mechanical counter over a period of six hours. My observation time: I was watching for _6__ hours and _0__ minutes.
Hundred of Monarch's seen on the City Walking Trail at this location. My observation time: I was watching all day.

I The observed 25 females, 3 males and 20 unidenitfied monarchs during this 35 minute period.  They were traveling East to West. The day was very sunny. The temperature was 66 degrees and the humidity was 73%. Muskegon is located on the eastern shore of Lake Michigan.  My observation time: I was watching for __0_ hours and __35_ minutes.

I was traveling from Pittsburgh to Buffalo...about the last hour stretch on the NYS Thruway I was dodging Monarchs... traffic slowed, there must have been 100 spaced out but came at a steady rate.   My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and _30__ minutes.

The day was sunny and warm with a strong wind from the south southeast  at 20-25 miles an hour. During a late afternoon visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife  Refuge, 80 monarchs were observed in an hour. Several were noted fighting the wind, but most were found in the savanna trail area of the refuge. There they were nectaring on wildflowers on a forested hillside and stopping to rest on the branches of oak trees.

September 22
I was surfing in the afternoon off of the north end in Virginia beach...I noticed 2 monarchs gliding on the wind headed south out over the breakers. My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours.

September 20
I was coming out of the ocean from surfing...there was a 30 mph wind coming from the north...I observed at least 10-12 monarchs pass over my head while out in the ocean....once i was done surfing and came back over the dunes I witnessed at least 11 monarchs hanging around several pine trees behind the dunes trying to keep out of the strong wind. Our class is busy looking for monarchs. We have had students see them on bike rides, morning bus rides, skateboarding and just in their backyards. We have seen a total of 613 since the weekend! My observation time: I was watching for 48hours and ___ minutes.

Still observing some Monarchs traveling SW across LBI. Estimate 12-15 rate per minute.While kyaking Barnegat Bay observed a single Monarch returning back eastward from over the bay (forgot something for the trip?) My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and __5_ minutes.

Saw several dozen monarchs over a distance of a couple of miles. Sadly, most of them seemed to be crossing busy roads and highways, but I didn't see any of them take a direct hit. My observation time: I was watching for 0__ hours and _30__ minutes.

Tonight around 7:30pm there were hundreds of Monarch butterflies flying pretty high in a westerly direction, is it too early for their migration?

Poor Mountain Hawk Watch
Definitely a monarch butterfly day with butterflies passing by the whole time, with a total of 2129 counted. They were still passing by when we left the count site.

Total observation time: 4.5 hours

My wife Karen and I spent this past Friday (9/17) to Sunday (9/19) at Pelee and despite some cooler and cloudy weather at times, there were some interesting butterflies to be seen.

Friday was cloudy and cool with northeast winds, but in less than 2 hours walking south along West Beach from the VC (Visitor Centre to the tip I estimated about 5000 Monarchs flying south in a constant stream overhead. Best day was Saturday when winds were brisk out of the southwest.

Forwarded by Don Davis

On 9/21, north of DC, there was a steady stream of monarchs migrating right over the C&O Canal Towpath. They were flying low, between 6-10 feet off the ground.The location was Dickerson Conservation Park, just south of the Montgomery County/Frederick County line. If they continued over the towpath, they would have gone right through Georgetown and into DC.

Nectar sources were plentiful, and included blue mistflower, tickseed sunflower, wingstem, upland boneset, several asters, and 3 species of goldenrod.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We are second and third graders from the Woodhull School on Fire Island. We took a walk down to the beach and saw thousands and thousands of butterflies migrating. The weather was nice. The sky was blue and gray. We watched for about 20 minutes and we counted about 45 butterflies in one minute. We watched from 1:45 to 2:05.

September 19

We were on the ferry from Lewes, Delaware to Cape May, New Jersey and the Monarchs just kept coming, flying over the ferry from the New Jersey side to the Delaware side. It was truly an amazing sight! My observation time: approximately 10:30 am. I was watching for about an hour

September 20

Coming back from N.J. to Lewes, we spotted 5 Monarchs on the way to Lewes. One exceptional sighting was on the Ferry Boat from Cape May, N.J. to Lewes, DE. It was actually hitching a ride over the bay.!!!!!!!!!!

I have been watching..waiting.......only occasional sightings for the last 5 or 6 days.  My home is located about 20 to 30 miles south of Cherry Gap Cove on the Blue Ridge Parkway, a low pass used by the monarchs.  Today, two waves of monarchs passed through, from about 3:00 to 5:00.  Skies had become overcast and there were scattered showers in the area, though none here.  I counted 100 quickly..............I am sure our area saw many hundreds in two waves..........my husband and a friend confirmed from  two other close locations.  A few monarchs lighted briefly in trees as a larger cloud and mist formed, and one of our four resident hummingbirds  was observed challenging a resting monarch for his territory .  Skies cleared about 5:30, no more butterflies today. My observation time: I was watching for __4_ hours and ___ minutes.

I was very lucky to witness the mass migration on Saturday, Sept. 18. We went to Corson's Inlet State Park in Strathmere, NJ. It is located at the very end of Ocean City. We arrived at 7:45am. The air was still brisk, but as the sun warmed the grasses and shrubs, the monarchs lifted out of the dunes like magic! I didn't get very good photos, but I did take some video! We estimated that we saw several thousand monarchs between 7:45am and 10:30am. It was an amazing morning that I feel so privileged to have witnessed! My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours and _45__ minutes.

67 monarchs were seen yesterday. I think this must be the peak or near peak for migration in my area. My observation time: I was watching for 7 hours and _0 minutes.
I saw many monarchs (more than I have ever seen here). I live in the mountains of NC.

We were traveling on the Blue Ridge Parkway in NC on Tuesday September 21, 2010.  We stopped at EB Jeffress Park (MP 271.9) for a picnic.  Monarch butterflies were coming in a continuous stream from the direction of the parkway into the picnic area.  They would stop at a sunny patch of goldenrod near our table before continuing on over the mountain. I watched and photographed them between 1 and 3:30pm. My observation time: I was watching for 2 hours and 30 minutes.

After school students reported seeing 73 monarchs. After a stormy morning the sun came out and so did the butterflies. They were on the move again

September 22
Yesterday students sighted a total of 21 butterflies. We started the day with a deluge and they weren't flying around much!

Sitting on the beach we counted 23 monarchs in one hour...we saw hundreds throughout the week while we were vacationing in Myrtle Beach that week...I was in Monarch Heaven!!!  They were flying south, following the ocean/coast. My observation time: I was watching for __4_ hours and __30_ minutes daily.

too many to count! watched from 2:45-3:15pm and counted over 30 monarchs on their way south...all came from same direction high in the sky then fluttered down near the small water hole and butterfly bushes but didn't see any feeding, just floating south.  My observation time:2:45pm-3:15pm I was watching for ___ hours and _30__ minutes.

We were hiking at the Outer Harbor Nature Preserve,located on Lake Erie in Buffalo,NY- last Saturday (9/18) and we came across hundreds of Monarchs, perhaps a thousand! It was very windy and there were at least 5-10 of them on each goldenrod plant that we could see, there were many plants that were inside the outer area, that we could'nt see! They were flying all over the place and it was an awesome sight! It looked like Christmas tree ornaments, swaying in the wind! There were also some Viceroy Butterflys and I found my very first, ever Buckeye, too! My observation time: I was watching for _2__ hours and _30__ minutes.

The monarchs were feeding on shepherd needle flowers in a field about half an acre.
There were about 200 of them. The wind direction at the time was east at 20 mph. It was like that for about a week. My observation time: I was watching for 45 minutes.

It was really a surprise for me to see them. But I hadn't really looked before. I will be sure to notice from now on. I didn't think we had monarchs here.The flowers they were feeding on are sheperds needles, they would stay on the flowers for about 40 seconds then move to the next one. At one point I saw one try to light on another monarch and they both flew to about 10 feet and started fighting or playing I don't know which.Here are some photos. In the top photo that flower is not the sheperds needle. I am not sure what that one is.

We have been witnessing the Monarch for three days now.  We have seen them on the wildflowers at Wildacres and flying across Lake James. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

This from a naturalist acquaintance to my husband who had heard about it via another friend:

From: William Martinus
Date: September 23, 2010 6:12:53 PM GMT-04:00
To: Russ Schipper
Subject: Re: Monarch flight question

Russ,
The below is what I sent to Steve Mueller on Labor day, Sept. 6, 2010.
Bill

We had storms all morning, and at 2:00, I checked the Lake MI beach because the sun had just come out. There were only a few monarchs by the house on maple saplings in the yard. When at the bank-crest, monarchs were heading south over the beach, bank to about mid- tree top level, flying in clumps, pairs, and individually all over. I could not count them as they few by in such multitudes to I got Shirley out there to sound off minutes and I counted; singles at first then by fives to keep up. Over 200 butterflies passed by per minute !! high of 235/ minute. We did this for several minutes and watched the phenomenon for about 1/2 hour and then I went over to tell the neighbors and we watched for another hour. All in all, about 2 hours of continuous monarch parade. Eventually tapering off a few hours later to only 75-120/ minute.

My husband checked the weather record for Grand Haven on Labor Day in the afternoon: the wind was mostly from the SE and around 10 mph. It started to clear up about 1 or 2 PM and was sunny by 5 PM. The temp was about 65 - 71.

During a visit of one hour and 15 minutes to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, 65 monarchs were observed. Once again, many of  them were in the savanna area of the refuge where they were nectaring on hillside flowers and resting on oak tree branches. A visit on September 21 showed 139 monarchs in the same general area. Rain and strong winds have hampered monarch movements in recent days.

A bit belatedly I thought to mention some nice sightings along the shores of the Rockaway peninsula of Queens County, N.Y. City on September 17, 2010 - many of these sightings were in a 2-hour period walking along Riis beach, that is to say while actually on the beach and in the surf line. The Monarchs in particular were really "motoring" along on a good northerly wind and there were constantly dozens, occasionally 50 or more in view at any instant in that mid-day time period. There were actually additional Monarchs seen in other area locations by two of us that day & the total numbers of Monarch butterflies seen that day easily exceeded 5,000 - for the day. I haven't seen that many other notes from elsewhere in the mid-Atlantic or northeastern regions to indicate whether that day was a particularly big day for that species southwesterly-directed migrations, or just a part of a relatively good season for the species. My guess (only) is that it was a very big day. We have good potential for big Monarch & other butterfly movements in the next several days with a possibility of southern-afinity species as well.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Hello From Cape May!

Our normal â€œweeklyâ€ report was delayed for the best of reasons.While week #2 saw an increase in migrant monarchs through Cape May, an orange blizzard hit in the middle of week #3. Even by historic standards this was a huge flight. On the 3 road census runs on September 18th Jenny Howard and Michael Oâ€™Brien recorded 1592 monarchs in a total of 60 minutes of observation! Weekly totals are posted on our website.

For those of us (including yours truly) who were not in Cape May last week there are likely more monarchs on their way.

Cape May Monarch Monitoring Project

I remarked to myself this morning that I was observing along the north shore of Lake Ontario a good monarch migration along the north shore of Lake Ontario near Oshawa in spite of threatening rain clouds and strong westerly winds. Further west at the Cranberry Marsh Hawk Watch at Whitby, after the day turned sunny, it got spectacular. Must be some of those I reported last night minus the 140 I captured:

"It was a quiet day today with only 10 hawks moving through in 4 .5 hours, but other spectacles were truly amazing. It was perhaps the best Monarch flight I think I've ever seen with many hundreds (thousands?) of them going though. At most times all through the observation period, 30-50m were in view as they streamed westward.

Forwarded by Don Davis

Between 10:47am and 11:00am witnessed 21 Monarchs flying in a southerly direction on Holly St. (1200 W) in the Coleman Highlands neighborhood. Sunny, virtually cloudless sky, 60 degrees F. Rain previous evening.

From 3:02pm to 3:09pm witnessed 31 Monarchs (all singles) flying in a southerly direction in the 3400 block of Central St. Clear sky, moderate breeze, 73 degrees F, relative humidity 51%.
100+ Monarchs feeding on asters and Heptacodium in the garden. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and _20__ minutes.

My back yard is filled with thousands of monarch butterflies today. The monarchs were nectaring in my flower planters in front of the house, and were roosting in the trees in the back yard. The trees were full of them. There were thousands! There were so many in the air that they looked like bats! I have never seen anything like it.

An awesome day of Monarch migrators! For a 3 hour period...from 1:30-4:30pm, I counted 128 arrive from the north and nectar in our gardens before moving on. There are 2 more days when the winds will be northerly...9/28 and 9/30, so time will tell if today was the peak day or not. However, a note of reference is that today, 9/24 was the same day in 2008 it was the peak here too! Last year the peak day was the 19th. The Monarchs are right on time...So cool!!! :D My observation time: I was watching for 3 hours.

A wonderful day for Monarchs!  Wind finally came from the north and with it came the Monarchs!  Clear skies, temps ranging from upper 60'sF to low 70'sF.  In 4 hours I observed 471 Monarchs.  Most came after 2:00 pm.  It was fun to see hourly "bursts" of butterflies as they came in groups.  At 2PM I observed 69 Monarchs in 10 minutes.  At 3PM there came 60 Monarchs in 20 minutes.  This has been one of the best migrations in years! My observation time: I was watching for _4__ hours and ___ minutes.
Observed approximately 100 in an hour heading SW today.  We had about a 10 knot wind out of the N that seemed to be helping them move.

We are noting many Monarchs on the Meadow throughout our small farm.  They seem to be nectaring on Asters which are newly opened.  Their wings look fresh and new.   My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours and ___ minutes.

Hooray!  A beautiful orange wave of Monarchs just came through the city around 1pm!  In one hour starting at 11:30am, I counted 95 Monarchs, but then, around 1pm, the wave arrived and I counted 171 butterflies in 20 minutes.  Sky was overcast, no wind, cool temps near 70F.  They flew through my yard, some stopping to nectar at the flowers, while others came in at all levels, some quite high above the trees.  An hour later, it is now raining, so they knew they had to move on before the weather changed! My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and _20__ minutes.

HUNDREDS of them!

They were flying overhead, heading south, and very determined to keep flying. I'm not sure just how many, but there were literally hundreds. One big flock would go over, then a handful, then another huge flock, and then a handful. It was amazing. A lady that lives in the same area told me later that the day before we saw all of them she was out in a pasture and there were a bunch on a tree.

At 6:00 p.m., in one minute, I counted 58 Monarchs flying south overhead.Last night, there were 200-300 Monarchs roosting in our Maple tree. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

Sitting on the Cape Henlopen State Park beach.  It was a windy day-wind from the North. Watched continually for 45 minutes from 1200 to 1245 and counted 30 Monarchs flying from the ocean to land.  I'm sure I saw just as many, if not more, throughout the day (1100 to 1600), but did not keep track of them. My observation time: I was watching for _0__ hours and _45__ minutes.

Hundreds of monarchs stayed overnight in my brother's yard over a couple of days in late August.  This is the first time it has happened.  He has many types of flowers and plants in his yard. Article in local paper: http://www.lenconnect.com/features/x353247604/Migrating-butterflies-visit-Riga-Township-residence   My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.
Constant parade one or 2 at a time past my terrace alongside the ocean. My observation time: I was watching for _1__ hours and _15__ minutes.

We drove West to East from McPherson area to Hillsboro on HWY 56, mid afternoon on Sat.  A very heavy thunderstorm had dumped almost and inch of rain.  The Monarchs were everywhere passing across the HWY.  It was a challenge not to hit them with the car.  Many of them were stopping and  resting on the ground at the side of the road.  Far too many to even count.Later i was at Tabor college football stadium in Hillsboro and counted for 10 min. across an area about the width of a football field.  I counted 36 just passing that small area.  They were all around me and many did not get counted.   That evening i found many in a Park further east in Marion.  They were gathering under the oak trees for the night.  A strong cold front had passed through and temps were in the 60s. My observation time: I was watching for ___ hours and ___ minutes.

Rain on Saturday halted monarch movement, but on Sunday, monarchs still were  being sighted at Neal  Smith National  Wildlife Refuge. During a two-hour visit, 201 monarchswere counted. The day was clear and cool with a temperature in the low  50s. A mild northwest breeze of 5 miles an hour was blowing. Most  of  the  monarchs were observed nectaring on  sunflowers.

66 butterflies counted in 10 minutes, all flying south-west parallel to Lake Erie shoreline. Most flying between 10 feet and 300 feet above ground. Hundreds of other Monarchs are at ground level throughout the park feeding on nectar plants. Recently the weather has been very warm with strong head winds and the butterfly numbers dropped. Weather is now cooler with favourable winds for butterfly migration so they're back in larger numbers. The peak at Clearville Park was Sept 17 when I counted 5 thousand per hour moving through the park.   My observation time: I was watching for 10 minutes.

The Monarchs seem to be headed pretty straight south. Heading toward Tulsa! Activity started between 9am & 10am. Counted 59 plus 7 Dragonflies. I must be blind because I was up at a little before 7am this morning and I could not spot them. It was too cold for them to be moving. It was only 44degrees. We watched them land in the Birch Tree & also saw them landing in an Elm Tree out back to roost(hundreds). They must be masters of disguise because I went out armed with binoculars, camera, coffee & a stocking cap. I walked around pretty much the whole block craning my neck, switching from my glasses to the binoculars looking up in the trees until my head felt like it was going to fall off. I spotted one, mind you only one about 9am way about 70-75ft up in the Elm tree as the sun hit it. Between 9 & 10 they just started appearing in the sky. After 2 hours of looking up I could not take it anymore & came inside.﻿ My observation time: I was watching for _3__ hours and _15__ minutes.

In the morning when they began to fly my husband estimated they were flying at several hundred feet. The sun was hitting just right and you could tell with no problem that they were Monarchs. As the day went on I would go out on our deck periodically & continued to see Monarchs heading south. Probably saw another 30 to 50 or so. The ones we saw in the afternoon were flying much lower rooftop level & below. Things were different today at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. In two hours of observations  in the afternoon, 24 monarchs were counted, suggesting the migration through central Iowa may be winding down. What was apparent was the remaining monarchs seemed to be changing their nectaring habits to the purple New England asters rather than sunflowers. At least 20 of the 24 monarchs were found on New England asters. The day was sunny with a temperature in the 70s and a brisk wind from the southwest.

Just saw 12 Monarchs in 10 minutes. There on the move after the bad weather we had for the last two days here in Statesville. My observation time: I was watching for 10_ minutes.

Arrived home at 4:00 P.M. and began to watch for Monarchs. Saw 6 to 8 in a matter of minutes. All headed west to south west. I had an idea to use binoculars an scan the sky away from the Sun(with my back to the Sun). I looked at clouds and could easily see many Monarchs flying several hundred feet up above me. They were scattered out one here,five there and so on. It has been a great afternoon of Monarch watching. My observation time: I was watching for __2_ hours and __30_ minutes.

A bit belatedly I thought to mention some nice sightings along the shores of the Rockaway peninsula of Queens County, N.Y. City on September 17, 2010 - many of these sightings were in a 2-hour period walking along Riis beach, that is to say while actually on the beach and in the surf line. The Monarchs in particular were really "motoring" along on a good northerly wind and there were constanty dozens, occasionally 50 or more in view at any instant in that mid-day time period. There were actually additional Monarchs seen in other area locations by two of us that day & the total numbers of Monarch butterflies seen that day easily exceeded 5,000 - for the day. I haven't seen that many other notes from elsewhere in the mid-Atlantic or northeastern regions to indicate whether that day was a particularly big day for that species southwesterly-directed migrations, or just a part of a relatively good season for the species. My guess (only) is that it was a very big day. We have good potential for big Monarch & other butterfly movements in the next several days with a possibility of southern-afinity species as well.

Monarchs are flying in large numbers down the Blue Ridge: LOADS of monarchs were sighted at the hawkwatches all week. At Rockfish Gap, average numbers being counted were 400-500/day.

However, the most spectacular monarch migration I observed was yesterday (September 22), starting up the mountain toward Harvey's Knob hawkwatch from Peaks of Otter. Monarchs were EVERYWHERE! The largest numbers I have seen in years of hawkwatching and/or parkway trips. It was difficult not to hit them. They were migrating, though slowed by the SE winds.

I stopped at the hawkwatch for a couple hours in early afternoon at Harvey's Knob before resuming my journey. (The sky was raining stinkbugs. The whole place SMELLED of stinkbugs when I got out of the car. ) You could not look up into the sky without seeing many, many monarchs drifting on the wind. They were up high, down low, everywhere. It took some doing to distinguish monarchs from birds, initially, because the birds were flying pretty high up. Just thought you would want to know. If there is a wave of monarchs moving down the Blue Ridge at the moment (I drove from Reid's Gap to just north of Boone before beginning to run out of daylight), the crest of the wave is currently close to Roanoke, according to my observations. And there are SO many in the crest! A very heartening sight. I figure that my doing my program at the Orchard on Sunday will be right at the height, totally serendipitously, as the north wind that we endured at Rockfish Gap that was driving the monarchs south a few days ago had swung around to the SW/S/SE on Tues. and Wed., slowing things down. I would love to see the numbers coming along the ridge at the Orchard on Sunday that I saw yesterday. Keep you fingers crossed. It is such a glorious sight.

Clouds of Monarchs crossing west to east across the Chesapeake Bay (Sept. 17) Annapolis, MD to Stevensville, MD

The monarchs roosted Thursday night in the bayberry/groundsel tree thickets along the bay shore at Sandy Point State Park. With the rising sun, their flight muscles warmed and they lifted off. Feeling the tug of a strong west wind, they surrendered to it and found themselves sailing over Chesapeake Bay. Some glided just above the car rooftops on the eastbound lanes of the 4-mile bay bridge; others soared over the white-capped waves. They weren't alone. Their fellow travelers-- common buckeyes and green darners rode the same wind. They made landfall at Terrapin Park on the eastern shore. The monarchs drifted over the sand, through the Spartina and Phragmites, over the freshwater ponds to the fields. The wind was perfumed with the seductive scent of tickseed sunflower. Masses of golden flowers lured monarchs down into the fields by the hundreds. By mid-morning the wind picked up to 15-20mph. By late afternoon, monarch numbers had increased to several thousand. Standing amidst of this dance of swirling orange wings and gold petals, I felt infused with energy. I also felt grateful for being able to witness this scene and knew that it would not have been possible without the managed fields. The fields were planted and are maintained by the Anne Arundel County Parks Dept. They could have kept this area as mowed grass for visitors to play frisbee on. Instead they put in the time/effort to create a habitat-- an old field stage of succession with an emphasis on native warm-season grasses.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Forrest Rowland of Cape Henlopen Hawkwatch reports:

Something quite incredible that began yesterday morning at about 7:45am in Cape May, NJ, and ended over Delaware shores sometime just after noon.

At approximately 8:45am yesterday morning, Doug Gochfeld (swing counter Cape May Bird Observatory) called me up and urgingly requested that I get myself to the bunker...or else. I immediately thought that an early falcon flight was starting! His next sentence was, "The monarchs here are crazy". I smirked inwardly (and outwardly) and told myself I was not really interested in spending time during what *might* be the only day I take off of work this week up on the platform counting butterflies. Sure, we take down monarch numbers here and there, when a big movement is going on, but...it is a HAWKwatch, after all.

I was birding with Cyrus Moqtaderi at Prime Hook when I got a second call 20 minutes later. It was Doug again. Cameron Cox and Michael O'brien were there. Doug implored that I get over to the hawkwatch and start counting butterflies. I said the equivalent of "yeah yeah yeah, yada yada yada". I heard Cameron yelling at me in the background. Michael got on the phone and...I quote: "Forrest, get over there. This is like getting 500 Golden Eagles. You've GOT to see this." We decided, given that we were notified by 3 of the best birders in Cape May County (and the country), that we should get ourselves over to the Hawkwatch Platform. Cyrus and I arrived at the Cape Henlopen Hawkwatch platform at 10:15am to something on the magnitude of 50 Monarchs a minute. By 11:00am I was counting 100's of monarchs PER BINOCULAR VIEW at any given instant all up and down the beach!!!! It was one of the most amazing things I've ever seen. I will never forget.

Looking South, North, straight up in the air, one could not avoid seeing thousands of Monarchs pouring forth over the Ocean! For an hour, we marveled, and spoke of similar amazing migrations. We estimated an discussed and smiled. We forgot about Falcons and Hawks and whatnot. We stood, watching, smiling some more. Onlookers on the beach were watching from under umbrellas. People in parking lots carrying coolers, and chairs, were watching. Everyone that had seen, was watching.

The spectacle slowed and was mere memory by 12:30pm, give or take. Things returned the constant trickle of some few hundred Monarchs per hour. It was over nearly as quickly as it began.

I spoke to Doug Gochfeld this morning. The rough estimate from Cape May was that 1.4 million Monarchs had migrated over the point between then hours of 7 and 9am. At the Cape Henlopen Hawkwatch we had seen some 550,000 - 600,000 of that. Reports from Rehoboth Beach/Gordon's Pond were upwards of 150,000.

The rest came ashore between the two points, delighting and confusing and astonishing beach-goers, and hawkwatchers, as they went. I have seen Monarchs migrating each Fall for 4 years. I have seen them waft and weave in and out of view; overhead, over flowers, and thought these sights happy and amusing, but never impressive. I hereby beg forgiveness.

We are offshore doing scientific research and a monarch butterfly appeared today on our ship, the R/V Atlantis. Maybe it was blown off course by the storms? He is presently relaxing in a box and will hopefully make it back to Woods Hole, MA with us in a few days where he will be very disappointed and have to start migration all over again!

We were about 120 miles from shore when we discovered the butterfly. We left Woods Hole, Mass. on Sept. 10 and have been offshore since then.Â  Just about 1 1/2 days before the monarch turned up we had that weather system go through that dumped so much rain on the Carolinas.Â  We had 35-40 knot winds and swell averaging about 20 feet. (That was pretty rough for us, and science work was suspended while the system passed.)Â  The butterfly, oddly, turned up in the galley near the breakfast fruit (That's why I thought it might like the syrupy peach that I gave it.) I don't think it was a stowaway; I think it would have been discovered in the three weeks we've been out here.Â  I feel certain that it was blown out here during the storm.Â  We also had several birds and other insects show up, too.

I am a regular on the R/V Atlantis.Â  I work with various scientists from around the world (oceanographers, marine biologists, geologists, etc.) and help them collect oceanographic data.Â  Our ship also carries the submersible Alvin. (I am assisting with an Alvin recovery in this picture.) Alvin takes scientists down to as far as 4500 meters below the surface to do research.Â  I, unfortunately, only get to ride occasionally on top of it on the surface :)Â  This trip is mostly scientists studying the chemistry of the water column. (Alvin is on the ship, but not diving this time around.) You can view the cruise track for the R/V Atlantis at sssg1.whoi.edu (we're in red)

Unfortunately our lonely traveler did not live through the night.Â  I'd put him/her in a box (with just an open top) and sugar water and a syrupy peach hoping he/she would eat something.Â  It was probably pure exhaustion because he/she sat on the edge of a paper bowl all day barely moving (like I said the top was open and it did not have very high sides, just enough for protection, but no attempts to escape were made).Â  I have placed the "remains" out on the deck hoping that one of the stowaway birds might benefit and the butterfly will not have died in vain.Â I was saddened that this little guy gave up after such an exciting journey!

While I still have about 65 chrysalis left to go, I was relieved today to be out in my waystation and saw 5 monarchs that were not tagged.  Most of the monarchs in the garden for the past month have been my tagged ones that hang around for a couple of days.  I figured the peak was starting here.  So we went to Lynch Park in Beverly and sure enough, as I reported in the first week of October two seasons ago, there were monarchs everywhere.  I was able to tag 18 of them but ran out of tags.  I'll go back tomorrow with more tags.  Sunny day, North Easterly winds, very favorable for the trek SouthEast.  I suspect that because we are so close to the warmer ocean waters, that we lag behind in the standard Peak times for our latitude. My observation time: I was watching for 1 hour.

Saturday was a beautiful day with temperatures in the 60's with a northeast wind. The previous day Tropical Storm Nicole passed through. I observed over a six hour period over 700 monarchs. Unlike my last spotting two weeks ago where the monarchs came in droves over a shorter period in time, on this day the arrivals were spread out over many hours. The majority of monarchs looked strong, healthy and were eager to feed on golden rod nectar, a few had torn wings but were just as diligent to feed. At sunset they roosted in a much larger area. Their predecessors two weeks before, where hundreds of monarchs roosted on one pine tree, today there were 10 -40 on a tree, but many more trees.On the next day I only spotted 30 over a 5 hour period. I can't figure out when they leave the South Shore of Long Island, if they fly out over the Atlantic Ocean to their next stop or do they fly west along the coast and skirt New York City?  Bon Voyage!! My observation time: I was watching for 6 hours and ___ minutes.
