Our Monarch hike is every evening at 7 PM and leaves from the Tip Area parking lot. The hike lasts for roughly 30 to 40 minutes. We also offer a family oriented hike on Saturdays and Sundays at 2 PM. Both hikes are included with park admission.

With a nice northerly breeze, Monarchs were making their way across central Oklahoma today!  From about 11:30 to 11:45, I counted 20 Monarchs in directional S-SW flight about 30-50 ft. in the air.  Temps were in the upper 70's, cloudy, with a light NNW wind.  After the 1st 15 minutes, they went from occasional to rare, but periodically throughout the day when I had a chance to check.  I had about 10 Monarchs stop to nectar, and roost in the trees tonight.  With Oklahoma in an extreme drought, and breaking our record of 63 days of triple digit temps, I am so proud to have a small patch of flowers for them to enjoy.  Welcome Monarchs!

Many monarchs in clumps on shrubs I have seen them on in previous years. There was a strong westerly breeze and the temperature in the sun was 71. There were many also flying in the area. We saw them while we were at the park about 12 to 2 PM. I went back the next morning and there were only a few remaining, though the weather was much the same.

After strong head winds most of the day, the wind relaxed mid-afternoon and thousands of butterflies started appearing in huge numbers along the beach and cliff top bluffs at Clearville Park on Lake Erie, all flying in the same direction - South West between 20 feet and 300 feet elevation. 1200 were counted in 60 minutes. This continued on for about 4 hours at which time the butterflies hunkered down in surrounding trees for the night. All butterflies heading in the same direction - toward Rondeau Provincial Park 15 miles to the south-west of Clearville. Weather was warm and sunny today with calming winds.

300 observed flying along the beach on Lake Erie at Clearville Park. These numbers continued for most of the afternoon. Numbers not as high as yesterday (1200 per hour). Weather is about 10 degrees cooler today and only partly sunny.
One every few minutes as I bicycled along a busy road.  A few got hit by windshields, most made it!  Tehy fly right at truck windshield height - poor things!

Temps in the 60's. Windy and overcast, with breaks in the clouds. The butterflies were out and moving more when the sun was out.We found the monarchs in a sheltered goldenrod meadow. They were all moving west toward I-86. We tagged 5. We also collected 2 caterpillars.

Small to medium flights of Monarchs passing through YMCA Camp Grady Spruce. Monarch's are feeding on Cowpen Daisys and Milk Weed vines. The cooler weather has been pushing them through the area. Not large congregations of them in the Live Oaks yet.

Between Noon and 12:05 today, I counted 38 monarchs nectaring/flying in our small backyard in Stillwater, OK. About 25 were nectaring on yellow crownbeard (on 50 to 100 plants)      10 were nectaring on tropical milkweed (on 6 plants)       3 were nectaring on Lantana camara       3 were in flight from one flower to anotherMy previous record in 8 years at this location was 11 monarchs (set yesterday).  Why so many this year?  Perhaps due to the fact that much of the surrounding prairie in KS, MO, and OK is brown due to the drought, and probably has little blooming. I have the same number of flowers as usual, as I've watered my backyard quite a bit.

Over the weekend 4T observed many monarchs.  Some observations included: monarchs on a butterfly bush, a branch, a window and just fluttering around.  Observed sizes ranged from 1.5 inches through 5.5 inches wide.  We also observed small, white eggs, and females laying eggs on milkweed.18 people spent a combined total of about 46 hours observing over a period of 5 days.

I work at a wholesale nursery in east central Kansas, we have appx. 2500 Buddleia davidii (Butterfly Bush) on the property. The past few days I've noticed an influx of Monarchs, but today there were hundreds (400? 500? 600?) sitting on these plants. I thought it was worth reporting. I just wanted to tell SOMEONE what I'm seeing.

September 21
I took some pictures today, unfortunately it has been rainy and overcast all day. How long do they hang around? I think that 4-6 hundred that I observed was a conservative guess; today there was < 20. Maybe they're not as active today do to the cooler temps/rain/clouds and then again maybe they've just moved on. In the pictures of the plants, just imagine them COVERED in Monarchs. The reason it caught my eye yesterday was because from a distance I thought I had a serious problem with the plants! Boy, was I wrong! It was an amazing sight that I hope I'll get another chance to photograph.
First year berm on golf course specific for Monarchs.  Cluster of Monarchs mostly feeding on Buddleia davidii
About every 5 minutes they would pass by traveling in packs of 3.
I have a large patch of Ragweed...today I saw 15 Monarchs between 12:30-1:00pm. The total number for the day was at least 30.  This is an area in a valley roughly 200'wide from East to West.

Monarchs are continuing to trickle thru central Oklahoma.  Traveling from Kingfisher thru El Reno to Yukon and back, I saw about 20 Monarchs traveling S/SW.  There was a light wind from the south, and they were flying lower to the ground.  The winds are supposed to change to the N/NW Wednesday with the next front.  Reported to Monarch Watch.

about 100 or so a day now for about 2 weeks, (9/7 - 9/21) flying right in front of my porch , heading south west . every one of them are taking the exact course using the thermals coming up from the valley floors. this is very cool and hope to see more !!! its amazing how they fly in the same way over and over sticking to the edge of the ridge i live on.
We sat outside our school building and watched butterflies migrate south.  It was cool and cloudy and a bit breezy.

For me to see 63 monarchs in less than 1/2 hour is pretty exciting...I was seeing 3 in my binos at once..they were flying N to S and above them 30+ Broadwinged Hawks flew over in less than 5 minutes...also 18 chimney swifts and a few dragonflies in the mix also...it was very cloudy until a small patch of blue sky opened up and seems like everything just released from the gates...Heavy cloud cover and winds, most of the day...windchills in the 40s....felt cold...now it's sunny and clearing up...wanted it to stay cloudy, so there won't be a chance of frost...high 30's here tonight and tomorrow night. Should be a good weekend to hopefully CATCH and TAG monarchs for my monarch program...(If it warms up on Saturday at Noon).

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Even though I wasn't there, I was excited to read the following in today's report of the Detroit River Hawk Watch-Lake Erie Metropark:

"When the winds were calmest during the midday hours, an impressive monarchflight occurred. Conservatively, more than 2,000 monarchs must have passedby within view of the watch site."

Across the lake, Pt. Pelee reported 26 monarchs roosting at the point. Another 1/2 dozen stopped by my yard for nectar (and tags).

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I was near Lake Champlain and spotted Monarchs in the parking lot behind the Shanty Restaurant.  I counted at least 15.  I then walked towards the lake and saw 11 more in the Perkins Pier parking lot, then 6 more further on in another section / off-shoot of that parking lot.  The lots were all unpaved.  There was a fairly stiff wind blowing off the lake (west to east); when any flew away, they flew east, with the wind.  The butterflies were just sitting on the ground, once in a while fluttering around and landing again.  The lots were unpaved.  A few monarchs flew towards a grassy area, but always came back to light on the dirt parking lot.

The front came through, and along came the Monarchs!  Around 1:30 p.m. I counted about 25 Monarchs in 15 minutes.  They were flying single, pairs, and groups of 3's.  I was pleasantly surprised to find about 40 Monarchs intently nectaring in my garden upon coming home! So pleased that I was able to have food for them.  Some moved on, some stayed, and I will probably have about 40 roosting in the trees tonight!  Chance of rain tonight, and wind will be from the east tomorrow.  Reported to Monarch Watch.

I counted 19 monarchs during a 20 minute bike ride. They were all nectaring in fields of purple clover. It was easy to spot them from the distance as soon as I trained my eye:

1) Watch for little sulphur butterflies dancing above the flowers (this means nectar),
2) Look for the large, dark dot hanging on a flower. That may mean a monarch. Also look for clover that seems to be bending under a butterfly's weight.
3) Keep watching and, within 30-60 seconds, the butterfly is sure to fly off to the next flower. Once it's airborne there's no mistaking a monarch.
viewing at Kauffman Gardens in KC,MO

Temps were in the low 70's. The sun was bright and it was windy.The monarchs were resting on dirt roads, then flying south feeding on goldenrod along the way. They were on the move. We did discover one newly hatched butterfly. It was drying its wings on a goldrod plant.We only captured 8 to tag.

21 September 2011: Cat Rock Mountain
Monarchs still here,,, counted > 50 with binocs on our Buddleias in a couple of minutes. They must be clustering nearby, but have not yet found one.

Our 4-5 Butterfly Bushes were filled all day with a slow and steady turnover of Monarchs, sipping and then lazily heading south, either over the top of the roof, or around the side of the house. My last Monarch caterpillar stopped munching Swamp Milkweed and fell off the branch he was chomping on to have a little rest in his fattened state before crawling off to pupate.  I will be looking for this one in another 9-14 days as he/she emerges and hopefully scoots off in a southerly direction!!!

SQUEAL!!!!! FINALLY sighted more than one monarch at a time, a first for this migration. They are definitely on the move now, how exciting! While at National Zoo Monday I checked out every butterfly bush I knew of, and found between 1-3 monarchs visiting each:-) This is the most I've ever seen there in my four years of volunteering. Most likely my count of "9" is conservative, too. I took as many photos as I could, some quite lovely despite the overcast skies. Am SO happy!

We laid out by our school garden and saw the butterflies gliding overhead on their way to Mexico.

After school I saw three more Monarchs heading south over our school.

I could not get accurate count but about 2 dozen very new-looking monarchs are visiting my flowers, especially asters, buddlei and asclepias.  I live in a narrow valley and seldom see more than a few monarchs at a time, so I find this very surprising.

I sat in my field at about 6:00 in the evening. It was warm and sunny (about 70 degrees) after a day of rain and showers. I counted over 300 monarchs flying south overhead in a space of 30 minutes. Most seemed to come in well spaced groups with the occasional straggler. Magical!

The next day, the students and I did a count which we entered on this site, and saw 61 in 10 minutes. They are definitely moving.

Observed more than I could count through the window of office for the duration of a fairly ho-hum meeting.  The Monarchs made the meeting much more enjoyable.Time 3:00pm Sunny weather, light breezeThorough overnight rain just ending.

Major migration day today with Monarchs nectaring on my butterfly bushes from dawn until dusk.  (Heavy rain expected most of the day tomorrow.) Usually had 5 or more on my two bushes every time I looked, with others flying through the yard.  They didn't seem interested in the zinnias at all today.  Had lots of hummers and dragonflies in the around also.  Lovely evening on the porch watching them all as they danced about, feeding in their various ways. I miss them all so when summer had left me and taken them away with it.
Approximately 300/hr for 3 hours at Hawk Cliff today, near Port Stanley. They were gliding over the cliff, rarely lighting on Goldenrod or Asters.

My Environmental Science class had been waiting for the arrival, so on Tuesday we went out to observe any Monarchs we might find on our natural wildflower patch near the school.  We could not count the total number seen, they were everywhere!  We captured and released 30, making careful note to compare the number of males to females.  (22 males/8 females).  We saw new wings mixed with old, worn wings.  The wildflowers have been a big attraction this year, with the sky clear and temperatures in the upper 70s.  We plan to observe again on Friday to see if the numbers have increased or decreased.
11:30am-12:45pm.  In a rural, agricultural area.  The monarchs were moving north to south and none of them were over 10' off the ground.  The wind was from the southwest, not overly strong.
Golfing along Lake Ontario this Morning we had a stream for hours of Monarch Butterflies going south.i hope they allmake it. Ute

Beautiful. From 10 feet above ground to upper heights of 300 feet. Flew right over the house heading south. Accompanied by a few birds and dragon flies. I noticed them at 10:30 and it went on for at least an hour or a bit longer. I can't be sure when it started exactly.

We saw thousands of monarch butterflies, flying toward the fields in search of flowers. We also saw them heading south in the direction of Point Pelee, Ontario. They stopped for a break in our neighborhood, in the ope fields and near Lake Ontario where there are wild flowers. We saw a few of them flying over the lake.

Starting seeing 2-3 fly pass my building every few minutes from1:00 pm onAlso small yellow  and white ones as well. Very tiny compared to the monarch butterflies. Beautiful to see them fly from above. On the 26 th floor of condo at Air Canada Centre. So cool.EK
While travelling west on the Gardiner Expressway (highway) for about 20 minutes, we saw about 40 - 50 Monarch Butterflies travelling east (usually a group of 3 together). It was a sight to see!
Lovely day for a migration!  Spotted Countless Monarchs at the waterfront area today.  Seemed they were busy gathering and feeding on flowers before flying further.  Amazing!

Kept checking the skies(cloudy and clear during the day) and monarchs were moving in small groups of 2 to 5 at a time, then a break and then a few more.  10 came into the yard, nectared and took off before I caught them, but I was able to tag 6 wild and 1 reared.  Saw kettles of Broad-winged hawks and my first Bald Eagle for the year in the yard...also lots of swarms of dragonflies.

I was out walking my dog this morning and suddenly noticed something quite extraordinary - something I have never noticed before. I saw a Monarch butterfly floating past - then another, then another, then another... all following the same path. There must have been at least 50 (I didn't count, sorry) that flew past us before we went on our way. I watched as they gathered around a butterfly bush to "fill up" before their journey. Then through the park, across the parking lot, down the path next to the Balmy Beach Club then over the roof and out over the lake. I wished many of them a good trip and told them to be safe as it was a long way to Mexico. Quite an experience to find yourself in the middle of a migration!
My brother Allen, a birder was on Afton Mountian about 30 mile SW of our location counted about 500 Monarchs an hour crossing over Afton Mountain.
Travelling south/west in groups of 2-8.

We live on the shores of Lake Erie. This is the most monarchs I've seen at one time in many years! Today is warm and partly cloudy. Many of the monarchs are stopping at the vegetation on our hill then continuing their journey.
This week we have seen extensive numbers of monarchs in oakville, some 20 at a time

On a return trip from Niagara Falls to Tottenham we observed at least 150 monarchs migrating.  The majority were from Niagara Falls to just south of Burlington, Ontario and between the hours of 1030 and noon.  I made the same trip today (25th), a couple of hours later and saw no more than 10.

Eagle Marsh has many sunflowers and goldenrod that the Monarchs seem to be feeding on.

Photo by David Tremain

While birding, observed Monarchs feeding on Goldenrod.  As I scanned sky with binoculars, I observed a stream of about 30, heading south, later I observed a group of about 100 flying in a southerly direction.  This was between 11 AM- 12:30 PM.
While doing a butterfly count at the Tallgrass Prairie Preserve north of Pawhuska, we noticed 100+ Monarchs nectaring on liatris without any southerly movement.
Rural, agricultural area. Wind was light from the nw.  Individuals were seen from ground level to 100'plus.

My sister in Graham, Texas reported that Monarchs began showing up this morning in small numbers (3-4) just after 11:00 a.m. Central Time. She then called to report their numbers had increased to 15, and within an hour reported her backyard was full of Monarchs. She said some stopped to feed and then moved along with a purpose.
Actually the # may be more than 20....was hard to count them.

Monarchs drifting NNE to SSW. Sightings were random at 2 to ao minute intervals. Driftng at rooftop and lower height. 10:30 a.m. 68 deg, RH 61%, DP 56 deg., 27.77" & steady. Breeze NNE. I had a limited field of view.
While driving down the road we started seeing Monarchs every where in droves. We stopped counting at 55 as there were too many.

My daughter and I were out for a walk after a wonderful birthday breakfast.  We crossed Lakeshore Rd. to Spencer Smith Park, and that is when I noticed a few Monarchs.  We continued toward the lake and noticed tons!  Some were close to the ground and others were higher in the sky.  They just kept coming!  It was one of the most amazing things I have ever seen!
Drove up the eastside of Cayuga Lake along Rte. 90 - in 1 hour long car trip, observed at least 50 monarchs flying East to West across road

Many, many monarchs on my butterfly bushes today. I have also seen many the last few days also.

I didn't sit there and watch continuously. I'm tagging monarchs for Monarch Watch, and I watch my butterfly bushes from the house intermittently while I go about my day. I would estimate I saw a total of 40 to 50 all afternoon. I would see 5 to 7 at a time on the bush. We've had a lot of rain the last few weeks so I don't know if they are staying around longer because of the rain and that's why I'm seeing so many. This is only my second year tagging, but I didn't see that many last year. I was only able to tag 50 last year. This year I've tagged 100 so far and could tag more, but I've run out of tags.

Wow!  After a rather soggy night, the sun appeared and with it a LOT of migrating monarchs!  This is the most of seen in one sitting so far this year.  I don't think it's as big as previous years but then again I have seen migrating monarchs for a good month which is very unusual.  I think they were more spread out this year due to weather extremes in all areas of the country.  I hope the numbers surprise us when the final count is in.  All I observed were making the most of this beautiful day and heading due west/southwest in a hurry!
many Monarchs flying south throughout the morning

Many single Monarchs sighted evening of 25th.  By the next morning more were gathering and now this evening we can see swarms in shady tree groves.  I expect a roost for tonight.  A lot of excitement in the air and picture taking.
Have been seeing monarchs on butterfly bush for several days. Monarchs have stayed as late as dusk. May have used the tree above to rest. and average of 2-3 per minute for one hour observation.
On 09/26/11, at 10:30 am, we saw about 50  or so monarch butterflies riding the winds going from NE to SW direction. They would appear three or four at a time high in the air for about an hour.
Monarchs observed flying decidedly south over the meadows and past the sculpture fields of Storm King Art Center.
we have a lot of wild sunflowers that they stopped on ( also have water source)

On a partly sunny/cloudy 78 degree humid day I spotted over 85 monarchs flying from east to weston Ocean Parkway and Jones Beach. There was a slight north-westerly wind. The unusual thing is historically I spot them at Robert Moses beach which is approximately 15 miles east of today's sighting, however this year there are very few less than 10% I spot at Robert Moses Beach. Over the past week the golden rod which has been a feeding staple for the monarchs, had popped and is now in full bloom and plentiful.I don't know if they modified their flight pattern or why the change?I returned to Robert Moses Beach again on Monday 09.26.11 and I did not see a single monarch, very bizarre.

Nature writer, Elizabeth Hunter, forwarded this observation from the hawk watch team at at Harvey's Knob hawk watch on the Blue Ridge parkway:

Hundreds of monarchs & dragonflies migrating today. Biggest group of Monarchs I have observed this year. Seemed every time I put my binocs up to scan I was seeing 3-5 Monarchs streaming through. Same with dragonflies.
massess of Monarchs moving South across I-40 near Oklahoma City.

I just want to report the largest sighting of Monarchs I have ever seen. We were riding our horses through Arcadia Park in Edmond when we came upon a large area of yellow flowering weeds - as we rode (walking) through the weeds hundreds of monarchs exploded up from the plants.  Throughout the remainder of our ride (approx. 2 hours) we encountered monarchs everywhere in the park near the lake - in the wooded areas, in the open areas and mostly on the flowering weeds and grasses.  Truly an amazing day!

Sitting along the shore of Lake Michigan I spotted 164 monarchs heading south at 1500L on Sat. 24 2011.  While a light rain fell during the two hours, this did not deter the flights.  While most were single travelers, a few times a cluster of three to four were seen.  The few that stopped on plants were not observed drinking.
First monarchs began arriving a week ago.  Yesterday (26th) and today they are here in record numbers.  Roosted last night in the soap berry trees.
Yesterday and today, being warm and sunny, the Monarchs are flocking to our plants.  Over three dozen each day.

I counted 20 monarchs in my yard Sept. 10, 2011, and the number has been dwindling ever since. Right now (9/27/11) it's 59 degrees and has been rainy and windy all day. The monarch, pictured below, was flying around the yard today and then nectared on the white lace clematis.
Our 4th grade sat outside at 10:30am today and counted 20 monarchs. They were flying low and going south. The sky was clear, approx 75 degrees, with a light breeze.
monarch butterflies were flying approximately 30' high in a south westerly direction just off the shore of Lake Erie

Saw over one hundred monarch flying along Wasaga Beach today. All flying from north to south except for one (??) - not sure where that one was going. Really impressive day for the Monarch migration at this end.
400 Monarchs sighted from 2:00 - 3:00 at Hawk Cliff, near Port Stanley on the north shore of Lake Erie.

I have seen only single monarchs on any day all summer but for one observation with 2 butterflies in sight a few days ago.  Today I observed my first monarch of the day flying SW at 0901 hrs and at 1.5 m elevation above ground.  During the next 5.5 hours I observed a total of 9 monarchs (not much of a high count for the season!!).  The highest rate of observation was between 1230 - 1330 hours with 4 sightings.  After 1430 a freshening W wind stopped monarch flight (or perhaps the supply of monarchs was exhausted for the day.  NO monarchs observed 27 SEP 2011
We have been watching for an 45mins. and have seen 109 butterflies, they are passing us quickly, some very high and some low. Fluttering and mostly soaring, some groups mostly single.
Sighted during lunch in the parking lot of the Middletown Mall.

Holiday Beach Conservation Area
During 9.25 hour observation time, 119 monarchs were counted.
Just had about 5 minutes outside. But saw at least 25 monarchs flying through.

Detroit River Hawk Watch- Lake Erie Metropark
During 8 hour observation time: Monarchs were everywhere throughout theday.* There were few times when a scan of the sky didn't yield at least a handful of them.*
I have been setting by the window all afternoon, and there has been a study stream of monarchs heading south the whole time. Probly one every 10 to 20 seconds.

Today, I took my class on the Parkway near milepost 292 to observe the Monarch migration from the Boone area. We parked at an overlook facing Southwest. On the other side of the road was a field covered with goldenrod and asters. We saw 37 Monarchs in a span of 1 hour flying in a southwest direction.
Surprised to witness a clan of these beautiful butterflies in my sisters backyard!

Had barely any all summer or Spring for that matter, But Tuesday cleared to Sunny and breezy and we had about 1 an hour all day from 10 am on,and 1 of the 8 was here today the 228th,, I had a bumper crop of Milkweed  ,but no Monarchs till yesterday.

The Monarchs have been here everyday with roosts at night.  Saturday was a peak day with upwards to 70 Monarchs nectaring mid afternoon.  Sunday through Tuesday, the winds were from the north and the numbers diminished some.  Today, the winds have been from the southwest, and the Monarchs have seemed to "backup" into the yard.  This evening, I counted at least 40 nectaring.  It's hard to get a good count as they move.  While I was mowing, about a dozen swirled up into the air from a Vitex bush.  This is my favorite sight--dancing butterflies!
Still plenty moving along the north shore today with a spike in activity from 11:45 to 12:45 when 150 Monarchs glided by the cliffs.
We were golfing at Willow Valley in Ancaster.  We saw easily over 50 monarchs heading in the same direction.  They just kept coming, one or two or three at a time.
I have had hundreds in my back yard the last 3 days but this evening I had the most that I can tell.. In my trees and grass..
Class went out about 12;30 pm. We saw 35 monarchs. It was a little hot for many sightings, but we have being seeing 100's every morning on the football field during practice.

Just wanted you to know that we drove through Rocksprings in Edward's county this afternoon about 3:00pm and there were hundreds of Monarchs on the trees and lawn at the old courthouse.

Betty sent a video confirming this sighting, the first this far south of this many individuals, I believe. Mike Quinn

Since seeing a monarch in the rain last Friday, I had high expectations for seeing a good number of them at National Zoo Monday (a mostly cloudy but very warm and dry 80º day), and I was not disappointed! I went to what seems to be their favorite clump of white butterfly bushes, and this time found nearly a dozen of them, YAY!!! It's even possible there were more, as these bushes are massive by this time of year, both quite wide and quite tall; the monarchs were top-to-bottom and side-to-side, some even overhead, and none of them still. SO exciting to see them at their peak! Even got a photo of one in the sunshine when it peaked out briefly:-)

Am making a separate report for this particular National Zoo sighting as I saw these six monarchs at a totally different time of day, near sunset, which seemed unusual, as they were still nectaring at the white butterfly bushes like crazy! They didn't seem to be ready to roost at this hour at all (6:45PM). I would've stayed even longer, but, unlike these butterflies, I wanted to head home before dark:-) I took some photos of course as again, couldn't quite believe it! Finding this year's monarch migration to be full of surprises, that's for sure!

Our school habitat (thank you Ms. Fragala!) was visited by over 30 Monarch butterflies on Monday, mostly females and several males.  They were feasting on the New York Asters, Hardy Ageratum, Butterfly Bush and Sunflowers in preparation for the journey south for the winter.  Among the Monarchs were two Common Buckeye, two Clouded Sulfurs, several Delaware Skippers and many bees.  We have never had this many Monarchs in the habitat at any given time that I can remember.  What a wonderful sight for everyone to see!

Arrived on 9/26/11 and still here (9/29) in the thousands in my yard, feeding on pecan, oak, landscaping, including salvia (red Tex.) in full bloom. Usually sighted every year but this year my yard must be an oasis due to drought because they are dense, seemingly hanging on every leaf and flower. (Magical!)

As to numbers, I’d guess three or four thousand at peak. We live very rural. The drought has been devastating...nothing grew in the vegetable garden, and really not much even germinated with irrigation. Non-irrigated pastures are bare. Tanks are dry. Central Texas has to this point registered 90 days of 100 degrees or more...and this started in May. Trees are dying/dead all over the hilltops, even the mesquite and prickly pear is suffering. However, my yard of less than 1/4 acre has had the benefit of daily irrigation to stay green (primarily for wildfire protection) but also to keep the flowers blooming for Hummers and to save the big pecan trees(lost one of them to the 2009 drought). So, this little spot is probably an oasis of sorts this year, but how did so many of the Monarchs find it, a needle in a haystack? One other note, the barn swallows left several weeks ago, at least a month ahead of time, because of food shortage, I think. Hope the Monarchs tanked up enough here to make it to the next green spot farther south, wherever that may be.

September 30
We had a cold front with RAIN overnight, so where yesterday there were thousands of Monarchs, today we have only tens, maybe 50 total. Photos tend to be fuzzy due to windy conditions, but as you can see, the remaining butterflies tend to be getting nectar primarily from the native red salvia, but also appear to be getting something from the pecan leaves and an althea (rose-of-sharon). A couple of my ten foot tall altheas did show evidence of aphids last week, but the Monarchs did not seem to prefer those bushes any more than anything else. They also hung on to the hummingbird feeders, and probably visited the ground level water troughs (3) around the house perimeter, but I did not witness that specifically. During the three-four days of huge populations, roosting was primarily in the old pecan trees on the north and east of the house. The Hummingbirds too are really busy this morning getting stocked up for their own migration, hitting not only the salvia, but morning glories as well, saving the feeders for later in the day, I think.

September 29
Driving a 2 mile stretch observed 15 monarchs from 11:55am- 12:15pm flying towards the south.

September 27
Observed in a 2mile drive 40 monarchs - flying individually heading south.

I was at MP 266 on the Blue Ridge Parkway, at altitude 3532ft at an overlook called The Lump watching for broad-winged hawks. Most of the Monarchs passed over this location between 12 and 2pm! If I could have stayed longer the numbers would have been very much higher. I suppose the weather conditions must have been perfect for them and the wind direction sent them from NW to SW. The location is an exceptional area for spotting hawks and for seeing monarchs with binoculars and spotting scope. Some monarchs were at very high altitudes, others were not.

September 29
Temp is 62 deg with scattered showers with the sun poking out of clouds between the showers. 40 Monarchs observed in a 15 minute time frame moving south west along the cliffs on Lake Erie's north shore. Many butterflies were stopping to get a quick snack on asters, golden rod and red clover before taking flight again. The weather tomorrow is supposed to be very cold (50 deg F or less for a daily high) and very windy with gale warnings posted along the lake but warming up nicely again next week. It's not unusual to see migrating Monarchs at Clearville Park until mid October and even early November as happened in 2009.

September 27
Beautiful sunny day today with light winds at Clearville Park. I estimate about 1500 butterflies per hour passing through along the cliffs on Lake Erie's north shore. These numbers continued for several hours until the wind shifted in the afternoon. When there is an off-shore wind the butterflies are concentrated along the lake side and easily observed. When there is an on-shore wind the butterflies get redirected further inland and are not visible from this location. The butterflies are heading toward Rondeau Park and Pt Pelee where they cross the lake to Ohio. There are lots of migrating dragon flies heading in the same direction.

September 23
Rained most of today but clouds broke and sun come out around 4:00 PM. Butterflies resumed migration along the cliffs on the north shore of Lake Erie. I counted 60 butterflies in 10 minutes which continued for about 1 hour until it clouded over again.
Monarchs are everywhere you look this week in SW Virginia.

Today is a beautiful day at the Kenesserie Road Tall Grass Prairie. Temp was high 70's F with light winds. This new 8 acre prairie was seeded with a high diversity native grass and prairie flower mix including butterfly (milk)weed and Sullivants milkweed in spring, 2011. Today I counted about 30 monarchs emerging from this prairie every 10 minutes. This continued for a couple of hours. Some of these butterflies are migrating and dropped into the prairie from points north and east for some nectar but many others are emerging from their chrysalis and drying their wings while snacking on asters, golden rod, blue vervain and great blue lobelia before taking flight high into the southwest sky.
These Monarchs seem to have more energy and usually go over the top of my house rather than around. Great weather 80's!
a total guess of 100-200 monarch butterflies and dragonflies went over our home Saturday and headed west bound.what a sight.
Saw 9 Monarchs on a 40 minute walk, two on flowers while the others either looking for flowers or just heading south(before the next rainfall!)

On the Leslie St Spit on Saturday (9:30am-2pm) we saw thousands of Monarchs. I didn't attempt a per hour count. The most surprising record of the day was 3 summer azures.

Forwarded by Don Davis

I work for a railroad and go on runs between Altoona, PA and Johnstown. Saw hundreds if not thousands of monarchs working their way down the tracks landing on the boneset and golden rod. Wonderful and beautiful little creature.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
In only a 20 minute period, I observed 5 monarchs headed south!

On the western portion of the Rockaway peninsula (Queens County, in N.Y. City) on Tuesday (9/27) there were at least 800 Monarchs on the move. This is conservative as the tally includes a bit more than 700 in flight plus what were actually well over 100 on flowers (mainly on non-native flowers, it seemed). The Monarchs were still moving later on in Brooklyn and Manhattan as well- all on a day with thick fog, then overcast, and a breeze later from the south. Other butterflies were noted in very minimal numbers, however Common Buckeye was present.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Our fifth grade class saw an average of 19 monarchs in 2 min eating nectar on our butterfly bushes outside our school.  Some were so hungry they were very easy to catch and tag.

There's a constant flow of Monarch's past my window today, since early morning. There are 4-8 every time I look out the window at the native coreopsis at the edge of the woods. I would estimate I've had over 100 come through thus far. This year, because of the drought, I decided not to mow so close to the woods. The Monarchs and I are happy we did that!

Since we did not mow to protect the soil this summer, many "weeds" have sprung up in the 5 acres around the house. I have selectively pulled them out as I go by, usually just as they are going to seed, leaving the flowers for the bees and butterflies. Right now the coreopsis scattered throughout the lawn and along the edge of the property is blooming. It appears as if the monarchs are going from cluster to cluster. That and the morning-glory-like groundcover that has small, almost unnoticeable blooms seems to be the only nectar source for the butterflies. We have clumps of milkweeds in the hayfields where I have seen a few monarchs this week, but generally they are going for the blooming plants. I have water available for birds, bees, and other wildlife in two places in the yard, but I did not see the Monarch's attend those.

Yesterday (10/1) I put out applesauce and a jelly-nectar on a plastic plate that I placed on a stump in the middle of the morning-glory-like flowers. I did not see any Monarch's take advantage of it, in fact they flew right around it to get to the blooms.

I saw the 100's of Monarchs on Friday over a 4-5 hour timespan. A front came through Friday night, so perhaps they were taking advantage of the weather to move south. There were fewer Monarchs on Saturday than on Friday, by about half. (There were fewer hummingbirds as well, probably for the same reason.) I took a tour around the 5 acres adjacent to the house, but could not find a place that they were roosting here. I saw them all the way up to sunset on the coreopsis on both Friday and Saturday evenings.
In just six minutes, our 5th grade class was surprised to see 8 monarchs flying in a southwesterly direction this morning.

Toronto Report Saturday - Hundreds of Monarchs Crossing Lake Ontario

Forwarded by Don Davis

Monarch Butterflies- 800 to 1000 per hour

The Toronto Ornithological Club held a waterfront outing along the Lake Ontario shoreline east of Toronto in Durham Region (where Cranberry Marsh is located) on Sunday. Birder Geoff Carpentier reports:

hundreds of monarchs today - few flying - most sitting on goldenrod and NE Aster.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

In my corner of Chautauqua County there was a steady stream of monarchs stopping in the yard and feeding on the New England Asters which are in prime bloom right now. They would nectar for awhile in groups of two and three, and then head southwest only to be replaced a while later with a new batch. The Joe Pye Weed and most of the goldenrod are done blooming, so butterflies are feeding primarily on the several types of wild aster I have growing on the property.

At one point there were seven monarchs feeding on just two of the aster bushes, and that is the most wild ones I have ever seen in my yard at one time, since I moved here five years ago. In fact that is more than the number of wild ones that I have seen here all summer. : )

These ones most likely crossed the center of Lake Erie, as I have observed them coming in right off of the lake in previous years and roosting in the trees in small batches of 20 - 30.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monarch Butterflies- 800 to 1000 per hour

The Toronto Ornithological Club held a waterfront outing along the Lake Ontario shoreline east of Toronto in Durham Region (where Cranberry Marsh is located) on Sunday. Birder Geoff Carpentier reports:

hundreds of monarchs today - few flying - most sitting on goldenrod and NE Aster.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Blue Ridge Parkway Field Trip Sep. 24-25, 2011

The trip was timed for around the peak of Monarch migration. There were a few on Saturday, but there were times on Sunday morning when the air seemed full of Monarchs and it was hard to count them all. We were happy with our total of 95 adult Monarchs plus one caterpillar. The total number of butterfly species for the two-day trip was 27, not too bad for a mostly cloudy and cool weekend.

We had expected a beautiful display of late summer wildflowers, and we weren't disappointed. The roadsides and hills were splashed with yellow and white and highlighted with reds and purples. We walked through meadows dotted with clumps of goldenrods, ironweeds and cardinal flowers.

Monarch 7 on the 24th, 88 + 1 caterpillar on the 25th.

Courtesy of Carolina Leps
Watched 10 or so Monarchs nectering on large lantana shrubs. Saw them at noon and still there at 5pm.

First sighting increased from a few here and there to several hundred throughout the day.  Evening watch found many roosting in junipers and engaging in reproduction activities.  Also sighted flitting around yellow cut leaf daisies and white brush.
I watched many monarchs come thru the yard today and stopped to feed on the butterfly bush. I watched for about half an hour saw about 50 monarchs

October 9
Steady stream of many monarchs (and many dragonflies, buckeyes, some painted ladies) came into Cape May today from the north....it ain't over yet! Monarchs were abundant on the butterfly bushes near the cottage, impossible to count but I'd say somewhere in the 400-500 range stopped in between 7:30 am and 3 pm when we left). Most dropped in for a bite and left going towards the point.

We were at the point between 12 and 1; not much along the trails-the action was all by the beach where they were flying in great numbers along the dunes and stopping on the goldenrod here and there. Some were clearly fatigued (flying low, hitting the ground at times) so there will be roosts tonight.

My husband had to literally drag me out of Cape May earlier today to go home; it was hard to leave all our flutterby friends. On the drive to Jackson on the Garden State-counted 39 all flying south between 3 and 4:30 pm (and many dragonflies, etc). Once home we were greeted by five more in our garden.

October 8
All day today the 3 butterfly bushes at our cottage were covered with butterflies-over 3 dozen monarchs for much of the time-unusual to see this many at once (not even last year with huge numbers stopping through did I see this many on the bushes). Working by the cottage today I did not observe any in flux into the city from the north. At 5 pm some of the monarchs roosted high up in a deciduous tree behind our property; I counted 16 going in to roost but then left to go to the point. We walked down at the point from 5:30 to sunset and saw very few monarchs-some on the goldenrod and some roosting individually in trees.

October 1
In a 35 minute walk we saw at least 1000 monarchs at Cape May point. From 11am until 4ish we noted monarchs coming into Cape May from the north-we did not count them.... This evening we found two significantly sized roosts-one on the dunes near Lincoln Ave at the point and the other in the state park at the end of the blue trail--this one was very large--several deciduous trees were literally covered with monarchs. Could not count them-lighting was poor but definitely a large roost!

I arrived at Robert Moses State Park Field 5 at 2 p.m. and even before I got in the parking lot there were monarchs every where! They were most numerous in the dunes and on the beach going westbound. I counted 17 Monarchs on a single seaside goldenrod on the inner dune facing the parking lot. I also noticed that seaside goldenrods in full bloom. As the sun was setting I observed monarchs starting to gather in small groups in the pitch pines on the north side of the field 2 parking lot. They seem to favor wind buffered areas within the stands of pitch pines. It was really neat seeing so many of them fluttering about the trees over my head.

At noon on 10/1/11, while walking on the Long Branch boardwalk near the ocean, I counted 58 monarchs in one hour both in flight and/or nectaring on goldenrod. The temperature was in the mid-upper 60's and it was partially sunny. I overheard people commenting on seeing a lot of monarchs this year. Many were flying very close to people. This week, we spotted a tagged monarch in our back yard on tropical milkweed. Capturing the monarch, I realized it was one of those we released at my school 7 days earlier, 22 miles north of where we live.
Thirty monarchs flew by between 9 and 930am.
Monarchs flying around the creek and getting nectar from Milkweed vine, Vitex trees and golden rod.
Sporadic butterflies observed thoughout the town

I went to a high school cross-country track meet and a Monarch migration broke out.  A cold front on 09/30/2011 brought north winds and clear sky.  At 09:40 a.m. the first butterfly was sighted.  During the next 1 hour and 20 minutes 53 Monarchs were observed.
I observed as many as 27 Monarchs today nectaring on Frostweed and Gregg's Blue Mist flower in my yard today. All looked to be in good condition with no tattered wings.

Yesterday (10/1) as I conducted an environmental program for TOEA at the HE Butt Foundation in Leakey I observed literally hundreds of Monarchs along the Frio River. About the only flowers present in any degree of abundance were Lindheimer’s Senna, Goldenrod, and Frostweed. Almost every frostweed plant with a flower had a Monarch on it. As I drove through the Concan area about noon at about 65 mph I counted 69 Monarchs in a 7 mile stretch. Most were looking very good with only a couple being obviously worn.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

Just wanted to report, I am seeing many more Monarchs in this area than I have in previous years, particularly in the last five days (9/28- 10/2). I am in the Hanover/Lebanon, New Hampshire area.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Saw 50 monarchs per hour in Cape May, both on the beach & in down for the October fest.  Were the monarchs inspired by the um pa pah band?  I think not, nonetheless they kept flying.Best part of the day was at the Cape May Nature Center on Delaware Avenue.  Overhead 3 women (presumably a mother, daughter & granddaughter from PA) on their way to see monarch tagging.  I told them I think it's a great project to watch.I asked the mother if they had a good summer in their garden, she said yes, they had lots of monarchs & her daughter brought many inside in advance of Hurricane Irene, then released them after the storm left.  I say Hurrah to that kid!  Can she be the next Jane Goodall?

WOW!!! Last week was a big week for Northwest Arkansas when it came to Monarch Butterflies.  The students reported a total of 239 for the week of Sept. 26-Oct. 3.  It has been pretty awesome.  I'm sure we will have more!!!

A very large number of Monarch butterflies visited the library butterfly garden today. There were 20 at the very least -- probably many more. We were able to tag 3 for MonarchWatch.orgNote: There seemed to be many more boy butterflies than girls. Is this normal? Do male and female butterflies migrate at different times? We will keep watching, to see if we can figure this out.

We saw hundreds of butterflies on the playground from about 8:00 Am through our recess. We could see them through the window in our classroom, that's where we observed them for most of the day.

The water sprinklers on our new playground and there are several flower bushes across the parking lot from our school is what we figured attracted them. We were surprised they hung around so long, it was such a beautiful sight. The children noticed right away through our window that something unusual was going on outside on the playground. It is so dry around here that the puddles from the water sprinklers was probably the only water they had seen for no telling how long. There are still a few lingering around here but for the rest they seemed to have completely passed through.
We observed about 50 monarchs from 8:45-9:30am.  Most were feeding on New England Asters.  We later tagged 15 monarchs.

October 5
Less today (100), plant blooms falling off. I think their going to be moving on soon.

October 3
Taken at mid morning. They're everywhere feeding and knocking each other around. I haven't gone back in the evening to see what trees their roosting in ....Sorry.

We are getting many reports of large numbers of monarchs in the Davis Mountains region of West Texas.

I just spoke to a rancher that has thousands of them roosting in pecan orchards near Valentine. He said that this is the first time that they have ever seen this many monarchs.

Also, I received a report today of hundreds of monarchs in the Post Park just south of Marathon.

We have also documented dozens of monarchs on our weekly butterfly counts at the Chihuahuan Desert Nature Center--more than I have ever seen in the 10 years that I've been with the Nature Center.

We also have monarch caterpillars on the broad-leaf milkweed that came up in the grasslands that burned in April.

Lots of monarchs have been seen at the Chihuahuan Desert Nature Center (4.5 miles south of Fort Davis, TX). But these seem to be coming in to nectar at the wildflowers (primarily Asteraceae of many species) growing in our grassland (Photo of nectaring monarchs) and at the native plants growing in our botanical garden. I also noticed last week that several of the broad leaf milkweeds (Asclepias latifolia) have monarch larvae on them. We have a small stock tank near where the wildflowers are growing that captured a little water during a heavy rain several weeks ago.

Roost at Post Park
The two images of roosting monarchs was taken at the Post Park about 5 miles south of Marathon, TX. The park has a spring and pond which is surrounded by large pecan trees. I received a report earlier in the day from a birder that had gone to the park and was annoyed because there were so many butterflies that he couldn't see the birds! After hearing that, I made a point of making the trip to the park that evening.

All weekend long (10/1-10/2), Monarchs were airborne and inview at the Davis Mountains Preserve, often dozens if not hundreds ata time. Then today (10/3), from Fort Davis to Alpine and on up US67 to FortStockton, nearly always there were multiple individuals crossing thehighway at windshield height the entire way. East of Fort Stockton,there were far fewer, and I mention this "path" as I more frequentlyencountered these densities around Ozona or Sonora in other years, andthink the "lanes" or corridors may vary from year to year. Along theselines were high numbers from the Davis Mountains Resort (MaryannKremesec Eastman, Marathon area (Matt Matthew York and around Gate 4of Terlingua Ranch (Betty Alex) all reported on Facebook postings."

"Betty Alex I dodged Monarchs all the way from Gate4, through StudyButte and into Panther Junction (Big Bend NP HQ) this morning around 930am. LOTS! Nobig bunches, but 2-6 at a time all along the road. I think I actuallymanaged to NOT hit a single one (I hope). about a minute ago"

These reports are on the far western edge of the "Central Flyway".They are seen in good numbers there, but not every year. Looks like itwon't be a good yr for the I-35 corridor (the eastern edge of the"Central Flyway").

Courtesy of Mike Quinn

We had hundreds and hundreds on the Llano River. ~50 km ESE of San Angelo. I tagged 104, just by myself. Almost all were nectaring on Frostweed. Very scattered, don't seem to be doing the roosting thing the way they usually do.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn

Texas Lepidoptera Surveyfrom Big Bend Nat'l Pk, north to Davis Mtns, and west to Del Rio, TX.

We easily saw between 3-5000 from BIBE and DM to Del Rio in the last few days. There were few nectaring places except for that stretch of Pecos Co. between Brewster and Terrell Co.'s, and extreme eastern Brewster Co., where there had been some rain and lots of composites were in full bloom, covered with Monarchs. Lots of road kill, too.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn
Monarchs have invaded in mass! They are literally everywhere - I see them driving through town and country. Every flower patch has hoards hovering.

October 5
Monarchs on the Butterfly bushes and wildflowers. Not as much activity as yesterday (12).

October 4
It was amazing to see so many Monarch Butterflies. In past years, I was lucky to see a couple in a year. This year, I have been seeing one or two, almost every day since last month. To see so many today, in a 40 minute period, far surpasses my record for sightings. I'm sure I missed many more. Many stopped to feed on my Butterfly Bushes, others on the wild flowers, and some kept heading south.

Have observed for many years.  Today I saw more monarch butterflys than have ever seen.  After several days of rain, the sun came out this afternoon and the Monarchs appeared as if on cue.  I am located in the Ohio River Valley. They continue to pass by my location, even as I sit here typing this. Great day for sighting Monarch's!!!
Sighted 75 monarchs within 1.5 hours. Of them, 95 percent were flying higher than the average bird and all were going south

Saturday I received reports of huge numbers of monarchs. We visited two locations where monarchs were roosting. At least three other people have mentioned the monarchs covering the rtees in their yards in the past two days.
This is the first time I have ever seen a migration. I love butterflies and I'm a very happy girl right now!! :) It was beautiful!
Until today, haven't seen a monarch migration since the late '60s. It was amazing!

This is my first observation so I'm not sure of peak migration, but monarchs have been flying past our beach front house for 4 hours and are still doing so.  Not a large number at a time but 1-15 every few minutes.  Monarchs have been flying by since we arrived on 10/01/11 but many more today.

They were unbelievable. You would think being at the beach to watch the dolphins not today the glory of the Monarch has arrived. It has now been 3 hours and still they are passing by our balcony.Tonia Shaw

From 9:09 to 9:19 a.m. on Oct.5, 2011 I counted 117 monarchs flying from north to south past the porch of my beach house on Topsail Island, NC.  This was a sampling of what appears to be typial daytime migratory activity here at this time of year.
25 - 50/min flying SW on the beach of Surf City, NC
Monarchs flying all over the place and above highway near Steubenville, Ohio.
A few were flying high but most were actively feeding on the seaside goldenrod at West Meadow Beach. I netted and tagged 2 butterflies.

I wason break at work and noticed several Monarch butterflies, then while driving to lunch I saw dozens more. I eventually lost count. They are everywhere today. Thsi is the first break in weather in several days. A nice cool autumn day with sun and clear skies. Perfect for Monarch Butterfly migration.

Denise Gibbs of Chincoteague Monarch Monitoring Project reports from Assateague Island, VA:

The monarchs migrated down the beach today in a continuous stream from 8:15am to 6:15pm. The average was about 600 per hour. Once they arrived at the narrow section of the island (about 100 yards between ocean and bay), they stopped to nectar on seaside goldenrod or they turned around and headed back over to the causeway. One side of the causeway has a freshwater impoundment and the other has a saltmarsh. The causeway is elevated so monarchs stayed low in the bayberry thicket at the edge of the marsh, completely out of the wind. The grounsel-tree (bushes) in this spot were loaded with nectaring monarchs all day. This is where I could safely tag and release them, without risking having them blow backwards out over the ocean. However it wasn't so safe for me because if I stood too long in one place, I would sink down about a foot into the soft mud, making me an easy target for the saltmarsh mosquitoes (the things we do for Monarch Watch . . .)

The winds remained from the NW all day, usually from 10-15mph, but picking up speed to about 20mph for an hour or two. By 6:30 there were some sizeable roosts forming along the causeway near the NPS visitor center in the bayberry bushes that had survived Irene, and in the bare branches of those that did not. I estimated about 5,000 monarchs in 7 separate roosts (that I could see from the road), but there were likely more in the dense thickets on the small islands in the freshwater impoundments, since I saw monarchs flying into them at dusk. This was one of those days that left lasting impressions, both in my memory and on my memory card. Monarchs, buckeyes, green darners, black saddlebags, Carolina saddlebags, wandering gliders, spot-winged gliders, Peregrine falcons, merlins, harriers, bald eagles, osprey, tree swallows, ruddy turnstones, black-bellied plovers, semi-palmated sandpipers, palm warblers, yellow-rumped warblers, cormorants, herons, egrets, terns, gulls, sanderlings, yellowlegs, oystercatchers, and pelicans all graced the island with their beauty and lifted the spirits of those few who opened their eyes to see it.

Yesterday and today the monarchs have been sailing through Cape May Point in the dunes, down the roads.... They're feeding on english ivy flowers, seaside goldenrod, lantana, butterfly bush, zinnia's and asters in resident's gardens.  It's an amazing sight to be seen.  The hawks and dragonflies are also cruising through in amazing numbers!!  I'll post any roosting but it may be too warm tonight.

Most amazing day ever for this observer.  More that 200 per hour.  No let up in sight. Started seeing Monarch's around 10:00am.It is now 2:00pm and they continue to pass by.  Cannot sit and count all day, but it has been a wonder to behold.Counted over 600 and then had to do some yard work.  They passed by in a continuous stream.

The migration has finally arrived on Long Beach Island...the monarchs are everywhere! Within 1000'from my home to the beach, I observed over 30 at 10 AM...while on the beach they were coming off the ocean in groups...continually! Some were so tired they were seen resting on the beach...others were flying in groups toward the dunes and heading for food and cover for the night...they are feeding on our flowers and ignoring the feed stations...one just flew by my window as I was typing this report...absolutely magical to be surrounded by these magnificent creatures!
THE MONARCHS ARE ALL GIONG IN A SOUTHERLY DIRECTION. AND CROSSING THE OHIO RIVER  SOMEWHERE NEER BELLAIRE OHIO.
there were hundreds of them.. they were flying south
We watched from our porch just across the street from the beach.  The Monarchs were feeding on two flowering bushes nearby.  Every minute 2 or more would fly by heading southwest.

I was on the Atlantic coast at a beach access site  and saw monarch after monarch drifting west.  Some were flying low and some were flying high. I have never seen so many monarchs pass through one location.  I felt uplifted watching them as the last chrysalis at my home didn't make it.  I was glad to see all of those that had made it. I wish them well on their journey.
As I took my kids to school we spotted them flying over. They kept coming and coming all day.
Monarchs sighted along north end shore of Long Beach Island, NJ.  More sighted on ocean side than bay side.

On Saturday October 1st, I paddled along the Colorado River 25 miles southeast of Austin from near Webberville to near Utley. In the 7 river miles we traveled, we consistently saw Monarchs in the ones and twos. If I had to put a number on the total, it would be 100-200. All were nectaring on the riverside flowers, none were engaging in directional flight. I did not see any monarchs traveling to or from the river.

Over the past two weeks I have seen monarchs in and around Austin engaged in directional flight, but only one or two on any given day.

Away from the Cororado river, there are essentially no blooming flowewr. Frostweed which is normally a migration staple around here are desiccated stalks with withered leaves and no flowers. The white mistflower (another migration staple), in my yard, behaved abnormally this year. The plants without irrigation bloomed in July, while the plants under irrigation are blooming now, their normal time. Outside my yard, there are no white mistflowers blooming.

Much contrast between the verdant river edge and the desiccated upper bank. Moving away from the river, it is just as brown or browner than in the photo. The Colorado River in this section has a daily variation of about 18 inches as the River Authority releases water from the highland lakes for rice farmers along the coast. Without the lake releases, the river flow here would be essentially zero except the effluent from Austin.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

After several days of a pitiful migration, the cold front seemed to push down some big numbers. From Sep 20 to Oct 1 I tagged 17 monarchs. Today Oct 2 I tagged 117 and there were at least thrice that I was not able to catch. I had 15 folks with me on the CBS field trip this afternoon, and nearly every one of them caught and helped tag a monarch, many caught several. As the group left, I returned to our first spot and hit the mother load. Tagged 75 in 1.5 hours and saw another 300 at least, three times I caught "doubles" in my net, and at one dead end spot at the lake I had a Baccharus shrub full of them and I netted SEVEN in one net swing!!! A new personal record! One was a recapture, the other six were tagged and released. Nectar was an even mix of Goldenrod, Bidens and Baccharus. I hope to get out this week to get more, from the last two years this seems to be a later migration, or at least a later "peak". Bidens is about bloomed out.

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

October 5
Oct 2 I tagged 117 and saw about 400.

Oct 3, same exact place and nearly the same time I tagged 8 and saw total of 12.

I have never seen a one day push of monarchs through my area. In what I thought was a more typical migration here, I would see a week of singletons, a week of double digits peaking with maybe a day of triple digits and then a week of singles again. This season has ben a week and a half of singletons, one day of triple digits, now whats next another week and a half of singletons??? Wierd.
