First large influx of migrating Monarch butterflies, undoubtedly more than 100 and probably many more.

Saw quite a few monarchs late  yesterday, and today was able to tag 27 monarchs in my neighbors' garden from about 2:30p.m. til 4:30p.m.(with very little effort!). During this time I saw numerous others ( it must have been dozens and dozens) stopping to have a drink of nectar on their way through. It was a beautiful afternoon!
clear sunny evening-talking to neighbor outside and we counted at least 50-55 monarchs flying at different altitudes, going from north to south

I was biking out to the beach (Assateague Island) and noticed monarchs all over.  They would flit in and out, being all of a sudden in front of you and behind you.  When I got to a goldenrod field at Assateague, there were 100s, many of them in multiple numbers on one plant.  it was mystical.

At approximately 1:30 PM EDST on Wed. 10/5/11 I observed Monarchs at the rate of about 25/minute passing over Long Beach island in NJ.There was a steady westerly,north westerly breeze of about 10 mph on a beautiful sunny day.
We were on the playground at recess and counted the monarchs fluttering across the playground on their way south.

We have had a higher thanusual occurrence of monarch butterflies at Guadalupe Mountains NationalPark this fall. One of our staff, Dennis Vasquez, reported going on a hikeinto the Guadalupe Canyon area along the El Capitan Trail on Sunday, October2, 2011, and they accidentally flushed hundreds of monarchs that wereresting in a large Juniperus deppeana (alligator juniper). I have noticedseveral wafting along on October 3 and 4 in the Pine Springs area of thepark. I also had a few visiting the flowering lantana in my yard inCarlsbad, NM on October 1 and 2.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn

Monarchs were whizzing by the classroom windows today, so I went to the beach, Harvard Avenue in Ventnor. Counted over 1,000 monarchs from 5-6:40pm. Multitudes of monarchs nectaring on seaside goldenrod in the dunes. Monarchs gliding over the people strolling on the beach and boardwalk. Observed many butterflies beginning to roost in black pine trees along boardwalk. Temperature was in the mid 70s with a northwest wind of about 12 mph.

While sitting on the beach at Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge the monarchs were constantly migrating, as well as a smaller butterfly with white on the edges of the wings.  For every 10 monarchs, there was one or two of the smaller butterfly, also migrating.

The Monarch Monitoring Project (Cape May Bird Observatory / New Jersey Audubon) in Cape May, NJ is conducting its 22nd year of research and education. Road Census data (sampling migrant monarch numbers along the mid-Atlantic coast) for the first four weeks of the 2011 season is now posted on our website. Details of our project may also be found on the website.

Cape May Monarch Monitoring Project

November 4
Tori Pocus counted 10 monarchs on the final census run of the 2011 season.Despite some rather dire predictions prior to the 2011 migration, in Cape Maywe recorded slightly better than average numbers of monarchs as measured againstour data for 2 decades. Of course this is just one snapshot of migrants moving across a broad front. However, our the Cape May Road Census is one of only two (Peninsula Point, Michigan is the other) quantitative measures of southbound migrants. Details are onour website.

We thank all who have taken an interest in our work and as always we hope to . . . See You At The Point

October 27
We have completed the last full week of the 2011 Road Census and the numbers are posted on our website. In fact, we were somewhat surprised by the relatively large numbers (70 monarchs/hour)of monarchs still migrating through Cape May . Was this weather related with migrants bidingtheir time northwards? Perhaps it was a surge of emerging adults? Or have these migrantsbeen displaced eastwards this year? While we don't have any definitive answers at present.anecdotal reports from monarch watchers in other parts of North America also mention a similar push of "late" migrants.

We were delighted to have a recapture (male monarch PLA 141) from Tyaskin, MD. The monarchhad traveled approximately 80 miles since tagged by Louise Zemaitis on October 9th. He wasin good shape and we wish him well on the rest of his journey!

October 21
While we are on the downslope, 90 monarchs/hour for the 2011 season Rebecca and Tori continue to see numbers of monarchs on some of the census runs. Week 7 results are posted on our website. A link from the website will take you to the blog for details.

October 13
While the migration got off to a slow start this fall monarchs have put on quite a showin Cape May the last two weeks. Week 6 results, posted on our website, 261 monarchs/hourtell the story - but only part of it.

Rebecca Allmond's latest blog post gives the details including highlightsof the week, an updated graph and a summary of recent weather patternsin Cape May.

http://capemaymonarchs.blogspot.com/

October 5
Week 5 was a good week for monarchs in Cape May. 210 monarchs/hour. The long awaited cold front delivered asexpected and everyone fortunate enough to be in Cape May over the last several days saw the dunespainted orange.

Details on week 5 numbers are posted on our website along with a corrected figure for week 4 (13 monarchs/hour).Rebecca and Tori have posted numerous photographs and details about the recent flight on their blog. A link to the 2011 Monarch Blog is on our website's home page. Check it out.

Courtesy of Dick Walton
Director, Monarch Monitoring Project
Monarchs passing Plymouth Place and Ocean AVenue easily one every minute heading south.

Had about 20-30 butterflies in my bush until sundown.  After sundown only found two or three .... so they must be roosting somewhere near.  My bush is shaded in the morning ... maybe that's why they don't stay the night.   Mid-morning there are numerous - probably 20-30 in my bush along with sulphurs and admirals.  Quite a site.  I'll keep watch to see if they stay the night

Wind diverted migrating monarchs -- pushed seaward by persistent hard west winds -- are heading back westward, across Long Beach Island (NJ). The numbers are as high as we've seen in many years. Unfortunately, road attrition is high to very high, despite generally light off-season traffic on the main boulevard. Approximately 50 injured or DOA monarchs per road mile, times 18 miles.
Standing in our backyard, we saw more than we could count! Estimate: 50-100 in 10 minutes.

October 6
Saw 47 butterflies along Trustees Road at West Meadow Beach in the early afternoon. Most were flying high in a southerly direction, but several were feeding on goldenrod. Captured and tagged 6 specimens.

October 5
Most of the butterflies observed at West Meadow Beach were on the creek (leeward) side, feeding on the seaside goldenrod. Captured and tagged 47 specimens.

12:30pm, 89 degrees, 13% humidity, sunny, windy from the south.  The butterflies were headed south to the Chisos Mountains (less than a mile from our home).  Our peak days were probably within the last 4 days, we think these are the stragglers.  We are in the Chihuahuan Desert and we are in a drought, so it is hard for them to find food.
The most we have seen at one time, thus far, around 12 in our yard.  They feed on butterfly bush, vitex tree, and chocolate daisies.
Dozens of monarchs in small clusters heading west. I live 2 blocks from the Atlantic, to my east
Began seeing them Wednesday or Thursday, 09/28/11.  Many here -- 7 miles out in the country!  Hanging on the mesquite limbs!  They were still there today--even in 30 to 40 mph winds!!  10/7/11

It was the middle of the day, a beautiful sunny day after a week of very cool cloudy weather.  This was in my yard both front and back on my butterflybushes and also zinnas, cosmos and lantana.  I also have a lot of butterfly weed however its not in bloom at this time. Today I saw several monarchs but not as many as yesterday.

I have a field with a bumper crop of wild daisy . There are adult Monarch Butterflys all over the place . To many to count . They have been feeding on the daisys for several days . I wondered where they were .
Coastal area. Butterflies were everywhere taking bread to fuel on goldenrod and butterfly bushes. All sighted were stopped on flowers or flying on the beach. None sighted were flying purposefully.

Had monarchs dropping out of the sky into our gardens all day, a steady stream, 3-4 at a time nectaring on butterfly bushes. (Our goldenrod is past bloom now). They are in great shape too!  Many stopped for brief periods and then up and away moving south.  At one point--around 4 pm I watched three come down at once....Quite unusual to see this here in Jackson. Many painted ladies and a few buckeyes around as well.  Lots and lots of dragonflies traveling today too.Yesterday while working in NYC I kept going out to watch the monarchs as they glided down 1st Ave....Counted 36 in a 10 minute period in the early afternoon....wanted to move my office outside!

This was a unique experience for me. I sat down at 2:30pm today at the window of my home looking out towards the water's edge of Tangier Sound, Chesapeake Bay. My location is due west of Assateague Island State Park in Berlin, MD; on the Atlantic Ocean. It is about 40 miles by air I believe.   At my home I looked out the window and noticed a Monarch flying in front of the window, I continued to watch to study its path and flight...30 seconds later, another, both headed west into the sun...30 seconds later another, 1 minute later 2 more..and so on it went for the entire 2 and a half hours I sat there. There was a continuing stream of butterflies. I went to the other side of the house and saw them approaching from the east. Occassionally a group of five would come by in a few seconds time. As time went on I noticed some of them were turning south continuing to fly over land instead of water, in essence changing the route followed by the others. By this time it was approaching nightfall, maybe that had something to do with it. I would say I saw a parade of Monarchs, very impressive!
A steady stream of monarchs pass by my house every year at this time. They follow the same path. They fly one by one.  Stopping to feed on some beach roses.

An amazing sight was beheld by us this day, that of hundreds of butterflies coming past us in waves. Neither one of us had ever been honored by the thrill of being in the midst of the monarch migration...We happened to be out at 11:30 am, and we don't truly know how long they had been passing through. Here is a photo of one of them as it stopped to eat something...

A spectacular Fall evening!  Spent an hour in my hammock under a cloudless sky, relaxing after a busy week.  There was a breeze coming out of the North and I observed 36 Monarchs all sailing along in a Southerly direction.  I bid them all a safe journey!
Two monarchs flying level with the second story of my house with purpose toward the south

There were thousands of Monarchs in the formerly flooded lake bed, fields, and woodlands north of White River Lake (Crosby County) on Sunday (10/2).  They were nectaring, so far as I could tell, on the flourishing crop of milkweed springing from formerly flooded open areas or on the now abundant sunflowers coating every other surface of the lake and river beds.  The sunflowers never achieved their normal height but, even stuck at the three foot high stage, are blooming nicely.  When not nectaring, the Monarchs were sheeting on both willows and cottonwoods.  I tallied close to 2000 along a winding path roughly six miles long and feet wide.  It was the best day of butterflying I have had at the lake so far this year (five eight-hour visits so far) with 33 species of butterflies seen - including a startling number of very fresh Eastern Tailed Blues; a species I see very rarely in my region.  Then again, it was the first visit this year where there were enough flowers going to set off my allergies:)

As regards the condition of the Monarchs: they looked pretty darn close to mint condition to me and did not strike me as particularly thin-bodied nor lethargic.  It may be a rare phenomenon in this drought-stricken year but this one spot seems to be fairly high quality for visiting and resident butterflies.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

I have been seeing lots of monarchs wafting through Allen (Collin County) lately, and found one monarch caterpillar on Asclepias viridis last Tuesday at the Connemara Meadow Preserve. The caterpillar was about 1 3/4" long, and looked healthy.

I have taken photos showing them nectaring on Maximillian sunflower in the wild, and Gregg's blue mistflower, and frostweed in the garden. Conditions are worsening here, with most small plants either completely dead/dormant, and many of the large trees suffering ill effects of the drought too. Human maintained landscapes are the best sources fro flowering plants in this area right now, and the monarchs are stopping by the yard daily to fill up on my garden flowers.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn

I am a college biology teacher living on a private WMA (35 acres) and observe movements of plants (primarily) but also follow nesting of certain birds (primarily dickcissel) and the movement of Monarch butterflies. In 2009 there was a mass migration across our property. The count, which went on for 3 days, was in excess of 1500. Unfortunately, a computer hard drive problem resulted in loss of the photos. I can only hope, each year, that we will see another 'fall of monarchs' but fear that is a once in a life-time occurrence. This year, 1 hour of observations over a 1 mile walk yielded 27 butterflies on 10/07/11.

This past Sunday, October 2, I stood in my yard most of the day, due to having landscaping work. I estimate 100 Monarchs passed low over my house. Several even flitted down to check out the new plants going in - Flame Acanthus and Butterfly Bush; none stopped, though, due to the constant human activity.

Not a "significant movement" (in the past, I have seen MANY more). I have had 1-2-3 Monarchs at a time over the past two weeks feeding from my native Texas Lantana horrida, in the evenings when I'm home from work to see them. I also see 1-2 now and then, resting on the leaves of my Shumard Red Oak trees.

On Sunday morning, I was thrilled to find five Monarch Caterpillars on my Mexican Butterfly Weed plants - the first Monarch cats I have ever seen in my yard!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn
My butterfly bushes are covered all the time with 40-50 Monarch Butterflies.

The sea watch in Avalon said yesterday (10/5) that they stopped counting after approximately 5,000 monarchs flew by!  The hawk flight was fabulous too with many kettles of mixed species but also 2 kettles of approximately 100 broad-wings.

Driving east along the Gardiner Expressway, Lake Shore Blvd E, Queen Street East and finally Kingston Road.  Sunny day, 18 deg.C, after a day of windy, rainy weather. Monarchs flying mostly below 15m altitude, in loose groups of 2-7 and many solo adventurers. Every single on was heading South-West. Some resting / feeding on hanging flower baskets. It was hard to keep my eyes on the road!...no accidents :)Was on route to visit my mom in palliative care....helped both of us to bring her news of this wondrous sighting. Monarchs have been in our lives since I knew what a Monarch was. I have raised and released over 200 of these beauties at home and with my high school science students at Centre Wellington Dist. High School in Fergus. How DO they find their winter home in Mexico?!?!

The peak Monarch migration has hit Dallas.  Their numbers have been steadily growing over the past 2 weeks, and today there were approx. 60+ butterflies in the garden (at the same time).  They fly around so much it's impossible to count them all.  They nectar primariy on Frostweed and to a lesser extent, Mexican Sunflower and Gregg's Mistflower - but Frostweed is their favorite.  If it wasn't for human gardens, there would be next to nothing for them to nectar on due to the drought in Texas this year.  I made a short video today of all the action and posted it to www.youtube.com for all to see.  Here is the link:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=woGb3VyeIuc

It was the most amazing sight. After five days of rain. Temperature 58 degrees, the sun finally came out, then it started. Butterflies floating out the northeast traveling southwest into a mild headwind. We counted 125 butterflies in one(1) hour. Mostly one at a time,but some were in groups of up to three. Vaya Con Dios!

I observed 250 monarchs between 1:30 and 4:30 PM flying south over the beach at Harrisville State Park. Some were almost red in color and I estimated that there was 1 male per 12 females as they stopped to nectar on goldenrod and minerals on the shore. It was a very sunny day with the temperature starting out at 52F., in the morning, and climbing to 81F., Wind S-10.

I spent an hour this afternoon at the NCSU Raulston Arboretum in west Raleigh. Despite the dry conditions, and the taking up of some of the lantana from the gardens by staff, the activity was fast and furious among what is left. Of course, on Oct. 9, diversity is dropping weekly, though 15 species isn’t bad, along with a few hundred individuals. Here’s the list:

Monarch 35 everywhere! One had a fresh round wing tag, under the right FW; banded by Brian B recently at Falls Lake?

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

Many were perched on goldenrods. They were were flying low near the dunes of Crookes Point. Unusually warm and sunny day. They were observed between 12:45PM and 1:45PM. 4 Monarchs were found dead under one goldenrod.

A friend just reported seeing 20-30 monarchs nectaring on a butterfly bush on the north end of the island and "lots of them" along the boulevard as he was driving north. It was warm (mid 60s) and sunny, no comment on the wind. This should bode well for a great weekend at Cape May.And I am at work, not seeing many monarchs except the ones we've been raising in school. The kids just tagged and released 6.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Date: October 3, 2011
Location: Sunset Point at Presque Isle State Park
Time: 7:25 to 9:25 AM
Weather: Cloudy, wind N to 10 mph, waves about two to three feet. Temp. about 51 to 55 F. Light misty rain at times.

Comments: Not much moving this morning with most birds heading east. Eagles, Peregrines, and Merlins seem to becoming quite regular on the watch. Unfortunately, it appears the cold front passed during the heaviest movement of Monarchs of the fall season. Evidence of this was the high mortality. Hundreds and perhaps thousands were washed ashore all along the beaches of Presque Isle S.P. Many were still alive, but wings were battered severely.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

In Austin, I have 1.25 in the rain gauge with more on its way; Jennie S texted me from the Hill Country and said they got 3+ inches. She tagged 500 yesterday (10/08) on the San Saba yesterday. Temps are down for sure, 60s - 80s.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

October 10
I saw lots more warming up and flying at 9 am this morning.

October 9
I saw about 100 monarch butterflies leaving NH's seacoast today in about an hour of continuous flow. Wow, were they flying fast, headed south. Beautiful sunny day 85 degrees at the beach. They were loving the breeze and the heat. A few were stopping on a flowers, but moving on quickly to find a roost for the night. (They like the weeping willow trees along the coast)

Monarch's were flying over at about 40ft-60ft high in one's and two's. I spotted about 70 in an hour of observation. Only once did I spot a group of eight together. The Monarchs were flying in a southwest direction.

Saw about 40 monarchs nectaring on a garden row of New England aster.  Tagged 12.  10/8/11 returned to same patch, but only saw about 10 there.  Further north along the seashore, found 8-10 on Montauk daisies.  All heading south/southwest!
I saw about 50 Monarchs flying overhead at soccer practice.

There was the large number of monarchs around Monarch Watch last evening (10/8)- at least 60 - about 4 days after the last date (4 October) when it is usually possible to find monarchs in modest numbers on heath asters in the field. We have had a superabundance of monarchs at MW for over a week and it got me thinking..

We have 6 large A.curassavica in full bloom in front of the entrance to our building and for the last 9 days, as one approached the entrance, a cloud of 20-40 monarchs lifted off and drifted to the north on the south winds only to come back to the flowers within minutes. It has been quite a sight and Jim Lovett posted a video on Facebook that captured some of the action.

There are several reasons for this assemblage - there are good numbers of late monarchs, strong S and SW winds and above normal temperatures are limiting opportunities to migrate and lastly Monarch Watch and Monarch Waystation #1 is an oasis in an otherwise mostly dry landscape.

This morning while taking a break in our "Park" (an area covered with mulch among ash, elm and oak trees behind our building) behind the building, I noticed stems in the rain garden where swamp milkweed should have been. On inspection, I found 5 fifth instar larvae finishing the last of the swamp milkweed leaves. That's not too surprising here at the lab but last week in the country, I also found 5ths feeding on cut-over but re-sprouted common milkweed. Those larvae would probably become adults between the 15th and 20th of Oct- well beyond the get out of town date of 4 Oct or earlier.

It is also the case that there is a good turnover among these monarchs. We are releasing tagged monarchs at this time. They join the untagged monarchs for most of a day and then disappear as if moving on. similarly, monarchs with distinctive marks are seen for a day or so and then they are gone.

Last night at 7 - almost complete dark here - I looked for clusters in the trees near the Biohouse and in our "park". The monarchs were scattered - the temperature was near 80F - and the biggest cluster I found only contained 4 individuals. Above normal to normal temperatures are expected to continue for the next 9 days.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I am seeing monarch butterflies in clumps of 2-5 fluttering south, south west.  I started seeing them about 10:15am central and watched them for about15 minutes.  They were still coming as of this writing at 10:32am central time.

We have seen more than 200 Monarchs fly past our office building this morning.  They are still coming!  So beautiful! We are on the third floor but many of them were higher.  We had to look upto see them. I spoke with some women on the 5th floor and they saw themoutside their windows as well.  We had a lot of hard, heavy rain last night.I woke up and couldn't stop thinking about the little guys, praying theywere able to find refuge.  Maybe they got far enough south.  I am certainthey knew it was coming.  They were so much fun to watch.  There wereseveral that were flying in circles around each other, very playful.

We spent a birding weekend in Cape Charles, VA (10/7 - 10/9).  Saw at least 150 monarch butterflies in the WLR and flying all over the small town.  They were strong and their color was deep and vibrant.  They were gathering nectar wherever there were flowers, especially the goldenrod.

Oct 4- only 1 Monarch seen today after several days of cold windy weather. Today has warmed up to 71'F. Observation time - 3 hours.

Oct 8 and 9th- Both days sunny and warm. High 72 each day. The long migration tail has re-emerged after a spell of cold windy weather. About 60 butterflies per hour observed for most of the day dropping down to about 30 per hour around 5:30 PM. Monarchs are flying south west towards Rondeau Provincial Park at elevation ranging form ground level up to 300 feet.
Since Sunday, our butterfly garden has been visited by dozens of Monarchs. So glad they stopped by on their journey to Mexico.

El 5 de octubre observamos a las doce del día cerca de *300* mariposas monarca alimentándose en las flores de las jarillas (Baccharissalisifolia) a la orilla del Río Bravo en la comunidad *Paso de Lajitas, Municipio Manuel Benavides, Chihuahua.

Courtesy of Correo Real

After a 5 inch rain over the week end, the Monarch's were eating on the Blue Mist. More than 100 in a small area. The temp.was 63* at noon when I took the picture. I think there will be some roost tonight. The rain washed the sap off the pecan trees which they had been feedin on,due to the lack of flowers.
On Oct 10 while commuting from Jackson to Atlantic Highlands to catch the NY ferry saw 9 monarchs all flying south.

I saw so many monarchs today!  At least a hundred, probably more but I wasn't counting, as I drove around Keller this morning. Then when I got off work there were lots more coming and going through my butterfly garden until around 5 pm.

October 11
Just watched from 10:09 to 11:08.

Most in 1 minute: 3
Total for hour: 45

If there is going to be a hard edge to the migration through this region, then it's possible I missed it or it's still early.

October 10
I sat in the front yard from 4:40 to 5:40 making a count of the flow through this neighborhood.

48 monarchs in 61 minutes.
Most in one minute: 5
First 30 min.: 35 monarchs, then tapered off to 1 a minute.78.8dF, 40% humidity
breeze from 140 degrees and monarch flight in same direction.breeze sporadic between 3-5 mph.
Monarchs moving into grove of dense trees on Southeast edge of my and neighbor's property. About half are doing lazy circles around trees: Japanese yew and bull mesquite. Some nectaring on antigonon vine, cannas, hibiscus cresanthemums.

Can't tell if this is the precursor to the migration but all are working below the canopy and just over the roofcombs of houses about 20 yards back from the crest of the bluff (between 80 and 100' above the river vega of the Rio Grande.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments:
Lots of Monarchs passing thru Hammo today. Two were tagged with # PEE 748 & PEE 481. If the tagger is on this server would be interested to know when and where they were tagged.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
We saw 39 monarchs in less than 30 minutes!  All were flying low to the ground.

I was paddling on Western Lake, and realized that Monarch Butterflies were flying over me, and my naturalist friend confirmed that they were Monarchs.  I counted 40 in an hour of paddling.  They were primarily flying single, although I saw one couple that seemed to be interacting by circling around each other.

Butterflies were everywhere! such amazing creatures: so delicate, yet determined and strong enough to withstand high winds. I have no Idea how to even begin to estimate - they were just everywhere: as I was walking up the street towards the beach I noticed a large (4 x 4 ft) purple butterfly bush that was covered with monarchs. There must have been 50 - 75 just on this one bush. Besides the bush, the monarchs were flying around too. When I stepped outside the front door,  just within five minutes I saw at least 20 butterflies. I never witnessed anything like this before. It was so spectacular!
Sitting in front yard and looked up to a massive amount of butterflies. They were beautiful and saw them flying for about 35 minutes.
In yard at least a100 or more, feast on flowers.
While doing a falcon watch today,  I counted 51 Monarchs along the beach line between 7 AM and 1 PM.
DRIVING ALONG I-30 FROM WEST FORT WORTH TO DOWNTOWN FORTWOTH I OBSERVED HUNDREDS OF MONARCHS FLYING FROM NORTH TO SOUTH CROSSING I-30. SOME WERE FLYING 4 AND 5 IN A GROUP BUT MOST WERE SOLO.

Several hundred on abundant liatris that recent rains have stimulated. 1/2 hour after sunset many remained on liatris. Some had flown to trees but were still flying around rather than settled. If they all moved to trees, it was well after dark.

Several hundred is the best I can estimate. Liatris covers at least 50 acres in varying density. One 50 x 15 foot patch had 22 monarchs at 14:45. On one of our interior "roads" at 16:00 a 900 foot transect with effective viewing width of 30 feet (done from tractor moving at constant 5 mph) counted 67, which surely missed some. That would scale to over 5000 for 60 acres, but I think the road included some of the denser patches of liatris so not entirely representative. leave it at several hundred. On the other hand liatris doesn't stop at our fence, so local area count could be much larger.
Found about 300 monarchs nectaring on frostweed under a thick canopy of pecans along the dry Medina River in Medina, Texas.
At Garner State Park and the Frio River we found about 300 nectaring on stunted (but blooming) frostweed under pecans.

Personally this has been a bad year for us in the number of butterflies we have seen. I have food and milkweed in my garden and no butterflies during the summer. I was suprised when I noticed a neighbors butterfly bush was covered on sunday. My Mom who lives close had a monarch sit on her hummingbird feeder for almost 5 minutes and drink the nector!

There have been lots of monarchs here. Sunday at the end of the day I estimated that there were 80 monarchs in the garden and around the building. That's more monarchs than I've ever seen at one time at MW.

The flow of monarchs has continued over the last three days and this afternoon some young volunteers (Kirin and Toshita) tagged 16 monarchs while chasing a much larger number out of the area. This is a remarkably late migration.

One of our lab reared monarchs tagged on the 5th was found in another Monarch Waystation over 4.7 miles to the NW yesterday. We had several days with 30 and 40 mph winds from the S, SW and SE last week so it's not too surprising that this monarch found itself further N than it's starting point. It's lucky it didn't find itself in Nebraska. We are releasing quite a few tagged monarchs, maybe some did.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

An afternoon, 3:30 PM count on my 1.4 acres produced 43 Monarchs on what I call Cow Pin Daisy, (?). Central Johnson County, between Cleburne and Alvarado.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

For the past several years I could count on monarchs visiting our yard in August, especially the milkweed and blue mistflower. By mid to late August I had fresh monarchs enclosing. Last year the number of cats on our milkweed defied accurate count. This year: nada. The first two monarchs to appear in our yard came on September 13, one a female. Though I've had several since drift in to nectar, there has been no sign of eggs or cats. Our heaviest numbers came through on October 2nd, in ones and twos every minute or two.

An interesting side note--perhaps the result of the intense heat--i have had no aphids on my milkweed that normally act as aphid magnets.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn

El *11 de Octubre del 2011,* durante recorrido de campo hacia la parte sur del poblado Kikapoo, municipio de *Melchor Múzquiz*, Coah., se detectaron *más de 100 mariposas monarca volando entre las 10:00 y las 12:00 hrs,* el día estaba medio nublado, fresco y con viento ligero, las mariposas volaban entre árboles de encino (Quercus fusiformis), nogal (Carya ilinoinensis) y sabino (Taxodium macronatum) principalmente, aunque se detectaron algunas cruzando la carretera entre Múzquiz y dicho poblado, destaca que el día anterior hubo abundante lluvia y el terreno estaba fangoso, se recorrieron sitios cercanos al nacimiento del río San Juan.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Of the hundreds here yesterday after sunset, this morning before sunrise there were almost none. Observed about 25 spread among several large live oaks. A few still hanging but most flying above trees. None on the liatris where they were feeding yesterday afternoon.

About 0730 Saw what was apparently the mating pair observed and photographed yesterday, still on the same small juniper, not yet active.

The general opinion seems to be that Monarchs don't fly at night. More accurately no one has documented that they fly at night. But some of them definitely went somewhere during the hours of darkness. The wind turned north late yesterday with a front passing. There was a full moon and clear sky last night. So if Monarchs do sometimes fly at night, these seem like good conditions. Temp yesterday at 9pm was 78F with overnight low of 60F. Obviously many insects do fly at night and at that temperature.

At 1600-1700 this afternoon counted about 30, widely spread with most feeding on liatris. None near past roost trees.

It's hard to get a good image to convey the number of monarchs spread out on Liatris Small sample of density is the best I could manage. Once during afternoon peak, One later after dark with flash.

Monarchs have been present here longer and in greater numbers than any season I have noticed in the past 10 years.Sunday over a period of about forty minutes I counted monarchs 4 times, each for one minute.  With a fairly broad and unobstructed view the range was 20 to 60 butterflys in a 60 second period.  They were still roosting all over town early  in the week, and I received several calls to check out the large numbers...sorry this report is late!Today (10/14), monarchs are still common but numbers seem much lower.
Besides the 102 counted during our 30 min recess this morning, we are observing a monarch fly by our second story window every 60 - 90 seconds! Beautiful!
Was eating lunch outside at work and observed the monarchs struggling to get up over the office building which is approximately 50 ft high.
Drove from Timberwood Park Elementary School to Timberwood Park and within about 10 minutes saw at least 15 Monarchs heading south :)
My son counted 10 Monarchs within 10 minutes at Timberwood Park Elementary School.
thousands all along the Rio Grande.

0800, 65F, no significant wind.

Made quick survey of past roosts and this year's liatris fields, never leaving truck. Counted 27, 6 flying 10-25 feet up, the rest feeding in liatris.
Observed Monarch butterflies all over town.  All day long.
Drove from Kerrville TX, south to Del Rio Texas (on the Texas/Mexico border).  Observed many Monarchs en route.  Spent the next day on Amistad lake, and observed many flying over the lake, as well.

October 18
We checked and that big group of monarchs did NOT roost on the Anacua (only about 5 on Sunday night -10/16) and not one was seen roosting on Monday (10/17).

October 17
My neighbor saw only about 5 monarchs roosting on the tree that morning at 7:30 am. I went over there at 8:15 am and I did see those 5 as well as some monarchs roosting on the Red Oak next to the Anacua (I counted about 20). I checked the Pecans nearby and did not see any on them.

I returned around 6pm and saw close to 200 feeding. They fed on the blooms until very late --it was getting dark. Many stayed on the blooms until 7 PM and one or two were still nectaring on the tree at 7:15 pm. By 7:18 pm all were off and not one roosted on the Anacau! I really searched the interior of the tree and not one was on it. I saw a few sail off - a few went to the Red Oak and a few to a Crepe Myrtle, and all the rest - who knows? There are some Pecan nearby.

October 16
On Sunday in the day, we estimated around 300 on the tree between 3-4 pm - all were nectaring. Greg shot some video. I went back at around 6 pm and there were still lots on the tree nectaring on the blooms. I had to leave at 6:45 and quite a few (around 50) were still on the tree feeding! The owner looked and said they did not see any monarchs on the tree at 7:20 PM

October 15
My neighbor called me this afternoon to go look at the monarchs on an Anacua tree (Ehretia anacua) near her house. The tree was in full bloom. This was at 2:30 PM and there were over 100 monarchs nectaring on this very large tree. They appeared as if in clusters hanging from the tree-but each butterfly was nectaring. I counted up to 110 using my binoculars. There may have been more high up in the canopy towards the interior of the tree, so this number may be a bit conservative.

15:30 wind steady south 5-10 85F. 10 on liatris. 15 inside a hardwood/juniper grove, 10 inside a separate live oak grove. Those in groves were active: easily disturbed by approach or already flying.

19:15 wind calm 75F. 10 outside grove of trees, visible against post-sunset sky. All flying strongly and straight generally in direction of sunset at 10-25 ft altitude. A couple stopped briefly on trees at same height.

Oct 14: weather is turning colder and becoming very windy. Despite weather conditions I observed 14 butterflies nectaring on purple aster during a 30 minute walk at Clearville Park (located on the north shore of Lake Erie). Later in the afternoon I observed 5 butterflies in a 10 minute time frame flying south-west along the shoreline. Today's high temp was 59F, partly sunny but very windy. See attached photo.

Oct 15: Wind gusting to 40 MPH from the SW direction, High temp is 55F. I saw one Monarch in the breeze trying to grab onto a tree branch.

I saw several monarchs from inside my house. When I went outsideI was amazed to see 25+ monarch butterflies within a 30 foot radius of one of our orange Lantana bushes that just happened tobe blooming profusely after last weeks soaking rains. I was justamazed, they were like bees buzzing. I want to track these beautiful creatures to know if and when they will be coming backthrough in the spring. I did not get pictures but next time I hope to be better prepared.

A minor front passed through 10/14pm.  Around 10:30am 10/15, I saw 7 monarchs on SW directional flight, 4 to 10 feet off the ground, in 10 minutes.To put that in perspective for my area, that is the biggest number of monarchs I've had in the 10 years that I've lived here.  Generally the fall migration is west of me.

A report from Jim Varnum's "This and That": "Monarch butterflies are coming thru the DFW Metroplex in droves.  They are stopping to nectar on Gregg's (blue) mistflower in our yard.  Ditto at Twleve Hills Nature Center in Oak Cliff.  We witnessed hundreds together at LLELA on Friday, concentrated in trees near the boardwalk.  Amazing!  Hope they can make it across parched central Texas."

I live on a gentleman's pecan orchard and wherever you walk there are Monarchs either flying or resting on tree branches. The first observations began on 10/13/2011.

October 17
They are still here. I truly believe there may be groups passing through each day. I do not know that for certain. I have a six acre pecan orchard and they seem to be throughout the 140 trees. Today is another good day. I can not begin to count how many are passing through. Question: my grandson asked me where do Monarch butterflies 'sleep' at night? I do not see them 'hanging' on tree limbs at dusk . . .

October 18
We have maintained our garden throughout the drought. We have many wildflowers in bloom, etc. I maintain two hummingbird feeders and have seen a couple butterflies sipping from the feeder! I maintain two birdbaths for my birds and I am certain that the butterflies take advantage.

Today there is a cold front passing through Texas so I expect a decrease. I have seen some this morning, however, I will give you a better report as the day progresses.

Altus and I moved our RV trailer out to our pasture in NW DeWitt County (TX) on Friday (14th) and had monarchs flying by and around us all afternoon. Saturday morning (15th) about 11, Altus and I did a ride-about thru the pasture for an hour and half and found monarchs flying by, nectaring on abundant narrow leaf gay-feather, and ovipositing on A. asperula that was all over the pasture. The A. asperula was from small sprouts to stems nine inches long, many multi-stemmed plants, up to seven blooms on a plant ... like March/April all over again! Altus checked as females visited asperula and found as many as five eggs on a stem of asperula ... larvae to small 3rd instars. There were times we had 3 and 4 monarchs flying around us. Also a few A. viridiflora to 8 inches and A. oenotheroides about 6 inches tall. We probably saw 150, mayby 200+ just flying Friday afternoon and middle of Saturday in the pasture! Altus was up earlier and said she was watching them out the picture window flying past to the S and SSW, most low, over the asperula. Picture of A. asperula, short gay-feather, vetch.

They were just fall monarchs to us. We have never been to our pasture at this time in October as we concentrate on the Coastal Flyway here on the midcoast and just never have been inland in the fall. The coastal monarchs will be coming along in about ten days ... after the 21st ... so next year we will have a decision of where to be! We may make a quick trip back to the pasture again this week to see what the number is like before things begin to happen here on the coast.
A mixed group of monarchs feeding on frostweed flowers in our back yard.

I thought the monarchs would never come!!  Starting this Saturday 10/15/11monarchs have been drifting and nectaring on butterfly bushes on Lake Greenwood, South Carolina.  They seem to take a 5 second drink and then they are on their way southwest. They fly until they reach the thermals.  Much wind so they will get a free ride for awhile.  Temps. a beautiful 78 degrees, with blue skies.
Monarchs flying all around the area today. In my backyard in a 15 minute period I saw at least 75. I also saw a lot while driving this afternoon.
Groups of 2-3 and 10 individuals seen today at midday. All heading in a southerly direction

Over the past weekend (10/15-16), my butterfly garden was full of Monarchs. Today (10/17), only 1 remains. North Texas is expecting a cool front, with low temps in the mid 30's. Are they all gone and headed to Mexico? I hope they have a safe journey!!!

Wow! Counted over 15 monarchs on the drive from Canton, GA to Athens, GA. Even more amazing was able to observe well over 100 monarchs at the State Botanical Gardens in Athens. They were nectaring on lantana and butterfly bushes.

They were absolutely monarchs. I am part of the Monarchs Across Georgia Steering committee (www.monarchsacrossga.org) and we were in fact, able to tag 15 of them and test for OE too. I seem to see Gulf Fritallaries along the coast of Georgia as they migrate to Florida.

100 is a conservative count. 16:00 south wind 84F. 75% widely distributed feeding on liatris patches and 25% perching/flying in shade of groves and individual trees. Pictures show typical liatris growing in prairie grass and difficultly of seeing monarchs down in grass. (I will upload one here and send others by email) Reddish grass is Little Bluestem.
We were camping and just kept noticing these monarch butterfly,s flying right over our campsite and then it hit me....this is their migration time!! So cool to see.
Friend driving across causeway sighted and called

Hundreds and hundreds of dead and dying monarchs on the beaches of Lake Michigan from Ludington to Manistee. They are being buried alive in the sand due to gale force winds for the last 3 days. We took no pictures. It just was a difficult event to witness. For the past 3 days we've been down on the beaches trying to relocate as many as we could to the back side of the dune, out of the wind. The worst part is that many only "look" dead in the sand. When you lift up the sand they start moving. I went down to Ludington State Park this morning and walked about 1/2 mile down the beach and only found 3 today. They were in good shape physically compared to the ones that we've been seeing. So put them in my pocket and walked them out to some beach grass away from the wind. The worst area in recent days was a remote beach called Magoon Creek Nature Area about 4 miles south of the city of Manistee city limits. We rescued as many as we could on the beach itself, carrying them up the dune. Then I realized that almost every other blade of beach grass had a monarch attached to it, totally battered, in most cases no wings, only the skeletal outlines of the wings, but still holding on for dear life. Just awful, awful stuff. Honestly, the numbers are enormous, going on for miles and miles and miles. We've so enjoyed the huge numbers of Monarchs's here in Ludington all summer. So this event is just so sad. But glad we could let someone know what was/is going on. Winds have died down temporarily for today only. Gale warnings begin again tomorrow.

Editor's Note: Stranding observation at peak on Saturday, Oct. 15th. This account was written Oct. 18 & 19, 2011.

More...]

Crossing causeway going south, 1 or 2 at a time.
Began seeing Monarch's moving across Lake Cherokee on Oct 5 and on Oct 14 were seeing groups of 3 or 4.  Probably saw 40 to 50 in two hours
Numerous Monarch butterflies on lantana in my yard.  Also several butterflies and some caterpillars on A.currasavica milkweed in yard.

15:30,  brisk south wind, gust in 20's,  87F.  //  This report date is four days later than in any previous year for sighting large numbers of monarchs.  //  Similar situation to yesterday. Widely spread rather than grouped together.  Less than 50% on liatris.  Most were sheltering, but alert, in groves or simply perched on north side (shaded, downwind side) of individual junipers.  There were probably just as many as yesterday actually here, considering strong south wind, but harder to spot.  Most seen only if they flushed on approach.

Unfortunately all were dead in the sand. It has been very, very windy here the last several days...sad to see, but I will be spending time on your site this eve, learning more about butterfly migration.

I drove to Dallas, Texas from my home in north Houston on Saturday, returning on Sunday.  About an hour north of Houston I started to notice Monarch's crossing in front of me and this continued all the way to Dallas (5 hour trip) and on the return trip the next day it was the same thing.  It was hard to tell what the density was as I was driving and could only see those that crossed in front of me.  What I did notice, was that they appeared to be heading south west as opposed to straight south but not sure if that was my perception or a fact.  I do that drive regularly and have not seen that many previously so is defintely a southerly migration.

We are on vacation in Bluffton Harbor, MI (Near Muskegon)- counted 32 dead or dying Monarchs on the shore, and that seemed excessive.  We'll go back to double-check that they're no Viceroys... Made us sad because they are so far from where they should be!

Dr. Lincoln Brower forwarded this observation from his son who drives from Christiana, TN, to Murfreesboro, TN (about 10 miles) each day.

"Last two days have been big migration days here. Driving to work yesterday. I saw 9 fresh-looking monarchs crossing the road, and today (10/17/11) about 25. All flying southwest. I haven't noticed them in such numbers before - there must be thousands passing through here now."
First time since spring that Monarchs have been seen here in large numbers

Migration is not done yet, a late wave started coming through after the days of rain last week, tagged a dozen last Wed evening. This afternoon tagged 45 and saw another couple dozen. Goldenrod is spent, Baccharus is by far the chief nectar source with Bidens and aster also used. The wind had them hunkering lower that normal on the Baccharus and in thicker areas out of swing of the net. I had to penetrate the thickets and literally hand caught about 15 timing my grab with the wind bending the boughs down to me. For baccharus that had multiple monarchs this actually helped me get more, since a swing of the net usually scares any remaining monarchs away.

Three times I caught "doubles" in my net, not uncommon while nectaring, but I caught a pair in circling flight which is tougher to do! There were a few tattered Viceroys out there and they joined in the chases too anytime a monarch went by. I still don't understand the advantage of chasing off a passing monarch from your nectar but many do.

My batting average was pretty good today with about 95% catch rate on nectaring monarchs and 40% on in flight. Always get a few bees and flies in the net as bycatch, but a chinese mantid today made me wonder if it was targeting the monarch! No bees or mantids were harmed in the netting of monarchs....in fact I have never killed or even damaged any critter while netting/tagging, the Monarch is one tough bug.

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

They took their sweet time getting here: After the major push of Monarchs apparently went through W Texas and the western Hill Country, only today did I finally see substantial numbers of Monarchs moving and nectaring in the I-35/Balcones Escarpment corridor.

I spent a long day birding in western Bell County and adjacent parts of Burnet and Lampasas Cos. This morning at Stillhouse Hollow Reservoir west of Belton, many Monarchs got up and started moving about 10 a.m. Many of these Monarchs undoubtedly came into the area on the NE winds the previous day but they did not make it far as Austin as of yesterday evening. (I was on my roof watching in the late afternoon and saw only 3 or 4.)

Today's numbers were gratifying but not massive. I probably saw 1000 Monarchs today in an 11-hour field day. The early morning was calm, but by about 10 a.m., winds at Stillhouse Hollow Lake picked up strong out of the SE for a time. Monarchs were struggling to move SW in those headwinds or crosswinds. After mid-morning, just about anywhere I was in the Belton-Temple-Stillhouse Hollow area, I would see 2 to 10 passing per minute at any location. Any scan of the sky with binoculars would detect 10 to 20 in the air. By mid-afternoon, winds were actually calming a bit and most Monarchs in the air were powering S or SW with little difficulty.

Nectar resources are limited in the region. There was a smattering of Liatris blooming in upland areas of western Bell and Lampasas County but I did not see Monarchs visiting that. The major resources were primarily only in the immediate floodplain of the Lampasas River and the margins of Stillhouse Hollow Lake. These included patches of Marsh Fleabane (Pluchea purpurascens) which have grown on the exposed mudflats and the male False Willows (Depression Weed; Baccharisneglecta) which are patchy but fairly numerous along the lake margins and river banks.

By late afternoon, numbers of Monarchs were gathering to roost in willow groves along the Lampasas River and also in the big oak groves in Lampasas (City) at Hancock Park.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

weather today was sunny & very strong NW winds 15 to 25 mph  gusts.A cool front passed through & it only got up in the 60's today. I was out in my garden around 2pm, the monarchs were coming through the woods & from the back of our pasture,which still has some goldenrod blooming. We have 5 acres, behind us is farmland & we're surrounded by woods & live on a lake.  Most monarchs just keep going but around 10 or so stayed until the evening nectaring heavy. They really were going for the zinnias,tropical milkweed is still blooming as well. I've never seen so many monarchs in such a short time, really amazing experience. I was only able to get a shot of a couple on my zinnias.

Altus and I started out early this morning seeing monarchs on the peninsula at the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway.  We had to make a trip to Victoria and saw monarchs all day.  When we got home at 3:30 there was a message: "Altus, the monarchs have returned to Port Lavaca!" from a family friend.  Back at the peninsula there was a steady stream of monarchs coming out of the ENE.  I parked next to the water's edge, looking to the NE, and watched over the steering wheel as they came off the mud flats and passed over the two lanes of white top in front of me at about two feet for as long as I could stay.  I leaned back against the headrest, checked the clock to time, and watched intently down the two lanes of the old causeway road.  The monarchs came by at about two feet into the strong NW wind and right my door to the WSW ... one a minute, sometimes two, three, and four a minute ... but steady ... averaging just over 90 an hour.  I watched over 200 pass me plus saw a dozen  nectaring on seaside goldenrod and another dozen on short sunflowers ... clusters tomorrow morning on the saltcedars?    Another cold front early next week and might see this many in 30 minutes ... they are stuck between here and Cape May!

For the past few days, I have been sighting Monarchs on their way through, maybe 5 an hour. Since we are under a severe drought here in Central Texas, it was nice to find these islands of daisies to help fuel the Monarchs on their way through.

A cold front moved into the Bryan-College Station area, Brazos County, Texas, mid-day on Thursday, Oct. 27, 2011. We could see the dark clouds many miles to the north a couple hours before it reached us. Out in front were hundreds of Monarchs, moving southwesterly. During one hour period I counted at least 75 individuals, maybe twice that number, at various heights. Once the front arrived, I did not see any more of the flying Monarchs; they apparently had moved on with the front. However, the number of Monarchs feeding in our yard, especially on a large blooming crucita (Eupatorium odoratum), increased from six to eight to twelve to fifteen. That number remained about the same, with some moving out and others moving in, until just before dark. Only one remained at dark. None were seen the next day and today (10/29).

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

Almost a week and a half ago I reported but had some problem in getting my post to post. Sorry I am so late in getting back.At Yzoo NWR in the Swan Lake Greentree Resevoir which is dry at this time the palce is loaded with Bidens and I estimate seeing 400 to 700 of them all feeding on the Bidens. When this place floods this winter the Bidens is also a great nutrition for Water Fowl.Yazz is about five miles east of the Mississippi river flood plain and in the middle of the Mississippi Delta. the flood plain is almost intact except for some places where urbanization is dominant but the Ohio Basin and Mississippi river Basin is still the funnel for most migratory species. They do run into a lot of hardship trying to make it osuth through this corridor.I was in Desota NF last week end for three days. Near Glen's Pond two days and in Buttecup flats one morning. Glen's is home of the last known breeding site of the Rana Capito Servosa and Buttercup Flats is home of several hundred acres of pitcher plant bog and it is georgeous. I suspect because this locatiosn is not near a north south laying river of any regional magnitude and Glen's Pod is a coastal plains mostly upland longleaf pine ecology not many Monarchs pass through and Buttercup flats does not have the forage the Monarchs really like. I only saw a few in these places.Did see a few Gulf Fritillary and Buckeye, Checkered Skippers, some spreadwings and some small moths, hardly not mosquitoes, a few wasp and bees on flowers, no reptiles and no amphibiams. The early frozen precipition and cold snap in the north east proably whipped many migratory species into flying south or not making it due to hardship and really squshed the biomass: insects, plants, vertebrates and

A brief, strong migration that dies quickly? Night time temperatures again dropped to 50 F last night. Must return to Toronto briefly to take care of other business....and get more tags!

August 28
I arrived later than I had anticipated from Toronto, and headed out for my favorite clover field east of Cobourg. On the trip down from Toronto, Monarchs were seen along the Hwy. 401 expressway soaring westward. On arrival at this field about 1 pm, I noticed that the Monarchs were particularly fidgety and difficult to capture.

However, in about 3 hours, I had collected 170 Monarchs. The first 35 were carefully captured with a clean net and placed in clean envelopes for O.E. testing.

A couple of noticeable changes: these Monarchs seem to prefer the patches of red clover with the round flower heads vs. the smaller blue clover. Joe-Pye weed was also popular. As well, I was capturing many more beautiful large females, with thick dark veins.

We were promised rain last night, and some fell, but oh so little. Getting dry again. Next few days expected to be sunny with a few clouds. Night time low of 50 F tonight.

August 29
Dropped into my favorite field about 11 am (a field I have incorrectly called clover....it is alfalfa! with some red clover). There appeared to be very little activity in spite of the fact that outside of this area, Monarchs were streaming westward. After returning home to test 30 monarchs for the O.E. study, I returned at 2 pm to find Monarchs soaring on the westerly winds over the highway, fields, trees and homes. In two and a half hours, I had another 170 to tag. Feeding actively on alfalfa and clover, but sometimes challenging to capture.

August 30
I took a trip across Cobourg this morning and found monarchs fighting a strong westerly wind. Soaring high over town streets. Headed to my favorite ALFALFA fields (with some clover) and went to an area where a new structure called a "wind break" of trees had been planted along the road a long time ago - south to north. As I suspected, this windbreak provided shelter and a rest on alfalfa for the monarchs and they were really numerous here. After two hours and about 120 monarchs, I left.

Sadly, we are in another dry period and I am suddenly finding new eggs. Small milkweeds in fields are drying up. Even larger stalks drying up and turning tough. Will be hard for teachers to find caterpillars.
One adult flying high headed Southwest..
Saw the monarchs on the beach at Woodlawn Beach State Park.  Every 5' or 6' was a monarch sitting in the sand or playing with other monarchs.
Tagged 50 monarchs the last couple days!  Steady stream!  I have an adult emerging tomorrow!

Yesterday (Aug. 26) myself, Peter M and Duncan H explored a section ofhydro line corridor at the southern tip of Algonquin Park.Butterfly Highlights Included:

1000+++ Monarchs

Forwarded by Don Davis

The monarchs were on my meadow blazing star in my front yard garden and i did count them all at once. i counted them after i got home from school but they usually would hang around all day from 11am to 5pm.

These beautiful flying jewels are everywhere!  The butterfly bushes are covered and it's a joy to watch!  There are several swallowtails, painted ladies, viceroys and clouded sulphurs, too ... what a gift!
All seemed to be flying south westerly. Singles, doubles and trlples, over the long island sound and huntington harbor.
The migration is in full swing.  Each day, for the last three we are seeing more Monarch's.  The all look to be in good shape.  Big in size and bright orange in color.
Woke up in the morning and saw close to two hundred monarchs on our butterfly bushes.
We were at Pine POint beach from 8 AM - 2PM on sept 1, 2012. We counted 43 butterflies heading south , and most were flying singly.
25 to 30 monarchs flying south west over south lake Huron 1 mile offshore between 12:00 and 14:00 hours
Hundreds of monarchs in flight. Not a swarm but a steady flow.

A friend whose home is on the shore of Lake Erie (at Bay Village/Rocky River border, west of Cleveland) counted around 90 monarchs coming in off the lake, probably around 9:30-10 AM. I had about a dozen in my butterfly bushes and soaring around my yard even before the sun hit it, and saw a few in the nearby tree. I also counted at least 20 in a period of 15 min, flying high and heading west. Around noon, I checked Bradstreet pier and Edgewater park, but did not see any significant activity. My neighbors also have had increased activity at their gardens, probably today being peak so far.

Thursday, August 30th was another wonderful butterfly day at Point Lepreau. Wednesday’s strong westerly winds made for ideal conditions to blow Monarch butterflies to the coast, I decided to pack up my nets and tags and make an afternoon visit to the Point in search of Monarchs to tag.

I had made three previous trips to Point Lepreau and tagged a total of 115 at that location, and Jean and I tagged 20 more at Southwest Head on Grand Manan early this week. So I went down yesterday (8/30) with 40 tags remaining and the hope that I might use the rest of them up.

When I arrived at the tip of the Point the stands of goldenrod and aster were covered with large orange, black and white butterflies. There were dozens of MONARCHS nectaring in areas that were sheltered from the stiff southwest wind. And with them were many AMERICAN LADIES and RED ADMIRALS along with a few CABBAGE WHITES, COMMON SULPHURS and COMMON WOOD NYMPHS.

Within an hour I easily netted the 40 Monarchs I needed to complete my summer’s tagging effort and I could almost certainly have tagged two or three times that number with no problem. There seemed to be a steady trickle of new Monarchs arriving from further up the coast and all were very intent on feeding once they arrived at the several hectares of blooms at the Point.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

180 Monarchs Counted - Cranberry Marsh Hawk Watch, Whitby, Ontario

Monarch migration: 180 in the first 2 hours and then the flight got very high.

Courtesy of Don Davis

There were 55 Monarch butterflies (all fairly fresh) nectaring on Blazing Stars at Wildflower Farms just west of Orillia this afternoon.

Today (Sunday) at the Rosetta McClain Gardens Raptor Watch in Toronto the sky was absolutely filled with Monarchs heading westward along the lakeshore. Low to extremely high, they were everywhere!!! Surprisingly, not huge number's in the park around the flowers.

September 3
Dropped into Cranberry Marsh early this afternoon to see what the monarch situation was like. Rien! Nada!....well almost. Beautiful huge field of goldenrod, but only about 20 to capture and tag during the hour I was there, and that meant slugging it through tall goldenrod. Easterly winds. The hawk watch had only counted 18 monarchs by 1:00 pm. Actually it was quite entertaining and interesting to be at this great location, watching from the platform as migrating raptors and other birds head west.

Many Monarchs fluttering about the various buddleia bushes in my garden -can be seen throughout the day.  Really constant visitors.

There were many (50?) Monarchs today nectaring in the prairie on the bluff above Lake Michigan at the Schlitz Audubon Nature Center today. Unfortunately, below on the beach, were about as many dead butterflies washed up on the shore. What happened? We were guessing that they may have been attempting to cross the lake, or got caught in last night's storm.

The storm was from 2am-3am with a 7 mph SW wind. The winds were from the NW before the storm at 6-12 mph (midnight to 2am)

2 - 3000 Monarchs Reported in Late August in South Algonquin Park

Three of my colleagues at Algonquin sighted 2-3000 Monarchs in the park's southern panhandle on August 26th.

Approx 100 plus monarchs feeding off thoroughwort plants

Hundreds of monarchs were arriving at Marshall Point lighthouse during the afternoon.  The remenants of storm Isack had the wind blowing NW at 20-30 kts.  Butterflies were flying against this and upon making landfall at the lighthouse filled the trees and shrubs as they rested after their flight from the Maritimes and offshore islands of Maine.  Fantastic sight to watch.

August 25th counted 12 monarchs in my front - have liatris aspera (blazing star) in bloom.  Also milkweeds.  Now at 9/5/12, there are 3 or 4 monarchs.  We just cooled off and the liatris is drying up.

During the four hours I was out at the South Shore of Robert Moses Beach I spotted over 300 monarchs. The day was sunny about 82 degrees and a light northeast wind. The monarchs were accompanied by many dragonflies and painted lady butterflies. Although there was limited food in the immediate area, within a three - five mile radius there was plentiful golden rod and other food sources. This was the earliest I have witnessed such a large amount of monarchs, they appeared to be traveling the migration path of their predecessors. Due to the NE wind, the biting flies were out and I could not locate where they were roosting. The monarchs looked very healthy.

30 monarchs were First observed flying in Cleveland on Labor Day the 3rd at the St.Rocco Festival. And since haveobserved 3 - 4  were flying in Brooklyn on the 6th.  The suburb of Brooklyn is about 10 miles fromSt. Rocco.

This is a resubmission of a "single adult" category sighting that I just made -- incorrectly.  Obviously, this should properly be categorized as "peak migration."Field of red clover on N. Williston Rd., opp. Deer Run Cemetery.The monarchs were coming faster than I could count...  Dizzying, Amazing!  Hooray!
Second day of viewing, still 100 plus on site - have heard that this batch might have been blown off course on their way south. They really love the thoroughwort plants!!

Several acres planted to red clover, now in profuse bloom, with Monarchs streaming here to feed.  In just half an hour I counted 55 -- but as in all kinds of peak migrations, it is impossible to count every individual.  Probably thousands of Monarchs will feed on this several acres of clover today. Photos do not do the situation justice, as the butterflies are concealed below the surface of the cloverfield as they feed...[Sorry, computer glitch is preventing me from sharing photos -- will try to fix....]
Nectaring butterflies are plentiful here in the Hudson Valley. Today I counted 41 Monarch Butterflies on our Butterfly Bushes over 20 minutes.  Here are some pictures:

Many monarchs were seen nectaring in a field with clover.  Estimated numbers were 30.  One larva in the 4th instar was seen on a milkweed plant.  along with the clover were large patches of milkweed.  This was a mowed hayfield with young milkweed growing.  Temperature 85.  Sunny

After days of no monarch activity at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, the weather had cooled down, and monarchs were on the move. During a late-morning visit to the refuge, 71 monarchs were counted. They were riding a brisk northwest wind, and nectaring on sawtooth sunflowers in the north part of the refuge. The temperature was in the high 60s--down considerably from previous days.What a delightful sight!

A dozen monarchs appeared in our garden this afternoon quite suddenly at about 4 pm. We've had only a single monarch each day, so this was a clear spike in migration. We planned to watch them as evening fell in hopes of finding where they'd roost. But we took our eyes off them from about 5-6 pm--and then they were gone. Temperatures fell to about 65 degrees as soon as the sun went behind the hill, so they must have moved as they sensed that change. We hope today will be another big day so we can watch where they go as evening falls.

Monarch activity continued today at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, with 228 monarchs being observed over two hours in two different areas. The temperature was in the low 60s, and the wind was from the northwest on this bright sunny day. Sawtooth sunflowers were the main source of nectar for the monarchs.
75 Monarchs moved uninterrupted (no lighting on plants) cliff edge at Hawk Cliff from 1:15-1:45.

Another sunny day and temperatures in the 50s provided a nice setting for monarch butterflies at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge in the morning. During 2 1/2 hours of observations, 172 monarchs were counted flying across the prairie and nectaring primarily on sunflowers. As a means of comparison, 104 monarchs were seen at Neal Smith on this day in 2011 and 1744 were observed during a very heavy migration in the fall of 2010. The drought this year dried up some areas of a favorite monarch stopping point--the tickseed sunflowers.
My second grade class sighted about 15 monarchs flying amongst the butterfly bushes at the front of our school.
We were riding up the coast of New Hampshire and saw about 100 monarchs flying along the road sides of the highway.
Monarch butterflies are streaming by today in the hundreds on the northeast breeze.  They are passing by 10-20 feet above ground level.

We went on a camping trip this weekend to Lake Rathbun.  We were walking along the lake at the beach and discovered a huge area with yellow wildflowers.  There were hundreds (too many to count) monarch butterflies fluttering from flower to flower and drinking nectar.  They were very big and healthy looking!  We stayed for about 20 minutes and got some nice pictures of them!

Lighthouse Point Hawk Watch

Most of yesterday's dragonflies have left, but there are still hundreds of Monarchs and other Leps, about.

Morning rain gave way to mostly cloudy skies, northerly wind and drier air. A good flight of Manarchs. I counted 47 in an hour and a half.

Saw scores of monarchs at the south end of Town Line Road, mostly within 100 yards of the beach, all flying WSW (parallel to the coast).  I'd estimate 10 - 20 feet in the air.  Only a few over the beach itself, most over the dunes and a bit inland.

Monarch migration report, 9-10-12.A report from friends:We counted 20 Monarch's heading south between 7:00 pm and 7:30 pm.  and between 7:30pm and 7:40pm, we counted 16.  This observation was done about 15 miles south of South Haven, Michigan, on the shore of Lake Michigan.   The sky was clear, winds were light from the west.Dan KamermanKay Maxey
Watched them for a few hours heading West on the shore of Lake Ontario...I was in Webster Park for the evening.
Since 10:00AM (5 hours ago) I have been watching the Monarch butterflies migrating.
Witnessed hours of Monarch's heading west along Lake Ontario shoreline.
I spotted an unuasual event on Dune Road in Hampton Bays. Over 100 Monarch butterflies were resting on the beach.  I have never seen this happen here in Hampton Bays, NY.
I was on a bike ride and saw so many butterflies that I came back and googled and it seems it's the time of year for migration.

My co-worker and I were working on a ski tower at the top of Tussey mountain when I noticed quite a few Monarchs flying around.  This was at around 10 am.  The top of the ski hill is essentially open ground like an alpine meadow giving us a great view toward the northeast.  The Monarchs were flying from the northeast toward the southwest.  They continued to fly past us all day in a steady stream in loose groups of up to twenty or so.  Literally hundreds of Monarchs passed by, over and around us through the course of the day.  I found myself many times pausing to watch the procession!  It was one of the loveliest things I've ever been privileged to see.  My only regret was not being able to take a picture or video of this enchanting event.

Saw at least 15 monarchs migrating towards the Atlantic from Beavertail State Park this afternoon within 10 minutes' time, between 12:10 and 12:20 p.m.  They tend to show up here often during migration.  They were doing the migration dance (flutter-float-flutter).

On the 11th anniversary of the 9/11 tragedy, 21 monarchs were counted in the fields of Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge in the late morning. On the previous day, Sept. 10, the count was 23 in one-half hour of observations. The comparative elements of monarch movement from year to year are one part of understanding the overall population. In the fall of 2010 on Sept. 11, we witnessed the largest single-day numbers ever at Neal Smith--3085 monarchs, truly a sight to behold.

There was a nice movement of Monarchs through Cape May Monday afternoon through Tuesday afternoon this week. The Monarch Monitoring Project recorded 150 Monarchs per hour on the 3:00 census Monday and over 420 Monarchs per houron the noon census Tuesday (9/11) (that was the peak of the flight). There were quite a few Monarchs nectaring in the butterfly gardens on Cape May Point. A mystical 911.

There were a couple of small roosts seen at Cape May Point State Park by a local birder on Tuesday morning and a roost of over 100 Monarchs seen by Pat Sutton (noted on her website) on Monday evening at East Point Lighthouse, Heislerville, NJ.

I just wanted to let you know that the MMP has also been recording Cloudless Sulphur numbers. These southern emigrants, and others, have been seen in unusually high numbers this year. They may eventually become a barometer of climate change...

I'm a little late reporting this, but on this past Sunday, September 9, I think I witnessed the monarchs migrating twice! In our back field I noticed that there were many more monarchs than usual, and as I stood counting them I became aware that more were flying over my head in a southwest direction. I counted at least a dozen, most didn't stop to nectar but just kept on flying high above my head. Later in the afternoon my husband and I went to Bristol Harbor, a restaurant that overlooks Canandaigua Lake, one of the fingerlakes of NY. On the terrace I became aware of a steady flow of monarchs all heading in a southwesterly direction. I walked outside and counted about four a minute for at least fifteen minutes. Soon I was joined by others who were witnessing the butterflies as well. I pointed them out to one woman and she said yes...they're on their way to Mexico....so I was not alone in my awareness of the event. What a perfect day!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Little Round Top Migration Observatory Hawk Watch

The king of the day was the Monarch Butterfly, migrating in such vastnumbers that it was often difficult to distinguish a distant potentialRaptor from a Monarch at first glance, and more than once I was pulled offa bird thinking there was another, only for it to quickly show itself forwhat it was. I counted 540 in the first few hours... and the density ofoccurrence was such that I estimate well over a thousand went by the site.
Our friend in Watertown, CT had about 40 monarch’s on a Seven Son’s (Heptacotium) plant.  No roost reported.
Windy day & Monarchs were working hard in migratory flight.
Saw dozens of monarchs while driving along the beach road (Ocean Avenue)

A dozen monarchs were feeding hungrily all day today on the red clover in the meadow. Tonight I watched at least a dozen monarchs as they settled in for the night. Each flew around the treetops singly and seemed to take forever to select a place to land. Ultimately a little after sunset a group of 10 were close together toward the tip of a branch of the black walnut tree, but they were not tightly clustered. They did not seem to flash their wings to attract nearby butterflies; they only flashed when a new monarch began to land. It looked as if the monarch already at rest was showing its wingspan to claim the necessary space. (I'm not reporting this as a roost because I haven't been at this location for a week, so can't claim to know when monarchs roosted here first.)

We took a slow cruise in our boat and observed 60 adults within 45 minutes all flying in a south-westerly direction. All were sighted over open water. The time was between 11:00 am - 11:45 am, bery light wind, clear sky around 70 degrees air temperature.  The wind came up about an hour later and we didn't see as many, just about 10 more within 20 minutes. it was fun seeing them flitting and soaring.
We are seeing many migrating butterflies in the fields and roads, and flying high above.  Just about any time you look around outside you see a monarch!
I was just leaving the parking lot and saw 4 monarchs one after another flying overhead.
school: Lake iowa nature center board member

comments: Noticed about 30 monarchs (give or take) fluttering in our front and back yards for a couple of hours Sunday evening. They would light in the trees, then flutter about some more. Never did see all of them settle in, but I'm sure they did, somewhere close-by. Saw several early the next morning.
I was again working at the top of Tussey mountain (approximate elevation 1800 ft.) today as the Monarchs started to fly by.  It was 80 degrees and sunny with a light swirling breeze much of the day.

DETAILS: http://blog.pennlive.com/wildaboutpa/2012/09/monarch_butterflies_set_record.htmlINFO RE;  Hawk Mountain in PA (http://www.hawkmountain.org/) So exciting, I thought: wow, there's a lot of butterflies everywhere.  I climbed up to their North Lookout coincidentally, and it was like being in a Disney animation.  One of those once-in-a-lifetime things.  In Dauphin County where I live (Harrisburg, capitol of PA) the weekend prior a wildlife docent at a park was lamenting the poor showing of Monarchs this year.  Goes to show ya!  Hawk Mountain is sponsoring a Monarch event this weekend (9/15/2012) --it'll be exciting!
Tagging for Monarch Watch in a two acre alfalfa field outside of the school.
During a one-hour visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge in the late morning, 92 monarchs were observed. They were nectaring primarily on sunflowers.
Day two of monarch tagging during science class.  Successfully tagged 81 monarchs, recapturing 2 previously tagged monarchs.  Approximately 15 - 30 additional monarchs sighted but not captured.
Monarch Tagging event at Kuehn Conservation Area. Took about 10 of us an hour and a half to catch and tag them. They were mostly nectaring on pitcher sage.

We were at the Marshland Walkway in the Point Pelee National Park and watched over 100 Monarchs fly over our heads, one at a time, heading toward the point (North to South).  It was partly cloudy, about 75 degrees, and about 3-4pm.  They did not stop seemed to be moving with a mission!  Later that evening (7-8pm) we observed about 30 Monarchs fluttering around the point.Photo is one of the many we saw that day!

At Hawk Mountain Sanctuary (North Lookout) in Kempton, PA... 10 September, 2012:

Single day count: 2,806 monarchs!
Previous one day record: 883 on 4 September, 2012
Prior to this year the single day record was 815 on 4 September, 1997.
The highest monarch season total at Hawk Mountain was 5,705 in 1997.
The lowest monarch season total at Hawk Mountain was 115 in 2002.
The average monarch season total at Hawk Mountain: 1,804 (SD: 1505.796)
This one day count is greater than 76% of the SEASON totals at Hawk Mountain.

Pretty impressive numbers. On 9 September, in a clover field at the base of Hawk Mountain in New Ringgold, PA... I netted 25 monarchs in just less than 45 minutes -- 42 monarchs by the end of 2 hours (with a broken foot I might add!). It's been a good flight year here in Schuylkill County, PA.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

On 9 September, in a clover field at the base of Hawk Mountain in New Ringgold, PA... I netted 25 monarchs in just less than 45 minutes -- 42 monarchs by the end of 2 hours (with a broken foot I might add!). It's been a good flight year here in Schuylkill County, PA.

The monarchs are still coming to my Seven Son Tree as soon as they warm up from the cold nights we've been having in mid-New Hampshire.  I've also seen them flitting through the traffic downtown in our small New England college town.  More than many of us can remember ever.  People area noticing.  Though nothing like the pictures you have of those clustered along the shore.

Noted quite a few monarchs coming into Cape May today. On the beach there were fatalities.  I managed to remove two from the water but 3 others were washed away from shore. We were only on the beach for about an hour. All around town, as Louise noted, we saw an abundance of sulfurs. Some buckeyes and red admirals came in with the monarchs. Plenty of dragonflies too. Painted ladies are still around in large numbers.
