Count is approximate-after the beach (1 hr saw 90 monarchs + others) we hiked through the point blue trail and later walked through the city as a stream were still coming in.Most of the monarchs appeared in good shape.

Today I counted two dozen monarchs during a 10 minute walk in a 5 acre field. Both of the past two days I counted one dozen monarchs during the same walk and thought that was the peak. However, with another day of strong south winds the monarchs seem to be stacking up. It was a joy to walk through the field with so many monarchs topping the red clovers. They'd take wing as I approached, get caught by the and briefly sail backwards. Then fly up and away and off toward a distant clover.
Observed 24 high-flying north to south and six low-flying monarchs from 1:30 PM to 2:30 PM. Partly cloudy, 71Â°. Winds east north east at 14 mph.
Probably 50+ butterflies spotted throughout the day. All were flying high, heading south. Not feeding (goldenrod not in bloom yet), just flying.

Today at the top of Tussey mountain (elevation 1800 ft) was sunny, 80 degrees with a slight swirling breeze.  The Monarchs started flying by at 9:30 am and continued in one's and two's until 4:00 pm.  I counted 170 but that was a smaller number than actually passed by as I was also working...  Many stopped to feed on the thistle as those who passed before them had done.

After a rainy day on Sept. 13, a visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge turned up 15 monarchs amid the sunflowers today. The day was mild and partly cloudy with a slight wind from the southwest.
Observe 32 low-flying monarchs. Directional flying north to south. None of which stopped to nectar. Cloudy, 67°. Winds east north east at 8 mph.

This observation was my backyard, 200 feet from Long Island Sound on a peninsula 1200' wide enclosing Stony Brook Harbor.  However, this migration has continued since first noticing while sitting on the beach, Labor Day, Sept 2, watching pairs and singles flutter in from across the sound at about 2- 5 every 5 minutes heading south/southwest.  I also notice they are at peak in the am when sunny thru sunny early pm.  I live on Long Island north shore and watch significant amounts of Monarchs cross from Connecticut on to my beach, cross my peninsula, (and backyard) then cross Stony Brook harbor all heading south/southwest.

Thousands of butterflies located at the southern end of Jamestown at Beavertail State Park. It appeared that they were pairing up for mating. The entire park was engulfed with them. They were flying east to west and I also saw many of them in Narragansett Bay in the area of Narragansett beach also flying east - west. I have never seen this amount of monarchs. The park was filled with people watching the event.

I am not sure if I reported the time correctly.  We saw the migration for about 2hours duration but is occurred at 6PM.  I converted the time into military time above.  They flew right over my house.  Unfortunately there is one dead on my porch.

At least 25 of 38 monarchs noted today during a morning visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge were found flying in and out of oak trees in the savanna area. In past years, the oak trees on a hillside adjoining the prairie have harbored roosts of monarchs for overnight stays. Today the monarchs were nectaring on goldenrod and other wildflowers in the area. The day was sunny with a mild breeze from the south.

Along South Shoreline land outcropping areas of Staten Island, are fields on protected hills with trail that extends to waterline, in Staten Island.  I have had some of my college students that live in area checking for telltale increase in Mon. numbers.  Slow increase of number of flying pairs seen here since 2nd. week of August.  Informed that student counted almost 60 in 2 hrs., on 9/14. Spent 3 hrs. on 9/16 by milkweed concentrations and only spotted approx. 32-40. Temp. dropping to avg. 66-76 F from last week's 78-88 F, Thanks.

Walking along the ocean at 8:30 a.m. in Kennebunkport, Maine. Observed 'many' but didn't count (approx. 30 to 40) perhaps more flying with a headwind at them. It seemed to throw them off and they would gravitate to be closer to buildings and roofs as they made their way south. A few stopped on flowers, but most were just trying to make their way through the wind.

I had to look up the wind direction, and think I am right in saying it was south easterly. Those beautiful little creatures were flying south and had to deal with that steady south easterly winds. I am sorry I can't tell you how strong the winds were, but they were taking it in stride and moving forward down the coast.
We observed thousands of monarch butterflies at Ft. Foster, an oceanside town park in Kittery Point, Maine. It was like being a dream sequence,nature at it's most amazing!
Along the Hampton Beach coastline, hundreds of Monarch Butterflies swirling in the air.  Beautiful fall-ish day.  Beautiful sight to see all the Monarchs.

Here's one photo from yesterday, 9/11, taken by Clay Sutton ... EVERY Tall Sunflower along the trails at the Cape May Point State Park was covered with nectaring Monarchs.

It was hard to count. They were everywhere. We estimated that we saw about 1,000 between 10 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. while walking the Red Trail and the Yellow Trail at the Cape May Point State Park ... some floated by, migrating, while others nectared heavily on the Tall Sunflower, Boneset, and Mistflower growing along the park trails. Bewitching and magical.

We spent the day at Island Beach State Park. We started seeing a few Monarchs flying over the road as we drove to our spot. While we were on the beach for 4-5 hours we would see Monarchs come flittering by every few minutes. Most were single, but a few flew together in pairs. I got a picture of one as he flew by, but it's out of focus.
Absolutely Amazing!!!

A weather front went through earlier today with a gusty wind switching to the North. Temp 75F. When the sun came out around 3:00 PM there were thousands of butterflies flying at twice tree-top level with many much higher. Monarchs could be spotted far up in the sky with binoculars.  They were all gliding along the lake shore in a SW direction toward Pt Pelee where they cross Lake Erie to Ohio. I  counted 30 per minute flying overhead which continued for three hours (6:30 PM). The weather conditions were perfect because the north wind aids their flight as well as funnels them along the lake on their journey to Pt Pelee, Canada's most southerly location.

Favourable wind conditions today to see lots of Monarchs funneling along the lake . Approximately 15 per minute moving overhead. This flow was consistent all day from 10:30 AM until dusk. I estimate that several thousand Monarchs moved through Clearville Park today on their journey to Pt Pelee where they cross Lake Erie to the USA.

Editor's Note: We estimated the daily count based on the observer's description as follows: Fifteen monarchs per minute would be about 900 per hour. Assuming the flight occurred consistently for 7 hours, the 6,300 total was reached.
Sitting on the beach watching packs of 3-5 monarchs flying along the coast line in a stead flow during early evening

Further drop in Temp at Staten Island migration observation location by coastal hills/milkweed fields on South Shore of Staten Island.  Three of my college students that agreed tospot for me, only saw in the 2-3 hrs. they were at site:7, 14, 10 Mon. Bfs.  I went out this mornng for two hrs., &only saw 12.  It appears that our core concentrations (whichwere smaller when spotted than last year) have mostly movedon.  Thanks.

At Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge during the late morning, monarchs were observed nectaring on sunflowers in several areas of the refuge. The day was partly cloudy with a temperature in the 50s and a light wind.

Last several days have been clear, sunny, and warm in the afternoon. Seems to be a fairly constant stream of monarchs arriving from the north, feeding along the line of butterfly bushes , then leaving toward the southwest. In addition to Buddlea we have goldenrod, snakeroot,black eyed susans, and several varieties of sedum in bloom. Lots of butterflies, in addition to monarchs, and other pollinators arefeasting in the flowers.
Observed 19 low-flying monarchs, with a north to south direction. Observation time 9:45 AM to 10:45 AM. 71°. Mostly cloudy with calm winds.
Annual event. Hundreds of Monarchs in 2 trees covered with milk weed type vine.I wish I had a better camera. This photo was taken with a cell phone.

Observed 18 high flying monarchs. Directional flight north to south. And five low flying monarchs, two of which stopped to nectar on my butterfly bush. Observation time 12:15 PM to 1:15 PM. Partly cloudy 77° wind west south west at 3 mph.

Sixteen monarchs were spotted 1 at a time traveling just over us as we sailed out of Mattapoisett Harbor, Mattapoisett, MA. About every half minute or less another butterfly would go right over us.

The best we can determine the butterflies were heading from the northeast to the southwest.  We were making forward motion at about 5.5 kts.

Overall there was a constant NW wind when we saw them. So, it seemed they were flying across the wind, not into nor along with. We were sailing in the direction the butterflies were flying, called a broad reach, which is a comfortable sail with good progress! How interesting!

   I must say we are quite wind-conscious when sailing so am quite sure about the direction.  I looked at local records in the area and there was variation but that accounts for the 'shifty'.

This morning while sitting in my car at a red light I saw a monarch butterfly. Further up the street I saw a couple more. Then several more. In the space of about 5 blocks I must have seen 12 butterflies. I have never seen butterflies in Everett before never mind Monarchs! They were heading south right for Boston! So I had to let some one know. I'm going to look for more!
Wow, 68 high flying monarchs in a half hour. From 4:20 PM to 4:50 PM. 77° mostly cloudy wind Northwest at 9 mph. The picture is three separate pictures combined.
Driving from Jackson up to Marlboro in NJ counted 38 monarchs flying from NE direction to SW.

Observed around 8:00-10:00 am My husband was running a half-marathon and it almost felt like there were as many monarchs as there were runners! It was amazing! Specifically we were at Misquamicut Beach in Westerly RI.

We drove down the day before, 9/15 to pick up his race packet. This was in the afternoon. We first noticed them when we drove to Misquamicut Beach - and our first sighting was around 2:30 pm that day. We usually saw them in small groups. Some were even flying near the coastline! Most however were back by the dunes, by the street, or across the street in the marsh area. We stopped counting when we saw 30 or so, and continued to see them in great numbers until we left that evening around 5:30. If I were to guess we saw 50-80 per hour.

My report (9/16) was my count during the morning (as I a lot of time on my hands between the start and finish of the race). I didn't notice as many monarchs between 11am and 2pm. Sometime between 2 and 3 pm the frequency increased again, equal to or slightly less than the afternoon prior. What an amazing experience and what an honor to see this migration! I've already started to look into planting next year to provide plants to help these guys fuel up for their journey. I've never seen a monarch in the wild before this weekend. Not sure if I can do the milkweed, but dahlias and zinnias for certain.

Monarchs are everywhere right now in Salem, MA!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I've never reported monarchs before because I've never seen such a wonderful sight before. For most of this sunny afternoon at least a dozen monarchs (there were a lot more but I couldn't see all of the bush and butterflies at once) were at the large butterfly bush in our yard.  What a joy they were to watch coming and going, rising and settling. Gorgeous!

My brother Jamie took a photo at the Boston Lighthouse. He said there were hundreds of Monarchs. Migration underway!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

It is an incredible year for butterflies in Québec. It started with a red admiral invasion in May, they were thousands and all the stinging nettles were striped completely of their leafs, leaving the larvae no place to hide.

Then a huge abundance painted lady appeared for 10 days in late august. These guys kinda disappeared with the monarchs, around at that time, when the cold front came.

After that there was more warm weather and more monarchs( hundreds in each of the 4 clover field I visited), then a cold front took those away. Now (9/13) there is more warm weather and more monarchs in my yard(didn't check the fields, maybe tomorrow).
They were swarmed around my butterfly bush and flowers.

I was devastated early last week to discover that the large field of red clover that had provided a large,rich source of nutriment for our Fluttery Friends for some time, had been mowed.So I tried another place, an overgrown, abandoned pasture nearby, that had been a fruitful place for sightings in past years ... and found a Sweet Spot -- an open area providing a migration corridor, and rich in autumn asters just coming into bloom.  The Monarchs were POURING through this corridor, filling up on nectar, and then continuing their astonishing flight south ... I find this so moving, so heroic.
observed at least 75 monarch butterflies feeding on the blooms of a 7-sun tree at a client's property on Hale St., Beverly, MA this morning.

On Saturday 15 September 2012 the monarchs starting flying strong around 12 noon over the 4 hours a total of approximately 2000 monarchs flew over Robert Moses Beach with the largest showing around 1pm. There was a fierce north wind, which caused the monarchs to fly lower to the ground to avoid the wind. The weather was 70's and sunny.
Strongest cold front of the season so far moved through during the morning. By the afternoon we saw a consistent stream of monarchs (mostly single) until the early evening.

On Sunday morning 16 September 2012 at Gilgo Beach (which is 10 miles west of Robert Moses Beach) at 7 am more monarchs continued their flight. Similar to the previous day, there were over 3000 in 4 hours. There was a strong NW wind, again in the 70's and very sunny early in the day. Both days the monarchs were accompanied by many dragonflies and other butterflies. The constant flow of monarchs was amazing. They gracefully flew over the ocean, the beach, the roads and the sand dunes. In the later afternoon there was nominal monarch activity.

On a whale watch trip... first saw hundreds of Monarchs gathered along the shore road between Rye and the next town (about 4 miles). Then while on the whale watch boat on both the 15th and 16th at least 50 (over several hours)fluttered around us even when we were 10 miles off shore... headed predominately south .

It took your breath away to see these tiny brilliant orange fluttering beings way off shore with land just out of sight. Some would flutter around the boat as if to land but then flake off behind us. A winded red-breasted nuthatch did take a break on the boat, but I don't think of them as migrators so wonder what it was up to.

Observation point is 3rd story deck facing southern NC coastline. Monarch Butterflies are flying westerly, parallel to coast and between the dunes (100ft away) and the building where I am. Observation was made beginning at 1:50 PM EST. Temp. Is 80 degrees with overcast skies.

I am positive they were monarchs. I am a volunteer at the NC Museum of Natural Sciences. Among other things I taught life cycles including that of the monarch. These were monarchs. The ones near enough to inspect did not have the two spots common to males. I did see a few other " mimics" but did not count them.

Am on vacation in Maine sitting on Schoodic Point. Endless number of monarch heading south. Unbelievably impressive. I'm seeing 10 to 15 per minute. They come in a cluster. Then a short gap.  Sometimes there are a few stragglers before next cluster. Even more impressive that they a fighting a strong breeze (from the west).

I live about 1,500 feet from the Atlantic Ocean (Old Orchard Beach, Maine). I observed Monarch butterflies flying overhead continuously but widely spaced (one by one or sometimes two together) for about two hours going in a northeasterly direction. It is now 3:25 and I am still seeing them fly by sporadically...

I sit in an office building along I-75 in Cincinnati, OH, with a west side office window on the 3rd floor that I face most of the day. The monarchs fly by and catch my attention. I noticed about a dozen on Monday, Sept. 17 and many more today ~30! Yesterday was rainy and I didn't see any.I can't take pictures at work.

Torrential rain and winds here last night may have blown Monarchs off course.  This afternoon, in perfect migration conditions -- warm temperature, light wind, abundant food plants -- I observed only six.
Many thousands of migrating monarchs!
all heading south at a fast speed. Beautiful sunny day. Light breeze. perfect flying weather before the rainstorms coming on the next weekend.
Multiple Monarchs were nectaring in the fields above Lake Michigan.  There were many flying in directional flight from the Lake.  The wind was from the northeast at 5-10 miles per hour.

Swarms of monarchs after a storm that brought them from the Maritimes and islands. There were nearly a hundred in sight at any one time, so hundreds. The wind was NW at 15 and gusting to 20 kts. Our shoreline is quite rocky, so it was difficult to see if any washed up.

A cold front came through on 09/19/12 and brought an even more dense swarm of monarchs. All of our visitors forgot about the Marshall Point Lighthouse and instead stood in awe of this spectacle. Around 5 pm, the monarchs were joined by dozens of large dragonflies. It was a spellbinding sight. There seemed to be little, if any, interaction between the two species. Wind was SW 10-15 kts. Again, we were unable to see an washed up monarchs.

As of September 21st, we have seen no monarchs for the past two days, but it has been in the low 40's at night and barely 60 during the day.

I saw about 100 Monarch butterflie flying around the beach at East Matunuck State Beach in S. Kingstown, RI.  They were swarming out from the tall beach grass. They were also around the salt marsh which is adjacent to the beach.  I started seeing them gathering last week but there were many, many more today.

We were right on  the beach in Madison CT and we observed a steady stream of Monarchs heading southwest.  It was approximately 4:30 pm.  Standing in one place, we were observing 25-30 per minute passing by us.  Amazing sight!

I enjoyed a beach day on Monument Beach in Bourne, Mass on Sunday and was amazed at how many Monarchs were heading south along the water.  Monument Beach is on Buzzards Bay and near the southern entrance to the Cape Cod Canal.  In a period of 3 hours, I was able to see 35 Monarchs.  I especially enjoyed those that landed nearby on the sand to rest.  I could get very close to  them before they would take flight again.  It was a great morning.
I've never experienced that before in my life ~ They were coming by the dozens...off the ocean~  They were everywhere!  Quite magnificent.  :)

A day after the NYC and Long Island experienced tornado warnings with high winds up to 70 mph and teaming rain, a beautiful sunny day was upon us with temps in the mid 70's and a NW wind. The monarchs continued their journey. I spotted about 1500 in an hour at Robert Moses Beach, settling into their roosts for the night. It is amazing to watch them settle into select pine trees, and how they interact with each other. Although many branchs on the trees are empty, they have to snuggle in among the masses. Similar to the previous days they were champeroned by dragonflies and various other butterflies. Once again it was breathtaking to watch them elegantly dance overhead crossing the sand dunes, pine trees and the road. This is truly a dream come true.
Slow but continuous stream of monarchs flying in from the ocean to the sand dunes

Observations from Sept 11 through Sept 18. I had only 4 monarchs in my garden on Sept 11th through Sept 12.  They left on the 12th. No sightings since. However, I have surveyed other Monarch Enthusiasts and had reports of Monarchs in larger numbers nearer Two Rivers and Manitowoc on Sept 12th along the Lakeshore. The largest sighting was 12 monarchs nectaring in a field south of Two Rivers on Sept 12th. There were only 6 monarchs in directional flight spotted by another associate in Manitowoc.  Other observers reported only 1 or none during the week. Another friend of mine mentioned that on Labor Day weekend he witnessed a number of monarchs that had washed up on the beach in Two Rivers. I drove along the lakeshore during the week and found only 1 or 2 monarchs on various occasions. However on Sept 18, I spotted 4 monarchs along the 5 mile stretch between Two Rivers and Manitowoc. In better years, I would be able to count between 50 and 100 while driving those same 5 miles. The weather really messed things up this year.

Once again, in the warmth of the late afternoon, the healthy monarch's are fluttering around and getting their nectar from our garden plants.  At least 20 or more sighted as soon as we sit out out on the deck and observed for as long as we are on the deck.

We were walking along the beach on Long Beach Island, barrier Island of coast of NJ...Monarchs were flying in from the ocean, exhausted...against a westerly wind...just making it to the dunes and safety..on 9/15/12 we saw literally 100's in bushes at the end of Great Bay Boulevard, Little Egg Harbor...Seems to be a gathering place, as many people there come to see them each year..We were told they have not reached "full occupancy there yet" It was reported that the bushes and trees are literally filled, covered at full occupancy....This is west of Long Beach Island across Barnegat Bay...These bushes are at the southern end of Great Bay boulevard, overlooking the bay...I will try to get a picturenext week...
This is over the course of two half-hour drives, to and from Boston. Between around noon and 12:30, I saw 10 Monarchs. Between around 2:45 and 3:15, I saw 5 more.
FLYING OVER THE BUILDING 3 AND 4 AT A TIME IN LITTLE GROUPS.
Observed hundreds of monarchs, all traveling in the same north to south direction for several hours on Sept 19, 2012. Location was along the seacoast. Beautiful sunny weather, no wind.

The Peak Migration in our area seemed to be the week of 9/10/12 to 9/16/12.  They were still few and far between but were more directional and abundant than earlier and on a mission to head south.  They were stopping at stiff goldernrod, sunflower, and aster patches in sheltered and southeast facing locations.

These were observed from the 34th floor of my building, just south of Central Park.  I have observed 2 - 10 butterflies, per day, for 10 days.  They have been observed at or above my floor level. Almost all have been gliding in a stream path, and not flapping their wings.

Millions of Monarchs migrating along the south shore beaches of Long Island, New York.

My Wife Donna and I were out at my aunt's house on the ocean in Westhampton Beach for several days. On Wednesday morning, the 19th, There were small groups from three to ten at a time. By noon time there were larger groups, and it was fairly constant. About 2PM, we went for a walk down the beach road, and the numbers were noticeably increasing. There were literally hundreds of Monarchs at a time heading west through the beach and dunes. There were large swarms at times, and it reminded us of the movie "The Birds". It was quite an impressive sight. I had heard about this happening in the past from my Aunt, We were amazed!! About five thirty or so, we were heading back and noticed that the Monarchs were settling down for the night on the trees. The trees were covered with groups from three to twenty at a time. A very unusual sight.

I would conclude the numbers were in the hundreds of thousands, maybe not a million. I'm pretty good at math and estimating, but this is a tough estimation. On our walk back later in the day, the mile long hike had thousands of the Monarchs settling in the trees everywhere for the nights rest. Possibly 50,000 to 100,000. Best estimations that I can give.
I constantly observed monarch butterflies in groups as small as two, or as large as maybe 15/20 flew over Long Beach, in the town of Nissequoque on Long Island, NY.

Took the preschoolers out side to watch how many butterflies were flying over our playground.  We just released two butterflies that we hatched from caterpillers found on our milkweed plants.  They swear they saw Ying and Yang fly over with all of their new friends!

This was a peak day, but I do not see as many Monarchs here as I did 10 years ago, either during seasonal migrations or during breeding season.  I check of milkweeds often and rarely find eggs or chrysalae, though I used to see them at every outing.  Wonder why?

While sitting on my back deck I noticed a monarch fluttering along moving from the NE to the SW across my backyard. A few minutes later I noticed another and then another, all moving in the same direction almost in the exact location. I had my wife join me as we watched these amazing butterflies migrate. I did see another one this evening after I mowed the yard, same location and direction!
While on the beach, monarchs were crossing the beach and making their way south.
Observed about 20 monarchs today, first sighting this year's migration.

We went to Sea Gull Beach at So Yarmouth, Ma.  on Sat afternoon about 2:30pm..while there seated on the beach we noticed a number of Monarchs fluttering by along the waters edge...there was a stiff breeze from the west....so after a bit of observing  we started counting and within the roughly 9o minutes we were there I counted  104 monarchs....sometimes only  a single one then maybe two and sometimes three together.As we watched the migration came into our heads...It was amazing to watch nature in this event. Now we  would like to learn more about it.
Many sighted 9/19/2012,9/20/2012 gone none seen
Observed flying 20 feet above Lake Huron shoreline heading south. Temperature 68F and cloudy. First north wind of September.

These three adults have been the only "migration signs" seen thus far this year. The 3 adults flew west past the large windows on the North side of the building, then turned south around the building to. Noted on this sunny yet slightly windy day.   We've been checking all the usual places for adults: prairie plots, wildflowers along the Disc golf course, school butterfly gardens, wildflowers bordering cemeteries..... the population is very low here.

The migration resumed today on the north shore of Lake Erie at Clearville Park after 4 days of wet, cloudy , windy and cool weather. I estimate about 1000 butterflies per hour moving overhead today starting at 10:00 AM at 2-6 times tree-top height. The migration today is not as strong as last weekend when I estimated about 1200 -1500 per hour moving through the park on Friday and Saturday. Today there are also numerous Monarchs at ground level moving along the Orford Bluffs 60 feet above the lake. All butterflies are heading in the direction of Pt Pelee - 80 KMs SW down the coast from here. Flight conditions perfect today,  65-70 F, partly sunny with a light north wind.

I watched hundreds of Monarch Butterflies feeding on mostly Goldenrod in some fields near the Gay Head Cliffs on Martha's Vineyard Island late in the afternoon on Sept. 18th. I then found the trees they were roosting on and watched them gather onto some privet trees. I'd say there were somewhere around 1000 butterflies. The trees were covered. I returned the next morning (Sept. 19th) to watch them all fly off the trees as they warmed up. By evening it seemed most of them had moved on.
On and near the Greenway in Boone in late afternoon, every minute or so I would spot another one, some low and some higher, all generally headed in southwesterly direction.

Near downtown Roanoke at the River's Edge complex, my family and I sat and watched at least 20 Monarchs flying across the parking lot. Occasionally they would stop and rest, and nearly disappear with their camouflage in the gravel. It was sometimes hard to count, since they might have been resting and starting off again. But there were many more flying on the way home, at least 4 crossing the road in only one mile. Amazing!
Many monarchs travelling directly over our back yard and house, from Northeast to Southwest direction.
Monarchs are passing through my yard. They are all over zinias,butterfly bushes,cosmos and goldenrod.
We tagged 81 in a period of about 2 hours!!

Observed 150+ (conservatively) Monarchs, one after the other in Doughton Park on the Blue Ridge Parkway in the NC mountains. Saw many more near Sparta, NC. All heading South. Started seeing them early, around 9am. Originally went to the mountains to watch Broad Winged Hawks migrate.

We spotted at least 80-100 Monarchs at the Thunderhill Overlook on the Parkway - close to Boone. They were all flying in a southwest direction - some of them would stop and nectar up on the asters and goldenrod in the area before crossing the Parkway and soaring over the escarpment which overlooks Boone. They all seemed to be enjoying the powerful uplift as they soared through.
20 mph winds, north-easterly. Multiple small groupings of monarchs throughout the afternoon

Monarchs are migrating across central Oklahoma!  I noticed new ones sporatically moving into the garden, and others moving out all afternoon.  The temp has been 85 degrees with wind NNE.  From 5pm to 5:45pm, I noticed an increase of Monarchs flying.  I counted 20 Monarchs in that time period in a directional southerly flight.  The winds will be easterly today, then change to the south this week until the next front comes next weekend.  We remain in extreme drought conditions.  Has been a challenge to keep the grasshoppers from decimating the flowers intended for the migrating Monarchs. No roost noted.
Constant stream going from east to west. No more than 5 seconds without at least one (and usually 3 or 4) being is view.
Observed many Monarchs in my wildflower garden which consists of mostly cosmos and zinnias right now.
Have been on native plant tours the last couple of days. I have seen migrating monarchs at every stop.
At Jones Beach witnessed Monarch Butterflies travelinf in same direction along shoreline between hours of 12pm-2pm
I live next to a rare southern Appalachian bog called Lewis creek while I walked around for about 2 hours I counted 43 monarchs feeding
we were in Lake James; saw many between 9:30-10 AM.  A few more between 5 - 5:30 PM

Monarchs continuing to move across central Oklahoma- one by one.  Today from 1:45pm to 2:45 pm, I counted 10 Monarchs headed in a southerly direction.  Monarchs would come into my garden and leave, but I never saw over 5 Monarchs at a time.  The Monarchs appeared to look fresh, medium to large in size, good body fat, and were not acting like they were very intent on nectaring.

Yesterday started out to be a slow morning for monarchs but as the day continued with North winds the monarchs began arriving in numbers.  The best time for observation was from 2 - 6 pm.  Observers counted approximately 60 per 5 minutes flying down the dunes.  In any binocular view on the dunes one could see at least 30 butterflies at a time!!  It's always sooo good to see them back in Cape May!!!!  The numbers kept increasing during the afternoon hours with the butterflies coming in off the dunes to nectar in gardens (as our goldenrod isn't in bloom yet) and to roast for the night.  We can't wait to see what today brings with more north winds ((-:
Was participating in a Hawk Watch count and saw approx (7) Monarchs....Not sure how high, but below the clouds around 3PM. It was amazing to see them through binoculars!
Best day for monarchs thus far this fall. Prior to this day, I have seen many more painted ladies than monarchs.
While traveling interstate 81 near Roanoke, counted around 40 passing by headed south.  Saw more in Radford the same day.
I was at Big Cedar Lodge right off Tablerock Lake and there were at least 100 Monarchs feasting on Butterfly bushes around the resort.
300 Monarchs moved through Hawk Cliff, just east of Port Stanley, Ontario, Canada today, in spite of very strong SW winds

Was a great day watching the monarchs fly by one by one looking out this 3rd floor window. I know I missed several as I can't look out the window all day, although it sure is hard not to!I know this isn't going to last forever :(It was a beautiful day with sun and blue skies (no clouds). It was a frosty morning though! Saw the 1st monarch fly by at 9:30 AM (45F). They just kept on flying by peaking about 10AM-1PM with the last one at 5 PM.

Standing on the beach early in the morning I stood in amazement as the monarchs streamed down low and close to the water line.  At one point I counted 100 oer minute going by me.  Once they reached the curve of land(the point) in Cape May Point they moved up in the dune areas.  Many stopped on the beach to rest on the sand.  Most of the monarchs stayed in the sheltered dune areas on trees with blooming English ivy or on groundsel bushes.... to nectar.  Hardly any were seen inland in gardens!!  It was like a snow globe today as the brilliant orange of the monarchs flew against the bright blue fall sky!!!!  Itw as so great to see them everywhere you looked!

Perfect winds and weather resulted in an amazing monarch migration day at Cape May. At 4:30pm, I stood at the top of the primary dune and counted monarchs flying past me. It averaged about 70 monarchs per 5 minutes, or about 800 or so monarchs per hour. Their flight behavior was very interesting-- they were coming through in small groups of 3, 4, or 5 at a time. They chased each other, they swirled around each other, and there was some close spiraling. It was a relaxed flight. How could they know they would soon rest at the point on the dense vegetation in residents' yards, or the dense stand of small eastern red-cedars beyond the houses? And imagine how they enjoyed the abundant nectar sources at TNC Meadows sanctuary and in nearby yards.

Rest up and eat well, monarchs. You still have to fly over the choppy Delaware Bay. Next stop. . . Chincoteague, I hope. I will be waiting for them.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Montclair Hawk Lookout, Montclair, NJ

The hawk watch in Montclair had a massive movement of monarch butterflies from 4:00 in the afternoon until about 6:00. Unfortunately, my wife Diane and I were not there to witness it, but the counter, Joe, and another "regular", Ray , tried to count them. Joe and Ray's best estimate of the number is between three and five thousand in a couple of hours.

Never in the long history of this second oldest regularly staffed hawk watch has anything like this been seen. Must have been amazing to see.Joe and Ray say there were monarchs everywhere they looked for that late afternoon period.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monarchs Still Migrating on Toronto Waterfront - Leslie Street Spit

By checking the visible satellite picture I decided the sun would appear after 3 pm, but the hummingbirds drew me to Rosetta Mclean Gardens first so I didn't arrive at the Spit until after 4:30pm but I did see many fresh monarchs (40+) nectaring on goldenrod near the gate and the parking lot - very little action on the New England Asters which are now in full bloom. I also saw a mating pair and found 3 milkweed caterpillars, 2 about half grown and 1 very small one. Interestingly enough all 3 were feeding from the top of the leaf so they were quite easy to spot

Forwarded by Don Davis

Wed, Sept 19, from 1-3pm:
Some friends who live in Annapolis told me they were sailing on the Chesapeake Bay from Rock Hall (on the eastern shore) to Sandy Point State Park (on the western shore just north of the Bay Bridge) and saw numerous migrating monarchs fly past them, heading due southwest. Wind was NNW at 12mph so the monarchs flapped continuously to stay on course. Once at Sandy Point, they saw more monarchs hugging the western shore of the bay as they continued migrating south.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

While carrying my net through a large field of abundant Canada goldenrod, along with thistle, boneset, and New England aster on the warm afternoon of Sunday, September 16 between 12:00 and 2:00 I watched in wonder the diverse insect communities. Lepidopterans present were black swallowtails, Common Buckeyes, American Painted Ladies and many migrating Monarchs. I counted 10 at a quick glance at any one time in my close surroundings and hundreds in a couple acres. Also darting around the field were several species of migrating dragonflies. I've learned recently there are 12 species that migrate in Ohio. To my surprise I saw a Green Darner snatch a Monarch in flight and carried it away! This field, one that Sarah Dalton and I meet yearly, seems to be a favorite for migrating Monarchs and this year it seems the number of migrators are good.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Finally, a decent number of monarchs at Pt Pelee tonight!

Monarch Count – September 19, 2012...800 Monarchs tonight. A roost of ~700 just east of the shipwreck display.

Perhaps the Canadian monarchs are beginning to move from more westerly locales. There was also mention of frost in Northern Ontario last night - that should hurry them along.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

For the last three days (9/16-18) there have been more migrating monarchs than I have seen since I moved here four years ago.

Sunday, September 16. I returned home in the early afternoon to find about fifty monarchs on flowering goldenrod and asters in the back yard of my 1/4 acre lot. The SW wind has been blowing since yesterday afternoon so these monarchs are stopping by until the winds are more favorable. At dusk they flew off towards the woods. I have suspected a roost on the island for two years now - still looking for it. Keep losing them when I try to follow.

Monday, September 17. Morning: On the Northeast of the island, facing Cape Cod, they were blowing in off Buzzard's Bar at the rate of one about every three minutes for the entire hour I spent there. Seaside goldenrod has been flowering for about a week now, but also saw 3 monarchs nectaring at flowering Groundsel Bush (Baccharis halmifolia) Afternoon: At the SE beach, I counted over 150 in an hour, clinging to the goldenrod in the stiff breeze. 40-50 in the back yard every time I counted.

Today we have weather rolling in. About 20 -25 in the yard on the goldenrod even as the wind is blowing over 21 miles an hour. Fewer on the beach in the open wind than yesterday but a few were still coming in every few minutes on the NE sideI am interested to see the numbers after the weather. Most of the smaller white asters are just beginning to bloom and they were heavily used by migration monarchs last year.

Will they find a roost to wait out the storm? Do they always roost together or will some of them try to ride out the storm wherever they find themselves?

In boat we traveled from Hull, MA across Boston harbor to Stellwagon Banks. No whales sighted but approximately 20 monarchs sighted flying from open ocean toward land. We don't usually see butterflies on open ocean.
Just did a 15 minute watch and counted 12 Monarch Butterflies traveling west.

When I was at recces I saw 37 butterflies going south for the winter. It was Friday, September 21st. It was about 3 butterflies coming at once. We saw all those butterflies in 15 minute. A couple of them went west but they came back and went the right way.  We have been seeing like 1 or 2 a day but last Friday was the most.

my daily trek to Big Cedar Lodge on Table Rock lake once again brings 50 or more Monarchs feasting on butterfly bush, with others flying thru on a south/southwest direction.  Also Hummimgbirds are still abundant and are getting nectar from Rose of Sharon bushes.

The sky and trees were filled with orange wings today!!!  Huge numbers of monarchs were feeding on English Ivy flowers again.  In one view hundreds could be seen flitting around in the trees flowers.  An interesting observation - in the last 3 days very few of the monarchs are feeding in the gardens that are filled with flowers around Cape May Point.  They continue to feed on the ivy flowers.  Last year the monarchs would roost on the ivy flowers too, this year they are moving at dusk to cedar or deciduous trees to roost.  It was incredible today!!

Many monarchs and red admirals stayed over at one of their favorite bread and breakfast locations at Cape May point and as of 10 am many have just moved down a little and are eating breakfast on the favored English Ivy.  Spectacular! Numbers are likely several thousand, since they roosted all along the block and there were big clusters last night.

Still some monarchs migrating at Eastern Point.  Over 100 were busily gathering nectar from New England aster in the hour I observed.  I tagged about 25.  When I released them, they either flew back to the flowers or generally flew off to the south.  I saw a few flying high in a southerly direction.

A friend who lives close by called to report her asters and butterfly bushes were full of monarchs. She estimated 40-50 of them. She actually lives on the road to Caesar's Head, which just on the border of North and South Carolina, about 10 miles away. I didn't get there until about 6PM, but there were still many around. My friend's sister who is tall did the netting and I did the tagging. We were able to tag 16 of them--8 females and 8 males. All looked in good shape except for the raggedness on the hind wings of some of them. Many of them escaped, but I'll be back tomorrow afternoon and see if we can tag some more.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Once again the skies and trees were filled with monarchs in Cape May Point!!  The monarchs are still feeding on the English Ivy flowers while the sedum, ageratum and butterfly bushes go untouched.... hmmmm.  Some monarchs were even roosting during the daylight hours in clumps of 50 or more with tree branches weighed down by the many clusters.  We'll see what the weather brings for tomorrow.  It is so glorious to see them flying around our town - it's a little Mexico here at home.

I observed about 600 butterflies per hour moving SW through Clearville Park from 11:30 AM until around 2:00 PM. Today is a cool day, ptly cloudy, gusty NW wind. High 59 F. Migration stopped around 2:00 PM when it clouded over and temp fell into mid 50's.  Most butterflies spotted moving along the Orford Bluffs high above Lake Erie which provides shelter from NW wind. Butterflies are heading toward Rondeau Provincial Park 15 miles SW and Pt Pelee - 80 miles SW of Clearville Park.

Today was a cloudy, cold windy day at Clearville Park. Low last night 42F. West wind gusting to 22 MPH. Migration along the north shore of lake Erie continued today but at a slower pace because of the wind. High 60 F. Migration continued until 3:00 PM when temp fell. Most butterflies spotted moving along the Orford Bluffs above Lake Erie which  provides shelter from W wind. Butterflies are heading toward Rondeau Provincial Park 15 miles SW and Pt Pelee - 80 miles SW of Clearville Park. All they have to do is follow the lake shore. The weather man is calling for good migration weather(sunny, warmer) over the next 2 weeks.
Many more monarchs today. Over a two hour span, it was rare not to see at least one either heading south or on our butterfly bushes.

We were back out at Westhampton Beach along the ocean over the weekend. On Saturday the 22th, there were sporadic sightings throughout the day. Maybe several hundred for the day. Sunday the 23rd was a bit more busy. Over the peak four hours from about noon to later , we counted about 20-30 per minute average. Doing some rough calculations, we would estimate that there there were 7,000 to 8,000 for the 12 hour period. This show was nothing compared to the sightings we had on Wednesday the 19th. The amounts of Monarchs were astounding and hundreds of times more. Maybe, not in the millions, but certainaly in the hundreds of thousands for the day.

Adult Monarch butterflies congregated on a pair of butterfly bushes in our small garden, and were flying in groups within the condominium complex around noon on an overcast day today. There was a similar sighting yesterday. Up until this week, we've only had one or two monarchs at a time visit the butterfly bushes this summer. The bushes were planted four summers ago, and this is the first time that we've noticed the migrating Monarchs in our garden. I plan to plant milkweed next spring.
Off the Blue Ridge Parkway at Pounding Mill overlook near Pisgah Forest, NC., the Monarchs were high and low, single and pairs, one after the other...we didn't want to leave
Sunny, breezy, about 75*; floating N to S.I was driving for about 10 minutes and I counted 5 Monarchs fluttering at varying intervals about 20 feet high, in front of the car.
Flying south scattered aroundj
We tagged 81 in a period of two hours!

We saw 32 butterflies migrating across our playground today!  The weather is warm and beautiful.  We have chilly mornings and warm afternoons.  We will keep looking for butterflies.  We have not had any caterpillars.

Early this morning the monarchs started lifting off from their roosts in Cape May Point, circling in the air.  Some butterflies went across the Bay to Delaware, while others turned back and re-settled into the gardens and ivy flowers.  While observing there was anywhere from 150-200 butterflies in the air above us.  When looking through binoculars you could see the monarchs stretched out all across the Bay and dunes along the Point.  This was the first day in the last 5 days that the monarchs spread out more in the local gardens to nectar but the vast majority kept returning to the ivy flowers.  It was another special day in Cape May.
Monarchs were coming into Cape May all day, from 10:30 am until around 5.  I counted 62 in 1 hour this afternoon. I am sure I missed some, while working in the garden.

this may not seem peak migration to others, but 7 adults per hour is rather high at this location.  perhaps more remarkable is that migrating monarchs have been passing here since 24 AUG 2012 in small but steady numbers from just after dawn most days to at sunset.
Watching Monarchs and Fritilaries migrate here at Folly Beach, SC. Large numbers taking advantage of a gentle sea breeze.

September 28
I saw a few monarchs on my butterfly bushes this morning. As I looked to the sky I kept seeing them (2 or 3 at a time) flying north to south. After 3 hours I've seen about 50 and am still seeing them.

October 2
Only 15 - 20 monarchs this am between 10 and 11am. Same as before, flying from the northeast to the southwest in groups of 2 or 3. Some stopped at the butterfly bushes others just flew over.

Was standing outside in my yard with my 8 year old son when he said look at all the Monarch Butterlies on our butterfly bush. I looked over and up and saw hundreds of Monarchs in the sky, some stopping by our butterfly friendly yard, and hundreds of others flying through the sky. I didn't have my phone because it was just raining hard so I left it inside. It was a beautiful and amazing experience.
They were all flying high in the sky in the same direction toward the south
Southwesterly breeze, partly cloudy and we are at the southern end of Long Beach Island.  Wonderful sight as the butterflies ride the breezes heading south.
What a treat!  We were at our playground and spotted them flying over.  My kindergarteners journaled about the cool experience.

9/29 at 8am (heavy cloud cover, temp 65, wind NNW at 8mph, showers in the forecast)

The wind finally changed and the small roosts of monarchs on Chincoteague Island were able to leave. I watched as one of the monarchs I had tagged on Thursday lifted off and (with constant flapping) successfully made the crossing over the Chincoteague Channel.

Since this wind direction blows monarchs out to the ocean's edge, I headed out to the beach on Assateague and saw that monarchs were already migrating. This was not a huge wave, but constant at about 2 monarchs per minute. Most flew about 50-75 feet above the sand. The wind speed was light enough so that the monarchs did not get blown out over the ocean. As I have seen many times in the past, they were facing SW but being blown sideways while they flapped to stay true to their course. The flight pattern reminded me of that of a sharp-shinned hawk-- flap-flap-flap-glide, flap-flap-flap-glide. So it wasn't the easy soaring flight the monarchs enjoy on a NE or N wind.

There is some good news to report. The wide expanses of open beach where the ocean breached the dune and overwashed into the cove are narrower this year. (In past years, these areas were wide, barren areas with no wind buffer and monarchs got blown out to sea). Last winter's storms must have deposited an unusually large amount of sand which has built up the existing dunes and created new ones. Today the monarchs were flying over the narrow overwash areas without difficulty. Even if the wind picks up speed, I think they will be able navigate these areas with some additional flapping.

The bad news is that there were just as many monarchs heading north up the cove shoreline as there were monarchs heading south along the ocean shore. So somewhere between me and the elbow of Tom's hook the monarchs were turning around. The wind direction and speed would normally take them right off the island, but for some reason they were not leaving land. The only thing I can think of is that they just didn't have enough fat reserves and they were back-tracking to look for nectar sources. The problem is-- the seaside goldenrod is not in bloom yet. The plants look stressed, with the bottom half of the stems' leaves brown and crispy. The plants really need a good soaking rain to stimulate the flower buds to open. If the monarchs keep heading north about another half mile, they will find some groundsel-tree bushes to nectar on. If the wind remains the same all day, there might be a roost near or in those bushes this evening.

An abundance of monarchs in Brevard, NC

On 9-25 and 9-26, two friends and I captured, tagged and released 84 monarchs on the site at route 276 heading south toward Caesar's Head, SC--10 miles away. There were a lot more than that, but I ran out of tags (I ordered more)! Of these, there were 66 males and 18 females. We also found a mating pair. Other than some raggedness and a few slim abdomens, they looked healthy. They will fill up on the plentiful asters, golden rod and butterfly bushes on their flyway.They were so abundant that one of the women just stood at the aster bush and plucked them off. She handed them to her sister, I tagged and recorded. A most wonderful way to spend an afternoon. The whole thing was video taped.

I'm hearing reports of hundreds migrating through our mountains. Another friend told me there was another group of them at Henderson's Nursery in Rosman, NC and Ina Warren took those on (GO INA!!!). I'm still seeing a few flying around the city of Brevard.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Report from Cranberry Marsh Hawk Watch on the north shore of Lake Ontario near Whitby

Sept. 25
128 Monarchs

Forwarded by Don Davis

Huge influx of monarchs today throughout Cape May (please note I put in an arbitary number above-it is impossible to say how many came in). I noted activity around 9:30-the point had large numbers building up in roosts along the dunes in pine trees at 10ish am.  In the state park we found scores of monarchs on the ground on grass (11:30 am), they seemed to be puddling?!  Monarchs were also nectaring throughout the state park but many were resting in small clusters, others (many, many) flying toward the point.Near our cottage, large numbers were dropping out of the sky all afternoon. More still coming in though it seems to have slowed down now.

While at National Zoo, saw monarchs ALL over, nearly everywhere I turned, from several stories over my head, shining orange against a cerulean sky, to the tiny wildflowers amidst the grass in the various animal yards, to eye-level in the various butterfly bushes that I'm always checking out this time of year. Definitely felt like a 'peak' in their migration!

i had taken 3 preschoolers into a wooded area near the state lake, where monarchs are  often tagged in the fall. we stayed for about half an hour.  it was a cool, overcast morning.  we saw 8 monarchs in an adjacent field of wildflowers, and observed a greater number (approximately 40) in the wooded area - red cedar, pine, oak, and walnut.  the numbers were nothing like i had observed in previous years.  i would like to hope that we were ahead of, or behind the major migration.

The monarchs streamed through Cape May today.  The migration went on for hours down the beach.  Many of the monarchs came in and started roosting early in the day in cedars and pines along the dunes.  The team found approximately 8,000 butterflies roosting but I'm sure there were many more around the Point we didn't see!!!   It's so nice to see another wave of monarchs on their way to Mexico!!  So many visitors were  awed by the spectacle.  It was an awesome migration day for songbirds and hawks as well.

Noticed migration late afternoon 4:30pm-ish.  Constant stream, one after another.  Observed for approximately 30 minutes.  We are located at 3200ft elevation on the North face of mountain (at the peak)
Seeing multiple at a time in groups of 3 - 7 flying around.

Many of the 10,000 roosting monarchs from last night warmed up in the sun this morning, some flying across the Bay, others heading into the gardens at the Point to feed, some flying in the dunes feeding on the goldenrod, and some staying in small roosts on the pines and ivy.  More monarchs arrived in Cape May today on the light W winds.  Tonight was a warmer night and so the roosting was in smaller clumps scattered throughout the Point, 50 and 100 here, 1,000 there...  Another amazing day with these magical critters flitting everywhere you looked!!!
While driving on Interstate 65N I counted 30 monarchs flying south.  They were in groups of two and three.

What an incredible day!  Started out at 7:30 am, with monarchs coming down into our rear garden.  A trip to the point at 8am revealed the monarchs waking up at many roosts, and by 10 am, many were out and about nectaring at the point and state park. At the state park it was clear that another wave of migrants was coming in, monarchs, red admirals, buckeyes and many many dragonflies. At our butterfly cottage in the city of Cape May, all day monarchs dropped in the front and rear gardens, and from 4:20-4:35 I counted 63 dropping down from the north while sitting on our front porch.  This evening it appeared that some of the monarchs may have left today, although there were some nice sized roosts around the point. A magical day in Cape May.

Traveled up to Blue Ridge Parkway, Cherry Cove Overlook on 9/29/12, the day was cooler, dreary day, didn't see any monarch's. Today traveled back to BRP, Cherry Cove Overlook and the first 10 minutes, nothing, then just a steady flow of monarch's, for the next 50 min., we saw 51 monarch's and 1 swallowtail...it was awesome. At another place near Brevard N.C. at Dolly's Ice Cream Shoppe, we counted 14 monarch's heading south toward Brevard....
Mid-day flight over houses on the island and over the water and onto the beach.  Butterflies flew in pairs or small groups (3-4).

Many many monarchs warmed up in the morning sun after roosting for much of the day on Saturday in the cooler weather.  Some of those 10,000 roosting monarchs crossed the Delaware Bay, others found gardens to nectar in, some settled into the goldenrod on the dunes and a few stayed in roosts in the conifers.  We did get an influx of new monarchs arriving along with dragonflies and some other butterflies.  The songbirds were also phenomenal!!  Another amazing day in Cape May where the sky was filled with flying colors!!!

I saw 2 Monarchs flying south in Laurel Springs, NC. When leaving the mountains I asked a member of a bird watching group if they had observed any. A member stated he had counted 18 while bird watching. The birdwatchers were near Roaring Gap, NC which is before Laurel Springs so it's possible the two I saw had already been counted. I then observed 2 more flying south before the bird watching group. Sunny day with cool temps around 65-70.

I first noticed monarch butterflies on Monday 9/24/12. The number steady increased each day with the peak coming on Thursday 9/27/12.  That day they were flying by my house in groups of 2,4 7,8 at a time.  I observed this for 12 hours.  From 8:00 a.m. till 8:00 p.m.  I estimate that on Thursday alone I saw over 1000 butterflies. Since 9/27 I have seen butterflies, but in decreasing numbers each day.  Total for the week of 9/24 to 9/28 must be 2000 plus. I am retired from a 35 year career with the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation.  This sighting is on par with anything I saw during those years. Absolutely amazing.

Yesterday (9/30) we witnessed a splendid migration through our back field. I'd been waiting for the day I'd see larger numbers instead of the 10 or less I'd observe in an hours time.

On Friday while fueling up around 2 I witnessed several monarchs passing through from the northeast. There were 5 just while I was at the pumps. Driving home I saw another 6 so I knew this could be the weekend.

Yesterday (9/30) they were migrating through in a steady flow coming at us from the north and northeast. It was 1:30 and my husband and I witnessed 10 or more a minute coming through! Some were soaring high and riding the wind, others flapping madly as they passed at lower altitudes and then those stopping at our perennial bed to nectar on the butterfly bushes and plants in bloom. None of the butterflies nectaring in the flower beds were tagged so all were migrating through!! We had to leave but were out there close to an hour. Very happy news to see so many yesterday – it’s about 2 weeks later than normal for us.

October 1
After a rainy morning, my husband went out to release two ‘late bloomers’ we had from yesterday. The sun is out and he said ‘migration has started back out’. A constant flow through the clear cut which runs at the back of our property. I just love it!
After a day of minimal activity, today I saw a monarch heading south every few minutes.
I sited about 23 Monarchs flying around in a field of tall grass near my home.  This was late afternoon.

Cherry Cove Overlook near milepost 415 on Blue Ridge ParkwayElevation near 4500 ftKnown as an annual migration route with exhibit recognizing the siteOne female monarch was in shivering mode for several minutes and stayed put on a leaf for about 30 minutes allowing onlookers to shoot many photos--we thought that she was just plumb tuckered out!

Noticed 2 monarchs in the backyard. Drove to the south end of Lake Ft. Phantom Hill, and saw monarchs in the tall brush. (We had 7 inches of rain over the weekend, and the temps have been cooler.) The brush is very dense and my estimate of 200 monarchs is only an estimate.  Driving home we saw 10 in the sky.  Welcome monarchs!

Some of the Monarch Monitoring team witnessed a "river of monarchs" this morning in the dune areas of Cape May Point.  The monarchs then dispersed with some feeding on seaside goldenrod, others on butterfly bushes and flowers in gardens, and still some on the ivy flowers.  They were scattered throughout the Point and no matter where you looked you could see them !!  Amazing to have such a continuous migration if them this fall ((-:

My husband and I were in Cape May all day, where monarchs were pouring in once again in large numbers (will post separately). My daughter in Jackson, emailed us noting "we have CRAZY monarchs here today...the butterfly bush is covered in them."  This was around 3 pm today.

Monarchs were coming in from the north all day along with some buckeyes, red admirals, painted ladies and dragonflies.  Between what we saw dropping out of the sky by our cottage in the city (at one point groups of 3-5 were dropping down, and what we saw coming in along the beach and state park, we had to have seen at least 1000. In the morning over at the point some seemed to be trying to leave and many were turning back. The golden rod along the dunes was covered with butterflies, the majority were monarchs.

spotted the first one floating in my front yard area (really a field) so I went outside to get fotos.  I only got one good shot of the first one on goldenrod as most of the others did not alight long or near enuff for a shot.  Most wafted in the breeze under cloudy skies in over the trees then on off into my fields.  Hard to say exactly how many there were but I know I saw at least 10.  I may go out hunting later to places I know they like.

Sighting for the last two days prior had dwindled to one or two butterflies a day but today after a front passed the monarchs were back. I saw 4 feeding on hardy ageratum in an abandoned farm field of ageratum, goldenrod and boneset. I had two feeding on althea flowers and then saw 7 feeding on a butterfly bush and one on a red knockout rose. Go Monarchs!!! (Sadly, yesterday I only saw one all day and it was a male dying next to the road--probably hit by a car.)
Monarchs were sighted along the sand dunes on the beach. They were all heading south.

Walked along the perimeter of the Sachuest National Wildlife refuge. I counted 52 monarchs over the course of about two hours. Most of them were flying in various directions over the interior areas of the refuge. There was a lot of goldenrod, and many of them were alighting and feeding on the goldenrod. About three or four of the butterflies headed out in a southwesterly direction over the water towards the RI mainland.
Continuing to see many Monarchs (one every few minutes) haeding south.

Several singles over a 3 hour time span.  I am not watching all the time, working in yard and sighted these flying in southerly direction.  Not as many as last year.  Numbers have been low to this observer.

My wife and I are vacationing in the White Mountains in upper New Hampshire

We left our home in Central Texas this past weekend after having an almost constant presence of Monarchs around our home since mid-March

As we left we had about 50-60 larvae in our milkweed patch and we were still seeing eggs from a single female who seemed to have an endless supply

It was tough to leave but we'd been planning this trip for quite some time and knew when we headed back next weekend we'd still have Monarchs at home

Well......while we were hiking today (10/02)at about 1pm on the Lincoln Woods Trail along the East Branch of the Pemigewasset River east of Lincoln when we saw many migrating Monarchs (N 44 3.9 ,W 71 35.3)

We were about about a 1/2 mile north of the suspension bridge off Hwy 112 on the west shore when we noticed Monarchs flying down the river which at that point was flowing S/SW

The wind was blowing upstream but they were soaring against the wind at or just below treetop levelThey were coming at a rate of about one every 2-3 minutes and we stayed until we saw about a dozen pass by our locationQuite a treat and really brought a smile to our face to see the Monarch journey from a perspective we rarely get to experience

As we ended our hike and stood on the suspension bridge heading to our parked car....yet more Monarchs were passing over the bridgeMost of them at a height that the majority of the fall foliage tourists like us never even knew that they were there....unless you knew to look for them

We headed East into North Woodstock and ate a late lunch on Hwy 3 at the Woodstock Inn and were pleasantly surprised to again see Monarchs everywhere. 2 or 3 of the businesses in that area had beautiful flower gardens around their shops (including the Woodstock Inn) and the nectar needy Monarchs were descending into the area in large numbers

We counted about 30-40 while we ate lunch in the patio area and saw several flying south down the highway as we drove away to the north

The temps are supposed to get colder this weekend but today was mostly sunny early in the day and then became overcast in late afternoonWe're here until Sunday and we'll be watching the skies hoping to spot more southbound Monarchs

We were leaving our plant (Shaw Plant 15) for lunch around noon and observed 1000s of Monarchs flying West over and around the Plant.  We watched for about 5 minutes and they kept coming and coming.  When we returned from lunch about 70 minutes they were mostly gone with only a few lingering about.  It was the first time in my life that I have observed a monarch migration and it was thrilling and  amazing!

I noticed one lone Monarch flying south and began looking for more. Right away i began to see more flying over. All were heading south and none stopped. I took the students out to see them and explain their migration briefly. They all saw them.

I saw 17 Monarchs this evening over a 45 minute period. It is very overcast and calm on the ground, but there must be a good Southerly breeze because 16 of the Monarchs were flying very high (maybe 4 or 5 stories) and were gliding along, not having to flap their wings much.  I saw one fluttering about the yard, possible looking for a food source.  I wished them all a safe journey!
Between 1pm and 5pm I observed 39 Adult monarchs feeding on various wildflowers in this field. I captured 26 of them for OE sampling and released them the following day.
Steady movement of insects southward on peninsula point today

Monarchs were coming across Salem Bay from(most likely)their fall roost at Eastern Point, Gloucester and travelling southwest down Marblehead Neck, funneling into and across the causeway to the mainland.  I observed and counted from 3:10 - 4:10 pm.  It was a bright sunny, warm afternoon following a chilly night and morning. Many stopped to feed in residential gardens on the Neck. The Monarchs were fighting a southwest wind that I estimate was blowing 10-12 mph. I observed that they were following the causeway road across the harbor rather than flying across the water.  They flew low - at a height of inches up to 10 feet above the road (following warm updrafts from road?) - individuals and groups of as many as 15 together.  It was a parade that was stopping traffic!

Good moving day for the Monarchs. From 10am to 11 am, counted 30 Monarchs flying in a southerly direction, with a light northerly wind.  Only a few stopped to nectar.  The were mostly flying singular.

Yesterday I counted 5 monarchs in the garden here in Jackson around mid-day(very unusual to see this here now).  At around 5 I looked out my kitchen window and found 2 were roosting in our crab apple tree in the rain. One looked a bit worn-it was not a new adult. This am I left for NY in a fog, but my husband reported seeing 2 monarchs in the morning fog and then again saw 4 in the afternoon. Today while walking in NYC (my 10 minute walk to work from the ferry) I saw 2 monarchs, both flying about 2 stories high down 1st Ave (north).
Headed southwest with an easterly tail wind over farm fields and HS stadium.

While in the drive thru lane at Chick-Fil-A, monarchs were streaming by one after another.  In this path also included a few cloudless sulphers.  Monarchs were also seen moving all around the area.  It was a beautiful sight!

While on the playground at 11:00 AM to release a male monarch we had raised, our class observed 21 other monarchs in flight.  The temperature was around 78 degrees, blue skies, and a light wind. (PS:  We also just completed our Symbolic Monarch Migration packet.  What a special day for this class of first graders!)

Fresh Monarchs continue to emerge, visit and nectar in my garden.  They are especially drawn to my old-fashioned tall zinnias and occasionally visit the Joe Pye Weed.  Next year, along with planting more asclepias, I'm planting fresh zinnias in late July so there will be more to eat come next October!  These past two days have more Monarchs than previously seen this year.
They seemed to be going in the same direction,pretty amazing.I have not saw very many monarch butterflies this summer so I am enjoying watching them migrate

Seen on the Blue Ridge Parkway at milepost 426.5, at the Haywood Gap/Pass. The sign called it Haywood Pass saying it was at "The crest of the Balsams" at 5,000+ elevation. This is also where the Mountains-to-Sea hiking trail intersects with the Parkway.Entered the BRP at the Balsam Gap on-ramp and ascended up and past the highest point on the Parkway. It was a seasonably warm day, and we saw more and more monarchs the farther up we went. At the Haywood Gap section — the land flattens out a bit, and the road skirts the edge — the butterflies were concetrated, streaming in overhead, touching down on the purple and yellow wildflowers at the overlook and continuing on in a southwesterly direction. They were everywhere! Some nectaring for a long time, others streaming over the canopy and down into the deep valley below. We couldn't anywhere without seeing a monarch.We went a few miles beyond to Devil's Courthouse and there were no butterflies at all. They were all concentrated in that gap. And we went back this afternoon (nearing sunset), Oct. 4, and didn't see a single butterfly at the overlook! Went with my 11yo daughter who loves butterflies. It was an amazing experience! Thanks so much for your informative site! We've learned a lot and I hope this info helps!
Plenty of Monarchs here at YMCA Camp Grady Spruce. Observed a couple hundred feeding on the Cowpen Daisys. Tagged and recorded eight. There were more this morning!
Yesterday around 12:30 I watched a flow of monarchs, one by one, fly over my house from north to south at about 7 a minute. Unfortunately, I only got to watch for a total of 5 minutes.
Steady stream of monarchs today. I have two butterfly bushes in my yard. First one spotted at 9:00 am. One,two sometimes three at a time. Some showed a lot of wear and tear on there wings.
they are especially interesting today because there is no wind

Dawn in Cape May Point - the monarchs were up and flying down the dunes.  Everywhere you looked - butterflies in the air!!  They settled into the English ivy and gardens to nectar.  The NW winds were a bit strong on the beach for any to be on the seaside goldenrod.  They were also seen getting moisture off the dewy grass.  While I was swimming in the Bay quite a few flew over me - how fun !!

After several days of rain,plus a foggy morning, the sun appeared at 11 AM bringing temp up to 70 degrees.  Wind was east and very light (5 mph). I observed 25 Monarchs flying in across Salem Bay and arriving on Marblehead Neck between 2:50pm and 3:50pm. They flew in high - above the low fog bank - and dropped down to 6-10 feet when they reached land. They appeared to be flying faster and more steadily than the large number I had observed on 9/19.  Todays Monarchs were flying alone or in pairs in a fairly regular stream about 2 minutes apart.  They were not observed to stop and feed; and I did not see any butterflies circling each other in the 'playful'(?) manner of the earlier migratory groups.

We have been observing more Monarchs passing through our area. The days have been warm with gentle breezes to lift them up.I found an injured Monarch today with a torn wing. It's a male in otherwise good shape except for the wing. Anyone out there know how to make a prosthetic wing?

Monarchs, along with many red admirals, some buckeyes, painted ladies, and mourning cloaks (I counted 16 of them-I thought it was most unusual), arrived in a continuous stream from the north today.  While on the beach between noon and 1:30 I counted 210 monarchs but only watching within my line of vision.  When I looked off shore, I saw many butterflies fighting the wind to get in. In the late afternoon monarchs were roosting in MANY small clusters (the largest I saw was about 50) all over the city, and at the point.  Most were in deciduous trees.
In the last hour saw 12 Monarchs just floating by.  Attached is a photo I took of one of them that stopped  on my hearty ageratum, just like yesterday.
9 AM to 10:30 AM walking along surf line observed butterflies flying alone or in small groups of 3-5. Noted increasing numbers as sun rose higher and clouds cleared off.
Observed lots of Monarchs flying over the soccer fields today at Gardner Webb University.

Friday, Oct 5
The first migrating monarch appeared just before 10am. The NW wind at 4mph brought a steady flight of monarchs down the beach until about noon, when the wind shifted from NW to NNE. That was just what the monarchs needed-- a light NNE wind to take them off the island and over to the Delmarva (and possibly across the Chesapeake). Then late in the day, the wind became SSW. That halted the flight any monarchs that were still on the island. I found some monarchs scattered in small numbers in the Bidens wetlands, but they were all too skittish to net.

Saturday morning, Oct 6
No monarchs to be found anywhere on the island this morning. Hopefully, the ones that passed through yesterday are well on their way down the coast. Weather-wise, this certainly has been an unusual 2 weeks, with higher than normal temperatures and lots of wind from the south. We've had only one brief period of rain, otherwise it has been dry. I noticed yesterday that the Bidens is wilting and even the seaside goldenrod looks droopy. No cold fronts have come through since I've been here, which really is strange. But finally, there is a cold front predicted on Sunday, expected to bring lots of rain followed by cooler temperatures on Monday. It that happens, I would expect one last good wave of monarchs to be riding the North wind. Hopefully that happens in the morning since I must leave by noon.

I just watched a constant one by one flow of monarchs flying over my house from north to south at about 7 a minute for 5 minutes. I live next to the NJ Turnpike. Then I had to go back to work. It is drizzling now so, the flow may slow down.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monarchs woke up early and had a good breakfast on our butterfly bushes and all around town on the goldenrod and ivy down at the point. Many appeared to be heading out today-although we didn't stay on the beach too long this morning.  Not much activity coming into Cape May either.

I spotted the butterflies around 4 pm while working outside with my dad.  They were flying south/ south west.  There were several butterflies at first and then fewer as the evening progressed. We have a butterfly bush and several stopped to take a drink before going on.  It lightly rained off and on during the evening while the butterflies migrated.  It was so cool.  I called my whole family to watch.  They were still flying but it got too dark to see  them anymore.

We viewed solitary monarchs, as well as groups of 25 or so, all moving from northeast to southwest. We were amazed at the high altitude at which some were flying, maybe 150-250 feet high! Many appeared to be gliding on the wind effortlessly.

dozens of monarch butterflies on goldenrod at Pahranagat wildlife refuge today. There were 50-100 butterflies seen in a period of 2hrs that included Painted Ladies,Red Admirals and Monarchs. Majority were monarch.

All monarchs were flying west with 10-15 feet spacing between butterflies and 6-19 feet above ground.  I saw them while on the job driving a forklift along the mill road at Gerdau Steel Mill in Cartersville, GA.

After a few rainy days earlier in the week we finally got some nice warm weather.  With bright sunshine and temperatures in the lower 80's the butterflies were on the move.  While at recess (1:30 pm) on the playground my class spotted a total of ten Monarchs flying from North to South from about 5 to 30 feet above the ground.  When we made attempts net and tag the Monarchs they would quickly gain elevation to avoid capture.  Later in the day about 5:00 pm, while heading north on 321 to Hickory, NC, I spotted three to four more heading the the North to South direction.
Traveling along A1A north from Ormond Beach, FL to Jacksonville Beach, FL many many Monarchs were seen working their way down along the coastline.  At least 200 and probably more.

We were back out in Westhampton Beach on Saturday. We saw about 100 for the approximately four hours out in the afternoon. Some pairs, but mostly singles. I was amazed at what strong flyers they were, as they were traveling west along the dunes into a constant 30 mile per hour wind and making substantial progess. I've noticed that the sightings along the New Jersey coast, mostly around Cape May resemble the sightings we've a little furthur north up the coast.
Monarchs seen at Chateau Elan,  flying toward setting sun, we watched for approx. 20 minutes and mostly flew by one-by-one.

We had our biggest numbers of migrating monarchs this week.  Some students saw 6 in 30 minutes on Tuesday, others saw a few on different days, and one student reported 8 on Thursday.  We hope they have a safe journey to Mexico.

Literally HUNDREDS of Monarchs passing through Catawba County today.

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

About 11:30 the clouds dissipated and temperatures rose rapidly into the 70s here in western Forsyth County, so I took a 20 minute walk around the yard. Most popular nectar plants; aster, bidens, verbena, butterfly bush, mustard.Most Monarchs I have had in the yard at one time in several years. They flew in and flew out all afternoon.

18 Monarch all very fresh

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

From 9:00 to 14:30 I tagged 42 monarchs migrating through Adams Farm in Walpole, MA., just a very small fraction of the hundreds passing through.  Every one I released after tagging flew southwest.  They were drawn to the butterfly bushes in the butterfly garden in a steady, non-stop stream.  Great sight to see.

Numerous monarchs flying over Reynolda Gardens and some stopping to nectar on globe amaranth, zinnias and other flowers.  Tagged 3: 2 males and 1 female.  Also saw a dozen or so within 10 min. the day before floating over the fairgrounds during our Dixie Classic Fair! Most monarchs I've ever noticed flying through the middle of the city during the fall migration.

Spread across Gay Feather (Liatris sp.) which is growing extensively at this time.  Feeding heavily, usually not flying unless disturbed by observer.  Monarchs were on every patch I checked, in some areas with one every 5 or 10 feet.        Total of 500 is a safe estimate based on flower area and density of Monarchs.  It is possibly low.   For example 10 acres of flowers with a Monarch every 20 feet calculates 1400 total.

Con la llegada del frente frio N° 5 a nuestra querida Cd. Acuña llegan a México las esperadas LAS MARIPOSAS MONARCAS....

Con una temperatura de 18 grados y justamente a la hora del receso los alumnos del Jardín de Niños Profr. Apolonio M.
