Avilés, integrantes del club ecológico "911 AL RESCATE DE LA NATURALEZA" fuimos muy afortunados al ver las primeras Monarcas y a las 12:30 del medio día pudimos observar aun más mariposas que pasaban sobre los salones de clase y logramos contar *50 ejemplares* en un tiempo de 30 minutos. Se sentía un viento ligero y eso les permitía avanzar y continuar con su viaje.

Courtesy of Correo Real
most are flying above the tree tops, a few coming down to our yard to rest.  Overcast day, high humidity.

I did not check for overnight roosts, but Monarchs here often do not go to concentrated roosts when overnight temperature is warm, which is was.

Strong South wind all day. Checked about 3pm. Monarchs Spread thinner than yesterday and mostly on the Liatris that was shielded from wind by trees or terrain. Also saw around 30 flying under some of the trees where they sometimes roost. Possibly sheltering from wind. They were not located located uniformly enough to do a statistical estimate of numbers. 150 is direct count. It is possible that more were sheltering in other trees and shrubs which are too numerous to check individually.

My butterfly bush is awash with butterflies this morning ... ever since the sun came out.  I am seeing them arriving at the front of the house --either flying over or around the house to get to the butterfly bush in the back.   What a sight!   I am estimating the #

Check at 8 am. Sunny at that time but has now clouded over. Wind turned calm overnight and remains calm to light from south.

Many perched on trees in sun. Occasionally flying and flushed readily when approached. Located not just near previous roost trees, but also on many smaller trees and larger shrubs. More were already feeding on liatris. I will check in the afternoon to see if number visible has increased. No suggestion of concentrated overnight roosts. Overnight Low 62f so this is not surprising. I had also checked just after sunset the night before and saw none at all, in roosts or otherwise.
The butterflies were sighted along the dunes on the beach!
This morning I have seen 14 flying high. One will fly over then two or five. They keep coming. I will count several times today.

The Kindergartners came in from the playground all excited!  They had spotted a dozen Monarchs flying overhead while they played.  The teacher's assistant confirmed that there was a 'flock' of Monarchs passing overhead.  We have tagged and released 10 newly emerged Monarchs in the last week.  There are still 13 chrysalides and 1 half-grown caterpillar in the classroom.

My first grade class was at Betty G. Ross Park for the Fire Safety Fair.  While we were waiting in line for lunch we began noticing monarchs. We ended up seeing 25 in less than 20 minutes.  This may have continued, but we were too busy to be able to continue counting.  It had been the first sunny, warm spell for several days.
Refueling on my backyard Vitex and Pinta
seeing 20-30 per day nectaring on blue mist and cosmos.  none laying eggs yet.

Peak migration happening here in Dallas.  Just driving around town you can see one or two flying around here and there.  If I wasn't on the lookout for them, they would go un-noticed, but when you get to the garden, they're all over the place.  Easily 60 to 70 nectaring on Gregg's mistflower and Frostweed.  They nectar all day and as night falls they fly up into the live oak trees and roost, but not in big groups like a true roost.  They spread out individually.  The picure is of Frostweed, and it's covered with Monarchs.  When this plant is in bloom, nothing draws them in quite like it.
my friend saw 12 or more monarchs at her home nectaring heavy.

Greetings from the beautiful Eastern Shore of Virginia!  This afternoon I visited Assateague Island and headed to the beach!  I had spoken with a Park Ranger by phone and found out that the monarchs had finally begun arriving the middle of this past week.  The north wind finally kicked in, the rains stopped, and the cool temps finally rose!  On earlier visits these past 2-3 weeks, there had been no real peak sightings, because of low temps, no north wind, plus the goldenrod had not fully bloomed yet! Today was glorious, however!  As I headed to the southern end of the beach area, the monarchs were everywhere nectaring on the huge area of full blooming goldenrod.  There are several acres of the goldenrod covering small dunes and flat places in this wide open area!  There were clusters of  butterflies everywhere I looked...all flitting around or gathered on the plants holding on tight in the breeze and feasting in the beautiful sunshine!  What a sight! No way to really tell an actual number as I couldn't even see how far down the beach this went...it was the first time for me in this spot!  I just walked, watched and took pictures for about 2 hours. The area is truly an "ocean" of goldenrod...and therefore, an "ocean of monarchs"!  I did my "happy dance" all the way back to the car! Oh!  And as a bonus, I even saw a pair mating!  Guess priorities vary, even for monarchs!

I have been tagging for MonarchWatch and monitoring for University of GA; Monarch Health all morning.  Monarchs have been flying from the NE and over Lake Greenwood SW @ about 5 @ minute!  I can't keep up!!!  Many other butterflies are here too.  Painted ladies and Gulf Frittalaries join the wave of orange.  However those black veins stand out and are here.

After three straight days of a rainy dreary cold front, today's 70 degrees and sun was a boom for monarch through Granville and Durham counties, just north of Raleigh NC.

Away from my "migrant traps" I had a few singles on Bidens, goldenrod and aster. But in my nectar superhighway from 2-4pm I tagged at one spot a record 109 monarchs, out of an estimated 900 that were passing through. Nearly all were on Baccharus, with a few on aster, goldenrod, eupatorium, verbena bon. Each swing of the net would scatter the lot, so I put the net down and caught probably 80 of them by hand, picking them off the smaller baccharus shrubs. They were quite intent to nectar!!!

Suprisingly I did not find any that were already tagged, though I did see many of mine again. I got some great photos of clusters of 25-30 monarchs in one field of view, several of them tagged. I could have tagged more but didn't want to run out.

October 12
As last years boom followed by bust, yesterday 10/11 same location, same time, same temp, same clear skies, same nectar, and only 35 monarchs tagged out of 50 seen. NOT dripping from the trees, and only a few caught by hand, my net extension was needed as many were high in the baccharus.

A dozen miles sw along I85 in Durham county I tagged several also on baccharus, and I hope to get some more coveries along this route. From Richmond, VA to Atlanta, GA I85 seems like a likely southwest route to follow. Through the developed cities and even around the non developed Falls Lake area, numbers of monarchs have always ben much higher along what I call the nectar superhighway, which is road shoulders, gravel access roads, power lines and rail lines that parallel I85.

Could it be that the monarchs are following the pavement southwest with many nectar "rest stops"? Could it be that they are catching any wind currents from southbound traffic? Though I have found them on both sides of the road with no clear preference other than where the nectar is!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Greetings again from Virginia's beautiful Eastern Shore!  I went back to Assateague Island yesterday from about noon until 4:00PM to see what the monarchs were doing.  My husband went with me this time because I had been so excited about my wonderful experience on Friday. This time, there was little or no wind, but it was another lovely warm day.  There were fewer monarchs, but still many covering the goldenrod in more widely spread out spaces. We walked the whole large dune area between the ocean and Tom's Cove (probably about 10-15 acres) and certainly got a feel for what a real "all-you-can-eat" buffet this is for these awesome creatures! Bright yellow blooms accented by vibrant orange and black beauties...what a show!!  Indeed, the numbers were not as large as Friday's but there were still many monarchs to see!  With not so much wind, they did not need to fight so hard to enjoy their feast!  Throw in a great picnic lunch for ourselves and a lovely quiet  coastal setting as far as we could see...it was another wonderful day on Assateague Island! It looks like the monarchs are well on their way!

On a partly sunny day with temperatures in the low 70's I spotted approximately 350 monarchs in four hours. In the late afternoon the rain clouds rolled in. The monarchs took to an early roost during the 5 minute rain shower and when the sun returned they took to the sky on their journey.

Monarchs were migrating through central Maryland in good numbers on Wed. Oct 10th. They were seen flying about 30' up over highways and back roads. I didn't see any come down to nectar; the wind they were riding on was just too good. We still have not had a frost, but it the temperature bottomed out at 34 degrees F last night. Nectar sources are still plentiful-- goldenrods and asters in fields, annuals in yards.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Ny friend Jenny S, in Menard, texted last night (10/08): "They're here! Tagged 30 right at dusk--most too high to reach. Going back in the AM for more."

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY
Monarchs streaming along the beach about 50 an hour.

Small area (approximately a square yard) with Texas Blue Mist. Up to 25-30 monarchs at a time on flowers. There are some older monarchs (tattered wing edges) as well as younger ones (color more vivid and wing edges fairly smooth).

I have not seen snouts in the area I monitor.

Large groups-approximately 25-30 at a time on blue mist. There were a few Queens in the group. Again the majority of the monarchs seem to be a newer generation due to their coloring and wing edges.

I have not seen snouts in the area I monitor.

It is about 85 degrees F, and sunny. The monarchs were sighted as I drove from my work to pick up my daughter and then home.

I just taught the look-alike lesson to my gifted 1st graders, and have been watching monarchs for many years. Was riding in a car, so no pictures, but I am very sure they were monarchs. We did see many butterflies, snouts and gulf fritillary’s especially, but only counted the ones we were sure about. The weather that day seems to have been perfect.

Today was the biggest Monarch flight day of the fall here so far.  There had been small numbers a week ago, maybe 5 a day, but today was a constant light stream for several hours of passage.

I'd say I saw at least 500 Monarch marching southbound, in half the day.  I saw 100 per hour for 3 hours, and less than that for 3 or more. Often five at once in a binocular field of view, or scope field of view, or in a 30 degree 5 second pan of horizon.  There were hundreds that went by, due south. They were beating tracks and, since it was coolish with high overcast thermals were limited, they were working.

What I don't know is how big a swath they were occupying. I was only looking east from my place, so can't say if or not as many were going by behind me to the west where I don't have good visibility. And at that really only scanning 45 degrees or so of open space where I can see some distance eastward.  Was using scope and binocs both, and based on how whenever I got a group of migrating vultures and hawks I would spot some way way up in binocs, I'm sure many more were going over out of bare-eyed view.

As I was mostly trying to see hawks, the Monarchs were easy to spot against that perfect ground glass sky here today.  I spotted some up a thousand feet, and more, at the limit of binocular spotting. I'm up on a ridge a couple hundred feet above valley floor so many were going by just a hundred or two feet up, likely not visible from down in town as they move down the divide at the edge of the valley.

The crop this year seems very beat and worn, more so than normal.  Almost all of those I've seen nectaring or roosting at the woods in Utopia park have been shredded, in very poor condition, the best are very worn and pale.  Yes, some are always, but this year it is a higher percentage.  I thought a higher number were flapping faster than normal, presumedly due to torn up wings.

There were hundreds of Monarchs and thousands of Snout.  Today the Monarchs were flying due south, the Snouts due north.  Last week you could tell the Snouts from the Monarchs as the Monarchs go west or west-southwest, and the Snouts east. 

It was a major post-frontal parade today.  It was goin' on.

Mitch Heindel
Utopia Nature
Observed eight monarchs nectaring in our garden over 5 minute period.
Crossing the bridge over Pensacola Bay, I saw 25-30 monarchs.  It was quite difficult to see them, but they extended far out over the water, thus I assume they'd have to have been migrating.

We have been seeing them since October 2, and now PEAK (10/15) stopping on our butterfly bushes from morning to night. Also spotted them the first of October (10/2-3)while playing golf in Dalonegha, GA

We have roughly ten acres of sunflowers that have grown to as high as six feet. I had mowed a few paths in the fields, so I am able to walk out and around the sunflowers. Yesterday there were hundreds of butterflies and finally I realized that they appeared to be Monarchs. I don't know much about the determination of adult or peak migration, however, I do know what a Monarch looks like. It was wonderful. They would float around my head and weren't bothered by the dogs because the sunflowers are so tall. Several times I stopped and watched one gather necter. I didn't have my camera with me!

Hoy a las 11:45 horas salí de la oficina para hacer mi monitoreo diario y me tocó ver un buen flujo de mariposas volando al sur. Las observé por 15 minutos y saqué un promedio de 48/min. Mañana nublada y templada con viento suave.

Courtesy of Correo Real

My friend, Captain Gerald Turan of the shrimp boat Predator, reports that he observed a number of Monarchs resting and nectaring on an "island" of water hyacinths in the Gulf of Mexico about 20 miles due south of Vermillion Bay of Louisiana one day last week.  He was quite amazed to see that these butterflies are very resourceful navigators and finders of nectar.  I don't know the coordinates or the exact time of day, but I found that very exciting and wanted to share it for him because he does not have computer access. The water hyacinths grow in inland waters like ponds, canals and bayous and are washed out to sea sometimes.  He saw the butterflies on Sunday 10/21. The wind was out of the North and a front was passing through the area.

I have not been monitoring high fliers but for the last three days Monarch numbers here at ground level in Sabinal have steadily increased. The numbers are still relatively low compared to a couple of years ago but glad to see some anyway. Their condition appeared to be good with no seriously worn specimens.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

5 adult monarchs nectaring on orange mexican sunflowers (tithonia) in our back gardens at 6 p.m. this small group has been the largest we've seen this fall. they roosted in the white pines close to the garden.

Lots of sightings in the last ten days (10/03-13). Last Saturday Oct. 6, was a big day. Was on a bike ride in the country and the stream was non-stop. Also visited my local Lowes store last week and there were four or five in the garden center constantly visiting a dozen or so Budleia plants. Have had two or three on my Butterfly bush ever day this week (10/14-19). Alas...no tags.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I've heard and read all the talk about the small migration thru central Texas this year and wanted to chime in on my experiences. We have a place along the San Saba River in Menard County, Texas where we have tagged thousands of monarchs over the last 15 years as they come down to roost in the trees at night. Last year, when Texas experienced the worst drought on record the river quit flowing along our land for 6 months. We had no butterflies roosting in our trees, but further up the river where there was still water in the river, we were able to observe and tag hundreds.

This year, the river is flowing and the monarchs were there. Not as great We tagged 450 over 3 days last weekend (Oct 11-13). There was a strong SW wind all week which kept the little guys in the trees for 4 days and made it easy for us to observe and tag. After a big rainstorm Saturday (10/20) night, they left the river bottom and were gone on Sunday.

At my friends ranch, also in Menard county, Texas and along a spring fed creek that never goes dry, she has had wonderful numbers of monarchs last year and this year. We tagged 125 in her giant pecan trees during and one hour time period in the middle of the day. All seemed to be roosting, very few were nectaring. However, there were hundreds of Queens nectaring in the abundant frost weed, blue mist, and maximillian sunflowers. She reports they were still there in large numbers on Wednesday (the 17th). So, I guess it just depends on where you are.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Hundreds of Monarch butterflies were stuck in a holding pattern this weekend (10/20-21) along the Llano River as 20-mile-per-hour wind gusts postponed their journey south. We observed several small roosts and many clusters. All were holding tight to pecan tree branches or seeking refuge in the low persimmon trees hugging the Llano’s limestone cliff embankments when not battling the winds in their attempt to move south.

My husband and I tagged more than 130 Monarchs in 24 hours. The insects’ orange-and-black coloring made them perfectly camouflaged in the autumn colors of the pecan tree leaves–even more so in dappled afternoon light. While Monarch butterflies were ubiquitous, their numbers appeared drastically reduced compared to years past.How to tell? Usually, we see clusters of hundreds. This year it was clusters of 10s and 20s.

Of the hundreds we saw this weekend, only one Monarch butterfly was spotted nectaring. Usually dozens of Monarchs break from their flight in the late afternoons and evenings to fuel up on abundant Frostweed or Goldenrod. Not this year. The insects seemed hell-bent on moving south.

Trolling up and down the banks of our stretch of river, we spotted the tenacious flyers fighting the wind, pushing into its gales, only to be forced back with a wind gust and advancing only a few yards south at a time. As Sunday afternoon rolled around, we found ourselves netting Monarchs tagged on Saturday, thus making the case that their efforts to move south were stymied.

While nectar sources have been depleted because of the drought, Frostweed, Poverty weed, purple mistflower, goldenrod, water hemlock and other late season bloomers awaited Monarchs’ this weekend, But they didn’t seem interested.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
On the Loop Trail of Enchanted Rock, there were hundreds of butterflies covering the branches of a single Texas Oak Tree.

Desde el 5 de octubre y hasta el pasado 19 de octubre, he observado el paso de las Mariposas en un trayecto entre Jiménez, Coahuila y la Presa la Amistad, entrando a Territorio mexicano provenientes de Texas, la mayor parte el clima ha estado entre los 18 a 24 grados centígrados, teniendo días medio nublados y algo de humedad, también me tocó verlas descansando sobre los encinos que hay en la presa la Amistad por centenas de ellas y revoloteando para continuar su viaje. Los últimos días solo las he observado volando a baja altura en dirección de norte a sur y muy pocas, quizá de 5 a 6 por minuto.

Próximamente entrará otro frente frío que seguramente empujará a las rezagadas y veremos más todavía.

Courtesy of Correo Real

They are definitely flying through today. They are a ragged-tagged group flying toward their destination. I saw them coming through 2-3 at a time within my yard as well as the golf course across the street.  Some were singles, of course.

This morning surprised me-while eating breakfast with a friend on the beach front I witnessed monarchs floating down the dunes!! At first I thought, well, maybe a few today, but one of the monarch monitoring team members reported 36 in 3 minutes flying by, our intern counted 62 in 20 minutes flying by and at the end of the day the census was 136.5 per hour!!  It was a warm day with variable winds; north, west, north east....  So, they continue to visit Cape May on their way to Mexico - makes us smile here ((-:
observed 12 monarchs  feeding on mexican sunflowers

I was back at Fort Morgan Saturday and Sunday last week (10/20-21) and there are monarchs galore. I didn't attempt a count. It would be especially difficult since there were so many Gulf Fritillaries. The photo below is typical of the area, which is a restricted part of the refuge, but it is many acres covered with these yellow daisy like flowers with Monarchs, Fritillaries, and a few other species in countless numbers.

I have not been there at dusk or dawn, so can't speak to roosting, but may very well be there at dawn this coming weekend (10/27-28).

Yesterday the gardens were filled with nectaring monarch butterflies!  The monarch monitoring team tagged well over 150 butterflies!!  The number sighted was from one of the census runs but anywhere you looked in gardens you could see monarchs - what a year!!!

On Tuesday 10/9 at about 10:00 am we were driving up the Horseshoe Meadows Road in the Inyo NF when we saw many 100's of Monarchs feeding on Rubber Rabbitbrush along the side the road. it was at about the 6000-7000' level. It was cool (55-60) and cloudy with a Cold Front coming in.  We did our hike and returned to the area about 4-5 hours later, and none were to be seen.  By that time it was very windy and spitting snow.

During the first week of Oct, I noticed the monarchs starting to hang around outside in the trees.  They were very active BUT there were soooo many LESS than last year. I was waiting for the rest of the monarchs to show up any time but they never did.  Then, on the night of Oct 25th, a cold front came in.  The monarchs left just as they did last year with a cold front the end of Oct.

I was walking in the park and 1 day before there were no Monarchs but today I saw like 50+ in no more than 10 minutes, all flying in the same direction. Today a cold front entered the town so I think the winds brought them. Its the first and biggest monarch sighting of this year. Previous to this I personally saw no monarchs.

Went to Fort Morgan today under dark gray skies and North winds gusting to 25 mph.  Don't know what Monarchs do on days like this but they were not where they were last weekend.  I spent some time walking the South side of a small wooded area and found numerous (maybe 500 individuals) along about 1/4 mile of the woodland edge.  Some photos from today are attached.

I have attached 3 shots of Monarchs on bottle brush bushes at the Fairhope pier this afternoon. There were several hundred just on this one clump of bushes and there are many other bottle brush bushes in this park, so there could easliy be 1,000 here alone. By the way this park is on the Eastern shore of Mobile Bay and any Monarch headed south or west could hardly resist stopping here to dine on the bottle brush before heading across the bay.

The wind has been strong out of the northwest and now down to north @ 11 mph. We saw the first monarch on the peninsula at the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway midafternoon yesternoon (10/27).It was staying at the height of the grass along the edge of bay as did the few that followed.

Today (10/28) we saw the first coming across the causeway on our first trip over at 11:00. We let it calm down a bit more and at 1:00 there was a good trickle coming from the NE. We saw about 60 in 25 minutes some flying hard to the SW, others nectaring on a thin row of camphor daises that TXDot couldn't mow. Coming back across the causeway in the 3 minutes that I looked at the clock, we drove by or under 8 monarchs crossing Lavaca Bay.

Now to see what they are doing later when the wind calms a bit more and temp gets into the 70's ... Altus is getting her netting gear ready ... tomorrow may be the best day before the wind turns to the east.

i observed the monarch butterflies at natural bridges park. there were a lot of big beautiful butterflies flying around between the eucalyptus trees. at the time my class was visiting it was foggy. we visiting . we all had to be very quiet when we were observing the butterflies . our guide informed us that more butterflies come out when the weather is warmer.

Ayer viernes 26 de Octubre me tocó ver infinidad de monarcas en mi trayecto de Cd Acuña, Coah. hasta Monterrey, por la carretera se atravesaban a cada momento pero para fortuna volaban un poco más arriba que los autos, como iba manejando no las conté fielmente pero mas de 100 a 150 si lo fueron y sobretodo en el tramo de Morelos hacia Sabinas y Monclova.

Este día en los alrededores de Acuña, muy temprano por la mañana tras la llegada del frente frío me tocó ver varios mezquites con monarcas descansando en ellos y tomé varias fotos. Ya para media mañana, alrededor de las 10am se empezaron a ver volando más constantemente, en un lapso de 10 min conté 65 individuos, de los cuales el máximo en un minuto fue de 15 ejemplares. Hoy hemos visto un total de 147 ejemplares en hora y media. De las 9:00 a las 9:15 vi solamente 11, casualmente como ayer, casi a razón de 1 por minuto. Hoy fueron casi 2 por minuto* durante la hora y media de observación. Como fue aumentando la temperatura aumentó la frecuencia. A las 9 había 15 grados y ya estaba soleado, casi sin viento (soplaba ligeramente del sur? no sé por qué) Al concluir la observación había 19 grados.Esta vez el vuelo fue más bajo. La mayoría pasaban sobre los árboles, con un vuelo más tranquilo y despreocupado. Dos de ellas se detuvieron atraídas por una anacua en floración y permanecieron allí por más de una hora.

Casi al concluir la observación, fue haciéndose un grupo de 5 o 6 (ya en lo arriba no puedo asegurar cuántas eran) que formaron espiral y se perdieron en lo alto.

I noticed about half a dozen Monarchs from November 1-3, 2012, feeding on orange zinnias in my garden. (I am not associated with teaching. I am an amateur naturalist.)

I was seeing them from the first of November, for a number of days, but wehad our first freeze here on November 12th, and while there are stillbutterflies (& moths) during the warm days, I have not seen any Monarchssince the freeze (as of November 19th).

This morning at 10am, I observed 6 monarch butterflies flying thru my neighbor. They were all females and in groups of 3 and they stopped, laid eggs on my milkweeds and drank some nectar. But they were more interested in laying their eggs. They are so beautiful, 2 landed on me; one on my shoulder and one on my hand.

Monday, 8/26 was the first day we saw significant number of adult Monarchs this summer. They were feeding mostly on our Meadow Blazingstars. Some were roosting in the shade - it has been hot here the past few days. I scared up ~12 from one 10x10 foot patch of shade.

We walked our trails, around our 15 acres, Monday evening, and although we saw Monarchs beginning to roost on trees in many spots, they were singles and maybe a couple times we saw two in proximity.

I was paying special attention to the Monarchs since our Audubon chapter co-sponsors a public tagging event each August, and this summer has been very sparse for Monarchs and indeed for many species of butterflies. They showed up just in time for Tuesday evening's event. We had over 80 people, about half kids, and tagged and released over 100 Monarchs. Quarry Hill Nature Center would have the numbers, and they manage the tags and data. This has been a great way to interest folks in butterflies.

We're up to 50 monarchs nectaring at our large planting of Meadow Blazing Star in our suburban prairie garden. It started with 3 butterflies 8/21 and has been increasing each day to 8/28 total of 50. During the evening the butterflies roost scattered widely throughout our trees and nearby trees, not in a traditional cluster. Observed a few pairs mating, so not all of these butterflies are preparing to migrate.

50 was my highest one-day nectaring count (50 butterflies here all at one time - it gets hard to count!). They've been slowing building each day since 8/21. eg on 8/27 I counted 42 nectaring at once, on 8/26 33 nectaring at once, etc. We had a bumber crop of meadow blazing star this year as well, so we're luring them in. I'm surprised and glad since we saw only a couple of adults and had fewer caterpillars than past years on the milkweed this summer.

Our front yard prairie garden is roughly 280 square feet and we put it in 3 years ago (using mostly adult bare-root plants - no seeding). This year we have a whopping 60 flower stems of the blazing star. We also have about 60 square feet prairie/rain garden in the back yard with another 12 blazing star stems. And another 500 square feet of woodland gardens split between front and back.

Dozens of monarchs seen nectaring on Meadow Blazingstar (Liatris ligulistylis) adjacent to Hwy 19 and railroad tracks, 2 miles east of Winthrop, Minnesota, Aug. 28, 2013. 44.542860 -94.314613

I toured the GMO corn and soybean monocultures of south-central and southwestern Minnesota Aug. 27-29 as that is the region and time window when fall migrant monarchs are typically the most numerous.

I found numbers of migrants were very low by historical Minnesota standards, but common by western USA standards. The alfalfa fields had only widely scattered individuals and no roosts were found in the evening adjacent to those fields as would be typicalin an average or high monarch population year.

Meadow Blazingstar (Liatris ligulistylis) - was blooming strongly this year and many monarchs - sometimes dozens - were seen in patches of those plants that were typically located adjacent to railroad tracks. In a 4 minute video I shot (above) of one such largepatch that had dozens of monarchs.

Overall, it appears the fall migrant population in southern Minnesota is moderately lower than last August. And like last August, it was difficult to find caterpillars (I didn't see any). Thus at this point it appears the overwintering population in Mexico could possibly lower than last winter. However, the summer monarch breeding populationin the huge region between Iowa and Texas and westward to the Rocky Mountains may to be higher (based on mid-late summer sighting reports to Journey North) this year and could potentiallyboost the numbers of fall migrants entering Texas and Mexico to levels near or above those seen last year. We should know by early October based on the number and size of the "fall roost" reports to Journey North.

Paul CherubiniEl Dorado, Calif.

Joyous event! At 11:30 today I observed roughly 12 adult monarchs nectaring on Meadow Blazing Star in an 8-foot boulevard garden of native plants on my urban street! Prior to this, I had only seen two monarchs all summer. Several were clustered on the same stem while others fluttered around. An hour later I walked past again (this was on a dog walk) and now the number was up to about 16! We startled them into a flutter but they soon settled down again to nectar. It was amazing after such a dearth of sightings. This appears to be the preferred garden, even though I have some of the same plants 1 block away. Go monarchs!

Counted 49 adult Monarchs in the prairie pasture and the yard early this evening.  21 individuals were perching in trees in the yard and the grove; none were clustered or perched together, or even close to one another, just singularly.

We had 51 adult Monarchs on the property this evening, 21 of which were in the yard flitting in and out of the trees or perching on branches...the rest were still nectaring in the prairie pasture.  Those in the yard were not clustering although some branches contained two or three individuals.  Would 21 in a yard in different trees be construed as a roost?  Our past roosts have always had dozens or more  sharing the same branches.

All week I have been seeing more Monarchs than I have seen all summer.  They were mainly on my newly blooming Meadow Blazing Star.  It has been so hot and dry almost all of my nectar plants have gone to seed.
Lowest number sighted in years and years.

On a beautiful sunny, 80 degree day with a moderate north wind I spotted 18 monarchs fluttering by in a three hour period. They were flying from east to west and mostly solo. This is the first sign of the migration I have witnessed this season. The monarchs were flying with dragonflies and damselflies. I counted in upwards of over 1000 dragonflies, so the monarchs should hopefully be arriving shortly. More than half of the pinetrees in the area where the monarchs traditionally roost overnight were destroyed by Hurricane Sandy, so although food is abundant, not sure what will happen at nightfall.

Yesterday, Sept. 6, I cycled to Toronto Islands and checked out the Centre Island ornamental gardens and Hanlan's Point. I also briefly checked a few ornamentals en route to the islands. I tallied a total of 53 Monarchs (the most I've seen this year), 41 of them on the islands which is normally a hot spot for this species in migration. This is just a fraction of what I would normally see there at this time.

Forwarded courtesy of Don Davis.

Yesterdays (6 Sept.) cool overnight temperatures, sunny sky and N-NWwind. Triggered the first noteable Monarch migration of the season at Monarch Landing (one mile east of Port Burwell-north coast, central basin-Lake Erie.). A fairly regular stream of Monarchs were pushed from the north and ended up below the cliff face, sheltered from the north wind and moving S-W along the north shore of Lake Erie. Ten minute counts, three times an hour averaged about a butterfly a minute, for about six hours so I estimated between 350 and 400 monarchs passed by Monarch Landing yesterday. Most of these did not stop ,andÂ  these numbers, are very light for these dates and weather conditions (based on 16 years of counting at this location). However considering Monarch numbers over the season it is at least a flow heading to Mexico.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Today (7 Sept.), with S-W breezes off the lake, Monarchs were above the cliff and more likely to stop to nectar on the goldenrod and liatris. I estimated a total of perhaps 250 Monarchs for the day.

Forwarded courtesy of Donald Davis.

What a joy it was to count 20 butterflies dropping down into the prairie and nectar together.  In year's past we would be seeing many more,but this is the largest group we have seen all year. They really seemed to gravitate to the Ironweed plants!

Checked several alfalfa fields in bloom this afternoon, and all of them had feeding monarchs.  Counted a dozen in the first, and a dozen in the last.  In between, I checked half a dozen fields where I saw 3-6.  I can safely assume that there were many times more monarchs than I saw.  Conditions here have been dry and warm and today is very windy, mostly west but with a northern bias.  One farmer I talked to said that because it has been so dry he does not plan to cut his alfalfa.  Perhaps others are doing the same.  I am entering this in the PEAK migration category for a couple of reasons.  For one, I have never made an entry here before.  For another, I am calling this DesperationMigration2013.  I had just about given up on a late hatch and flight but today is proving me wrong.  There will definitely be roosts tonight.  Even though current temperatures are 80+, the night is supposed to bring 50s........the monarchs will know.Tomorrow is supposed to be northerly winds, so today's monarchs will probably be gone.  Perhaps I will be lucky enough to catch new sightings on these same fields.If so, tomorrow night should be another good roosting night, with temps perhaps reaching the 40's.

Today, between 10:30 AM and 2:30 PM, I counted 224 monarchs heading south and southwest down the Lake Huron shoreline. Some had landed on the wet beach spots where I tagged 13. Weather was sunny with high fluffy clouds with the Wind NW-10-15 mph and temperatures 67 to 73 degrees F.

A South-west wind over the last few days ( September 10-12) resulted in a larger group of Monarchs in the prairie near lake Michigan.  As soon as the wind started blowing from the  North East, on the afternoon of the 12th, the majority left.  We only spotted 1 monarch today (September 13).  We miss seeing them, but wish them well on their journey.

I got to the wildlife area where I work around 10am & foundour extensive fields of flowering Maximilian sunflowers holdingsurprisingly good numbers of feeding Monarchs! I tagged 25rather quickly remembering that I only tagged a total of 13monarchs during the 2012 migration here in NE Kansas. They all appeared on the north winds of a passing cold front whichcame through this area yesterday. I couldn't make it out thisevening to look for their roost, but will give it a shot after I tagsome more tomorrow. We'll update then...:)

I couldn't locate their roost today due to the light rain & unfavorable winds, but I was able to find small pocketsof Monarchs feeding on pink thistle flowers along my wildlife area roads. I ended up tagging 15 which brings my tag total this migration to 50!...:)

On 9/11, Wednesday, Mr. Val Rukavena of Minnetonka, MN, rode his motorcycle from Minnetonka to Chaska to Carver to Belle Plaine and back (80 miles round trip). Weather was still warm, sunny, but the winds had switched so that on this day the winds were from the N/NE. During his ride he observed dozens of migrating monarchs heading south. Most were single monarchs, and a few seemed to be in pairs. Jim remarked that the observation by Mr. Rukavena was "significant" , because Jim himself has not observed any monarch migration of this magnitude, and instead has seen only a few migrating monarchs, usually only single monarchs heading south through his yard.
178 Monarchs moved through Hawk Cliff, near Port Stanley, Ontario today. A noted surge was between 2:00-4:30.
Four adult migrants sighted.Two of these four caught and tagged.Perhaps peak migration for this location.
I have seen one monarch the entire summer.  Then today there were 10 in a short span of time.  I hope they have a successful migration.
Close to 500 Monarchs passed through Hawk Cliff, just east of Port Stanley, Ontario. Finally,a visible migration as Monarchs can be seen gliding along the edge of the cliff. 67 were tagged.

I tagged 18 more Monarchs today out on the windy & hot wildlife area. The strong southwest wind kept most of theMonarchs out of the migration mode as they were feedingmostly on pink thistle blooms in shaded, sheltered areas.

A little more than a hour to sunset, I spotted 16 monarchs all roosting in individual pine trees. The day was sunny with a light variable wind with temps in th mid 60's. Nightfall the temperature dropped to the low 40's. The few monarchs I spotted looked healthy.

I saw about 15 monarchs in Webster Groves MO at Larson Park at about four o'clock in the evening.
Seven migrants sighted.Of these, five were caught and tagged.Perhaps the peak migration day, given the sparse numbers this year.

They moved in near sunset (19 Sept.) and roosted in elm and hackberry trees. They are behind a large weather front that brought rain and cooler temperatures. They appear to be settled in for night in several of the same trees and branches of previous years. There were well over 100 in one corner of the farm. Because of the darkness I couldn't check the rest of the farm. It was quite a sight to behold to see them move in!
Observed 265 monarchs, 90% high flyers, in a southerly direction. Observation time was 12:50 to 2:50 PM with 90% cloud cover and a temperature of 71°F. Winds NNW at 9 mph.

We noticed the dark cloud of butterflies coming in from the North of our property.  As they flew in we noticed it was Monarch butterflies. The temperature had suddenly dropped significantly and there were some scattered thunder storms scattering our area.  The Butterflies roosted in one of our tall pine trees, seemingly hunkering down until the storms passed.  (The storms all missed us)  This all occured at dusk.  We observed until dark.  When we woke in the morning they were gone.

Total 23 caught: 10 females, 13 Males

Birding, primarily, but there were numerous monarchs and queen butterflies everywhere and a fair amount of a milkweed species.  Number is approximate, but there were a *lot* of monarchs. Location ~ 15 miles S. of Yates, NM.
151 Monarchs moved westward, under very favorable conditions through Hawk Cliff, just east of Port Stanley,Ontario.

As we hoped with the NW winds today the monarchs were slowly making their way into Cape May along the dunes.  I counted 1 monarch about every minute coming in for about one hour.  When I surveyed the gardens around Cape May Point there were clumps of monarchs feeding on English Ivy flowers.  Some groups were as big as 40 other ivy had approximately 20, some only 10.  It was so nice to see the numbers increase today ((-:  And yes, there was a roost found with about 100 monarchs this evening!!!!  Happy people in Cape May.

I had ten monarchs nectaring on mainly New England Aster. They also like buddleia and tropical milkweed. In the past I've had as many as a hundred, but these days, ten seems like a lot.Normally this might not make the Peak Migration list, but with numbers being down, you may have to adjust your criteria.

We are seeing Monarchs everywhere now.  Pottsville Schools are situated in the middle of 100 + acres of what was farmland.  Wildflowers grow around the ponds and creek providing plenty of feeding opportunities.  On an outing to make observations, numerous Monarchs were spotted flying over and then feeding on the flowers.  Later in the day,  as I drove home (20 miles of interstate towards the west) I observed a Monarch every few minutes flying over the roadway, all southern bound.  My milkweed patch has numerous eggs and some newly hatched larva.

This week has been a gift.  We are seeing a secondary peak migration here, thanks to the warm weather and a number of emerging monarchs.Tuesday, the 24th of September, I saw about 18 monarchs on a blooming alfalfa field, perhaps 20-30 acres.Today there were only two there that I saw from my car, but I suspect there were probably many more.Other fields confirmed that monarchs were widespread.  I checked eight different alfalfa fields in bloom, some peaking, some not, some half cut, but all with plentiful nectar.  Sightings ranged from two to six, but in every case, I feel safe in estimating that there were twice as many there, perhaps three or four times as many.......All my sightings came sitting in a car with binoculars, covering only a portion of the field.  In addition, the plush alfalfa and blooms made sightings tough.In addition, I saw a new emergee on the back hill and another monarch flying south along the ground in the morning, causing me to believe that part of their day is spent migrating, even though the wind is consistently SE.I saw 29 monarchs today; I believe the fields held closer to 100.  Remarkable for this late date.  Bad news is that winds are forecast to remain from the south for the next four days.
I observed about 20 Monarch butterflies per hour on this day. It was warm and clear skies.

We tagged 52 today in three hours at Lynde Shores Conservation Area in Whitby, and just in time because I am making a presentation in a grade 1 and kindergarten class tomorrow. The students will each be able to release a tagged Monarch.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Ann, Eric, Blake, and Kendall caught 41
And Dale Goetz caught 50+ by noon in Overland Park.
After 11AM monarchs were not as apparent, perhaps because they had ascended on thermals and were no longer at ground level.

This is the first day this year we have seen a "flow" of monarchs through the area. Such flows have been seen as early as the 10th of September as the leading edge of the migration arrives in this area. However, "first flows" are more commonly observed on the 15th-16th September.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

As others have documented Monarchs were seldom seen this season, but beginning this week numbers picked up daily. It sounds ridiculous compared to what we've seen in prior years, but we saw 12 monarchs on one Buddleia with many more throughout our gardens. I can't but underscore the decrease in numbers from prior falls-where we would see so many-it was as if a tree had suddenly dropped all it's leaves. Let us hope that next years numbers will increase-our nectar garden will be waiting.

Frequently, within the last week I've noticed about 7-14 Monarch butterflies on about 10 Tropical Milkweed plants volunteers planted in our K-State Extension garden here at work. Hard to get a photo with the wind blowing but a detail shot is enclosed.
sighting of monarch butterflies heading south to Mexico

I don't know if at least 8 adults in our yard at once qualifies as a roost.  I was surprised to see so many.  We have never before had this many at once.  There were both males and females.The attached photo is of a male.
From 10 AM to 11 AM we counted 30 monarchs. Low flying, feeding, moving in a southerly direction. Clear skies, 55°F, and calm winds.

47 Monarch (all fresh, males an female, all nectaring on Red Clover and avoiding the breeze off the lake (SW wind) nearby; that is the direction they fly when crossing the lake or migrating down the beach using the bluff as windbreak)nectaring, (not roosting or  "doing the leaf-mimic wait for favorable winds")sunny , slight SW breeze in the early afternoon

While driving out of Manitowoc WI, north on Johnson drive(about 2 miles west of Lake Michigan) I spotted 7 Monarchs flying south west. This is the most Monarchs I have seen in the wild for the entire season! Eggs were found in our area as late as Sept 1st. I still have 8 chrysalis that will emerge by next week. A friend of mine still had a caterpillar as of Sept 25th.

As I stepped put of the house shortly after 10AM this morning, the first thing that caught my eye was a monarch feeding on Verbena bonariensis. Then I spotted two more feeding on a vitex I maintain for honey bees. We usually only see one or two around the house over a more extended period.

On the way into the lab I spotted 10 more monarchs in flight. I checked the garden when I arrived and found at least 7 more feeding on various nectar sources. This movement is similar to what we witnessed on Wednesday the 25th. The numbers aren't great but monarchs are still moving through. That's good news but for these butterflies to make it to MX, the conditions have to be favorable for the next month as they move further south in the US and then through and along the mountains in Mexico. Given the relatively recent rains here and there in TX and in northeastern Mexico, the conditions for the rest of the migration are looking good.

An analysis of the tagging data has shown that monarchs migrating early have the best chance of reaching Mexico. Let's hope these late migrants reach the overwintering sites in good condition.

The flow of monarchs continued throughout the day with 7- 25 monarchs in the garden most of the late morning and afternoon. The numbers are good for this late in the season but not unusual. Overall the monarch numbers in this migration are far below normal and they are late. The lateness may be due to a number of factors including late arrival in the northern breeding areas and the unusually warm first half of the month.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I tagged 32 in just over an hour at Lynde Shores (next to Cranberry Marsh Hawk Watch). This is the same place I tagged over 50 on Wednesday. As reported by Don re. other locations, some of the people who are regulars at Lynde Shores remarked that they are seeing more monarchs now than they have all summer. At a similar date a year ago we tagged 5.It does look as if we are observing a late surge. Hopefully there will be enough nectar sources to enable their journey southward!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

At our first meeting of the Toronto Entomologists' Association today (9/28), a number of members noted seeing more monarchs than they have seen all year. All week has been sunny, with temperatures above 70 F. These monarchs have traveled from points north and east, and when they reach Lake Ontario, they continue westward, with some flying directly across the lake when there are favourable conditions. Numbers still low, but the peak seems later this year. Perhaps because we had a cool, damp and late spring?

Some reports:

Steve Laforest: I counted 31 Monarchs at Pumphouse Marsh in Oshawa (east of Toronto) on Thurs. Sept. 26, 2013. This was by far my best count of the year, including all of our butterfly counts. They all looked very fresh.

Bob Yukich reports counting 79 monarchs on Thurs. Sept. 26 on the "ornamentals" in High Park, a 400 acre urban park west of the downtown core of the city, stretching north from Lake Ontario to Bloor Street. Also over 60 the following day.

Courtesy of Don Davis

Sighted several flying over our house from the north to the south one hour prior to sunset.

This is a mowed utility trail that runs parallel with the main road. We followed this trail for about an hour. We counted 42 adult monarchs visiting a field of mostly Maximilian Sunflowers. This field contains some liatris, and goldenrod, but the golden rod was mostly spent, and the liatris was sparse. The butterflies we counted looked robust, and healthy. We were only able to identify one male and wondered about that, though we were not able to check the gender of each butterfly we counted. In total this is about half of the number of butterflies we normally see in this area. But given the years of drought before in this region, the poor things were hit pretty hard in previous years. The time we spent on that trail was 1.5  hrs and the time we visited was 1:30 pm til about 3pm .
Flew over my yard about 10-30ft high one by one for about 20 minutes then stopped counting, heading in a southerly direction

We returned to the roosting site we visited last night and counted a lot more butterflies. 121 Butterflies, and I am sure given the size of the fields of sunflowers that we didn't get all of them.  We observed this field for about 30 minutes, at 10:30 AM this morning

The monarchs were nectaring on the butterfly bush along with a hummingbird. There were several in late morning, a few in early afternoon and a few in late afternoon.  We tried taking pictures with the app we downloaded, but the app just froze after the camera snapped inside the Journey North app.  We will try again. This is the most monarchs we have seen in 2 years.

I spent 4 hours in the morning and 2+ hours in the afternoon in my back yard and sighted 14 different Monarchs.  Most flew across the yard, pausing briefly for a few sips at a butterfly bush then flew on south.  A few stayed to nectar.
There were literally hundreds of monarchs all over the flowers at the Myriad Gardens per Chad OKbirds Listserve.

We checked the utility trail again, and conducted a short recount. We are starting to see more males in this bunch. We also observed a larval monarch, but it was on a Liatris. We have seen that before, but it was sickly. We tried to collect it but it launched itself into the grass and were unable to find it. We see no milkweed in that area. What there might be is spent and died back or has been mowed down in the brush near the roads. The common milkweed in this area is Green Antelope Horn Milkweed. Because of it's green flowers many people don't realize that it's a milkweed or a flower. They expect oranges and pinks like the ornamental milkweeds sold in the stores as bedding plants.

While we were working at Waystation 6165 we tagged several Monarch Butterflies. We could have tagged more as they were very numerous on the French Marigolds and the Zinnias.I am saving tags ( I have only 50 this year) for the 20 chrysalids I still have left. These should all be on their way south by Oct. 8. which is about a week later than they have left in the past.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Late flow - day 7. While I didn't see any monarchs in flight as I drove in this morning, there were at least 20 monarchs in our Monarch Waystation at 10AM. In addition, there were a dozen or so visiting the flowers in the front of the building. Given all the bleak reports we've heard, and have passed along, these numbers are gratifying. It will be interesting to learn if these late migrants successfully make it to the wintering sites in Mexico. It is late enough in the season at this latitude to worry about the probability of actually surviving the long journey ahead.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Detroit River Hawk Watch

Early overcast skies became gradually clearer throughout the day. Fog limited visibility for a few hours in the morning but quickly burned off. The wind was light and variable.

Monarchs (50+) were abundant in the afternoon.

Separate sighting in fields around the roost: 87 sighted in all not counting butterflies that took to the cottonwood. 21 on the west side of the road, 66 on the East side. There were probably more than that, because some parts of this sunflower field are not visible from the roadside and it extends a couple hundred yards to the highway directly South, and for at least half a mile going both east and west of the bridge. There are also extensive sunflower/goldenrod fields across the bridge crossing I-240 that go on for several miles in every direction. We noted that there were many more males in this bunch than in the first days sightings.

I spent a couple of hours at Olbrich Botanical Gardens yesterday. They have several Buddleia shrubs planted in pots and raised up on platforms. There were too many monarchs at the gardens for me to count them. Excellent spot for observing the migration in late September/early October.

A friend of mine in Sturgeon Bay WI called me this afternoon to let me know that she had a steady stream of Monarchs flying through & feeding in her yard today. The winds were lighter today as compared to the strong southerly winds of previous days.

Late flow - day 8. It was misty this morning and no monarchs were on the move as I drove to the lab. During a walk through in the garden at 10AM I flushed up at least 14 monarchs and one just flew past my window. So, a fair number of monarchs are still in the area -- 2 days before the end of the "migration window" (4 October)- the date at which the sun angle declines to 47 degrees above the horizon at noon at this latitude. We see monarchs after this date but the numbers diminish rapidly and tagging shows that the probability of monarchs reaching Mexico is less than 1/15th that of monarchs tagged within the migration window.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Counted 30 highflyers from 1230 to 1:30 PM. 72Â°, cloudy, wind southeast at 6 mph.

On a gorgeous sunny 80 degree day, between 2 -3 pm I spotted 28 Monarchs mostly feeding on golden rod along the south shore beach of Long Island. Similar to yesterday the monarchs were flying from east to west and looked very healthy. I truly hope this continues through the weekend.

Holiday Beach Conservation Area

Observation time:07:00:00-14:30:00
A mostly cloudy day, although the predicted rain lasted all of 10 minutes and came just before Noon EST. Temperature ranged from 19 - 23C. Winds started out of the E, but then shifted S after 3 hours. Wind speeds only slightly exceeded 6 km/hr on a couple occassions.

We had the highest count so far this year for Monarch Butterflies at 57. For the month of September 2013 we have counted 177 Monarchs compared to 495 in September 2012.

Monarchs have been flying in from the Northeast all morning, nectaring, and leaving to the Southwest. At any given time there have been two to five on the tropical milkweed. Also had an adult female emerge from its chrysalis this morning. Link to Picasa web album.  https://picasaweb.google.com/JohnVincentAlexander/MonarchEmergesOct42013?authkey=Gv1sRgCLf83fu7ja2rvAE#5930949459803369682

Hawk Cliff Hawkwatch

Monarch butterflies were on the move today; a count was taken during the last half hour of the hawk watch with 54 seen migrating close to the cliff. Many were flying fairly high, although a few were seen passing just below the edge of the cliff above the beach with a few flying out over the water.

Weather conditions at Clearville Park are perfect today. 75 F, very humid, sunny with light winds. A steady stream of Monarchs are flying south west along the Lake Erie shore line on their way to Pt. Pelee where they will roost until favourable weather conditions take them across the lake to Ohio.  About 300 butterflies per hour are moving through Clearville Park at tree top level or higher with the odd one dropping down to fill up on nectar. Native nectaring plants such as Golden Rod and the various types of Aster plants at Clearville Park are still abundant and in good condition. Weather conditions are expected to hold through tomorrow with change occurring on Sunday, Oct 6. It is not unusual to see a good migration tail this time of year. What was unusual this year was the lack of butterflies during the normal peak migration which occurs around Sept 15 at Clearville Park.

Report from the field North Texas: In 25 minutes, observed 15 monarchs heading south; Highest rate this season; to date it's the peak, but the next couple of days and in to this week could see higher rate, or sustain this rate; Cold front just passed thru day before- today day time temp = 70 degree and skies are clear; slight wind out of the north- perfect migrating weather!
There were many many adult Monarchs nectaring in Arcadia Trail Park particularly on Maximillian Sunflowers and Broomweed.

This year's arrival of large numbers is about a week EARLIER than we usually get peak migration. Varies year to year of course, mostly with timing of cold fronts and wind direction.

Today's estimate of 500 monarchs is a safe low end estimate. If your asked me if 1000 or more was possible, I would say yes. Spread through liatris growing in many locations on our property. Direct count and even estimates are challenging, because flowers grow mostly intermingled with tall prairie grass. Can't see Monarchs from very far away and even then, when wings are folded they are very difficult to spot. Have to sit and wait for them to open wings. I did do a couple quick transits in truck to verify the estimate is in the right order of magnitude.

Image shows Monarch on Gayfeather growing in Little Bluestem prairie grass. They are not all this hard to see, but it illustrates why migrating monarchs, even in large numbers,  may be overlooked.  There were many more Monarchs within feet of this one   You have to walk through and stir them up, or sit and watch for a long time for wing spread or short fights to the next flower stretches for a long time. I know Monarch is small in the image, but cropping misses the point.

Weather Observations
Prior to this report: There were a lot of Monarchs parked near Oklahoma City for a week (El Reno and Midwest City reports). Prevailing wind was south or east (not north anyway) for several days. Abrupt shift north at 8 am Oct 5 from passing cold front. Temp dropped 15 degrees as well. Less than 0.1 inch rain - much more rain to north. I think one of the OKC area reports commented on front passage earlier. Wind remained brisk and generally north yesterday (Oct. 6). Dropped to nearly calm overnight. Lighter wind today (Oct. 7) but still north.

Monarchs are back at least as dense as yesterday. Same comments on estimate.  I may update number at end of day.  This morning I saw Monarchs emerging from trees where I did not spot roosts last night.  The rest were likely on smaller trees and shrubs that I did not check.  Overnight low 52.  Temp popped up quickly to 65 after sunrise, and is forecast for 80's today.  Winds are currently light.   Images later.

South Llano River State Park on yellow composite flowers. If I see any larger concentrations I will try and photograph.

Interestingly the day (10/07) I reported to you the Monarch's (and my estimate was probably low), well, the next day (10/08) most of what I observed were Queen's in the same area.

A fellow Texas Master Naturalist, who I have entered as observer,  told me by email that "I mowed (the walking paths) at the Acton Nature Center today.  Between the parking lot and the Butterfly Garden there are hundreds of Monarch's on the GayFeather."   The route he refers to is about 250 yards long.   I entered 300 for count because the database requires a numerical input.  Cannot be blank or text.
Monarchs are migrating south throughout the day.  Feeding on pansies and beds of marigolds at Weaver Plant Nursery.
Craig Hensley, TX Parks & Wildlife Interpretive Specialist, reported the monarchs to me from Anita, Iowa. I told him I would post them for him. .

There was a major uptick in the number of Monarchs today!  A cold front with rain passed through Saturday night, and as expected, the numbers jumped after the front passed and the sun came out.  There were around 40 in the garden this afternoon, mainly nectaring on Frostweed which is in full bloom right now.  A few on Gregg's Mistflower, but they shun everything else - no Goldenrod (in full bloom now), no Mexican Milkweed, nor Liatris - just Frostweed please!  By far, when in bloom, the greatest Monarch plant ever.

On Saturday I had 1 each of Buckeye and Red Admiral still present at Turkey Point. Perhaps 40 Monarchs seen migrating over a day and a half in the Long Point Area. Otherwise the only butterflies were Mourning Cloak, Eastern Tailed Blue and Whites/Sulphurs.

Forwarded by Don Davis

I counted 21 monarchs while driving from Garnett, Ks to Eudora, Ks after lunch today. A distance of about 60 miles. I counted 4 monarchs on the return trip.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

125+ flying around my 1.5 acre property in Glenn Heights, TX (about 20 miles south of Dallas), with numbers increasing throughout the day. Most taking nectar from various lantanas, eupatoriums, pentas and tithonias.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Finally seeing bunches (12+) of Monarchs sipping nectar on Buddleia, Verbena and Asters on their way to Mexico. What a relief! It has been just one a day up till now and they are expectedin Mexico for dÃ­a de los muertos on Nov 1 & 2!!!

While driving south on Memorial Drive around 11:00 AM this morning, I spotted 5 monarchs flying in various directions. (About 1 per minute) At 12:40PM, as I was driving to West of the Lake Gardens from the south, I spotted 2 more monarchs appearing to be coming from the Gardens. Upon my arrival at the Gardens, I was greeted by 30+ monarchs happily feeding on the glorious display of heliotrope & other nectar producing flowers. After speaking briefly with the head gardener, I was told that last week there were hundreds of monarchs roosting there.  Because of the strong wind blowing from the south today, there will most likely be another roost of 30+ monarchs sheltered and feeding at West of the Lake Gardens tonight & tomorrow morning.
75+ mostly nectaring on tropical milkweed and gregg's blue mist.A couple of pairs mating.

I forgot to say on Oct 6 and 7 reports that this year's arrival of large numbers is about a week EARLIER than we usually get peak migration.  Varies year to year of course, mostly with timing of cold fronts and wind direction.      Today I did a transit at 14:30 of 275 yards, watching within 50 feet of path.  Counted 50.  Many were as usual difficult to see perched with wings folded on liatris, partly in tall grass, so likely I missed a few.  Wind was higher than yesterday, from southeast.  Also a little warmer, but never above 85.  A conservative scale up of count to total liatris area give 250.  In addition I found many Monarchs under trees and groves typical of night roosts.  Resting on typical roost perches.  But alert and would flush when I approached, then land again.  I Counted 50, mostly in one large grove.  I have no method to scale up for other areas, so 50 it is.  For a total of 300.  There could actually be as many as yesterday, since winds have not been blowing toward Mexico.  I suppose the ones already under trees at 14:30 were sheltering from sun and wind.  And  that their lipid tanks must be full or they would still have been be feeding.  Ready to go when the wind changes.  Image is Monarchs sheltering mid afternoon grove of mostly Ashe Juniper.
Monarchs in the Mist...

After torrential rain storms last night, today was sunny with a crisp strong north wind and temps were in the low 60's. Around 2 pm I spotted 34 monarchs feeding on golden rod. The strong wind was a challenge for the monarchs, blowing them off the golden rod. They congregated in an area that was partly sheltered from the wind so they could replenish their reserves. Temps are supposed to drop below normal over the next few nights to low 50's with rain returning tomorrow night and Friday.
Nectaring on Liatris mucronata. Seemed to be trying to roost for the night in a post oak tree (Quercus stellata).

I did a walk around the property today at roughly the same time as yesterday. Numbers have tripled to 477 today. I've been at this location for ten years and around 500 or so has been the most I've seen, so this pretty much equals that. Don't have my notes available to break it down by years, but I'm sure there must be a way to look at the Dplex list from past years. Last year was pretty dismal -- probably a 100 - 150. I don't think I even reported that to Dplex. Individuals are fresh and healthy and fattening up fast. I've posted a couple of short videos on the Dallas County Lepidopterists' Society Facebook page (link below).

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Dallas-County-Lepidopterists-Society-Butterflies-and-Moths/202233936525781

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We are students at the fire Island school. This year we have seen very few monarchs. We think this is so because of the weather conditions. Last year Hurricane Sandy came through and killed a lot of plants here. So we believe there is very little food to attract the butterflies.
Our butterfly bush was practically swarming with Monarchs all afternoon.  The bush is in full sun and the temperature was about 17 degrees C.

Here is a video I shot in my butterfly garden this afternoon. Monarch migration is peaking in Dallas, TX and there were easily 80-100 Monarchs nectaring on various flowers, but Frostweed was the main draw. They absolutely love it! As a side note, this plant is easily grown from seed and if it can take Texas weather, it can take yours. Enjoy!
More arriving by the hour and if like other years will spend about a week in my back yard as I have a lot of butterfly attracting plants.

Over about an hour at noon today my wife and I tagged and released 20 monarchs (13 males) at The Lynde Conservation Area (near the Hawk Watch) in Whitby. It was sunny with temp of 18 C with a slight breeze. With the exception of one female they were all in excellent shape. They were nectaring on asters, clover, and the odd goldenrod, most of which is going to seed. When released, they almost all flew high into the air in a south westerly direction, heading along the shore of Lake Ontario. We observed approx. another 8 during this time, flying out of reach of my net.This is the highest number I have ever tagged this late in October, the previous being on Oct 5, 2011.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Nine monarchs counted in one hour today. We seem to be experiencing a migration peak in mid-October. A few years ago at this location we experienced peak numbers in mid-September and a second peak in mid-October.  2013 is the first time in years that we have seen significant numbers in mid-October.

Seeing constant stream of migrating monarchs in the North Texas area into this week! Today in the span of 15 min around 10 am I counted 5 monarchs heading south;  throughout the day I have been in Collin and Denton counties and have continued seeing monarchs; We have clear, mild weather, perfect for migration, and lots of fields, pastures, and neighborhoods have nectaring flower sources in bloom;

These adult monarchs were flying west along the shore line of Lake Ontario. I was most excited to see them as I only saw 4 all Summer. My friend whom I was visiting has continued to see small groups in the last few days.

Was surprised when about 6:30 pm tonight I saw monarchs coming in to the parking lot at work. I saw lots come through this same location last year. Tonight I first saw one on the mulberry tree then I saw more come in, circle the the same tree and the Tree of Heaven right next to the mulberry. Several did this one after the other then they flew on south. I've never seen anything like it.

There were so many monarchs enjoying my butterfly gardens on Monday and Tuesday of this week, so I could only estimate what I observed in a 15 minute time span. Aside from adults feeding on Mexican Milkweed and Blue Mist blossoms, there were several caterpillars of various sizes feeding on the milkweed.

I have hatched both Queen and Monarch butterflies in my classroom. In fact, there were some Queen butterflies in the mix when I saw so many Monarchs. The Monarchs spent several days in my yard. Could it be that they hatched in my garden? I saw some quite large instars on the milkweed. Every year, my students & I have a release in the spring.

I checked the route to large grove and the grove itself starting at 15:30. Wind south, brisk, gusty. Temp about 80. Monarchs on liatris were flying more than yesterday, probably stirred by wind gusts. Not directional flight. Numbers seemed somewhat fewer than yesterday, but conditions were different. The grove itself had many MORE Monarchs in it than yesterday, sheltering from sun and wind. Most perched, a few flying. As I walked through the grove, small clouds of Monarchs would bloom from branches, then resettle after a minute or so. For total number I just went with same as yesterday.

I drove by a few other shelter trees and most had Monarchs flying around downwind side.

At sunset I saw a number of Monarchs flying into the large Live Oak (Q. fusiformis) near to our house, which is an archetypical hollow half sphere with outer leaf canopy descending right to the ground. The few Monarchs that I could track to final perch, all perched more than 30 feet from ground, inside the leaf canopy.

Detroit River Hawk Watch

Clear as a bell again today; only blue to be seen. The wind was light and out of the southeast early and strong and out of the southeast late.

Songbird migration was limited. Monarchs (250+) on the other hand, weredrifting past from start to finish

On October 8th, the count for monarchs flying past on part of the sky was 197 in 1.5 hours.  I am 1.5 miles east of Cherokee, TX.  I have not seen nearly this many in the 10 years we have lived here.  On our place they like Dwarf Crownbeard instead of the Golden Crownbread others tell me they like.  We have both. 

Editor's Note: A roost was present at this location the night of 8 October (59 monarchs) and 9 October (97 monarchs).

Today was a good Monarch day at Clearville Park. Temp 68, sunny, light winds. Weather is expected to hold for next 5 days and get warmer each day. A steady stream of Monarch butterflies flying at tree top height SW along the Lake Erie coast towards Pt. Pelee. Starting at 11:00 AM I counted 140 butterflies per hour flying through the park. This increased to about 220 per hour by 1:00 PM and continued without stop until 5:00 PM when I was still counting 140 per hour. By 5:00 PM butterflies were dropping out of the sky to roost in trees throughout the park. We have not yet had a frost. Nectar sources are not in as good a condition as last week. Still some asters available for nectar.

Today was not as good a viewing day as yesterday because the wind shifted later in the afternoon which tends to re-direct the Monarchs flight path further inland so they can’t be seen along the Lake Erie coastline. At noon today I was counting 30 butterflies every 10 minutes moving through Clearville Park. This number tapered off in the afternoon when the wind shifted.

Today is a very good Monarch viewing day at Clearville Park. Temp is 70F, sunny blue sky with a moderate east wind. The butterflies are making use of the east wind to soar to great heights (4-5 times tree top level and even higher). The wind is moving them in the direction of Pt. Pelee where they cross Lake Erie to Ohio. As happened yesterday and the day before there is a steady stream of butterflies flying over and through Clearville Park with a few stopping to nectar. I counted 25 butterflies in 10 minutes. Todayâ€™s winds are favourable so I expect this to continue throughout today.  Nectar sources are drying up here and are not in as good a shape as last week but they can still be found.  This weather is expected to hold for 2 more days until Saturday Oct 12.  There is no frost in the forecast for this location.
We were on vacation and stopped at Stonington Peninsula Point Lighthouse in Stonington MI to see the monarchs.
Steady at about 12 migrating monarchs at a time all day. Cool, sunny, light breeze. Glad to finally see monarchs.
Two groups of about 20 Monarchs spotted along Gentry Creek headwaters. Not roosting but nectaring on the Frostweed and sunflowers growing there.

At least 50 Monarchs within an acre of land near Gentry Creek, Were seen drifting among tall Pecan and Elm trees growing in the creek bottom. There were never a cluster just numerous butterflies within that small area.

Monarchs were on the liatris patches near the house as densely as previous days. ¶ Visited large grove at 1400.  Temp mid 70’s.  Brisk south wind, gusty.  More humid than yesterday. ¶ On the way to the grove Monarchs on all liatris areas, but seemed less dense than yesterday. Especially to upwind direction.  They are hard to see as they align with wind, wings folded, on the  opposite side of flower.  See image which shows the spotting challenge. ¶ Still many monarchs flying and perching in the grove, perhaps more than earlier near sunrise. ¶ I will send video link later.

I am so pleased to report I am seeing a dozen or more super monarchs each day in my monarch gardens in Southern Illinois.This is far fewer than three years ago, but given the recent environmental factors effecting monarch numbers, I am very happy.

We're still under peak migration here in Dallas.  The Goldenrod has finally bloomed enough that the Monarchs are interested.  While not the greatest picture, I got lucky and caught a Monarch in flight just before it landed on the flower head.  I thought it was interesting to see the wings completely flapped forward and the body hanging behind.  I never knew their wings flapped forward like this since in real time, it's impossible to see this happening.
40-50 adult monarch butterflies sipping nectar from blooming Texas Kidneywood-I have seen them the last two days. Occasionally one will sip from Gregg's Mistflower.
Lots (in the dozens) coming through between Branson and Springfield on US 65
We saw thousands of monarchs outside of the butterfly exhibitin fair park Dallas Texas munching on many frost weed pants. I have never seen so many.

Today (Oct. 12) is the 3rd day of their visit. They are fluttering around and feeding on the Frostweed in my yard, a rural setting on the south face of the highest hill 37 miles Northwest of San Antonio.

October 10, 2013 Monarch Butterflies at Broad View Wildflower Seed Garden, central Iowa. Hundreds of monarchs feeding on Monarda citriodora, common name Lemon Mint. Monarda citriodora is not native to Illinois or Iowa, but is a prairie plant of Missouri, Nebraska, and elsewhere in parts of the south.

It was thrilling to be there at this impressive event first hand.Monarch event location is central Iowa, 55 miles west of Iowa City and 65 miles east of Des Moines.The Prairie Map lists exact location of Broad View Garden: http://prairiemap.com/Broad View Garden is 5 miles NW of Brooklyn and 15 miles east of Grinnell, Iowa.

The CRP field is 20 acres. This entire field had blooming Lemon Mint. I focused on the edge of the field near to the farm pond's Broad View Garden Area. Thus, in saying hundreds, I have little accuracy in surmising the number across the entire field. The greatest concentration appeared in the CRP field near the edge of the pine trees lining the pond. Maybe, five hundred all total across the CRP field. In evening they all flew into the maple and pine trees at the pond. However, they flew in so staggered, again it is difficult to estimate the numbers.

This CRP field was planted May 20th and had been mowed about six times to keep the weeds down and give the prairie plants a chance to become established. Therefore, only when we stopped mowing in late summer did the Lemon Mint get going enough to produce blooms. As a result, the Lemon Mint was in the peak of blooming when Monarchs gathered October 10th. There appeared an increase in Monarchs sited at the CRP in the days leading up to October 10th. I do not know if each day those Monarchs left and new Monarchs arrived, or if Monarchs arrived over several days--staying to feed and building up in large numbers--but, the large group of October 10th had left by October 11th.

The next day, October 11th, I only saw two Monarchs. Yesterday (October 14), I looked over the area and again only saw two Monarchs.

Over this past summer, the Garden with prairie forbs has four to six Monarchs observed every day. The farm has about 110 acres in CRP and most of that is in native plantings, although the forbs are few in most of the fields. However, there is scattered common milkweed here and there on the farm.

Strong winds out of the south have pretty much stalled directional flight. Went around my 1.5 acre property (heavily planted with butterfly host and nectar plants) and counted 850+. With temps in the 80s a good number, maybe a fifth, are hanging out in the trees. If I walked the treeline of the adjacent property I'm sure the tally would be well over 1,000.

Am in very southern Okla. had 30+ so far today. All flying south. No Queens either.

Central Johnson County, south of Ft Worth. For the past two (October 8-10) days there has been 75-90+ Monarchs feeding on my Cow Pin Daisy inmy garden which I did not till this year. Best days in awhile for Monarchs here in Johnson County. Large groups in neighbors dairy-cowpins also. 25-40 on his property.

These were seen late afternoon to early evening near an almost-dried up lake. Most were feeding on Baccharis neglecta or flying into an interior area of trees. This fall, unlike past years, I have not seen a single monarch feeding on sunflowers, lantana or any other yellow flower. In the past these have been prime sources (along with milkweed and poverty weed).

Visited large grove starting at 1600 temp 82. Party to mostly cloudy. South wind.

Some monarchs on flowers on the way, especially in wind sheltered areas. Many monarchs in the grove and other groves and trees. Flew when I approached then resettled.
