Fog covered the valley to south early morning.  Turned to cloudy and overcast with storms to south, but they did not reach us.  High humidity.  South wind.  Turned to partly cloudy after 13:00.  Temp approached 90 degrees late afternoon. South wind.  Checked monarchs about 16:00.  Monarchs on flowers, especially where wind sheltered, and  many in trees and groves.  Monarchs flew when I approached but resettled very quickly.
We tagged 175 monarchs in three hours today (Oct. 11) at ANC. We are hoping the weather holds tomorrow.

We tagged 340 monarchs total: 175 tagged Friday, October 11 and 165 more on Saturday (October 12). Total 340. Not just seen, but caught and tagged.

Courtesy of Rio Brazos Chapter of Texas Master Naturalists

16:30. temp 76. Overcast. S to SE wind. Humid.

Monarchs on flowers, but once again far more in groves and large trees. Mostly perched, fly briefly when disturbed.

This is by far the longest period (since Oct 6) we have seen peak migration monarchs continuously. We have had pulses separated by more time, but not continuously here. We have now only begun the usual period in which peak migration passes through this location. Wind forecast is south until sometime Tuesday Oct 15.

First saw them on October 10 nectaring near my house. Did not look on 10/11.  I'm not trying an accurate count, they are  not holding still and are over a broad area. Numbers were greatest on  the 12th: over 50.  Sighted fewer again on 10/13 and 10/14. It rained a lot Sunday the 13th, saw few, maybe 5. Monday, more than Sunday.

Rain overnight. humid. south wind.  overnight low 69.  I did a quick check about 16:00.  Temp 76, still overcast.   A few spots of sun around 17:00.  Essentially no monarchs on flowers.  Still many in groves and trees.  More reluctant to fly when approached than previous days.  Some tolerated my camera one foot away.     Fewer counted primarily, I suspect, because fewer flushed from trees, especially if perched high in trees.

Late flow - day 17. The remarkable late flow of monarchs continues. Again, there were >20 monarchs in the garden and on the flowers in the front of the building at 10AM. The temp is 69 and the skies are clear for the moment. Winds are S/SE at 13 mph, a good quartering wind that will help monarchs (the bearing for monarchs here is 210 so even a wind from the S becomes a quartering wind) move toward the SW.

Yesterday, October 10, at noon when I headed for class, there had to have been 30-40 monarchs at Monarch Watch. The most I've seen at any one time this year. As I've mentioned, the numbers of monarchs in this area are typically quite low after the 4th of October. I expected the numbers to drop off over the last few days but they haven't.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

It is overcast, about 2:00 pm. Many Monarchs to be seen in several areas of yard, all around frostweed. Too many to count, but it appears their numbers have increased in the past few days. My land is a highpoint, that is, a high hill in the area.

My Mom and I  were walking in Norbuck Park (Dallas, TX) when something strange  caught  my  eye.  I looked again and saw hundreds of tiny silhouettes- they were all Monarch butterflies.  I was  amazed but I also wanted to find out why they were there.We looked up information on Monarchs and the type of shrub we saw them feeding on- Baccharis Shrubs and we found out all about the Monarch's migration from Canada to Mexico.  We also determined that the butterflies were most likely stopping on Norbuck Park to feed on the Bacchris nectar and roost for the evening.

A showing of Monarch's came in on Oct. 11. Maybe 50 butterflies. Afew were very large  maybe 4or 5 inches...all were colorful. Theyenjoyed my flowers. Rain came on Sat. so I did not get to look forroost.

1155. Large grove only. The â€œcoldâ€ front is almost here. Temp 72. Wind WSW brisk. Light rain, large drops. Some Monarchs flying around grove, many gliding high, but not directional - flying around then landing. But some also still perched immobile on low limbs.

1230. Temp 67 wind NW, less rain. Some Monarchs could have been riding off on the wind, but hard to tell. Monarchs are starting to gather on south side of trees that line an interior opening in the grove. Some fly out and re-perch. Others folded.

1300. Temp dropping slowly, now about 65. Wind N. Monarchs continue to glide high around and over grove.

1430 temp 60. Raining harder. Saw fewer than 20 monarchs. Some flying just outside grove, others perched along outside flexing wings. Others under trees wings folded.

Hard rain overnight.

10:45. Overcast earlier. Not raining. Patches of blue sky starting to move in from north. temp 60. Wind north 12G20.

Monarchs spaced apart and sunning spread-winged on south side of trees that face an interior opening in the large grove. Some flexing wings. Some flying up.

Some landed again but others appeared to fly off with wind. As I watched over ten minutes, numbers flying increased and number on the trees decreased. Increasing numbers more clearly seemed to head up into the wind, where they were carried south.

Image is a group sunning. I have some video that looks good. I will send later after editing down to a minute or two.

Lots of things had to be flushed from fields, and lantana was mostly lacking butterflies.

My husband and I drove around town today and noticed that we were seeing quite a few monarchs and then remembered seeing an IMAX film about the migration to Mexico. Sure enough they were headed south and we just keep seeing them everywhere. Quite beautiful!

About 4:00 p.m. October 16, 2013, I noticed a few monarchs floating around my yard.  Within an hour, countless monarchs were coming through at various altitudes.  I caught my quota of 50 for the tagging program in about 45 minutes.

After about a week of no sightings, observed several today. 2-3 at a time on the butterfly bush and counted  15 passing the house during an hour span. Also saw several butterflies heading south on my drive from Dallas to Fort Worth.
Observed loose groups of 5-6 passing through. By noon it had dwindled to 1 or 2 Monarchs every few minutes. There were one here and there passing through until late afternoon.

Between 3:30 and 5:30 this afternoon I counted 383 monarchs. They were taking a path directly over the house, some stopping at flowers, some continuing on to the south. I also collected 2 more monarch caterpillars from the Hierba de Zizotes in the ditch, which make 6 I have collected, 3 of which are now in chrysalis stage.

I have a small butterfly garden full of assorted plants (mostly Greggs Mist) that butterflies love. For the past few days, the garden has been full of Monarchs. Today we had at least 50 at one time. Not all were monarchs; about 10% were Gulf Fritillaries.

About 50 monarchs in backyard.  This appears to be the peak time I see them I. Allen texas.  The are covering my Greg's mist flower and even down deep where you can't see them.  I cant really capture in photo but tried.  They are also on my milkweed, butterfly bush and mexican sage.

Observed dozens of migrating monarchs in North Texas (McKinney) on 10/17 throughout the daytime hours; in fact in one 30 min obs/count session, in the mid/late afternoon saw them at the rate of 1 per minute; Most were flying through but some were nectaring including some on Texas Sage bush flowers (Leucophyllum frutescens). Conditions included clear skies, temp was mild, 70 degrees;  Today (10/18) weather is cloudy, some drizzle, a cooler) and so the monarchs preceeded this weather change by a day.
I obserbed 58 adult monarchs clustering in the eucalyptus grove at Artdenwood Historic Farm at about 9am.

Spotted one right after the othe while running errands today.  It's the most monarchs I've ever spotted in one day!

The 2013 tagging season resulted in my lowest totals of monarchs since discovering my “nectar superhighway” migration pathway. So far (October 18) I have tagged 82 monarchs out of 113 seen. Migration started slow with reports of 80-90% decline in monarch numbers. The hawk watches at Pilot Mountain noted a severe decline in migrant Monarchs, singles as opposed to hundreds!

As noted in previous years, sunny clear skies after a prolonged frontal system can cause a “flood gate opening” resulting in Oct 15 (10 monarchs), 16th (37) and 17th (30) making up the most of my season. What I term the “nectar superhighway” of rail lines and power lines along and north of I85 were again the hot bed of activity. The rail line right of way that was sprayed with herbicides two years prior had still not recovered so had no nectar. This again further concentrated the monarchs on the other sites along I85.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Observed six monarchs feeding in my butterfly garden. They are feeding primarily on Gregg's Mist flower and are ignoring Zinna, Lantana, and Buddlia blossoms. Also observed eight Monarchs bypassing the flowers and flying steadily south.Mixed in with the Monarchs are numerous Fritterilly butterflies.

During a three-hour trip, we counted 729 monarchs while driving on the highway from San Antonia to Del Rio (150 miles). Time:  9:30 am- 12:00 pm. Then there were hundreds along San Felipe Creek.  On the way home we saw fewer than 20!  It was a glorious monarch trip! I hope this report will "gladden the hearts" of all those who are so worried about the monarchs. I know so many are sad. (Of course this is just a small number considering the whole loss in numbers that they feel.)

Editor's Note: The location used for this highway trip report is Uvalde, Texas, mid-way between San Antonio and Del Rio.

I worked in the garden all day and observed countless Monarchs passing through. This was the first day we had seen any Monarchs at our location. I waited until the morning to check the spot in our garden we saw the roost in 2010; to no avail.

First, I sighted a Monarch Butterfly at the end of July! On August 7, I counted 14 instars. On August 18, three adults had emerged and flew. the next day I found two dead. On October 7, I saw one adult. On October 18 I lost count, but for the entire day, I can guess that a couple of hundred flew over, a few of them stopping for the nectar plants and depositing eggs on the milkweed.I will keep monitoring and send any information regarding further developments.We saw three adults on October 19, and two on the 20th.

Whether the numbers tomorrow or over the successive 6 weeks will at any time exceed the numbers of today remains to be seen. I only got to count between 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. today, but I had 141 monarchs crossing the backyard in 14 minutes, then moved to the front for the rest of the time.Just counted monarchs from 11:54 thru 12:53 and it looked like this:85% in dedicated flight due S.Five minute segments:21 (with 6 of those kettling @ 60'57 (12: to 12:053448 (12:05 to 12:10241861210106 for a sum of248 in one hour passing over a spot that allowed me to see a field of vision like a half dome about 100 yards by 50 yards and about 70 yards up with occasional binoculars. Sky is mostly now clear and temps moving into low 80s.Add these to the morning count from 11: 24 through 11:39 of 141 in the backyard where they are traveling right along the shelter of the bluff.I had things I had to do before my initial start time, but think there were even more moving between 9:00 a.m. and 11:24. I had 22 monarchs cross the bank parking lot in just a few minutes and had to put off other tasks to run home and start counting!
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

10/20 A substantial flight of Monarchs is in progress on the Point this afternoon . . . Moving thru about one every 90 seconds; many are starting to seek roosting sites in the bayberry and fluffy goldenrod seed heads. Watching one roost of about 20 forming right now on a bloomed-out boneset. Numbers are easily on par with many previous years here.

A rivulet of Monarchs passed over near Utopia today from 6 to 7 p.m.,just ahead of the cold front. I'm a couple miles south of town atedge of the river corridor habitat. Earlier around 4-5:00 p.m. adozen Gulf Frits blasted past south to southwest bound. I don't knowif the Monarchs started earlier than 6, I was in the office, but at6 p.m. when I went out there was a good flow, so likely it had begunearlier, though there was no sign of it at 5:00 lookabout.

Besides right overhead, I could see them a quarter mile or so in either direction from my place, most were in the 50-500' AGL altitude range. Ten at once in the binoc field of view was regular. I saw a total of about 500 Monarch from 6 p.m. to 6:30 when I went in for dinner. At 7 p.m. a few werestill going over, and a few were looking for roost sites in the pecansand hackberries around yard.

The most amazing thing though was about 50' AGL moving S-SW with themwas a female Black Swallowtail beating tracks. I got it in binocsas it went right overhead and saw the double row of red dots on VHWquite well. I was unable however to determine if it was in reproductivediapause, my x-ray bins are on the fritz and in the shop...... Surely it is my personal AGL altitude record for P. polyxenes. I don't think I've seen one 12' off the ground before. I'd had another female earlier in the day nectaring on the Purple Mist Eupatorium. Have not thought of them as migratory.

A number of Green Darner dragonfly were also moving, some Red Saddlebagsand Wandering Glider, and a few small groups of Sandhill Crane.

Might be some movement tomorrow behind the front? Keep your eyeson the skies.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

Oct 18 Monarch's came in about noon. At 4:30 pm A large number 50 or more in back yard . They were feeding on Blue mist and yellow bells. I looked for them at 6:30p.m. But could not see any roost. However at 8:30 p.m. a cold front moved in with a bit of hail,' lighten and a short rain fall.  The day was sunny in the 70's.

Hace menos de 30 minutos empecé a ver monarcas por el cielo de Saltillo, un promedio de 1/min. En mi monitoreo diario a las 9:00 horas que inicié desde el 1o. de octubre no había observado ninguna. El cielo medio nublado con una temperatura de 19°C y viento suave del norte. Las mariposas vuelan a una altura de 3-20metros con dirección al este. Espero que este promedio de monarcas mejore un poco en los próximos días.

Courtesy of Rocio Treviño of Correo Real
Noticed quite a few Monarchs, about 6 feeding in my butterfly garden. Then observed many fluttering around tops of trees around my garden. Never have had this many before.

Hoy por la tarde me avisaron que estaban pasando las monarcas, salí incrédulo y vemos que estaban pasando a unos 3 metros por encima del  techo  de la  casa la mayoría, otras mucho más alto, 8 o 10 metros, pero bajando. Inicié el conteo a las 6:12 y lo cerré a las 6:32 Contabilizamos 225 en esos 20 minutos. Antes ya había pasado un grupo de más de 25 y después siguieron pasando unas y llegando otras. Deben haber pasado más de 300 y se percharon aproximadamente otras 200 en la ceiba que está, al lado del estanque. Las últimas que vimos llegar se percharon a las 7:25 PM. Parecían conocer el lugar exacto donde llegarían. A las 7:30 pm había poco más de 20º Centígrados (menos de 21) no se sentía viento pero en lo alto se veía que a ellas las arrastraba una corriente de aire que no las dejaba volar directo a la ceiba. Para esa hora el cielo estaba muy nublado, parecía que pronto llovería. En este momento (10:15 PM) el cielo está despejado y hay 18ºC espero mañana tomar una buena foto. 

Courtesy of Rocio Treviño, Correo Real.

Multitudes of Monarch butterflies visiting my Purple Mist flowers everyday for several weeks. A steady daily flow that stay around most of the day, visiting my many flowers, with the heaviest concentration on the Purple Mist flowers. I have seen as many as 20 at one time between the two clumps of flowers, with others stopping by the various flowering plants in my yard, including my Lantana and Butterfly Weed.

There were many Monarch Butterflies at the South Bass Island Light House on South Bass Island, Lake Erie Ohio. The butterflies were all in the trees and came out about noon eastern time until about 2:30pm. They would come out when the sun had warmed them up and fly high to get to the thermals and then fly south to the mainland across the Lake. I hope they all make it. It was actually cold only about 50 degrees so I was really surprised that they were even out and still migrating.

Tuve suerte hoy viaje hacia Monterrey y desde Apasco en el municipio de Ramos Arizpe hasta el Cesteo de las Aves (municipio de García, N.L.) conté 90 monarcas. Al llegar a este lugar, detuve mi auto porque un río de mariposas estaba pasando, conté en 10 minutos un promedio de 35 mariposas/minuto, también había gran cantidad de picudas o gallitos volando con ellas. Las mariposas entraban directamente al cañón del Jonuco, espero las aspas de los aerogeneradores no las afecten. Estuve observando con los binoculares y parecía que las mariposas podían evadir las aspas.

Seguí mi camino y se siguieron viendo abundantes mariposas hasta la entrada de Santa Catarina. Para no variar los tráileres y otros automóviles estaban dejando su estela de mariposas muertas.

Estoy completamente sorprendido. Hoy hice un recorrido nuevamente por carretera y vi varios ejemplares Uno en Allende, otro en Cadereyta y 3 en Juárez...quizá porque mi desplazamiento fue más lento y despreocupado por lo conocido de la ruta. Un de ellas fue en el camino a la casa como a 300 metros. Llegué dispuesto a hacer el reporte y estaba conectándome cuando me avisan (León) que andaban 4 MMonarca afuera. Salí incrédulo y vemos que estaban pasando a unos 3 metros por encima del techo de la casa la mayoría, otras mucho más alto, 8 o 10 metros, pero bajando.

Inicié el conteo a las 6:12 y lo cerré a las 6:32 Contabilizamos 225. en esos 20 minutos. Antes ya había pasado un grupo de más de 25 y después siguieron pasando unas y llegando otras. Deben haber pasado más de 300 y se percharon aproximadamente otras 200 en la ceiba que está, al lado del estanque. Las últimas que vimos llegar se percharon a las 7:25. Parecían conocer el lugar exacto donde llegarían.

A las 7:30 pm había poco más de 20o Centígrados (menos de 21) no se sentía viento pero en lo alto se veía que a ellas las arrastraba una corriente de aire que no las dejaba volar directo a la ceiba. Para esa hora el cielo estaba muy nublado, parecía que pronto llovería. En este momento (10:15) el cielo está despejado y hay 18o. Espero poder tomar alguna buena fotografía para compartirla mañana.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Hoy 23 día tradicional de arribo de miles de Monarcas a Monterrey y su Área Metropolitana.Durante varios años de la década de los noventa (Ya llovió) estuvimos yendo al Parque Chipinque a trabajar con los grupos escolares el tema de la mariposa Monarca y varios 23 de octubre nos tocó presenciar migraciones espectaculares precisamente ese día, y hoy se vuelve a presenciar el mismo fenómeno. Espero esto nos traiga esperanzas de que este invierno aumentará la población que hiberna en los santuarios del estado de México y Michoacán. Crucen los dedos.

Courtesy of Correo Real

On Tuesday our monarch monitoring intern was very excited as a little wave of monarchs pushed into Cape May Point!!   The road census showed 39 monarchs in 39 minutes.  I was also told that Stone Harbor Point had quite an influx of monarchs. Most of them seen nectaring on Seaside Goldenrod.  A gorgeous sight!!!  Unfortunately, it was rainy and cold the next day, but we were all hoping that today, Thursday might bring more monarchs to Cape May.   But alas, it was very windy and cold, with the monarchs that were here, staying high in the trees on the dunes.  No real movement was seen.  We'll see what the next few days bring as the winds should be in their favor for migration.
Zaida saw the monarch butterflies in the field.  She saw them flying around everywhere and going towards the trees.

I saw ~300 monarchs at Folly yesterday (10/25). I tagged 215. Today (10/26) there were many fewer. The wind subsided and today was a monarch “moving day’. I captured about 65 and saw about 80-90.

The wave of monarchs peaked on Friday (25 Oct). My results of number captured and number observed at Folly by day for the past week or so are:

20 Oct. – 41 captured; ~50 seen
21 Oct. – 51 captured; ~60 seen
23 Oct. – 55 captured; ~70 seen
24 Oct. – 12 captured; ~22 seen
25 Oct. – 215 captured; ~300 seen
26 Oct. – 77 captured; ~100 seen
27 Oct. –19 captured; ~25 seen
28 Oct. –36 captured; ~50 seen
29 Oct. –31 captured; ~35 seen

The number captured by day includes recoveries tagged/released at least a day before. I did recover 1 monarch that was likely tagged well north of us

El domingo 3 de Noviembre registré el paso de 475 monarcas volando de norte a sur a una altura aproximada de 12 metros, desde mi casa pude observarlas y contarlas durante una hora a partir de las 16:15 horas. Y el día 4 de Noviembre mi esposo Luis Martínez contó 362 monarcas en un alto de una hora de camino de Altacima a Gómez Farías alrededor de las 14:00 horas, las mariposas estaban posadas sobre distintas flores incluyendo las asclepias. Para ser sincera nunca había puesto atención a su paso y fue algo que me impactó mucho sobretodo verlo sobre mi casa y en tal cantidad. Algunas personas de los ejidos cercanos me han comentado que años anteriores para principios de Noviembre pasaban en grandes cantidades pero que ha disminuido el número de mariposas que ellos observan pasar. Espero poder seguir informándoles del paso de la mariposa monarca por la RPC El Cielo, reciban ¡muchos saludos y un gran abrazo!

42 monarchs Thur & Fri netted

Altus and I got out across the causeway about 10:15this morning and Altus worked the line of sunflowersfor over an hour. She managed to net twenty-onemonarchs that wanted to stop to nectar on thefreshest of the flowers. I could sit in the Tahoeand watch with binocs and many times call out to herwhere a monarch was or it was going to land. Many,many more than this were going past to the other sideof the TX35 peninsula towards Port Lavaca ... at the besttime there were at least three a minute passing withinfifty feet of a fixed point. Not good, but therewere at least some!

We went back about 3:30 and Altus worked a narrow line ofseaside daises for about an hour plus a few very shortseaside goldenrod and got an additional dozen. So onThurs and Fri she has netted 42 monarchs coming downthe Coastal Flyway.
100s of Monarchs, everywhere!!! Beautiful!

This weekend we went camping along the Colorado River in Western Arizona. Earlier in the year we scouted areas to look for monarchs on their migration or during the winter. Now it was time to see if they were there - or not. About two weeks earlier Keith Graves spotted about sixty monarchs near Lake Havasu. But this area was unexplored. A few hours after we set up camp, we walked along the Colorado as the sun was lowering. It didn't take too long to find them! Monarchs were flying high above the tree tops of three massive Willow Acacia trees, Acacia salicina, in bloom nestled together a short distance from the shore on a peninsula. The trees were huge, over 35 feet tall and the monarchs favored the top branches for the night. We needed binoculars to confirm they were monarchs in the dimming light and took photos. The queen butterflies congregated about half way up the trees and were easier to see. We even saw a small number of painted ladies in proximity to each other for the night. Each morning and evening we watched. In the morning they nectared on the Acacia flowers and by 10 a.m. a few would dip down to sip the morning dew in a nearby thatch of grass. We tagged a few and their abdomens were plump. By 10:30 each morning at least 20 to 25 began flying south along the river and more would arrive during the day. Out of the 150 or more monarchs we saw over 3 days we only saw two males exhibiting territorial behavior. No mating was seen. A park volunteer said this was the largest number of monarchs he has seen at the park in six years. He also said the Acacia trees were blooming a few weeks earlier than usual this year. A true "Bed & Breakfast" break on their journey. We were glued to the trees - quite a glorious event to

Miles de mariposas monarca alimentándose el falsos girasoles y perchando en nogales y mezquites en parcelas agrícolas del ejido Monte Redondo del municipio de Jaumave. Este lugar es uno de los principales sitios de estadía durante la migración hacia Michoacan y el estado de México.
Adult monarch, directional flying. Unable to tag.
Adult monarch, flying in southerly direction along bike trail beside river.

On Wednesday 8/20, I observed 10 adult monarchs on my liatris liguistica.  The next day 8/21, I observed 18 adult monarchs Today, 8/24, I have seen as many as 9 adult monarchs plus a hummingbird and numerous bees.
Pictured Rocks-Miners Castle at the Nature Center on Joe-Pye Weed. Over 100 were there.
Monarch butterflies were nectaring at the mouth of Beaver Creek on Lake Superior in Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore.

center of five areas surveyed with 10x binoculars of fields with red clover and milkweed  intin 2 miles of each other ( includingg my residence where I had 4 on on one white buddleia. Several  were "yellow dot" fresh and some had damaged wings.

On vacation in northern Michigan. Kayaking on Lake Michigan we observed over 20 Monarchs flying south along the shoe near Sleeping Bear Dunes.  They were singles and every so often one would fly by.  This occurred over a 2 hour period.  We also observed several Monarchs on flowers in the sand dunes around the lakeshore.Here in Ohio near our home in Yorkville, I am happy to report several sightings of Monarchs on flowers in nearby fields.Also, I have seen more milkweed this year than any year in recent history.These sightings are more than we observed all of last year.  Hopefully Monarch numbers are on the rise this year.
Had about 4 dozen in the yard tonight. Went out at 6:45 to see where they were roosting and most were gone. I will have to check earlier.
A beautiful evening in our school nature area.  Monarchs on the blazing star everywhere I looked.

Visited the wildflower gardens again yesterday afternoon and the number of Monarchs nectaring increased from the day before.  Fluttering around the flowers it was hard to get a count but all were fresh looking and busy nectaring.
Group of monarch's warming up while roosting on Jerusalem artichokes and willow shrubs after a cooler night. Some were starting to fly and gradually move to south.
Lots of monarchs nectaring on liatris!  At least 90, if not more this morning at 11:30.

Several seen in rain gardens, and a number floating together in circles. Nectaring on liatris. Damaged wings on 2, ripped and holes in both. These 2 sitting quietly on leaves, not nectarine. Cloudy, 70 degrees, humid.
only about 50 here today after the 100 yesterday.  lots of rain overnight.  cool temps today.

At the Apostle Islands Park Service building, across the street from my home, there is a wild garden.  Someone had the foresight to plant many Blazing Stars, a column of purple that the Monarchs love.  Last year we saw 2 or 3 butterflies recharging on this blossom.  This year the flowers are mobbed, at least 2 per plant and as one leaves, more land and feed. We are so glad to see them again in such numbers and hope that this wonder of nature will obtain endangered status to begin the process of changing agricultural practices to allow for biodiversity.

It looks like the peak of Monarch migration here was a few days ago.  I now see just one or two an hour, while I could see a dozen in a few minutes four days ago.They nectar on the flowers in our planted prairie.  Meadow Blazingstar is their favorite flower; its bloom time corresponds better to Monarch migration than other Liatris.  Monarchs also like our Joe-Pyeweed.

We had seen a huge number of migrating monarchs in this exact spot 2 years ago. We went back to the same location last year during the same week (first week in September) and saw none. Today we saw 15 adults, busy feeding on the abundant milkweed and golden rod in a mountain meadow clearing off the East Pond Hiking Trail near Osceola Mountain just outside the White Mountain National Forest. We were overjoyed that they are back, although so many fewer than 2 years ago.We will go again each day we are still up here this week. We'll report on our sightings.

Driving around today looking to tag some monarchs.  Seen 40+ while driving around.  Then I came across a small clover/alfalfa field.  I seen a lot of butterfly's and stoped.  There were aleast 160 monarchs and I tagged 24 of them ( ran out of tags) did a couple counts and left.  Partly sunny and muggy about 82 degrees out. Cold front coming, might have to go back tomorrow and tag more.

At Hwy 169 and Canterbury Road in Shakopee watched a group of 20 adults stream across the highway going due south.  They were in a loose collection and all 20 went by in about 30 seconds.  I was in stop n go traffic for about 20 minutes and only moved a few miles.  After this group of 20 there were ones and twos crossing until total of at least 30.  Hard to count when driving and mesmerized by these beautiful creatures.  I noticed the roadside along those miles were unmowed and full of late blooming natives, especially goldenrod.  Seeing LOTS of unmoved roadsides everywhere going "au naturale"!  Could it be the word is getting out and the highway department is responding?  Love it!
First time I have ever seen so many in one place and they were flying around and around in my yard.  Several landed in an evergreen tree.

Over a period of about 3 hours, I saw around 75 monarchs. About 15 of those were spied flying near/over the road as I was driving. I tagged 25 at a nearby arboretum, and saw at least 35 more that I wasn't able to tag in the same location. There was a Mexican sunflower plant, on which there were always 10-15 monarchs at any given time over a 2-hour period.I also saw two monarchs mating(?) The male was very old--faded and worn. While tagging, I also caught a monarch that I had tagged one week previously in the same location (local arboretum).
This is the most I've ever had. We went to a Monarch Festival today. When we left there were about a dozen and came home to this. What joy they bring!

While visiting a friend in Oshkosh, Wi I observed many Monarchs fluttering about and nectaring on Meadow Blazing Star flowers as well as a variety of yellow wild flowers. It was a sunny afternoon with a southwest wind and 78 degrees F.
1000 plus Monarchs sighted feeding and resting on above date at Plover Prarie , southeat of Big Stone NWR, Minnesota. Liatris species was prefered food source, with Helianthus species second choice.
80-100 adults feeding at Yellow Bank Hills SNA in western MN on above date. Liatris species prefered food source, with Helianthus species second.

Waystation 6866.. from noon to 1pm counted over 50 adults flying in from the north, briefly alighting on Joe pye weed, budellia,lazy susans and sunflowers, then flying off to the south. Have seen this activity for last few days, first chance to do a count was today.

We are blessed to be a hotspot for monarchs right now. An 18 acre field of fully blooming alfalfa and prairie grasses backs up to our property. The monarchs feed there by day.  Hundreds of them right now. It is difficult to estimate how many are in the field right now, I'm guessing more than 400 - but that's what I could reasonably report. They roost in our tree groves at night. A dozen are free flying around our property at any given moment. They have been roosting for a week, and flying around and feeding for about 2. It was a labor of love to go out into the field this morning to observe them. The flowers are taller than my knee high boots, and the honey bees and bumble bees love the field too. Didn't need one of those down my boot.
We were at Nickel Beach on the north shore of Lake Erie and there were hundreds of monarchs.
Another perfect weather day here in N. Minneapolis.
in the short time that we were at Lookout Point in Harpswell we saw at least 10 Monarchs flying from  our position towards Birch Island, 1 1/2 miles west. Time was 3:45 PM at low tide.

We were at Selfridge Air National Guard Base near Lake Huron. We were there from about 10 am to 4 pm. We were sitting in the same location pretty much all day. At least a dozen Monarchs flew past us. They were headed south. Large and beautiful. They were all cruising too. I couldn't even pull a camera out and they were just sailing past us. My daughter was in another location at the air show and she said she was seeing them all day as well. Great sign.

It was a beautiful autumn day with temperatures in the mid-70s, slight breeze, sunny skies. We saw at least 20 monarchs, among many other species of butterflies, at the Waterloo-Mud Lake Wildlife Area. The butterflies had many nectar sources to choose from, but most of them seemed to prefer Thistle flowers.
68 Migrating adults in a 200 acre field in Gratiot County.

Allens Pond Census by the Mass Butterfly Club forwarded by Lauren Miller-Donnelly, MassAudubon South Coast Sanctuaries reported 214 monarchs at Allens Neck on Saturday, September 6th.Location: 41.530, -71.01Great turnout for yesterday's count (9/6/14).  It was foggy and wet to start off. After the group searched the Field Station quickly we decided to head to Allens Neck to check out the large fields on the grassland loop.  Once wegot there we started to see Monarchs sitting/resting and some nectaring in in the red clover/big bluestem dominated field. We walked through in a spread-out line and in the end we tallied 214 Monarchs, but I feel it was likely 300 considering we only walked though half.  We did see one female laying eggs at the start, and saw some large caterpillars. There is a lot of milkweed in these fields. With all the Monarchs and wet- vegetation that was quite a feat! Grassland Loop is in bright green, just south of Allens Neck Road.  It’s a Monarch magnet with goldenrod and red clover abundant J I manage these fields for Grassland Birds, the field that they were in are restored warm-season grasses and red clover that are mown after Bobolink fledge ~ July 15th.  I believe a lot of the Monarchs were fresh from the region as these fields also host thousands of vigorously growing milkweed plants.The sun then came out after lunch and it looks like a great list for Sylvan for the the afternoon.Counts (monarchs only): Field Station garden: 2 MonarchAllens Neck: 214 MonarchSylvan Nursery: 5 Monarch
During a two-hour sail, we saw 35 monarchs flying WSW over Lake Minnetonka between Gray's Bay, Stubb Bay and St. Louis Bay
Have about 3 dozen monarchs nectaring on my liatris again today.  Quite windy here.  Temp 72.  Cold air coming Wednesday.

Clear, 70 degrees, light variable winds.  All Monarchs were feeding on a large planting of flowering Joe Pye Weed in the town garden.  It was the largest group we have observed in three years.In addition, we spotted three Monarchs flying general south along the Lake Michigan shoreline at Van's Beach in Leland.

Hundreds of monarchs emerged out of the wooded peninsula just north of my cottage on Blind Sodus Bay, Lake Ontario this evening. They flew primarily solo and in pairs following the shoreline from north to south along the lake.The monarchs were not settling near here, they were on the move down the shoreline after emerging out of the wooded area just north of my cottage which is located on a peninsula that separates Blind Sodus Bay from Lake Ontario. From my vantage point I cannot tell how far they travelled down the shoreline as they were soon out of sight about 1/2 mile away. This sighting occurred at 7:30 pm, just before the sunset, and the wind was very calm. After the sun set, I did not see another monarch. As far as I know there was no unusual stimulus north of me that would cause the monarchs to move.  Monarchs have been flying south past my place for the past two weeks or so at random intervals throughout the day and always one at a time. This evening's sighting was different in the increased quantity and frequency of their appearance.

While conducting the Rosetta McClain Gardens (RMG) Hawk Watch on Saturday (9/6) we watched as Monarch after Monarch flew over the park on migration. They were everywhere! Between the hours of 11:00AM and 5:30PM my best guess would be that we saw somewhere in the neighbourhood of 1000! Oh, happy day!

Rosetta McClain Gardens is situated atop the Scarborough Bluffs in the east end of Toronto. Entry to this small 9.3 hectare park is off of Kingston Road where it intersects with Glen Everest Road, approximately 1 km east of the Kingston Road/Birchmount Road intersection. Coordinates are: 43.415185, -79.152275
During an hour and one-half visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, we observed 52 monarchs. They were nectaring primarily on sunflowers.

Almost all day on Sept 3 we had Monarch visitors. Individuals came and went through the day on our patch of buttercups, and a group of 12 alighted in the vegetable/flower garden together and then went about their business. :) Since that time several more individuals have come through but no other groups.

Waystation 6866 in Mariatown, Ontario:   Counted 108 adults between 11 am and 12:30 pm. They are still flowing through. Probably similar numbers yesterday but had no time to do a proper count. All headed from the north to the southwest. Most stopping briefly to feed some just flutter about and leave.

Here's a shot from Friday, Aug. 29th in the late afternoon.  Around 31 monarchs all at once at in our small prairie garden in Minneapolis, Minnesota. It's full of blazing stars that have attracted a large number of monarchs this year, much more than last year. The monarchs leave near sunset and we don't know where they spend the night.Season Summary as of August 29:Thursday, August 21: 21 monarchsFriday, August 22: 21 monarchsAugust 26: 14 monarchsAugust 27 and 28: Fewer 6-9 at any given time together, none taggedAugust 29: 30 monarchs
A cloudy day. The observation and photo were done about 4:30pm CST.
Most adult Monarchs sighted along Lake Michigan.
Monarchs were flying in our yard and enjoying the thistle along the river.

Initially about 60 which increased to around 100 in size all grouped on a cluster of Zinnia and Milkweed we have in our yard just for them.  All spring and summer this cluster would draw 1-2 a day until this event. Since then we've had 3-4 on this cluster of plants at all times jousting with the bumble bees for the red zinnia's which seem to be the favorite.

I saw over 100  Monarchs nectaring on goldenrod around the information center at the Miners Castle formation in the Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore in Michigan's Upper Peninsula along the southern shore of Lake Superior.  Also saw at least 30 Monarchs flying along the shoreline on a trail east of Miners Castle.
Fewer today than the past week. Very windy, they burrow down lower in the flowers. Harder to see them and count them. So beautiful.

I captured,tagged, and released 50 adults in two hours time.   There were many, many others that I missed or didn't catch.  They absolutely love clover/hay fields that are in full bloom.  Two of my students brought in two monarch larva this morning (9-10-14).

Today I took a drive from Elk River, Minnesota (northwest side of the twin cities) to Fargo, North Dakota and back. I counted at least 120 monarchs while driving up and back and around 20 while in Fargo for about 2 hours. Also yesterday I was at a wedding in Roseville, Minnesota and seen around 20 nectoring in the flowers around the outdoor wedding. Lastly I have tagged about 120 monarchs in the last 2 weeks.

Lots of nectaring going on in the alfalfa field near our home!
Counted at least 35 Monarchs nectaring on flowers in the gardens surrounding the Grand Hotel.

From Long Point, Ontario - an Important Bird Area and significant bird and insect migration location. A sand spit 40 km long and stretching into Lake Erie, and across from Erie, PA: James Holdsworth reports: I would add that my wife and I had est. 400 along the main beach at Long Point yesterday (9/7).

Hello this morning We were in Lachine yesterday morning (9/7) around 11am. Super nice day for a walk along the river. I saw a monarch who was crossing the river. We sat down and we could see monarchs approximately every 5 minutes. For the short time that had stalled, there were about twenty of them, all were heading south. We continued our walk into town, and yet you could see monarchs who were heading toward the river. At home, I saw only a few monarchs throughout the summer. Have you seen an increase in population this year? I met people from Sherbrooke this weekend and it seems that there are more Monarch this year. have a nice day
