Courtesy of Don Davis

9/7, Kent Island, MD (just across the Bay Bridge from Annapolis)Terrapin Park had plentiful nectar sources in their planted meadow and along the beachfront trail. A tickseed sunflower (Bidens sp.) was in full bloom and was luring in red admirals, painted ladies, American ladies, pearl crescents, grey and red-banded hairstreaks, orange and clouded sulfurs, sleepy orange, sachems, and monarchs. In 20 minutes we counted about 3 dozen nectaring monarchs, including 2 ovipositing females. Common milkweed was spent, but swamp milkweed had been mowed back along the ponds and had re-sprouted with tender growth. Even though conditions were favorable for migration (sun, 78 degrees F, wind NNE at 11mph) we did not see a single monarch engaging in directional flight. Nor did we see any monarchs making the bay crossing as we drove back and forth over the bridge.Chesapeake Environmental Center in Grasonville had saltmarsh aster, seaside goldenrod, groundsel-tree, and saltmarsh fleabane in bloom, but no monarchs were spotted there. However, red-spotted purple and common buckeye were seen sipping from smashed fruit in the parking lot.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

gliding at slow relaxed pace protected from the wind by the tall trees in the park but not stopping to nectar on garden plants such as Helianthus, Buddleia or coneflower as was common last week. The onshore wind was forcing movement towards the southwest along the shoreline (towards Kingsville and no doubt, Holiday Beach.No signs of mating activity or even male territoriality.As the sun set, four late arrivals from the cornfields north of Leamington arrived at a roosting area on a relic homestead's overmature landscaping material reaching 90 feet skyward from a good Goldenrod patch. All were fresh.The coming storms may cause accumulation of migrants there.
Maintenance team reported seeing 1,000 monarchs or more on the site of Carpenter St. Croix Valley Nature Center

On the 7th and 9th of September,  H U G E numbers (close to a thousand) nectared on a red clover field (sunny afternoons, temp near 70 degrees) taking our collective breaths away.  Only a video camera would have encompassed the sight.  (Oh, to have observed THAT roost!!!!!)
Observed between 6:30 am and 8:30 am on Schoodic Point, Gouldsboro, ME

I participate in an annual hawk watch and we also tag monarchs for Monarch watch.  Sept 12 about 2pm after a steady stream all day the monarchs just took over.  They were literally everywhere.  1000+ to be conservative.  They were also roosting just west of Rosetta McClain gardens.  Quite a sight!
Steady flow of monarchs along the bluffs, nw side of lake ontario.

First big day of monarch movement along the Scarborough bluffs.  Up to and over 1000 flying west along the NW shore of Lake Ontario.  Quite a site.Check the blog at http://raptorwatch.blogspot.caScroll down to see monarch numbers and click on Monarch at the top of the blog.Terry
cloudy, winds coming out of the north
First good day of 2014 monarch migration south along the Scarborough bluffs.  Monarchs definitely  starting to move through!
Day 2 of monarch movement south - 21 counted
Good solid flow of monarchs today, 200 moving south
A good day.  50 monarchs migrating.
Slower today but monarchs still moving south!

After five straight days of cloudy/rainy weather I was ready for some sun.  It seemed like the monarchs were too.  Today I went outside with my brother to see if we could tag monarchs.  We were out there for half an hour and we saw fourteen monarchs.  All of them were headed south.  One of them was nectaring on our zinnias.  At one point we saw two monarchs in the sky pretty close to each other.  It was mostly sunny and the temperature was 57 degrees fahrenheit.
We was at least 100 monarchs in directional flight from northeast to southwest at our house in Manitowoc, WI from around 2pm to 3pm.  Some were low and stopping at the flowers others were very high.

Cold front hit this morning (9/13) - had an early frost.  Found 17 monarchs roosting (that presumably arrived last night) about 50 feet up in our old red pine.  Took a photo with the waning gibbous phase moon descending behind them. Found 120+ monarchs in the mid afternoon (9/13)! - already clumping together in our north grove trying to stay out of our strong/chilly SW wind.

Tremendous migration continues through Rosetta McClain along the Scarborough bluffs.  Monarchs are being sighted all along the lakeshore in the Beaches area of Toronto.  Mexico, get ready! here they come!

Monarchs were definitely on the move today as the early morning temperature was 39 degrees before the day warmed up. During two hours of observation at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, we observed 225 monarchs--the largest number this fall. The monarchs were mostly nectaring on sunflowers as they flew from point to point. While driving to and returning from the refuge, we counted another 25 monarchs along the roadways.
On daily walk we are seeing about 10 to 15 monarchs every 15 minutes
Monarchs are moving from North to South thru our yard, generally following a tree line that lines the west side of our property. It is a cool morning with a 10-15 mph wind.

Colonel Samuel Smith Park - also know as Etobicoke Spit is along the Lake Ontario shoreline, with the City of Toronto to the East.  Between 8:30-10:30 AM, numerous adult Monarchs could be seen on the Goldenrods throughout the entire park.  I am sure I under estimated the count of 1000 plus.  Monarchs were nectaring and flying on the Goldenrods.  What an amazing sight and one of those moments when you do not have a camera.  Weather conditions: Sunny at the time, Temperature - 12C, Humidity 63%, Winds N @ 13kph

Monarch numbers continued to rise in our backyard and in the  lot next to our house.  In 30 minutes  I counted 19 monarchs flying south and one taking a break to nectar on our zinnias.  It was sunny and the temperature was around 60 degrees Fahrenheit.  The wind was coming from the SW at 7 mph.

The monarchs were flying across a 15 mile wide expanse of Lake Huron from Canada to the Lexington, Michigan area.  I was at the pier on the water in Lexington and counted no less than 40 adults in migration coming across the lake and going up into the pine trees on the US side in Lexington, within less than a two hour period.  I have watched the migration at New Haven Michigan Beach also, of the monarchs coming across Lake St. Clair from Canada to the US side.    I am 59 years old, not school age.

Driving home from church, which is about 2 miles, i saw at least 25 monarch. At church on the butterfly bush and the surrounding grounds there were 5 monarchs. Before i left for church in my backyard there were 5 monarch.  Omaha must have hundreds if not thousands of monarchs passing through today.  The temperature is in the high 60's. The wind like yesterday seems to be out of the northwest.  Hope Mexico is ready. I have never seem monarch like this.
Unloading hay and noticed many monarchs just passing through. Singles and some loose groups of up to 6 butterflies.

Hundreds of monarchs were gathering along "Sunnyside Park" in Toronto. The park is on the north shore of Lake Ontario. As the day became cooler the monarchs were collecting in the upper branches of the willow trees. I had observed them throughout the day floating through the south end of the city, just above the lake. I had counted 72 and then decided to head to the lake where I was sure I would see more. And I did. Can't help but feel that the numbers will be better this year. I had counted 21 throughout the summer and was happy with that. But this day was spectacular.

Editor's note: Also in Roost
Had 138 Monarchs in the native pasture and yard this afternoon - feeding mainly on the aster, particularly the New England Asters...attaching a photo file from today.
We rented a home on lake mi.  We saw at least 50  flying along the beach  wonderful   Experience for the grandchildren!

This was another excellent day for monitoring monarch butterflies at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. The day was sunny, and the temperature was near 60 degrees. In two hours and a half, 285 monarchs were observed nectaring on the many fields of sunflowers. Another 15 monarchs were seen along the roadways.

Today (9/14), I witnessed my first decent push of migrant Monarchs here in Riley County, KS. While doing collections for a Plant Taxonomy class, I was surrounded by hundreds of blooming Dotted Gayfeather (Liatris punctata), Rough Blazing Star (Liatris aspera), Maximilian Sunflower (Helianthus maximiliani), and others. On all these wonderful nectar plants were dozens of Monarchs loading up on nectar and heading slowly south (final estimate after 3.5 hours ~ 45). I noticed that in this early push, the Monarchs were not as frantic and oblivious to my presence as they usually are during our peak in a week or so, when you can easily walk right up to them while they probe desperately for nectar, and they are observed moving southward with greater zeal. I also noted that out here in the Flint Hills, I have been finding numerous larvae in various stages (3rd-5th instar), especially on Milkweed Vine (Cynanchum laeve) over the past week. I don't recall seeing many larvae this late into September in past years. I hope the weather cooperates and allows these later larvae to mature and head south to Mexico. Looking forward to increasing numbers of Monarchs,

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

First fall living here. Past week or so have seen quite a few singles but this morning there seemed to be a steady flow for over an hour with stragglers before and after. For the peak time, of about an hour between 930-1030am, there were about a half dozen always visible flying by my window. Surprised and thrilled about it, I decided to google their migratory path and came across this site...
From 1 PM until 2 PM, we observed 24 Monarchs making their way south, along the shore of Lake Michigan.  There was a light, persistent breeze and they were cruising!
We were on the lost Dunes Golf Course and observed many monarchs flying south
The morning was windy and cloudy after a brief overnight rain at Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge. In an hour visit, we observed 20 monarchs.

Peak monarch migration continued through Rosetta McClain Gardens in Scarborough  today.  We counted conservatively 4-8 per minute 11-am to 2pm.  Then the sun went behind clouds and all stopped!Conservatively 1000 monarchs went by.  Tagged 16 today TGL 358 to TGL 376 on the remote chance anyone finds a tagged monarch south/west of Rosetta!  The monarch flow must slow down soon!  Quite a sight!
cloudy, cooler day, many clustering together on the asters on the north shore at sunnyside park

Driving from LIncoln to North Platte, we observed 2-4 monarchs every several miles crossing in front of the car. On the Previous evening, at the Spring Creek Prairie Audubon Center, in Denton, NE we saw many adult monarchs, and many caterpillars as well.

Canary district to St. Lawrence market and beyond along the train tracks there were 100+ monarchs on the move or feeding on the wild plants along the tracks. This was observed while I was on the GO Train @8:30AM September 15, 2014.

I just got to my office after doing two of my weekly butterfly counts at local tallgrass prairies, and it was obvious that the crest of the migration wave was passing through Omaha today. The weather conditions were very good: sunny, upper 60's, winds very light & variable (although mainly from the west/southwest). The numbers observed were incredible. Both of my transects are about two miles around. At one prairie, I counted 79, almost all in directional migratory flight or nectaring. At the other prairie, I counted 150! By contrast, my peak daily numbers for the equivalent migration period last year were 8 and 12, respectively.A lot were nectaring; here's the flowers they were on: Tall Thistle â€“ 92, Rigid Goldenrod â€“ 47, Canada Goldenrod â€“ 23, Azure Aster â€“ 2.There were also a lot in my backyard at home this morning, on the zinnias and buddleia.There are also quite a few Painted Ladies at the moment, and the skies were full of migrating green darner dragonflies.An amazing day!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I saw monarchs passing through on Saturday and Sunday- 9/14 and 9/15/14. I saw a few dozen when I went for a jog in West Des Moines, IA around 11:00 in the morning. I tried to take some pictures of them, but they were on a mission. I also saw some flying over Saylorville Lake, near Ankeny, Iowa on Sunday afternnon. I did manage to get some pictures of those. Tricky little buggers to catch on camera. It's exciting to see more this year.

While taking a group of seniors for our daily walk aropund the waterfront at Frenchmen's Bay in Pickering I noticed my first monarch, then a second, and a third. What followed was amazing. I haven't seen so many Monarchs in 3 three years. We totalled 87 in all. And that was a half hour walk.
I'v seen over 20 monarchs flying through may small yard in the last 30 minutes.  They're stopping to nectar on many plants but are especially keen on my butterfly bush and seven sons flower.
From 1:30PM - 2:00PM, 50 Monarchs flew across our beach yard on the shore of Lake Michigan.  A few stopped to rest on the goldenrod in our yard.

I counted 180 monarchs in ten minutes along the Western shore of Lake Michigan on the Concordia University Wisconsin campus.  Wind was from the NW @ 4mph gusting to 10mph.  Temp 62 degrees F. Later the wind shifted to the Southeast and the numbers dropped to 18/10 minutes of observation.  This is the largest count we have had in several years!

Over the past few days I've observed monarchs one or two at a time, today  I observed several monarchs in large group definitely 60 plus heading south. The weather was unseasonal cold the past few days but to is warm, clear skies and light breeze.

Over the past few days I've observed monarchs one or two at a time, today  I observed several monarchs in large group definitely 60 plus heading south. The weather was unseasonal cold the past few days but to is warm, clear skies and light breeze.

During a 1hr walk in Thompson Park/Leslie Spit by Lake Ontario in Toronto we counted 75 Adult Monarch butterflies flying around  and nectaring on and among the numerous Golden Rods in bloom in this park. It was a wonderful surprise to us, since we so far this Summer had only seen 2 Monarchs in Toronto. The previous 2 nights had been very cold in Toronto (`7-8 C)for Monarch activity, so we thought they might just be waiting for warmer weather to fly across Lake Ontario. However when I got back home I discovered (on this web-site) that a lot of Monarch 'fans' along Lake Ontario have been seeing large numbers of migrating Monarchs the past few days. I am so happy. Does it mean,that the numbers of Monarchs migrating south have increased quite a lot this year?

Our team is happy to report that this afternoon brought a nice steady flight of monarchs in to Cape May Point!!! We had a gentle NW wind all day. The dragonflies were also sailing in on the winds. We hope to report more in the coming weeks.

Yes, we've been waiting and hoping they'd arrive!! Our census results; 55.6 monarchs per hour which translates to at least 500 monarchs through CM. The census was done 3 times for about 18 minutes each time. The interns tagged at least 50 plus butterflies. The weather was sunny, 73 degrees with a light north west wind.
160 Monarchs moved through Hawk Cliff which is just east of Port Stanley, Ontario.
Approximately 500 Monarchs moved through Hawk Cliff just east of Port Stanley, Ontario

20-25 per hr moving westward along shoreline bluff through Seacliff Park starting about 13:00 EDT. They were moving along Robson Rd from Sturgeon Creek area into a SW steady but light wing, by using the deciduous trees and landscape material. At 18:30 there were fewer flying but more high in the maple trees.I counted 100+  flying at low altitude and the I rest counted with binoculars monarchs feeding mostly at about 70 acres of Red Clover being used to condition Brookstone clay fields 3 miles north of Point Pelee National Park.  At 16:00 EDT, there was movement westward from this field towards the sun,  rather than southward towards the park.Smaller numbers were found in two spots on both red clover and Solidago.air temperature 19 Celsius (66 F)

My husband has reported seeing 4 monarchs per minute while at work in north eastern Manitowoc today.  I have also been getting phone calls from people in the Two Rivers area reporting a significant increase in Monarchs in their area.

On September 15th, we started noticing more and more monarchs and they all seemed to be heading in the same direction. We sat across the street from Lake Champlain and watched them fly overhead.

We saw 206 and they were flying by. I did not notice them nectaring.September 16th was a cooler overcast day, but the monarchs were still heading south.

Today I counted 606 monarchs in 10 hours of a stationary spot at the shoreline of Lake Huron at Harrisville State Park. Weather was mostly sunny and winds were very light from the WSW. Temperature was 55F at the start of the count at 9AM and 63F at the end of the count at 7PM, with a high of 65F in between. Most of the monarchs flew 50-70' above the beach with a few at 300'. When the sun was out, the monarchs were high and with the clouds around the monarch flew lower and some landed on the beach or nectar on goldenrod or white asters. This is the highest peak day I have had here since September 12, 2010, when I counted 517. Here is my hour to hour count between 9AM and 7PM: 1st hour-60, 2nd hour-120, 3rd hour-106, 4th hour-92, 5th hour-80, 6th hour-56, 7th hour-40, 8th hour-28, 9th hour-14, and 10th hour-10. Total= 606.

Update September 21:The week started out with rain and ended in rain. From September 15 to September 21, I observed 729 monarchs on migration as compared to 40 last year for same time period. From August 18 to September 21, I counted 764 as compared to 310 last year for same time period. By the way, I observed just 44 for the entire season in 2012!
Slower migration today, but steady all day long.  About 3pm the monarchs started to land in the gardens.  Tagged 9 today.  Migration definitely  slowing down here.
My friends invited me on their boat, and while we were moored in the harbor off of Stamford, CT, we noticed a Monarch headed Southwest.  Eight more streamed by.

40 adult Monarchs were spotted very high up as they came from northwest to southwest over the Allegheny Front at Dolly Sods.  They were observed at the bird banding station.  It was thought that they were tiny birds flying up very high, and binoculars proved them to be Monarchs!

I've been seeing more Monarchs every day. Today I observed 29 monarchs in 30 minutes, so the rate is about one monarch per minute.  I've definitely seen over a hundred monarchs this fall all ready.  Last year I saw one in Chicago but none in Iowa.  Now I just want to see a roost.
Lots of monarchs migrating through while at work. Counted 48 in a 1.5 hours!
While walking to recess we spotted a large number on our butterfly bushes planted in our drive.  Absolutely gorgeous!
A very calm mild day. I was looking at the clouds and saw one monarch, then another. I got to 7 then stopped (about 4 minutes).
Bright sunshine, a bit of a breeze, 60 degrees

Our class is very excited today because we just keep seeing Monarchs all day long.  We saw them from our classroom window, from the school library and while outside playing. We expect to see more because we know that this is a sign of fall migration.  We are happy to know that there are more butterflies this year than last year. We are proud of the work we did raising them over the summer and last year.

I observed 150 butterflies in 1 hour today passing by the Orford bluffs overlooking Lake Erie at Clearville Park. Weather conditions today are partly sunny 65F with a light southeast wind. This wave of butterflies appears to extend several miles inland from the lake which would make the actual number in the many thousands per hour moving through. Traffic was dodging butterflies all the way to Ridgetown this afternoon. These butterflies are in their way to Pt. Pelee, 30 miles to the south-west and the southernmost point in Canada.  The current weather is expected to hold for several days.

Today was a beautiful sunny day at Kenesserie Tallgrass Prairie. Sunny 65 F. I observed about 60 Monarchs per hour moving past the observation deck, all moving in a south-west direction. This flow continued for several hours in the afternoon and diminished to about 25 per hour by 4:00 PM.
Butterfly bush swarming with many kinds of butterflies, but mostly Monarch.

I thought the monarchs were slowing down, but the flow continued very steady 10am to 2pm today.  At times close to 6 per minute passing our hawk watch at Rosetta McClain.  A conservative 350+ monarchs today.  Tagged 7.  Interesting that so many go by high and occasionally through the day they start landing and feeding in the park.  I'm not sure what starts this process, sun,temp, wind? but the change in the monarch flow is very noticeable when it occurs.  Terry See attached photo of TGL 387 tagged and on its way to Mexico!

While birding in Bloomington Park near the town of Clinton, Kansas between 11:30 and 2:00 p.m. on 9/16/14, I saw several adult Monarchs flying in the area around Clinton Lake.  I estimated 15-20. I looked up once while standing on the beach at Bloomington Park to watch migrating American White Pelicans, flying high and headed straight south, and during that moment a Monarch flew right past me, headed in the same direction. Yesterday's temperature was 69 degrees, sunny, calm.
Many groups of butterflies feeding on clover

WE observed over 100 Monarch Butterflies while working outside in our back yard.  They particularly liked our Zinias flower garden as well as our Marigold flowers.  We also observed Rufus Hummingbirds on our feeders as well as one female Ruby Throated.  This year has not been a good summer for the Hummingbird sightings.
Over 1000 Monarchs moved through Hawk Cliff, just east of Port Stanley, Ontario from 10-5. 64 were tagged for Monarch Watch. Migration Rate: 143 per hour

Took a short 2 lane highway road trip on US Highway 6 (Hwy 6 Parallels a few miles south of I-80)between the Moline, IL and Iowa City, Ia. Heading west on Hwy 6 at about 10:30AM with temperatures still brisk in the mid to upper 50's and overcast sky's I spotted 8 Monarchs at separate times crossing U.S.Hwy 6 heading South. Returning back East at about 3:30 pm with Temperatures now in the mid 60's and beautiful Sunny sky's spotted 2 more for a total of 10 Monarchs in Flight. I would like to note all but 2 were observing my rules I set down to my released Monarchs, telling them before release to fly high, but when they must fly low stay at least 30 feet above the Roadways and Highways to avoid being struck by motor vehicle, my released Monarchs are passing the word :)I mark this a Peak sighting because: 1.Usually (while that number is small) you still don't see that many Monarchs in flight, especially on a cool morning. 2. Saw no other Butterfly's Period in the AM besides the Monarchs braving the cool overcast sky's.3. The biggest clue however was they were all heading without a doubt directly to the South, no messing around. Note: I believe the reason I saw fewer in the PM because they were sensing the evening coming on and were looking for to feed and roost.
The weather was perfect. I seen them all day while gardening.

YESTERDAYS NUMBERS UNDERESTIMATE HOW many adults are nectaring in the 100 acres (minus 30 turned under already) of Red Clover at this location. Today I counted and estimated after a more thorough inspection from the concession roads with binoculars. In the west half of the fields bisected by Mersea Rd 12 (N-S) driving along Mersea Rd C (east of Point Pelee Drive) I counted over 700 monarchs. So it is easy to estimate at least 1500 butterflies feeding on Red Clover in both fields. The farmer property owner estimates that he saw over 5000 Monarchs today in the field he's plowing, and at least that many in the untouched field. Many of the butterflies are actually roosting in these fields overnight, even though some are flying to nearby trees.Another property on the Bevel Line had 70 Monarchs on Red Clover in 150 ft x 150 ft feet approx.

Just a multitude of monarchs in the yard today and everywhere I went.  30 miles south , 10 miles west, just everywhere today, flying and nectaringNice sight, have not seen so many in a long long timeJust sorry to see them leave, knowing winter will be knocking at our door soon!
Observed 6 monarchs within 10 minutes flying southwest at about noon today

Observation made 3:30-5 pm while kayaking on Lake St Clair.  Monarchs flying  from the north/NE to the South/SW over southern portion of Lake St Clair. Clear bright sunny skies. Wind 8-10 mph.Migration Rate: 33 per hour

I saw my first wave of migration here today.  I have been seeing them in small groups and singles at various times today but heavier later in the afternoon.  They were headed into our trees for night but with day temps in the nineties there were no tight roosts that I could find.

My friend Jackie Taylor, a naturalist with the Lake Erie Islands Nature Center, reported seeing "many many monarchs around the island today." She is on South Bass island in Lake Erie.  Jackie did not ake an exact count, but niticed dozens all day long.  The JN form requires that a number be entered, so I just put 100.  But Jackie does not know the exact count.  She has used up all 100 of her tags since this past weekend.

During a two-day trip from central to western Iowa and return,  we observed 75 monarch crossing the roadways the first day and 45 the   second day. Nearly all were headed south. The weather was mild,and the days were sunny.
~30 Monarchs heading West over Sayers Reservior

same clover patch as reported on 17 Sept. 2014Emptied clover field after sunset, Wind shifted from SW to North and temperature dropped to ca. 50 F Check at 8:05 EDT revealed no Monarchs left here. The Point Pelee tip area roost was reported (reliably) to have emptied between 7:30-8:30 EDT and latecomers got to watch single Monarchs flying and Sharp-shinned and Coopers Hawks in migration.Fresh Monarch migrants are collecting at the clover sites as the days progresses with the clear skies, sunshine favourable winds are working for them.
I captured 25 for tagging but missed many, many more. Healthy, large adults nectaring on goldenrod flowers between 5:30 and 7 p.m. I don't think this is the peak of migration yet however.

Not as a group but as a steady rate.  Some very high, some lower to ground, some 6 feet or so from ground.  Lots of dragonflies in the same field where we saw the monarchs. Do dragonflies eat monarchs?  I need to check.  1:00 to 1:30 PM

While at a fast food restaurant in Scarborough, went to look at the hydro corridor, which is a miles-long 100 m wide green space on the middle of this suburban area. In my immediate vicinity I could see more monarchs flying about and feeding on clover than I have ever seen before at one time.

Pulled in the driveway at 5:00PM, weather sunny 18C light SW wind and saw one monarch in the usual flight path we have been observing this year (south).  And then they kept on coming; over the roof of our ranch-style house; down the side yard; across the abutting soybean field; even through the intersection of Essex County Road 46 (our road) and County Road 19 (Manning Road) in ones, twos and threes!  Many were flying just above our heads; I could have reached out and touched them!  We stood at the end of our driveway and just kept counting.  A very small number stopped to nectar on Red Clover in an empty field across the street to the south; most just kept on going.  At about 6:15 I noticed some starting to roost on the east side of a large cottonwood tree abutting the soybean field to the north of our 1 acre yard (separate report) but many more kept going.  We have lived here 20 years and I have never witnessed anything like this!  Where were they coming from; there are no significant natural areas to the north of us?  The MacDonald Cartier Freeway (Highway 401) is to the north and the Ministry of Transportation to their credit, has for many years now left the substantial verges as a natural regeneration area and I have noticed lots of Common Milkweed and native nectar sources there.  Could they all have come from there?  Could Manning Road which bisects the county just west of us have acted like a barrier to channel them here?  Look out Ohio here they come! Migration Rate: 191 per hour

Edward Cole and three other members of the AuSable Valley Audubon Club called me today to report monarchs in the "hundreds" at Tawas Point State Park, East Tawas, MI, in Iosco County last night. Temperature was in the 60's with a cold front approaching on strong north winds predicted by morning. Monarchs were perched on pines and aspen trees way out on the point.

180 Monarchs were counted at 9:50-10:00AM. The wind was from the Northwest.  In the afternoon the wind shifted to the Southeast and a ten minute count dropped to 18 monarchs.  Apparently the west wind blows them toward Lake Michigan (Our Campus is on the Western shoreline) and they concentrate along the shoreline when the wind direction is from the West or Northwest.

I was waiting for a cab at 520 Maple Street, Saratoga Springs, NY when I noticed that monarch butterflies were migrating south. I watched as every few minutes another monarch fluttered by. They were above tree line and even though alone, each followed the same course south. It was thrilling. As executive director of Happy Tonics, Inc. a nonprofit with the Mission: Sanctuary for the Monarch Butterfly, I was thankful to see the monarchs migrating through Saratoga Springs, NY. Yesterday, I watched as one monarch was sipping nectar from fall flowers on Broadway, main business street in Saratoga Springs, NY. Viva las mariposas!
Definitely migrating, but the numbers this year are 10% or less of what we normally have in the yard.  Yard is designed with flowers for monarchs including milkweed, that didn't bloom this year.

200+ Monarchs continue to migrate through Rosetta McClain Gardens.  A slightly slower but still steady flow all day.  Monarchs were higher today...  all business "migrating".  Non tagged today as few came down to feed.  At the hawk watch we have anywhere from 10-40+ hawk watchers.  All are calling out "monarch" observations as they see them!  Many monarchs are sighted very high as we look for raptors!  They often fly with the eagles!  Migration Rate: 29 per hour

Another sunny day provided a scenario for migrating monarch butterflies. During a 75-minute visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, we counted 125 monarchs nectaring on the sunflowers and flying across the prairie.
The hawk watch counter tallied 160 monarchs coming down the dunes in about 5 hours, this morning. Migration Rate: 32 per hour

Sighted in morning between 8:30 a.m. and 8:45 a.m. and then again at about 5 p.m. and 5:30 p.m.  None tagged. Morning butterflies were mostly feeding.  Afternoon sightings were just passing through.  One found dead (not reported in 16 live sightings).

We were at the Charlestown Breachway between 5:15 and 6:30 pm.  Saw 107 monarchs during that time.  As I looked across the Sound at Block Island I was awed to think those tiny beings were able to fly over that stretch of water[or go into Manhattan and cross one of the bridges].
Over 25 (many in pairs) flying south past my window on the second story.
Lots of monarchs migrating through seeing 1 to as many as 5 a time every few minutes heading south. I'm less then a mile from downtown chicago!

Saw at least 15 adult Monarchs over my lunch time walk on the south end of the University of Illinois campus.  In addition, we released 25 tagged adults this morning, reared wild-found eggs or larvae.  The migration is in full swing, in east central Illinois.
Many adult monarchs spotted, all headed southwest flying along the Cherry Grove beach in Fire Island NY.

At around 2pm the sun came out and the monarchs started coming from the north at the rate of 2 a minute. At times there was more than two drifting. I counted until 3pm a total of 134 in that one hour.

I stopped for lunch at a park in Arapahoe, a small town in Nebraska, and immediately noticed a few large Monarchs flying & landing. Got out of vehicle to walk through trees and flowers and was pleased to see more Monarchs than I expected. Several flying and landing on flowers. When I walked under some pine trees I saw many more clinging to the underside of tree branches on this misty, foggy day. Walked around this small park to get a rough idea how many were visible in this area before sitting down for a wonderful lunch.
Running around town, saw 10 migrating south and a few stopping by my Butterfly Bush.
At least 10 monarchs an hour visiting out next or plants.
A beautiful sunny day with temps in the mid 70's we spotted 19 monarchs along the South Shore of Long Island.
Another beautiful sunny day with temps in the mid 70's and a light easterly wind,  spotted 31 monarchs. Subsequently on 09.19.14 I spotted 3 and on 09.20.14 I spotted 2 monarchs.
230 Monarchs moved through Hawk Cliff from 9:00-2:00. Migration Rate: 46 per hour

Today, I finally saw the first monarch, in my yard, for 2014. We watched for over 2 hours and counted 15 monarchs heading in a southerly direction. This sighting is probably my first and peak, fall migration all in one.

We have hedgerow alongside the road to our house for about 1/2 mile on both sides.  As we were driving down the road about 6 or 6:30 pm. I noticed Monarchs crossing the road from one side to the other along the whole half mile.  The 90 count may be a little conservative.  It appeared that it may have been a staging area for them.  About 2 hours later a cool front and brief rain storm came thru and may have taken them south.
Monarchs were flying, following the bluff of Lake Michigan and observation was at about 4:00 pm on a calm day with temperatures in the upper 60's.

While Traveling East on I-74 between Indianapolis,In and Cincinnati,Oh (my other set of eyes at the house here) observed approx. 20 Monarchs all flying in a southerly direction in the early AM hours of the day.

Very warm today in Northeast Pa. today. 80 degrees light 5 to 7 mph winds and very sunny. Best day so far for Monarchs passing through here today. Started seeing them as early as 8:15 a.m.  Finally decided to walk around the yard and lost count after 59 of them! Noticed they are really loving the butterfly bushes, zinnias and mexican sunflowers.

Have seen an increase in monarchs visiting our butterfly bush in the last 3-4 days. Yesterday we had a few dancing around all afternoon but today the number of visitors has jumped tremendously. Seems like a late arrival this year.

From 9:30AM - 10:00AM, I observed approximately 2 Monarchs per minute traveling south along the beach at Kohler-Andrae State Park, outside Sheboygan.  Returning to my home, along Lake Michigan, outside Cedar Grove, WI,  approximately 1:00PM, the wind had picked up and the temperature had dropped.  Not a Monarch to be found!
Calm morning (9:30AM - 10:00AM) along the beach at Kohler-Andrae State Park.
Today was an incredible Monarch day! I tagged 17 and saw dozens more!
Over 200 Monarchs through Hawk Cliff, just east of Port Stanley Ontario, today.
From 1-4 pm about a dozen mostly large monarchs stopped to tank up on tall zinnias and tithonia. Happy day! Last year I saw only two, and they were late. In 2010 we had a fall roost on Sept 25.

On Sunday, September 14, 2014 my friend, Mary L and myself went to one of the Waterman Prairie units in southern O'Brien County, Iowa to photograph a family of Trumpeter Swams that nest there. We parked in the roadside parking area and started our walk back to the pond. It was a beautiful and sunny late summer afternoon, the temperature hovered around 68 degrees and there was a mild breeze from the SW at about 10-15 MPH. Our visit lasted from about 4:00 - 6:00 pm.

Waterman Prairie at this location is in the Little Sioux River Valley and consists of rolling hills, valleys, and river overlooks now covered in prairie grasses and flowers. There is a lot of big bluestem, maximillian sunflower, goldenrod, coneflowers, and numerous other prairie plants. A small portion of the preserve is leased to an area farmer, so intermixed amongst the prairie grasses are smaller plots of corn, sunflowers, and alfalfa. The farmer gets to harvest these plots but must leave a certain percentage of the crop stand through the winter as food plots for the wildlife.

We started our hike down the path bordered on one side by mostly big bluestem and on the other side a corn plot backed by a sunflower plot. We were happy to see a few Monarchs flying here, perhaps 2 or 3 every 10 feet or so. After a short walk we left the standing corn and entered a field (photo) of approximately 30-40 acres that at one time may have been a hayfield but looks now like it has been seeded with a prairie/wildflower mix and is in its second or third year since established. There are a lot more prairie flowers here along with a good stand of red clover. This is where we encountered the mass of Monarchs.

As we walked across this field they would just rise up in a cloud - magical. About the only way I can describe it is like being in a Butterfly House say at an arboretum where the butterflies are flying all around you, only this was an open air one. Hard to place a number on how many were in the field but it was the same concentration across the entire field. If you would stand and turn in a circle there would probably be 20-30 you could count in a 50 foot radius. And there were probably two to three times that feeding on the flowers. It appeared they especially liked the red clover. There were easily thousands, perhaps 10's of thousand of Monarchs in that field and they appeared to mainly feeding rather than passing through.

I did return on the following Sunday, September 21, 2014. The weather and time was similiar to my first visit except the wind was out of the north. While their were a few butterflys in the fields this time, no Monarchs were seen. I assume they have moved further south.P. S. - We didn't find the Trumpeters on this trip - they had left the pond they had spent the summer on but I found them a few days on a neighboring pond outside of Waterman Prairie.

At least 100 butterflies nectaring in this 10 acre field of red clover. The roost I saw and reported had 50 monarchs, so I'm sure this number is an underestimate. This is definitely my peak migration sighting of the year. The abundance of blooming clover in this field is no doubt the reason so many were here.
Many more monarchs than could actually count - nectaring and roosting in shelter belt of honey locust and red cedar.
Many more monarchs than could actually count - nectaring and roosting in shelter belt of honey locust and red cedar. More sighted than on Friday, Sept. 19.

I was out at the Park this morning. Besides a fair showing of shorebirds, there were lots of Monarchs there, especially on Owen Point, and close by. But then you probably know that. Several times I trained my binocs on a "raptor" high in the sky and it turned out to be a Monarch!Winds were from northwest when photo taken, but later changed to south west. Not sure about temperatures, but there were no clouds and may have been in the mid 60's F at that time of day. Later approaching 70 F but cooler in the shade. About 60 monarchs sheltered at Owen Point tip.

Courtesy of Don Davis

After observing 3 Monarchs this morning, we were delighted to see 8 or 9 this afternoon; all drinking nectar and then resting on our Butterfly Bush. On another bush, across the yard, there were 3 more drinking. Maybe we are on a Flyway from NH or ME? There were 2 Fritillaries with them, and 4 big bees. Never seen so many together at one time before; they were very thirsty; let us get very close, and kept drinking!
Approx. 2pm -- 30 monarchs feeding on blazing star liatris!

Driving through Lewisburg today I spotted at least 12  Monarchs.  They were flying fairly low on this sunny but breezy day.  I am so thankful to see many more migrating this year!Migration Rate: 12 monarchs per hour
42 sightings of individual butterflies in flight, east-to-west, passing through our yard between 1:00 and 4:30 pm. Six of them stopped to feed on the zinnias in our Monarch Waystation.

Monarch migration continued all day today with most monarchs quite high. Temperature was cool with little sun.  The idea NW winds kept a steady flow along the Scarborough bluffs.  Few landed in the gardens as most just kept on going!  Attached is a shot of one tagged last Friday. Migration Rate: 19 monarchs per hour.

Stopping along Highway 175 several miles east of Eldora to photograph fall asters in a "Do not mow or spray" section of the ditch at about 5 pm on a sunny day, I encountered at least 15 monarchs feeding on the flowers, as well as clouded sulphurs, bees and other insects.  What beautiful "roadside bouquets!"

After so few monarchs migrating through the Maine Coast in 2013, it was delightful to make the following observations.Time: 2:00 pmHabitat:  Lush array of fall nectaring plants growing in extensive gardens directly on the ocean with a rocky coastline, surrounded by tall pine trees.Temperature and weather conditions: Bright and sunny with groupings of large cumulus clouds, light winds out of the North100 + nectaring migrating monarchsThe majority of monarchs netted and tagged or visually observed were males, 2 out of every 12 were females.Approximately 50% of the males were tattered, small pieces of their wings torn, looked like bird predation.  The females tagged or observed were pristine.When the sun was behind a large cumulus cloud for 3 minutes or more and the gardens became totally shaded, the monarchs departed from nectaring and flew up into the pines.When the sun came out again, they floated back down to the gardens and resumed nectaringThis was very similar to the "cloud effect" behavior exhibited in the overwintering Monarch colonies in Mexico.Overall, it has been an impressive year in downeast Maine for the Monarchs. There was ample milkweed late spring and summer, cool temperatures, enough rain, an abundance of native nectaring plants, and the summer was void of nor'easters or early hurricanes.
They were flying following the path of the Atlantic Ocean. In less than 5 minutes I saw 6. This is the most in two years.

Paul, Walker, and Conner were outside playing and we have been studying the Monarchs in school. We counted 35 Monarchs over 4 hours.  3 were on a butterfly bush but the rest were flying west toward the Jefferson National Forest. We were excited to bring our data to school for our teacher to add to the migration map.

Upon Releasing my last Monarch#6 today I observed 10-15 Monarchs feeding and most of them clustering on the Verbena Lollipop at the "Friends of Riverside(park)Garden"(Earlier Reports I called it something like Moline Parks Garden Club but this is the official name). I suspect a Roost nearby so in a few hours I'll attempt to go back to see what I can find. Never seen this many as I recall in my life in one place, except maybe as a child. I will do a separate report on my last Monarch#6 of the Season, who I am naming The Miracle Monarch.

I've observed monarchs in smaller groups of 10 - 12. They look very healthy, they're vibrant in color with wings unspent.The evenings bring a heavy dew just waiting for the right temperature to become a heavy frost. Migration Rate: 30 per hour
Two days ago witnessed directional flight. Today they are staying in the sunflower bushes.
About 15 Monarchs were sitting around my holly bush and marigolds
Driving between Lawrence and Kansas City I observed over 300 monarchs generally heading Southwest.  Migration Rate: 75 per hour.

540 Monarchs were sighted today, passing through Hawk Cliff just east of Port Stanley, Ontario. The peak was between 1:00 and 2:00 when 223 were sighted by a stationary count.  Overall Migration Rate: 77 monarchs per hour (over 7 hours).
Report from a friend visiting out east. Dozens of monarchs flock gardens at the mansion of Harkness Memorial State Park on Long Island Sound.
8 sightings of individual butterflies in flight, east-to-west, passing through our yard between 1:00 and 4:00 pm.

As the cloudy skies cleared and the temperatures rose to the lower 70's, the Monarchs began to fly in the early afternoon.  I was pleased to finally see them come one by one into my yard for refreshment from the flowers.  Several were very hungry and would spend at least 30 minutes feeding at the butterfly bushes.

Another sunny and beautiful day with temps in the mid 70's and a light southwest wind, I spotted over 220 monarchs. I arrived at the area at 5:45 pm and the monarchs were already roosting in the pine trees with the setting sun's rays caressing them. The golden rod has finally bloomed and is plentiful.
riding bikes along bike path in Humber River area observed hundreds of Monarch's flying over head, heading south west, in the mid afternoon.

Warmer temperatures brought the monarchs down into the gardens.  We tagged continuously through the day with a final tally of 20 tagged.  Final count was 103 passing through!  Migration is slowing down but its still so impressive and encouraging that the monarchs are recovering.  The final counts in Mexico will be very very interesting to see!Migration Rate: 17 per hour

9 Monarch butterflies spotted in 10 minutes today at Kenesserie Tallgrass Prairie. Some butterflies where dropping down into the prairie to nectar on sunflowers and goldenrod before resuming their south-west flight pattern at tree top level.  Nectar plants at this location are abundant and in good condition. I snapped a photo of a monarch nectoring on golden rod.
During a one-hour visit to Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge and its environs, we observed 10 monarchs.

Clearville Park is on the north shore of Lake Erie about 30 miles north east of Pt. Pelee. Monarchs pass through Clearville Park on their way to Pt. Pelee where they cross the lake to Ohio. Today there was very strong head winds blowing from the south-west so Monarchs were unable to make any progress so they just hung around the park. They were easy to spot on nectoring plants which are still abundant at this location.

My friend's report from Copan, OK:I saw them at copan lake swim beach yesterday (9/22).  There were about 30 of them.  It was about 1500 (3:00pm) weather was about hight 70's clear no wind.  they were all over the beach, sand. there are wild flowers still in bloom right along the lake and it appeared they were "swarming" from there to the sand on the beach.  thanks for taking interest.

oh, my ! ! !  i'd taken grandchildren to the pumpkin patch for the day.  in a wooded area, mostly hackberry, were unbelieveable numbers of roosting monarchs.  within a 2 square foot area, on one branch, were 17.  the numbers were consistent as we walked through the area.  what a blessing in too many ways.

Nectaring in our garden. Saw 6 at same time. I count the highest number visible at one sitting. They were coming and going about the flowers, so possible there were a higher number. Very active today, thus thinking migration is peaking.

Rob D reports to Ontario Butterflies: - not the numbers like Point Pelee etc, but out here in Eastern Ontario (Cornwall) on Sept.17, about 120 (+) Monarchs were observed between 2 and 3 pm feeding and resting on Asters below a transmission line.

Forwarded by Don Davis

Note received from Don T, Biodiversity Specialist in the park. While these reports of large numbers of monarchs along the north shores of Lakes Ontario and Erie are impressive, they do not give an accurate impression of where the population is at. These are excellent and strategic locations along the migration route, containing lots of flowering plants such as golden rod and New England aster, and generally reliable for seeing large numbers of monarchs:Hi DonYes lots of Monarchs this week at Presqu’ile. I was on High Bluff Island on Tuesday (Sept. 16) and did a few counts of the widely dispersed butterflies. 1000 is a conservative estimate based on a few random spot counts. I suspect the “real” number was at least twice that.

Courtesy of Don Davis

Today at 12:59 PMMany people enjoying an outdoor lunch are enjoying some free entertainment today 23 Sept 2014Monarchs are floating past their picnic tables at eye level, in quantity.Along the bluff overlooking Pigeon Bay with Pelee Island on the horizon, the Monarchs are moving along the crest of the bluff (westward) at a rate of more than 200 per hour) at heights from inches to 10 feet. The bluff is about 60 feet higher than the lake level.They are sampling white clover in the lawn and some are enjoying Helianthus in gardens at the edge of the park.There is a gentle wind from the southwest (at the movement).The parking lot at the Leamington Marina and at the Pelee Island Ferry are providing a similar spectacle for those who are interested.

The weather has been warm with little wind the past two days.  Witnessed a very steady flow of monarchs, all headed in the same direction, with many monarchs flying very high.  They seem to be on the move and much more noticeable.  When tagging, only about half have been stopping for feeding.  Monarchs seem to be increasing in numbers very gradually.  Tagged about 13 individuals so far in 2 days, with probably 3x that number actually seen.  Surprisingly seems to be half males, half females so far.  Hopefully peak will occur in the next week for tagging purposes.

As I traveled east to west and west to east there would be single monarchs going north to south across the highways.  This happened throughout the days.  The first one was at Florence, KY at a rest stop and then throughout the day on Saturday.  On Sunday I saw two.
I counted 26 out driving around Cheyenne Bottoms Wildlife Area and 87 at the Kansas Wetlands Education Center in 30 mins. nectaring on goldenrod.

For the last week, at afternoon recess, my fourth graders and I have observed at least 15 monarchs flying, they always come from the east direction and fly towards the west.  It is always the same route, just monarch after monarch flying! What a beautiful sight!

A beautiful day to watch Monarchs as a nice flight came through the area from 10am CDT to 12:30pm.  Observed 72 Monarchs during that period.  Thereafter, Monarchs continued to fly through my yard or stopped to feed at the flowers, but not in the numbers of the earlier wave.
Have been seeing multiple multiple monarchs for past 10 days!

After 24 hrs of blowing NE winds and rain, along the Outer Banks of North Carolina, in the morning hours of September 25th, the skies somewhat cleared and the winds diminished. While viewing the ocean, we began to see Monarch Butterflies soaring with the NNE winds, headed South along the dune line. Observing for only a total of about 1 to 2 hours during the course of the day, we were able to see approximately 20 to 30 Monarchs. At one point we were able to see or photograph at least 10 Monarchs feeding on Gaillardia, (Jobell) flowers that were growing along Hwy 12 just North of Buxton, NC.Sarah KingDoug Waters
I planted milkweed this summer, and it is blooming now.  I had 6 adult monarchs visit it--the most I have ever seen in my backyard.  I plan to plant more milkweed seeds before winter hits.

I am teacher at the Iowa School for the Deaf.  My students tagged the Monarch from Sept. 15-19th.  Our field next to our school is used for conservation.  The Monarch appeared like popcorn. They were in the hundreds. They were having a feeding frenzy.  Not able to tag as many as we hoped due to the denseness of the plants.  We went to the field Sept. 24th and saw only a few. Most of the Monarch have passed through the Council Bluffs area.
Numerous monarchs were spotted throughout the day with prime weather conditions.

Over 50 adults caught to tag for Monarch Watch.  Large, robust adults on nectar plants of all kinds.  New England Aster is in full bloom and a particular favorite.  Sunny day in the 80's.  Some were taking time to bask and/or roost in trees close by.
Beautiful monarchs migrating through our backyard. They nestled in our pine trees, directly next to some fruit trees, for the night. They are still here the morning of 9/26/14.

2:10pm - 2:25pm - 10 Monarchs passed through Detroit Metro Airport, in a southerly direction. They are often seen flying over the DTW runways during migration time. If only they were aware of the added risk they subject themselves to by going that route, or perhaps they know if they get on the right plane they could conserve a lot of their energy :)

Most of the Monarchs are nectaring on Lantana, some on New England Aster. Lots of other butterflies around, but Monarchs abound. This is the best year in four or five years. I've been on vacation and just got back and I'm glad the Monarchs are still around. I just walked around my yard and counted the Monarchs.

Point Pelee reported 2000+ Monarchs roosting in the trees on the evening of 9/16/14. My sister and I arrived at the park by 9:00am on 9/17, it was a clear and sunny morning and we were not able to locate the roost before they warmed enough to leave the trees. We traveled the West Beach foot trail, and there was a continuous stream of monarchs flying in the direction of the shore, but no matter how far we went in the direction they were coming from, they just kept coming from further away. When we finally decided to turn back and go south, we noticed a few stop in a tree. We stopped for a photo op and witnessed one after another join the group. They multiplied into the hundreds before our eyes. The time of this grouping was approximately 12:15pm, with another similar experience further down the trail around 1pm.I was able to tag 13 with my remaining tags for this season. THE512-THE524, (8) males and (5) females.

Our community college has a large patch of annual blood flower milkweed in their demonstration garden. Today we counted over 50 monarchs nectaring on the blood flowers! We have never seen so many concentrated in one area like this-what a beautiful sight! It was obvious that they were migratory monarchs feasting on the nectar. It was a warm, sunny day and they were just fluttering all over this patch of flowers.
Have had a large amount of monarchs this week stoping and eating off our butterfly bush. Today has been the most all week

Today I saw the most monarchs migrating south than I have seen since September 15.  I was pretty surprised.  We were at a soccer complex in Des Moines.  A few of them were even flying in the rain.  If we had been there later in the day we would have seen more.  I think this is one of those last big migration days before the end.  I also saw a monarch stop by in our garden on the zinnias.
Consistent sightings for a week now of 10 or more an hour. Some nectaring on hyssop plants in the garden but most are in flight.
approx 75 monarchs flying south along the shore line of Lake Michigan at about 50 to 75 feet altitude.

Estimate count of four hundred Monarchs on 40 acres plus of aster and sunflower.  Across the hill, a Maximillian Sunflower patch planted into a water way has count of 100 Monarchs.  A patch of .6 acre of Maximillian estimated at 500 Monarchs.  In total 1000 Monarchs at the farm late this afternoon.  Photo shows the largest patch of Sunflower which is in full bloom with Monarchs feeding today on the nectar.

Another beautiful day for the Monarchs to fly.  A nice flight came through the area; I saw butterflies most of the day, but officially counted 82 in 2 1/2 hours.  Mostly clear skies, temperature in low 80's (F), very light breezes.
My observations are just an estimate, over TWO days, Sept. 23-24. Monarchs feeding on asters, great sunny weather.

Driving around our immediate area I observed Monarchs constantly.  It was similar to a Disney movie.  All were in flight at a height between 6-30 ft. Beautiful sunshine day with temperature in the mid 80's, moderate humidity, soft breeze.most all were flighing in a SW direction.  The most Monarchs I've observed one "ONE" day in over 8-10 years.  Seems like the population is on the mend!!

Monarchs passing through the gardens are slowing down a little.  They are still migrating through but not in the numbers we have seen last week.  Tagged another 17 to finish my 100 tags!  We are on pace for a record number of raptors this year!  Let the north west winds stay strong!Terry
150 monarchs observed today from the raptor team at Rosetta McClain! Get ready Mexico!
The Monarchs keep flying by about four at a time, consistently.  They are all coming from the northeast, headed southwest, all following the exact same path!

While sitting on beach at Montauk Point I observed monarchs flying west towards Fire Island, N.Y. I arrived at beach abt noon and while sitting on sand started seeing monarchs flying over the dunes. They were alone and in small groups coming from water and flying over the dunes. I observed at least one hundred. Beautiful sight.

I stayed on the ocean beach at Montauk from about noon till near six pm. The weather was sunny and warm with a gently breeze coming from northeast (I think). I noticed a monrch while crossing over the dunes. After sitting and greeting friends, I started to notice more of them. Some coming from the direction of the ocean and others coming from the east. All heading west and flying low over the dunes. Some were traveling alone and others in groups of up to five or six. I was thrilled to see them. It seems that I was the only one who noticed them. I did make sure that others knew they were there. I even spoke to a beach employee asking if he had noticed the migration during the past week. He had no idea but said that he would be looking in the future. I walked the beach heading west staying close to the dunes and sure enough there they were beautiful big colorful monarchs some resting and others in the air. Not really just how many I saw because I lost count. Last year on Fire island during migration only saw about seven.

Just when we had given up hope of seeing more monarchs, they appeared in a grassy field with red clover near the butterfly garden.  We were able to tag 18!  We have never seen this many monarchs in late September. But the total number has not been real large.  Last year we tagged 100 fairly easily in early September.  So far we have only tagged 59.  During the peak years, we were tagging 1000 in a matter of days!! So we have quite a way to go before we can say the migration is back.

We arrived at Cherry Gap Overlook on the Blue Ridge Parkway about 2:45 PM.  Small groupings of Monarchs and single butterflies were passing overhead just at treetop level and higher.  Several of us began counting, and I kept tally. We counted for 15 minutes and reached 95.  It might have been 100, but as the last group of 5 could have been reported twice, I discounted the additional number.  The flow was steady for about an hour then tapered off as the temperature lowered.  The gap in the mountain ridge was much wider than we could cover, and likely many other Monarchs crossed that were not counted.This was the first time we ever observed the Monarch migration, and with me were my wife, a son and daughter-in-law and their three children, and two adult friends. The sky was mostly overcast and a rain front is supposed to be moving in tonight.  At Cherry Gap Overlook a sign is posted that discusses the Monarch migration and how the location is a good one for observation. We drove up last weekend and saw none, but today it was amazing.  The butterflies in the photograph performed something of a dance together in the air, and someone said they were mating.  I had mistakenly expected I could get some close-up photos, and since we had planned to bike ride, I had left my telephoto lens at home to save weight. So, the photo was taken with a macro lens and cropped tight.
Another beautiful fall day with clear skies and temps in the high 70's I spotted 35 monarchs.

I went out to fill my bird feeder at 5:45p.m. CDT, when I noticed a Monarch feeding at a butterfly bush.  Then I looked up and saw several others flying above tree top level.  I am so glad that I pulled up a chair to watch and count as a very nice flight of Monarchs came into the area as the sun was setting.  Except for about 6 Monarchs, all were flying well above 50 feet.  The air was humid, still, with temperatures in the upper 70's.  Most did not have to flap their wings, but sailed quietly against a deep blue sky and gray and white clouds tinged with hues of peach and pink from the sunset.  It was a remarkable sight!

Monarchs observed flying along the beach going south along Lake Michigan by observers of an Audubon Socierty of Kalamazoo field trip. Bird migration was poor. This seems late. Asters still blooming, goldenrods passed peak.8:45 to 9:45 AM, 58 monarchs, start temp 57 degrees, wind ESE 3 m/hr.9:45 to 10:45 AM, 84 monarchs counted, start temp 64 degrees, first 1/2 hour winds were calm, then shifted to NE at 2 m/hr the 2nd half hour.
61 Monarchs migrating through at Rosetta McClain gardens today.  Raptors were also very slow as winds were not right to push them!  A beautiful day non the less!
Another excellent day for Monarchs in East Tennessee!  I caught 31 Monarchs.  I tagged 26 of them myself and passed the last 5 of the day over to another group to tag.  I saw dozens more also.

The day was sunny and warm with a slight breeze in central Iowa, and the movement of monarch butterflies was surprising after limited numbers seen in recent days. At Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, 20 monarchs were counted in an hour in the late morning. Most were flying into the refuge from the north. Another 15 monarchs were seen along central Iowa roadways. Back in our butterfly garden in Altoona, the monarchs were having a field day visiting the purple and pink asters--much more so than earlier this autumn. At least 15 monarchs were coming and going for several hours in the afternoon. A wonderful sight to say the least.

I have continued to see many monarchs flying south.  Some were flying quite high.  I saw two flying together at one point.  There must be some late wave of monarchs pushing through.  I didn't see any nectaring in the butterfly garden though.  The temps topped out in the 80s with little wind.
While Traveling between Columbia and Myrtle Beach South Carolina(my other set of eyes at the house here)observed approx. 15 Monarchs flying in a southerly direction in the mid hours of the day.
I have seen more Monarchs this year than ever before.  Caterpillars are all over my butterfly weed and I see adults everywhere.  I sure hope they are making a come back!

In an undeveloped field fully planted with purple clover we observed hundreds of adult Monarch.  All you had to do was walk through the field of approx. 2 acres and you could see a dozen or better of them flying around.  Their were hundreds feeding.  This is in addition to seeing hundreds the previous day hear 95th & Renner rd. Again on purple clover.
Saw twelve monarch butterflies feeding and flying through. This is the most I've seen in a few years! Mostly sunny day with a cold front and light rain coming in by midnight.

Nancy Keeney reports for her brother and sister in law:On Sept 24 Ted was walking around his field where they have a track set up with a nearby section they leave uncut and he saw what he said was as many as 50 Monarchs there. They were on Iron Weed blossoms. He took several photos and one of the photos was of a male. He said they were gone the next day. Also, earlier in the month Sonja discovered early one morning over 20 Monarch larva on her Butterfly Weed plant but in the heat of the day when she checked they were gone.They didn't know about Journey North so I asked their permission to report their sightings. They also have 100 or more hummers all summer long. She fills a gallon feeder and 7 or 8 smaller feeders DAILY!! I've never seen so many  hummers in one place. Almost makes me dizzy to watch them when I go there.

corner of Hwy 34 and 33 at the edge of urban Leamington - central spot of several is the location given here; detail on Ontario butterflies google discussion group q.v.Red clover shared with many Painted Lady butterflies was cut several times this summer.

11 AM, wind WNW at 17 mph (according to weather.com)Monarchs are migrating along the primary dune and getting blown out to the ocean's edge and then must flap to get back to vegetation or to a wind buffer.Wind remained strong for most of the day until late afternoon when it became NW at 12 mph. Monarch flight was constant all day. My unofficial counts throughout the day averaged about 50 monarchs per hour. At 6 PM I started noticing monarchs coming down to nectar on seaside goldenrod, and around 6:45 a few monarchs were seen flying down the streets of the neighborhood at Cape May Point, looking for roost sites. I found a few Eastern red-cedar trees with small roosts forming.All told, I was observing for 7 hours (11-6), so an estimate of 350 monarchs is about right. I did not see any tagged monarchs, and the ones I netted were in pristine condition.It was a good day for all migrants particularly the falcons. Kestrels, merlins and peregrine falcons stole the show, and at one point I had three peregrines in one binocular view. Other migrants included osprey, black saddlebags, green darner, spot-winged glider, wandering glider, common buckeye, and painted lady. It's important to note that my counts were unofficial. The official counts were conducted by the Cape May Monitoring Project team by driving a transect 3X daily.  I haven't looked, but I would guess their average numbers were lower than mine, since they were limited to a view from a car windshield. I want to be sure to mention them, and all the good work they are doing collecting data and educating visitors.Editor's Note: We are estimating 350 monarchs counted, based on the observation period of 7 hours @ 50 monarchs per hour.

On Friday (9/26) we tagged 101 and this afternoon (9/28) 76 at Lynde Shores Conservation Area in Whitby. Last week it looked as though the migration was almost over. This weekend, with the warm, sunny weather, much larger numbers than expected have been nectaring, virtually all of them in excellent condition.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
during the past week i've seen a continual wave of monarchs feeding in my milkweed garden, usually 7 to 12 at a time.  they headed southward "after dinner".

A very slow day for raptors as the wind was wrong, so we turned to monarchs!  93 passed by very low and most stopped to feed.  They looked very very fresh almost like a second wave of young monarchs compared to say 2 weeks ago.  Comments?  See attached photo.

It was cloudy and continuing to drizzle rain when someone said that they saw some orange butterflies.  I flew outside,,this is my place of work and saw the Monarchs on 2 big butterfly bushes.  I returned this morning and they are still here feeding on the bushes.  someone did take pictures so will get those as soon as they email them to me.
Here is the recent picture. It was taken about 30 minutes ago.
Monarch migration was continuing in central Iowa. At Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge, we observed 16 monarchs making their way across the prairie. Along the roadways we noted another 24 monarchs.

Today was a non-stop migration day. I don't know how many I saw fly past, but if I had to guess I would say it was 3,000 - 4,000 monarchs. And those are the ones who were migrating at a level that could be seen with the naked eye. There may have been many more soaring higher, visible only in a binocular view. If you look at the data page for the Cape May Monarch Monitoring Project, you will see that they had an increase in monarch numbers on their road censuses today. But that doesn't tell the whole story. I spent the day observing from along the primary dune where most of the monarchs were migrating. It was probably one of the best migration days I have seen in a long time. Monarch flight was constant but every now and then there would be a spurt of hundreds of monarchs all at once. At one point I counted monarchs for one minute and my total was 79. It wasn't the frenzied flight of Monday; it was more of a lazy, relaxed flight. The wind was NE most of the day between 4-6 mph, so they didn't have to flap much. Monarchs were swirling around each other quite a bit, usually with 3-5 individuals, but one spiraling group had 12 monarchs in it. They were also landing frequently to nectar on seaside goldenrod on the dune. Many monarchs were making a detour at Cape May point State Park to visit the butterfly garden. New England aster and Zinnias were the most popular flowers. This provided a photo op for the many photographers and it attracted quite a crowd of curious onlookers.Tuesday afternoon around 3pm, I checked the boardwalk ramps that cross over the heavily vegetated primary dune at Cape May Point. At the top of each crossover, there is a platform with seating around the sides, and in the middle there is a large round picnic table bolted to the deck. At the St. Peter’s Church crossover, I put my folding chair on top of the table so that I had a high view of the surrounding vegetation and beach. I settled into the Zen of monarch-watching. The scene was mesmerizing, with a ceaseless flow of monarchs floating by me at eye level. This is just about the most southern point of the cape, so I assumed it would be the “jumping-off” spot for monarchs to cross over the Delaware Bay. (To see the platform location, see Google Earth image of South Lake Dr. and Ocean Ave at Cape May Point NJ). They did in fact fly up to where the waves were crashing on shore, and made an abrupt stop and turnaround, and then continued along the dune. It was a clear day, and with just my eyes, I could plainly see the enormous blades of the windmill on the shore at Lewes DE, as well as land on the horizon. But I guess it was too far and too late in the day for the monarchs to cross. I sat there until 5pm, when I noticed that monarchs were coming down—not to nectar but to perch in the pines, red-cedars, and wild black cherry trees on the dune. I watched until 5:30, and still no collective roosts were forming—only individual monarchs perching wherever they happened to be when it was time to land—with no time or energy spent on searching for other roosting monarchs. The wind was still favorable for migration—NE about 5mph, and some monarchs were still on the move. They continued around the point and up the western side of the Cape. I later checked other public access locations up there, but never found a roost. I searched until it was too dark to see. While I was perched on my table pedestal, I had many wonderful conversations with others who came to watch this migration spectacle. Several people stayed until I left. There were so many good questions, and so many facial expressions of awe (my favorite part). The sharing of monarch stories and experiences was illuminating. Two women, both in their 80’s, who were there for a religious retreat, thanked me for bringing meaning to their visit. It got me thinking—with such a perfect and accessible location, it seems to me that the state park and the CMBO are missing a perfect opportunity to educate people. There should be a volunteer at every crossover platform on days with good migration winds and flows of monarchs to focus people’s attention and answer questions. Most people I met referred to the monarchs just as butterflies (didn’t know their name) and were clueless about what was occurring. A lack of interpretation at these locations is criminal. I will contact the two organizations and make suggestions.It's important to note that my counts were unofficial. The official counts were conducted by the Cape May Monitoring Project team by driving a transect 3X daily.  I haven't looked, but I would guess their average numbers were lower than mine, since they were limited to a view from a car windshield. I want to be sure to mention them, and all the good work they are doing collecting data and educating visitors.
Walking along the shoreline of Lake Ontario, there were dozens of monarchs feeding off the flowers.

Mid-morning at Long Beach, more than 20 monarchs were feasting on the goldenrod in the beach dunes directly behind the high water mark. We returned to the beach mid-afternoon and saw them again, feeding in the same area.

While commuting downtown via express bus to the Metro station, I saw a total of six monarchs flying south at "migration level" (20-40 feet up; is also roughly treetop level around here). Two of the monarchs were traveling "singly", while the last four I saw were in a V-shaped grouping, not unlike what birds do!! I was SO surprised by this, a definite first for me. Fascinating...
We were on a short drive and saw lots of monarchs along the road.  On our 20 minute drive, we saw 23 monarchs!  Monarchs have definitely been traveling through the midwest over the past few days.

Observed 100+ adult monarch feeding feverishly on Mexican Sunflowers or Tithonia and Milkweed. They have been here for days feeding. So much fun to watch!!!!!!

I been seeing them (Sept. 25) for a week anyway. They just love the Tithonia and are on it again today (10/2) even though it is cooler.

counted from paved private roadway behind development area nectaring on Red Clover along with approx. 20 Painted Lady and the usual Sulphurs in late afternoon. 8 Canada Geese were in the field capturing grasshoppers and being vigilant about my car. We have had good numbers of monarchs at Monarch Watch for each of the last 4 days (25-28 September) with the promise of another good day tomorrow. The numbers seen are certainly greater than observed during the last two migrations. This is another late migration.The leading edge of the migration usually reaches here between the 9-11th of September with an estimated peak on the 23rd. It's hard to say but, it's probable that the peak occurred yesterday - the 27th.The monarchs are passing through so there is constant turnover. I know that because I watch a flower outside my window. Monarchs approach it from the north and leave to the south at a rate of several per hour and the butterflies are different sizes, and sexes. There were times on the 27th when there were as many as 50 monarchs on the flowers around the building, resting in the trees and visiting the flowers in Monarch Waystation#1. I made periodic observations from about 11:30AM to after 7PM.The butterflies have their distinctive migratory coloration - a deeper and more intense orange than summer monarchs - and are larger than usually seen on these dates - leading me to suspect we will see slightly smaller monarchs in the next 10 days with an increase in the proportion of females.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch. Monarch number estimated by JN

The Cape May Monarch Monitoring Project census tallied 27.9 monarchs per hour yesterday.  Actual counts of monarchs are impossible in Cape May Point, with monarchs in many scattered locations.  In the early years of our project it was determined that counts made along the dunes are typically misleading, as monarchs moving along the waterfront here at land's end routinely move back and forth or loop around to pass the same point repeatedly.  Accordingly we have found that our census is the best source of comparative data on monarch populations from year to year.  See our census data from 1992 to the present at http://www.monarchmonitoringproject.com/mmptwo.html.
We saw monarch butterflies flying above us.

64 degrees at Pounding Mill Overlook on the Blue Ridge Parkway.Mostly cloudy although the sun did peak through the clouds. 69 Monarchs sighted in the 4 hour span with 1:45 to 2:45 having the highest rate of 24 per hour

Traveling north on the Blue Ridge Parkway from Hwy 276 to the Pisgah Inn. The Cradle of Forestry overlook had the largest number, then Pink Beds overlook and the next overlook. The sign was gone for this overlook. It was the last one before the Inn.

I observed 10 monarchs this evening shortly before sunset.  All of them were flying due South and not stopping to feed.   Beautiful weather, calm breeze.  With an expected cold front  forecast for the weekend I imagine this is probably one of the final waves for the season.
