Monarchs were drifting over from 6:11 p.m. CDT to 6:50 p.m. October 2. They drifted at tree top level or just higher. From 6:11 to 6:24 they averaged four per minute then 3 per minute and finally one every minute. We expect NW wind 20-25 mph this morning (10/3) so they will have a quick flight.

While stopped on US 221 for a lane closure, I was able to take a closer look at a large field system on the east side of 221. I estimate 3 dozen adult monarchs over the area of field within view of the road. However, the field is quite large and any butterflies further back in the field from the road would be out of my sight. The field has a LOT of milkweed.

Unlike last Sunday, we didn’t see many Monarchs at Cherry Gap, so we drove up and down the Blue Ridge Parkway in the vicinity and checked various other locations. The best place was the 5494’ elevation Fetterbush Gap overlook (near Devil’s Courthouse) where my wife and I counted 50 in 15 minutes. Most paused in the asters and goldenrods south of the road, which allowed me to take some nice pictures. Another strong place was the View of Funnel Top overlook. The sky was a mix of sunshine and cumulous clouds, and the temperature ranged between 65 and 80 degrees depending upon the shade of the moment. We also saw ten or so brilliant migrating Cloudless Sulfur Butterflies fluttering by in a hurry and what might have been 12 Broadwing Hawks spiraling up in a thermal to gain altitude before zipping away southwest.
I watched many Monarchs nectaring in the gardens of the Newagen Inn. It was a lovely sight. The gardener said they arrived about a week ago (Sept.20) and he expects them to leave soon.
Monarchs all over Cape May NJ.  They rest & refuel at Cape May before crossing Delaware Bay
Monarchs flying high, riding on the wind from East to West in the evening at a rate of about one every five minutes.  Saw one grouping of four.

The front wave of the migration has hit Dallas!  We had a nice cold front blow through October 2nd, and the day of the 3rd was sunny and cool with a steady north breeze.  By the afternoon, there were approximately 50 Monarchs in the garden, nectaring on Gregg's mistflower and Frostweed.  If you looked up in the sky, every 3-5 minutes you could see Monarchs soaring south - some were very high.  The garden Monarchs are not chasing eachother around looking for a mate (normal activity), but instead totally ignoring eachother in favor of nectaring.  The numbers of Monarchs in the garden at this point (October 3rd) are much higher than last year - a welcome development!
I live in a pretty populated area and was surprised to see so many flying above me! So awesome!

Cape May Monarch Monitoring Project census results for Friday, Oct. 3: 34.3 monarchs/hour.  We saw a small increase late yesterday and this morning, surprising given east winds.  A cold front is expected to pass midday Saturday, bringing northwest winds on Saturday afternoon and Sunday.  Northwest winds are best for bringing monarchs into Cape May, we're hoping for a good influx.
Beautiful groups of Monarchs soaring across an open field. Crowds of neighbors observing.

In Dutch Branch Park in Benbrook, TX, there is a field that is loaded with purple spiked flowers. Another strong place to observe Monarch Butterflies was the View at Cherry Point Overlook. The sky was a mix of sunshine and cumulous clouds, and the temperature ranged between 65 and 74 degrees depending upon the sun/shade. Also, saw 5 at Pounding Mill Overlook....

The peak Monarch migration has hit Dallas big-time.  Monarchs were in my butterfly garden in droves - easily over 100 individuals all nectaring on Frostweed and Gregg's mistflower.  The migrators show little interest in eachother - only in nectaring (unlike in non-migration times when the males chase eachother around all day looking for a mate).  Frostweed is their preferred plant to nectar on.  They drape all over it as does every pollinating insect there is - bee's of all kinds from large to small, beetles of all kinds and colors, wasps of all kinds, fly's, and even mosquito's (plus bugs I have no idea what to call them)!  Here is a picture of the action.
Butterflys were headed southwest from a wooded area in small groups, or single individuals.

More monarchs that I can count are nectaring on the liatris and other native wildflowers in my garden. They showed up a couple of days after a cold front came through on 10/02/14. I have pictures and a video on my blog http://planobluestem.blogspot.com/2014/10/gayfeather-and-monarchs.html

Had about 19 folks with me this afternoon for a tagging field trip, started slow at 1pm with just a few monarchs, then It warmed up and the numbers grew! We tagged about 60 and missed at least thrice that many. One 12 year old girl caught a total of 14, and both her and i each had a "double" (2 in one net swing). Every participant that stuck around past the first hike ended up catching at least a few, even the real young ens! Though i think the parents had just as much fun as the kids!!! 250 monarch!Nectar use was about 40% each goldenrod and tickseed sunflower, then 10% baccharis. There were several clusters, especially at the lakes edge before crossing, about a dozen backed up there! I even had one attracted to a cluster of paper monarchs i attached to a tall cluster of goldenrod. Flight was very directly southwest, right along i85 and the power line we were hiking. Kudos to the bulk of the group that finished the rugged 4 mile hike, we got back around 430 and could have kept going there were so many monarchs! Kids caught almost everything else too, three lined flower moth, chinese mantids etc. One family said it was an adventure of a lifetime! Going out again tomorrow most likely!

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

The Monarchs are off their roosts and again nectaring heavily on Frostweed this morning.  As I was taking this shot, I noticed that a tagged Monarch had joined the group!  You'll clearly see him (or her?) in the middle left of the shot.  I was able to zoom in the picture and get the tag # #THE 669. I have e-mailed Monarch Watch as I am dying to know where and when it was tagged. When I get some info on  I'll let you know. Hopefully, he'll make it to Mexico intact and help spawn (to use a fish term) the next generation.  Go Monarchs! October 8 updateIncidentally, I saw the tagged butterfly 3 days in a row in my garden. So it migrated in from somewhere, and stuck around for at least that long. For all I know, it could still be out there as there are approximately 150-200 Monarchs in my yard right now. So finding it is hit or miss.

Looking back at my tagging data, I believe the "peak" migration dates in my area might be 8/30 to 9/1, although that is based on times I was not at work and I was able to observe them. I tagged a total of 56 this year, 28 wild and 28 reared by myself or my neighbor. What are the odds of that!? Wild were 8F and 20M, reared were 19F and 9Mâ€¦which I guess proved that guys ARE wilder! The reared ones were emerging in "waves", probably due to us collecting them as eggs or small larva from our garden milkweed plantsâ€¦ based on tagging data starting 8/15, butterfly baby booms were 8/14-16, 9/3-5, and 9/18-19. Another noteâ€¦ A neighbor child reported seeing some monarchs in her tree on Sept. 13. I didn't see them myself, so didn't report as a roostâ€¦I scoured the area and didn't see them, only had a couple at my butterfly bushes and tagged them. It was VERY windy that day and they may have traveled across Lake Erie and taken a quick rest before heading on. It was encouraging this year compared to last year when I was only able to tag 12 wild and was not able to find ANY eggs or caterpillars to raise. I hope the trend continues and we have more next year. I have some leftover tags (about 40) - if anyone in the southern states is in need, I can mail them to you if you send me an email. Thanks!
Monarchs coming through the garden of orange cosmos nectar plants at a rate of about 10-20 at a time, continual through the day until dusk.

all afternoon, over 50 in my backyard

Overnight temp 54. High 80. Very low humidity. South wind. Light in the morning, growing stronger throughout day. No successful directional flight. Any that went high were blown north rapidly. A few seemed to work south using trees and shrubs as windbreaks, but mad elittle progress. .

I’m entering this as peak migration because of numbers, but this is likely not the actual peak, which has occurred in the Oct 11 to Oct 18 window in past years. And JN reports show many still further north. Note that this count is at least partly additive to the roost repot for the same day.

Monarchs on every liatris patch I checked, plus several other flower types. I saw about 250 directly. Density varied too much for me to do an estimate based on known area of liatris. But I would be uncomfortable estimating twice the direct count.

Direct counting is more challenging than usual this year. Liatris emerges in the spring, but doesn’t bloom until mid-Sep through Oct. Stalks stay 12-18 inches most of the year, but grow taller if moisture is available in September. This year September was dry, so many are relatively short. On the other hand we got huge rain in June and above average in July, which is ideal timing for Prairie grasses, so grasses have grown as uniformly tall as I can recall. The shortest species, Little Bluestem is 3-4 feet tall. So Liatris, and Monarchs on it, are concealed.

The first picture is shows of the tougher examples. Monarch on Liatris in Little Bluestem. It’s not the toughest case of course, since the sun is lighting his wings. The second picture is a liatris patch that happens to be in the open, and apparently has local soil moisture. Even this is not too easy to count. A few Monarchs are clearly visible. But close inspection shows at least 15, most in shadow or partly hidden. There are probably more out of view.

Overnight low 56, high84. Low Humidity. Strong south wind all day.

Monarchs feeding in all locations with liatris or other flowers. Mostly dedicated feeding, not flushing until I approached to 3-4 feet. However strong wind stirred them into short flights more than yesterday, so a bit easier to see at a distance. At least as many as yesterday, so leave it at 250. In addition, a few flushed from trees several times as I passed.

Rather than one more picture of a Monarch, this picture is an example of what not to count and report. Easy to confuse at a distance when you see only color. This is a Gulf Fritillary, Agraulis vanillae, and queuing up behind, an Invasive Eurobee, Apis mellifera.

Note that the separate roost report for today is additive to this report.
Monarchs were constantly in sight. I was at the same location yesterday and saw only a couple.
Overlooking the Lake from Big Cedar Lodge, I observed 1-2 Monarchs heading southwest for about an hour.
During several hours this morning and early afternoon, I witnessed 41 monarch butterflies flying over our back yard - winging their way southwest.  It's such a treat!

Have never seen this many monarchs here.  100 +.  Oct. 3-6 many every day:  Dozens, sometimes 100's at once.  Healthy looking.  Mostly in post oak trees.  Had terrific storm here afternoon of Oct. 2.  Monarchs here the next day.  Unable to report earlier due to storm taking out our computer.

We saw around 10 adult Monarchs throughout the hours of 10:45 am to 12:45 pm.  Most eating at our butterfly bush and a few flying.  The most we saw at once was 3 on the bush and 1 flying along the street.  One stayed and ate for more than 30 minutes.  This is the most we have ever seen in one day!  We also saw 4 - 5 American Ladies and 1 Red Admiral.

Many monarchs passing over Lake Greenwood in Upstate South Carolina.  I have been sampling for UGA School of Ecology.  I haven't seen this many monarchs at one time in over 11 years.  Amazing. Could they be the comeback kids?
Sitting on our front porch shortly after 3pm we witnessed the monarchs flying in a south westerly direction. We are in the country about 15 miles from a small town.
On my commute to work in Springfield at 11am.

Nectaring. We have hundreds of monarchs feeding in the Fort Worth Botanic Garden, especially on the Gregg’s mistflower and abelia.

I didn’t check throughout the garden, but I saw about 300 in two areas. They are usually equally abundant in a number of other places, so I would say 500 on grounds is a low estimate.

We observed at least 12 monarchs feeding and resting on goldenrod at Long Beach in the Lordship section of Stratford.  A stiff 15 mph wind from the south, off L. I. Sound, made flying difficult.  We also saw several painted lady butterflies.

The Monarchs are still going strong on Frostweed!  The winds have been from south to north for the last few days, and are projected to stay that way, so the Monarchs are content to hang around and feed.  I wish these shots could relate the magnitude of different pollinators on these plants.  Go Monarchs!

I have seen the Monarchs in the 100's like this several years ago here at my work down next to the river in the trees. So every year about this time I go and look to see if I can see the hundreds like that year. I reported them that year on your site also. Well there was always a couple but never like it was that year. But now they are back! 100's It brought a smile to my face and warmth in my heart to see the hundreds flying around when I scared them. Not sure how long they have been down there or how long they will be here but I am blessed to get to sit in peace with the Monarchs flying around me.

Hiking the Woodland Trail at Frito-Lay I counted 65+ adults coasting from tree to tree and plant to plant.  I didn't see any milkweed along the trail but there was an abundance of Frost Weed & Daisies where they were hanging out.  They were also lighting on Maple and Pine trees.

I was contacted by a fellow Master Naturalist, Hollis Neier, who lives on Lake Buchanan that she had many Monarchs.  I went to see and found at least 300 in the area between her home and the lake.  This area would ordinarily be under water but with our drought, the lake is 35 feet below normal.  The vegetation is thus what has sprouted in the 6 years since the drought began.  Most of the vegetation that the Monarchs were nectaring on was Poverty Bush (Baccharis neglecta)and a few Frostweed.  The Monarchs were there yesterday (10/06) also.  Don't know if they roosted there and stayed or if today's are different ones.  We looked at about half a square mile of area and believe there were still more.

Have seen some Monarchs in early October. On the 6th when I was gardening I saw anywhere from 400 to 500 feeding or roosting in my big old Cedar tree . The nectar they favored was Frostweed, second was Gregg's Blue Mist. They seem to have over tied here again.
I observed at least 43 monarchs floating overhead - heading south/southwest - over a period of 2-1/2 hours in our back acre.
The Monarchs were flying all around the lake.  The milkweed bushes on the shores were covered by adult Monarchs.  Beautiful sight!

Overnight temp 66F. Humidity at sunrise 80-90%, much higher than last two days. Wind light and variable in the morning.

Between 10:00 and 11:00 I drove a check route. At least as many monarchs as yesterday feeding on Gayfeather Liatris sp.) and perched in tree groves and individual trees. Those in trees, as yesterday, were easily disturbed, and mostly perched 4–10 feet from the ground. By 11:00 temperature up to 80F and humidity down to 50%. For this report I decided to put all in peak migration rather than split some out into roost, since this was still early in the day. Yesterday I reported those perched in trees as a roost.

At 13:00 wind came up and remained brisk initially almost east but working to south by end of day and overnight. High 84F.

I did a quick check of tree grove roost sites roosts at sunset. Monarchs were more spread out and higher in trees than earlier in the day. They also flushed from many trees/clumps as we drove past, then returned to perch.

Picture is a group of Monarchs jostling for a perch on the same apparently irresistible Cedar Elm twig.

The last two days have seen good numbers of monarchs around the gardens of Cape May Point.  Todays census calculated 65 per hour.  On any one butterfly bush, goldenrod or aster patch there would be 25 - 40 monarchs nectaring.  It's been very windy, so the butterflies are staying in the sheltered garden areas versus the dune goldenrod.

I was surprised this morning to find a great many monarchs feasting on my butterfly bush here in maryland. We see very few of the monarchs in the summer but I planted milkweed this year- only a small pot of it. They stayed until late afternoon and may be roosting now. I will look in the morning. My daughter will show my video to her 4th grade class in chicago tomorrow. They are studying biomes.

I was sitting on the dock of the Steamship at Table Rock State Park in Missouri when I noticed a monarch butterfly passing by 2 trees, over the dock, heading straight south over the water on Table Lake.  It was followed by at least a dozen more, one at a time, about 3 to 4 minutes apart!  They all followed the same flight path until the steamship came into the dock.  6-8 minutes passed, then, when the ship stopped, another, then quickly the next one passed, as though they were on a schedule and could only delay for the moment until the ship stopped and it was safe to continue on the same route!  We saw monarchs off and on for several days at the park and at our campsite at the State Park. The photo is at our campsite, directly in front of our RV!

Monarchs are everywhere in the yard on the lantana plants.  More than 60 sightings throughout the day.  Sprinklers are on in the yard, and the Monarchs are attracted to the water on the grass and shrubs.

Oct 2, a friend and I started at White Lake WMA in Dyer County, TN at 0715 looking specifically for monarchs.At start, we worked about a 100 yard strip of vegetation, maybe 20 yards wide, dominated by Pennsylvania smartweed.  I estimated about 70 monarchs between 7:15 and 8:30.  We counted independently and my friend thought over 100.  But more importantly, we both thought monarchs were flying from the forest and into this vegetation to nectar or bask.  Many did not stop at all.Short story, we ended with a conservative count of over 100 by 10:00, and a total by end of day at 2:30, 141 individual monarchs, again conservative.Another point, number of individuals dropped dramatically betweenabout 9:30 and noon, then by the afternoon, monarchs became hard to find.  I assume left on migration.
Count of adults while working the area.  Counted only the highest number of individuals in any single location, moved around a lot in and around Moss Island Wildlife Management Area (WMA).

West wind 12mph, gusting to 24mph.  Temp 49.Weather, clear.Monarchs were migrating  past our observation point at a rate of about one per minute. We are on the Western edge of Lake Michigan and the wind blows them toward the lake. They tend to follow the lake line along our Campus when the wind is from the West.

Our class (Allison, Brianna, Ellie, Jeffrey, Peter) went out at 10:13 a.m. for a Monarch observation.  We saw two flying over the soccer field.  Then we saw 3 more leaving the butterfly bush and take flight.  Then we saw 1 flying high over the school. They were all flying southwest.

Overnight low 67F. Sunrise humidity 90%. At 11:00 temp 80F humidity 50%. At 16:00 temp 96F humidity 20%. Wind strong SSW all day.

I made some incidental observations around 11:00 while doing another project. Monarchs were on Gayfeather essentially as last three days, some places fairly dense. For example 8 Monarchs in one small 10’ x 25’ patch. A number also flushed from trees and shrubs I passed.

I made at more complete circuit starting at 16:00, when it was 96 degrees, low humidity, sunny and windy. Few Monarchs on flowers. But those that were did not behave any differently in the heat.

Checking one of the larger the tree groves, initially I saw only a few inside on the usual twig perches. After a few minutes I caused a large flush when I walked near the edge of the trees. I discovered that Monarchs had collected at the edge of the grove in the shade which was also the downwind side of the grove. Most were in the grass just outside the grove. Others were just 5 feet or less within the grove edge. All were on the ground or on vegetation within 6 inches of it. They flushed readily, flew up quickly, then returned more or less to where they came from. They appeared to sit motionless when settled.

The other large grove I checked was essentially the same situation. A few more inside the grove. A greater share at the shaded edge were on shrubs inside the edge vs. in grass outside, but all still low to ground.

Their location on the ground would have higher humidity, in addition to being in deep shade and on the downwind side of the grove.

I also flushed Monarchs when passing smaller trees and shrubs. These Monarchs were usually not right at the ground, but not higher than about 5 feet either. Those trees were mostly along a creek, more protected from wind and sun by terrain than the groves on higher ground.

The first picture is one almost on the ground. Incidentally there are at least ten species of native plants in this picture. The second is actually on the ground. Both a couple feet inside the edge of grove. (I didn't get close enough to those in grass to see them before they flushed.)

Sixth day of large nos. of monarchs.  today's batch seem larger and brighter.  Saw a male and female mating.   Thought they just did that in late winter and on way north.  B'flies in urban post oak forest makes it very hard to count.  At least 100 or more.

While sitting outside on a beautiful (73 degree) late afternoon, I was observing the sky for monarchs as I had seen several earlier as I worked in the gardens.  They were flying high (50-80 feet above ground) and heading south.  I counted 23 from 4:00-5:00pm.  Best of luck to you!
Fluttered past as I sat in the Walmart parking lot.

The Forked River Branch of the Barnegat Rail Trail in Forked River NJ, was loaded with Monarch butterflies today. I counted 50 individuals at one point, nectaring on the wildflowers, while waiting out the stiff south winds we had today.
counted 115 as they flew southwest..

Today was another good day for monarchs in Cape May.  With the winds calming down the monarchs moved to the goldenrod on the dunes.  It was a spectacular sight.  Our daily census route, which is in Cape May Point, calculated 158 per hour today.  The monarchs were also seen on the goldenrod in Cape May City along the dunes, which is not on our census route.  So calculating a total for the island is a bit challenging but it had to be at least a thousand.  There were also reports that Stone Harbor and Brigantine had lots too moving and feeding in the goldenrod.  Roosts were small groups of 25 - 75 butterflies with many of these spread out along the pines in the dunes.
On one butterfly bush there were easily more than 15. One bloom had four sharing and another had 3 sharing, with more scattered all over. It truly looked as though it was raining Monarchs.
For the last couple of days I have had multiple Monarchs in my Monarch Waystation. Absolutely wonderful to see them!

We sighted the monarchs starting from Table Rock Lake State Park in Missouri as we traveled East out of the park, north on 165, then east on highway 65, the bulk of which we saw at Table Rock and Seymour, MO.

I have seen a few everyday all week but on Sunday late afternoon there too many to count.  I have 8 permanent wide rows in my garden about 70 feet long. To attract pollinators on the ends of each row I have mexican sunflowers.  I also have zinnas everywhere between rocks and garden species.  The uphill side of the 4 rows with support fences have marigolds every foot.  The mexican sunflowers were their favorite but they we obviously drinking nectar from all.  I have never before seen so many Monarchs at one time.
Looks like the peak migration--there were not very many a few days later

A wonderful afternoon in my own backyard watching constant activity at my patch of NE Asters (native) and Butterfly Bush (non-native). Even though I have plenty of various small white asters and several kinds of goldenrod in bloom...it is the NE Asters and Butterfly Bush that get the most business. Most of the butterflies sip for 15-20 minutes and then swirl up and over my house in a southbound direction. I also regularly see individual Monarchs flying across roads as I travel in and out of town. Sooo much better than last year!
Haven't seen this many in years!
Watched orange monarchs flying over my neighborhood
Dozens seen in the gardens at the State Fair of Texas.
Dozens sighted in the gardens at the State Fair of Texas.

At least 150 Monarchs still nectaring and resting in our yard. Yesterday I saw four pairs mating.  Most are perfect and beautiful. I suspect most will be moving on when a cold front moves into the area tomorrow night. This evening we counted nearly 100 roosting in our yaupon holly trees and our neighbor's live oak. We saw two clusters of 30+ and many other smaller groups. I have never seen this many in my yard since I started mu  butterfly gardein in 1995.  This is amazing!
Video of a 200+ day!

winds SW lighter than yesterdayMonarch's collecting on Hackberry, Wild Grape and Hop Tree on east side of tip area nearing sunsetmales seem small compared to summer phenotypes while females seem only slightly smaller

We sighted the Monarchs enroute from Big Spring Mo to Central City, KY.  This lovely specimen attached was dining at the Welcome KY Welcome Center at Paduca off highway 60.  It was so busy dining that it was not the least bit concerned I had my tablet nearly on his dinner plate!  We did not see another Monarch as we turned south toward Mammoth Cave NP in KY.
This the fourth day the Monarch's have stayed on property! Provided fruit and water source on day two. They fed and rested here again, it is dark now and they all are asleep.
Sylvan Prairie Park

Started witnessing dozens of Monarch Butterfly's on Saturday 4 October 2014, and throughout this entire week, not only in our neighborhood but while driving around the city of Abilene, Texas. Currently, 9 October there is a gathering of about 50 or more individual Monarch Butterfly's roosting in our neighbors tree for the night! It's quite the sight to see.  Very Exciting!
5 monarchs per minute, flying southwest at Kew Beach in Toronto.
Last Sunday, 10/5 noticed over 100 Monarch butterflies resting in our bamboo.  During the day they will fly but come back to the bamboo.  They have been there 6 days now (10/5-10/10)
Counted at least 20 along I-44 in a 15 minute period.

I live on a creek in a wooded neighborhood. I went out to work in the yard and saw some Monarchs flying by me and followed them down to the creek and there they were, flying all around me and landing on all the bushes and tall grass. I ran and got my camera and started taking pictures and they were not disturbed by me walking in amongst them. I have been to a butterfly house in St. Louis, Mo and it was even better than that because there were so many.  As an old Science teacher, it was awesome to see them in such numbers.Today, 10/10/2014, I went down and they were still there, but not in such numbers, around 25-30.

A fantastic day at Rosetta McClain gardens.  Basically stopped counting monarchs at 350+ as our attention turned to the hawks!  Over 1200 raptors on the day with over 900 turkey vultures.  Monarchs were constant as they flew overhead and I tagged 7  in the gardens.  The monarchs just continue to migrate when the winds are the right direction and strength!  They are definitely in sync with the raptors!   There seems to be an endless migrate of monarchs this year!

Oct 9 tagged another 45 monarchs, could have quadrupled that if I wasn't so busy trying to get HD video footage of them for our NC State Parks 100th anniversary video that will be in 2016.In the lower wake county portions of the lake I saw one every 30 minutes or so.In the granville/durham county portions near I85 and the nectar superhighway, I saw one about every 2 minutes. Also saw several clusters of 20-30 monarchs especially towards evening. Netting them would scare them all off, so for the big groups I just start picking them by hand one by one, get more that way.Nectar use has changed over almost completely to Baccharis, which is typcial for this time of year. Male blooms preferred, the "yellow" as opposed to white.31 of the 45 were males, and most of what I was viewing but not catching were predominately males.I only bought 200 tags this year thinking I would not have much luck, and now I only have a few left! One of these years I'll have time to hit them really hard and get a 1,000 or more tags.

Falls Lake nectar superhighway (Durham/Granville counties, north central NC)Oct 2 - 15 tagged, 30 seenOct 3 - 2 tagged of 2 seenOct 4 - 65 tagged of 250 seen (cold front) Oct 5 - 47 tagged of 200 seenOct 9 - 45 tagged of 250 seen

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

Spent today around Kerr Lake and didn't find any monarchs and little nectar, it started raining even, so I returned to my usual haunts at Falls Lake, this time on the Durham county side of the lake.38 tagged (27 male, 11 female)150 seen I missed a lot, the heat and mosquitoes were brutal and nearly all were on baccharis, some too high even for my extra long net! The other side of the lake is more conducive to netting, though the fire ants are worse.In a patch of milkweed I did find three 5th instar larva, latest I've found! Nearly all my other local larva emerged a few days ago, so these may not make the journey!Last year with more effort I only tagged 83. So for my neck of the woods, or neck of the migration route, I guess it's safe to say the numbers are rebounding!!!!

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

200 monarchs is a conservative count of the migrating flypast today!  More would have been counted but the raptors took over again today. The Rosetta McClain blog is worth checking at http://raptorwatch.blogspot.ca   I do believe there is a correlation between the monarch flights and the raptor flights based on our daily observations.  If correct its great news for monarchs as the raptors are just exploding in numbers this year!  Good tagging Terry

I was working in Founders Park in immediately south of downtown Dallas where we have a way station.  Roughly half of the sightings were of butterflies that were flying overhead and didn't stop for nectar or to lay eggs. The others were feeding primarily on the candlestick plants, Santa Barbara Salvia and the Pavonia. A smaller number were on the lantana and milkweed. The weather was sunny and about 85 F, with a breeze of about 10mph. I am a retired science teacher and spearheading the development of butterfly gardens in Oak Cliff, probably the most green part of Dallas. I will be encouraging members of our garden club to begin reporting sightings to this sight.
Observed about 50 monarchs nectaring on clover at Openlands Preserve along Lake Michigan north of Chicago.

Over the past several days I have observed Monarchs heading south on an occasional basis. Today however, while seated in my office on the 9th floor, I've noticed their activity has increased. On average, over the past 3 hours, I'm seeing a Monarch every 3 minutes.

There were at least 100 on several different flowing bushes near this creek. More were arriving as we watched and took pictures. I was about 12:45 pm. The wind was blowing slightly from the south, so they were staying in place.

Tons of monarchs headwind s 30 mi w of Ardmore Okla

Have seen around 250-300 already this AM. Steady stream.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

With today’s cold front, hundreds more monarchs are nectaring throughout the garden.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Point Pelee/Leamington area:Oct 09: fresh migrants arriving daily and leaving at daybreak both in the park and heading west in urban Leamington.Oct 8 there were approx. 200 at the tip late in the afternoon. Today 9 Oct there were approx. 230. They are collecting on the Hackberry and Hop Trees and also on the Wild Grape draped over the trees within 200 ft of the vegetated part of the tip.Outside the park there are many sites with RedClover that get recharged with small numbers of fresh monarchs daily. The fliers stay close to the ground cover. Painted Lady numbers remain comparable to Monarchs in those pasture-like spots. The male migrants are showing reduced size in this late brood. The fresh females seem larger, but still smaller than summer adults.Whitecaps were on Pigeon Bay both days.Sulphurs and Whites remain in high numbers.

Forwarded by Don Davis (via Ontario Butterflies Google Group)

"Tons of Monarchs" - Lake Ontario Shoreline in West Toronto

Today at 3:13 PMI have seen tons of Monarchs both yesterday (10/08) and today (10/09). I saw one goldenrod today with 4 of them on it! I'll bet I saw nearly 100 today in total between the time I was at both Marie Curtis and Colonel Sam Smith parks.

Forwarded by Don Davis

Oct 7 at 8:52 PM - After 6 hours of observationEleanor B and I counted 156 Monarchs today migrating west along LakeOntario past the hawkwatch at Cranberry Marsh. Many observers have remarkedon the unexpected large numbers of migrating Monarchs they seen this fall.

Forwarded by Don Davis

An average of 5-10 Monarchs on patch of Frostweed at any given time over the last week (10/06-12). Cold front and rain came through Friday night through Saturday, Oct. 10-11.  Today's count (10/12) on Frostweed was 10 at 2:00 p.m., 70 degrees.

Raining and cool today...after the rain stopped I went out to attempt to take some photos, and observed them.  Compared to several reports that reported many, I have to report a small number, 25 or 30 the hour a spent outside.
Driving on interstate 35 we saw over 30. We lost count.

At 10:30 CDT I saw 2 monarchs a male and female feeding on orange Lantana.Around noon the monarchs starting coming into the garden. I counted at least 20 what a beautiful thing to see. The monarchs looked like orange oak leaves floating into the garden. They were feeding on the butterfly bushes and lantana all the butterflies were in excellent shape. They still were in the garden as it was getting dark. We have storms headed here tomorrow maybe storms brought them my way. I hope they will be safe tomorrow.I have great short video
I observed for about 20 minutes in a flowered area and within the 20 minutes I identified 7 different Monarch butterflies.
Working in the tower at Raleigh Durham International Airport, have seen a couple dozen Monarchs flutter by throughout the morning.  Not counted, but estimate 2 dozen.
On a windy, but sunny, 75 degree F day, there are about 35 Monarchs on my 9X6 yd. patch of Frostweed.

Few Monarchs on flowers, but both usual tree groves had many in the trees on the north sides – the downwind.  I also found them in a small grove in creek bottom that is wind protected by terrain.  I also checked a couple groves that I had not checked before.  These are a short onto two neighbors properties.  These also had Monarchs within the groves filling the north ends. Monarchs in picture are on Grapevine.

Weather overcast, winds light but sometimes up to 8 - 12 mph from the SE, occasional light rain.  Same location as 10/2/2014.  We split up and surveyed a larger field, see photo of field with a net of monarchs waiting to be tagged (as compared to 10/2/2014 when we stayed closer together on a narrow strip of vegetation).  Monarchs seemed to "appear" on plants early in the morning(not seen flying in), causing us to wonder if they roosted low in field vegetation and climbed up to flowers.  By noon, a brief stop on the Mississippi River, individual monarchs passing by, tree top level, following river south.
They are going by in dozens

I noticed our Butterfly Bush with dozens of beautiful Monarch Butterflies nectarying right outside my inn, the Gualala Country Inn.The day I took the picture 9:30am, October 1, there was only 20 to 30 Monarchs on the bush. The following day (10/02) in late afternoon (6:30pm) there was well over 50 to 70 Monarchs on one butterfly bush and many more (~30) on the other shrubs and hedges around the property. There were large numbers Thursday (10/02) and Friday (10/03).

Saturday morning, the 4th, a friend came down to photograph them but they were gone. Saturday afternoon (10/04) I was out looking around and some (~20) were back but not in the large numbers as before. Many are still hanging around (10/12), but in much fewer numbers, although, I have seen them flying back and forth into the large trees behind the Inn in China Gulch.

It was extremely warm on the coast the days we saw them. There was no wind and the sun was bright.

On Wednesday morning (Oct 1), a customer asked what type of tree was attracting all of the butterfly’s. I thought she meant the hedge, she said no the tree. Thursday evening (Oct 2) I went out and talked to guests who were taking pictures and watching them in late afternoon to evening. There was probably well over 50 monarchs at that time. The guests and I were commenting how many were on the trees and in the air flying back and forth to China Gulch. The guests were the ones who pointed out some of them seemed to be flying to and from China Gulch. If you looked that way you could see the sky above the tree tops seemed to have a small thin cloud of dots that seemed to be Monarchs.

It seems strange this is the first year all of my trees and shrubs have been almost dried up and looking majorly stressed and the Monarchs are flocking to them, but we have hardly ever seen them when the plants are lush, and in full flower. Sometimes it was difficult to see them because their orange and black markings made them difficult to see on tried out spent blooms.

During a visit to the Fort Worth Botanical Gardens we counted quite a few Monarchs feeding on Tickseed, at BRIT in their meadow area.  We also saw quite a few feeding on perennials in their Trial Garden area, every thing from Hibiscus to Sage to Echinacea.  It was great to see so many in the area, although seeing them fly down the highways was a bit heart wrenching.
Observation time was 20 minutes (5:20-5:40 central time). Moving northeast to southwest.

About 50 Monarchs at the Ladybird Wildflower Center on Gregg's Mistflowers.  The largest concentration was in the Family Garden, but there were 10-15 by the main entrance and entrance to the Family Garden.
The monarchs have been moving through Marble Falls all day. I counted 55 flying south during my 30 minute walk this morning
Many feeding on Golden Rod flowers. Wind from NNW 15 mph @ 6pm.

After a stormy Saturday and frigid overnight temps in the low 40's Sunday was a beautiful day with a light easterly wind and temps in the low 60's the Monarchs came out in full force. I counted over 350, many with tattered wings. They were  ravenous and feeding on goldenrod. The majority of the Monarchs arrived after 2:30 and fed on the goldenrod until almost sunset. The roosts were very small many with a single monarch snuggled into the pine trees.

WE had hundreds, possibly thousands on the Llano River this weekend (10/11-12) near London.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch Monarch number and time observing estimated by JN

After a second night of frigid temps in the low 40's, the sun was shining with temps in the mid 60's. With a strong southeast wind with wind gusts of 20+ mph I spotted 165 monarchs. The strong wind was a challenge for the monarchs feeding on the goldenrod in which many kept getting blown off. As the clouds started to roll in, they settled in their roosts in the pine trees early around 3:45. Many roosted on the goldenrod appearing hungry and fatigued. Similar to last night the roosts were small averaging 1-6 monarchs. The attached photo is a monarch who struggled with the wind to get back to the goldenrod and took a break on the fence.

I am located in Lytton Springs, about 25 miles South of Austin, and today I saw more Monarchs than ever before. I would estimate a good 300+ butterflies, although they were flitting about and impossible to count. I will not be seeing them roosting, but I have lots of willow, ash, and pecan as well as the usual oaks and junipers. They are very keen on the Frostweed we have in abundance on our 50 acres. Forwarded by Texas insect expert, Mike Quinn, who noted: It's unusual to receive reports of such numbers east of I-35 in the Austin area.  I did notice the recent NNW winds. They were a likely contributor/cause of these slightly wayward monarchs.<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/74d386OSuGI?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
observed at least 50+ monarchs nectaring on tropical milkweed and salvia in my front yard. Tagged 25
A stream of Monarchs is flying over my property, as they do every year.  It is a fairly continuous flow of about 1 Monarch every 10 seconds.
Butterflies were observed from one small window heading in a southwesterly direction from the north in the mid-morning hours in a pastured subdivision.
Adults in migration observed heading in a southwest to westerly direction from the north in a pastured subdivision.

The butterflies came in pairs or singles. Stopping only briefly if at all. Flying from north east and going south west

We counted 100 monarchs in 30 minutes. We continued to see more after that but just counted for 30 minutes.
This morning we have more monarchs nectaring on the frost weed in our back yard than we have seen in past years.  The strong winds of 2 days ago blew them our way!

I see many individuals heading south.

The 100 monarchs in one hour is correct. I'll be watching again today (10/16). I always watch them when I come through. They'll be out and I'll give you some more data. I'll update you guys in a bit.

October 16
I saw 12, in 12 minutes. I see them in a trickle and pockets. So I'll see 2 in 2 minutes but then I will notsee any for a bit. So in clusters during different parts of the days. I wonder are these guys lagging behind? Are they the slow pokes?

They were in pristine condition flying east to west starting at 9:00 am as it warmed into 70 degrees F.They emerged every few minutes in groups of 3-4, not interested in feeding but floating up and over the USDA People's Garden at 1001 Holleman Drive East, College Station, TX.  I have not seen that many before.  I was only able to tag 2 that settled.  Later,about 11:00 am, I took a photo of several feeding on nectar on a False Willow bush in the garden along with honey bees
They were settling and feeding in USDA people's Garden on Lantana and milkweed flowers.I caught/tagged/released 2 females in perfect condition
We are so glad to the Monarchs' have made it into Central Texas and have been coming steady through Wildseed Farms. Hope to see a roost - checking every morning.

They are here.. Lots of Monarch all over town.  The winds are right, North to South.  The Sea Myrtle is in bloom and a favorite of the Monarchs.  Each place we went around town, from the parks to parking lots, vacant fields to White Oak Bayou were filled with Monarchs.  Have not seen this many in a very long time. Next year we will get two sheets of Tags from Monarch Watch.  Feel so good..
Monarchs streaming along my crushed granite driveway, 12-15, lasting 15 minutes,Later in afternoon, 4 were nectaring on Gregg's blue mist.The most I've seen in 13 years living here.
seen them all day off an on. it was a nice sunny day clear day temp was about 75 an clear blue skies

We observed hundreds of migrating Monarchs flying above our school fast with a purpose heading south all day long on Tuesday, October 14th.

They stopped at our Labyrinth garden, the Bluebonnet Montessori Children's garden, to feast at our free buffet "drink all flower nectar you can" between 12:30 pm and 2:30 pm - there were hundreds of them in our 400 sqf garden and the beauty of the sight just took our breath away.

The children were so excited and happy. There were less Monarchs today (10/15). I will report again if the numbers increase. I would say Tuesday 10/14/14 was the peak in Lakeway, Texas as we have been waiting for a long time!

Monarchs (100 or more) ~35 mi. N. of Austin - Oct 14

Most of the monarchs were sailing southward, a few (10 or so) were nectaring on Frostweed (Verbesina virginica)and 1 was on a Maximilian Sunflower (Helianthus maximiliani). They are flying through the clear cut at the back of our property - not stopping to nectar at the garden but rather directional flying right over it!  Can't say as I blame them, cool weather is on the way and they are likely trying to beat it!  They look great!
Nice numbers of monarchs here in Cape May, most look very healthy, nectaring on abundant golden rod. In my garden two lovers, one with a tag.

Four monarchs crossed the playground today around noon.  All heading south.  One more flew over the parking lot just after the bussed pulled out at about 3:00 P.M.  This is the most monarchs we have seen in a couple of years!  Still none have been spotted in our native flower garden.  Still looking to tag a couple before it is too late.

we have butterfly weed, lantana, sage, roses, veggie garden, turks cap, and trumpet vine. The monarchs are using our yard as a playground - it is beautiful to watch. There are also a few, maybe 10+, yellow butterflies as well.

From Lake Dallas , North to Denton, TX I watched as stragglers and then small 'clouds' { groups of 100 or so ) drifted west across I 35 N. It was after 10 am and they were coming from the trees that clustered to the east of I 35. I saw them off and on all morning as groups of three or more would flit by me.
the monarchs stayed all day feeding on buddelia,mexican sage, mexican sunflower,zinnia,lantana,pinapple sage.  I couldnot believe I had this many!!!!!!. THE next dayI had 8,

I suspected that the few days of rainy weather and the cold front would cause another superflight today and it did!!!Tagged 129 monarchs and saw about 400 from 130pm-530pm, i should have started earlier!Saw two that were already tagged, from some point north, cant wait to find out where!Nectar use was mostly goldenrod and aster. Baccaharis and eupatorium had just a couple, bidens was spent. There were several clusters again, at goldenrod mostly, especially right before or after the lake crossings even though its a narrow crossing. Didn't bother with the net on clusters, just hand picked them which was a lot easier and quicker. Most abdomens looked pretty skinny, no wonder they were re-fueling!!!

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

The peak migration has moved on from Dallas, but there are still many Monarchs in the garden - approximately 50 +/-.  I found this unlucky one had been nabbed by one of its natural enemies - the Wheel Bug.  A pretty big and nasty looking insect!  It hung around on top of a Frostweed flower head and waited for the right moment to snatch his dinner.  While I didn't like to see the butterfly become someone's dinner, I  let nature take its course.  I have rarely seen adults fall to predation - it's mainly the caterpillars that fall to wasps and Assasin bugs here in Dallas.  Oh well.
Monarchs traveling along the shore line in Ocean City NJ.  Traveling south.  One every 10 seconds.  Time 1:57PM.  Sunny day. Temp 70degrees.

The numbers of monarchs have held pretty steady the last few days in Cape May.  But today, they were arriving on the W winds, streaming down the dunes in Cape May Point.  Everywhere you looked you could see monarchs.  100 at one time all around the dunes.  I counted 40 in one minute fly by me.  This did not include all the ones on the street below me, I was counting just in front of me on the dune line.  Our census run numbers, which are done below the dunes, tallied 146 in 36 minutes.  Only a few small roosts of 20 - 60, were found tonight.  There were also places with many single monarchs.  I did notice many monarchs fed on goldenrod til 6 pm.  The picture is of one of many goldenrod plants that had at least 25 - 30 butterflies feeding on it.  We'll see what tomorrow brings as it's supposed to be cold and very windy.

Monarchs are flying through - quickly moving in a southerly direction: 27 counted while I was outside for about an hour. Wish there were more.  their numbers are greatly down this year - lately (10/21), I might see 1 a day- that's why I thought that was significant

Relatively few monarchs have been seen in our area this fall, but we've noticed that the numbers have picked up over the past week.

I have had, each fall since living in Georgia. assigned several undergrads from my lab to catch monarchs each week during mid-Sept to early Nov. We typically capture several hundred adults to be measured and released during this time. Peak numbers here tended to occur around Oct 10-12 in past years. Last year (2013) we did not catch any adults in our area during the fall, because we barely saw any. This fall (2014) we've caught maybe 30 in total. This past week has been the most we've seen during the entire fall. It is not huge numbers but more than last fall.
Saw about a dozen monarchs flying south parallel to the Lake Pontchartrain Causeway.

Well, it seems that the monarchs got a little delayed. I expected Monday (10/13) to be a great day, turns out Monday and Tuesday were busts with only a couple visible during my travels in and around Austin.Today Wednesday (10/15), I saw close to a hundred flitting around the city. This morning, I had an assistant with great eyesight, together we spotted 30 Monarchs on a 20 minute drive from central to northwest Austin. Later in the day they were nearly constant one or two visible nectaring on flowers in different gardens I was tending. Conditions have been perfect with north winds and clear skies.Keep â€˜em coming

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

The NW winds were very strong, 25 - 35 mph, so as we thought the butterflies did not try and cross the Delaware Bay today.  Many were sunning on pine trees, goldenrod or bayberry in groups of 10 - 60.  There were also many singles hanging out in the trees or on grasses in the dunes.  Some came to the gardens to nectar, always keeping in the sunnier areas.   The team did not find one single big roost tonight, even with the 50 degree temp.'s, but again found many in smaller groups all along the dunes and in the State Park.   The monarchs aren't using all the same roost areas this fall as other years, so we're still trying to find all the ones that flew in yesterday!!

For two days in a row (Thursday, 10/16 and Friday, 10/17) we observed between 15-20 adult monarchs resting in our backyard on tiny purple flowers growing in the grass around lunchtime/early afternoon. We have seen a few sporadically in the yard in the last two weeks.
Traveling very high on the winds this morning and afternoon.  Nearly constant migration through the day.  I estimate 50 monarchs per hour all day long (approximately 8 hours).
100 migrating monarchs crossing hwy 90 around noon, between Bracketville and Uvalde.

Home garden, 14 in one buddliea, 7 in nearby Mexican sunflower.  Late afternoon, had to leave before I could track roost.  Next morning (10/18/2014) at 7:00 am, counted 12 as coming from various trees to buddliea.  By 10:30, none in garden.
Most I have observed yet; today best I could count, as they move around so much, I saw 14 !
I watched over 100+ adult monarchs flying over my house on 10/18/14 during the afternoon hours.....

Overnight Low 61. High 77. Light wind E to SE all day. Sun on and off as clouds moved past.

I first noticed monarchs about 10:00, which is when I first looked within a minute. But no continuous observation in the morning. From the back porch starting at 12:45 counted 100 monarchs in 45 minutes. Did not continue to count every one after that, but did check periodically to see if the rate had changed. It didn’t until about 17:00 when it slowed but remained at least 1 per minute. Last sighting at 19:05, which is 10 minutes after end of local sunset.

The easily observed view for counting was about 100 yards wide. In addition to those passing in this width, I checked with binoculars at right angles to their direction of travel. Visibility of ground level reaches 500 yards one direction and 200 the other. I saw monarchs traveling in parallel paths across the whole span.

To get an estimated count I used the initial rate from actually counting until 17:00, then cut in the rate in half until sunset. I did NOT scale up for those passing in the distance to either side, nor for any earlier 12:45.

All were flying generally south. Clearly directional flight. Occasionally some stopped at flowers for a few seconds, but no lingering. Never saw one fly into trees, but rather went over or around. In spite of prevailing crosswind to somewhat opposing wind, all traveled quickly. Wind pattern around trees and terrain apparently provided some useful local tail wind. All were flying individually, well spaced. Any groups of 2 or 3 were coincidental, and quickly separated as they continued. There was absolutely no suggestion of “flocking” or flying in formation. No reaction between individuals short of a random near collision.

Individual flight was a bit of everything. Some flapping, some gliding. Most were fairly low, but some at 50 feet or more. I even followed a couple with binoculars that appeared to be trying to ride small thermals upward, circling and rising.

All in all undramatic. No great activity or numbers all at once. No roosting, no gathering on food sources, just slow continuous flow, one at a time. We could easily not have noticed.
200+ today in Mills County, Tx

We're still seeing 40-50 Monarchs everyday nectaring on our Gregg's Blue Mist flower and A.Curassavica. Some migrating overhead. A few pairs mating. Several cats and three chrysallises that I know of.  Also seeing 20+ Queens, a few Painted Ladies, Buckeyes, Skippers, Giant Sulphers, Pipevine Swallowtails. And honeybees everywhere!  An extraordinary site!

El día sábado 18 de octubre de 2014 personal del PNCM comenzó con el monitoreo de la migración de la mariposa monarca, en la entrada al Cañón de la Huasteca, en el municipio de Santa Catarina, N.L.; siendo una de las entradas principales al Parque Nacional Cumbres de Monterrey, dicha actividad dio inicio a las 10:18 a.m. finalizando a las 15:18 p.m. teniendo un total de 5 horas de observación. Durante ese lapso de tiempo se pudieron contabilizar 300 mariposas lo que da como resultado de 1 monarca promedio por minuto. A continuación se presentan los bloques de horario y numero de monarcas volando:

El punto de observación se encontraba a la orilla de la carretera, a 100 metros del rio Santa Catarina, en las coordenadas geográficas latitud 25º33`56.93” Norte y longitud 100º27`4.71” Oeste (método por Google earth), el tipo de vegetación presente en el lugar es matorral submontano, el sitio presenta paredes escarpadas por la conformación del cañón. Las condiciones climatológicas que se presentaron fueron soleadas y con un poco de viento al inicio, aumentando de velocidad conforme el transcurso del día.Del total de mariposas avistadas, se pudo observar a dos mariposas que se encontraban alimentándose de un árbol con flores no identificado que se encontraba en el área de jardín de una casa habitación cercana al punto de observación.

Saw 100+ monarchs at Rick Evans' Grandview Prairie near Columbus, AR. We were able to tag 40 - saved some tags for some chrysalises we have in our science lab at school.  This is much better than last year when we saw very few monarchs and were only able to tag 4. We only ordered 50 tags this year, but could have used several more. Most of the butterflies were brightly colored but some had damaged wings (storms passed through our area several days before) and some had very thin abdomens. We took OE samples from them and sent them to University of Georgia Citizen Science program that uses volunteers to gather OE data.

This morning the roost was slow to wake up as it was a cloudy sunrise but as soon as the sun came out the monarchs were streaming down the dunes.  Our census for the morning run was 224 in 20 minutes.   While standing on the dunes we counted approximately 25 per minute going by for hours.  We also noticed that many were crossing the Delaware Bay.  Some tried and came back while others just went for it.  Maybe they know the rain and cold winds are arriving soon.  Our team will be out looking for roosts tonight but with the fairly warm weather, not sure we'll find any large size clusters.
flying over highway

One thousand monarchs were counted during a 3-hour drive of 165 miles from Reynosa to Cuidad Victoria. In Periquitos, there were hundreds of monarchs at a site full of Asclepias curassavica.

Ya estamos muy atentos a la llegada de las monarcas, hay grupos ya monitoreando en Valle Hermoso, Reynosa, Río Bravo, San Fernando, Matamoros, Ciudad Victoria, Jaumave y en el sur en Madero y Tampico.En Ciudad Victoria Tamaulipas, el lunes 13 de octubre se comenzó a ver gran movilidad de mariposas amarillas, mariposas reina y soldado, junto con libélulas, sin embargo en Reynosa, cerca del Río Bravo, y en “Periquitos”, se llegaron a observar alrededor de 1000 mariposas monarca en el trayecto de Reynosa a Ciudad Victoria a través del grupo de Operación Monarcas en Camino.

Sighting by the Red Tamaulipas forwarded by Rocio Trevino of Correo Real

There are close to a thousand monarchs at this location in a field of these flowers. I was watching for maybe 10 minutes.  The huge field was filled with the flower and monarchs were all over the field.

Dare and washington counties nc monarch movements

Mon oct 21 saw a couple hundred monarchs passing through eastern nc. Didn't have a lot of time to tag but...Around lake phelps they were flying sw. Around alligator river nwr and on roanoke island they flew west. From whalebone junction south they were all heading south along the banks as i have seen then in past at this time of year. I did see some crossing the sound too, but most heading west from roanoke island were concentrated on goldenrod along the manns harbor bridge and along 64bypass bridge, all heading west. I doubt its as neat and tidy as southbound coastal monarchs make a turn on 64 west to go to mexico, or stay south and head to florida or offshore (didnt see many over ocean). Or maybe just cross back to the mainland further south and head to mexico?? Or maybe I'm just looking at this from a human point of view because these are the routes I'm following. Surely its just a broad swath of movement, but nectar surely is a concentrator!I tagged 25 on mon and just 1 during a trip yesterday. Rain and wind but clearing up again later this week and i hope for some more movement. And hoping for some recoveries!!!!

Courtesy of Carolina Leps

At Lake Dardanelle State Park we saw 142 monarch butterflies.  We saw them near lots of trees and flying across the water. They were heading towards Mexico! They were flying a few at a time.
More than 20 adults spotted moving across I-40 while we were stopped in traffic west of Little Rock. Most were moving in a southerly direction.
I counted about 28-30 monarchs over a 20 minute period while running an errand.

Cindy from SEABA reported 22 monarchs in Monsota Canyon in the Santa Rita Mountains along the creek and picnic area as part of their butterfly count. This site was checked three times in the next two weeks with one singleton. (Reported to SW Monarch Study)
Tom reported 12 monarchs flying west over 3 days. (Reported to SW Monarch Study).
6 monarchs flying along the river and resting in willow trees, nectaring on seep willow and sunflowers.

Lisa organized a SW Monarch Study workshop in a rancher's yard. We found seven 5th instar monarch larvae still in Asclepias subverticillata patches and 6 pupae on a nearby fence. Tagged one fresh monarch in the field and spotted several others flying by. At the end, while still talking about the successful morning, a female monarch launched from a nearby tree like a bullet and together we watched her climb on a 45 degree angle high into the sky flying south. Then she paused and joined a hawk high in a thermal and out of sight - what an exciting moment for all of us watching her!

Donna and I spent from 1-3 PM today with Matt C's Biology Class at Ft. Moultrie NM, Sullivans Is, SC. It was clear with temps of 63 f and 10 mph NNW winds. We had the following most in the front of the fort along the water.:Monarch 100+ along the shore they were passing at the rate of 15/min

Moving through Fort Hood Texas. Moving tree to tree, live oaks,

I visited our Certified Monarch Station#7485 Monarch Butterfly Labyrinth garden at Bluebonnet Montessori school of Lakeway 4 times today and observed 20 - 30 adult Monarch butterflies each time. I was lucky to take a video of 2 mating Monarchs. Soon we will start looking for eggs! We are so excited. We have observed about 100 + monarchs feasting on the nectar EVERY DAY day for the last 10 days! And there are probably many more stopping by to drink nectar from their favourite Greg's BLue Mist blossoms nectar!!! We are just not 100 % of the day time in the labyrinth to watch and record precisely! They are migrating butterflies as their wings have so many marks and holes and bents and scratches from their long journey!!! It is so amazingly fascinating!!!!

The Oak Leaf Trail was swarming with Monarchs this weekend (Oct. 11 & 12). I have never seen so many together at one time!  I was at the bottom of the walkway near Brady and Prospect. The little purple flowers next to the trail were covered with them. People were stopping to watch them. I also so quite few where the trail begins near Prospect and Lincoln Memorial Drive.I went back on Monday about noon (weather was cool and overcast) and took some photos of the monarchs still in the same location, at the base of the bluff along the Lake Michigan shoreline. The monarchs were feeding at a patch of New England asters and boneset. I estimate seeing about 50 combined at the two patches on the weekend days. (We have not had a hard frost near the lake yet.)Contributed for Diane H. by Susan BorkinHead of Natural Sciences & Curator, Invertebrate ZoologyMilwaukee Public Museum
Saw Monarchs flying and feeding in several locations around town. There was a stiff NW breeze. Some were congregating in bushes out of the wind like in the photo here.

Todays trip to pelican island near oregon inlet nc, was wrought with strong winds and 58 degree temps. But the sun and abundance of seaside goldenrod on the leeward aide of the island provided big numbers of monarchs, easy catches too, we ended up tagging 42 exhausting the supply of tags i rationed for the day! Several participants on this wings over water birding festival trip were able to catch one or more monarchs. I don't facebook but they did post some pics and always we get a lot of good pr on this trip, even tagging a few back at the docks as several commercial fisherman watched in awe!Back on the mainland i tagged a quick 5 at jockeys ridge state park. most flying west here. a little yellow and a dusywing here along with more common ones. Next year ill have to buy more tags, could have easily tripled my numbers, actually a three or four hundred a day would be possible as long as its sunny and clear!!!!Another trip tomorrow and one sat morning, with only 50 tags left we can only do that much damage!!

Durante toda la semana del 20 al 24 de octubre he estado observando el paso de las Monarcas en dirección Sur, Sur-Oste en poca cantidad de 20 a 30 /minuto, por el área de la Presa la Amistad y Cd. Acuña, Coahuila, los días han estado nublados y los vientos del norte de 10 a 15 km /hr. El vuelo ha sido muy bajo. El día de hoy 24 de octubre aumentó el grueso de las monarcas, tal vez en cientos por minuto, volando casi al nivel del embalse de la presa la Amistad y cruzando la frontera del río Bravo hacia México. El tamaño es bastante grande en comparación a las primeras que pasaron, hago notar que vienen acompañadas por otra mariposa color oscuro, cosa que en años anteriores no había observado.

I experience three large migration sightings this season: Oct 25. 1 monarch every 2 minutes flying south. Oct. 9th:1-2 every minuteSept. 22.  1-2 every minute.I released 125 Monarchs and gave 75+ to NJ teachers.
Most were observed flying around vegetation. A few actually landed on the beach.

Over a four day period between October 21st and October 24th, I have seen hundreds of monarchs on move! This was on Bogue Banks, not on the mainland. It thrills my heart that they are still on the move, feeding on golden rod and a small yellow flower that looks similar to some sort of aster.

Along RT 30A there were masses of adult Monarchs nectaring from Groudsel(Baccharis halimifolia). There were often 50 or more on some bushes. I was by myself so it was impossible to count them all. I stopped counting at 600 hundred but there were many more. Bright Sunshine,78 degrees. Winds from the North West, which were variable and a bit gusty at times. There were many free-flying adults as well and many were stopping to nectar also at Bidens alba.I spent 12:30 to 2:45 along Rt 30A at Western Lake which connects to the Gulf of Mexico.

WOW.I have lived in the Panhandle of FL for almost 30 years and have never seen it like this.

Along State Road 20 in Choctaw Beach, North shore of the Choctawhatchee Bay. Monarchs were nectaring on Bidens alba and Groundsel Trees along the shoreline/roadside. Sunshine,76 degrees, winds from the Northwest variable.

October 20th was the busiest day of the season with so many monarchs stopping to visit. Nine at one time in the garden was wonderful to see. Continue to see individuals stopping by as they progress further south.

Traveling on the 331 Bridge over Choctawhatchee Bay between Freeport and Santa Rosa Beach, I observed 10 Monarchs flying South over the Bay. There were 19 nectaring in a clusters on the South end of the bridge on Groundsel(Baccharis hamilifolia).It was @ 12:15 in full sunshine, 75 degrees, gusty variable winds.

Went to the park at the beach at Pine Knoll Shores,N.C. Sat at picnic table on beachfront deck about mile marker 6 - 7. Saw 16 monarchs in just as many minutes!!!  16 = 16. One after another. Today is Sunday, Oct. 26,2014. Absolute delight to share with my husband there.

Cientos de Mariposas monarca alimentandose en los girasoles en el ejido Avila y Urbina en Jaumave Tamaulipas en la colindancia con el estado de Nuevo Leon en la Sierra Madre Oriental. No se han visto con la misma abundancia hacia el sur del municipio en La Florida, Santiaguillo o Monte Redondo. Se espera una aribazon fuerte en los próximos dias.
Two empty lots covered in fall asters and a few golden rod. We counted 150 adults nectaring. It was a very warm, sunny day.

It is difficult to pinpoint peak migration out here on the eastern edge of the main migration route.  Monarchs have been sighted singly and sporadically over the past week.  Six were tagged on the 19th while nectaring at our pocket prairie, however this coincided with a "surge" in our local (nonmigratory?) population.  It has been an exceptional season, we've raised and tagged over 20 since mid-September with another generation on the way.  We're hoping some of our raised butterflied join the migration.

Saturday and Sunday October 25 and 26 at Brunswick county beaches. Saturdaywinds light from the west, NW at 5 to 8 knots, sunny and mild, Sunday windsfrom the south steady at 10 knots sunny and mild. Count for both days.

Monarchs 100+

All were feeding on Golden Rod.I physically caught 100+ Monarchs and inspected for tags but found none. Ifound perhaps 15 Monarchs that were broken the other were in good shape andsome looked freshly hatched. I wish I had gotten some tags from someone as Ihave never tagged any Monarch. There were at least 100 that sailed thru thegolden rod and never landed I did not see any tags on those either but some Icould not get close enough to to see. I honestly did not expect to find so manyas it has been more than 20 years since I have tried to find any but luck waswith me.

Courtesy of Carolina Leps
Nectaring on Cowpen Daisy and Mealy Blue Sage at MO Ranch in Hint TX

Adult Monarchs were hugging the sand dunes along the coast of Salter Path/Indian Beach heading South.  I counted 35 in under an hour and they were steadily coming all weekend.  It was windy and they were headed into it. I did not see one in Goldsboro this year so it was an amazing sight as they lighted on the golden rod and blanket flowers.

Man-made park that forms an "L that juts south out into Lake Ontario and is about 5 kilometers long. Built from construction rubble and now primarily construction soil. Has it's own Friends organization and has been designated as an Important Bird Area. Lots of milkweed and in the fall, huge amounts of golden rod. FYI - From Anne Gray, member, Toronto Entomologists' Association:I have just checked my Monarch numbers for Leslie Street Spit on my monitoring days so far in October. They are: 1) on 2 October 2014, in 2 hours in the am - 14 Monarchs 2) on 10 October , in 5 hours of monitoring on this sunny day - 349 Monarchs. 3) on 16 October, in 6.5 hours of monitoring. There was drizzle and heavy fog until 12:20pm followed by sunshine and a SW breeze. - 42 Monarchs included 1 pair mating in flight. 4) on 23 October, in 5 hours of sunshine - 27 Monarchs. We monitor the Spit once a week and have for the past 16 years - all our reports go to the TRCA (Toronto Region Conservation Authority) database, and I attend the TTPUG (Tommy Thompson Park User Group) meetings on behalf of TEA and as a Volunteer Naturalist.

Forwarded by Don Davis
63 adults on Groundsel Trees outside the gates of Henderson Beach State Park in Destin FL. Sunny 78 degrees. South West wind at @10 mph

At Dune Allen Beach over 250 adults nectaring on Groundsel trees (Baccharis hamilifolia), and at Golden Rod(Solidago sp.) and and Bidens alba. Winds from the South West at @ 8 mph, Sunny and 78 degrees. I did notice and photograph a male and female incopula.

For the last week or so, there have been 100+ monarchs feeding on tiny white flowers in my yard and then bedding down in a group of large trees. Today, I stopped counting at 200 feeding on the flowers and I still have one unhatched chrysalis. This is the most I have ever seen migrating through our area. So hopeful for increased numbers for the Spring.
There was quite a few monarchs feeding in gardens this past weekend (10/25-26) and today (10/27).  We tagged approximately 100 + butterflies today and we didn't get them all!
Dee Wright was in Eastland, Tx and spotted many monarchs on broomweeds.

Great news!!! One of our monarch butterflies that was tagged here in Cape May Point, NJ on Oct. 7th at 3 pm was caught, recorded and released on Oct. 24th in St. Mark NWR, Florida. Safe travels to Mexico, monarch!

We drove south to the tip of the Delmarva Peninsula and observed about 6 migrating monarchs per  hour as we drove. We went to Kiptopeke State Park and observed at least that many as we walked the trails. We saw the most monarchs on the beach along the mouth of the Chesapeake Bay, where they were nectaring on goldenrod before they made the trip across the water

As expcected Fri 10/24 and Sat 10/25 under warm sunny skies we tagged about 25 each day exhausting my supply of tags each day. The daily total of monarchs each day was about 300. On 10/24 we had two recoveries of monarchs tagged on 10/23. On 10/25 we had one recovery of a monarch tagged on 10/24. As I noted before there were many skinny abdomens so a lot of nectaring going on! By Saturday abdomens were looking bigger.So tagged a total of 92 at the coast last week (10/13-18), most I've tagged out there because of the earlier timing of the birding festival this year. If it's early again next year I'll make more of an effort to tag more and hopefully get a few recoveries from points north.From week of Oct 20-25, Dare county, nc: 1000 monarchs. Hope SC gets a few of these...

Courtesy of Carolina Leps
Another big day of monarchs feeding & roosting.  Cold front coming in tonight - will be interesting to see how the numbers change tomorrow.
About a three mile wide area. All adults heading south at about 20 feet elevation. Many more seen on the horizon.

Today was another good tagging day. The team managed to do another 100.  The monarchs were in every garden there was feasting on nectar.  So happy that the residents here plant flowers that bloom this late, since the native goldenrod is past bloom now.  Happy trails monarchs!

I received the e-mails below from one of the volunteers who helps me plant seaside goldenrod each year at CNWR. Apparently, for several days, the wind has prevented monarchs from leaving the island. They won't make the water crossing on strong W or NW winds. The attached photo shows monarchs nectaring on Oct 21 around 4pm on one of the seaside goldenrod plants that my volunteer group planted about 15 years ago along Tom's Cove. In her message below, she mentions the hook. She is referring to the "elbow" in the southern-most tip of the island at Tom's Hook.I checked the 10-day forecast for the island, and it seems there won't be a NE wind until Thursday and Friday, Oct 30 & 31. At least the monarchs have plenty of seaside goldenrod to nectar on to build up fat reserves while they wait out the wind.

Tuesday, the 21st was the day to be on the beach at the Refuge. I am attaching a photo to show you what I mean. It was glorious! Friday, the 24th: In the afternoon I checked the hook again. There was still asizable number of Monarchs out there-- even after all the rain and highwinds we have had. The wind was bad again today and they were lying low.Hope Mother Nature gives them a break so they can make a run for it thisweekend!

October 29
On the day the photo was taken, monarchs were clustered as in the photo in the stands of taller goldenrods. If memory serves, the wind was NW but the wind speed was very low and the afternoon was warm into the mid to upper 70's. There were good numbers of monarchs in the air just drifting about, not hurried, seeming to be enjoying the day and the availability of good nectar. So, with all that in mind, I would estimate that I saw about 600--700 Monarchs. I was there for about 2 hours and walked from the beginning of the OSV zone (parking lot 5) halfway to the old Coast Guard station on Tom's Hook.

A weak cool front moved in overnight. Gentle winds are now from the north. The monarchs are drifting lazily south. All are about 75 - 100 feet high in the air. Some are even drifting backwards (i.e.: their tails are facing south) None are descending to feed at my butterfly garden.

Courtesy of Correo Real
At 1:15 PM, observed dozens of monarchs flying North to South at altitudes above 75 feet. Flying very determinedly, not drifting aimlessly. None are descending to nectar at flowers.
Sunny, 80-82 degrees, very very light breeze from the north. In a 2 hour span in my backyard (2-4pm) I counted 86 on their way south, many of them way high in the air just cruising along.
Mrs. Latkowski's very excited 2nd grade class observed 53 monarchs in 15 minutes, flying due south.

We have had a few days of cloudy weather with cooler temps and the numbers of Monarchs visiting our Waystation #7485 Labyrinth garden have been down to 1-5. I have seen a few early in the morning under the Live Oaks canopy and found the first dead Monarch on the ground, at least he had a delicious last supper in our garden sanctuary. I went to check this afternoon around 2:30 pm when the sun finally emerged from under the long lasting gray clouds and my heart was overflowing with joy: there were SO MANY MONARCHS - swarming and drinking nectar from the Greg's Blue Mist blossoms - their absolute favorite!!!! It was BREATHTAKINGLY BEAUTIFUL!!! Just like on October 14th! I can only assumed that they were roosting in the Live Oak grove as there were 1-5 occasionally in the last 5 days and only 1 this morning and at lunch time!!! I suppose Monarchs LOVE the SUNshine or perhaps the flower nectar is more delicious and more fragrant when the the sun is shining bright! It was a PARTY of dancing happy Monarch 50-100 all afternoon!!!! We hope more will find us tomorrow - the sun is here to stay till Monday, November 3rd!!!

I am seeing several hundred monarchs as I drive thru our ranch in the afternoons. More today than yesterday. They seem to love the salvia. We are blessed to have had a little rain, so tanks are full also. We are located about 15 miles east of the Devils River State park. Beautiful to see so many. Last year here, very few. Not seeing them in waves as a about 5 years ago, but still many many more than last year.  Will try to post a few pics tomorrow evening.

Taking the point of the Schleicher County Courthouse (in Eldorado, TX) where the film crew had just spent the morning taking movies of large clusters and MANY monarchs, and the predicted flight path, given the wind direction and speed and their optimum 17° tacking into said winds, we headed south of Sonora to FM 189. Less than 3 miles down that road, which runs SW, we saw 100s of monarchs exactly where I'd predicted! Editor's Note: The distance from El Dorado to the location of the sighting is about 40 miles.

At about 5:30 PM we started noticing hundreds of Monarchs flying over our house in the far north part of San Antonio.  Hundreds and hundred kept coming, and by around 7:30 it looks like many were looking for a place to rest for the night.  We have many trees on our property.   This morning at around 8AM, we saw many still resting on some oaks.

Hoy por la mañana Félix y yo vimos cerca de 68 monarcas volando sobre los jardines de nuestras oficinas aproximadamente a unos 6 o 7 metros sobre el suelo, en 10 minutos de observación. Por otra parte vimos también cerca de 4 hembras ovopositando en nuestros algodoncillos y hemos contado más de 15 huevecillos, ¡más los que no hemos visto aún! En estos momentos hay 6 mariposas revoloteando por nuestro jardín, no se están quietas por lo que es difícil saber si son hembras o machos, pero seguiremos reportando.

Many high flying monarchs this morning about 2 per minute for periods of 20 minutes or so.  Then periods of none.  Gliding on northeasterly winds.
75 - 100 roosted in my yard overnight, but early in the morning, saw hundreds fly over, Checked with 4-5 friends in SA. They saw them also.

Film director, Kay Milam, texted me to say she'd just arrived at Seminole State Park and monarchs were flowing in there, too! (In addition to my sighting at Del Rio). Kay says she saw one rivulet of monarchs so large that she thought is was a murmuration of birds!

Editor's note: Number of monarchs has been estimated by JN. We will update when we hear from observer for an actual estimate.
